6. Re: my 4x4x4 solution. purely intuitive or is it?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 01 Jan 2005 23:43:49 -0000

Gosh, I was so blind it's a pain in the brain... Much better (cause pure): (R U R' U') (l' U R U') (l r') Similar situation, very fast: (Rr) U R' U' (Rr)' R U R U' R' I've recently seen someone solve the 4x4 by solving centers first, then pairing up edges and solving as 3x3 on the same time. But he had a hard time pairing the LL edges without breaking the "F2L"... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I don't see how your algorithm solves the last three pieces. It does > pair up the edges, but it even seems to destroy most of the F2L. I'd > suggest this instead: > (Rr) U R' U' (Rr)' > That's very fast and pairs up all those edges. And if you follow it > with this, the F2L is restored again: > F R F'
7. help reassembling 2x2x2 correctly
From: egregiousguy <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 02 Jan 2005 06:38:39 -0000


aside from the cubies, there are 12 slider things, 3 of which are
different and of those 3, 2 are the same. I read somewhere that those
3 pieces go in one cubie and then fill in the rest. But the problem i
have is that when i reassemble it and start playing with it, it gets
stuck and won't rotate unless forced. My guess is that one of those 2
different pieces is rotated and hits a corner that has that bump
stopping it from rotating. If anyone can help me with this on where
exactly those special pieces go i'd really appreciate it. Pictures,
links, any info will help... oh btw it's the 2x2x2 that i got from the
rubik's site. Thanks in advance.





8. Re: [Speed cubing group] help reassembling 2x2x2 correctly
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 00:37:52 -0800

This question gets asked so many times. I'll be honest; I don't know
how to put one together myself. Someone should make a webpage
detailing the instructions on how to do this and the next time someone
asks, all we have to do is feed them the link.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

9. beginner of 4*4*4 cube
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 09:00:14 +0000 (GMT)

Hi members,
wish you all a happy new year!
I can solve a 3*3*3 cube blindfolded. But, I do not know anything about 2*2*2 and 4*4*4. At last, I have a 4*4*4 cube in my hand after a year running after it.
Where can I get the notations and methods to solve it ?
John Louis
Grand Master of Memory

Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partneronline.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

12. Re: [Speed cubing group] help reassembling 2x2x2 correctly
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 02 Jan 2005 15:05:19 -0000

Sounds like me. I have two broken cubes which I salvaged into one by using only the similar inner pieces. Anyway, this question just came up yesterday among some of my cubing friends concerning their broken Bart Simpson 2x2x2 cube. I don't know how many of you have ever tried to assemble one, but all of the pieces are larger and each piece is the same. Theoretically, this should make it easier to assemble, since that's what I did to salvage one cube from my two. But I found it difficult to put together because of the size of the outer pieces, which restricted the movements of my fingers to snap the last piece in place. Has anyone tried this before and have any hints? How about contacting Seventowns/whoever makes the cubes? They have to be assembled somehow without breaking. Oh, and has anyone else noticed on the 2x2x2 that sometimes the side of an outer piece can come off? I think this might be the trick to assemble it, although I have yet to try it. -Thomas Bischof --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > I need this info myself. My 2x2 has been in pieces for a month now, > and I can't work out how to put the damn thing together. Frankly, I > really don't like it much, but it's fun to show others, so having it > in one piece might be a good idea. > > I'll write an article about it once someone teaches me - unless that > is another article. :P > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > This question gets asked so many times. I'll be honest; I don't know > > how to put one together myself. Someone should make a webpage > > detailing the instructions on how to do this and the next time someone > > asks, all we have to do is feed them the link. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Jan 1, 2005, at 10:38 PM, egregiousguy wrote: > > > > > aside from the cubies, there are 12 slider things, 3 of which are > > > different and of those 3, 2 are the same. I read somewhere that those > > > 3 pieces go in one cubie and then fill in the rest. But the problem i > > > have is that when i reassemble it and start playing with it, it gets > > > stuck and won't rotate unless forced. My guess is that one of those 2 > > > different pieces is rotated and hits a corner that has that bump > > > stopping it from rotating. If anyone can help me with this on where > > > exactly those special pieces go i'd really appreciate it. Pictures, > > > links, any info will help... oh btw it's the 2x2x2 that i got from the > > > rubik's site. Thanks in advance.

14. Re: [Speed cubing group] help reassembling 2x2x2 correctly
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 10:42:47 -0800

Ok, 2x2x2 assembly isntructions a series of pictures is in the photos section somewhere. If these instructions aren't clear i would recomend finding those pictures and having a look. So three of the sleeves are different, they are bigger. Choose your favorite cubie and put these three sleeves on that corner. You will notice that one of these three is slightly smaller, it goes on the side that has a bump inside. (hope i'm making sense) Now look at the axles, you will notice that three of them are fixed, and cannot move. These three go where the three big sleeves are on your favorite cubie. Now add three more cubies with sleeves to complete the bottome layer. Keep adding cubies and sleeves until you only have one cubie left. Now for the hard part. Put the cubie over two sleeves, the third one is difficult. Turn the layer that you are putting the cubie on 45 degrees, just as when putting in the last edge peice on a 3x3x3. Now you have to push the peice rather hard, but also try to pull it up over the sleeve, kind of coax it into place. I hope that helps. Good luck, Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Sun, 02 Jan 2005 15:05:19 -0000, tsbischof <tom@...> wrote: > > Sounds like me. I have two broken cubes which I salvaged into one by > using only the similar inner pieces. > > Anyway, this question just came up yesterday among some of my cubing > friends concerning their broken Bart Simpson 2x2x2 cube. I don't > know how many of you have ever tried to assemble one, but all of the > pieces are larger and each piece is the same. Theoretically, this > should make it easier to assemble, since that's what I did to > salvage one cube from my two. But I found it difficult to put > together because of the size of the outer pieces, which restricted > the movements of my fingers to snap the last piece in place. Has > anyone tried this before and have any hints? > > How about contacting Seventowns/whoever makes the cubes? They have > to be assembled somehow without breaking. > > Oh, and has anyone else noticed on the 2x2x2 that sometimes the side > of an outer piece can come off? I think this might be the trick to > assemble it, although I have yet to try it. > > -Thomas Bischof > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > I need this info myself. My 2x2 has been in pieces for a month now, > > and I can't work out how to put the damn thing together. Frankly, I > > really don't like it much, but it's fun to show others, so having > it > > in one piece might be a good idea. > > > > I'll write an article about it once someone teaches me - unless > that > > is another article. :P > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > This question gets asked so many times. I'll be honest; I don't > know > > > how to put one together myself. Someone should make a webpage > > > detailing the instructions on how to do this and the next time > someone > > > asks, all we have to do is feed them the link. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Jan 1, 2005, at 10:38 PM, egregiousguy wrote: > > > > > > > aside from the cubies, there are 12 slider things, 3 of which > are > > > > different and of those 3, 2 are the same. I read somewhere > that those > > > > 3 pieces go in one cubie and then fill in the rest. But the > problem i > > > > have is that when i reassemble it and start playing with it, > it gets > > > > stuck and won't rotate unless forced. My guess is that one of > those 2 > > > > different pieces is rotated and hits a corner that has that > bump > > > > stopping it from rotating. If anyone can help me with this on > where > > > > exactly those special pieces go i'd really appreciate it. > Pictures, > > > > links, any info will help... oh btw it's the 2x2x2 that i got > from the > > > > rubik's site. Thanks in advance. > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > ADVERTISEMENT > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! 15. cube quality
From: "johnbender91" <johnbender91@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 02 Jan 2005 20:59:41 -0000


Hi,

my little brother and I got Rubik's cubes on xmas and I was able to
solve it with a method I found online and my brother got so mad he
smashed my cube against the wall and lots of pieces jumped out. Of
course I took revenge and smashed his cube against the wall, too, but
nothing happened, I needed a baseball bat to kill it. My cube is old
(from my parents) and my brother got a new one, so now I'm wondering
about the different cube quality. For this purpose, I ask all of you
to smash a cube against a wall and tell me what happened and the type
of cube. I will collect the data and publish the results soon.

Thank you,
John

From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>

My cube contains something known as corbomite, which upon impact transfers all energy back to wall leaving the cube unharmed and the wall decimated. 19. Tournament Reminder
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 02:02:32 -0000


Just letting everyone know again that there will be a Tournament in
Schaumburg Illinois on Saturday, January 29th. Scheduled events are
3x3, 4x4, and 5x5 speedsolve. Anyone can come and compete.
Regestration forms and info can be found on my site
www.geocities.com/cubecrazy2/cubemain
You can email me with questions at cubecrazy2@...
and this tournament will follow WCA regulations and will be
official. Regestration forms are due on January 8th.
Again feel free to email me anytime

jake





20. Re: cube quality
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 17:04:35 -0000

Hi John, For Christmas I got a special DIY kit in a bag. Not only did it have adjustable screws, it had plastic tiles instead of stickers. When I threw it against the wall it assembled itself. The insert said that Nanobots (TM) use the energy of an impact to assemble the cube. Pretty neat! And sometimes when I yell at it loudly enough it solves itself. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "johnbender91" <johnbender91@y...> wrote: > > Hi, > > my little brother and I got Rubik's cubes on xmas and I was able to > solve it with a method I found online and my brother got so mad he > smashed my cube against the wall and lots of pieces jumped out. Of > course I took revenge and smashed his cube against the wall, too, but > nothing happened, I needed a baseball bat to kill it. My cube is old > (from my parents) and my brother got a new one, so now I'm wondering > about the different cube quality. For this purpose, I ask all of you > to smash a cube against a wall and tell me what happened and the type > of cube. I will collect the data and publish the results soon. > > Thank you, > John
21. speedcubing.com
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 10:13:03 -0800 (PST)


Hey dudes/guys/gals...,
This is just a suggestion, and I'm not accusing anyone or anything, but this is just for the good of the Professional Cubing community of the world.
I was considering if speedcubing.com received a record from an unknown person, then a slight 'something' of proof should be necessary. (Unknown person would be someone that has not participated in any tournaments, and just "came out of nowhere", per se, or someone unfamiliar with the cubing community). I just think keeping this as professional as possible will benefit everyone, since this is a sport of mastery and for some of us it isn't a mere game. A 'something' of proof could be a simple video or something, I'm not sure. But if "Joe Rookie" (a guy that has never been associated with and/or is unknown to the cubing community) said he did a 15 second average, that's intense information, and just posting the record on speedcubing.com out of blind faith is, in my opinion atleast, not enough.
Alot of the people are known on the speedcubing.com lists, and this post may not apply to most of us.
However, asking for a "something" of proof, will require more time and effort on the posting committee, which could be a problem, but solutions can be made about that.
Besides, the International Solitaire Ranking site requires a screenshot of the record you have made every time you post a record.
This is just a suggestion, any thoughts/plans?
Thanks, peace out :P.
-Brent



:)
--Brent

---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Mail - Find what you need with new enhanced search. Learn more.

22. Re: cube quality
From: "John Bender" <johnbender91@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 19:31:07 -0000

I get the feeling you guys don't take this study very serious... Anyway... my little brother got a new cube and also learned how to solve it (our parents made me show him the online solution). Today I took his solved cube and wrote this on it: !!I DIO T!! TUR NTH ECE NTE RSR IGH TYO UPA THE TIC LOS ER! !!M ORO N!! But I wrote the middle I of "IDIOT" rotated 90 degrees. Then I mixed the cube and gave it to my brother. He "solved" it and now he's been trying to get the centers right for several hours. He's getting more and more angry and frustrated. A lot of fun to watch. John --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi John, > > For Christmas I got a special DIY kit in a bag. Not only did it > have adjustable screws, it had plastic tiles instead of stickers. When > I threw it against the wall it assembled itself. The insert said that > Nanobots (TM) use the energy of an impact to assemble the cube. Pretty > neat! And sometimes when I yell at it loudly enough it solves itself. > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "johnbender91" > <johnbender91@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi, > > > > my little brother and I got Rubik's cubes on xmas and I was able to > > solve it with a method I found online and my brother got so mad he > > smashed my cube against the wall and lots of pieces jumped out. Of > > course I took revenge and smashed his cube against the wall, too, but > > nothing happened, I needed a baseball bat to kill it. My cube is old > > (from my parents) and my brother got a new one, so now I'm wondering > > about the different cube quality. For this purpose, I ask all of you > > to smash a cube against a wall and tell me what happened and the type > > of cube. I will collect the data and publish the results soon. > > > > Thank you, > > John

27. Re: [Speed cubing group] help reassembling 2x2x2 correctly
From: egregiousguy <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 22:14:01 -0000

Ahh... so that's what i've been doing wrong, the fixed ends point towards those different slider pieces. I never had a problem reassembling the cube to begin with but i wasn't sure of those 3 different slider pieces and the direction of the middle piece and i know that was why it locked up. Well i reassembled the cube again and so far it hasn't locked up so i'm happy and thanks Evan. Perhaps i'll make instruction guide in flash and post the link somewhere if pictures and text don't seem to help anyone. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > Ok, 2x2x2 assembly isntructions > a series of pictures is in the photos section somewhere. If these > instructions aren't clear i would recomend finding those pictures and > having a look. > > So three of the sleeves are different, they are bigger. Choose your > favorite cubie and put these three sleeves on that corner. You will > notice that one of these three is slightly smaller, it goes on the > side that has a bump inside. (hope i'm making sense) > > Now look at the axles, you will notice that three of them are fixed, > and cannot move. These three go where the three big sleeves are on > your favorite cubie. Now add three more cubies with sleeves to > complete the bottome layer. Keep adding cubies and sleeves until you > only have one cubie left. > > Now for the hard part. Put the cubie over two sleeves, the third one > is difficult. Turn the layer that you are putting the cubie on 45 > degrees, just as when putting in the last edge peice on a 3x3x3. Now > you have to push the peice rather hard, but also try to pull it up > over the sleeve, kind of coax it into place. > > I hope that helps. > > Good luck, > Evan > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk > > > On Sun, 02 Jan 2005 15:05:19 -0000, tsbischof <tom@w...> wrote: > > > > Sounds like me. I have two broken cubes which I salvaged into one by > > using only the similar inner pieces. > > > > Anyway, this question just came up yesterday among some of my cubing > > friends concerning their broken Bart Simpson 2x2x2 cube. I don't > > know how many of you have ever tried to assemble one, but all of the > > pieces are larger and each piece is the same. Theoretically, this > > should make it easier to assemble, since that's what I did to > > salvage one cube from my two. But I found it difficult to put > > together because of the size of the outer pieces, which restricted > > the movements of my fingers to snap the last piece in place. Has > > anyone tried this before and have any hints? > > > > How about contacting Seventowns/whoever makes the cubes? They have > > to be assembled somehow without breaking. > > > > Oh, and has anyone else noticed on the 2x2x2 that sometimes the side > > of an outer piece can come off? I think this might be the trick to > > assemble it, although I have yet to try it. > > > > -Thomas Bischof > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > > > > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > > > I need this info myself. My 2x2 has been in pieces for a month now, > > > and I can't work out how to put the damn thing together. Frankly, I > > > really don't like it much, but it's fun to show others, so having > > it > > > in one piece might be a good idea. > > > > > > I'll write an article about it once someone teaches me - unless > > that > > > is another article. :P > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > > <tmao@i...> > > > wrote: > > > > This question gets asked so many times. I'll be honest; I don't > > know > > > > how to put one together myself. Someone should make a webpage > > > > detailing the instructions on how to do this and the next time > > someone > > > > asks, all we have to do is feed them the link. > > > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > > MSC #631 > > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > On Jan 1, 2005, at 10:38 PM, egregiousguy wrote: > > > > > > > > > aside from the cubies, there are 12 slider things, 3 of which > > are > > > > > different and of those 3, 2 are the same. I read somewhere > > that those > > > > > 3 pieces go in one cubie and then fill in the rest. But the > > problem i > > > > > have is that when i reassemble it and start playing with it, > > it gets > > > > > stuck and won't rotate unless forced. My guess is that one of > > those 2 > > > > > different pieces is rotated and hits a corner that has that > > bump > > > > > stopping it from rotating. If anyone can help me with this on > > where > > > > > exactly those special pieces go i'd really appreciate it. > > Pictures, > > > > > links, any info will help... oh btw it's the 2x2x2 that i got > > from the > > > > > rubik's site. Thanks in advance. > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > > ADVERTISEMENT > > > > ________________________________ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > Your use of Yahoo! 28. My Introduction
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 19:13:16 -0400

Hey everyone,

I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only lately have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a speedcuber yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich Method (It seems to be the method of champions).
I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently started learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. I seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method.
My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method?

My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the Fridrich Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks Dwayne

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



29. Re: My Introduction
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 23:37:28 -0000


Practice your F2L. If you can consistantly solve the F2L under 20
seconds, then solving under 30 seconds will be a piece of cake (even
when you have not learned all the OLL algs.)

-Chris





30. Re: [Speed cubing group] My Introduction
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 15:51:13 -0800 (PST)

well dude, first off, cool! :P your becoming a speedcuber. next stop yeah, it will take you about 4 to 6 weeks to fully implement and do f2l fast and also learn all pll and at least about 7 or 9 out of the total of 57 oll (the ones that have edge already oriented) it takes time, but if you put in extreme dedication, you can go from 1min to about 30sec in jsut 4 to 6 weeks, i know, i did it :P even failed one of my college classes cos i spent more time cubing that studying lol. have fun. --- Dwayne <ddollard@...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, > but only lately have I taken it more studiously. I > don't consider myself a speedcuber yet. Although > I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich > Method (It seems to be the method of champions). > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have > recently started learning PLL algs. I used to > average about 1:00 with my old method. I seem to be > slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s > with a hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > My question is how long should it normally take to > memorize the Fridrich Method algs, and fully > implement the Fridrich Method? > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to > about 30s and maybe better. I know, I need to learn > finger trick after the Fridrich Method. Any other > advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > appreciated. > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been > removed] > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? 31. 4x4x4
From: "Jim" <psyrules444@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 00:22:30 -0000


Ok i bought a 4x4x4 from Rubiks.com. I think it's fine. Just needs a little
greasing. I tried solving it and i managed to finish matching all the edges. So
when i start solving it like a 3x3x3, something is wrong when i get to OLL and
PLL. I use the OLL algorithms which should have fixed up the LL but there is
one corner twisted the wrong way. I notice that it is always twised the wrong
direction in the OLL stage. So i looked the solution up online and ended up
going to Chris Hardwick's page which had the solution and some very useful
algorithms. The thing is, there is no algorithm to fix a messed up corner. He
has one that fixes two corners when they are switched but the LL has to be
finished for that. I cannot even finish the LL!

Is it something wrong with my cube? Should i take that corner out and flip it
and then try to solve it? Plz HELP!

-Jim





32. Re: My Introduction
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 00:35:54 -0000

Welcome Dwayne, It's always nice to see new cube adepts. But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's method, and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same fingertricks. I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with significantly different systems. Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) Gilles http://grrroux.free.fr --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only lately have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a speedcuber yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich Method (It seems to be the method of champions). > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently started learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. I seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the Fridrich Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly appreciated. > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
33. 4x4x4
From: "Jim" <psyrules444@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 00:40:27 -0000


Ok i bought a 4x4x4 from Rubiks.com. I think it's fine. Just needs a little
greasing. I tried solving it and i managed to finish matching all the edges. So
when i start solving it like a 3x3x3, something is wrong when i get to OLL and
PLL. I use the OLL algorithms which should have fixed up the LL but there is
one corner twisted the wrong way. I notice that it is always twised the wrong
direction in the OLL stage. So i looked the solution up online and ended up
going to Chris Hardwick's page which had the solution and some very useful
algorithms. The thing is, there is no algorithm to fix a messed up corner. He
has one that fixes two corners when they are switched but the LL has to be
finished for that. I cannot even finish the LL!

Is it something wrong with my cube? Should i take that corner out and flip it
and then try to solve it? Plz HELP!

-Jim





34. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 16:54:37 -0800

If a single corner is twisted, then you have to take it out and put it in the right way. It is impossible to have a single corner twisted. Evan On Tue, 04 Jan 2005 00:40:27 -0000, Jim <psyrules444@...> wrote: > > Ok i bought a 4x4x4 from Rubiks.com. I think it's fine. Just needs a little > greasing. I tried solving it and i managed to finish matching all the edges. > So > when i start solving it like a 3x3x3, something is wrong when i get to OLL > and > PLL. I use the OLL algorithms which should have fixed up the LL but there is > one corner twisted the wrong way. I notice that it is always twised the > wrong > direction in the OLL stage. So i looked the solution up online and ended up > going to Chris Hardwick's page which had the solution and some very useful > algorithms. The thing is, there is no algorithm to fix a messed up corner. > He > has one that fixes two corners when they are switched but the LL has to be > finished for that. I cannot even finish the LL! > > Is it something wrong with my cube? Should i take that corner out and flip > it > and then try to solve it? Plz HELP! > > -Jim > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
35. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcubing.com
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 18:01:24 -0800

Maybe if we keep in mind that speedcubing.com is unofficial and based
by just personal records. The real list is the official rankings list
which I mean, only measures times achieved in an official competition
setting.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 3, 2005, at 10:13 AM, Brent Morgan wrote:

> Hey dudes/guys/gals...,
> This is just a suggestion, and I'm not accusing anyone or anything,
> but this is just for the good of the Professional Cubing community of
> the world.
> I was considering if speedcubing.com received a record from an unknown
> person, then a slight 'something' of proof should be necessary.
> (Unknown person would be someone that has not participated in any
> tournaments, and just "came out of nowhere", per se, or someone
> unfamiliar with the cubing community). I just think keeping this as
> professional as possible will benefit everyone, since this is a sport
> of mastery and for some of us it isn't a mere game. A 'something' of
> proof could be a simple video or something, I'm not sure. But if "Joe
> Rookie" (a guy that has never been associated with and/or is unknown
> to the cubing community) said he did a 15 second average, that's
> intense information, and just posting the record on speedcubing.com
> out of blind faith is, in my opinion atleast, not enough.
> Alot of the people are known on the speedcubing.com lists, and this
> post may not apply to most of us.
> However, asking for a "something" of proof, will require more time and
> effort on the posting committee, which could be a problem, but
> solutions can be made about that.
> Besides, the International Solitaire Ranking site requires a
> screenshot of the record you have made every time you post a record.
> This is just a suggestion, any thoughts/plans?
> Thanks, peace out :P.
> -Brent




36. improvement and my method
From: "heretogame" <heretogame@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 02:14:29 -0000


hi all i know you will all get tired of hearing from me but i am
happy i have been stuck at 45 second average for a very long time...
but i got back into the cube and i am finally working on my f2l and
in 2 weeks have gotten my f2l down from 30 seconds to around 12-15
second... on top of that i am looking at my solves and looking for 2
oll's and one pll's that will help me every week... i'll work on
those three maybe add a few more all week and practice them all week
on saturday i will review and on sunday take averages... within 2
week's i've dropped almost ten seconds and have regular sub 30
solves... my fastest still is only 25 seconds and my best average
around 35 seconds but i think i'm doing pretty good.... oh yeah
within 2 weeks i've changed from a 4 look ll to a 3 look ll still
working on it hopefully in a few more weeks i might be able to
actually compete.....





37. Card stacking (off-topic from cubing)
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 02:55:20 -0000


Hey guys. Just as a warning, this topic isn't directly related to
cubing, but I don't think it'll be a problem. I just found this site
at www.cardstacker.com where this guy named Bryan Berg makes
incredible designs with decks of cards. This made me think of
cupstacking, which I know has been picked up by a few cubers (I hope
to try it out soon). Maybe this is the next challenge for us cubers?

His store sells decks of cards designed for stacking, and Berg has
written a book about cardstacking. The cards don't seem to be that
expensive, so maybe I'll give it a shot. If anyone does try this, let
us know how it turns out.

Chris Parlette





38. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 04:25:34 -0000

Hi Dwayne, Simple shortcut methods that cut down the number of algorithms you need for OLL and especially cna be found on http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle. Even the simple L2L1 strategy cuts down the moves dramatically. As well as making the number of moves to memorise much smaller it also means that you cnas recognise the positions much more quickly. Its as few moves as Fridrich but just much easier! If you've already learned a lot of Fridrich then its even easier to switch. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, January 04, 2005 12:35 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction > > > > Welcome Dwayne, > > It's always nice to see new cube adepts. > But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's method, > and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same > fingertricks. > I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with > significantly different systems. > Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) > > Gilles > http://grrroux.free.fr > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only lately > have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a speedcuber > yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich Method > (It seems to be the method of champions). > > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently started > learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. I > seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a > hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the > Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and > maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the Fridrich > Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > appreciated. > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
39. Mefferts or rubiks.com 5x5x5
From: "Alan C." <cub3r_alan@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 04:54:35 -0000


Which kind (in your opinion) works better, the Mefferts 5x5x5 of the
rubiks.com one?





40. Re: [Speed cubing group] Mefferts or rubiks.com 5x5x5
From: Doug Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 23:02:32 -0600

There are a couple of different 5x5x5's you can buy on Mefferts.com.
The mini-cube is very well made, but all of the layers have to be
aligned near-perfect to get the darn thing to turn. It's very easy to
turn though, and a lot of people prefer these. I don't know about the
full-sized 5x5x5's at Mefferts.

The Rubiks.com 5x5x5's (from what I hear) tend to have very tight outer
layers. Personally I don't think they're as well made as the eastsheen
5x5x5 cube (Mefferts mini-cube) but they're your best bet if you want
one for legal tournament use.

Doug

Alan C. wrote:

>Which kind (in your opinion) works better, the Mefferts 5x5x5 of the
>rubiks.com one?
>
>
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>



41. Re: Card stacking (off-topic from cubing)
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 07:12:25 -0000



--- "Chris Parlette" wrote:
> at www.cardstacker.com where this guy named Bryan Berg makes
> incredible designs with decks of cards.

I bought his book at the Toronto world championships. It is
fascinating stuff. I was at a talk he gave (at the Gathering for
Gardner 6 last year) about his cardstacking. It was highly
entertaining, he was an unexpectedly good speaker.

He uses cheap cards, partly because he needs so many, but also
because he found that they actually do work better than more
expensive cards (not sure why, maybe because they are lighter). He
chose the particular brand he sells because he liked the design.

Jaap

Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 12:01:54 -0000

I also like to add this quote from the speedcubing.com rules-list: "If we have serious doubts about record posts, then we may ask you to show some kind of proof of your abilities, before putting your record on the list." - http://www.speedcubing.com/records/records- rules.html So the suggested 'rule' already exists. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Maybe if we keep in mind that speedcubing.com is unofficial and based > by just personal records. I just think keeping this as > > professional as possible will benefit everyone, since this is a sport > > of mastery and for some of us it isn't a mere game. A 'something' of > > proof could be a simple video or something, I'm not sure. 45. Lucky cases on the mini-cube
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 12:10:17 -0000


Hi everybody,

I have been practicing the 2x2 again lately, and I am wondering if I
should also count lucky cases in my average, or what the definition
of a lucky case on the 2x2 cube really is. I just took an average 5
minutes ago: 12 solves, including 3 'lucky' cases (cases where I
could skip one step).

I use Geatan Guimonds method, which is basically a three-step
solution. The first two steps are often just 3 moves, and I think
the chances of skipping one step are much bigger than with the
Fridrich method on the 3x3... So, what do you all think?

- Joel





46. Re: 4x4x4
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 13:10:02 -0000

Hi, Are you sure the cube was solved when it came out of the package? I am not sure if really understand what you mean, but you really make it sound like you have a corner twist. If you can solve seven corners (their position and orientation), than the last corner is solved as well. If this is not the case, the cube is unsolvable. You can fix this by taking you cube apart, and putting it back together again. -Joel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jim" <psyrules444@y...> wrote: > > Ok i bought a 4x4x4 from Rubiks.com. I think it's fine. Just needs a little > greasing. I tried solving it and i managed to finish matching all the edges. So > when i start solving it like a 3x3x3, something is wrong when i get to OLL and > PLL. I use the OLL algorithms which should have fixed up the LL but there is > one corner twisted the wrong way. I notice that it is always twised the wrong > direction in the OLL stage. So i looked the solution up online and ended up > going to Chris Hardwick's page which had the solution and some very useful > algorithms. The thing is, there is no algorithm to fix a messed up corner. He > has one that fixes two corners when they are switched but the LL has to be > finished for that. I cannot even finish the LL! > > Is it something wrong with my cube? Should i take that corner out and flip it > and then try to solve it? Plz HELP! > > -Jim

51. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 16:35:37 +0000 (GMT)

I am anewbie here. Yes, I solved 4*4*4 yesterday for the first time in 8 hours following chris hardwick's page. Thanks to him. I think, Jim faced the same problem I faced. I think, he means the cornors are not properly fixed and not only one cornor is twisted. What I did was I just switched edges and the cornors became solvable and finally I switched the edges. The cube was solved. I am sorry, if I have confused you furthur. Let me thank chris once again for making me to solve 4*4*4 cube. John Louis Jim <psyrules444@...> wrote: Ok i bought a 4x4x4 from Rubiks.com. I think it's fine. Just needs a little greasing. I tried solving it and i managed to finish matching all the edges. So when i start solving it like a 3x3x3, something is wrong when i get to OLL and PLL. I use the OLL algorithms which should have fixed up the LL but there is one corner twisted the wrong way. I notice that it is always twised the wrong direction in the OLL stage. So i looked the solution up online and ended up going to Chris Hardwick's page which had the solution and some very useful algorithms. The thing is, there is no algorithm to fix a messed up corner. He has one that fixes two corners when they are switched but the LL has to be finished for that. I cannot even finish the LL! Is it something wrong with my cube? Should i take that corner out and flip it and then try to solve it? Plz HELP! -Jim --------------------------------- Yahoo! Groups Links To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partneronline. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

54. [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 18:43:43 -0000

Very nice page, hadn't seen it yet... but the "Introduction" is not about speedstacking and Chris's 18 sec blindfold feat is not really that "hotly contested" ;-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Hi Dwayne, > Simple shortcut methods that cut down the number of algorithms you need for > OLL and especially cna be found on > http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle. Even the simple L2L1 > strategy cuts down the moves dramatically. As well as making the number of > moves to memorise much smaller it also means that you cnas recognise the > positions much more quickly. Its as few moves as Fridrich but just much > easier! If you've already learned a lot of Fridrich then its even easier to > switch. > > Duncan > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Tuesday, January 04, 2005 12:35 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction > > > > > > > > > > Welcome Dwayne, > > > > It's always nice to see new cube adepts. > > But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's method, > > and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same > > fingertricks. > > I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with > > significantly different systems. > > Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) > > > > Gilles > > http://grrroux.free.fr > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only lately > > have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a speedcuber > > yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich Method > > (It seems to be the method of champions). > > > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently started > > learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. I > > seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a > > hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > > > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the > > Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > > > > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and > > maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the Fridrich > > Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > > appreciated. > > > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
55. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcubing.com
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 11:21:51 -0800

People only cheat themselves if they lie on speedcubing.com. When they
get to a competition and they can't perform even remotely close to what
they claim, we start to speculate and I think that's the worst feeling
to have hanging over your head. If someone has a sub-20 average and
they can't manage to solve a cube under 30 seconds, well, that's a good
clue that they aren't telling the truth. Furthermore, if you lie, it
makes it all together more difficult for you to go to a competition and
you will be left out of all the fun that everyone else has been having.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 4, 2005, at 7:44 AM, Brent Morgan wrote:

> What does it mater if it's official or unofficial?

Tyson Mao

> applied, even though I don't know Fridrich :)

I actually did the wrong OLL and, after performing the correct OLL,
the cube was solved ;)

> a strange question, isn't it?)

It's called "gymnopedie no. 1" by Erik Satie.

59. Re: [Speed cubing group] Mefferts or rubiks.com 5x5x5

Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 05:44:17 -0000

So Eastsheen is illegal? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: > There are a couple of different 5x5x5's you can buy on Mefferts.com. > The mini-cube is very well made, but all of the layers have to be > aligned near-perfect to get the darn thing to turn. It's very easy to > turn though, and a lot of people prefer these. I don't know about the > full-sized 5x5x5's at Mefferts. > > The Rubiks.com 5x5x5's (from what I hear) tend to have very tight outer > layers. Personally I don't think they're as well made as the eastsheen > 5x5x5 cube (Mefferts mini-cube) but they're your best bet if you want > one for legal tournament use. > > Doug > > Alan C. wrote: > > >Which kind (in your opinion) works better, the Mefferts 5x5x5 of the > >rubiks.com one? > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! 61. Re: My Introduction
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 09:56:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Gilles is right, you should clone him instead ;-) Stefan :-) I don't need a mini-me (but if a younger and more talented cuber wants to try it my way, I think it has some potential). Of course learning Fridrich is not a crime. But there are different methods that allow you to become sub-20. And how many top cubers are using them? Even before starting to think, people are taught to learn F2L+OLL+PLL. Why not F2L+CLL+ELL? Has it really been proven to be much slower? Who is using it except Masayuki and Guus? At least, this approach requires fewer sequences, and many corner sequences can be used in different solving methods. And what about methods like Waterman's. Is Josef the only one who's using it nowadays? Corners-first is another option (Ron, are you still interested in trying it for real?). The problem of corners-first comes from edges, but I feel there are still tricks to find out (inserting/adding slice moves in corner sequences, or preserved pre-orientation, or...). I can understand that people have more interesting things to do in their lives than to look for original cube tricks, but I would prefer to see 15 slightly different cubing styles and videos in the 15s-20s range than 10 more sub-15 clones (by that time, Macky will be sub-13) ;-) Gilles. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > P.S. Or invent your own way. But it might help to know other > solutions, partly because then you know you're doing something new... > Should I ever finish learning full Fridrich, I'll probably learn > Gilles' method next... > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > Welcome Dwayne, > > > > It's always nice to see new cube adepts. > > But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's > method, > > and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same > > fingertricks. > > I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with > > significantly different systems. > > Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) > > > > Gilles > > http://grrroux.free.fr > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only > lately > > have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a > speedcuber > > yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich > Method > > (It seems to be the method of champions). > > > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently > started > > learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. > I > > seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a > > hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > > > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the > > Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > > > > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and > > maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the > Fridrich > > Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > > appreciated. > > > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
62. Re: DIY kits
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 11:29:32 -0000

Hi! I also recieved my DIY cube-kit from Rubiks.com a few days ago. My core/axel was in white plastic. I didn't have any problems with the screw. They fit quite nicely into the core at the correct friction, so they won't unscrew themselves easily. My only gripe with those DIY kits is that it is troublesome to fit the centercaps. What i did was to cut off the "feet". And also remove the extra "support bridge". Then i glued them to the centers after adjusting the cube tension carefully. I did this with all edges and corners removed, so as not to spill glue on them. Then i sanded, no i used a knife ... hehe ..., the edges of the caps cause some edges were slightly sticking out. Then i added the stickers to them. The cube now turns beautifully, and it's as good as my normal racing cube even before breaking it in properly :-) One suggestion though. My kit came with hollow corners. There is no need to glue on the caps that are suplied for them. If u glue them on it will only create more friction, besides making the cube heavier :- P But from reading the posts here it seems that the kits vary somehow in content and quality ?? Kind regards, -Per PS! It seems that i got the real vinyl stickers too :-) PPS! Some late nite practice yesterday gave me real good times :-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ryan Patricio" > <ryn_patricio@y...> wrote: > > > > I just got some DIY 3x3 kits...and for some odd reason the screws > > don't go into the axel...and to top it off rubiks.com gave me those > > really annoying paper stickers instead of pvc.... > > I just got a DIY from Rubiks.com as well. I too recieved paper > stickers. The screws you got may fit into the axel, but a little > convincing is needed. It took a little force to get screws in as well. > In the end, the finished cube was acceptable, but no better than the > new 'pre-made' arched cubes, in my opinion. > > -Chris

Hi everybody,

I think all post must mentionned all 12 times for the average, this
is not the case for the moment.... And it will be good to send a
screenshot of the timer (to moderators of speedcubing.com) to prove
the credibility of the record.

Another thing:
Refresh the list all 3-4 month and deleted the records that haven't
be updated. Some cubers have stop to cube and records are here again.


Nico.

What i did was to cut off the "feet". And also remove > the extra "support bridge". Then i glued them to the centers after > adjusting the cube tension carefully. I did this with all edges and > corners removed, so as not to spill glue on them. Then i sanded, no i > used a knife ... hehe ..., the edges of the caps cause some edges > were slightly sticking out. Then i added the stickers to them. > > The cube now turns beautifully, and it's as good as my normal racing > cube even before breaking it in properly :-) > > One suggestion though. My kit came with hollow corners. There is no > need to glue on the caps that are suplied for them. If u glue them on > it will only create more friction, besides making the cube heavier :- > P But from reading the posts here it seems that the kits vary somehow > in content and quality ?? > I put a picture of the kit on my site: http://grrroux.free.fr/workshop/workshop.html Other pictures on Jon Morris' site (different screws): http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001/dyi.htm It looks perfect. 15 minutes after assembling it (+sandpaper) I was averaging 16s. Don't know what's best. With or without corner caps? Sure there are more contact surfaces, but flat ones, and with lubricant it's not a problem. I'd like to test a cube with edge cubies that are not hollow. > Kind regards, > > -Per > > PS! It seems that i got the real vinyl stickers too :-) > PPS! Some late nite practice yesterday gave me real good times :-) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ryan Patricio" > > <ryn_patricio@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I just got some DIY 3x3 kits...and for some odd reason the screws > > > don't go into the axel...and to top it off rubiks.com gave me > those > > > really annoying paper stickers instead of pvc.... > > > > I just got a DIY from Rubiks.com as well. 72. Re: DIY kits
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 15:24:16 -0000

I should fix those caps once and for all ... I also glued the corner caps on. I like my cube to be 'complete' if you know what I mean, and the extra friction is negligable. The cube is not extremely good, it feels like I never have to fiddle with it again. I love it... I even set a new avg-of-50 record with it yesterday. Flat centers? Pfft... gimme my DIY, I say! :P --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "hovardt" <hovardt@y...> wrote: > > I had trouble with the caps as well. I found if I mixed and matched > with various sides and tried different orientations, they seemed to > fit better if you could find a good match. Some caps worked better > on different sides for some reason. > > -Howard > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "joel_vn" > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > About those corners, > > > > I did glue those caps on them. They did not really 'fit like a > > glove', so I had to remove some rough edges with a knife. > > > > Still have problems with those centre caps though. Maybe I'll try > to > > do it your way when I have more time :). > > > > Bye bye now, > > > > Joel. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > I also recieved my DIY cube-kit from Rubiks.com a few days ago. > My > > > core/axel was in white plastic. I didn't have any problems with > > the > > > screw. They fit quite nicely into the core at the correct > > friction, > > > so they won't unscrew themselves easily. > > > > > > My only gripe with those DIY kits is that it is troublesome to > fit > > > the centercaps. What i did was to cut off the "feet". And also > > remove > > > the extra "support bridge". Then i glued them to the centers > after > > > adjusting the cube tension carefully. I did this with all edges > > and > > > corners removed, so as not to spill glue on them. Then i sanded, > > no i > > > used a knife ... hehe ..., the edges of the caps cause some edges > > > were slightly sticking out. Then i added the stickers to them. > > > > > > The cube now turns beautifully, and it's as good as my normal > > racing > > > cube even before breaking it in properly :-) > > > > > > One suggestion though. My kit came with hollow corners. There is > > no > > > need to glue on the caps that are suplied for them. If u glue > them > > on > > > it will only create more friction, besides making the cube > > heavier :- > > > P But from reading the posts here it seems that the kits vary > > somehow > > > in content and quality ?? > > > > > > Kind regards, > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > PS! It seems that i got the real vinyl stickers too :-) > > > PPS! Some late nite practice yesterday gave me real good times :- > ) > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ryan Patricio" > > > > <ryn_patricio@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > I just got some DIY 3x3 kits...and for some odd reason the > > screws > > > > > don't go into the axel...and to top it off rubiks.com gave me > > > those > > > > > really annoying paper stickers instead of pvc.... > > > > > > > > I just got a DIY from Rubiks.com as well. I too recieved paper > > > > stickers. The screws you got may fit into the axel, but a little > > > > convincing is needed. It took a little force to get screws in > as > > > well. > > > > In the end, the finished cube was acceptable, but no better > than > > the > > > > new 'pre-made' arched cubes, in my opinion. > > > > > > > > -Chris

74. Re: DIY kits
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 16:01:05 -0000

It seems that they have changed the DIY kits slightly since I purchased mine. Appears that the screws are different now and my corners were complete, no caps for them. I also had trouble with the center caps and had to adjust them with an exacto knife to make them work. As far as the sticker issue goes... There are two kits available from rubiks.com: "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube" for $8.99, and "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube&Stickers" for $10.99. The more expesive set comes with two sets of PVC stickers and it doesn't say, but I assume that the cheaper one comes with the paper stickers. Maybe someone can verify this. All in all I really like my DIY cubes too. Jon www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > Well, that was a bad typo. 76. Re: My Introduction
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 18:01:14 -0000

I know, I know... that's why in my P.S. I mentioned he could invent his own method. But I think learning your method would be good, too. Not only for the person learning it but for the cubing community, because it could make the community (and especially newbies) more aware of different methods. Plus, I do think your method looks very nice. And it does include CLL, right? So to learn CLL+ELL I'd only need to add ELL... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Gilles is right, you should clone him instead ;-) > > Stefan :-) I don't need a mini-me (but if a younger and more talented > cuber wants to try it my way, I think it has some potential). > Of course learning Fridrich is not a crime. But there are different > methods that allow you to become sub-20. And how many top cubers are > using them? > Even before starting to think, people are taught to learn F2L+OLL+PLL. > Why not F2L+CLL+ELL? Has it really been proven to be much slower? Who > is using it except Masayuki and Guus? At least, this approach requires > fewer sequences, and many corner sequences can be used in different > solving methods. > And what about methods like Waterman's. Is Josef the only one who's > using it nowadays? > Corners-first is another option (Ron, are you still interested in > trying it for real?). The problem of corners-first comes from edges, > but I feel there are still tricks to find out (inserting/adding slice > moves in corner sequences, or preserved pre-orientation, or...). > > I can understand that people have more interesting things to do in > their lives than to look for original cube tricks, but I would prefer > to see 15 slightly different cubing styles and videos in the 15s-20s > range than 10 more sub-15 clones (by that time, Macky will be sub-13) ;-) > > Gilles. > > > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > P.S. Or invent your own way. But it might help to know other > > solutions, partly because then you know you're doing something new... > > Should I ever finish learning full Fridrich, I'll probably learn > > Gilles' method next... > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > Welcome Dwayne, > > > > > > It's always nice to see new cube adepts. > > > But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's > > method, > > > and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same > > > fingertricks. > > > I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with > > > significantly different systems. > > > Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) > > > > > > Gilles > > > http://grrroux.free.fr > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only > > lately > > > have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a > > speedcuber > > > yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich > > Method > > > (It seems to be the method of champions). > > > > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently > > started > > > learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. > > I > > > seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a > > > hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > > > > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the > > > Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > > > > > > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and > > > maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the > > Fridrich > > > Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > > > appreciated. > > > > > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

78. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 19:15:06 -0000

More like the worst way to solve it. Devil's algorithm is an imagined algorithm that, by being applied over and over again, sorts through every single possible position so that you are bound to solve it if you keep at it long enough. I've thought about it a little and may give it a shot. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > does anyone know the devil's algorithm? > > You mean the shortest way to scramble a cube? Or what is it?
79. Re: DIY kits
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 20:43:16 -0000

My opinion on the DIY kit I bought while ago. It came with the greenish teal kernel and corner caps on. Yes, those center caps are horrible. I'm not sure on this but it seems like those little support triangles on the caps actually hit the circular plastic things that sticks up in the center piece before the cap is on tight, thus making it impossible to put them on without modifications! For the record, it was the 10.99 kit. I also didn't like the fact that the yellow and orange stickers were a bit transparent making them look darker and dull. The cube was pretty good. Like all cubes with arched centers, they lock up more frequently wich prevents me from reaching my full cubing potential, but the lack of popping associated with that is nice. But then I dropped it on the floor from 4 feet high max and it broke-The kernel actually split in half and now I have don't have a good speedcube:( Summaruy: center caps-bad. Cube-decent. Stickers-okay. Durability-bad(at least in my experience). --barefoot Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, nascarjon2001 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > It seems that they have changed the DIY kits slightly since I > purchased mine. Appears that the screws are different now and my > corners were complete, no caps for them. I also had trouble with > the center caps and had to adjust them with an exacto knife to make > them work. As far as the sticker issue goes... There are two kits > available from rubiks.com: "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube" for > $8.99, and "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube&Stickers" for $10.99. > The more expesive set comes with two sets of PVC stickers and it > doesn't say, but I assume that the cheaper one comes with the paper > stickers. Maybe someone can verify this. All in all I really like > my DIY cubes too. > > Jon > www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001 >

81. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 21:35:29 -0000

If you find it, please don't post it here. Assuming it looks random, it'd take a lot of memory: M = 12!*2^12*8!*3^8/12/1260 = 3.43*10^16 That's the minimum number of moves it'd need. B = M*log2(18)/8 = 1.789*10^16 That's the number of bytes. B/2^50 = 15.89 That's the number of petabytes. Btw, peta comes after tera, which comes after giga. B/(300*2^30) = 55546 The number of 300GB hard drives needed to store the algorithm. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > More like the worst way to solve it. Devil's algorithm is an imagined > algorithm that, by being applied over and over again, sorts through > every single possible position so that you are bound to solve it if > you keep at it long enough. > > I've thought about it a little and may give it a shot. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > > > > does anyone know the devil's algorithm? > > > > You mean the shortest way to scramble a cube? Or what is it?
82. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 21:46:04 -0000

Oh, before I forget it: 4325 - The number of years to download it with a 1MBit/sec internet connection. So yeah, please don't fucking post it here ;-) Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > If you find it, please don't post it here. Btw, peta comes after tera, which > comes after giga. > > B/(300*2^30) = 55546 > The number of 300GB hard drives needed to store the algorithm. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > More like the worst way to solve it. Devil's algorithm is an > imagined > > algorithm that, by being applied over and over again, sorts through > > every single possible position so that you are bound to solve it if > > you keep at it long enough. > > > > I've thought about it a little and may give it a shot. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee > <no_reply@y...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > does anyone know the devil's algorithm? > > > > > > You mean the shortest way to scramble a cube? Devil's algorithm is an > > imagined > > > algorithm that, by being applied over and over again, sorts > through > > > every single possible position so that you are bound to solve it > if > > > you keep at it long enough. > > > > > > I've thought about it a little and may give it a shot. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee > > <no_reply@y...> > > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > > > does anyone know the devil's algorithm? > > > > > > > > You mean the shortest way to scramble a cube? Or what is it?

From: h_howee <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

89. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 00:30:42 -0000

*Sigh*, always the assumptions ruin my hour of triumph! :) CO stands for Corner Orientation. COC1 twists UFR clockwise and UBR counterclockwise. COC2 does the same, but with UFL instead of UFR. The idea is the same with COCs 2 to 7. They all twist one corner clockwise and UBR counterclockwise. By applying COC1 three times (which is COT1), we can iterate through the three possible orientations for the first corner. By applying COC2 three times, with COT1 inbetween each time, we iterate through all possible orientations for the first two corners. And so on... up to seven. The last corner we can ignore since its orientation is decided by the others. So, COT7, which I have called CO, will cycle through all possible orientations of all the corners. The idea is similar with the EO algorithms, except that in EOT1, CO is called. This means that EOT11 (which by now is getting freakishly long, and I have called simply "O") cycles through all possible orientations of all the pieces. So now, we only need to cycle through all permutations, and apply O once for each of them. The EP algorithms does that with the edges. EP (EPT12) is a 12 cycle of edges (EPC12) done 12 times with EPT11 done once inbetween each. EPT11 is an 11-cycle (EPC11) done 11 times with EPT10 done once inbetween each... and so on. At the lowest level (EPT2), O is invoked. For each even cycle, two corners are also swapped, but they're the same two corners all the time. The edge that is left untouched by the 11-cycle is also left untouched by all the others, etc. (This is important, I reckon.) Now, EP is then an algorithm which, given a cube with correct corner permutation, will eventually produce the solved cube. The CP algorithms work excactly the same as the EP ones. At the lowest CP level (CPT2), EP is invoked. So.. there you go. I think it should work. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > how about god's algorithms? > is there a site where i can find them? Honor and glory is up for grabs for whoever can find God's algorithm first, mate!
90. Re: My Introduction
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 01:02:49 -0000

Hi Gilles, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Gilles is right, you should clone him instead ;-) > > Stefan :-) I don't need a mini-me (but if a younger and more talented > cuber wants to try it my way, I think it has some potential). > Of course learning Fridrich is not a crime. But there are different > methods that allow you to become sub-20. And how many top cubers are > using them? I'm not a top cuber yet, but I think my method can be quick. > Even before starting to think, people are taught to learn F2L+OLL+PLL. I think people should be encouraged to solve the cube on their own before lerning omeone else's methods. > Why not F2L+CLL+ELL? Has it really been proven to be much slower? Who > is using it except Masayuki and Guus? I do last level corners then edges. > At least, this approach requires > fewer sequences, and many corner sequences can be used in different > solving methods. > And what about methods like Waterman's. Is Josef the only one who's > using it nowadays? > Corners-first is another option (Ron, are you still interested in > trying it for real?). Ever try edges first? David J
