93. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 05:05:00 -0000

Ok, thanks a lot. Very very nice! Actually I've once done something quite similar a while ago, so I should've had that idea, too :-) Damn. .. You've built it bottom-up... I think it's also a nice idea to look at it top-down. The algorithm first "chooses" a certain corner to place at some spot by cycling all corners through that spot. For each choice made, it chooses the next corner to place at the next spot. And so on. Same with edges (for each choice of all corners, choose all edges). And then deeper inside (or "later") "choose" the orientations of all pieces, one by one. Hmm, do you remember that the cube group can be generated by just two different algorithms? I.e. two algorithms that you combine a lot to get to any state you want. I'm not sure I have an idea for a much shorter Devil's algorithm than yours, but maybe for one that can be described shorter. Based on those two algs. I don't remember the exact two algs, but I think the idea was this: Do you know these sushi restaurants where lots of plates with some sushi run around in a long chain and people pick out what they want? Now imagine you're the only one sitting next to that cycle of plates and you already hold one in your hand. The plates are running around all the time and from time to time you pick one out and replace it with the one in your hand. This way you can easily create any order you want, it just may take a while. The two algs work just like that, but you have one cycle on your left with seven corners and one cycle on your right with eleven edges. And you hold one corner in your left hand and one edge in your right hand. Both cycles cycle with the same speed, and whenever you want, you replace both the corner and the edge currently next to you in the cycles with those in your hands. One of the two algs does the cycles (i.e. cycles seven corners and eleven edges). The other alg does the swaps, i.e. swaps the left out corner with a certain corner position in the cycle and same for edges. For example, this second alg could just be the T-permutation swapping (UL, UR) and (URF,UBR) and the first alg could cycle all corners but URF and all edges but UR. Why should this work? Let's talk about permutation only. It should be clear from the sushi example that you can get any order when you're just dealing with one cycle. But with the two cycles we can "simulate" that they move independently, even though they're not. Consider cycling both by one position, but do it 22 times. That will not change the edges (just cycle them completely two times) but it will cycle the corners completely three times and one more position. To cycle the edges one position forwards, move both cycles 56 forwards. Why does it work, why can we move them independently? Because 7 and 11 are relatively prime. How about orientation? This is actually not covered yet. We need to modify the above construction. The algorithm that moves the cycles one step forward must also do some orientation. For the edges, imagine that they don't cycle on a "normal" strip, but on a Moebius strip (http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MoebiusStrip.html). That is, the cycle is not a normal 11-cycle, but at some point it twists 180 degrees. So after 11 iterations, the edges are in the original position but all flipped. After 22 iterations they're the same. For this to work we also need to flip the edge in your hand, though, i.e. the one at UR. For corners, we do the same, but we "open" the cycle somewhere to include a clockwise twist and twist the corner in our hand (i.e. at URF) counterclockwise. The claim is that everything can be done independently: 1) Move edge cycle one forward without flipping edges, and leave corners completely intact. 2) Move corner cycle one forward. 3) Flip all edges. 4) Twist all corners. This is how that's done: 3) Apply the alg 11*7*3 = 231 times. Thanks to factor 11, the edges will stay at their place. Thanks to 7, corners will stay. Thanks to 3, corners won't be twisted. Since 231 is odd, edges will be flipped. 4) Apply it 11*7*2 = 154 times. 1) Apply it 7*3*10 = 210 times. Thanks to 7*3, corners won't be changed. Since 210 is even, edges won't be flipped. Since 210=19*11+1, the edges will make 19 complete cycles plus one more step forwards. 2) Apply it 11*2*15 = 330 times. Since 330=47*7+1, corners will make 47 complete cycles plus one more step. And why does it work? Why is it all independent? Because 11, 7, 2 and 3 are all relatively prime. Ok, I think I'd better stop for a moment and continue with the original idea of using this for the Devil's algorithm in another post. .. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > *Sigh*, always the assumptions ruin my hour of triumph! :) > > CO stands for Corner Orientation. COC1 twists UFR clockwise and UBR > counterclockwise. COC2 does the same, but with UFL instead of UFR. The > idea is the same with COCs 2 to 7. They all twist one corner clockwise > and UBR counterclockwise. By applying COC1 three times (which is > COT1), we can iterate through the three possible orientations for the > first corner. By applying COC2 three times, with COT1 inbetween each > time, we iterate through all possible orientations for the first two > corners. And so on... up to seven. The last corner we can ignore since > its orientation is decided by the others. So, COT7, which I have > called CO, will cycle through all possible orientations of all the > corners. > > The idea is similar with the EO algorithms, except that in EOT1, CO is > called. This means that EOT11 (which by now is getting freakishly > long, and I have called simply "O") cycles through all possible > orientations of all the pieces. So now, we only need to cycle through > all permutations, and apply O once for each of them. > > The EP algorithms does that with the edges. EP (EPT12) is a 12 cycle > of edges (EPC12) done 12 times with EPT11 done once inbetween each. > EPT11 is an 11-cycle (EPC11) done 11 times with EPT10 done once > inbetween each... and so on. At the lowest level (EPT2), O is invoked. > For each even cycle, two corners are also swapped, but they're the > same two corners all the time. The edge that is left untouched by the > 11-cycle is also left untouched by all the others, etc. (This is > important, I reckon.) > > Now, EP is then an algorithm which, given a cube with correct corner > permutation, will eventually produce the solved cube. The CP > algorithms work excactly the same as the EP ones. At the lowest CP > level (CPT2), EP is invoked. > > So.. there you go. I think it should work. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y.. .> > wrote: > > > > how about god's algorithms? > > is there a site where i can find them? > > Honor and glory is up for grabs for whoever can find God's algorithm > first, mate!
94. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 05:10:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Ok, I think I'd better stop for a moment and continue with the > original idea of using this for the Devil's algorithm in another post. > .. Ok, I'm too tired for it tonight, but the point is that these two algorithms, cleverly combined over and over again, will be powerful enough to do all that your basic algs (COC1 to CPC8) did. So it's a lot less to write (unless you also want to explain it, then it might get as long as my previous post ;-). The first part of your Devil's alg could be replaced by just two lines, and I'm convinced the second part can then be replaced by just a few lines as well. Cheers! Stefan
95. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 05:42:56 -0000

Ok here's an attempt: Let AC be the cycling alg and AS the swapping alg. My Devil's alg does 3*AC, then AS, then 1*AC, then AS, then 4*AC, then AS, and so on. Using the digits of pi=3.1415... Short and beautiful definition, har har. No proof ;-) Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Ok, I think I'd better stop for a moment and continue with the > > original idea of using this for the Devil's algorithm in another > post. > > .. > > Ok, I'm too tired for it tonight, but the point is that these two > algorithms, cleverly combined over and over again, will be powerful > enough to do all that your basic algs (COC1 to CPC8) did. So it's a > lot less to write (unless you also want to explain it, then it might > get as long as my previous post ;-). The first part of your Devil's > alg could be replaced by just two lines, and I'm convinced the second > part can then be replaced by just a few lines as well. > > Cheers! > Stefan
96. Re: devil's algorithm
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 07:40:35 -0000


I would have thought that the "devil's algorithm" would be the
shortest way to cycle through all N positions of the cube, i.e. a
move sequence N-1 moves long that never repeats any position. (Here N
is 43 quintillion and something.)

It has not been proven (im)possible as far as I know. For the
mathematicians, it would be a Hamiltonian path on the Cayley graph of
the cube.
One of these days I'll try to do one on a 2x2x2 cube.

Jaap

(Here N > is 43 quintillion and something.) > > It has not been proven (im)possible as far as I know. 98. Re: cross
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 10:36:59 -0000

The cross, more than any other step, requires lots of "real" practice to get right. I.e. you can work on the LL without actually having done the F2L first, but the best idea for cross + F2L is actually just to mix up the cube and go at it. Remember that the cross is an integral part of the F2L, they should never be separated. By practicing your cross, you should also practice your F2L and vice versa. In the beginning, spend more than 15 seconds preinspecting so that you can start making out complete crosses before actually turning a side. Your preinspection times will gradually improve. Look for ways to do two things at once. Also, though you may do this already, it often helps to put down the cross edges disregarding the middle layer centers, and just putting the edges down relative to each other, and finishing off with a turn of the D layer to line them up correctly. Dan has a nice cross tutorial at: www.cubestation.co.uk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "sfodd66008" <sfodd66008@y...> wrote: > > hey guys, im new here and have been speedcubing for about 8 months. > i used to be down around 45 for a average time and i havnt done it > in like a month(cause my cube needed new stickers) but i finally got > them and i am getting back into. now i am averaging about 55. and > before i learn a bunch more algoithms i was looking at my start.It > takes me on average 8 secs to get the cross in and right. this seems > way too long and i think i can cut from 4-6 seconds a solve if i > improve here. so i want to know if u have any tips or just how u do > it. thanks a lot > ~Andrew
99. Re: devil's algorithm
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 12:33:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > I wasn't aware that it would have to be the shortest one. That makes > the problem a bit more delicate. :P I really like the idea of an explicit algorithm for this; the problem is distinct from finding a Hamiltonian circuit, though obviously that would solve the problem, too... A horrible (but trivial) alternative is just to simulate a depth- first search: consider a sequence of identities, beginning with E1 = F F F F U U U U R R R R B B B B L L L L D D D D which produces all states at depth 1. We might as well abbreviate it to E1 = F4 U4 R4 B4 L4 D4 Then E2 = (F E1)4 (U E1)4 (R E1)4 (B E1)4 (L E1)4 (D E1)4 E3 = (F E2)4 (U E2)4 (R E2)4 (B E2)4 (L E2)4 (D E2)4 ...and so on, up to E29. You can see that performing En will produce all the states at depths up to and including n. Since we know (from Mike Reid's work) that the diameter of the Rubik's cube group is no more than 29 (HTM), applying E29 will solve any position at some point. E29 is so long anyway that it is scarcely worth making the obvious modifications to account for commuting moves. Question: Is there a neater way to specify a sequence that simulates a depth-first search? Mike
100. Re: devil's algorithm
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 12:42:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Ok here's an attempt: Let AC be the cycling alg and AS the swapping > alg. My Devil's alg does 3*AC, then AS, then 1*AC, then AS, then 4*AC, > then AS, and so on. Using the digits of pi=3.1415... Short and > beautiful definition, har har. Even simpler, map BFUDLR to the digits 012345. Then read off the "solution" from the digits of Pi, in base 6 :) Mike
101. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 12:56:57 -0000

Your depth-first algorithm is this long (worst case scenario): 11,081,777,224,076,574,027,294,514,344,648,207,681,624 moves So I gather mine is _slightly_ more efficient still. Although yours is easier to describe. ;) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > I wasn't aware that it would have to be the shortest one. That makes > > the problem a bit more delicate. :P > > I really like the idea of an explicit algorithm for this; the problem > is distinct from finding a Hamiltonian circuit, though obviously that > would solve the problem, too... > > A horrible (but trivial) alternative is just to simulate a depth- > first search: consider a sequence of identities, beginning with > > E1 = F F F F U U U U R R R R B B B B L L L L D D D D > > which produces all states at depth 1. We might as well abbreviate it > to > > E1 = F4 U4 R4 B4 L4 D4 > > Then > > E2 = (F E1)4 (U E1)4 (R E1)4 (B E1)4 (L E1)4 (D E1)4 > E3 = (F E2)4 (U E2)4 (R E2)4 (B E2)4 (L E2)4 (D E2)4 > > ...and so on, up to E29. You can see that performing En will produce > all the states at depths up to and including n. Since we know (from > Mike Reid's work) that the diameter of the Rubik's cube group is no > more than 29 (HTM), applying E29 will solve any position at some > point. > > E29 is so long anyway that it is scarcely worth making the obvious > modifications to account for commuting moves. > > Question: Is there a neater way to specify a sequence that simulates > a depth-first search? > > Mike
102. Re: devil's algorithm
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 13:19:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > Your depth-first algorithm is this long (worst case scenario): > > 11,081,777,224,076,574,027,294,514,344,648,207,681,624 moves > > So I gather mine is _slightly_ more efficient still. True, indeed. Let's not neglect the practicalities ;) Mike
103. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 14:48:42 -0000

Excactly. :) I wrote a little script for those who really have time on their hands: http://www.stud.ntnu.no/~eivindfo/devalg.php It serves up the moves in standard cube notation, nicely divided into 4186315524107413 pages. I would offer a means of jumping directly to a page number, but I haven't found an easy way to work out the parameters for an arbitrary page number yet. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > Your depth-first algorithm is this long (worst case scenario): > > > > 11,081,777,224,076,574,027,294,514,344,648,207,681,624 moves > > > > So I gather mine is _slightly_ more efficient still. > > True, indeed. Let's not neglect the practicalities ;) > > Mike

106. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 19:56:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Even simpler, map BFUDLR to the digits 012345. Then read off > the "solution" from the digits of Pi, in base 6 :) Haha, this is definitely the winner in the "simple to define" category :-) Though maybe not in "simple to prove"... Cheers! Stefan
107. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 19:57:37 -0000

I love it :-) Though I think in the recursion steps you should do all 18 possibilities, not only six. It gave me the idea of using this with my two algs: Let AC be the algorithm for cycling. Let AS be the algorithm for swapping. Let A(0) be the empty algorithm. Let A(n+1) = AC A(n) AC' AS A(n) AS'. Find the maximum number N of applications needed to reach any state with combinations of AC and AS. It must exist because every state can be reached in a finite number of applications. Let the Devil's algorithm be A(N). Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eivind Fonn" > <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > > > > I wasn't aware that it would have to be the shortest one. That makes > > the problem a bit more delicate. :P > > I really like the idea of an explicit algorithm for this; the problem > is distinct from finding a Hamiltonian circuit, though obviously that > would solve the problem, too... > > A horrible (but trivial) alternative is just to simulate a depth- > first search: consider a sequence of identities, beginning with > > E1 = F F F F U U U U R R R R B B B B L L L L D D D D > > which produces all states at depth 1. We might as well abbreviate it > to > > E1 = F4 U4 R4 B4 L4 D4 > > Then > > E2 = (F E1)4 (U E1)4 (R E1)4 (B E1)4 (L E1)4 (D E1)4 > E3 = (F E2)4 (U E2)4 (R E2)4 (B E2)4 (L E2)4 (D E2)4 > > ...and so on, up to E29. You can see that performing En will produce > all the states at depths up to and including n. Since we know (from > Mike Reid's work) that the diameter of the Rubik's cube group is no > more than 29 (HTM), applying E29 will solve any position at some > point. > > E29 is so long anyway that it is scarcely worth making the obvious > modifications to account for commuting moves. > > Question: Is there a neater way to specify a sequence that simulates > a depth-first search? > > Mike
108. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 20:06:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Though I think in the recursion steps you should do all 18 > possibilities, not only six. Ok, I'm stupid. You already do all. But you could write it a bit shorter using A(0), then A(1) can be defined like all others: A(0) = empty algorithm A(n+1) = (F A(n))4 (B A(n))4 ... (same for L, R, U, D) Devil = A(29) Cheers! Stefan
109. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 20:14:07 -0000

Even better: A(0) = empty A(n+1) = (((F A(n))4 x)4 y)4 Devil = A(29) Hehe... Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Though I think in the recursion steps you should do all 18 > > possibilities, not only six. > > Ok, I'm stupid. You already do all. > > But you could write it a bit shorter using A(0), then A(1) can be > defined like all others: > > A(0) = empty algorithm > A(n+1) = (F A(n))4 (B A(n))4 ... (same for L, R, U, D) > Devil = A(29) > > Cheers! > Stefan
110. Advanced tricks for the F2L
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 23:13:12 -0000

Hi everybody, I have finally created some pages about advanced F2L stuff, for your perusal. It is not quite complete yet, but since I have been working on it quite a lot I think it is only fair to release what I have written for you to work on! I hope you all find it useful, please let me know what you think. You can find it from my website www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the F2L link in the orange panel. Keep it fun! Dan Harris :-) [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

112. Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 00:48:13 -0000

Hi Dan, thanks a lot for your effort, even though you're a bit too late for me with some of it ;-) Now my comments... 2. Empty Slots -------------- I love (r' R U' R' F R U R' r), thanks a lot :-) Though I might prefer to pull M' with my left ring finger instead of doing (R' r). But only practice will show me what's better for me... 3. Solve from all angles --------------------- You say "you must imagine the movement which your hands have to do". I think this is a bit misleading. What you should really know is how the pieces move and why they move that way. This does get clearer in the examples but I think your introduction is unnecessary confusing. Well, maybe I just think so because I didn't learn the F2L algs without understanding them. If someone does that and all he knows is what his hands do, then maybe your text is good. How on earth do you execute (F' U F) ?!? That just feels wrong ;-) I mean, honestly, do you do that? How??? Also, FR-F3 might not be the best example, as I'm sure the 2nd and 4th angle cases should really be solved as (y' R' U R U' R' U' R) and (y R' U R U L' U' L) instead. But even Lars Petrus doesn't seem to like it ;-) See http://lar5.com/cube/fas4.html section "Advanced", first example on the left. Similarly, I'm convinced the second angle for BL-R5 should be solved as (y' R' U' R L' U L). General ------- It would be nice to have some explicit examples to practice. I'm not asking you to describe more examples in the great detail you do, but just maybe provide "exercises", i.e. some cases we can try to solve ourselves and maybe including as a hint the number of moves we should try to achieve (or other goals like not rotating the cube) All that said, thanks again for all your effort you put in your pages. I hope one day I'll master it all, too, currently my F2L is maybe around 16 seconds... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hi everybody, > > > > I have finally created some pages about advanced F2L stuff, for your > perusal. It is not quite complete yet, but since I have been working on it > quite a lot I think it is only fair to release what I have written for you > to work on! > > > > I hope you all find it useful, please let me know what you think. > > > > You can find it from my website www.cubestation.co.uk > <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the F2L link in the orange > panel. > > > > Keep it fun! > > > > Dan Harris :-) > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

116. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 01:28:22 -0000

Yes that's right, perhaps I should have made that clearer. but I was including the cross also. I like your ideas about the "exercises", I shall include them for each section, especially the early ones. * I love (r' R U' R' F R U R' r), thanks a lot :-) Yes, that's a cool algorithm, I only use it for the final pair however because it doesn't give you a very good view of the pieces while you are solving it. If the UL and UR edges are up, then that algorithm (or it's equivalent into the FR slot) will orient all the edges. * 3. Solve from all angles --------------------- You say "you must imagine the movement which your hands have to do". I did have trouble putting it into words! It's probably not the best description, maybe I will find something better tomorrow. * Well, maybe I just think so because I didn't learn the F2L algs without understanding them. That's very true. I can see how this wouldn't be relevant for someone who learnt the algorithms like you, but for some poor cuber like me who just blindly learnt the F2L algs from Peter Jansen it's definitely the way to go :-) F' U F is pretty awkward I know, but I was just trying to demonstrate the point. In practice I would probably rotate slightly one way or the other, and do it like that with cramped hands ;) There's always tomorrow, I'm glad you liked them :D Dan :-) _____ From: Stefan Pochmann [mailto:pochmann@...] Sent: 07 January 2005 01:05 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L Thanks. 117. [Speed cubing group] Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 02:24:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > F' U F is pretty awkward I know, but I was just trying to demonstrate the > point. In practice I would probably rotate slightly one way or the other, > and do it like that with cramped hands ;) Hi Dan, thanks for your answers, but this one still keeps me wondering. Do you do it as (F' U F) or rotate 90 degrees (what do you mean with "slightly"?) and then do it with L or R? I'm serious about this, I've been wondering whether people do this or not even before your new articles. It's horrible to do, but I don't need to rotate the cube (which takes time and may be bad because all pieces/slots move around with it) so maybe it's really an advantage? Cheers! Stefan

I would turn the cube as I place it. Turning the cube is alright, if it helps you to look ahead. I can't vouch personally for that, but I have read it from a few different places including tips. 120. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 09:52:32 -0000

Hey Stefan You know, it really depends on what moves come before something like F' U F. If the move was say R F' U F, you wouldn't need to rotate at all, it is quite natural to make R and then push F' with your thumb, and then follow your thumb round and push U with your thumb again, and finally push F back down with your right index finger. If the move was R' F U'. it's easy to do also. The same applies for L F'. and L' F. If I had to begin a trick with an F move though, most likely I would rotate the cube very slightly, change grip to holding the B side (which is pointing NE as you look at it) with my right hand, and perform the F moves with my left hand. The advantage with this is the view of the cube doesn't change. Although you have had to change grip, you would have to do this anyway if you were to rotate and perform it on R or on L, and you have the small advantage of keeping the same view. Dan :-) _____ From: Stefan Pochmann [mailto:pochmann@...] Sent: 07 January 2005 02:25 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Advanced tricks for the F2L --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > F' U F is pretty awkward I know, but I was just trying to demonstrate the > point. In practice I would probably rotate slightly one way or the other, > and do it like that with cramped hands ;) Hi Dan, thanks for your answers, but this one still keeps me wondering. Do you do it as (F' U F) or rotate 90 degrees (what do you mean with "slightly"?) and then do it with L or R? I'm serious about this, I've been wondering whether people do this or not even before your new articles. It's horrible to do, but I don't need to rotate the cube (which takes time and may be bad because all pieces/slots move around with it) so maybe it's really an advantage? Cheers! Stefan _____ Yahoo! Groups Links * To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri be> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

122. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 12:56:39 -0000

Hey! I haven't really been follwing this thread ;-) Has it been proven that this recurrence relation will end up with a scramble actually passing through all possible cube-states? It seems not trivial to prove that ... Or hmm ... just came to think of something. A(0) is even. A(1) is even. 64 quarterturns. And likewise every A(n), n>1 will also be even. So it seems half the states ... Ha, i'm stupid. It's not the ENDSTATE of each A(i) we are interested in. We will certainly pass through just as many odd states on our way towards the end of each A(i). OK, so the problem still remains ... Happy cubing (just don't cube the A(i)'s ... lol) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Even better: > > > > A(0) = empty > > A(n+1) = (((F A(n))4 x)4 y)4 > > Devil = A(29) > > > > Hehe... > > Stefan > > Oh, I like that. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, nascarjon2001 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > It seems that they have changed the DIY kits slightly since I > purchased mine. Appears that the screws are different now and my > corners were complete, no caps for them. I also had trouble with > the center caps and had to adjust them with an exacto knife to make > them work. As far as the sticker issue goes... There are two kits > available from rubiks.com: "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube" for > $8.99, and "Rubik's 3x3 Assembly Cube w/Lube&Stickers" for $10.99. > The more expesive set comes with two sets of PVC stickers I ordered some last month, and stickers are not PVC ones. It's still the same old shit with a transparent film and a kind of colored paper under! (thin PVC stickers are no better - too thin, too dark) (I don't know you, but before the cube the only problem I had in my life with stickers was to remove them) > and it > doesn't say, but I assume that the cheaper one comes with the paper > stickers. Maybe > I'll try > > > > to > > > > > do it your way when I have more time :). > > > > > > > > > > Bye bye now, > > > > > > > > > > Joel. > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > > > > > > > I also recieved my DIY cube-kit from Rubiks.com a few days > ago. > > > > My > > > > > > core/axel was in white plastic. I didn't have any problems > with > > > > > the > > > > > > screw. They fit quite nicely into the core at the correct > > > > > friction, > > > > > > so they won't unscrew themselves easily. > > > > > > > > > > > > My only gripe with those DIY kits is that it is > troublesome to > > > > fit > > > > > > the centercaps. 124. Is there a 2-generator scrambler generator?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 13:48:21 -0000


Hey everyone,

Does a two generator scramble generator exist? I know I could just
use a normal 3x3x3 scramble generator, start on R say, and use the
turn sign of each move in the given alg and alternate faces U,R,U,R
etc., but I think it would be cool if there was one that generated a
scramble with just U's and R's. I'd try to write one but my
programming knowledge is dismal.

I guess it would also have to be length 25 or greater (I think I
remember someone saying recently that the max depth of 2-gen was 25
moves).

Anyway I just thought I would ask since there are some very good
programmers among this group ;-) It doesn't have to have any nice
graphics or display, just as long as it can generate a bunch of 2-
gen algs that would be totally cool. (hint hint, help!!) ;-)

Thanks,
Chris

126. Re: Is there a 2-generator scrambler generator?
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 14:12:26 -0000



--- cmhardw wrote:
> Does a two generator scramble generator exist?

I don't know of any. As a stopgap you could use my applet:
http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubie.htm

Choose the two-generator option, and click the 'solution' button at
the bottom left to change it to 'generator'.

Now press mix, and press solve.

This will give a completely fair mix (all 2gen positions equally
likely), but the generator will be optimal.

Jaap





127. Re: devil's algorithm
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 14:20:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > I haven't really been follwing this thread ;-) Has it been proven > that this recurrence relation will end up with a scramble actually > passing through all possible cube-states? Yes, it is simply a depth-first search, 29 turns deep, to be performed by hand (see my first post in this thread). 29 is the current upper bound on the length of God's algorithm, so will improve with time -- not that that matters particularly! I guess, though, that that silly construction shows that the devil's algorithm is not so very interesting, unless you impose some additional constraint such as trying to minimize the number of turns, or making it look as simple as possible :) Mike

> quite natural to make R and then push F' with your thumb, and then
follow

F back

> If I had to begin a trick with an F move though, most likely I would
rotate

pointing
> NE as you look at it) with my right hand, and perform the F moves
with my
> left hand.

Wow, now that you say it it looks so obvious. Can you believe I never
even thought about turning the F's with my left hand? I only thought
about doing them with my right hand (by rotating the cube slightly in
the other direction and regripping with left hand) and of course also
do the U with the right hand. If I do it your way it feels so much
better!!!

Stefan

135. Re: DIY kits
From: "Josef Jelinek" <gloom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 19:06:26 -0000


Hi,

I have completed two DIY kits recently, seen various
versions and gained some experience to share...

1. Stickers you can obtain can be of two different kinds
- thin colored plastic ones (dull orange and yellow
after applying to a cube).. relatively durable..
I have a cube for about 2 years with these stickers
and they are still ok (but glue went too soft
and stickers move around a bit)
- stickers covered by a thin transparent film.
they are similar to paper stickers, but actually
are even worse, because they are plastic, but just
painted white plastic... the painted color is
easy to remove after the transparent film is gone..
and the film is even easier to remove from painted
plastic than from paper...
it takes few weeks to destroy them ... so if you
want to use the cube more, try another alternative...
(it is quite difficult to get rid of the glue if
you remove the stickers...)
The really bad thing is that rubiks.com can claim
that the stickers are made of plastic, because they are...

2. Center caps are really bad. You often have to adjust them
in order to use them...
I played with them a little and now they hold well even
without glue. The first thing is to shorten that two juts
(may be longer than the center depth!!) by a half or so...
Remove also part of their support heels (often hit the ring
in the center!!). Now try to put the cap on the center and
incrementally sand the inner touching parts of the cap until
it creates not too big tension...
The last step I had to do was to reduce the size of the caps
so as they are not bigger that the center piece...
(if they are bigger they can be popped by adjacent moving pieces)
I hope, these modifications will not be supposed illegal,
because they do not provide me with any real advantage and
only makes the cube possible to assemble...

3. You can obtain 2 types of screws.
The small head (older) and large head (newer) ones.
If you have kit with small-head screws, you also have
metal washers. These metal washers are missing if you
have screws with a bigger head...
What a surprise, the screw and its head-ring may be
non-concentric, but it should not be a big problem and
IMHO affects only the cube life-time a little..
The smaller washers are plastic and quite easy to break,
so be careful if removing imperfections...
(Much better alternative would be metal 2mm washers with
an enlarged hole...)
The kit also contain rivets, but I see no point to use
them (buy a complete cube instead)..

Despite the necessary tuning of the center caps and bad
quality of the stickers provided, the cube have really
big advantages. It is very smooth from the beginning
and it can be adjusted to not pop pieces while beeing
very loose (it is nearly imposible to disassemble the
cube by removing an edge then!).
The disadvantage could be a different feeling compared to
flat-center cube and that the cube locks more when not
well alligned (but is not really a big problem compared to
springless cubes).

Just my two cents (why two?).

Josef





136. cube pictures
From: "John Bender" <johnbender91@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 19:34:10 -0000

http://f4.aaa.livedoor.jp/~shozy/files/tetris/rubik's_cube.jpg
The cheapest way to get a DIY 3x3...

John






137. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: DIY kits
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 14:53:33 -0500

I'll add two more cents :)

The vinyl on my Rubik's Studio cubes is very
thin and isn't all that durable so those stickers
get chewed up pretty easily.

There's no reason why the manufacturers or modders
couldn't use a thicker vinyl. They still make vinyl for
road signs and it's pretty tough.

These DIY cubes sound like they are an improvement
but not perfect. I can't even remember how the centre
lids worked on the original Ideal Toy cubes but I seem
to recall drilling little holes in the lids so I could
get at the screws underneath.

In fact I recently drilled out the centres on one of my
Rubik's Game/Challenge cubes. My efforts on removing
lids on the Game were so horrific I'm not even going to
try it on the Deluxe cube.

I'm curious though, is there any way to know by the
box if a new cube has the arched centre pieces?
The lids of future cubes could have some sort of
snap-on technology with a LCD move counter built
into the white centre. Of course the plastic would
be some space-age super frictionless type. And
on future Deluxes picky cubists can easily remove
coloured plastic tiles so white is opposite yellow
or white is opposite blue.

Easily available replacement parts like spindles
would be nice. When the spindles go it's game
over.

Ok I'm done.

Mark




On January 7, 2005 02:06 pm, Josef Jelinek wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I have completed two DIY kits recently, seen various
> versions and gained some experience to share...
>
> 1. Stickers you can obtain can be of two different kinds
> - thin colored plastic ones (dull orange and yellow
> after applying to a cube).. relatively durable..
> I have a cube for about 2 years with these stickers
> and they are still ok (but glue went too soft
> and stickers move around a bit)
> - stickers covered by a thin transparent film.
> they are similar to paper stickers, but actually
> are even worse, because they are plastic, but just
> painted white plastic... the painted color is
> easy to remove after the transparent film is gone..
> and the film is even easier to remove from painted
> plastic than from paper...
> it takes few weeks to destroy them ... so if you
> want to use the cube more, try another alternative...
> (it is quite difficult to get rid of the glue if
> you remove the stickers...)
> The really bad thing is that rubiks.com can claim
> that the stickers are made of plastic, because they are...
>
> 2. Center caps are really bad. You often have to adjust them
> in order to use them...
> I played with them a little and now they hold well even
> without glue. The first thing is to shorten that two juts
> (may be longer than the center depth!!) by a half or so...
> Remove also part of their support heels (often hit the ring
> in the center!!). Now try to put the cap on the center and
> incrementally sand the inner touching parts of the cap until
> it creates not too big tension...
> The last step I had to do was to reduce the size of the caps
> so as they are not bigger that the center piece...
> (if they are bigger they can be popped by adjacent moving pieces)
> I hope, these modifications will not be supposed illegal,
> because they do not provide me with any real advantage and
> only makes the cube possible to assemble...
>
> 3. You can obtain 2 types of screws.
> The small head (older) and large head (newer) ones.
> If you have kit with small-head screws, you also have
> metal washers. These metal washers are missing if you
> have screws with a bigger head...
> What a surprise, the screw and its head-ring may be
> non-concentric, but it should not be a big problem and
> IMHO affects only the cube life-time a little..
> The smaller washers are plastic and quite easy to break,
> so be careful if removing imperfections...
> (Much better alternative would be metal 2mm washers with
> an enlarged hole...)
> The kit also contain rivets, but I see no point to use
> them (buy a complete cube instead)..
>
> Despite the necessary tuning of the center caps and bad
> quality of the stickers provided, the cube have really
> big advantages. It is very smooth from the beginning
> and it can be adjusted to not pop pieces while beeing
> very loose (it is nearly imposible to disassemble the
> cube by removing an edge then!).
> The disadvantage could be a different feeling compared to
> flat-center cube and that the cube locks more when not
> well alligned (but is not really a big problem compared to
> springless cubes).
>
> Just my two cents (why two?).
>
> Josef


138. SpeedStacks timer 2nd generation review
From: "Josef Jelinek" <gloom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 19:58:11 -0000


Hi all,

I have obtained the 2nd generation speedstacks timer with
minipad. So there may be some people interested in info here.

This combination is cheaper than the original timer and much
easier to transport, because timer is now separable from a
pad. Pictures are on http://speedstacks.com.
I will focus on issues important for cubers.

Since the timer is not part of pad, and buttons, LEDs, and
the LCD display is between two hand sensors, it is thicker.
The highest part is about 1.3cm above the pad, the sensors
are about 3-4mm above the pad (they are slanted toward the pad).
This is not a problem for cubing, however, for Rubik's magic
it can be a problem, because magic can hit the timer
and and/or be in illegal position when stopping the
timer (verified...).

The sensors probbably use the same technology as notebook's
touchpad, because they do not register pressure, but the
area of touching hands (so hard pressing of two fingers
does not work, light touch of palms does). This means
that they do not contain mechanical parts and are really
sensitive. This can increase durability (I hope so)
To avoid unwanted stopping of the timer,
the timer ignores the first 0.32s, so it cannot be used
to time anything shorter than 0.32s...

The timer can be split horizontally to two parts:
the top part contains all functionality, the bottom
part is used to attach a pad...
The top part contains two strong magnets to attach
the bottom part (the bottom part contains two steel
pieces). These magnets can be used to attach the timer
to ferromagnetic materials as an iron desk etc...

The timer uses one 3V thin battery and has a display port.
The tournament display port is not on a side as I would
expected, but in the middle, facing to a user (?).
It automatically tuns off after 5 minutes if stopped, and
10 minutes if running. The last time remains on the timer
even after turning off until the reset is pressed.
There are only "reset" and "power" buttons on it.
There are 2 LEDs (green, red) on the timer and they are
both flashing fast when the timer is running, which
can be disturbing, because they are between the sensors...
(But personally, I do not have any problem with this)...

I really like this version of timer. For home usage,
it is much better than the original timer.
You really can use only the top part of timer without
the pad if necessary...
However, in competitions, the original timer would be
still more appropriate (because of sensors in a pad and
separated controls to be used by judges(!))...

I hope, somebody will find this text useful.

Josef






139. Re: devil's algorithm
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 20:06:32 -0000


Hello all,

Here's some of my thinking on the Devil's algorithm.

Since the diametre of the Rubik's cube group is 29 moves, then we
can get from a position to any other position in at most 29 moves.
There are 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 distinct positions so a Devil's
algorithm based on this idea would be at most 29*
(43,252,003,274,489,856,000-1)+1 moves long. It would be constructed
by indexing in some way the positíons on the cube and then using the
optimum way to get from one position to the next one, from the first
to the last position.

Now we have to think of a smart way to index the positions so that
the distance between one position and the next is the smallest
possible, that is (hopefully) 1 move.

I haven't yet found such an indexing (not that i have thought too
much on it), but I think it's quite easy to find one. I guess that
there already exist such indexes based on computer solving, you
surely know better.

The bad side of this algorithm is that it's not easy at all to write
it down, if it is possible.

Good luck in optimising!
Sebastian

From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>

141. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 20:24:57 -0000

Oh Dan... what shall we do with you... ;-) Don't you remember that any algorithm applied over and over again will be the identity after at most 1260 times? That is, an alg with 50 moves can produce at most 1260*50 different states. That's also why I immediately divided the 4*10^19 by 1260 in my computations... Cheers! Stefan P.S. Sebastian, how come you know the diameter is 29? I thought it's proven to be *at most* 29. Wait, weren't you also the one who once claimed there are people using full ZB already (or was it full 1-look LL?)? 143. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: DIY kits
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 15:39:27 -0500

I'll add two more cents :)

The vinyl on my Rubik's Studio cubes is very
thin and isn't all that durable so those stickers
get chewed up pretty easily.

There's no reason why the manufacturers or modders
couldn't use a thicker vinyl. They still make vinyl for
road signs and it's pretty tough.

These DIY cubes sound like they are an improvement
but not perfect. I can't even remember how the centre
lids worked on the original Ideal Toy cubes but I seem
to recall drilling little holes in the lids so I could
get at the screws underneath.

In fact I recently drilled out the centres on one of my
Rubik's Game/Challenge cubes. My efforts on removing
lids on the Game were so horrific I'm not even going to
try it on the Deluxe cube.

I'm curious though, is there any way to know by the
box if a new cube has the arched centre pieces?
The lids of future cubes could have some sort of
snap-on technology with a LCD move counter built
into the white centre. Of course the plastic would
be some space-age super frictionless type. And
on future Deluxes picky cubists can easily remove
coloured plastic tiles so white is opposite yellow
or white is opposite blue.

Easily available replacement parts like spindles
would be nice. When the spindles go it's game
over.

Ok I'm done.

Mark

On January 7, 2005 02:06 pm, Josef Jelinek wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I have completed two DIY kits recently, seen various
> versions and gained some experience to share...
>
> 1. Stickers you can obtain can be of two different kinds
> - thin colored plastic ones (dull orange and yellow
> after applying to a cube).. relatively durable..
> I have a cube for about 2 years with these stickers
> and they are still ok (but glue went too soft
> and stickers move around a bit)
> - stickers covered by a thin transparent film.
> they are similar to paper stickers, but actually
> are even worse, because they are plastic, but just
> painted white plastic... the painted color is
> easy to remove after the transparent film is gone..
> and the film is even easier to remove from painted
> plastic than from paper...
> it takes few weeks to destroy them ... so if you
> want to use the cube more, try another alternative...
> (it is quite difficult to get rid of the glue if
> you remove the stickers...)
> The really bad thing is that rubiks.com can claim
> that the stickers are made of plastic, because they are...
>
> 2. Center caps are really bad. You often have to adjust them
> in order to use them...
> I played with them a little and now they hold well even
> without glue. The first thing is to shorten that two juts
> (may be longer than the center depth!!) by a half or so...
> Remove also part of their support heels (often hit the ring
> in the center!!). Now try to put the cap on the center and
> incrementally sand the inner touching parts of the cap until
> it creates not too big tension...
> The last step I had to do was to reduce the size of the caps
> so as they are not bigger that the center piece...
> (if they are bigger they can be popped by adjacent moving pieces)
> I hope, these modifications will not be supposed illegal,
> because they do not provide me with any real advantage and
> only makes the cube possible to assemble...
>
> 3. You can obtain 2 types of screws.
> The small head (older) and large head (newer) ones.
> If you have kit with small-head screws, you also have
> metal washers. These metal washers are missing if you
> have screws with a bigger head...
> What a surprise, the screw and its head-ring may be
> non-concentric, but it should not be a big problem and
> IMHO affects only the cube life-time a little..
> The smaller washers are plastic and quite easy to break,
> so be careful if removing imperfections...
> (Much better alternative would be metal 2mm washers with
> an enlarged hole...)
> The kit also contain rivets, but I see no point to use
> them (buy a complete cube instead)..
>
> Despite the necessary tuning of the center caps and bad
> quality of the stickers provided, the cube have really
> big advantages. It is very smooth from the beginning
> and it can be adjusted to not pop pieces while beeing
> very loose (it is nearly imposible to disassemble the
> cube by removing an edge then!).
> The disadvantage could be a different feeling compared to
> flat-center cube and that the cube locks more when not
> well alligned (but is not really a big problem compared to
> springless cubes).
>
> Just my two cents (why two?).
>
> Josef


144. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 20:49:22 -0000


> P.S. Sebastian, how come you know the diameter is 29? I thought
it's
> proven to be *at most* 29.

Well that's what I meant, at most 29. I just read it from a message
on this topic (Mike said that I think). First i thought it's much
smaller, something like 20 moves.

Wait, weren't you also the one who once
> claimed there are people using full ZB already (or was it full 1-
look
> LL?)? Hehe.. ;-)

I didn't claim such a horrible thing. I myself use about 20
algorithms, the fact is that using the Petrus method orients edges
before getting to LL, and I also permute corners (since the two-
generator conservs the corner permutation as well as the edges
orientation) so that it's quite easy to do the LL, or what's left of
it, in only one step. More details on my web page

http://www.geocities.com/portoseb/cube/

Sebastian





145. Playin' mind games
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 21:17:19 -0000


I just came across this website recently, and thought this might be
the type of site that many of you would also enjoy. It has a variety
of brain teasers, including an old favorite of mine... logic-grid
puzzles! Come solve some Math, Logic, Rebus, or Riddle teasers.
It's free to play, and if you register (free as well), you can
eventually post your own teasers, once you've earned enough points.

Enjoy!

- Grant

147. My new homepage

Hi,

as some of you might have noticed my webpage has been unavailable for
quite some time. I'm now in the process of building a new one at

http://www.cubezone.be/

This website is going to focus more on speedcubing methods and
techniques as opposed to my old pages which mainly contained photo
albums and video clips. At the moment everything is still pretty
basic, but I already added my customized PLL algorithms since a lot of
people have been asking me about them.

There will be more to follow!

Cheers,
LarsV

149. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jan 2005 01:39:41 -0000

Hi Sebastian, Is the devil's algorithm one long algorithm which is applied once and hits everything, and never repeats movements (not positions), or is it one which takes two or more cycles to reach that goal? I wonder if it could be one, for example, which starts and ends with red facing you and white up, and then you rotate the cube, and do it again, eventually though 24 applications. If the devils alg is one which is allowed to be applied more than once to reach all the positions then: Of the 43 quintillion possible positions only a small percentage are at the maximum distance away from the solved state. There are probably a great number of positions which are halfway to the maximum distance. Couldn't you have an algorithm which is only half as long as God's algorithm? Applied twice it could reach one of the furthest-away-from-solved positions. There are 18 positions which are one move away (within the half turn metric) not only from the solved position, but from every other position. For another question in this thread: If "a penny for your thoughts" invites you to speak your mind, perhaps it takes your "two cents" to be allowed to enter into an ongoing conversation. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hello all, > > Here's some of my thinking on the Devil's algorithm. > > Since the diametre of the Rubik's cube group is 29 moves, then we > can get from a position to any other position in at most 29 moves. > There are 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 distinct positions so a Devil's > algorithm based on this idea would be at most 29* > (43,252,003,274,489,856,000-1)+1 moves long. It would be constructed > by indexing in some way the positíons on the cube and then using the > optimum way to get from one position to the next one, from the first > to the last position. > > Now we have to think of a smart way to index the positions so that > the distance between one position and the next is the smallest > possible, that is (hopefully) 1 move. > > I haven't yet found such an indexing (not that i have thought too > much on it), but I think it's quite easy to find one. I guess that > there already exist such indexes based on computer solving, you > surely know better. > > The bad side of this algorithm is that it's not easy at all to write > it down, if it is possible. > > Good luck in optimising! > Sebastian
150. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jan 2005 01:52:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > Well that's what I meant, at most 29. I just read it from a message > on this topic (Mike said that I think). First i thought it's much > smaller, something like 20 moves. Btw, how about using a similar construction as yours but shorter... my first idea would be to define a bijection between even and odd states (permutation I mean), for example the "partner" of an even state is the odd state you get by doing a U turn. Now we could just walk over all even states and at each even state interrupt the walk with (U U'). That is, we get all the odd states almost for free (guaranteed 2 moves instead of up to 29). That's a factor of almost 2 that we save (29+2 instead of 29*2). The next idea is to walk over a certain subset of states using your way and at each state, interrupt the walk with (U4 D4 L4 R4 F4 B4), i.e. visiting all 18 "neighbours" almost for free... > Wait, weren't you also the one who once > > claimed there are people using full ZB already (or was it full 1- > look > > LL?)? Hehe.. ;-) > > I didn't claim such a horrible thing. You're right, sorry. It was another user whose name starts with 'p': http://games.groups.yahoo. com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/11682 (and the claim was that some people are learning all 1211 LL algs) Cheers! Stefan
151. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jan 2005 10:16:13 -0000


>interrupt the walk with (U U').

Maybe we could interrupt it with U U, or F F, or any other face, and
this gives me another idea. Say that we take a state, preferably an
even state, preferably the solved position. Then we go to all
positions that can be reached inside the U2 D2 R2 L2 F2 B2 group,
meanwhile reaching the same number of odd positions. I just realized
now that those odd states are not part of the same half-move group,
so most probable is that we throw them away. But then, using this
algorithm, we are sure to take care of every even position, so there
might be a bijection betwen a set of even states inside the same
half-move group and another set of odd states.

I'll try to find a Devil's algorithm for the half move group. It
should be quite easy.

Sebastian





152. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jan 2005 21:28:22 -0000

Hmm, yeah, that should work, too. Reminds me of Thistlethwaite's algorithm I once coded for a cube programming contest. It solves the cube in four steps, the last one being that half-turn group. There's a nice description on Jaap's page but it still seems to be down right now :-( Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > >interrupt the walk with (U U'). > > Maybe we could interrupt it with U U, or F F, or any other face, and > this gives me another idea. Say that we take a state, preferably an > even state, preferably the solved position. Then we go to all > positions that can be reached inside the U2 D2 R2 L2 F2 B2 group, > meanwhile reaching the same number of odd positions. I just realized > now that those odd states are not part of the same half-move group, > so most probable is that we throw them away. But then, using this > algorithm, we are sure to take care of every even position, so there > might be a bijection betwen a set of even states inside the same > half-move group and another set of odd states. > > I'll try to find a Devil's algorithm for the half move group. It > should be quite easy. > > Sebastian
153. No Subject
From: andrew barnhart <abarnhart2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 22:41:57 -0800 (PST)

Hey everyone-

I've been in this group for a while, but haven't
anything to write about, until now. This may be kind
of unrelated, but i can't think of anyone else to ask.


Does anyone know where i can find a new square-1?
I've tried ebay, but they end up being really
expensive. A lot of sites refer you to mefferts to
buy them, but i can't find them there, i think they
may have stopped selling them.

I also am interesetd in getting a megaminx. Mefferts
carries tiled ones, but i am kind of picky, and am
not a fan of tiled cubes.

Any help would be appreciated.

156. Re: no subject (Square-1)

Date: Sun, 09 Jan 2005 11:50:55 -0000

Hi! I was just checking. It seems that www.puzzle-shop.de has the square- 1 in stock right now, so u are lucky. They sell it under the name Cube-21. Unfortunately they don't seem to have the Megaminx. And i seem to recall other posts in the past that the megaminx is hard to find now, particularly the 12-color ones. Hope this helps somewhat:-) If u do purchase from puzzle-shop.de u will probably have to pay using PayPal. 157. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 9 Jan 2005 14:31:55 -0400

Link Dead in your reply. What are L1L2 strategies Thanks Dwayne ----- Original Message ----- From: Duncan Dicks To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Tuesday, January 04, 2005 12:25 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction Hi Dwayne, Simple shortcut methods that cut down the number of algorithms you need for OLL and especially cna be found on http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle. Even the simple L2L1 strategy cuts down the moves dramatically. As well as making the number of moves to memorise much smaller it also means that you cnas recognise the positions much more quickly. Its as few moves as Fridrich but just much easier! If you've already learned a lot of Fridrich then its even easier to switch. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, January 04, 2005 12:35 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Introduction > > > > Welcome Dwayne, > > It's always nice to see new cube adepts. > But sadly, everybody has only 1 idea in mind: Learn Fridrich's method, > and become a clone of the top speedcubers. Same sequences, same > fingertricks. > I'm *certain* it's possible to solve the cube in 15s with > significantly different systems. > Please, don't become a clone, there are already tons of them ;-) > > Gilles > http://grrroux.free.fr > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I've been on & off since the release of the cube, but only lately > have I taken it more studiously. I don't consider myself a speedcuber > yet. Although I've been in the process of learning the Fridrich Method > (It seems to be the method of champions). > > I've memorized all the algs for the F2L and have recently started > learning PLL algs. I used to average about 1:00 with my old method. I > seem to be slowly reducing my times. Now I average around 55s with a > hybrid Fridrich/Jasmine method. > > My question is how long should it normally take to memorize the > Fridrich Method algs, and fully implement the Fridrich Method? > > > > My current goal would be to reduce my average to about 30s and > maybe better. I know, I need to learn finger trick after the Fridrich > Method. Any other advice, tricks or exercises would be greatly > appreciated. > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. 159. Recruiting more cubers
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 09 Jan 2005 22:18:37 -0000


I have been fairly successful in getting several people into cubing
since moving here (London) a few weeks ago. There are two people
who've solved it once or twice (with my beginner's guide:
http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html) and
three more who have expressed interest.

Once one or two people give it a go, it's easier to get others
interested. They see the first person making progress and then
realise that it isn't that difficult. I told them that being able to
solve the cube in a few minutes is easy to learn. It only gets
difficult when learning to solve it really quickly! :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

163. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 14:17:16 -0600

i recently taught my girfriend how to cube and she's now officially an addict. it took about 2 hours total to teach her a fridrich type system with a simple 4 look LL. she got her own cube (it's one of the weird ones with the 25 years logo) and we sanded and lubed it yesterday. she was averaging under two minutes before that, but hasn't had time to practice since. i'm working on convincing my little brother to learn, but i've only converted my gal to the light side, thus far. happy cubing and may the force be with you. -mike bennett >From: "lkyawkyaw" <lkyawkyaw@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers >Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 18:19:45 -0000 > > >sweet, more cubers on the way. heh > >i also got like 7 ppl into cubing, but only about 4 of them have >actually learnt solving the whole thing, the rest are reluctant to >learn the LL because they believe its too hard,they just do the f2l >lol. but im hoping that this coming spring when my cube club starts >on campus i can get more ppl into it. wish me luck :p > >john lwin > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "joel_vn" ><joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > Yeah, I also got one of my class-mates into cubing... 165. Rubik's Magic
From: "Jim" <psyrules444@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 04:41:37 -0000


My Rubik's magic came today. Using online instruction, i managed to solve it.
However while i was solving it, i think the chords got all tightened or
something because now it isn't exactly flat. The squares are all messed up.
They aren't in a straight line any more. They're all crooked. Is this normal?
How do i fix it?

Oh and wuts it supposed to look like when its solved? is only one side
supposed to be done?

Thx.

`Jim





166. RE: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Magic
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 09:41:09 -0000

Hi Jim, Matthew Burns showed me this trick, and from what I know he either was showed it by Jaap Scherphuis or discovered it independently. My magic gets into these positions all the time ;) Fold it long ways, and open it up so it forms a ring, one square wide and eight squares long. Then put both arms a little way inside the ring, and roll it around your wrists, very much like a boxer hitting a punchbag a million times, and do it quite tight so the pieces stretch apart from each other (but only a little way!). When you open your magic back out, it should be nice and flat again :-) Dan :-) _____ From: Jim [mailto:psyrules444@...] Sent: 11 January 2005 04:42 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Magic My Rubik's magic came today. Using online instruction, i managed to solve it. However while i was solving it, i think the chords got all tightened or something because now it isn't exactly flat. The squares are all messed up. They aren't in a straight line any more. They're all crooked. Is this normal? How do i fix it? Oh and wuts it supposed to look like when its solved? is only one side supposed to be done? Thx. `Jim _____ Yahoo! Groups Links * To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri be> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Well Grant, you've officially got me hooked on this site. I have been on it at work for the past 2 days, doing all of the logic grid puzzles and quite a few other assorted puzzles. 170. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Magic
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 14:57:08 -0400

And to answer your other question, it has two solved positions 1. A 2x4 showing three unconnected ring on one side (the one with the Rubik's Magic Logo) 2. A Heart Shape (2x3x3 turned Diagonally) showing three connected rings To get from 1 to 2 or vice-versa, you must perform a small algorithm. ----- Original Message ----- From: Daniel Harris To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Tuesday, January 11, 2005 5:41 AM Subject: RE: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Magic Hi Jim, Matthew Burns showed me this trick, and from what I know he either was showed it by Jaap Scherphuis or discovered it independently. My magic gets into these positions all the time ;) Fold it long ways, and open it up so it forms a ring, one square wide and eight squares long. Then put both arms a little way inside the ring, and roll it around your wrists, very much like a boxer hitting a punchbag a million times, and do it quite tight so the pieces stretch apart from each other (but only a little way!). When you open your magic back out, it should be nice and flat again :-) Dan :-) _____ From: Jim [mailto:psyrules444@...] Sent: 11 January 2005 04:42 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Magic My Rubik's magic came today. Using online instruction, i managed to solve it. However while i was solving it, i think the chords got all tightened or something because now it isn't exactly flat. The squares are all messed up. They aren't in a straight line any more. They're all crooked. Is this normal? How do i fix it? Oh and wuts it supposed to look like when its solved? is only one side supposed to be done? Thx. `Jim _____ Yahoo! 172. Re: New updates to CubeZone
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 20:40:44 -0000

Hmm... Don't you just mean CLL? :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > Hi, > > I'm glad to see some positive response on my PLL page here and there ; > -). I've also published my speed optimized OLL and COLL algorithms, > all to be found at: > > http://www.cubezone.be/ > > Enjoy! > > LarsV
173. Re: New updates to CubeZone
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 21:08:00 -0000

No, not quite. The algorithms I published solve the corners and also leave the orientation of the edges unaffected. So provided the edges are already oriented, these algorithms solve the corners _and_ orient the last layer in one go, which is way they are called COLL (Corners and Orientation Last Layer). I know that the pages on my website don't offer a lot of explanation just yet, but I'll try to change that in the future so that everyone should be able to fully understand what everything means even if you're not an expert already. LarsV --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "joel_vn" <joel_vn@y... > wrote: > > Hmm... Don't you just mean CLL? :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars Vandenbergh" > <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > > > Hi, > > > > I'm glad to see some positive response on my PLL page here and > there ; > > -). I've also published my speed optimized OLL and COLL > algorithms, > > all to be found at: > > > > http://www.cubezone.be/ > > > > Enjoy! > > > > LarsV
174. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 21:17:58 -0000

I've been thinking about this again. Actually, teaching noncubers how to solve the cube is a SIN at least as bad as peeling the stickers off for solving. Well, maybe it's just me. But I regret a lot that I learned a solution from a book when I was a little kid. I'd like to know whether I would've been able to find a solution myself. But I'll never know. Teaching someone a solution takes that chance from him/her and it's mean. A friend of mine saw me speedcubing a few months ago and decided to try it, too. He refused to look at any solutions and specifically asked me not to help him in any way, a request I very happily satisfied. He did find a solution (of course!) and it's much much cooler than learning it from someone else. But yeah, maybe that's just me (and that friend of mine)... Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I have been fairly successful in getting several people into cubing > since moving here (London) a few weeks ago. There are two people > who've solved it once or twice (with my beginner's guide: > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html) and > three more who have expressed interest.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > And to answer your other question, it has two solved positions > > 1. My magic gets > into these positions all the time ;) > > > > Fold it long ways, and open it up so it forms a ring, one square wide and > eight squares long. 177. 3x3x3 Blindfolded
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 23:33:56 -0400

Approximately how many in the world is believed to be able to solve the 3x3x3 blindfolded?

Dwayne

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



178. Re: 3x3x3 Blindfolded
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 04:14:01 -0000

I would say an extremely lower bound might be 100 people. I base this off of the 95 people in the blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube Yahoo group. Since probably not all (but most) of them can solve it blind folded, coupled with the fact that many people who CAN solve it blindfolded are likely not members of that group, I think 100 is a very low estimate. I would _guess_ that in the entire would the actual number is in the thousands. Having learned to do it myself, and realizing that it is not in fact as difficult as it sounds, I guess even that guess may be low. Hope that helps, Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Approximately how many in the world is believed to be able to solve the 3x3x3 blindfolded? > > Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

181. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:10:08 -0000

Hi Tyson, Commendably clear. I don't think you have fully specified x, y and z in that you dont specify the direction of the turn (e.g. moves with L or R in the case of x). A very minor point over the squared moves too - you don't really need to specify counter-clockwise! Hope thats helpful Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>; <caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, January 12, 2005 9:18 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge > > Will someone please proofread this for me? > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/Notation%20Standards.doc > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > Yahoo! 182. Re: Square-1
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:14:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mcmeatball" <smudge5546@a...> wrote: > > Does anyone have a good solution for the Square-1? If you don't want to solve a puzzle yourself, Jaap's site is always a good place to start: www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/ His page on square-1 is particularly thorough, with descriptions of several different solution strategies and programs for generating your own sequences... he also has links to other solution pages. Have fun Mike
