186. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:38:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've been thinking about this again. Actually, teaching noncubers how > to solve the cube is a SIN at least as bad as peeling the stickers off > for solving. Oh, I don't know about that. The 3x3x3 is rather a difficult puzzle to start on, and, left to themselves, many people would give up through frustration. If showing someone a solution keeps them interested, they can always go and solve another puzzle themselves :) Also, some people will be attracted by the sporting element alone -- and why not? So far I have taught only one person to solve the cube. It took a long time (much longer than the 2 hours mentioned in an earlier post), but the aim was to get some general principles across, so that she could re-invent forgotten sequences if necessary. It seems to have worked in that case. Mike
187. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers - its a sin!
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:52:28 -0000

No, no its in the list: Seven Sins of speedcubers 1.. Taking a cube to bed with you 2.. Solving a cube when you should be working or studying 3.. Intolerance of those who can't solve the cube 4.. Frustration at the stupid things people say when they find out you can do the cube 5.. Deliberately popping during a slow solve 6.. Talking cube jargon to those who have no way of udnerstanding 7.. Teaching other people to solve the cube Anyone want to improve the list feel free. I am currently guilty of sin 2 (although not actually solving)! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "mike_go_uk" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, January 12, 2005 10:38 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > I've been thinking about this again. 188. Live News Interviews
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 03:41:41 -0800

it's 3:40 AM... I'm having a lot of trouble sleeping so I figure I
might as well tell everyone about this.

189. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 11:46:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Is it all right if I say, "x goes in the same direction as R." and U > for y and F for z? Would that be clear enough? It is far too late to change the conventions used by such a large community, but it would have been nice to use Rc, Uc, and Fc for the whole-cube moves, since that notation has some mnemonic content. Similarly Rm, Um and Fm for slice moves. Stefan has made these (or similar) suggestions recently, and the notations were used earlier in Leinweber's program Hungarian Hexahedron. Usually I keep out of notational disputes (so will try to keep fairly quiet from now on), but in this case a small but significant barrier to learning/understanding is being perpetuated. Moreover, I still can't remember the dashed conventions ;) Mike

191. Re: 3x3x3 Blindfolded
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 16:30:54 -0000

Do you mean able to solve it *right now* or in general? Cause it's so easy that every sane healthy human on this planet is able to learn how to do it, i.e. several billion people. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r... > wrote: > Approximately how many in the world is believed to be able to solve the 3x3x3 blindfolded? > > Dwayne
192. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 16:40:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Oh, I don't know about that. The 3x3x3 is rather a difficult puzzle > to start on, and, left to themselves, many people would give up > through frustration. Then they're unmotivated losers that need not be worried about. > If showing someone a solution keeps them > interested, they can always go and solve another puzzle themselves : ) It's not the same anymore. I've solved many many other puzzles myself but it's not the same. Of course I can not really be sure, because I can't compare it because I don't know how it feels to solve your first puzzle yourself (or maybe I started with the 15-puzzle and I'm sure I solved that one myself but then again that one is so easy it doesn't count). It's not the same. You know some principles from your first puzzle so every other puzzle you solve subsequently you do *not* solve fully yourself. I'm assuming the satisfaction to solve your first puzzle (and possibly all subsequent) yourself without help is much bigger. I had actually thought about teaching some non-cubers how to solve it. As an experiment to demonstrate it can be learned in less than one hour. I'm sure that's possible. But now I decided I will never do this because I won't do that to people. It's too mean. > Also, some people will be attracted by the sporting element alone -- > and why not? How do you (or they) know beforehand? I'm only sad about this issue *now*, long after I started solving. I wish I could forget everything and start on my own, but I can't. Plus, they can still learn tricks from others *after* they solved it themselves. That's what I do nowadays when I get a new puzzle. First I solve it myself (which is not completely true of course because I already know a lot of general tricks like even/odd permutations and commutators and how they're useful for solving puzzles) and then afterwards I try to become faster myself and then finally look what other people do. The 4x4 and 5x5 I found parity fixers myself and practised solving them until I was within 200% or the record times. Only then did I look at other people's algs. Stefan
193. [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers - its a sin!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 16:47:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Seven Sins of speedcubers > > 1.. Taking a cube to bed with you I think this is only a sin if you have a girl/boyfriend or similar. > 2.. Solving a cube when you should be working or studying Me guilty muchos grande. > 4.. Frustration at the stupid things people say when they find out you can > do the cube I'd say there must be a limit after which we're allowed to get frustrated. Cause some people get so unbelievably annoying. > 5.. Deliberately popping during a slow solve Delete "slow". Why should it be allowed in fast solves? And what's slow/fast? The "during a solve" should remain, cause it's ok to pop just to show someone the mechanism of the cube. > 6.. Talking cube jargon to those who have no way of udnerstanding It should be allowed after the same limit of #4 is reached. And you forgot: 8.. Peeling stickers off in order to solve unless the cube is unsolvable without. Cheers! Stefan
194. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Recruiting more cubers - its a sin!
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>

Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 09:04:37 -0800

/Lars

On Jan 12, 2005, at 2:52, Duncan Dicks wrote:

>
> No, no its in the list:
> Seven Sins of speedcubers
>
>
>
> 1.. Taking a cube to bed with you
> 2.. Solving a cube when you should be working or studying
> 3.. Intolerance of those who can't solve the cube
> 4.. Frustration at the stupid things people say when they find out
> you can
> do the cube
> 5.. Deliberately popping during a slow solve
> 6.. Talking cube jargon to those who have no way of udnerstanding
> 7.. Teaching other people to solve the cube
> Anyone want to improve the list feel free.
> I am currently guilty of sin 2 (although not actually solving)!
>
> Duncan



195. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:17:09 -0000


I think I'll throw in my two cents as well.

>>>Oh, I don't know about that. The 3x3x3 is rather a difficult
puzzle
>>> to start on, and, left to themselves, many people would give up
>>> through frustration.

> Then they're unmotivated losers that need not be worried about.

I do agree with Stefan, but I wouldn't call someone who tries and
gives up an unmotivated loser. I would just say they aren't
interested in the cube, and there's nothing wrong with that. If
they were interested in really solving the puzzle as a puzzle they
would try harder when they found it to be difficult.

I think we have to consider two groups of people, those who just
want to solve the puzzle of Rubik's cube as a puzzle, and those who
want to become speedcubers.

If someone just wants to learn how to solve it as a puzzle, then I
agree - teaching them defeats their whole purpose. If someone wants
to know how to solve it every time then I would call that person a
speedcuber, and that person would potentially want to work on an
advanced system after learning their first introductory solution.

The way I see it, solving the cube once or twice is a puzzle that
people should try to figure out on their own. Speedcubing is more
of an art. So for speedcubing someone can either teach you the
basics and you learn from there, or you can learn the basics
yourself and move on. I don't think it's bad to teach a potential
speedcuber how to cube, but to teach someone who just wants to solve
it once or twice to say they've done it, then yes I agree it is bad
to teach them.

Just my opinion of course,
Chris

Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:46:25 +0000 (GMT)

Hi stefan & members,

cheers,
john louis

197. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:51:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Will someone please proofread this for me? > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/Notation%20Standards.doc > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology Hi Tyson, In Wordpad the counterclockwise notation L' comes out Lí. Why add so many different letters when r, f, u, (and l, b, d) can be used to denote slices, and QR QU and QB can be used to denote rotations? I know some people already use the notation you printed out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axis, like for map making, with z added for the vertical axia. I don't know who came up with the notation you use, but except for FLUBRD it seems to deliberately defy convention and simplicity. Regards, David J
198. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:57:12 -0000

Hi Tyson, I think your notation is perfect. --> Why add so many different letters when r, f, u, (and l, b, d) can be used to denote slices, and QR QU and QB can be used to denote rotations? <-- r f u l b d are already defined tokens, they are the letters used for turns of two layers. --> I know some people already use the notation you printed out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. <-- They need to get used to it. --> I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axis, like for map making, with z added for the vertical axia. <-- Get used to it. I know some people already use the notation you printed out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axis, like for map making, with z added for the vertical axia. 199. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 18:03:26 -0000

Hi Stefan, In the early 1980s I realised that those who believed that they could solve the cube on their own solved it, and those who believed that they couldn't handle something that complicated failed. Since joining this group I have been an advocate of people solving it on their own the first time. I also encouraging people to develop their own algoritms, but I know that it's harder to do that. I wonder if there are other speedcubers here who use only their own algoritms. Anyone? Anyway, I'm pretty sure that you could have solved it on your own. If you want I'll give you a problem (not like a twist puzzle) that takes a similar ability. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've been thinking about this again. Actually, teaching noncubers how > to solve the cube is a SIN at least as bad as peeling the stickers off > for solving. > > Well, maybe it's just me. But I regret a lot that I learned a solution > from a book when I was a little kid. I'd like to know whether I > would've been able to find a solution myself. But I'll never know. > Teaching someone a solution takes that chance from him/her and it's > mean. > > A friend of mine saw me speedcubing a few months ago and decided to > try it, too. He refused to look at any solutions and specifically > asked me not to help him in any way, a request I very happily > satisfied. He did find a solution (of course!) and it's much much > cooler than learning it from someone else. > > But yeah, maybe that's just me (and that friend of mine)... > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > I have been fairly successful in getting several people into cubing > > since moving here (London) a few weeks ago. There are two people > > who've solved it once or twice (with my beginner's guide: > > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html) and > > three more who have expressed interest.
200. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 18:18:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Then they're unmotivated losers that need not be worried about. > > I do agree with Stefan, but I wouldn't call someone who tries and > gives up an unmotivated loser. I would just say they aren't > interested in the cube, and there's nothing wrong with that. Yes, I exaggerated a bit. Actually I think the same as you, they're not interested and that's ok. But then again, why teach those who're not interested? > If someone wants > to know how to solve it every time then I would call that person a > speedcuber, and that person would potentially want to work on an > advanced system after learning their first introductory solution. Still, that's no reason to teach them their first solution. They can find a solution on their own first, and then learn better ways from others. Finding their own solution first will also give them the advantage of trust in themselves to develop something on their own. Which is good. And they gain a deeper understanding of what they're doing. Which is good. My claim: The people who want to become speedcubers are also interested/motivated enough to solve it on their own first. Cheers! Stefan

204. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 18:29:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > In the early 1980s I realised that those who believed that they > could solve the cube on their own solved it, and those who believed > that they couldn't handle something that complicated failed. I totally believe that. Maybe those who thought it's too complex could've been told how easy it is and then they would've continued and succeeded. Don't know. I think the 3x3 is easy enough for anyone to master who's sane, healthy, interested and has some time. I once came up with a 4x4 algorithm (to solve the LL edges) on paper by writing down some "destroy-and-restore-F3L" algorithms and their effects, then combining them over and over again. I ended up with an algorithm of about 250 moves that took me 5 minutes to execute, but it worked. And I was very very proud. Later I found better ways and eventually after getting good enough, I allowed myself to look at other people's ways. > Anyway, I'm pretty sure that you could have solved it on your own. > If you want I'll give you a problem (not like a twist puzzle) that > takes a similar ability. Oh yes, please :-) Cheers! Stefan

214. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 16:12:07 -0800

well i'm not going to comment on the actual notation, but since we now have a WCA and the notation can be standardized, i personaly think that we should try to make the notation as easy as possible to understand, even if this means moving away from some of the older standards. so i wont propose anything notationwise, but i think that the WCA should discuss it and decide, or if it comes to it, poll the cubing community asking them to choose what they like best of a few different standards. 218. Re: New updates to CubeZone
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 09:41:05 -0000

Lars, Thank you for the algs. Awesome stuff. I like them! =) Your OLL21 has an extra corner sticker, btw. Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > No, not quite. The algorithms I published solve the corners and also > leave the orientation of the edges unaffected. So provided the edges > are already oriented, these algorithms solve the corners _and_ orient > the last layer in one go, which is way they are called COLL (Corners > and Orientation Last Layer). > > I know that the pages on my website don't offer a lot of explanation > just yet, but I'll try to change that in the future so that everyone > should be able to fully understand what everything means even if > you're not an expert already. > > LarsV > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "joel_vn" <joel_vn@y... > > wrote: > > > > Hmm... Don't you just mean CLL? :) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Lars Vandenbergh" > > <lars.vandenbergh@t...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi, > > > > > > I'm glad to see some positive response on my PLL page here and > > there ; > > > -). I've also published my speed optimized OLL and COLL > > algorithms, > > > all to be found at: > > > > > > http://www.cubezone.be/ > > > > > > Enjoy! > > > > > > LarsV
219. Re: [Speed cubing group] A Rubiks link
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>

Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 12:33:45 -0000

Ok I know the cube appears everywhere but someone sent me this so I thought
I'd pass it on.

Odd thing about it:
- wonder why they chose a 4x4 picture rather than a 3x3?
- the subtitle "54 multicoloured facets of hell" does however refer to a

220. [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 15:06:23 -0000

Hey! Here we go again! Notation debate ;-) In principle i would like a notation where there is no existing ambiguity. Though x,y,x and likewise f,r,u,b,l,d and M,E,S have a meaning based on consensus, some ppl find those confusing. And also it seems that the f,r,u,b,l,d have 2 defined meanings: one for slices moves (middle layers) and one primarily for fingertricks (turning 2 layers on 3x3x3 at a time). And apparently there is also different opinions about the x,y and z. So i can repeat what i have suggested in past: FRUBLD - already well defined, no ambiguity, the inverses and quarterturns are also cool deal ;-) Fc - and so on for cube rotations. (To rotate about an axis other than a face one must need to do it in 2 steps) Fm - for rotation the middle slice parallell to F. Fm will be equivalent to S. I personally dislike M,E and S even i have learnt them. So this is what i suggest but i know it's hard to turn old rocks ;-) Ppl are mostly slaves to habits :D Happy cubing :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi DanH, > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hi Tyson, > > > > > > > > I think your notation is perfect. > > Would it have hurt to say hi to me, as well? > > > > --> Why add so many different letters when r, f, u, (and l, b, d) can be > > used to denote slices, and QR QU and QB can be used to denote > > rotations? <-- > > > > > > > > r f u l b d are already defined tokens, they are the letters used > for turns > > of two layers. > > Though they may have been online first that doesn't mean they hold > the precedent. > > > --> I know some people already use the notation you printed > > out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. <-- > > > > > > > > They need to get used to it. > > Actually many of they simply turn away from cubing. > > > --> I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axes, like for map > > making, with z added for the vertical axis. <-- > > > > > > > > Get used to it. > > What, you don't want to go with the precendent? > > > DanH :-) > > Regards, > > David J > > _____ > > > > From: d_j_salvia [mailto:d_j_salvia@y...] > > Sent: 12 January 2005 17:52 > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves > > Challenge > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > Will someone please proofread this for me? > > > > > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/Notation%20Standards.doc > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > Hi Tyson, > > > > In Wordpad the counterclockwise notation L' comes out Lí. > > > > Why add so many different letters when r, f, u, (and l, b, d) can be > > used to denote slices, and QR QU and QB can be used to denote > > rotations? I know some people already use the notation you printed > > out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. > > > > I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axis, like for map > > making, with z added for the vertical axia. > > > > I don't know who came up with the notation you use, but except for > > FLUBRD it seems to deliberately defy convention and simplicity. > > > > Regards, > > > > David J

Frustration at the stupid things people say when they find out > > you can > > do the cube > > 5.. Deliberately popping during a slow solve > > 6.. Talking cube jargon to those who have no way of udnerstanding > > 7.. 222. [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 16:33:47 -0000

Fm, M, E, r... I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves notation. The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so there's just no need to give them a name. No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like slice moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations if needed. This way you get fewer notational problems. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > Here we go again! Notation debate ;-) > > In principle i would like a notation where there is no existing > ambiguity. Though x,y,x and likewise f,r,u,b,l,d and M,E,S have a > meaning based on consensus, some ppl find those confusing. And also > it seems that the f,r,u,b,l,d have 2 defined meanings: one for slices > moves (middle layers) and one primarily for fingertricks (turning 2 > layers on 3x3x3 at a time). And apparently there is also different > opinions about the x,y and z. > > So i can repeat what i have suggested in past: > > FRUBLD - already well defined, no ambiguity, the inverses and > quarterturns are also cool deal ;-) > > Fc - and so on for cube rotations. (To rotate about an axis other > than a face one must need to do it in 2 steps) > > Fm - for rotation the middle slice parallell to F. Fm will be > equivalent to S. I personally dislike M,E and S even i have learnt > them. > > So this is what i suggest but i know it's hard to turn old rocks ;-) > Ppl are mostly slaves to habits :D > > Happy cubing :-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi DanH, > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > Hi Tyson, > > > > > > > > > > > > I think your notation is perfect. > > > > Would it have hurt to say hi to me, as well? > > > > > > > --> Why add so many different letters when r, f, u, (and l, b, d) > can be > > > used to denote slices, and QR QU and QB can be used to denote > > > rotations? <-- > > > > > > > > > > > > r f u l b d are already defined tokens, they are the letters used > > for turns > > > of two layers. > > > > Though they may have been online first that doesn't mean they > hold > > the precedent. > > > > > --> I know some people already use the notation you printed > > > out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. > <-- > > > > > > > > > > > > They need to get used to it. > > > > Actually many of they simply turn away from cubing. > > > > > --> I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axes, like > for map > > > making, with z added for the vertical axis. <-- > > > > > > > > > > > > Get used to it. > > > > What, you don't want to go with the precendent? I know some people already use the notation you printed > > > out, but it confuses a whole lot of people, especially newcomers. > > > > > > I'm used to x and y coordinates being the lateral axis, like for > map > > > making, with z added for the vertical axia. > > > > > > I don't know who came up with the notation you use, but except for > > > FLUBRD it seems to deliberately defy convention and simplicity. > > > > > > Regards, > > > > > > David J

224. Re: solution for 5*5*5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 17:50:07 -0000

Actually you can solve the 4x4 pretty much exactly like you solve the 5x5. If you understand what you're doing with the 4x4, the translation to 5x5 should be no problem. I will intentionally *not* give you any further advice, since I'm confident you can make it on your own and the satisfaction will be much greater this way. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@y...> wrote: > I have solved the revenge 4*4*4 again today after 5 days. In the last layer I am not still very comfortable. Again thanks to chris for his wonderful explaination. > Where can I get such instruction for 5*5*5 professor cube? > Thanks in advance > John Louis > > > Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partneronline. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
225. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 17:58:02 -0000

Yes you can do without but it's a pain for the brain. Simplicity is a measure not only for the language itself (then we would talk in Binary, not English) but also for its use. Example: U2 Rm U2 Rm' This is how my brain thinks of the alg plus it looks nice. U2 L R' F2 L' R Actually less painful than I would've thought. My brain can think of the alg this way, too. But not as nice. U2 L R' Rc U2 L' R Rc' Painful. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Fm, M, E, r... > > I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves notation. > The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so > there's just no need to give them a name. > > No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like slice > moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations if > needed. This way you get fewer notational problems.
226. [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 18:17:30 -0000

Hey! That notation i mentioned is what i consider "ideal" if a cube move notation was to be completely reinvented so to speak. Im not suggesting to actually now go forward and make it official or widely used. Too many ppl are now used to other notations, so yes it would create even more confusion. But at least "my" notation doesn't conflict with any existing notations. And i thought u Gilles were one of those who campaign that slice moves be counted as 1 move? Not reflecting that in notation is then a bit odd to me :-) If we can all agree on the notation as explained on speedcubing.com then it's fine. When the larger olympic cubes are out (when in that actually???) we will have to decide on notation for them. Or even for huge computer cubes ... I'm mostly philosophical about this. Not a fundamentalist ... Cheers :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Fm, M, E, r... > > I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves notation. > The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so > there's just no need to give them a name. > > No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like slice > moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations if > needed. 227. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 18:34:56 -0000

Hahaha ... That was only one example Stefan. How about this one? R'D'RL-U'R'UD-L'U'LR-D'L'DU or R'D'Ra-D'L'Da-L'U'La-U'R'Ua (for those who know about antislices) Which could be : (R'D'RL-Fc)*4 Sooooo much nicer ... anyway ... -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Yes you can do without but it's a pain for the brain. Simplicity is a > measure not only for the language itself (then we would talk in > Binary, not English) but also for its use. > > Example: > > U2 Rm U2 Rm' > This is how my brain thinks of the alg plus it looks nice. > > U2 L R' F2 L' R > Actually less painful than I would've thought. But not as nice. > > U2 L R' Rc U2 L' R Rc' > Painful. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > Fm, M, E, r... > > > > I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves > notation. > > The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so > > there's just no need to give them a name. > > > > No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like > slice > > moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations > if > > needed. This way you get fewer notational problems.
228. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 19:00:20 -0000

I know you know that I think that writing using slice notations is much more simple and it corresponds to a simple way of thinking and considering the cube. :-) But let's be logical. You don't need extra notation that does not correspond the very logic of the metric(*). Or else, you can decide to label permutation sequences, for example. More logical, and less confusion. Gilles. (*) Even for cube rotations, you could do without. I think David used to write sequences based on turning colors (centers). This way, you can look at the cube upside down, notation won't change. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Yes you can do without but it's a pain for the brain. Simplicity is a > measure not only for the language itself (then we would talk in > Binary, not English) but also for its use. > > Example: > > U2 Rm U2 Rm' > This is how my brain thinks of the alg plus it looks nice. > > U2 L R' F2 L' R > Actually less painful than I would've thought. My brain can think of > the alg this way, too. But not as nice. > > U2 L R' Rc U2 L' R Rc' > Painful. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > Fm, M, E, r... > > > > I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves > notation. > > The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so > > there's just no need to give them a name. > > > > No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like > slice > > moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations > if > > needed. This way you get fewer notational problems.
229. Mefferts vs Rubik.com
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 20:01:37 -0000


Hello fellow cubers, I ordered a blank pyraminx and the eastsheen 4x4
from Mefferts and then a set of the stands from Rubik.com, both last
Friday and I received the Mefferts order today ! Looks like the
shipping from Hong Kong to Tennessee is faster than from Florida.

Wayne





230. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 20:10:26 -0000

Hi Stefan, Gilles, Per, et al, > [SP] > Example: > > U2 Rm U2 Rm' > This is how my brain thinks of the alg plus it looks nice. I use U2 r U2 r' [note the fewer letters needed] > [SP] > U2 L R' F2 L' R > Actually less painful than I would've thought. My brain can think of > the alg this way, too. But not as nice. For quarter turn metric that's fine. FLUBRD only. But people who use a lot of slice moves tend to think in terms of a metric which counts any move, including slice moves, as one move. Even in QTM a quarter turn of a slice could be allowed. Basically the notation I recommend is the 4x4x4 notation applied to the 3x3x3. I added "Q" for cube rotations because its easier to remember. It's no big deal. If everyone doesn't want to unify notation that's all right. I just wonder why those who will put out a lot of effort to simplify everything else balk at simplifying notation. Perhaps, like it was suggested, it is resistance to change. Regards, David J > U2 L R' Rc U2 L' R Rc' > Painful. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > Fm, M, E, r... > > > > I don't know why you're looking for trouble with slice moves > notation. > > The metric is HTM, slices are not considered as simple moves, so > > there's just no need to give them a name. > > > > No really, I'm serious, if someone wants to do weird things like > slice > > moves, it's always possible to use normal moves and cube rotations > if > > needed. This way you get fewer notational problems.
231. Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 21:15:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > I know you know that I think that writing using slice notations is > much more simple and it corresponds to a simple way of thinking and > considering the cube. :-) I know you know I know ;-) > (*) Even for cube rotations, you could do without. I think David used > to write sequences based on turning colors (centers). This way, you > can look at the cube upside down, notation won't change. That's what I've been doing for FMC. And at the end before submitting, translate color names to face names... It's not that useful for other purposes, though, since you don't write algs four different ways just because it can be executed with four different cube orientations. Or, if you're color-independent, write it 24 times :-) Cheers! Stefan
232. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 22:22:18 -0000

Hey, * I know you know I know ;-) Really? I didn't know that you knew he knew you knew. I think we should all turn to the learned king of cubes himself. Ron. Let him choose a notation, and everyone must stick by it. Failing that, lets just accept that notations, like languages, will number many and varied, and to understand each other we will have to become fluent in more than one. I think David used > to write sequences based on turning colors (centers). This way, you > can look at the cube upside down, notation won't change. That's what I've been doing for FMC. It's not that useful for other purposes, though, since you don't write algs four different ways just because it can be executed with four different cube orientations. Or, if you're color-independent, write it 24 times :-) Cheers! Stefan _____ Yahoo! Groups Links * To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri be> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

238. Bandaged cube solution
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 06:31:43 -0000


Hey everyone,
I decided to type up the solution I've been using for my bandaged
cube lately. It uses pretty much the same algorithms as on Jaap's
site, but the steps are different, as are some uses of the
algorithms. With such a confining puzzle though, I think it's about
as different as it can be.

It's still a bit of the work in progress, and the drawings are
pretty poor, but it's up for public scrutiny.

In the files section it's "bandaged Solution.doc"

Link: http://tinyurl.com/5h775

Also hosted on my own webspace:
http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Bandaged%20Solution.doc

Let me know if you guys have any suggestions (step four was kind of
difficult to communicate).

-Daniel





239. Re: Bandaged cube solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 10:46:27 -0000

Good thing you reminded me of this :-) Maybe I should read yours and Jaap's solution first, but here's how my solution would work. Choose special positions X and Y, remaining are called A-E. The pieces that belong in those positions get the same names. 1. Get "home position" (correct "shape"), left to reader. 2. Look at position X. If you see piece A, apply algorithm #A. Same for B-E. If you see X or Y, pick a place from A-E that's unsolved and apply its alg. Repeat until solved. The algorithms #A-#E would be 3-cycles, e.g. #D cycles (X->D->Y->X). So you need to be able to reach home position and you need to learn five algorithms. Don't know how long these algs would be. Clearly the puzzle is solved after A-E are solved, and each of these take at most three alg applications, so 15 alg applications is an upper bound (but I'd assume a much lower average, probably below 10). How many alg applications does your method need, do you know? Or, how many moves do you need to solve? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > I decided to type up the solution I've been using for my bandaged > cube lately. It uses pretty much the same algorithms as on Jaap's > site, but the steps are different, as are some uses of the > algorithms. With such a confining puzzle though, I think it's about > as different as it can be. > > It's still a bit of the work in progress, and the drawings are > pretty poor, but it's up for public scrutiny. > > In the files section it's "bandaged Solution.doc" > > Link: http://tinyurl.com/5h775 > > Also hosted on my own webspace: > http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Bandaged%20Solution.doc > > Let me know if you guys have any suggestions (step four was kind of > difficult to communicate). > > -Daniel
240. Re: Bandaged cube solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 11:09:21 -0000

I just wrote a program to analyze my method. Here are the results of solving a million bandaged cubes my way: Average number of algorithms applied: 6.46907 373 times it took 0 algorithm applications 2038 times it took 1 algorithm applications 9774 times it took 2 algorithm applications 35780 times it took 3 algorithm applications 95670 times it took 4 algorithm applications 190359 times it took 5 algorithm applications 222971 times it took 6 algorithm applications 165524 times it took 7 algorithm applications 114895 times it took 8 algorithm applications 80383 times it took 9 algorithm applications 47234 times it took 10 algorithm applications 25759 times it took 11 algorithm applications 9240 times it took 12 algorithm applications So average is indeed less than 10, and worst case seems to be 12 :-) Here's the code: (Actually I just realized I'm pretty stupid. The million random tests should be replaced by 7!/2 tests, namely all possible scrambles. Oh well...) #include <iostream> #include <algorithm> using namespace std; int p[7]; bool solved () { for( int i=0; i<7; i++ ) if( p[i] != i ) return false; return true; } void show () { for( int i=0; i<7; i++ ) cout << p[i] << " "; cout << endl; } int main () { //--- Prepare... for( int i=0; i<7; i++ ) p[i] = i; int n = 1000000; int sum = 0; int freq[100] = {}; //--- Dance... for( int t=0; t<n; t++ ){ //--- Scramble. random_shuffle( p, p+7 ); //--- Fix parity. int parity = 0; for( int i=0; i<7; i++ ) for( int j=i+1; j<7; j++ ) parity ^= (p[i] > p[j]); swap( p[0], p[parity] ); //--- Solve. //show(); int steps = 0; while( !solved() ){ int target = p[0]; if( target < 2 ) for( int i=2; i<7; i++ ) if( p[i] != i ) target = i; //cout << "alg #" << target << endl; swap( p[0], p[target] ); swap( p[0], p[1] ); //show(); steps++; } //--- Statistics. sum += steps; freq[steps]++; } //--- Display results. cout << "Average number of algorithms applied: " << 1.0 * sum / n << endl; for( int i=0; i<100; i++ ){ if( freq[i] ){ cout.width( 4 ); cout << freq[i] << " times it took " << i << " algorithm applications" << endl; } } } --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Good thing you reminded me of this :-) > > Maybe I should read yours and Jaap's solution first, but here's how my > solution would work. Choose special positions X and Y, remaining are > called A-E. The pieces that belong in those positions get the same > names. > > 1. Get "home position" (correct "shape"), left to reader. > 2. Look at position X. If you see piece A, apply algorithm #A. Same > for B-E. If you see X or Y, pick a place from A-E that's unsolved and > apply its alg. Repeat until solved. > > The algorithms #A-#E would be 3-cycles, e.g. #D cycles (X->D->Y->X). > > So you need to be able to reach home position and you need to learn > five algorithms. Don't know how long these algs would be. Clearly the > puzzle is solved after A-E are solved, and each of these take at most > three alg applications, so 15 alg applications is an upper bound (but > I'd assume a much lower average, probably below 10).
241. Re: Bandaged cube solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 11:14:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Here's the code: Oh, and to clarify this: In the program I chose X=0 and Y=1 and the task is to order the array of numbers 0-6. In reality, X and Y are piece positions of course, and should be chosen so that the five resulting algs are on average as short as possible. Cheers! Stefan
242. Re: Bandaged cube solution
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 15:37:34 -0000



--- "Stefan Pochmann" wrote:
> Maybe I should read yours and Jaap's solution first, but here's how
> my solution would work. Choose special positions X and Y, remaining
> are called A-E.

You're solution would use the 3-cycles (AXY), (BXY),..,(EXY).
Unfortunately 3-cycles are not easy to find on the bandaged cube.

There is a short 3-cycle (9 moves), which I use in my solution. I
chose to solve those three pieces last. Most other 3-cycles
unfortunately have rather a lot of moves. There was one 3-cycle I
wanted to have, but my computer couldn't find it (I think I broke it
off after 25 moves or so).

In the end my first (computer-assisted) solution used a different set
of movesequences for each piece. This means you only have to apply 5
move sequences, but because of the missing 3-cycle case it can
sometimes be 6.

On the other hand, 5-cycles are much easier to find. My second
solution used one 5-cycle (applied in different ways), and the short
3-cycle. I don't know how many applications of those sequences are
needed.

Regardless, I can never remember either solution.

Jaap





243. Re: Bandaged cube solution
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 18:04:20 -0000

My method uses a 3 cycle, a 5 cycle (and their mirrors) and one more 5 cycle that's very intuitive and only used once. After a quick look back at the solution, I think the worst case solve would apply 11 algorithms, but I could be wrong (I'll have to think about step 4 more). -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Good thing you reminded me of this :-) > > Maybe I should read yours and Jaap's solution first, but here's how my > solution would work. Choose special positions X and Y, remaining are > called A-E. The pieces that belong in those positions get the same > names. > > 1. Get "home position" (correct "shape"), left to reader. > 2. Look at position X. If you see piece A, apply algorithm #A. Same > for B-E. If you see X or Y, pick a place from A-E that's unsolved and > apply its alg. Repeat until solved. > > The algorithms #A-#E would be 3-cycles, e.g. #D cycles (X->D->Y->X). > > So you need to be able to reach home position and you need to learn > five algorithms. Don't know how long these algs would be. Clearly the > puzzle is solved after A-E are solved, and each of these take at most > three alg applications, so 15 alg applications is an upper bound (but > I'd assume a much lower average, probably below 10). > > How many alg applications does your method need, do you know? Or, how > many moves do you need to solve? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > I decided to type up the solution I've been using for my bandaged > > cube lately. It uses pretty much the same algorithms as on Jaap's > > site, but the steps are different, as are some uses of the > > algorithms. With such a confining puzzle though, I think it's about > > as different as it can be. > > > > It's still a bit of the work in progress, and the drawings are > > pretty poor, but it's up for public scrutiny. > > > > In the files section it's "bandaged Solution.doc" > > > > Link: http://tinyurl.com/5h775 > > > > Also hosted on my own webspace: > > http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Bandaged%20Solution.doc > > > > Let me know if you guys have any suggestions (step four was kind of > > difficult to communicate). > > > > -Daniel
244. Re: Recruiting more cubers
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 18:45:08 -0000

I was quite surprised to see the volume of discussion generated from my initial post about teaching some new cubers! :) The only puzzle I worked out entirely by myself is the Rubik's Clock. My general approach with puzzles is to try and work out most of it myself but then not feel too guilty about reading a website when I get really stuck. I don't regret not having worked out the whole cube myself, but I certainly do respect those who have (very impressed!!). I am, however, an advocate for working out the F2L on your own and solving it intuitively. But perhaps this is just because I found the F2L pairs to be pretty easy. I guess I'd feel the same way about the LL if I'd found it easy (but I didn't). Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I think I'll throw in my two cents as well. > > >>>Oh, I don't know about that. The 3x3x3 is rather a difficult > puzzle > >>> to start on, and, left to themselves, many people would give up > >>> through frustration. > > > Then they're unmotivated losers that need not be worried about. > > I do agree with Stefan, but I wouldn't call someone who tries and > gives up an unmotivated loser. I would just say they aren't > interested in the cube, and there's nothing wrong with that. If > they were interested in really solving the puzzle as a puzzle they > would try harder when they found it to be difficult. > > I think we have to consider two groups of people, those who just > want to solve the puzzle of Rubik's cube as a puzzle, and those who > want to become speedcubers. > > If someone just wants to learn how to solve it as a puzzle, then I > agree - teaching them defeats their whole purpose. If someone wants > to know how to solve it every time then I would call that person a > speedcuber, and that person would potentially want to work on an > advanced system after learning their first introductory solution. > > The way I see it, solving the cube once or twice is a puzzle that > people should try to figure out on their own. Speedcubing is more > of an art. So for speedcubing someone can either teach you the > basics and you learn from there, or you can learn the basics > yourself and move on. I don't think it's bad to teach a potential > speedcuber how to cube, but to teach someone who just wants to solve > it once or twice to say they've done it, then yes I agree it is bad > to teach them. > > Just my opinion of course, > Chris
245. Lots of new cubers last Christmas?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 18:57:08 -0000


Speaking of people learning the cube from a website...

I was looking at the stats for my site the other day and I noticed
that the hits to my beginner solution page were *way* up in December
2004 and January 2005. Particularly the two days following Christmas
where the number of hits was up by about 250%!

I guess this means lots of people got cubes for Christmas?? :)

Did anyone else notice this with their website?

Jasmine
http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html





246. What's a good method for a beginner?
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 20:21:06 -0000


I didn't see a FAQ, sorry if I missed it. I'm trying to teach my son
(8) how to solve the 3x3 and wasn't sure what method to show him. I
started with a top down approach, but recently addopted the Lars
Petrus method (really liked his interactive site and that I didn't
have to reposition my grip as much as I use to), but wasn't sure if
there was a better method for a beginner that could evolve into a
speedcubing method.

250. [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 23:38:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > FRUBLD - already well defined, no ambiguity, the inverses and > quarterturns are also cool deal ;-) Yeah. I agree. > Fc - and so on for cube rotations. (To rotate about an axis other > than a face one must need to do it in 2 steps) I don't know about this, though... I would rather have a move like vR, which would be to turn the cube so that you're now looking at the R face. You could then also do vRU or vRB (different from vUB) also. > Fm - for rotation the middle slice parallell to F. Fm will be > equivalent to S. I personally dislike M,E and S even i have learnt > them. I'd like to propose a different notation for these, one that I saw in a book. They used the notation Fs and Fa: the s means 'slice' and Fs would be F B', and the a means 'antislice' and Fa would be F B. I can't stand the MES system myself, and I'd never use it on my site if I was presenting a solution. Also, with my definitions the centers will stay in the same position, there aren't any problems like worrying which direction an E' turn is, and it's just shorthand for something that would take longer to write.
251. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Lots of new cubers last Christmas?
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>

I am too tired to think of reasons why it might be, the Christmas rush is one I guess, but you can also see that some days of the week are more popular than others, and a big rush of hits coincided with my new F2L pages. 252. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 00:01:15 -0000

Lars V and I would also like to propose a new notation, which we feel is very intuitive and would be a useful standard. Whats more is its easy to remember! A = Above B = Back C = Counter-East D = Down E = East F = Front a, b, c, d, e, f = two layer turns + = clockwise - = anticlockwise 2 = half turn Rotation_A/A'/A2 = Rotation in the direction of A/A/A2 Same for B C D E F, use whichever is necessary. Dan :-) _____ From: qqwref [mailto:mzrg@...] Sent: 14 January 2005 23:39 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation Standards for Fewest Moves Challenge --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > FRUBLD - already well defined, no ambiguity, the inverses and > quarterturns are also cool deal ;-) Yeah. I agree. > Fc - and so on for cube rotations. (To rotate about an axis other > than a face one must need to do it in 2 steps) I don't know about this, though... I would rather have a move like vR, which would be to turn the cube so that you're now looking at the R face. You could then also do vRU or vRB (different from vUB) also. > Fm - for rotation the middle slice parallell to F. Fm will be > equivalent to S. I personally dislike M,E and S even i have learnt > them. I'd like to propose a different notation for these, one that I saw in a book. They used the notation Fs and Fa: the s means 'slice' and Fs would be F B', and the a means 'antislice' and Fa would be F B. I can't stand the MES system myself, and I'd never use it on my site if I was presenting a solution. Also, with my definitions the centers will stay in the same position, there aren't any problems like worrying which direction an E' turn is, and it's just shorthand for something that would take longer to write. _____ Yahoo! Groups Links * To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri be> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
253. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's a good method for a beginner?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 17:29:58 -0800

I have a beginner solution on my website http://www.deepcube.tk I have taught many people, probably well over a hundred, how to solve the cube using this method, but to my knowledge only one so far has actualy learned from my site. Although the method seems fairly good, and the feedback from that one person was good, just a warning, the website isnt tried and tested. The method on my site (not by any means my method, just a begginer one) also leads nicely to an intermediate method and etc. right up to full Fridrich. And i know i'm going to get hammered for creating clones, but nothing says that you can't learn another method or make up your own once you've learned. Another good beginner solution is Jasmine's, but i dont have a link to her site right now. Good luck, Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Fri, 14 Jan 2005 20:21:06 -0000, dwarmaj <Dwarmaj@...> wrote: > > I didn't see a FAQ, sorry if I missed it. I'm trying to teach my son > (8) how to solve the 3x3 and wasn't sure what method to show him. I > started with a top down approach, but recently addopted the Lars > Petrus method (really liked his interactive site and that I didn't > have to reposition my grip as much as I use to), but wasn't sure if > there was a better method for a beginner that could evolve into a > speedcubing method. > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! 258. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lots of new cubers last Christmas?
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 13:33:56 -0000

If you can get the already popular sites to link to you and vice versa, you're on a good way already, since Google will more often hit you. And it also turns out having unique and good content always help. Design is quite irrelevant. There are many ways to popularize a website. Those are probably the best. Don't expect your site to be a hit right away. Good sites have returning visitors, and returning visitors always have to arrive a first time, and then you need to have something there that makes them come back. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > Hey, > I have a site up with a begginer and intermediate solution and some > stuff about my robot, "deepcube". 259. Re: 4*4*4 blindfold solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 15:35:44 -0000

Hi John, You can solve the 4x4 basically very similar to 3x3, but of course you need other algorithms. The way I would do it (I've never done a 4x4, only a 5x5) is in 3-cycles, i.e. solve 2 pieces at a time. The algs I used for the 5x5 that also work for the 4x4: - centers: (l d l') U (l d' l') U' - edges: (l D l') U (l D' l) U' - corners: like 3x3 These algs for centers/edges are simple commutators and you can easily modify them, for example I'd also use this one: U2 (l D l') U2 (l D' l) Btw, for blindsolving discussions better go to the blindsolving group http://groups.yahoo.com/group/blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube/ Memorizing I do exactly the same way as 3x3. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@y...> wrote: > where can I get 4*4*4 blindfold solution ? I know only stefan's method of solving 3*3*3 blindfolded , in which only initial positions need to be memorised. > John Louis > > Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partneronline. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 15:43:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > C = Counter-East > > E = East Dan, Lars, this is very bad for me. I'm always confused by East/West. Therefore I suggest to swap and rename like this: C = Communists E = Europe Stefan

The way I would do it (I've never done a 4x4, only a 5x5) is in 3-cycles, i.e. solve 2 pieces at a time. The algs I used for the 5x5 that also work for the 4x4: - centers: (l d l') U (l d' l') U' - edges: (l D l') U (l D' l) U' - corners: like 3x3 These algs for centers/edges are simple commutators and you can easily modify them, for example I'd also use this one: U2 (l D l') U2 (l D' l) Btw, for blindsolving discussions better go to the blindsolving group http://groups.yahoo.com/group/blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube/ Memorizing I do exactly the same way as 3x3. 263. Re: devil's algorithm
From: h_howee <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 17:58:38 -0000


By applying the algorithm RBLF over and over on the cube, how many
states of the cube will it go through until it goes back to its
starting point and how many times will it have to be applied to get
back to the starting point?





264. Re: devil's algorithm
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 18:35:03 -0000


> By applying the algorithm RBLF over and over on the cube, how many
> states of the cube will it go through until it goes back to its
> starting point and how many times will it have to be applied to get
> back to the starting point?

You could have a litte fun and spend 10 minutes applying the algorithm
yourself. I just did it, and it doesn't take very long! I wish I would
have counted for you, but it's funner to discover things for yourself.
Have fun!

-Chris







265. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's a good method for a beginner?
From: "lkyawkyaw" <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 19:03:33 -0000

well for beginners check out taka's page, his link is on macky's site. the good thing about his method is, it gives a good transition into speedcubing full fridrich system later on. basically his method is solving the f2l using only of alg, then doing sunes to orient LL, after which only the three cycle permutations are used. pretty neat :P laterz. 267. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4*4*4 blindfold solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 20:42:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@y...> wrote: > Hi stefan, > Thank you very much. Let me give it a try. I do not have any idea about 2-cycle, 3- cycle etc. could you please explain me that ? > John Louis If you use my 3x3 method (using the T-permutation to do almost all the work), then you're already working with 2-cycles, which are simple swaps (A<->B) or write (A->B->A). And 3-cycles are (A->B->C->A). They're easy to come up on the fly using commutators. And they're the same as two 2-cycles, so you solve 2 pieces at a time instead of just 1. If you have more questions about this, please ask in the blindsolving group. Cheers! Stefan
268. [Speed cubing group] Re: Lots of new cubers last Christmas?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 20:44:21 -0000

Or something similar... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan. gates@g...> wrote: > Does anyone happen know how I go about trying to get my page on the > speedcubing.com links page?

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology

274. Three - 3*3*3 cubes solved blindfolded
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 11:16:55 +0000 (GMT)


Today, I tried out 3 cubes successively. Yes, I did them perfectly. I took 36 min to memorise. Revised 3 times to make sure my memorisation is perfect.And, I solved all the three perfectly in 54 min. Of course, all the 3 cubes are very rough. I had to fight with it to move!! More over I have not memorised the set up moves yet.
If I have a well lubed cube and memorise all the set up moves and reset up moves, I can improve my speed. I am planning to do 15 cubes very shortly to inspire my son BERNETT ORLANDO & it may be a new record also, I believe.
In the coming week ends I will try out 5, 8, 12 & 15 etc.
Regards,
John Louis

Although the method seems fairly good, > and the feedback from that one person was good, just a warning, the > website isnt tried and tested. The method on my site (not by any > means my method, just a begginer one) also leads nicely to an > intermediate method and etc. right up to full Fridrich. And i know > i'm going to get hammered for creating clones, but nothing says that > you can't learn another method or make up your own once you've > learned. > > Another good beginner solution is Jasmine's, but i dont have a link to > her site right now. > > Good luck, > Evan > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk > > > On Fri, 14 Jan 2005 20:21:06 -0000, dwarmaj <Dwarmaj@h...> wrote: > > > > I didn't see a FAQ, sorry if I missed it. 280. Timers
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 17:33:49 -0000


A few of my cuber friends and I have decided that we should pool
together our money and purchase a timer for when we hold meetings,
so we don't have to rely on using a computer for timing. But, before
we do, I'd like to know a few things:

First: Is there any major disadvantage to the new stackmats? I tried
one out yesterday at the Exploratorium and it seemed much better
than the original. But does it hold up, etc?

Second: The new Rubik's timer is coming out eventually. When it
does, how likely is it that the timer will become the official timer
of speedcubing? If it does, will the stackmat phase out of use? Or
are stackmats likely to be the tournament timer for a long time?
We're also considering holding a tournament at some point, so the
timer would be used for that.

I would really appreciate feedback before we sink $60 into a timer
that becomes obsolete...
Thomas Bischof





281. Re: [Speed cubing group] Timers
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 10:08:38 -0800

The stackmat will never become obsolete to cup stackers, so you could
always sell it to them on ebay if cubers start using something else.

In the tournament yesterday it happened twice that a solved cube became
unsolved when hitting the table after being dropped.

I'm not complaining about the rules, and neither were those affected,
but I think it shows that a specific cube timer would be better.

/Lars

On Jan 16, 2005, at 9:33, tsbischof wrote:

>
>
> A few of my cuber friends and I have decided that we should pool
> together our money and purchase a timer for when we hold meetings,
> so we don't have to rely on using a computer for timing. But, before

> timer would be used for that.

> that becomes obsolete...
> Thomas Bischof

291. Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 18:04:12 -0000



I see that Master Katsu reached sub-6 for the 2x2x2 cube
(congratulations, by the way ;-) I'm feel that you can be faster, but
it depends on the quality of your cube).

I know people who spend 10 seconds looking for the easiest set of
colors to begin with. Saving 5 moves for such a puzzle is a huge
advantage, it's almost more important than the effective solving phase.

What are the exact rules for such a fast puzzle? (*)

Gilles.






(*) Well, not as fast as the Magic. Hum...







292. Re: Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 19:50:28 -0000

Hi Gilles, Yes, congratz to Katsu... I am not sure if I can ever do that without learning CLL :). I don't know if there are any special rules for the 2x2, but I always use 15 seconds preinspection time... And indeed, it really helps to start with an easy color. I never really gave the inspection time any thought, because I am just used to those 15 seconds so much. - Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > I see that Master Katsu reached sub-6 for the 2x2x2 cube > (congratulations, by the way ;-) I'm feel that you can be faster, but > it depends on the quality of your cube). > > I know people who spend 10 seconds looking for the easiest set of > colors to begin with. 296. Re: [Speed cubing group] Timers
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 12:26:39 -0800

Hi Lars,

I think competitors should realize that the WCA tournaments all use
Stackmats and practice starting and stopping with a Stackmat. It is
true that a cube can become unsolved but that just means the competitor
needs to place the cube down more slowly. In a competition, we are not
measuring how fast you can solve a cube but we are measuring how fast
you can solve the cube in a competition. This means pressure and
certain standards. The time of course isn't the time it takes to solve
a cube either. It's the time to pick up the cube and put it back down.
I'm sure I've said this before, but the 100 meter race doesn't measure
how fast you run 100 meters. It measure how fast you run 100 meters
and your ability to react to the sound of the gun.

I feel the new timer introduces many problems into the competition
regulations so we will be sticking with the Stackmat even when the new
timer comes out. The Stackmat ensures that you can't make a move until
you start the time and also ensures that you can't make a move after
you stop the time.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 16, 2005, at 10:08 AM, Lars Petrus wrote:

> The stackmat will never become obsolete to cup stackers, so you could
> always sell it to them on ebay if cubers start using something else.
>
> In the tournament yesterday it happened twice that a solved cube became
> unsolved when hitting the table after being dropped.
>
> I'm not complaining about the rules, and neither were those affected,
> but I think it shows that a specific cube timer would be better.
>
> /Lars




297. Re: [Speed cubing group] Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 12:35:22 -0800

Are you saying that we should have a much smaller inspection time for
the 2x2x2? The main problem with short inspection times is that it
becomes harder and harder to actually give them that time. Imagine you
give someone 1 second of inspection time. Well, they already have 3
seconds of leeway in terms of starting and stopping. Basically, the
error of the inspection time because larger than the inspection time
itself.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 17, 2005, at 10:04 AM, Gilles Roux wrote:

> I know people who spend 10 seconds looking for the easiest set of
> colors to begin with. Saving 5 moves for such a puzzle is a huge
> advantage, it's almost more important than the effective solving phase.
>
> What are the exact rules for such a fast puzzle? (*)
>
> Gilles.

Sorry to disappoint you, it's not free

http://www.magic-cube.com/en/produits.php?

Still not expensive though. I clicked on Prices to get this link.

Gillian

Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net

And what his times with a > 2x2 would be... > > Cheers! > Stefan > > P.S. Magic doesn't even need preinspection :-)
300. 4x4 parity imposibility
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 07:29:39 -0000


Does anyone have an algorithm to swap two corners without disturbing
any other pieces? I can either line up the edges or the corners, but
not both. I don't care if I have to remember fifty moves, I just
need to solve this so I can go to work and live a normal life again.





301. Re: 4x4 parity imposibility
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 08:30:22 -0000

The usual way to attack this is to swap two edge groups using this algorithm: r2 U2 r2 (Uu)2 r2 u2 And proceed normally. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > Does anyone have an algorithm to swap two corners without disturbing > any other pieces? I can either line up the edges or the corners, but > not both. I don't care if I have to remember fifty moves, I just > need to solve this so I can go to work and live a normal life again.
302. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 parity imposibility
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 00:57:35 -0800

What's the quickest algorithm to correct the orientation parity? I
know Chris has one on his website that corrects the orientation parity
and doesn't disturb anything else but is there one that corrects it and
just retains the 3x3x3 status of the 4x4x4 cube?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 17, 2005, at 11:29 PM, mgwallisa wrote:

>

> any other pieces? I can either line up the edges or the corners, but
> not both. I don't care if I have to remember fifty moves, I just
> need to solve this so I can go to work and live a normal life again.

303. WCA Logo
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 01:12:47 -0800

Hi Everyone,

The World Cube Association is looking for an official logo. We're
looking for something distinct, catchy, and of course, cube-like. Let
us know if you'd be interested in coming up with something.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

306. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 parity imposibility
From: François SECHET <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:34:35 +0100 (CET)

try r²U²r²(Uu)²r²u², u being the slice next to U and turning in the same direction. There you get your life back again... Also try going to Chris' page on speedcubingdotcom and check his 4x4 solution. François mgwallisa <mattwallisa@...> wrote: Does anyone have an algorithm to swap two corners without disturbing any other pieces? I can either line up the edges or the corners, but not both. I don't care if I have to remember fifty moves, I just need to solve this so I can go to work and live a normal life again. --------------------------------- Yahoo! Groups Links To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- Découvrez le nouveau Yahoo! Mail : 250 Mo d'espace de stockage pour vos mails ! Créez votre Yahoo!
