307. Re: Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: planet_katsu <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:07:39 -0000


Thank you everybody a lot.

I am really glad to achieve first sub6. ;)
However, I have been practicing 2x2x2 only for a short term.

And, I apply and am using the method on the following page.
http://cube.misto.cz/ortegas.html
So, I am using only very few algorithms.

In addition, I am studying making the following page.
It connects with page 3 from the link under the page.
http://www.planet-puzzle.com/2x2x2.html
(I'm sorry only in Japanese.)

About pre inspection time:
I also am spending 15 seconds.
One example, http://www.planet-puzzle.com/a_cube_video.html
I want the extension of five seconds!!! (haha...)


> I'm only wondering what method Sébastien Felix uses to average
4.24
> seconds for solving the corners of a 3x3. And what his times with
a
> 2x2 would be...

I also feel the same mystery...
Does anyone know the method that he is using?

Thanks any!

Katsu

PLANET PUZZLE
http://www.planet-puzzle.com/

p.s.
I just learnt the DoubleParityFixer Pure algorithm YESTERDAY. (Too
LATE! I sweat...)
Anyway, Thank you for a super algorithm. :-D






308. Re: Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:42:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, planet_katsu <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Thank you everybody a lot. > > I am really glad to achieve first sub6. ;) > However, I have been practicing 2x2x2 only for a short term. > > And, I apply and am using the method on the following page. > http://cube.misto.cz/ortegas.html > So, I am using only very few algorithms. > > In addition, I am studying making the following page. > It connects with page 3 from the link under the page. > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/2x2x2.html > (I'm sorry only in Japanese.) > > About pre inspection time: > I also am spending 15 seconds. > One example, http://www.planet-puzzle.com/a_cube_video.html > I want the extension of five seconds!!! (haha...) > > > > I'm only wondering what method Sébastien Felix uses to average > 4.24 > > seconds for solving the corners of a 3x3. And what his times with > a > > 2x2 would be... > > I also feel the same mystery... > Does anyone know the method that he is using? > 1) Orientation. 2) Separation (U/D). 3) Permutation. The third step is the same as yours. With a lot practice, it seems that Sébastien knows how to anticipate 2) from start, when possible. And he uses very fast fingertricks of course :-) I like the method you are using too, because it's *very easy* to learn and powerful. I think it's possible to reach very good times using a layer-by-layer strategy too. Get used to solve the easiest layer, and then it's just a matter of 2.5s thanks to optimized sequences. Gilles. > Thanks any! > > Katsu > > PLANET PUZZLE > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/ > > p.s. > I just learnt the DoubleParityFixer Pure algorithm YESTERDAY. (Too > LATE! I sweat...) > Anyway, Thank you for a super algorithm. :-D
309. Re: [Speed cubing group] Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:58:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Are you saying that we should have a much smaller inspection time for > the 2x2x2? The main problem with short inspection times is that it > becomes harder and harder to actually give them that time. Imagine you > give someone 1 second of inspection time. Well, they already have 3 > seconds of leeway in terms of starting and stopping. Basically, the > error of the inspection time because larger than the inspection time > itself. > If you plan most of your solution before, you're only timing pure dexterity (including picking up the cube and stopping the timer), it's not the art of puzzle solving. But I know there's no practical way of timing a "no inspection" solve. :-( Gilles. PS: Oh! I just had an idea for a new brilliant patent: The "no inspection" speedcubing competition room... - The competitor enters a dark room. - The timer starts when the judge switches the light on. - Judges equiped with infra-red goggles. Ok, ok... Forget it.
310. Parity problem with 5x5x5
From: Heymbeeck Joël <sinac_be@...>
To: Rubik Club English <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 12:03:04 +0100 (CET)

Hello,
I have received my professor cube yesterday and try to solve it but I have a parity problem:
i have a edge triplet in UF looking like this:
ABA face U
BAB face F
and I would like to fix this, is there an algo or I have made a mistake when solving it ?

Joël

312. Re: Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 12:25:29 -0000

Whahaha.. That video is really cool :). I also had a 1.74 case like that once. It took me longer to see the cube was actually solved, than the total solving time. :) Your method looks a bit like Geatan's method. Last permutation step (of both layers) is the same... Maybe you should take a look at his algorithms. I think it won't be that hard to combine both methods. - Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, planet_katsu <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Thank you everybody a lot. > > I am really glad to achieve first sub6. ;) > However, I have been practicing 2x2x2 only for a short term. > > And, I apply and am using the method on the following page. > http://cube.misto.cz/ortegas.html > So, I am using only very few algorithms. > > In addition, I am studying making the following page. > It connects with page 3 from the link under the page. > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/2x2x2.html > (I'm sorry only in Japanese.) > > About pre inspection time: > I also am spending 15 seconds. > One example, http://www.planet-puzzle.com/a_cube_video.html > I want the extension of five seconds!!! (haha...) > > > > I'm only wondering what method Sébastien Felix uses to average > 4.24 > > seconds for solving the corners of a 3x3. And what his times with > a > > 2x2 would be... > > I also feel the same mystery... > Does anyone know the method that he is using? > > Thanks any! > > Katsu > > PLANET PUZZLE > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/ > > p.s. > I just learnt the DoubleParityFixer Pure algorithm YESTERDAY. (Too > LATE! I sweat...) > Anyway, Thank you for a super algorithm. :-D
313. Re: Parity problem with 5x5x5
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 12:37:20 -0000

Hi Joël, You can use the same algorithms for the 4x4 case, where one edge- group is 'flipped' (2 edge pieces a swapped). I use: (R2 r2) B2 U2 (L l) U2 (R' r ') U2 (R r) U2 F2 (R r) F2 (L ' l ') B2 (R2 r2). Hope it helps :). Joël :D. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Heymbeeck Joël <sinac_be@y...> wrote: > Hello, > I have received my professor cube yesterday and try to solve it but I have a parity problem: > i have a edge triplet in UF looking like this: > ABA face U > BAB face F > and I would like to fix this, is there an algo or I have made a mistake when solving it ? > > Joël > > > --------------------------------- > Découvrez le nouveau Yahoo! Mail : 250 Mo d'espace de stockage pour vos mails ! > Créez votre Yahoo! Mail > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

I had just realised I could use it ;) joel_vn <joel_vn@yahoo.com> wrote: Hi Joël, You can use the same algorithms for the 4x4 case, where one edge- group is 'flipped' (2 edge pieces a swapped). I use: (R2 r2) B2 U2 (L l) U2 (R' r ') U2 (R r) U2 F2 (R r) F2 (L ' l ') B2 (R2 r2). Hope it helps :). 317. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "tomrokicki" <rokicki@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 19:28:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > By applying the algorithm RBLF over and over on the cube, how many > states of the cube will it go through until it goes back to its > starting point and how many times will it have to be applied to get > back to the starting point? We've discussed this before, but: What algorithm has the longest cycle time (in count of the number of times it must be applied to go back to the starting position)? What is that count of times? What's the shortest algorithm with that count?
318. Re: devil's algorithm
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 22:09:26 -0000

I think the count in question is 1260. Don't know about your other questions, though I have asked them before and gotten answers back. The shortest one isn't long... there's one with some 6-8 moves. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "tomrokicki" <rokicki@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, h_howee <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > By applying the algorithm RBLF over and over on the cube, how many > > states of the cube will it go through until it goes back to its > > starting point and how many times will it have to be applied to get > > back to the starting point? > > We've discussed this before, but: > > What algorithm has the longest cycle time (in count of the number of > times it must be applied to go back to the starting position)? What > is that count of times? What's the shortest algorithm with that count?
319. Cubes in Discover
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 22:16:31 -0000


I don't know how many people out there read Discover magazine, but
this month's Bogglers are puzzles dealing with the Rubik's Cube,
Pyraminx, and Skewb. One asks questions about stickers and numbers
of unique moves. They also have some fill-in-the-blank ones, where
they show all six sides of a scrambled cube with some stickers
missing. There's more to it, but I figure you can find the article
on your own if you're interested.

One of their "Difficult" questions: "Suppose you are trying to twist
a mixed-up cube back to its original position. How can you tell
which face should be which color?"

Just thought you might be interested...
Thomas Bischof





320. Re: [Speed cubing group] Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 22:17:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > PS: Oh! I just had an idea for a new brilliant patent: The "no > inspection" speedcubing competition room... > - The competitor enters a dark room. > - The timer starts when the judge switches the light on. > - Judges equiped with infra-red goggles. > Ok, ok... Forget it. Hey wait, I like it! But I'd suggest this improvement: Timer *and* light are both triggered by the solver picking up the cube from the surface of the timer. That way we don't have to search for the cube first. Cheers! Stefan
321. Re: Question about 2x2x2 inspection time
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 22:22:08 -0000

Ok for Magic it's a joke, but for Clock I'm almost that bad. In competitions, pretty much the *only* thing I look for is the first move I'll do on the backside so that after flipping the clock I can continue smoothly. But I always do this and then realize I've looked at the wrong side, because of how clocks are scrambled and given to us in competitions, which differs from my practice (where I start with pins in random state rather than all up). And then I get angry at myself and do it again, this time using the other side :-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > P.S. Magic doesn't even need preinspection :-) > > lol that would be great if it was allowed though. > > "hmmm... let me see if the middle ring is still in the middle... > yep.. yep, still there. Ok.... Now.. is the rubik's logo still on > the bottom panel? ... yep... still there.... oh crap only 4 seconds > left!! um.. um... ok I think I've got it."
322. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 parity imposibility
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 22:34:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > What's the quickest algorithm to correct the orientation parity? I > know Chris has one on his website that corrects the orientation parity > and doesn't disturb anything else but is there one that corrects it and > just retains the 3x3x3 status of the 4x4x4 cube? The one I came up with for the UuRr-4x4 is quite fast: http://games.groups.yahoo. com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/13698 (also have a look at the replies to that message). In QTM it wins 24 to 25 against Chris's alg. Also, the second part in the "mirrored" (or whatever) version I mentioned is one long very fast finger trick: First half: (Rr)' U R U [(Rr)' U2] * 3 Second half: (Rr)2 U R' U' (Rr)2 U' R' U (Rr)' What exactly do you mean with "quickest"? Btw, my alg was build around [(Rr)' U2]*4.5 but only allowing UuRr moves, so maybe something even better could be found allowing other moves as well. And before I forget: Why do you ask? Any specific usage in mind? Cheers! Stefan

324. New York Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 16:34:51 -0800

Hey Everyone,

I was walking next door to turn in a homework set and on the way, I got
the idea of having a tournament in New York. This would be in March,
about March 20th. Either on a Saturday evening or Sunday. Anyway, if
you are not subscribed to the Caltech yahoo groups:
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/caltechrubiks/

I would suggest you sign-up because the organization and ideas will be
in there and it's your chance, if you plan to attend, to help work out
the details.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

If you > > have any sort of more specific requirements drop me a line. What > > format would you like the images in? 339. East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 22:22:23 -0000

stiff, though, and I'm wondering if any of you can tell me the best
way to lubricate it.





340. 5x5x5 Parity Error
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 00:09:17 -0000


I was solving the 5x5x5 and unexpectedly I came upon a case where the
FRu and FRd edges were flipped. I couldn't get it to solve, so I
figured it must be some kind of parity error thing and so I took the
cube apart and put it back together.

However, if this happens again I'd like to know: Is this really a
parity error? Can this be solved without taking the cube apart? If so,
what is a good algorithm to use?

I haven't found any half-decent sites for 5x5x5 solving; it's not like
I can't do it on my own, but when this comes up I'm totally lost.





341. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 16:11:22 -0800 (PST)

if you dont wanna take it apart, go get silicon oil or spray, the ones that have a spray straw included, and jamm it b/n the pieces and spray! it gets really stiff right after spraying, but you can put on a hair dryer and keep twisting it while you blow warm air onto it, its what i do :P --- qqwref <mzrg@...> wrote: > > I just ordered an East Sheen 5x5x5 cube in the mail. > It seems a little > stiff, though, and I'm wondering if any of you can > tell me the best > way to lubricate it. > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
342. Re: New file uploaded to speedsolvingrubikscube
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 00:42:20 -0000


The way the cube is looks very unprofessional, as does the fact that
there's just a plain white background. I like the idea of having a WCA
on the cube, though.

As the WCA includes 5x5x5s, I think it would be cool to take a picture
of a hand with the WCA logo on a 5x5x5 - which would make the letters
look more realistic - and then use the Photoshop function that changes
the picture to a few different tones. The hand and cube might look
cartoonish enough and yet real enough to look nice for a logo. Maybe.





343. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: Doug Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 18:53:48 -0600

Hey,

My Eastsheen 5x5x5 cube was fairly stiff before I lubed it, but
afterwards it was very, very slick. The best way to go about it is to
pop off one of the center caps (mine weren't glued down very well at
all) and unscrew it. Then you have to CAREFULLY lift up either the top
layer or the top two layers at once.

I don't remember exactly, but it might be best to have an empty cup
standing up right next to your cube to rest the top two layers on.
You'll know what I mean when you get the top layer off. If you try to
set it on your desk, or try to take out one piece at a time, you're
probably going to end up with a bunch of seemingly random pieces that
will give you trouble when you try to put them back together. If you
hold them together, they should stay together and after you lube it you
can just set the top layer(s) back ontop and put the screw back in.

Hope it helps,
Doug

On Wed, 2005-01-19 at 22:22 +0000, qqwref wrote:
>
> I just ordered an East Sheen 5x5x5 cube in the mail. It seems a little
> stiff, though, and I'm wondering if any of you can tell me the best
> way to lubricate it.
>
>
>

344. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 01:13:01 -0000

Personally, I think the best way to lube a cube is as described on gilles site. You take it apart, clean it, line up the pieces in gruops of four (look at the picture),then i wipe it off and wait for it to dry. Put it back together, and voila! I've found that if the cube sticks to itself, like...if you just spray into it, then the cube does not work as well. A light coating that dries before you put it back together has worked much better for me. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@y...> wrote: > if you dont wanna take it apart, go get silicon oil or > spray, the ones that have a spray straw included, and > jamm it b/n the pieces and spray! > > it gets really stiff right after spraying, but you can > put on a hair dryer and keep twisting it while you > blow warm air onto it, its what i do :P > > > --- qqwref <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > > I just ordered an East Sheen 5x5x5 cube in the mail. > > It seems a little > > stiff, though, and I'm wondering if any of you can > > tell me the best > > way to lubricate it. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. > http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail

349. Re: New file uploaded to speedsolvingrubikscube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 05:03:12 -0000

I also uploaded an idea, but it's in "Photos/stefan". After finally understanding how "WCA" is written on Mike's cube (took me maybe reading 5 replies and 10 minutes) I think though that his is already much better (at least the cube part). Btw, "Association" is a very very bad word. Very long and you have to be careful to not let the reader notice the first three letters separated from the rest (in my picture I tried to write two letters of "Association" on each sticker, so on top it'd start with "A" and "ss". Brilliant word!). Cheers! Stefan P.S. 352. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 08:46:30 -0000

Hey! >From my experience it matters little how u actually apply the silicone spray. What i have found is that the eastsheen varieties only need a very small amount of the silicone to turn nicely. However, what matters most for them is which type of silicone u use. I have bad experience with petroleum based silicone spray on them. Petroleum based silicone spray is however excellent on the rubiks.com cube varieties. I'm not sure why it is like like this, but i suppose it's just different kinds of plastic being used. There has been lots of posts in the past about this, so just do a search and u will find lots of good info, also with particular brands of silicone spray mentioned :-) Best of luck :-) -Per PS! Other stuff that has been recommended as lubricants are vaseline and olive oil (extra virgin? ... probably not). Some also claim that the plastic is somewhat self lubricating due to fine dust being formed. I don't think that this is the case for the eastsheen cubes though. Getting a good non-petroleum based silicone is ur best option. PPS! Don't disassemble the eastsheen cubes too many times. Only do this when u have to lube them. Otherwise they become too loose and will start popping annoyingly :-S > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@y...> wrote: > > Personally, I think the best way to lube a cube is as described on > gilles site. You take it apart, clean it, line up the pieces in > gruops of four (look at the picture),then i wipe it off and wait for > it to dry. Put it back together, and voila! > > I've found that if the cube sticks to itself, like...if you just > spray into it, then the cube does not work as well. A light coating > that dries before you put it back together has worked much better for > me. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, lwin kyawkyaw > <lkyawkyaw@y...> wrote: > > if you dont wanna take it apart, go get silicon oil or > > spray, the ones that have a spray straw included, and > > jamm it b/n the pieces and spray! > > > > it gets really stiff right after spraying, but you can > > put on a hair dryer and keep twisting it while you > > blow warm air onto it, its what i do :P > > > > > > --- qqwref <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > > > > > I just ordered an East Sheen 5x5x5 cube in the mail. > > > It seems a little > > > stiff, though, and I'm wondering if any of you can > > > tell me the best > > > way to lubricate it. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > > Do you Yahoo!? > > Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. > > http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail

>
>

Tyson Mao

On Jan 19, 2005, at 9:03 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> be careful to not let the reader notice the first three letters
> separated from the rest (in my picture I tried to write two letters of

355. Re: 5x5x5 Parity Error
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 12:32:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I was solving the 5x5x5 and unexpectedly I came upon a case where the > FRu and FRd edges were flipped. I couldn't get it to solve, so I > figured it must be some kind of parity error thing and so I took the > cube apart and put it back together. > > However, if this happens again I'd like to know: Is this really a > parity error? Well, it is a problem involving permutation parity... you've reached a state of odd parity (for those "wing" pieces). Perhaps you do most of your solving using 3-cycles (I know I do), but 3-cycles are even permutations, so they can't be combined to make a swap of a single pair of pieces. For a good introduction to permutation parity (and a lot of other useful ideas), see Jaap's Puzzle Page: http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/theory.htm > Can this be solved without taking the cube apart? Yes, since you scrambled the cube without taking it apart ;) If you'd like to solve this problem yourself (sounds as if you might want to), have a think about each of the possible kinds of moves you can make on the 5x5x5 and see which kind is an odd perm of the "wing" pieces. Apply a move of this kind, and fix the mess (it isn't a serious mess), by using the even permutations you already know. Then maybe try to optimize the procedure. Have fun! Mike Btw, a bit more searching of the web (even this forum?) will turn up some reasonably short readymade sequences to do the job.

Let me know > if you're interested... we have someone biting at the New York Hall of > Science so let's see how that goes. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jan 19, 2005, at 9:44 PM, Raul Garcia wrote: > > > > > Back to the topic... > > > > This sounds like a marvelous idea! > > You can count me in... Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > > http://mail.yahoo.com > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
357. Re: East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 15:48:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > From my experience it matters little how u actually apply the > silicone spray. What i have found is that the eastsheen varieties > only need a very small amount of the silicone to turn nicely. Just a smear on the curved internal surfaces will do: putting it on the flat surfaces may gum it up. I think the difference compared with Rubiks/Mefferts is that the pieces are more accurately molded, so that there are large areas in contact (rather than just contact at the "high" points) and less room for excess lubricant to escape to. > PS! Other stuff that has been recommended as lubricants are vaseline No, no! That's another Deadly Sin. And the wages of Sin are Puzzle Death. Don't risk it, unless (as suggested by Josef) you need to break in a puzzle quickly; that shouldn't be needed here. > PPS! Don't disassemble the eastsheen cubes too many times. Only do > this when u have to lube them. Otherwise they become too loose and > will start popping annoyingly :-S It shouldn't get loose if you dismantle it by unscrewing a centre piece. Mike

Rob







359. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 09:19:35 -0800

I suspect that "dust lubrication" is incompatible with silicone
lubrication. That is, the wet lube makes the dust clump up and make it
sticky.

Then again, I may just imagine it.

/Lars


On Jan 20, 2005, at 0:46, Per Kristen Fredlund wrote:

> Some also claim that
> the plastic is somewhat self lubricating due to fine dust being
> formed. I don't think that this is the case for the eastsheen cubes
> though.



360. Timer for Linux

does anyone know if there's a timer (like NetCube or Jesse Bonde's
timer) for Linux?

-Edgardo





361. Re: Timer for Linux
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 20:39:47 -0000


> does anyone know if there's a timer (like NetCube or Jesse Bonde's
> timer) for Linux?

You can use JNetCube on Linux. You can download it here:

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/jnetcube.html

The link for the latest Java runtime is also available on that page if
you don't have it installed.

-Chris





362. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen 5x5x5 lubrication

Hey! If u clean all the cubies before lubing it with silicone, then i guess the silicone "film" will prevent the self-dusting to happen to a large extent. So i guess it's not really a big problem. But the silicone "film" does wear off and/or mixes with dirt. That's why u need reapply the silicone every now and then. -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > I suspect that "dust lubrication" is incompatible with silicone > lubrication. 364. [Speed cubing group] Re: devil's algorithm
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 22:18:32 -0000


Hello all,

Since I didn't get any further with this, I will post it here until
it gets too old (maybe it already is too old, let's just hope...).

I managed to find a Devil's Algorithm for the sub-group R2U2L2D2
(yeah, it's not even the half-move group...), and I'm going to
explain here how I found it. For those of you less patient, the alg
is at the bottom of the post.

Let's start with the simplest possible subgroup, that is R2U2. It is
pretty obviuous that the Devil's algorithm for it is just (R2 U2)*5
R2, that is 11 moves (there are 12 possible position on the whole,
and no position repeats in the algorithm I just gave, so it works.)
After I got here, I tried to expand it to a larger group, it being
for the moment R2U2L2. Since this subgroup already has many more
possible positions, let's do some important notices:

1)There are certain groups of pieces which never break up, for
example the "column" made of the UFR, UR and UBR pieces. The other
kind of piece consists of two opposite edges on the same face
together with the center between them (we can for the moment regard
them as a whole), for example the three pieces UF, U and UB. So
we'll call these two kinds of "blocks" "column" and "oppedge"
(coming from opposite edges, please suggest a better name if you
find one).

2)Columns never change orientation, and oppedges never change
position, i.e. they don't permute. So all we got to worry about is
the permutation of columns and the orientation of oppedges.

Let's calculate the number of possible positions in this subgroup.
There are 4 columns which can permute in 4!=24 ways, and three
oppedges which can have 2^3=8 orientations, on the whole 24*8=192,
but we have to divide by 2 because the orientation of oppedges + the
permutation of columns must be even, so on the whole we have 96
possible positions. Our Devil's algorithm for this subgroup must be
95 moves long.

My idea was to use the Devil's algorithm for the R2U2 subgroup,
combining it with all the possible positions for the pieces at the L
oppedge (orientation of L oppedge) and the LD column. So if
(D)(R2U2) = the Devil's algorithm for the subgroup R2U2, then (D)
(R2U2L2) would be the form ((D)(R2U2))A((D)(R2U2))A......A((D)
(R2U2)), with (D)(R2U2) appearing 8 times and A standing for a move
sequence which changes the position of the L oppedge and LB column.
If we want our final algorithm to be optimal, we have to take A only
one move long, and since we have no other option to change the
position of the above mentioned oppedge and column than to turn the
face L, then, A=L2.

This obviously doesn't work. Why? (D)(R2U2) has the effect of U2, so
a sequence of alternating U2 and L2 moves would lead to the solved
state sooner than needed. But we can still use this, and then insert
somehow the moves needed to add the extra positions needed. These
positions (two in number) are the ones where we have the RD column
in LD, with the L oppedge being oriented either way. Now let's see
what the incompleted Devil's Algorithm looks like.

((D)(R2U2))L2((D)(R2U2))L2((D)(R2U2))L2((D)(R2U2))L2((D)(R2U2))L2((D)
(R2U2)) = (((D)(R2U2))L2)*5 ((D)(R2U2))

It is 6*11+5=71 moves long. We need to insert 24 more moves to
account for the missing positions. Now let's break it so that we can
see where we insert the two other positions.

First 12 moves are

R2 U2 [R2] U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 L2

This has the same effect as

R2 U2 L2. [R2] L2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 L2

only that it gets two more positions. At the dot after the first L2
the RD column is in LD. So we can insert here (D)(R2U2) for getting
12 more positions. We can put U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2
instead of the R2 in square brackets, and so we get 12 more
positions. Convince yourselves with the following alg:

R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 L2

which is 24 moves long instead of the original 12, so we have 12
positions left. Notice that after these 24 moves the L oppedge is
orientated the other way than at the very beginning, so that we can
repeat the maneuver to get the 12 positions left. So the first 24
moves of the original incomplete algorithm were

((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*2

and now they are

R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 L2

which is the same as

(R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2

The new sequence is 48 moves long instead of the original 24, so
exactly 24 new positions have been added. The devils's algorithm for
the subgroup R2U2L2 is

(R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3 (R2 U2)
*5 R2

I must now confess that I was thrilled when I found it. I had found
an optimal Devil's algorithm 95 moves long! But now, it's so easy to
make it twice as long, by finding the Devil's algorithm for the
subgroup R2U2L2D2, which brings us to the second part of this post.


You probably have noticed that the trick for inserting additional
positions in the middle of an already existing Devil's algorithm was
to add two L2 moves before and after a R2 move, so that nothing
messed up really. We are going to do same thing here. But first, the
basics.

The subgroup R2U2L2D2 has twice as many positions as the R2U2L2 one,
since we add the possible orientation of the D oppedge. On the whole
192 positions, so the Devil's algorithm must be 191 moves long.

I'm now going to mention an important property of any Devil's
algorithm: A Devil's algorithm is said to be cyclic, if after you
apply it to a certain position, you are only one move away from that
same position. In the case of (D)(R2U2L2), that move is L2.

Now, since we want to move the D oppedge too for getting (D)
(R2U2L2D2), we want to insert two D2 moves before and after a U2
move, and then applying the whole (D)(R2U2L2) in between, so that we
double the number of positions and hence we get the desired (D)
(R2U2L2D2). Since the (D)(R2U2L2) is completed by the move L2, and
not U2, we cannot insert it at the end. Now we'll make use of the
propoerty that this Devil's algorithm is cyclic, and we are going to
write

(R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3 (R2 U2)
*5 R2 L2

which gets us into the same position i.e. the solved position. Now,
if we start from another point inside this alg, we can still get a
Devil's algorithm if we cut the last move down. If this move is U2,
then we can safely insert the whole algorithm at the new end , and
we'll get the (D)(R2U2L2D2). So we can for instance have

(R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3 (R2 U2)
*5 R2 L2

=

R2 L2 (R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3
(R2 U2)*5

=

R2 L2 (R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3
(R2 U2)*4 R2 U2

so now it ends in U2. Take it out, and the new (D)(R2U2L2) is

R2 L2 (R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3
(R2 U2)*4 R2

Now we can safely add the D2 moves, so that (D)(R2U2L2D2) is

(D)(R2U2L2) D2 (D)(R2U2L2) D2

This obviously gets back to the solved position, but it's anyway 192
moves long, so tripping the last D2 would be just good. So there we
go:

(D)(R2U2L2D2)=

R2 L2 (R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2 U2)*5 R2 L2)*3
(R2 U2)*4 R2 D2 R2 L2 (R2 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*5 U2 L2 (U2 R2)*4 L2)*2 ((R2
U2)*5 R2 L2)*3 (R2 U2)*4 R2



Sebastian

Hi Everyone,

The Caltech Rubik's Cube Club will be accepting designs for the spring
tournament on April 16. The front side will have the WCA logo on it so
the design is for the back side. One color... should have the
information Caltech, Spring Tournament, April 16, 2005, and whatever
else you think is necessary. I mean, it can be Caltech or California
Institute of Technology or whatever...

Anyway, submit your designs in the Caltech Rubik's Cube group and the
selected designer will receive a free t-shirt or a few.

Tyson Mao

378. [Speed cubing group] Re: musicians
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

387. Re: 4x4 stages
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 10:55:13 -0000

Hey! I don't use ur method, but from what i heard in the past i estimate that the breakdown is approximately like this : centers : 20% of the time pairing up edges : 40% of the time solve as 3x3x3+parity fix : 40% of the time So from ur 30 secs doing centers u should be around 2:30 in total. But as i said it's just an estimate. U might have a particularly slow or fast stage :-) Good luck getting faster :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ryan Patricio" <ryn_patricio@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering because my times for solving the centers takes 30+ > seconds.
388. New updates to CubeZone
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 16:43:18 -0000


Hi,

I've made several additions to my website since the last time I
posted, so I thought it would be the right time to notify you. This is
what's waiting for you to be checked out:

* My personal/official records
* My tournament record
* The return of ImageCube
* 114 F2L algorithms for the ZB system
* 5 speedcubing videos including 3 exclusive first releases ;)

Of course, all to be found at:
http://www.cubezone.be/

LarsV

394. Wanted: web designer WCA website
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 22:19:26 -0000


Hi friends,

There is so much talent in this group!
So there must be some guys able and willing to design the WCA
website: http://www.worldcubeassociation.org

Required: creativity, time, dedication and some technical experience.

Offered: being part of a team of fools who love cubing and do
everything for free. :-)

Maintaining speedcubing.com is taking a lot of time already, so we
really need help.

Basically what we need is:
= a site that looks like what you would expect from an official
organization: professional and interesting
= loads fast
= simple, not too much technique behind it (we prefer: (X)HTML, CSS,
PHP, ECMAScript, MySQL, but no extensive content management system
like Mambo)

The site will offer all official stuff and the rest will be a
slightly interactive site with interesting functionality.
Ideas:
= organization information (board, reports and so on)
= regulations (including tournament information sets)
= events (past and upcoming)
= records and rankings
= profiles (interactive stuff)
= news
= contact information
and so on.

Examples:
http://www.iaaf.org/
http://www.uefa.com/
http://www.fina.org/
but feel free to post ideas!

Applications:
Make an example website (very rough design).
Send us an e-mail.

We are looking forward to hear from you.

Have fun,

Ron






395. Re: Wanted: web designer WCA website
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 22:57:20 -0000

When are these samples due? I consider myself fairly adept at precisely this kind of thing, but I want to know how much time I got. :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > There is so much talent in this group! > So there must be some guys able and willing to design the WCA > website: http://www.worldcubeassociation.org > > Required: creativity, time, dedication and some technical experience. > > Offered: being part of a team of fools who love cubing and do > everything for free. :-) > > Maintaining speedcubing.com is taking a lot of time already, so we > really need help. > > Basically what we need is: > = a site that looks like what you would expect from an official > organization: professional and interesting > = loads fast > = simple, not too much technique behind it (we prefer: (X)HTML, CSS, > PHP, ECMAScript, MySQL, but no extensive content management system > like Mambo) > > The site will offer all official stuff and the rest will be a > slightly interactive site with interesting functionality. > Ideas: > = organization information (board, reports and so on) > = regulations (including tournament information sets) > = events (past and upcoming) > = records and rankings > = profiles (interactive stuff) > = news > = contact information > and so on. > > Examples: > http://www.iaaf.org/ > http://www.uefa.com/ > http://www.fina.org/ > but feel free to post ideas! > > Applications: > Make an example website (very rough design). > Send us an e-mail. > > We are looking forward to hear from you. > > Have fun, > > Ron

of the face pieces on my rubiks revenge. As I was supergluing it
back into place, the warning about speedcubing on the revenge came to
mind. I realize that this cube will probably never be fit for
speedcubing, but where can I get a sturdy 4x4x4, or how do I get a
regular one up for the challenge?

Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 03:02:07 -0800

Just search for a course with the word "Rubik" in it.

I am SOOOO dropping by when I go home for spring break!

http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~decal/course_docs/syllabus_230.doc

403. Dan Knights page
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 12:16:38 -0000


Hello everybody!

I´m new to this group and quite new to speedcubing. I am very
determined to become fast (sub-20 or close to it) and have been
training and searching the web for different tips and advices. One
page if often find refeneces to is Dan Knight´s page but all the links
return me with a message that the page isn´t found on the server.
Could someone tell me the new URL of the page or does the page not
exist any more (or am I just too stupid to open it)?

Thanks,
Mikael

405. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Dan Knights page
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 04:40:12 -0800

I heard he moved to North Carolina. Back in September of 2003 after I
had just started cubing, I e-mailed him asking if he would autograph a
cube for me. (I think I was at 90 seconds average back then) He said
he was going on vacation but he would be happy to meet me at a BART
(subway) station in the Bay Area the week afterwards. I never got
another e-mail response after that...

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jan 24, 2005, at 4:33 AM, edgardo_deza wrote:

> because there were videos that showed fingertricks.
>
> Has anybody heard of Dan Knights lately or his page?
>
> -Edgardo




406. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: UC Berkeley
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 04:42:50 -0800

Yeah, I'd totally be up for the dinner! So the class meets on Mondays
from 4 to 5 PM. Maybe they would be interested in having some guests
go and give a talk or whatever? I doubt the class facilitators
(students teaching the class) can average faster than 45 seconds...
otherwise there's a good chance we would have heard of them. How can
you study the Fridrich method's websites (as advertised on the
syllabus) without coming across speedcubing.com? And how can you get
faster than 45 seconds without succumbing to the obsession which is
this yahoo group? I guess it is possible... in my experience, there
are only a handful of cubers out there that would be considered "speed
cubers" who have no knowledge of this cubing community.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

408. 5x5x5 Patterns
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 21:14:59 -0000


Does anyone have any good patterns for the Professor Cube (5x5x5),
other than Randelshofer (whose site I've already seen)? Where are they?

By the way, I found that if you apply the superflip to the (1 3 1)
cube (using only moves turning one layer) and then to the (2 1 2) cube
(using only moves turning two layers) on the same 5x5x5 you get a
really nice pattern which drapes over to the sides. Try it! It's cool!





409. [Speed cubing group] Re: musicians
From: "Ryan Patricio" <ryn_patricio@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 22:05:49 -0000

414. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity Error
From: Mofo Esad <mofoesad@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 18:38:18 -0800 (PST)

Although I'm not really answering your question, my suggestion for anyone solving larger cubes is to solve the centers last. You for all practical purposes eliminate all the parity problems I always here people talk about. I solve the larger cubes in this order. First the centers on two opposite sides. Second the eight corner pieces. Third all the edge pieces. Fourth the center pieces on the four remaining centers. Just my thought on the subject. Esad --- qqwref <mzrg@...> wrote: > > I was solving the 5x5x5 and unexpectedly I came upon > a case where the > FRu and FRd edges were flipped. I couldn't get it to > solve, so I > figured it must be some kind of parity error thing > and so I took the > cube apart and put it back together. > > However, if this happens again I'd like to know: Is > this really a > parity error? Can this be solved without taking the > cube apart? If so, > what is a good algorithm to use? > > I haven't found any half-decent sites for 5x5x5 > solving; it's not like > I can't do it on my own, but when this comes up I'm > totally lost. > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Read only the mail you want - Yahoo! Mail SpamGuard. http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail

419. Search Engines
From: "Evan" <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 07:34:44 -0000


So this isn't really cube related per se, but how do you get your
website to show up in more searches? My website right now only
shows up on google if you type in deepcube . I think it has
something to do with the meta tags or something, but I'm just not
sure. So can anyone explain how to get it to show up in searches
like if someone searches for "rubik's cube robot" or something.

Any help would be greatly appreciated,
Evan

Until next time, Happy Cubing
http://www.deepcube.tk





420. Re: [Speed cubing group] Search Engines
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 23:39:52 -0800

Google has an interesting algorithm that is commonly used as an example
of Markov Matrices in linear algebra classes. To sum it up... if your
website is linked from popular pages, then it will in turn be more
popular.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

421. Re: [Speed cubing group] Another WCA logo

Hello, Thanks for commenting. My submissions are just ideas, they're the result of a 2 hour work of a beginner in CG. Trajectories are not what they should, and the earth should morph into the cube. The important thing is to propose a logo, and I thought it could be interesting to show it in 3D. I like the idea of a cube as a globe. 'Worldwide'. But a thinner stand would be better. I like some other submissions too (http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/). I'm sure you can produce much better animations and lighting. If you have time, maybe you could try? 422. Need help to understand instructions
From: alan_davidson2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 11:29:53 -0000


After 40 years (at the age of 71) I've finally solved the cube using
the instructions at:

http://www.olympus.net/personal/prmhem/default.htm

This solution is simple, and involves hardly any memorisation, which
suits me at my age.

My problem is that there are about 25% of all cubes that I can't
solve, because I don't understand the instructions that relate to that
25%.

Perhaps one of the experienced cubists out there could help me to
understand the instructions - even if they don't use that specific
method.

The instructions relate to "Step Three: Top Edge Pieces", which is on
the page:

http://www.olympus.net/personal/prmhem/step_three.htm

About half-way down the page, there's a group of three consecutive
paragraphs. The first paragraph begins:

"In the fourth case all three top edge pieces on the top face are in
their proper position relative to each other."

The third paragraph of the group ends:

"Continue in this fashion until, in the fourth turn of the green face
the last white edge piece (in this case the white/orange piece)
returns to the top face of the cube and the fourth center section edge
piece moves into place at front/right."

In fact, this last sentence is the only sentence in the whole page
that I don't understand. I don't know what the author means by
"Continue in this fashion" :-)

Could some kind person please give the actual sequence of moves. They
can use text instructions (as in the web page), or they can use things
like RL'U''L, or whatever.

Regards,
Alan





423. Re: Need help to understand instructions
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 11:58:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alan_davidson2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > The third paragraph of the group ends: > > "Continue in this fashion until, in the fourth turn of the green face > the last white edge piece (in this case the white/orange piece) > returns to the top face of the cube and the fourth center section edge > piece moves into place at front/right." > > In fact, this last sentence is the only sentence in the whole page > that I don't understand. I don't know what the author means by > "Continue in this fashion" :-) OK, at this point (fig 6h) the green face has been moved twice... it needs to move twice more: once to put the white-green piece into position, displacing white-orange to the middle layer; and once more to move white-orange into position. So the sequence is U' R U' R' The thing, though, is to figure out why you are doing this: the nice thing about Philip Marshall's solution is that it proceeds by understanding, rather than blind application of hard-to-remember sequences (and still doesn't take very many turns). Hope this helps :) Mike
424. Re: Need help to understand instructions
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 12:20:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > So the sequence is U' R U' R' ...except that you need a final U in this case, if you want the U edges in their correct positions, rather than in their correct _relative_ positions(!) Not that it really matters for the next stage... Mike
425. Re: Need help to understand instructions
From: alan_davidson2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 12:50:19 -0000

Hi Mike, Thanks for your solution. Now I can solve all the cubes :-) I entirely agree with your comment that Philip Marshall's solution "proceeds by understanding, rather than blind application of hard-to-remember sequences". There's no way (at my age) that I could memorize, for example, the solution that I was experimenting with just before I stumbled across Philip Marshall's solution: http://puzzlesolver.com/puzzle.php?id=29 My grandchildren understood Marshall's solution without difficulty (apart from the missing info that you have just provided). Regards, Alan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alan_davidson2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > The third paragraph of the group ends: > > > > "Continue in this fashion until, in the fourth turn of the green > face > > the last white edge piece (in this case the white/orange piece) > > returns to the top face of the cube and the fourth center section > edge > > piece moves into place at front/right." > > > > In fact, this last sentence is the only sentence in the whole page > > that I don't understand. I don't know what the author means by > > "Continue in this fashion" :-) > > OK, at this point (fig 6h) the green face has been moved twice... it > needs to move twice more: once to put the white-green piece into > position, displacing white-orange to the middle layer; and once more > to move white-orange into position. > > So the sequence is U' R U' R' > > The thing, though, is to figure out why you are doing this: the nice > thing about Philip Marshall's solution is that it proceeds by > understanding, rather than blind application of hard-to-remember > sequences (and still doesn't take very many turns). > > Hope this helps :) > Mike
426. Re: [Speed cubing group] Another WCA logo
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 15:51:09 -0000

I really like idea of the cube in a globe stand... doubles as the C and everything... very interesting. In max, there is a deformer called "spherify" I think that should morph the globe into the cube. Also, if you make 2 maps and use a mix map (can't remember the real name) you can animate the change between them. put in a backlight so we can see the back of the globe, or if you're going for a more planetary feel, change the background to black. About Flash, as far as I know, you need a program called Macromedia Flash to make animations. You can convert AVI to swf files, but they end up BIG. Flash is a vector tool, this means that everything is stored as a math formula rather than a dot on screen (Which is why you can scale them indefinitely) much like the spline in MAX. This is your idea, and I'm just trying to help you make it excellent. It's the teacher in me. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Hello, > > Thanks for commenting. > My submissions are just ideas, they're the result of a 2 hour work of > a beginner in CG. Trajectories are not what they should, and the earth > should morph into the cube. > The important thing is to propose a logo, and I thought it could be > interesting to show it in 3D. > I like the idea of a cube as a globe. 'Worldwide'. But a thinner stand > would be better. > I like some other submissions too (http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/). > > I'm sure you can produce much better animations and lighting. If you > have time, maybe you could try? > > Gilles. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qwerty1110" > <qwerty1110@h...> wrote: > > > > What Program are you doing these in? > > Sorry if I go on for a while, but I'm studying Computer Graphics as a > > major. > > > > The first one was simpler and made a pretty good impression, but the > > final was pretty cluttered. Plus the actual animation and lighting > > were better > > > > The second one, I think, has a better final screen, but the animation > > into it is not well lit. Plus the cube growing into the the world > > seems a bit awkward. if you want to keep that idea, perhaps a > > different way to get the cube into the stand would help(but bomb > > routines are bad) > > > > I would personally suggest the first one, minus the W and A as a > > starting point. > > > > Or perhaps because the cube is such a geometrical entity would a flash > > style animation would work better? > > > > Just my thoughts > > > > TBTTyler Fox > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > I liked the wcb3.avi clip better... but that's just my opinion. > it was > > > simpler. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Jan 24, 2005, at 3:22 PM, Gilles Roux wrote: > > > > > > > http://grrroux.free.fr/wcb4.avi > > > >

428. Troubles in the land of F2L
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 13:05:05 -0400

Hey all,

Does anyone have any suggestions for recognizing the first pair after the cross is done when completing F2L? I seem to be taking the longest time, on average with the first pair then my wasted time seems to get better as I move onto next pair.
i.e.

- 1st pair longest
- 2nd pair not as long as 1st pair
- 3rd pair not as long as 2nd pair
- 4th pair not as long as 3rd pair


Thanks Dwayne

430. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity Error

Hi Esad, Very interesting. I solve the 4-by the same way. For step three, in what order do you do the edge pieces? I pair up the middle edge pairs and put them in place first. 432. CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 20:13:44 -0000


On Jessica Fridrich's website, Guus Razoux Schultz states that there
are 21 distinct algorithms for CLL and 17 for ELL. I recently tried
to verify this, but found 23 for CLL. (I agree with 17 for the ELL
case, which is much easier to check.)

Can anyone here confirm that 21 is correct for CLL?

Note that for these purposes, 2 algorithms are "distinct" if they are
not related by rotation (naturally), reflection, or "time-reversal":
i.e., inversion of the algorithm -- which may also be combined with
the spatial symmetry operations.

It wouldn't be hard to write a program to do the check, but probably
it is not worth doing it for just one problem :)

Mike






433. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity Error
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 20:59:44 -0000

Hey! My steps for the larger cubes are like this: 1) First layer - intuitive 2) Middle layer edges U only need as many algs as the number of middle layers, and those algs only differ with 2 moves (the layer specific ones). 3) Last layer corners Only a few basic algs are needed for positioning and orientation 4) Last layer edges A few basic commutator 3-cycles that u do fast when u know how they work. It takes some practice to see how to set them up though. There is only 1 parity fix which is quite easy. 5) All remaining centers. As u can see from the records at www.speedcubing.com im pretty fast with it. What times do u achieve w ur method Esad? (and David). Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mofo Esad <mofoesad@y...> wrote: > Although I'm not really answering your question, my > suggestion for anyone solving larger cubes is to solve > the centers last. You for all practical purposes > eliminate all the parity problems I always here people > talk about. I solve the larger cubes in this order. > First the centers on two opposite sides. Second the > eight corner pieces. Third all the edge pieces. Fourth > the center pieces on the four remaining centers. Just > my thought on the subject. > > Esad > > > --- qqwref <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > > I was solving the 5x5x5 and unexpectedly I came upon > > a case where the > > FRu and FRd edges were flipped. I couldn't get it to > > solve, so I > > figured it must be some kind of parity error thing > > and so I took the > > cube apart and put it back together. > > > > However, if this happens again I'd like to know: Is > > this really a > > parity error? Can this be solved without taking the > > cube apart? If so, > > what is a good algorithm to use? > > > > I haven't found any half-decent sites for 5x5x5 > > solving; it's not like > > I can't do it on my own, but when this comes up I'm > > totally lost. > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Read only the mail you want - Yahoo! Mail SpamGuard. > http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
434. Re: Troubles in the land of F2L
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 21:06:29 -0000

Hey Dwayne, This same situation used to haunt me every time I solved the cube. I would often find a good or decent cross, but lose time trying to find the first pair and end up wasting my good cross solve. At least for me, having been cubing for a while, I can now look back and say that I was going WAY too fast on the cross. I have also had the opportunity of teaching a lot of people in person. Every time I had someone say they were having the same problem of trying to find the first pair after the cross, whenever I watched them solve they too were solving the cross WAY too quickly. The best thing to realize is that for the F2L you don't really need to go quickly, just smoothly. The F2L (optimally) should take 32 moves on average, based on Ron's 100 average on speedcubing.com. If you do only two moves per second, but smoothly, you will solve the F2L in 16 seconds, which is pretty good despite turning so slowly. Here are the best tips I've heard and/or used myself for improving this. 1) Use all 15 seconds of the inspection and make sure you know the cross so well that even after having put the cube down to start the timer, you can jump right into solving it. I've heard people suggest practicing just doing the cross blindfolded. So examine for 15 seconds, then solve the cross with your eyes closed and see if it worked. 2) If you have an easy cross, and you are able to see it in less than 15 seconds, then spend the remainder of your inspection time looking for the general area of where some other pieces might end up. You don't need to know exactly that the red/blue/yellow corner will end up in UFR and be rotated clockwise, just get a general idea. It is enough to know that one of the corners for a CE pair MIGHT be on the left side rather than the right, things like that. 3) When actually solving the cross, go actually slow. Not slow-fast or smoothly fast, but actually slow. This may seem like you are wasting time by not going quickly, but you will be able to track that corner that you thought MIGHT end up on the left side of the cube. If you go actually slow (again not slow-fast, smoothly fast, or anything like that) then I guarantee that every single time you will have hardly any delay at all from the cross to the first pair. 4) When solving the first pair, speed up to about 50-70% speed and try to look around for other pieces. Now this time you actually want to be going slow-fast, not actually slow. You should be moving along fairly quickly during the first pair, but still nowhere near full speed. 5) When solving the third pair speed up very slightly again to maybe 70%-80% speed. Again try to look around to get the general idea of where those last pair pieces are going to be. 6) On the last pair go as fast as your hands will allow you to turn the faces without popping. You are going to jump into the last layer steps (whether OLL or a 3 look LL) randomly anyway, so you might as well save some time by going absolutely break neck speed on the last F2L pair. Again, that is what helped me, but everyone has their own style. I would experiment with the stuff above, and see how it works for you. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Hey all, > > Does anyone have any suggestions for recognizing the first pair after the cross is done when completing F2L? I seem to be taking the longest time, on average with the first pair then my wasted time seems to get better as I move onto next pair. > i.e. > > - 1st pair longest > - 2nd pair not as long as 1st pair > - 3rd pair not as long as 2nd pair > - 4th pair not as long as 3rd pair > > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
435. [Speed cubing group] Re: UC Berkeley
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 21:24:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > in my experience, there > are only a handful of cubers out there that would be considered "speed > cubers" who have no knowledge of this cubing community. I think you forget the "sleepers", i.e. the people who were fast in the early 80s, gave up in the meantime because everybody around them stopped it and who just haven't come across our community. I think there are *lots* of unknown people out there who could solve the cube in <45 seconds. I guess you'll contact the organizers of the course, can you also ask them for the correct URL of the reading material? This one is broken: http://match.stanford.edu/rubik.html The same link appears on the webpage of the author, so maybe it's his "fault" somehow. I'd be interested to see what it is. Cheers! Stefan
436. Re: CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really? (ELL)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 21:40:47 -0000

Actually, I've just found that the "distinct" ELL cases are listed at http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e4.htm and that there are 18 (I'd missed one), so perhaps GRS's numbers shouldn't be taken seriously. Nor mine :( Unfortunately, the CLL cases at http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm have not been reduced in the same way. (Why not?) Mike

438. Re: CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really?
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 23:25:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > On Jessica Fridrich's website, Guus Razoux Schultz states that there > are 21 distinct algorithms for CLL and 17 for ELL. I recently tried > to verify this, but found 23 for CLL. (I agree with 17 for the ELL > case, which is much easier to check.) > > Can anyone here confirm that 21 is correct for CLL? > I don't understand how he can get 21 distinct sequences. In my opinion, there are 24 + 1(solved). See Helmstetter's table: http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bh/cube/solutions_c1.html I have hints about symetries on my page, but it's incomplete: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_3.html Gilles. > Note that for these purposes, 2 algorithms are "distinct" if they are > not related by rotation (naturally), reflection, or "time-reversal": > i.e., inversion of the algorithm -- which may also be combined with > the spatial symmetry operations. > > It wouldn't be hard to write a program to do the check, but probably > it is not worth doing it for just one problem :) > > Mike

I recently tried > > to verify this, but found 23 for CLL. I recently tried > > to verify this, but found 23 for CLL. (I agree with 17 for the ELL > > case, which is much easier to check.) > > > > Can anyone here confirm that 21 is correct for CLL? > > > > > > I don't understand how he can get 21 distinct sequences. In my > opinion, there are 24 + 1(solved). See Helmstetter's table: > > http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bh/cube/solutions_c1.html > > I have hints about symetries on my page, but it's incomplete: > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_3.html > > Gilles. > > > > > > > Note that for these purposes, 2 algorithms are "distinct" if they are > > not related by rotation (naturally), reflection, or "time- reversal": > > i.e., inversion of the algorithm -- which may also be combined with > > the spatial symmetry operations. > > > > It wouldn't be hard to write a program to do the check, but probably > > it is not worth doing it for just one problem :) > > > > Mike
441. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5x5 Parity Error
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 20:57:07 -0500

There an alg on the 3-by for flipping over two opposite edges on
the Last Level: R' u R2 u2 R' U2 R u2 R2 u' R U2 (small case letters
mean the middle slices only).

Essentially you are doing something to one piece which messes up
part of the cube, then doing the reverse to the other piece - undoing
the mess.

If I understand your 5-by problem right, rotate your cube (QR) to
put the flipped edges on Last Level. Make the move f' then do the alg
shown above: R' u R2 u2 R' U2 R u2 R2 u' R U2 then move f.

Should I call you "double q double u" for short?

Regards,

David J

When I do f'R'uR2u2R'U2Ru2R2u'RU2f like you suggested, two edges are flipped. Unfortunately, I can do that,
but I need to keep the edges unflipped but flip the pieces between the edges and the corners.

I realized, though, that actually the parity move used in the 4^3 to flip a single edge would work for this situation.
It looks like it only comes up 10% of the time, oddly enough, but when it does I'll just do the extra 15 moves.

You can call me "double q double u" if you want, but I'd prefer mzrg or qq.

--MZRG


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



442. Re: CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really?
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 03:10:25 -0000


Hi Mike,

I am glad you are interested in CLL>ELL approach.

http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e4.htm
My ELL page is one of my oldest pages from my 25-year-old memmory.

http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm
CLL page was made from Ron's site with some modification.

I initially made these pages to learn CLL>ELL system for myself.
Since ELL recognition is much easier than CLL, and
reverse and mirror movements are also not difficult,
I didn't add those reverse and mirros.

I was new for CLL when I made this page.
My purpose was not categorization but easy recognition,
so I included reverse and mirrors as different algorithms.
As you see in my another page, you can find more algorithms for ELL.

To answer your question, I checked all reverse and mirror cases.
21 for CLL seems correct.

>From my site,
http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm
I can reduce the number as follow if I count reverse and mirrors in
one group.
4 corners oriented: 2 cases from 2.
2 corners oriented: 9 cases from 18.
1 corner oriented: 3 cases from 12.
no corner oriented: 7 cases from 10.
Total: 21 cases.


Masayuki Akimoto

445. Re: CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really??????
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 08:58:06 -0000



Hi Masayuki,

> [...]
> To answer your question, I checked all reverse and mirror cases.
> 21 for CLL seems correct.

Wow, you confirm it's 21??!!?!?

> From my site,
> http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm
> I can reduce the number as follow if I count reverse and mirrors in
> one group.
> 4 corners oriented: 2 cases from 2.
> 2 corners oriented: 9 cases from 18.
> 1 corner oriented: 3 cases from 12.
> no corner oriented: 7 cases from 10.
> Total: 21 cases.

I must be blind, I can't see how you can compute 21. For example, with
1 corner oriented, I agree with the total of 12 cases (rotations
excluded). But take these 5 sequences (from your page):
- R'U2RUR'UR
- B'U2BL'BLB'UB'UB
- RB'R'BU2BU2B'
- R'FU2F'RFR'U2RF'
- BU'F'UB'U'F

How can you reduce them to only 3?


Gilles.







446. Re: CLL+ELL... how many algorithms really?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 10:39:25 -0000


Hi all!

The fact that there is some dispute does suggest that the problem
isn't completely trivial ;)

Thanks, Gilles, for pointing me to Helmstetter's tables -- the
website address I had for these was dead. I've checked and found
that I made an error on Helmstetter's cases 20 and 21, which had made
me think they were equivalent.

So there do seem to be 24 nontrivial, "distinct" patterns.

Masayuki: thanks for explaining why you didn't reduce the corners
cases -- recognition does seem difficult to me (perhaps _too_
difficult), so your table should be helpful, if I start using this
technique for LL.

Ryan: the CLL table at www.speedcubing.com doesn't take account of
reflection/inversion, so it has the same 42 cases that Masayuki
lists.

Mike





447. Re: Troubles in the land of F2L
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:57:13 -0000

Hi Dwayne, I recognize this problem from when I began cubing. After the cross, I would sometimes freeze for a couple of seconds. The transition between cross and first CE-pair is really crucial. I think Chris' tips, and a lot of practice will really help you out with that. I general, you should remember that, even though we call it 'speedcubing', turning speed is not the most important. There should be a balance between your turning speed and smoothness/being relaxed. Good luck, Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Hey all, > > Does anyone have any suggestions for recognizing the first pair after the cross is done when completing F2L? I seem to be taking the longest time, on average with the first pair then my wasted time seems to get better as I move onto next pair. > i.e. > > - 1st pair longest > - 2nd pair not as long as 1st pair > - 3rd pair not as long as 2nd pair > - 4th pair not as long as 3rd pair > > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
448. How long does it take to become really fast?
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 17:47:31 -0000


Hey all!

I have been cubing since May last year and quite quickly got into
speedcubing. I found Lars Petrus site and liked the idea (and his
javacubes =D ) so I started using his method.

I´m still using his method and for the moment I average around 35
seconds with my best times a little under 30. I have now started to
train on different things I know I need to improve on. My biggest
problem is to be able to stay one step ahead all the time. For the
moment it feels a bit frustruating because I feel that I´m not
improving at all.

So how long did it take for you to reach sub-30 and sub-20 averages?
And every advice on how to practice is also more than welcome.

Mikael





449. Re: [Speed cubing group] How long does it take to become really fast?
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 10:02:09 -0800 (PST)

nice man :) i originally used lars method too. but the trouble i had was that i could not find the pieces for the 2x2 block fast enough :( i switched to fridrich system and have been using it ever since, took me 4 weeks learn everything, f2l,oll and pll and about another 4 weeks to master it (frankly you start forgeting oll :D ) yeah takes about 2 months of extreme dedication to achieve sub-30 with sacrifices of course, in all you will need about half a year or a full year if you cube "normally" to get under 20, personally my average is 26.78, and my best single solves were 18.17, 19.23. 18.40 :P remember looking ahead really, no two ways about that and plz go slow on the f2l laterz! practice practice! --- mikaelnybrg <stobe_98@...> wrote: > > Hey all! > > I have been cubing since May last year and quite > quickly got into > speedcubing. I found Lars Petrus site and liked the > idea (and his > javacubes =D ) so I started using his method. > > I���m still using his method and for the moment I > average around 35 > seconds with my best times a little under 30. I have > now started to > train on different things I know I need to improve > on. My biggest > problem is to be able to stay one step ahead all the > time. For the > moment it feels a bit frustruating because I feel > that I���m not > improving at all. > > So how long did it take for you to reach sub-30 and > sub-20 averages? > And every advice on how to practice is also more > than welcome. > > Mikael > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Meet the all-new My Yahoo! - Try it today! http://my.yahoo.com

452. LL Algorithms
From: albuscorvus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 20:21:00 -0000


Hey all. Just like to mention how thrilled I am that I found a
speedcubing community out there. Hopefully I can get good enough to
at least compete in a tournament one day. It would be fun.

This is currently the method I am using:
1. Cross
2. 3 Corners
3. 3 Edges
4. Final Corner
5. Final Edge
6. Orient Edges
7. Orient Corners
8. Permute All

I have pretty much plateaued at about 40-41 seconds for an average
solve time. I now want to start learning solving the F2L in corner-
edge pairs.

My question is what algorithms do the quickest speed cubers learn?

I was look at some of the algorithms out there for solving the F2L,
like the ones at speedcubing.com. Then I ran across Nathan Christie's
Optimized F2L algorithms in which each case is solved by a series of
triggers. This method seems much superior to me. Not only are you
able to execute the triggers very quickly, but they also seem easier
to memorize. Most cases are solved with one of five triggers on
either the R or F sides with a couple of U turns thrown in.

Any opinions either way?

Thanks.






453. Re: JNetCube
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 20:35:06 -0000


> I need to re-install JNetCube after rebuilding my laptop. Is the
> version in the Files section of this group the latest version? I
> vaguely remember something about there being a standalone version
> and a connected version? Is this correct? I'm actually after a
> standalone version.

You can download the latest version of JNetCube here:

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/jnetcube.html

The link to the latest Java Runtime Environment is on that page too,
so you can grab that if you need it.

If you are running Windows, then you can execute JNetCube by just
double-clicking the JNetCube.jar (after you have installed the latest
JRE).

-Chris

456. RE: [Speed cubing group] LL Algorithms
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 22:17:33 -0000

Hi, If you solve with the cross on bottom, then I personally believe that the quickest algorithms are those that involve R, U and F only. Maybe some fast cubers would look at and use my algorithms (although I cannot really take credit for them as I initially learnt how to solve the F2L using Peter Jansen's pages at http://www.speedcubing.com/peter/AllesFastTwoLayer.html ), I am quite fast myself and I have had a lot of positive feedback. You can find my F2L pages at www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and look at the algorithm section in the orange panel. Also Lars Vandenbergh has a great set of algorithms for the Last Layer, his page is at www.cubezone.be <http://www.cubezone.be/> Dan Harris :-) _____ From: albuscorvus [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 26 January 2005 20:21 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] LL Algorithms Hey all. My question is what algorithms do the quickest speed cubers learn? I was look at some of the algorithms out there for solving the F2L, like the ones at speedcubing.com. Then I ran across Nathan Christie's Optimized F2L algorithms in which each case is solved by a series of triggers. This method seems much superior to me.
