457. Re: LL Algorithms
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 22:45:13 -0000

Hey there, Nathan Christies algorithms look nice, but they are definitely not superiour to other F2L algorithms. In fact, I think the algorithms are really the same, but his notations shows that a lot of algoritms are 'macros' of 'triggers' or elementary moves. You also mentioned that it can be favourable to execute the algrithms really fast, but for the F2L (especially the first two CE pairs), that doesn't sound like a very good idea to me, because I usually get better times if I go a little slower during F2L. I started learning the F2L algorithms on Jessica Fridrich's page, but I think speedcubing.com or cubestation.co.uk would not be a very bad choice. On Dan's website, look at the applets to see what's happening to the pieces. Learning the F2L alg's without understanding them won't do you much good. Oh yeah, I don't really know you need to learn extra algoritms to get to 25-30 seconds. I know a speedcuber who uses your method, and averages in the lower 20's. All it takes is a good cube and lot's of practice ;). (But should also mention that the cuber I am talking about has a lot of cubing experience). Good luck, Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, albuscorvus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey all. Just like to mention how thrilled I am that I found a > speedcubing community out there. Hopefully I can get good enough to > at least compete in a tournament one day. It would be fun. > > This is currently the method I am using: > 1. Cross > 2. 3 Corners > 3. 3 Edges > 4. Final Corner > 5. Final Edge > 6. Orient Edges > 7. Orient Corners > 8. Permute All > > I have pretty much plateaued at about 40-41 seconds for an average > solve time. I now want to start learning solving the F2L in corner- > edge pairs. > > My question is what algorithms do the quickest speed cubers learn? > > I was look at some of the algorithms out there for solving the F2L, > like the ones at speedcubing.com. Then I ran across Nathan Christie's > Optimized F2L algorithms in which each case is solved by a series of > triggers. This method seems much superior to me. Not only are you > able to execute the triggers very quickly, but they also seem easier > to memorize. Most cases are solved with one of five triggers on > either the R or F sides with a couple of U turns thrown in. > > Any opinions either way? > > Thanks.

460. A variation on the Petrus Method.
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 00:50:09 -0000


I have added a set of algs to the files section to go along with this
description. I made the document on Open Office. Hopefully it works
ok if opened with MS Word, or whatever you happen to use. The file is
called WinterVariation.

The algs come into play after you have completed step 3 in Lars
Petrus's method (twisting the edges). http://www.lar5.com/cube/index.html

So at this point, you have a 2x2x3 block, and all the remaining edges
are properly oriented.

Next, solve the RD edge along with the RDB+RB corner-edge pair, using
R and U moves only, as per the Petrus Method.

Pair up the RDF+RF corner edge pair in the U layer, but DO NOT SOLVE.
Park it in the LUF+FU position. Again, U and R moves only.

Look for U facelets (i.e., U color) on the RFD, RFU, RBU corners. You
don't have to peek at the D facelet of RFD or the B facelet of RBU.
Find the corresponding pattern in the Alg list and do that alg. 1 of
27 algs, average of 8.6 moves.

If you have done this correctly, You will have solved the RFD corner
edge pair, as well as Orientating the Last Layer, leaving only PLL to
complete.

I don't know how well this variation performs, as I solve using a
Corners First method, so I don't know any PLL algs. A few of the
cases are marked with a *, which means that there might be a shorter
alg out there for that case.

Hopefully, this will be of some use to someone, or at the very least,
of mild interest.

Lucas










461. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: LL Algorithms
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 17:02:18 -0800

Hello, For the F2L algs, I would recomend trying to figure most of them out on your own. Try to figure out most of the cases, and understand what is happening. For ones you can't figure out, find an alg online, but don't just choose the first one you see. Try a couple different ones to find the one that works the best with your hands. And of course, when you learn a F2L alg, make sure you understand how it works, and then you can apply those tactics to other positions as well. After figuring out the F2L, then you can go back and learn algs to replace ones that you find are awkward, or too slow. F2L, in my opinion, is the hardest step of the Fridrich system. So be patient, learn the algs well, and just keep practicing. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 22:45:13 -0000, joel_vn <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > Hey there, > > Nathan Christies algorithms look nice, but they are definitely not > superiour to other F2L algorithms. In fact, I think the algorithms > are really the same, but his notations shows that a lot of algoritms > are 'macros' of 'triggers' or elementary moves. You also mentioned > that it can be favourable to execute the algrithms really fast, but > for the F2L (especially the first two CE pairs), that doesn't sound > like a very good idea to me, because I usually get better times if I > go a little slower during F2L. > > I started learning the F2L algorithms on Jessica Fridrich's page, > but I think speedcubing.com or cubestation.co.uk would not be a very > bad choice. On Dan's website, look at the applets to see what's > happening to the pieces. Learning the F2L alg's without > understanding them won't do you much good. > > Oh yeah, I don't really know you need to learn extra algoritms to > get to 25-30 seconds. I know a speedcuber who uses your method, and > averages in the lower 20's. All it takes is a good cube and lot's of > practice ;). (But should also mention that the cuber I am talking > about has a lot of cubing experience). > > Good luck, > > Joel. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, albuscorvus > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey all. It would be fun. > > > > This is currently the method I am using: > > 1. Cross > > 2. 3 Corners > > 3. 3 Edges > > 4. Final Corner > > 5. Final Edge > > 6. Orient Edges > > 7. Orient Corners > > 8. Permute All > > > > I have pretty much plateaued at about 40-41 seconds for an average > > solve time. I now want to start learning solving the F2L in corner- > > edge pairs. > > > > My question is what algorithms do the quickest speed cubers learn? > > > > I was look at some of the algorithms out there for solving the > F2L, > > like the ones at speedcubing.com. 462. Re: A variation on the Petrus Method.
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 11:03:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I have added a set of algs to the files section to go along with this > description. I made the document on Open Office. Hopefully it works > ok if opened with MS Word, or whatever you happen to use. The file is > called WinterVariation. > > The algs come into play after you have completed step 3 in Lars > Petrus's method (twisting the edges). http://www.lar5.com/cube/index.html > > So at this point, you have a 2x2x3 block, and all the remaining edges > are properly oriented. > > Next, solve the RD edge along with the RDB+RB corner-edge pair, using > R and U moves only, as per the Petrus Method. > > Pair up the RDF+RF corner edge pair in the U layer, but DO NOT SOLVE. > Park it in the LUF+FU position. Again, U and R moves only. > > Look for U facelets (i.e., U color) on the RFD, RFU, RBU corners. You > don't have to peek at the D facelet of RFD or the B facelet of RBU. > Find the corresponding pattern in the Alg list and do that alg. 1 of > 27 algs, average of 8.6 moves. > > If you have done this correctly, You will have solved the RFD corner > edge pair, as well as Orientating the Last Layer, leaving only PLL to > complete. > > I don't know how well this variation performs, as I solve using a > Corners First method, so I don't know any PLL algs. A few of the > cases are marked with a *, which means that there might be a shorter > alg out there for that case. > > Hopefully, this will be of some use to someone, or at the very least, > of mild interest. > > Lucas Hi Lucas, When I was using Petrus + orient corners + PLL, I considered orienting the corners this way, but it was too many sequences for too little improvement (and you have to learn symetrical sequences when finishing with RDB+RB). (Solve RDF+RF) + (orient corners) = ?1 + 7.7 moves (including many suprafast Sunes). (Position RDF+RF at LUF+FU) + (insert + orient corners) = ?2 + 8.6 moves. ?1 <= ?2 + (RU'R'). I would be surprised if we can save more than 2 moves. Anyway, thanks for the document, even if Word can't read it :-) Working with corners in different layers is *very* interesting, even if not always useful in speedcubing, because there so many powerful corner sequences based on a very simple move like RU'R'U that changes 4 corners (and swaps 3 edges). Such a macromove is a cornerstone of corner management: (RU2R') RU'R'U (RU2R')' --> RUR'URU2R' (Sune) (RU2R') R'FRF' (RU2R')' --> RU2R2FRF'RU2R (another well known one) ...and so many other more or less obvious combinations that can explain obscure CLL given by ACube... Gilles.
463. Re: LL Algorithms (how fast is "working corner"?)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 12:16:07 -0000


I guess that, to average in the low 20s, the cubist Joel knows must
be doing F2L in about 15sec (or even less?) using the working corner
method. This seems remarkable. It would be interesting to know how
fast other users of this method are, on the F2L stage. There must be
a few, or others who have tried it as a variation.

After a few hours' practice, I find that the F2L alone averages in
the high 20s for me. Pretty awful (the cross is not the problem,
btw), but will persevere with this for a while...

Mike





464. Re: LL Algorithms (how fast is "working corner"?)
From: albuscorvus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 13:08:18 -0000


Thanks to everyone's replies.

I agree with taking time to understand how the F2L algorithms work.
My learning process, since first learning to solve the cube on my
own, until the stage I'm at now, has been pretty organic. I find the
more intuitive it is, the more I'm likely to go quicker.

Averaging in the low 20's using the working corner method for the F2L
is impressive if true. I doubt very much I will ever be able to do
that. If you count every little twist while doing this, it comes out
to 4 twists a second. It takes me on average 85ish twists to solve
the cube.







465. Re: LL Algorithms (how fast is "working corner"?)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 14:08:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, albuscorvus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > It takes me on average 85ish twists to solve > the cube. Um... your last 3 steps should average around 26-27 total using optimal sequences (please correct me if I'm wrong -- maybe you count a half-turn as 2 "twists" instead?). So F2L with working corner is taking 58-59 turns on average. Seems high :s I'll try counting the turns this evening... Mike

471. Re: Cube Virus???
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 21:42:54 -0000

that's happened a lot to me.... I think there's something screwy with this yahoo group, because I've gotten viruses that are allegedly from people in this group, and a few people in this group have said to have gotten ones from me. you should just do what you do with all spam, and ignore it/delete it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > > I got a message in my inbox from someone called CubeCrazy. (That's > the only reason I suspect it might have originated here.) > > Anyway, there was a screensaver attached to the message and Norton > detected a virus in it. > > Just warning you.

476. No Subject
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 04:17:46 -0000

I've only listened to the first half (56k modem, sigh) but so far I like it :-) You make much more sense than me (I've been interviewed recently, too, and regret having said some bad things ;-). Just one tiny comment... "The idea to make things simpler in terms of blindfolding is not to memorize the cube in colors but to convert all the information to numbers." When will people finally realize that numbers are just as abstract as colors? I don't say it's wrong to do that (though I personally dislike it) but it's by no means the only way to do it... :-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/tysonradio.mp3 > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
477. Re:
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 04:53:40 -0000

I agree with Stefan on this particular point, though I haven't heard the interview yet (downloading as I type). I try to memorize in such a way that during the solving phase I have as few "conversions" as possible. What I mean by a conversion is say having to convert the numbers 3 4 5 into the cycle UR->UF->DB etc.. I just try to memorize the cycle UR->UF->DB since that is direct memorization, whereas memorizing as a cycle (345) means I have to later convert those numbers into an actual cycle on the cube. Personally it helped my success rate and times both to memorize such that there are as few conversions as possible during the solving phase. Again that is just my two cents, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've only listened to the first half (56k modem, sigh) but so far I > like it :-) You make much more sense than me (I've been interviewed > recently, too, and regret having said some bad things ;-). > > Just one tiny comment... > > "The idea to make things simpler in terms of blindfolding is not to > memorize the cube in colors but to convert all the information to > numbers." > > When will people finally realize that numbers are just as abstract as > colors? I don't say it's wrong to do that (though I personally > dislike > it) but it's by no means the only way to do it... > > :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/tysonradio.mp3 > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology

479. Conference Cubing for Cash
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 06:15:30 -0000


Last spring, I had the chance to do some (more or less) public
cubing. A company that exhibits at the PLRB/LIRB Claims Conference
(see http://www.claimsconf.org/ for more conference details) had
promotional (picture) cubes made that they were handing out to those
that visited their booth. I was there as their "cube expert", and
got paid to sit around solving my cube all day. Dan Knights did this
for them previously, when the conference was in his area.

If you are in the San Antonio, Texas area, and would be interested in
participating in this years conferences (being held April 17-20),
send me a private e-mail (preferably, since I don't tend to keep up
with this group right now) so I can put you in touch with the person
who organized it all for me last year. When I did it, I was at the
conference for two days, about 5-6 hours each day, and it paid pretty
well :-)

481. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cube Virus???
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 07:50:21 +0000

At 23:42 27/01/2005, you wrote: >yeh, it happens quite often... >-bm > >Michael Atkinson <unipsycho6@...> wrote: > >that's happened a lot to me.... I think there's something screwy with >this yahoo group, because I've gotten viruses that are allegedly from >people in this group, and a few p Seems odd that only a few people in the group are getting these - if it was someone's contact list being used to send the mail to the speed cubing group as a whole wouldn't it go to everyone on the list? Maybe it's someone who has you in their contacts but who is not on the list - remember e-mail viruses spoof both subject line and e-mail address. This is happening on other groups I'm on and is causing a lot of trouble with people unsubbing because they think the group is infected when it isn't. Anyway the advice is correct - delete without opening. Set your e-mail client to read as text only and that will give added protection because scripts can't run in a text only environment. Moderators please tell me if this posting is not OK, I'm new to the group but I'm something of an expert in virus security because I help out at an antivirus software forum elsewhere and have also taken a full course in computer security (in the autumn of last year) at one of the web schools. Must get my cube out this weekend and play with it:) need to practise. Gillian Gillian Buchanan Tatting Editor at Bella Online http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting http://www.craftsnlace.net
482. Re: LL Algorithms (how fast is "working corner"?)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 09:19:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, albuscorvus > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It takes me on average 85ish twists to solve > > the cube. > > Um... your last 3 steps should average around 26-27 total using > optimal sequences (please correct me if I'm wrong -- maybe you count > a half-turn as 2 "twists" instead?). So F2L with working corner is > taking 58-59 turns on average. Seems high :s > > I'll try counting the turns this evening... > > Mike Tried counting turns for working corner F2L, but going slowly to avoid mistakes such as removing edges that have accidentally become correctly placed. There were a few lucky (?) cases and no awkward ones in this series: 40 38 31 36 28 44 28 25 43 39 29 34 28 34 38 22 40 47 30 30, average 34.2 Also, corner placements were chosen to keep middle layer edges out of the middle layer, or to remove incorrectly placed ones. So this is not representative of what I usually manage to do -- I'd guess that it normally takes about 45+ turns on average, which wouldn't make 15sec unreasonable for F2L even so. My slow time is probably just from pauses (slow recognition) and low turning speed. It would be interesting to know what an expert could do. Mike

485. [Speed cubing group] Re:
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 18:23:29 -0000

In my defense, converting into numbers helps memorizing EP _so much_ (no need to "tap" the pieces to make sure I haven't missed anything), at least for me. Converting numbers back is not a problem for me since I can normally do this for the next cycle while performing one...kind of like "looking ahead" for blindfold. The only times that I don't use numbers is when the cycles are very symmetrical and easy to remember. Even then, I find that it's faster to memorize the first or the last few using numbers. ...and when I say numbers, I mean Japanese! =) Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I don't blindfold!!! I was quoting Macky! > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jan 27, 2005, at 8:53 PM, cmhardw wrote: > > > > > > > I agree with Stefan on this particular point, though I haven't heard > > the interview yet (downloading as I type). > > > > I try to memorize in such a way that during the solving phase I have > > as few "conversions" as possible. 486. [Speed cubing group] Re: (bld memorization)
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 20:55:33 -0000



For what it's worth I have no problem at all 'converting' the
numbers into pieces.

Actually I use a four-part memorization system:
- Corner Orientation visually,
- edge orientation either visually or numerically
- corner permutation I memorize by numbers and
- edge perumtation I memorize by letters.

I start memorizing with corner perm because it is the fastest way
(for me) to establish the parity question. If supersolving blind
then I start with center orientation for the same reason.

I use a tweaked form of the Major system (which Lucas directed me to
a while back on this forum - thanks).

1 - d
2 - n
3 - m
4 - r

5 - l
6 - sh
7 - k
8 - f

9 - p
(10 - g)
(11 - t)
(12 - w-z)

The last three are in brackets because they are my own code. With
just a little practise I got used to "reading" the UF piece
(white/blue for me) as "d". There is thus no need for me
to 'convert' from d to UF / White/Blue because for me it is a simple
identification - 'd' and 'd' always goes into UF. I memorize the
edges by cycles and always as pairs since I solve exclusively by
three cycles - thus memorizing in pairs gives me all the info I need
for any one element of my solution.

Hope this makes a little sense - I am in a hurry so I am just typing
off the top of my head.

My main point is that I memorize by numbers AND letters, but have no
problems at all with conversions (because I don't convert - I
identify). It also helps prevent cross-contamination of memorizaion
between corner cycles and edge cycles. Also, to look beyond the
3x3x3, memorization by letters - and then converting letters into
strange stories is very helpful for remembering the info for bigger
cubes.

There is no one way of memorizing. Figure out what works best for
you.


Rob

490. Blindfold cubing
From: kyuubree <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 04:07:20 -0000


I can actually do this in an average of 1 minute and 30 seconds now.
I will be making a website soon with my method. Stay tuned;
memorization is not bad at all!

But for that method, I found that memorizing shapes was much easier
than doing numbers. Or, if you're a number person, find some sort of
pattern that you can remember. For example, if I see the
string "486" I will think of a computer (a 486) or like a "236" I
will think 2 * 3 = 6. Whatever methods work for you, go for it. As
long as you can make mental associations, memorization is easier to
handle.

From: kyuubree <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 04:09:56 -0000

compliment your eye-hand coordination!). Although you can play the
game on the keyboard too.





492. Re: LL Algorithms (how fast is "working corner"?)
From: "Andy C" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 04:51:01 -0000


My fastest time with this method is 23 seconds. If I had to guess what my
average was, I would guess 28 to 30 seconds. I'm sure I would be faster if I
practiced it all the time, but I use the Fridrich method in practice.

Andy

http://andyscubepage.tk

495. My new website
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 18:35:07 -0000


Hello everybody,

I have just completed a new website last week, and it's online now.
The biggest part of it is a pretty big section about a beginner's
solution for the cube. It's rather large, and in that section, I
explain why that is. If you guys can take a look at it, and give me
some comments on what I can improve, I'dd appreciate it. Here's the
link:

www.solvethecube.co.uk

I am planning a couple of more (small) updates in the future, but I
don't know how much free time I'll have the next couple of weeks :).

Bye!

Joel. ;)





496. Re: [Speed cubing group] My new website
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 10:55:31 -0800 (PST)

hmmm nice site man :) i love the java applet. one thing though, maybe the orient last layer might be a little difficult for newbies :\ for oll cross, its reasonably easy, but then to orient the corners seems "dodgy". you could teach how to orient the last layer corners using only a sune. and as for last layer pll, only three cycle edge or three cycle corner will do. after all you can keep cycleing corners and edges till you get it right :) later, john lwin --- joel_vn <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > Hello everybody, > > I have just completed a new website last week, and > it's online now. > The biggest part of it is a pretty big section about > a beginner's > solution for the cube. It's rather large, and in > that section, I > explain why that is. If you guys can take a look at > it, and give me > some comments on what I can improve, I'dd appreciate > it. Here's the > link: > > www.solvethecube.co.uk > > I am planning a couple of more (small) updates in > the future, but I > don't know how much free time I'll have the next > couple of weeks :). > > Bye! > > Joel. ;) > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Mail - now with 250MB free storage. Learn more. http://info.mail.yahoo.com/mail_250
497. Re: [Speed cubing group] My new website
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 19:17:56 -0000

Hi John, Thanks for taking a look at it, and for your comments. I agree that the methods I present on my page are not really straightforward, and kinda tricky for beginners, but I did that on purpose. Like I said, there are a lot of websites that just give algorithms that can easiliy be memorized. But the moves on my page are more a 'system' rather than just algorithms. They really require the reader to actively think about what's happening... In one way, that is a disadvantage, because a newbie may be looking for something easy. But there a lots of websites that just give algorithms, so making another one is not really original. I did not see that many websites that really explain to a beginner what the moves are really doing to the pieces, so that's why I made this page. I am planning to make another section with some more efficient algorithms for the last layer, though :). And maybe something about working corners. But that would take me some time. Happy cubing, Joel. www.solvethecube.co.uk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@y...> wrote: > hmmm > > nice site man :) i love the java applet. > > one thing though, maybe the orient last layer might be > a little difficult for newbies :\ > > for oll cross, its reasonably easy, but then to orient > the corners seems "dodgy". you could teach how to > orient the last layer corners using only a sune. > > and as for last layer pll, only three cycle edge or > three cycle corner will do. after all you can keep > cycleing corners and edges till you get it right :) > > later, > > john lwin > --- joel_vn <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > Hello everybody, > > > > I have just completed a new website last week, and > > it's online now. > > The biggest part of it is a pretty big section about > > a beginner's > > solution for the cube. It's rather large, and in > > that section, I > > explain why that is. If you guys can take a look at > > it, and give me > > some comments on what I can improve, I'dd appreciate > > it. Here's the > > link: > > > > www.solvethecube.co.uk > > > > I am planning a couple of more (small) updates in > > the future, but I > > don't know how much free time I'll have the next > > couple of weeks :). > > > > Bye! > > > > Joel. ;) > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Mail - now with 250MB free storage. Learn more. > http://info.mail.yahoo.com/mail_250
498. Re: Blindfold cubing
From: kyuubree <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 20:09:30 -0000



> WHAT? I just had a session of about 2:10 average with a very low
> success rate a few days ago. My fastest single is only 1:40. ^^;
> What's your success rate at this speed?
>
> And, I'm a DDR fan, although I'm not half as good as some cubers
here
> are.... ;)
>
> Macky

It's pretty consistent I think... it's no different from speedcubing
in terms of time thresholds, like sometimes you get an "easy" case
which might be a few seconds less, and sometimes you get a "hard"
case which may take anywhere from 10 to even 40 seconds longer.

I don't have a place to upload it but I have a video of me AAAing
Quasar on keyboard at a really high speed and another one of Paranoia
Survivor Max Oni 1.5x rate 2x speed AAA score.





499. Re: [Speed cubing group] My new website
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 12:22:20 -0800

On my site ( http://www.deepcube.tk ) I have a beginner solution as well (although it doesn't look nearly as nice as yours). The method for orienting the last layer though I feel is well explained and easy for new commers. Although I only know of one person who has learned from my website, I have personaly taught somewhere in the range of 100 people, and the method is a mixture of a beginner method that Tyson was teaching people, and a few changes here and there that I feel make it easier to learn. Feel free to use any ideas or parts of the solution that you feel would help with yours. Hope it helps -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Sun, 30 Jan 2005 10:55:31 -0800 (PST), lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...> wrote: > hmmm > > nice site man :) i love the java applet. > > one thing though, maybe the orient last layer might be > a little difficult for newbies :\ > > for oll cross, its reasonably easy, but then to orient > the corners seems "dodgy". you could teach how to > orient the last layer corners using only a sune. > > and as for last layer pll, only three cycle edge or > three cycle corner will do. after all you can keep > cycleing corners and edges till you get it right :) > > later, > > john lwin > --- joel_vn <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > > > > Hello everybody, > > > > I have just completed a new website last week, and > > it's online now. > > The biggest part of it is a pretty big section about > > a beginner's > > solution for the cube. 500. Re: My new website
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 21:31:41 -0000


A very nice site! I like the idea of explaining what moves do and how
they work, good job on that.

I´m sure this will sound very negative but I firmly belive that
constructive critcism is far better than just saying everything is
good.

First of all I think you should devide the beginners solution in
smaller parts (on sub-section / step). This would make it faster to
load and might make it easier to follow, also give the solution more
structure.

You do have a good explanation about your move notation but I couldn´t
find an explanation to the positioning notation (UF,ULF etc.)

Well I think those were the major things I noticed, then there were a
few smaller things. First you have a typo in the last line of step 6 "
you should study the moves fist:" I´m sure you mean first ;)

In the video section I would like some kind of highlighting on the
download-button. Also the videos didn´t work on my computer (I got
sound but no picture) but that could be just me.

In the links section maybe you´d like to add Lars Petrus site as you
make a reference to it in your solution.


But all in all one of the better sites for beginners I´ve come across!

Mikael





501. Re: My new website
From: "joel_vn" <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 21:55:41 -0000

Hi Mikael, Thanks for your response. It doesn't really sound negative, in fact, I agree with you on most things. I am not really sure about how to devide it in parts. But I can imagine that the solution looks more friendly to beginners if I do it in parts, so I'll work on that. I only mention the UL ULF etc. notations very briefly, so maybe I could explain them more clearly, you're probably right on that too. If you see any more typo's, I want to hear about them. The links section can be expanded, but I am not planning to collect all speedcubing links there, I don't want that section to grow large. But indeed, a link to Lars Petrus' site would fit in perfectly. Really, constructive criticism is welcome. (although I must admit, it feels a bit bad to find out I did something 'wrong', I do believe that this type of criticism is usefull, as it can really improve my site :)). Bye, Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > A very nice site! 502. Re: My new website
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 22:40:05 -0000

Hi Joel, I like it very much, it's close to the method I've been thinking of that I think could be taught to non-cubers in an hour or so. For edge permutation, you could add that not only you can use corners as reference (you already say that), but you can see the color of the edge to solve next on the FD sticker. Also, I've thought about turning the top *two* layers between the basic moves instead of just the U layer, i.e. not the goal place comes above the piece, but the piece comes below the goal place. Well, even though I like it as well, it doesn't work for corners and thus it's not very good... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "joel_vn" <joel_vn@y... > wrote: > > Hello everybody, > > I have just completed a new website last week, and it's online now. > The biggest part of it is a pretty big section about a beginner's > solution for the cube. It's rather large, and in that section, I > explain why that is. If you guys can take a look at it, and give me > some comments on what I can improve, I'dd appreciate it. Here's the > link: > > www.solvethecube.co.uk > > I am planning a couple of more (small) updates in the future, but I > don't know how much free time I'll have the next couple of weeks :). > > Bye! > > Joel. ;)

505. [Speed cubing group] Re:
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 23:14:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > > > I don't blindfold!!! > > Well then shame on you!!! > > > I was quoting Macky! > > Well what does *he* know about blindsolving??? > > Cheers! > Stefan 1:38.67 EO: 001010100001 CO: 01120002 CP: (126)(34)(58) EP: (1 7 11 8 12)(3 4)(5 6) Did it just today. ;) Marcus, I would assume that you use something close to Richard Carr's not-even intermediate method (but maybe reduced number of algs by using setup moves), but with very optimized algorithms. Is this correct? I just counted 125 moves using only 3-cycles on a solve with a fairly easy corner orientation. If you can do 3/sec, that's 41 sec for resolution. 35 is probably close to the lower limit for any memorization technique with consistant accuracy, so that gives me 1:16 total on average as the lower limit with the algorithms I know. Except, I can never quite memorize in 35 sec.... Would you also mind telling us what speedcubing method you are using? Macky

It wasn't fast, of course :) Mike

513. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Anyone here a DDR fan?

Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 12:19:23 +0100 (CET)

Hi Per, yeah it took me a while to figure too... it's not a very well-known game in Europe, at least it's not in France. DDR is short for Dance Dance Revolution, a stupid flash game (well I figure there are other versions of it, but I only tried the flash one) where you have to tap the arrows of your keyboard following the rythm of a song, and the computer tells you which arrow you have to tap. There are different songs, different difficulties, sometimes it gets really hard. I bet someone here will know a URL, so you get the idea. François PS. I really suck at that game... 522. Re: Rubik's Clock
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Feb 2005 01:32:34 -0000

I disassemble it, then "paint" (with a paintbrush) all plastic parts with silicon spray. Earlier I sprayed a little cloth and then used that (instead of the paintbrush). It depends on the spray I use... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Does anyone know how to lube a Rubik's Clock? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

526. Cube Spotted
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>

Rubik's cube to good effect.

David J

528. Talk about a weird average
From: "Frank" <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Feb 2005 18:48:36 -0000


So, I think this is a little spooky.

17.12 (17.72) 17.14 17.23 17.59 17.42 17.14 16.53 16.58 (16.41)
16.83 16.67

Average- 17.02

Hmm.. odd.

532. solvetherubikscube.com
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Feb 2005 20:36:40 -0000


Did anyone ever notice this website? Some really funny quotes:

Not Anymore! After reading this guide:
Ø You WILL be able to solve the cube, GUARANTEED!

Yes, one thing that I didn't say was the ENORMOUS REACTIONS RECEIVED
WITH EVERY SOLVE!!!
Yes, in fact, it is LITERALLY IMPOSSIBLE for anyone to not notice
the colorful colors from the cornet of their eye...

They WILL see you solve it.
They WILL get a shock of their life.
And YOU WILL get an applause and you will feel good about yourself.

NO MORE confusing patterns like "R2 D' R' L F2 R L' U2 D R2"!

- Joel.

537. Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Feb 2005 23:45:56 -0000

Joel, you missed the funniest part, which is even highlighted: "less than 1% of the people who have ever owned a Rubik's Cube have never been able to solve it!" That means almost everyone did solve it, right? I don't like people who don't understand negation ;-) And why does he not simply show a picture instead of just writing "And just in case you didn't know what a Rubik's Cube is, it's the six sided cube [blah]" ??? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Did anyone ever notice this website? Some really funny quotes: > > Not Anymore! After reading this guide: > Ø You WILL be able to solve the cube, GUARANTEED! > > Yes, one thing that I didn't say was the ENORMOUS REACTIONS RECEIVED > WITH EVERY SOLVE!!! > Yes, in fact, it is LITERALLY IMPOSSIBLE for anyone to not notice > the colorful colors from the cornet of their eye... > > They WILL see you solve it. > They WILL get a shock of their life. > And YOU WILL get an applause and you will feel good about yourself. > > NO MORE confusing patterns like "R2 D' R' L F2 R L' U2 D R2"! > > - Joel.

I've written the same text in several emails to different people already ;-) Oh why am I so lazy... Cheers! 540. Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 00:59:32 -0000

wow............ just.... wow........ Why do I get the feeling that he will still use the algs R2 D' R' L F2 R L' U2 D R2 and R2 D2 B2 D L2 F2 L2 F2 L2 F2 D' B2 D2 R2 in the solution, but will only "explain how they work" rather than give the notation? I never expected to read anything like that about the cube. ... 542. Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 01:53:10 -0000

And no, this does not mean I suggest to *improve* that solution in the booklet. If you remember a recent thread, I don't have to explain why I'd instead suggest to *remove* that solution. Oh well, I hope people are at least clever enough to look for other solution sites first before giving $15 to that guy. Or, maybe I just have a wrong view of the world. I would never take money for something like that, I'd rather make my stuff as public as possible. I guess I'll never be rich. 543. Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: "Bob R. Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 06:39:34 -0000

In the defense of the solution that comes in the booklet, it is not overly terrible. It is inefficient, but it requires very little learning and CAN be fast. I currently use that method and have gotten sub-30 non-lucky solves with it. :) I will be ditching that solution to something faster, but it was good enough as a beginner. ~Bobby B. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > And no, this does not mean I suggest to *improve* that solution in the > booklet. If you remember a recent thread, I don't have to explain why > I'd instead suggest to *remove* that solution. > > Oh well, I hope people are at least clever enough to look for other > solution sites first before giving $15 to that guy. Or, maybe I just > have a wrong view of the world. I would never take money for something > like that, I'd rather make my stuff as public as possible. I guess > I'll never be rich. > > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > The sad thing is that people who just got a cube might even fall for > > this, because he's unfortunately right in saying that the solution > > that comes in the booklet with the cube is indeed awful (at least I > > think in mine even the single turning symbols were unreadable thanks > > to a bad font or maybe textual symbols where images were intended to > > be?)... > > > > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y.. > .> > > wrote: > > > > > > wow............ just.... wow........ > > > > > > Why do I get the feeling that he will still use the algs R2 D' R' > L > > F2 > > > R L' U2 D R2 and R2 D2 B2 D L2 F2 L2 F2 L2 F2 D' B2 D2 R2 in the > > > solution, but will only "explain how they work" rather than give > the > > > notation? > > > > > > I never expected to read anything like that about the cube. > > > > > > ... > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Joel, you missed the funniest part, which is even highlighted: > > > > > > > > "less than 1% of the people who have ever owned a Rubik's Cube > > have > > > > never been able to solve it!" > > > > > > > > That means almost everyone did solve it, right? 544. '82 revenge
From: andrew barnhart <abarnhart2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 1 Feb 2005 22:50:53 -0800 (PST)

Does anyone have an original 1982 revenge?

I got what i thought was one on ebay, but on close
inspection the white sticker with the name and the
blue sticker that says I.T.C 1982 made in hong kong
are placed over blank stickers of the same color. I
think i have been frauded. It did look in abnormally
good condition, and was cheap.

If anyone has a revenge they know is from 1982, could
you look and see if the stickers with text are placed
over others? i suppose its possible thats just how
they were made.

thanks

Andrew

545. Re: [Speed cubing group] '82 revenge
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Feb 2005 09:23:06 +0100 (CET)

Hey Andrew, I'm not totally sure about that, cuz I don't have one myself, but I used to borrow one from a friend, and noticed the same thing. So I figure that's just the way they were done, at least the Hong Kong ones. You may want a Hungarian one, because they're known to be a lot better, although I never owned one either, so... Well. The Rubiksdotcom ones are also ok. François andrew barnhart <abarnhart2000@...> wrote: Does anyone have an original 1982 revenge? I got what i thought was one on ebay, but on close inspection the white sticker with the name and the blue sticker that says I.T.C 1982 made in hong kong are placed over blank stickers of the same color. I think i have been frauded. It did look in abnormally good condition, and was cheap. If anyone has a revenge they know is from 1982, could you look and see if the stickers with text are placed over others? i suppose its possible thats just how they were made. thanks Andrew __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? 546. Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 09:25:26 -0000

Stefan! That page does indeed show many cubes right at the top of the page ... lol ... 547. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: solvetherubikscube.com
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 09:52:42 +0000

At 06:39 02/02/2005, you wrote:


>In the defense of the solution that comes in the booklet, it is not
>overly terrible. It is inefficient, but it requires very little
>learning and CAN be fast. I currently use that method and have
>gotten sub-30 non-lucky solves with

Quite apart from anything else I don't know if you realise that that web
site is a copy of some of the stuff people put up to get you to buy e-books
software - and those web sites are usually complete cons. You know the
sort of thing - "you too can make £40,000 a year if you buy this software
to make e-books and use viral marketing to sell them" type of stuff. In
fact I'm sure I've seen that particular page up somewhere but worded and
styled just like that (apart from the badly coded background image) to sell
the e-book software.

Gillian


Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net



548. Re: [Speed cubing group] '82 revenge
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Feb 2005 06:38:48 -0500

No, definitely not.

Original Ideal Toy Rubik's Revenge had an
extra blue sticker and an extra white sticker with
printing on it.

You can also tell by the thickness of the vinyl.
Original Revenge had thicker vinyl than the more
modern version.

Mark

On February 2, 2005 01:50 am, andrew barnhart wrote:
> Does anyone have an original 1982 revenge?
>
> I got what i thought was one on ebay, but on close
> inspection the white sticker with the name and the
> blue sticker that says I.T.C 1982 made in hong kong
> are placed over blank stickers of the same color. I
> think i have been frauded. It did look in abnormally
> good condition, and was cheap.

> you look and see if the stickers with text are placed
> over others? i suppose its possible thats just how
> they were made.

549. Re: [Speed cubing group] '82 revenge
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 14:40:44 -0000

Hey! Unless u are some sort of collector does it matter if it's an original 1982 Revenge cube as long as the cube is reasonably good. In fact i find that newer 4x4x4 cubes are better than the old 1982. The center cubies are stronger on recent ones. And also can be more easily repaired/glued. For most speedcubers anyway it matters most what color-arrangement the stickers are. Most prefer the "BOY" color scheme. Blue opposite green, orange opposite red and yellow opposite white. And with blue, orange, yellow in clockwise order around a corner. One way to be sure to get a real 1982 Revenge cube is to order one from Ton Dennenbroek (www.speedcubing.com/ton). Hmm ... it seems he no longer sells them. But u can contact him anyway :-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mark Longridge <zero1@l...> wrote: > No, definitely not. > > Original Ideal Toy Rubik's Revenge had an > extra blue sticker and an extra white sticker with > printing on it. > > You can also tell by the thickness of the vinyl. > Original Revenge had thicker vinyl than the more > modern version. > > Mark > > On February 2, 2005 01:50 am, andrew barnhart wrote: > > Does anyone have an original 1982 revenge? > > > > I got what i thought was one on ebay, but on close > > inspection the white sticker with the name and the > > blue sticker that says I.T.C 1982 made in hong kong > > are placed over blank stickers of the same color. I > > think i have been frauded. It did look in abnormally > > good condition, and was cheap. > > > > If anyone has a revenge they know is from 1982, could > > you look and see if the stickers with text are placed > > over others? i suppose its possible thats just how > > they were made. > > > > thanks > > > > Andrew > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > > Do you Yahoo!? > > Take Yahoo! 553. Re: [Speed cubing group] '82 revenge
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 17:25:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > One way to be sure to get a real 1982 Revenge cube is to order one > from Ton Dennenbroek (www.speedcubing.com/ton). Hmm ... it seems he > no longer sells them. But u can contact him anyway :-) You should be able to get them on German Ebay from the inventor himself for about 25 Euros: http://search.ebay.de/_W0QQsassZveroccio A while back a friend of mine and I bought two and since we live close to him, we even got to meet him, which was quite nice, we talked for a while in a cafe. You'll also get a copy of an old document (see the pics) which says his name (Peter Sebesteny) as inventor. And a sticker with a greeting and signed by him, which you can put on the box or whatever if you want to. Cheers! Stefan

561. Corners First
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 20:51:54 -0000


Hi All, is there anyone here who is at or near sub-20 using a corners
method. I can get to about 23-24 sec using an accelerated corner
starter but I have to do the slice moves at blinding speed while I
can get the same result with F2L going much slower. I've seen a
David Allen video made during the Toronto WC and can't imagine how
anyone could get a sub-17 time using a corner method like he did.

Wayne

564. Re: Corners First
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Feb 2005 23:16:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Wayne" <mylib_2000@y...> wrote: > > Hi All, is there anyone here who is at or near sub-20 using a corners > method. I can get to about 23-24 sec using an accelerated corner > starter but I have to do the slice moves at blinding speed while I > can get the same result with F2L going much slower. I've seen a > David Allen video made during the Toronto WC and can't imagine how > anyone could get a sub-17 time using a corner method like he did. > > Wayne Well, I don't exactly know the details of the method he (David Allen) uses. But I heard that he can make pretty cool slice moves, yes. But there are other cubers who use corners first methods, and get sub-20 times. Marc Waterman used his corners first method to average around 16 seconds. And Gilles also averages around 16 seconds, although I am not sure if that is really a CF method...

572. BOY cubes
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 3 Feb 2005 12:42:12 -0400

Hey all,

Is the BOY scheme the most popular? I have purchased a "Rubik's Cube" (has logo as shown below) and a "Rubik's Revenge" (also has logo below).

I have read on this web page:
http://www.foxtechcomputers.com/me/rubiks/cubebuyingguide.html
that the 'white-yellow' and 'green-blue' scheme, in his opinion, constitutes about 70% of cubes. Although the 'white-blue' and 'green-yellow' constitutes only about 25% of the cubes. Why does my Rubik's Cube with the official www.rubik.com have the latter scheme (WB & GY), although my Rubik's Revenge has the BOY scheme?



The following cube simulator has the latter scheme as its default http://www.puzzlingaddiction.com/Cube/applet/.

Although it seems that most speedcubers websites have the BOY scheme.


Thanks for feedback on the weird cubing habit.
Dwayne



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



573. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: I never thought of that
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 3 Feb 2005 12:05:37 -0500

Chris, It's Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene or ABS plastic. If you google for it you will find that the first electronic calculators had molded ABS housings. I've heard that some of the transparent spindles made from polycarbonate. ABS cubes parts are very tough. Early modders tried polyester resin, which is far more brittle, but it's very cheap. Next we tried polyurethane resin, which works better. It's actually pretty strong when the pieces are solid. Polymer chemicals can be rather nasty to work with. Eye protection and gloves and even a good breathing mask is recommended. Also good vents as the fumes will stink up the place. Not very environmentality friendly. I can see why some puzzle makers prefer working with wood. Mark On February 3, 2005 10:57 am, cmhardw wrote: > By the way I guess that question sounds a little weird now that I read > it again. What I meant by that is what type of plastic is the cube > made from? Does anyone have an idea? > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > I just received an interesting e-mail that I honestly have no answer to. > > > > What, specifically, is a Rubik's cube made of? I don't mean screws, > > paper stickers, and plastic, etc.. Rather, and again very > > specifically, what constitutes the pieces of a cube? > > > > I honestly have no idea. > > > > Chris > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > >
574. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: I never thought of that
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 3 Feb 2005 09:29:16 -0800

I'm waiting for someone to make Teflon cube. It seems like it would be
the ideal material.

Don't let your frying pan fool you. Solid Teflon is hard and durable.
It's a bit expensive for plastics, but material for a cube should just
be around $2.

/Lars

577. [Speed cubing group] Re: I never thought of that
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Feb 2005 18:10:53 -0000

Hey! If $2 is needed for the teflon for one cube, then a teflon cube should in theory cost maximum $2 more than current ones. Except if the molding is that much harder. And maybe parts need to be glued? Is teflon hard to glue? I have no idea about that. And if the plastic is too tough will it be less ideal. What i mean is: will a teflon cube ever break-in in that case? Is teflon more toxic than ABS? Does silicone work as lubricant on teflon? Will silicone be needed at all on teflon? There are many things to consider. And yes, why not titan instead of teflon? Or use a metal like aluminium or magnesium or some other ceramic material ... I have always dreamt of cubes with fused tiles. The tiles could be like on the impossiball so that u can rearrange the colors ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > I'm waiting for someone to make Teflon cube. It seems like it would be > the ideal material. > > Don't let your frying pan fool you. Solid Teflon is hard and durable. > It's a bit expensive for plastics, but material for a cube should just > be around $2. > > /Lars > > On Feb 3, 2005, at 9:05, Mark Longridge wrote: > > > > > Chris, > > > > It's Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene or ABS plastic. If you google for > > it > > you will find that the first electronic calculators had molded ABS > > housings. I've heard that some of the transparent spindles made from > > polycarbonate. > > > > ABS cubes parts are very tough. Early modders tried polyester resin, > > which is > > far more brittle, but it's very cheap. Next we tried polyurethane > > resin, which works better. It's actually pretty strong when the > > pieces are solid. > > > > Polymer chemicals can be rather nasty to work with. Eye protection > > and gloves and even a good breathing mask is recommended. > > Also good vents as the fumes will stink up the place. Not very > > environmentality friendly. 581. RBG and BOY cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Feb 2005 22:54:08 -0000

Hi Dwayne, Inconsistancy has been part and parcel of cube making since it began. At first, on the Polytechnica cubes, there was no "official color scheme." They were all over the map, trying out different colors. I like the purple they tried, and the original yellow. When Ideal started making Rubik's Cubes, the color scheme was RBG, that is, Red opposite Orange, Blue opposite White, and Green opposite Yellow, with one corner Red Blue and Green clockwise (hence the RBG). Of the estimated two or three *hundred million* cubes Ideal made beginning in 1980, most of the cubes were this RBG or Red Blue Green color scheme. All of the Ideal 2x2x2 cubes, 4x4x4 cubes, Deluxe cubes, Rubik's Game/Rubik's Challenge cubes, and all of the C*4 cubes were made with RBG, *not* "BOY" color scheme. RBG is the scheme on the cardboard tube which was used in Britain. At the time that the C*4 cube was introduced Erno Rubik announced that RBG was the official color scheme. Sometimes Ideal had quality control problems, so some of their cubes switched Red and Orange. Ideal cubes made with other schemes were in the minority, like "BYO" and "BOY" schemes, and Orange next to Red (a beautiful cube, see: http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2011%20Ideal%20US%20red%20next%20to%20organe%201980.htm) Seven Towns bought the rights from Ideal, and they make the Hasbro, Winning Moves, Rubiks.com and Oddzon cubes. Something like three years ago Seven Towns changed the "Official" Colors from the RBG scheme to the BOY scheme. Why they did this I don't know. I asked, but got no answer. I believe that fewer than 10 million cubes have been made since the change over. I think that some cubes made before that by Seven Towns had other color schemes, like the 3x3x3 which you have. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Hey all, > > Is the BOY scheme the most popular? I have purchased a "Rubik's Cube" (has logo as shown below) and a "Rubik's Revenge" (also has logo below). > > I have read on this web page: > http://www.foxtechcomputers.com/me/rubiks/cubebuyingguide.html > that the 'white-yellow' and 'green-blue' scheme, in his opinion, constitutes about 70% of cubes. Although the 'white-blue' and 'green-yellow' constitutes only about 25% of the cubes. Why does my Rubik's Cube with the official www.rubik.com have the latter scheme (WB & GY), although my Rubik's Revenge has the BOY scheme? > > > > The following cube simulator has the latter scheme as its default http://www.puzzlingaddiction.com/Cube/applet/. > > Although it seems that most speedcubers websites have the BOY scheme. > > > Thanks for feedback on the weird cubing habit. > Dwayne

585. Re: [Speed cubing group] RBG and BOY cubes
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 4 Feb 2005 01:14:02 -0500

> When Ideal started making Rubik's Cubes, the color scheme was RBG, > that is, Red opposite Orange, Blue opposite White, and Green opposite > Yellow, with one corner Red Blue and Green clockwise (hence the RBG). I like the short form of RGB, that's a term I can remember. > > Of the estimated two or three *hundred million* cubes Ideal made > beginning in 1980, most of the cubes were this RBG or Red Blue Green > color scheme. All of the Ideal 2x2x2 cubes, 4x4x4 cubes, Deluxe cubes, > Rubik's Game/Rubik's Challenge cubes, and all of the C*4 cubes were > made with RBG, *not* "BOY" color scheme. RBG is the scheme on the > cardboard tube which was used in Britain. At the time that the C*4 > cube was introduced Erno Rubik announced that RBG was the official > color scheme. This is a discussion we had on cube-lovers years ago. The "differing by Yellow" scheme was dominant in Europe and in North America & UK it was RGB as you call it. Differing by Yellow (BOY) had a certain logic to it but RGB cubes had better contrast. And of course there is Bela's LGI cubes which on the one I have is: Top = Black Down = Yellow Front = Green Back = Blue Left = Red Right = Orange So I guess this is a BRY cube. > > Sometimes Ideal had quality control problems, so some of their cubes > switched Red and Orange. Ideal cubes made with other schemes were in > the minority, like "BYO" and "BOY" schemes, and Orange next to Red (a > beautiful cube, see: > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2011%20Ideal%20US%20red%20ne >xt%20to%20organe%201980.htm) > > > Seven Towns bought the rights from Ideal, and they make the Hasbro, > Winning Moves, Rubiks.com and Oddzon cubes. Something like three years > ago Seven Towns changed the "Official" Colors from the RBG scheme to > the BOY scheme. Why they did this I don't know. I asked, but got no > answer. Maybe because the original Hungarian cubes had the BOY scheme. It's not that big of a difference, just Blue and Yellow have been transposed. I don't see any reason for just one colour scheme. Which reminds me, were the Rubik's Deluxe cube ever officially approved for cube tournaments? > > I believe that fewer than 10 million cubes have been made since the > change over. I think that some cubes made before that by Seven Towns > had other color schemes, like the 3x3x3 which you have. > > Regards, > > David J > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > Hey all, > > > > Is the BOY scheme the most popular? I have purchased a "Rubik's > > Cube" (has logo as shown below) and a "Rubik's Revenge" (also has logo > below). > > > I have read on this web page: > > http://www.foxtechcomputers.com/me/rubiks/cubebuyingguide.html > > that the 'white-yellow' and 'green-blue' scheme, in his opinion, > > constitutes about 70% of cubes. Although the 'white-blue' and > 'green-yellow' constitutes only about 25% of the cubes. Why does my > Rubik's Cube with the official www.rubik.com have the latter scheme > (WB & GY), although my Rubik's Revenge has the BOY scheme? > > > The following cube simulator has the latter scheme as its default > > http://www.puzzlingaddiction.com/Cube/applet/. > > > Although it seems that most speedcubers websites have the BOY scheme. > > > > > > Thanks for feedback on the weird cubing habit. > > Dwayne > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > >

reasons. The eastsheens are still sold (legally?). So it's mostly
just to demonstrate their power that they ban eastsheen cubes from
competitions.

590. Re: [Speed cubing group] RBG and BOY cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2005 17:38:04 -0000

Hi Mark, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mark Longridge <zero1@l...> wrote: > > > When Ideal started making Rubik's Cubes, the color scheme was RBG, > > that is, Red opposite Orange, Blue opposite White, and Green opposite > > Yellow, with one corner Red Blue and Green clockwise (hence the RBG). > > I like the short form of RGB, that's a term I can remember. Yeah, I sometimes write RGB when I mean RBG. :) > > Of the estimated two or three *hundred million* cubes Ideal made > > beginning in 1980, most of the cubes were this RBG or Red Blue Green > > color scheme. All of the Ideal 2x2x2 cubes, 4x4x4 cubes, Deluxe cubes, > > Rubik's Game/Rubik's Challenge cubes, and all of the C*4 cubes were > > made with RBG, *not* "BOY" color scheme. RBG is the scheme on the > > cardboard tube which was used in Britain. At the time that the C*4 > > cube was introduced Erno Rubik announced that RBG was the official > > color scheme. > > This is a discussion we had on cube-lovers years ago. The "differing by > Yellow" scheme was dominant in Europe and in North America & UK it > was RGB as you call it. Yes the "BOY" scheme tended to turn up in Europe, but I'm not at all sure it was dominant. I have seen several "Made in Hungary" cubes which are not "BOY." RBG was also the dominant scheme in Japan. > Differing by Yellow (BOY) had a certain logic to it Yes it does. And both schemes have the primary colors on one corner. COunterclockwise on BOY and clockwise on RBG. > but RGB cubes had better contrast. > And of course there is Bela's LGI cubes > which on the one I have is: > > Top = Black > Down = Yellow > Front = Green > Back = Blue > Left = Red > Right = Orange > > So I guess this is a BRY cube. You could call it that but there is a BRY Corner on the RBG cubes, since Orange, Red, Blue and Yellow are in the same place on both cubes. How about BBO for the Black Blue and Orange (clockwise) corner? > > Sometimes Ideal had quality control problems, so some of their cubes > > switched Red and Orange. Ideal cubes made with other schemes were in > > the minority, like "BYO" and "BOY" schemes, and Orange next to Red (a > > beautiful cube, see: > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2011%20Ideal%20US%20red%20ne > >xt%20to%20organe%201980.htm) > > > > > > Seven Towns bought the rights from Ideal, and they make the Hasbro, > > Winning Moves, Rubiks.com and Oddzon cubes. Something like three years > > ago Seven Towns changed the "Official" Colors from the RBG scheme to > > the BOY scheme. Why they did this I don't know. I asked, but got no > > answer. > > Maybe because the original Hungarian cubes had the BOY scheme. But they didn't. I have one of the original cubes from Hungary (circa 1977-1978) with the square cut stickers and it is BRY, not BOY. > It's not that big of a difference, just Blue and Yellow have been > transposed. I don't see any reason for just one colour scheme. > > Which reminds me, were the Rubik's Deluxe cube ever officially approved > for cube tournaments? Yes. Any cube which was liscensed to Rubik has been allowed so far. Technically that should include Bela's cubes. Speaking of white plastic cubes...too bad that Seven Towns has no interest in producing the white plastic cubes with arches and screws. That plastic is nearly as slick as teflon-impregnated plastic. I'd love to see the beauties which you sell in tournaments. Hmmm, I may bring mine to the next one at Caltech. Regards, David J > > I believe that fewer than 10 million cubes have been made since the > > change over. I think that some cubes made before that by Seven Towns > > had other color schemes, like the 3x3x3 which you have. > > > > Regards, > > > > David J > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > > Hey all, > > > > > > Is the BOY scheme the most popular? I have purchased a "Rubik's > > > > Cube" (has logo as shown below) and a "Rubik's Revenge" (also has logo > > below). > > > > > I have read on this web page: > > > http://www.foxtechcomputers.com/me/rubiks/cubebuyingguide.html > > > that the 'white-yellow' and 'green-blue' scheme, in his opinion, > > > > constitutes about 70% of cubes. Although the 'white-blue' and > > 'green-yellow' constitutes only about 25% of the cubes. Why does my > > Rubik's Cube with the official www.rubik.com have the latter scheme > > (WB & GY), although my Rubik's Revenge has the BOY scheme? > > > > > The following cube simulator has the latter scheme as its default > > > > http://www.puzzlingaddiction.com/Cube/applet/. > > > > > Although it seems that most speedcubers websites have the BOY scheme. > > > > > > > > > Thanks for feedback on the weird cubing habit. > > > Dwayne > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >
591. Cube jokes
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2005 18:44:20 -0000


Hi all,

I thought maybe we could start posting some cube
jokes. So here's one I wrote. It was inspired by
Stefan Schönwälder in the German speedcuber group.

------------------------------------------------
Cube Joke:


Two women have a chat.

"What kind of man do you prefer?
A mathematician or a speedcuber?"

"A speedcuber of course."

"Why?"

"Well, he'd know all these moves,
the RUR'...how do they call it...
fingertricks?"

"ooooh"

Then a third woman, who has listened
to their conversation says:

"You know what, my boyfriend rather
solves the cube slowly and even blindfolded."

"Ooooooh" the two other women say.

A fourth woman, who has also listened
says:

"Hah, that's nothing. My boyfriend
solves the cube slowly, blindfolded
and with his TONGUE!"

"(o_O)"

-----------------------------------------------------------

-Edgardo





592. Anyone have any pointers for me...
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2005 18:52:15 -0000


It seems that I'm stuck and am not sure how to best speed up my
times. I'm averaging about 75 seconds to solve the cube using Lars
Petus method (slightly modified):
25 seconds for 2x2x2
25 seconds to finish off F2L
25 seconds for LL

Maybe just writing this will help, but I've been at the same times
for about a month.

I think there are three main reasons for my times.
1. Inability to look ahead. Even during a 15 second head start I'm
only able to "see" the placement of two cubicles.

2. Cube over turning or locking. Maybe I'm trying too hard, but I
routinely performing a D2 instead of a D or trying to execute a R
followed by a D and having cubicals bump into each other. I have
several cubes. One of the store bought ones turns a but stiff, which
makes tuning a bit harder, but I rarely have lockups with it. The DIY
cube I bought turns really nice, but locks up when I turn too fast. :(

3. Having a hard time finding a particular cubical even when it's
right in front of me. After doing a 2x2x2 I usually look for the GR
cubical to see if I need to flip it. I sometimes wast 2-3 seconds
just looking around the cube for it.

Maybe I just need more time practicing, though any assistance would
be great.





593. Hello
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2005 19:01:29 -0000



I spent the week in an hospital and had nothing to do but cubing!!!
It was quite odd. A drip tube stuck in my hand, breathing carbon
dioxyde under a mask, eating tranquillizers... but still speed-cubing
like a mad!
I was thinking, just imagine a competition with a competitor using
such an equipment. That would boost media coverage!
(Uh... I think some parapraph should be added to WCA rules about
doping controls)

Ok, I'm out now, and faster :-)

Gilles.

598. Re: [Speed cubing group] RBG and BOY cubes
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2005 23:16:17 -0000

Hey! Yes they would say nothing about westsheen, northsheen, southsheen if they don't look like eastsheen. Of that i'm 100% certain. My point is that ppl should be allowed any kind of cube that is not made in any way made for cheating. Ppl have different preferences and should use the cube they are comfortable with. Olivier Gaucher might for instance have beaten Lars on the 5x5x5 if he was allowed to use his Eastsheen cube. I seriously believe that any sponsor who will restrict the brands of cube used we shouldn't use for our competitions. In fact i was about to not come to Amsterdam cause of this issue. But having cubed since 1981 and missing out the big opportunity of a championship was too sad so i changed my mind thanx to Ron. We live in a free world (for the most part). Let noone decide what brands of cubes to use and not to use in competitions. That is my very simple message. Seventowns are not losing a single penny or cent by allowing eastsheens, so my opinion is that banning those is stupidity. And it's not disrespect of Ernö Rubik either. Most ppl who are not cubists (whatever that is) still would call the Eastsheen a Rubik's cube. That shows how well associated the Rubik name is with cubic/twisting puzzles. And why not call the 4x4x4 Sebesteny cube and the 5x5x5 Krell cube. That would be equally well deserved. Cheers! (hmm Stefan did u copyright that greeting yet? ;-) ) -Per PS! I do indeed prefer Rubiks.com cubes personally but that is beside my point ... > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > I think any cube which is not eastsheen and does not resemble an > > eastsheen cube would be approved by a SevenTowns sponsored event ;-) > > So you say I'd be allowed to use my westsheen cubes, right? > > > So it's mostly > > just to demonstrate their power that they ban eastsheen cubes from > > competitions. > > That sounds like they're just mean. They do make business and they do > have rights, so I think it's understandable if they don't want clones > at their competitions (I'd like to have Megaminx&Co there, though, > which are not clones, at Euro2004 it was only Rubik stuff). I recently > saw a tv interview (cause rubik patented his cube 30 years ago) with a > guy who once worked with rubik and he had lots of eastsheen cubes in > front of him which I think is not very nice... > > Cheers! > Stefan

600. Oll+corners algs?
From: "James Stuber" <jstuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 4 Feb 2005 16:29:32 -0800

Anyone know the algs to orient all of the last layer and permute the
corners? I think there are 280 individual algs?? Then the last layer could
be finished off with an edge cycle, and you wouldn't have to learn ZB or VH
f2l algs. Recognition would be just like COLL, only then you'd have to see
which edges are flipped. I'm working on finding these and it'd be nice if
someone already had them, or what it would average. Thanks!



-James

http://www.stubers.org/jamesstuff/jamesstuff.htm





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



601. Re: [Speed cubing group] RBG and BOY cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 01:36:03 -0000

Hi Per, One of the things that bothers me about the "no eastsheen 2x2x2" rule is that the 2x2x2 was invented (and patented) by Larry Nichols long before Rubik invented the 3x3x3. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > Yes they would say nothing about westsheen, northsheen, southsheen > if they don't look like eastsheen. In fact i was about > to not come to Amsterdam cause of this issue. Let noone decide what > brands of cubes to use and not to use in competitions. That is my > very simple message. Seventowns are not losing a single penny or > cent by allowing eastsheens, so my opinion is that banning those is > stupidity. And it's not disrespect of Ernö Rubik either. Most ppl > who are not cubists (whatever that is) still would call the > Eastsheen a Rubik's cube. That shows how well associated the Rubik > name is with cubic/twisting puzzles. 602. Types of Cubes
From: Mark Longridge <zero1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 4 Feb 2005 22:49:35 -0500

I'm not saying your wrong. Nichols was the first to make a
cubical 2x2x2, but Ideal Toy turned Nichols down.

If Larry Nichols had an effective mechanism instead of one
based on magnets I don't think Ideal Toy (itself an American company)
would have passed on it. To be fair I've no first hand information about his
2x2x2 but I don't see how a magnet-based 2x2x2 could work except
by forcing it apart and then letting it pull itself back together.

I'm not personally against the idea of allowing eastsheen or other
types of cubes in tournaments. In bowling tournaments you're not
constrained to use a particular make of bowling ball. In tennis
tournaments I'm pretty sure the players don't use only one
manufacturer of tennis racket.

Mark




On February 4, 2005 08:36 pm, d_j_salvia wrote:
> Hi Per,
>
> One of the things that bothers me about the "no eastsheen 2x2x2"
> rule is that the 2x2x2 was invented (and patented) by Larry Nichols
> long before Rubik invented the 3x3x3.
>
> David J

From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 4 Feb 2005 19:51:32 -0800

Hey Everyone,

Have fun with the Chris Hunt Informal Tournament 2005 and compare your
results with how we did:

Scrambles:
1) D' B2 F2 D' R' B' U2 F R B2 U2 B' U' L U2 D2 R' U D B2 F L'
R' F R
2) B2 D2 U' R2 L' B' F U2 R2 L B R' D2 R' B2 L' B' R2 L2 U' F'
L R B2 U
3) F U L2 U2 B2 F' D U2 B R' B' R' U2 L2 U2 R' L F D' L2 B' L2
U' F2 R
4) F D' F B2 R2 F L U' F D L2 R2 F2 U' F2 D R L U2 D2 F' D2 U2
B2 R
5) B U L' U' L B L' R2 D R2 B R D2 F R2 B' L2 D2 R2 L2 D2 L D
R' L
6) R2 B U B' L2 D' F B' U L U2 B F L2 B2 L2 F' D F' B L' R D2
R F

1 Makisumi Shotaro average = 15.26
2 Mao Tyson average = 18.38
3 Lo Leyan average = 22.45
4 Hunt Chris average = 23.68
5 Lwin John average = 30.97
6 Chiu Steve average = 68.99

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

608. iPAQ cube timer
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 07:12:40 -0000


This is a duplicate of my post to the midwestcubeclub group... I
thought there may be people that are part of one group or the other,
but not both...

- G

I wrote the following in that group (URL's been modified for this
group):

I don't know how many people will really find this useful, but Rommy
saw me using a timer on my iPAQ and asked for it while we were at the
competition. I figured I'd just upload it to the files section on
here. It's pretty limited in it's functionality right now, and while
I have many ideas for future improvements, I unfortunately haven't
had time to change it since original development well over 6 months
ago, so who knows when it'll happen.

It provides good scrambles for 2x2x2, 3x3x3, 4x4x4, and 5x5x5 cubes.
Click start, you get a 15 second countdown (no sound to indicate your
start time, though) and then time starts. Stop and accept/discard
your time (or indicate a pop), and it will show you your times, most
recent at the top, along with a running average of 12. Additionally,
you can elect to look at your best, worst or current average, or
best/worst single time.

The file name is CubeTimes2Go.exe, and it can be found in the files
section of this group, which is at
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/files/ .
