610. Re: Oll+corners algs?
From: "Oliver Wolff" <OliverWolff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 10:43:50 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jstuber@p...> wrote: I think there are 280 individual algs?? Hi James, it should be 603 algs. 3 swap corners 7 twist corners 66 swap+twist corners 19 swap corners / flip edges 47 twist corners / flip edges 458 swap+twist corners / flip edges 3 flip edges ==== 603 I´m working on a complete overview of all 3915 LL algs, pictures are done, about 1500 algs to go. I´ll post it when done. Olli
611. Re: Oll+corners algs?
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 11:12:58 -0000


Hi James,

>Anyone know the algs to orient all of the last layer and permute the
>corners? I think there are 280 individual algs?? Then the last layer
could
>be finished off with an edge cycle, and you wouldn't have to learn
ZB or VH
>f2l algs.
I can't answer to your question "how many algs?" exactly.
But this is something what I have been working.

I already knew more than 100 but less than 140.
To my experinece, it pays a little bit but not much.
Of course, to expand the number of algs should help your skills.

For example, if you see just one corner is oriented in LL and
correctly placed, Sune or its variation is too easy to perform.
If you want to orient four edges, it takes twice as much as Sune.

If you are interested in, I can give you some optimized algs I use.
The only problem is I am too lazy to descibe those algs in text.
I wish I could have a set of small videos instead.

>Recognition would be just like COLL, only then you'd have to see
>which edges are flipped. I'm working on finding these and it'd be
nice if
>someone already had them, or what it would average. Thanks!

>-James
>
>http://www.stubers.org/jamesstuff/jamesstuff.htm


Macky, Lars, Ron, or someone who use COLL...
Could you give an idea to distingish CLL without edge-flipping and
CLL with OLL?
The naming of COLL, which you use, sounds like OLL with corner
permution, or CLL with OLL simultaneously, whatever....
Sometimes, it is confusing.

I would suggest eoCLL (edge-oriented) or eCLL for CLL without edge-
flipping.

Masayuki Akimoto





612. Square-1 lubrification
From: Heymbeeck Joël <sinac_be@...>
To: Rubik Club English <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 5 Feb 2005 15:23:40 +0100 (CET)

Hello,

Does anyone know how to dismantle a square-1 to lube it, or a tech to lube without dismantling it?

Thanks,

Joel


---------------------------------
Découvrez le nouveau Yahoo! Mail : 250 Mo d'espace de stockage pour vos mails !
Créez votre Yahoo! Mail

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



613. Re: Square-1 lubrification
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 15:19:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Heymbeeck Joël <sinac_be@y...> wrote: > Hello, > > Does anyone know how to dismantle a square-1 to lube it, or a tech to lube without dismantling it? > > Thanks, Hi! Ton used to have pictures, but I cannot find them right now. With the original Czech version, Cube 21, it should be relatively easy to remove the plate with the logo on it. (At least, mine was fairly easy.) This reveals a screw which holds the 2 halves of the puzzle together. Loosen the screw to help remove the pieces -- the screw may be very stiff. Only remove the screw if the spring/washer are incorrectly placed (the washer should be between the spring and the plastic). Warning: If you remove the screw completely, you may have to remove the opposite face plate to get access to the little plastic block that the screw screws into. Irwin Toys Square-1 (I have too many of these): Sometimes a lot of glue has been used and you cannot remove the face plates. In this case I have had to drill a 6mm hole in the face plate to get access to the screw. But you have to know exactly where the screwhead is under the face plate -- let me know if you need to do this... Alternatively, partially twist the middle layer, then try to turn a face so that an edge pops out. Warning: doing this may loosen the screw, so you end up drilling a hole anyway... Mike
614. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Chris Hunt Informal Tournament 2005
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 5 Feb 2005 11:35:18 -0800 (PST)

decided to retake my time again. average of 5 minus slowest and fastest. (31.23) (23.56) 25.45 27.32 26.11 average comes to 26.29333333333 OH well :( yeah! nervousness really kills. better luck to me next time :) John lwin. --- tsbischof <tom@...> wrote: > > Average of 5 (minus fastest and slowest): 22.07 > seconds [(19.91) > (30.26) 22.17 22.45 21.58]. > > -Thomas Bischof > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson > Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hey Everyone, > > > > Have fun with the Chris Hunt Informal Tournament > 2005 and compare > your > > results with how we did: > > > > Scrambles: > > 1) D' B2 F2 D' R' B' U2 F R B2 U2 B' U' L > U2 D2 R' U D B2 > F L' > > R' F R > > 2) B2 D2 U' R2 L' B' F U2 R2 L B R' D2 R' > B2 L' B' R2 L2 > U' F' > > L R B2 U > > 3) F U L2 U2 B2 F' D U2 B R' B' R' U2 L2 > U2 R' L F D' L2 > B' L2 > > U' F2 R > > 4) F D' F B2 R2 F L U' F D L2 R2 F2 U' F2 > D R L U2 D2 F' > D2 U2 > > B2 R > > 5) B U L' U' L B L' R2 D R2 B R D2 F R2 > B' L2 D2 R2 L2 D2 > L D > > R' L > > 6) R2 B U B' L2 D' F B' U L U2 B F L2 B2 > L2 F' D F' B L' > R D2 > > R F > > > > 1 Makisumi Shotaro average = 15.26 > > 2 Mao Tyson average = 18.38 > > 3 Lo Leyan average = 22.45 > > 4 Hunt Chris average = 23.68 > > 5 Lwin John average = 30.97 > > 6 Chiu Steve average = 68.99 > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? 617. Re: Square-1 lubrification
From: "sinac_be" <sinac_be@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 21:35:51 -0000

Thanks a lot, I have a square-1 and a Cube 21, I'll try both =) Joel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Heymbeeck Joël > <sinac_be@y...> wrote: > > Hello, > > > > Does anyone know how to dismantle a square-1 to lube it, or a tech > to lube without dismantling it? > > > > Thanks, > > Hi! > > Ton used to have pictures, but I cannot find them right now. > > With the original Czech version, Cube 21, it should be relatively > easy to remove the plate with the logo on it. (At least, mine was > fairly easy.) This reveals a screw which holds the 2 halves of the > puzzle together. > > Loosen the screw to help remove the pieces -- the screw may be very > stiff. Only remove the screw if the spring/washer are incorrectly > placed (the washer should be between the spring and the plastic). > > Warning: If you remove the screw completely, you may have to remove > the opposite face plate to get access to the little plastic block > that the screw screws into. > > Irwin Toys Square-1 (I have too many of these): Sometimes a lot of > glue has been used and you cannot remove the face plates. In this > case I have had to drill a 6mm hole in the face plate to get access > to the screw. But you have to know exactly where the screwhead is > under the face plate -- let me know if you need to do this... > > Alternatively, partially twist the middle layer, then try to turn a > face so that an edge pops out. Warning: doing this may loosen the > screw, so you end up drilling a hole anyway... > > Mike
618. Re: Oll+corners algs?
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Feb 2005 22:37:09 -0000


> Macky, Lars, Ron, or someone who use COLL...
> Could you give an idea to distingish CLL without edge-flipping and
> CLL with OLL?
> The naming of COLL, which you use, sounds like OLL with corner
> permution, or CLL with OLL simultaneously, whatever....
> Sometimes, it is confusing.
>
> I would suggest eoCLL (edge-oriented) or eCLL for CLL without edge-
> flipping.
>
> Masayuki Akimoto

Yes, we definitely need better names. eCLL looks nice enough to me.

What I would rather see is a good system for naming, though. Even the
acronyms in common use--OLL, PLL, CLL, and ELL--don't clearly show
what they mean. We call OLL "orientation of last layer," but can
permutation be disturbed (yes)? PLL is "permutation of last layer,"
but can orientation be disturbed (this time, no!)?

We could, for example, use capital letters to mean fixing that part
with any side effects, then list the preserved portion in lowercase
letters later. The problem with this is that you have to write PLLo
to mean PLL.

...yeah, that's kind of stupid. I would rather use RH, ZBLL, whatever
crazy acronyms we'll think of in the future, than precisely write out
their effect every time.

Macky

From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

Me neither. > In bowling tournaments you're not > constrained to use a particular make of bowling ball. That might be because they're not organized/sponsored by the "Bowling" company, though. > In tennis > tournaments I'm pretty sure the players don't use only one > manufacturer of tennis racket. That might be because they're not organized/sponsored by the "Tennis" company, though. Cheers! Stefan

623. Re: do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Feb 2005 17:28:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL > algorithms????, i've just finished learning all the > F2L, and my average time is 40 seconds, what should i > do??? or what is a better way to learn all the OLL and > PLL algorithms??? > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com The best way to learn all the OLL and PLL is first learn a 3 look LL. That means first you orient the last layer edges(make a cross on the LL) then you orient the LL corners then you permute them all. This is how first learned how, and after i learned all the algorithms to do it this way, i just slowly started added more OLLs until i knew them all

625. East Sheen cubes, Mefferts, and more
From: "Jason Preissig" <ELiTe185@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Feb 2005 20:52:41 -0000


I really want to buy a 4x4x4 cube. After I bought a 2x2x2 Rubik's cube
from rubiks.com, I was really disappointed. It was really bad at
turning. Then I heard that "Eastsheen" 2x2x2s are a lot better, so I
went out on a search. (I also heard that their 4x4x4s are the best too).
Finally, I found the eastsheen website. It was hard for me to find for
2 reasons:
1) It is actually "East Sheen" NOT "Eastsheen"
2) The website has a typo in the header of the main frame making the
title "ESAT SHEEN" instead of "EAST SHEEN>"

I found the site (link here: http://www.eastsheen.com.tw/ ) and
discovered that I want to buy their cubes. So, I sent them an e-mail
saying that:
1) I want to buy their cubes, and I wanted to know where I could get
them (or if I could get them straight from them).
2) To tell them about the typo

I got a response in about a DAY! Isn't that good customer service?
It read:

"Dear Sir,

Thank you for your enquiry about our products.
It is a pity that we don't accept retail due to we are manufactory of
magic
cube.
There are one of our customer who provide our products online.
The website is www.mefferts.com
I believe you will find something you like from that website.

In addition, thank you very much for reminding the mistake we made on our
website. We will correct it ASAP.

Sincerely,

EAST SHEEN CO.,"

So then I e-mailed Meffert's to ask which cubes they had are East
Sheeen cubes. I never got a reply.

So my question to you all is:
Which cubes on http://www.mefferts.com/ are in fact East Sheen cubes?


Thanks a ton, and I hope some of the information in this post helped.





626. Re: [Speed cubing group] East Sheen cubes, Mefferts, and more
From: Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 6 Feb 2005 13:43:25 -0800 (PST)

jason, u go into merfferts's puzzles. and the eastsheen 2x2x2, 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 will be like half way down the page i think. it should say the 2x2x2 is 5x5x5cm, 4x4x4 is 6x6x6cm and for 5x5x5 is also 6x6x6cm. those 3 are the eastsheens. and i am not sure if they can be used in competitions, which is something i wanna know too. chun hei Jason Preissig <ELiTe185@...> wrote: I really want to buy a 4x4x4 cube. 629. Re: [Speed cubing group] do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Feb 2005 19:24:26 -0500

Dear James,

You can also use a 4-step last layer.

1. Orient the edges.
2. Position/permute the corners.
3. Orient the corners.
4. Position/permute the edges.

Very technically, you only need to memorize 4 algorithms for this 4-step last layer.

~Erwaman~
----- Original Message -----
From: James Benedict Caares
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, February 06, 2005 5:36 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms????


do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL
algorithms????, i've just finished learning all the
F2L, and my average time is 40 seconds, what should i
do??? or what is a better way to learn all the OLL and
PLL algorithms???

Sorry about that. I haven't had a chance to put too much work into my OLL pages, let alone doublecheck anything. Thanks for finding the error, I'll fix it as soon as I have a chance. -Richard --- Michiel van der Blonk <blonkm@...> wrote: > > Hi > > I found another mistake > The second alg on your OLL1 page couldn't possible > be correct, it messes up > the cube. I don't know which alg you actually meant > to put there. > http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/cubeapplet.asp?alg=(R'U2R)F(URU'R'U)F' > > Michiel > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "portoseb" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Sunday, February 06, 2005 12:03 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: My Site > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "richy_jr_2000" > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I think I've got everything figured out for my > site. 633. Favorite OLL
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Feb 2005 04:52:37 -0000


I know there have been a lot of favorite PLL posts, but what about
OLL? Just out of curiousity, do most of you prefer short OLL
algorithms or ones that feel nice to perform? If so, which ones?

Personally, I like L'U2L2F'L'FL'U2L and LULF'L'FU'L' the best for
the speed and the way they feel, although I don't mind getting some
of the shorter cases (especially the Sune). What about the rest of
you?

-Thomas Bischof





634. Re: [Speed cubing group] do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 7 Feb 2005 08:18:46 -0000

James, If you want to cut down the numnebr of alforithms you needfor a 2-look last layer dramatically then you can try my site http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle. It is pretty easy to build on your F2L and avoid most of the OLL algorithms by using the L2L1a method. You only need the few (6) corner orientations which is so much easier to learn and to recognise. It gives you the option later of either learning the full OLL set or trying some of the other L2L strategies which are more efficient. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Anthony Hsu" <erwaman@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, February 07, 2005 12:24 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms???? > > Dear James, > > You can also use a 4-step last layer. > > 1. Orient the edges. > 2. Position/permute the corners. > 3. Orient the corners. > 4. Position/permute the edges. > > Very technically, you only need to memorize 4 algorithms for this 4-step last layer. > > ~Erwaman~ > ----- Original Message ----- > From: James Benedict Caares > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, February 06, 2005 5:36 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL algorithms???? > > > do i really need to memorize all the OLL and PLL > algorithms????, i've just finished learning all the > F2L, and my average time is 40 seconds, what should i > do??? or what is a better way to learn all the OLL and > PLL algorithms??? > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---- > Yahoo! Groups Links > > a.. To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! 635. Re: Anyone have any pointers for me...
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Feb 2005 08:43:12 -0000


I use Petrus method myself so I´ll try to give you a few tips. Most of
them are tips for speedcubing in general.

1.Go SLOW on F2L this is the same tip everybody gives you and the best
you´ll ever get. During whole F2L don´t even try to speed up, just
make slow turns and try to find the next cubies while doing this. It
takes a time to learn to do it but going really slow helps. Actually I
think it´s the only way to learn looking ahead. This also prevents
cube lockups and POPs.
It´s faster to go slow with no delays than to go fast with lots of
delays ;)

2. Take more than 15 seconds to examine the cube, take as long as you
need. Try to see the whole 2x2x2 solution before starting. When you do
this long enough you´ll be able to see it during the 15 sec you get in
competition.

3. Try to make clear what you need for the next step. Make rules on
how to look for and recognize cubies you need. One good trick is to
repeat the colors of the cubie in your head while looking for it.

4. For LL learn to recognize patterns fast and understand what the
algorithms you use do (how the cubies move and turn). Here you want to
use speed, so learn the algs by heart. Fingertricks and triggers are
the keys to fastness When you start feeling LL goes without bigger
delays learn a few new algs and start slowly with them until you can
do the in full speed.

5. Don´t only practice speedsolving. As Lars Petrus adviced me: "Half
the training should be "thinking solves" where you go slow and learn
how cubies move when you do different things".

6. Practice, without it you won´t become faster.

Hope that gave you some pointers,
Mikael





636. Re: Favorite OLL
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Feb 2005 12:47:26 -0000

My favourite OLL is still the Sune, because it is the first algorithm for LL that I learned. It's also the first move that showed me what a fingertrick is (Lars Petrus shows on his site how fingertricks work by performing the Sune). It's fast, easy, and I get no lockups with this alg. If I had to choose another one, I would take Case #57 from Dan Harris's site http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/orientations/ollprintablepage.html I sometimes get lockups with it but I like the way I use my thumb in this alg. -Edgardo --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "tsbischof" <tom@w...> wrote: > > I know there have been a lot of favorite PLL posts, but what about > OLL? Just out of curiousity, do most of you prefer short OLL > algorithms or ones that feel nice to perform? If so, which ones? > > Personally, I like L'U2L2F'L'FL'U2L and LULF'L'FU'L' the best for > the speed and the way they feel, although I don't mind getting some > of the shorter cases (especially the Sune). What about the rest of > you? > > -Thomas Bischof
637. Finding cubies fast
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 7 Feb 2005 09:16:06 -0800

On Feb 7, 2005, at 0:43, mikaelnybrg wrote:

> One good trick is to repeat the colors of the cubie in your head while
> looking for it.

That's exactly what I do. Or at least did when I learned it, don't
think I do it consciously now.

The other thing is to realize that there only are at most 8 or 12
places the cubie can be. As you complete more of the cube, those
numbers shrink.

The wrong, but very natural, way to try to find it is to look at the
whole cube and hope it will "pop out" and show itself for you. We've
all kept staring aimlessly, with rapidly increasing panic, for a piece
that refuses to be found. Instead I scan each of the positions it can
be in, one by one. You can do this very fast with practice.

The next level is when you can be confident enough that if it can be in
7 spots, and you've checked that it isn't in 5-6 of them, you can start
acting on the fact that it has to be in the 1 or 2 you can't see
without actually looking.

Of course, better than looking is to already know where the piece is.
To me, the ideal solve is when I can find the pieces for a step while
I'm performing the previous step. I suspect that is the essence of the
"go slow" advice. You need to go so slow that you can do that, but no
slower. Like most things, it's something you can practice. And you need
to know how to do it slowly before you can do it fast.

/Lars



638. Re: Finding cubies fast
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Feb 2005 17:33:36 -0000


Thanks for the advice. I've seen the same words on several site, but
they didn't seem to sink in until now.

When I'm trying to solve the cube fast, I do get paniced an
frustrated when I can't fine a particular cube or when the cube jams.
I guess I'll need to learn patience and move a bit slower so that I
can follow certain cubies.

Thanks to both of you for your advice.





639. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Finding cubies fast
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 7 Feb 2005 10:18:56 -0800 (PST)

one annoyiing thing is when the corner edge pair is in the wrong f2l slot in the wrong way. you can consider that as a free slot, so that you can bring it out while filling in another f2l slot. DanH has some good advice on that check out his site. --- dwarmaj <Dwarmaj@...> wrote: > > Thanks for the advice. I've seen the same words on > several site, but > they didn't seem to sink in until now. > > When I'm trying to solve the cube fast, I do get > paniced an > frustrated when I can't fine a particular cube or > when the cube jams. > I guess I'll need to learn patience and move a bit > slower so that I > can follow certain cubies. > > Thanks to both of you for your advice. > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Read only the mail you want - Yahoo! Mail SpamGuard. http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
640. Re: Finding cubies fast
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Feb 2005 18:28:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > The next level is when you can be confident enough that if it can be in > 7 spots, and you've checked that it isn't in 5-6 of them, you can start > acting on the fact that it has to be in the 1 or 2 you can't see > without actually looking. > /Lars This is something that I do a lot with the 4x4 edges step as well. It isn't typical 3x3 speedcubing, but it is still a useful technique for larger puzzles. I have a certain order in which I always examine the edge groups on the 4x4 while pairing edge groups. If I have examined 10 edge groups and still haven't found my piece then I automatically know exactly where the edge is without having to look (I know some information about two of the edge groups at all times). This is also a prinicple part of my startegy in that at certain points in the step I need to make sure that an edge isn't located in one of two specific edge groups of the 12. If I can be sure of this fact, then it makes it much easier to find the piece, knowing that now I only have to search 8 locations instead of 10. I think the strategy Lars mentioned about narrowing down the locations that a piece can be in, and acting on that "process of elimination" without ever having actually seen the piece is very important. For larger cubes too. Chris

part to form at least a cross. Some corners are in their correct
positions but the colors are in the incorrect position. Go into the
detail for this final step. R'D'RD X2 or X4 just messes up the
cube...





644. Re: Finding cubies fast
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Feb 2005 11:25:22 -0000

Hey! The most efficient way to get a good lookahead is to minimize ur number of algorithms. Then u subconsciously learn how the pieces are moving, where they are landing so to speak, and u also subconsciously use that to plan ur next step. In extreme cases u can then not only plan next step but maybe also 2 steps ahead. It also helps if ur algs move only a few pieces. I utlilise this to an extreme in how i solve the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cubes. Mostly using 3- cycles on edges or corners i by and large always know where the pieces will be. There's no "panic" after an alg to start searching for cubies. I know that minimising ur number of algs is maybe not a good approach if u wanna be among the fastest cubers on 3x3x3. But it sure helps on u lookahead and flow. I average about 27 secs now on the 3x3x3 using a minimum of algs and having a 4-look last layer. I can live with that ;-) Happy cubing! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> > wrote: > > The next level is when you can be confident enough that if it can be in > > 7 spots, and you've checked that it isn't in 5-6 of them, you can start > > acting on the fact that it has to be in the 1 or 2 you can't see > > without actually looking. > > > /Lars > > This is something that I do a lot with the 4x4 edges step as well. It > isn't typical 3x3 speedcubing, but it is still a useful technique for > larger puzzles. > > I have a certain order in which I always examine the edge groups on > the 4x4 while pairing edge groups. If I have examined 10 edge groups > and still haven't found my piece then I automatically know exactly > where the edge is without having to look (I know some information > about two of the edge groups at all times). > > This is also a prinicple part of my startegy in that at certain points > in the step I need to make sure that an edge isn't located in one of > two specific edge groups of the 12. If I can be sure of this fact, > then it makes it much easier to find the piece, knowing that now I > only have to search 8 locations instead of 10. > > I think the strategy Lars mentioned about narrowing down the locations > that a piece can be in, and acting on that "process of elimination" > without ever having actually seen the piece is very important. For > larger cubes too. > > Chris

646. Re: newbie - layer by layer method. help solve.
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Feb 2005 16:59:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Luke Skywalker" <humanvegetableonline2002@y...> wrote: > > I've solved the bottom part of the cube. thats 2x3x3. i got the top > part to form at least a cross. Some corners are in their correct > positions but the colors are in the incorrect position. Go into the > detail for this final step. R'D'RD X2 or X4 just messes up the > cube... Hi, I have a small website with a beginners solution, where I explain in detail how to solve the cube. It's: www.solvethecube.co.uk. From what I understand, the edges of the last layer are orientated, but not the corners. I think that would be step 5 of my solution. The solution on my website only uses moves that are pretty intuitive, and it is therefore a little inefficient. For a more straightforward solution of the last layer, check: http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html. P.S. What does X2 or X4 mean? It looks like R'D'RD X2 is not really an algorithm, but more like a part of a 'system'. Where did you find this? Joel.

648. Re: newbie - layer by layer method. help solve.
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Feb 2005 17:43:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Luke Skywalker" <humanvegetableonline2002@y...> wrote: > > I've solved the bottom part of the cube. thats 2x3x3. i got the top > part to form at least a cross. Some corners are in their correct > positions but the colors are in the incorrect position. Go into the > detail for this final step. R'D'RD X2 or X4 just messes up the > cube... Hi Luke, I'm surprised that your algorithms don't all begin R2D2! All you need for the Last Level is 4 algs. We call movement, or a swap, "permutation," and we call rotating and flipping "orientation", so 1. orients corners, 2. permutes corners, 3. orients edges and 4. permutes edges. Do each of these three times and you return to the beginning state. Such are called "three cycles." 1. R U R' U R U2 R' U2 (rotates three corners clockwise and moves three edges clockwise) 2. R U' L' U R' U' L U (rotates three corners clockwise and moves them counterclockwise, leaves edges alone) In truth this swaps two corners. 3. r U' r' U2 r U' r' (flips two edges moves three counterclockwise) 4. R2 U b U2 b' U R2 (moves three edges clockwise without affecting corners) You may need to apply an alg more than once. Tell Han he still owes me. Regards, David J

652. newbie - layer by layer method. help solve.
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Feb 2005 18:35:04 -0000

Hello! You can also (if you wish) follow the progress of my students who I am currently teaching to solve the Cube as part of our Society activities. Each week we are meeting, (this week was the first time), and we are building up a layer by layer solution to the Cube. Each week I will put the contents from the workshops onto my website, - www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/>  and eventually this will grow into a full, easy to understand solution for beginners. Just go to my site and click on the UEA Cube Club link which is in the red menu panel. I hope some of you will find this useful! Dan Harris :-) _____ From: Joël van Noort [mailto:joel_vn@...] Sent: 08 February 2005 16:59 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: newbie - layer by layer method. help solve. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Luke Skywalker" <humanvegetableonline2002@y...> wrote: > > I've solved the bottom part of the cube. thats 2x3x3. i got the top > part to form at least a cross. It looks like R'D'RD X2 is not really an algorithm, but more like a part of a 'system'. Where did you find this? Joel. Yahoo! > come through for Rubik's organization? The probable problem is that

654. RE: [Speed cubing group] newbie - layer by layer method. help solve.
From: "James Stuber" <jstuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Feb 2005 13:02:52 -0800

I believe you are using the new solution booklet. R'D'RD does mess it up. However, I think x2 or x4 means to actually do R'D'RD twice, not do that and rotate around the x axis. You have to do R'D'RD until the corner you were working on is oriented correctly, regardless of how messed up everything else is. Then do U until you find another corner that is messed up, and do R'D'RD until that corner is oriented correctly. Keep turning U to an un-oriented corner and doing R'D'RD twice or four times until the cube is solved. I hope that helps. -James -----Original Message----- From: Daniel Harris [mailto:dan_j_harris@...] Sent: Tuesday, February 08, 2005 10:35 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] newbie - layer by layer method. help solve. Hello! You can also (if you wish) follow the progress of my students who I am currently teaching to solve the Cube as part of our Society activities. Each week we are meeting, (this week was the first time), and we are building up a layer by layer solution to the Cube. Each week I will put the contents from the workshops onto my website, - www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/>  and eventually this will grow into a full, easy to understand solution for beginners. Just go to my site and click on the UEA Cube Club link which is in the red menu panel. I hope some of you will find this useful! Dan Harris :-) _____ From: Joël van Noort [mailto:joel_vn@...] Sent: 08 February 2005 16:59 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: newbie - layer by layer method. help solve. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Luke Skywalker" <humanvegetableonline2002@y...> wrote: > > I've solved the bottom part of the cube. thats 2x3x3. i got the top > part to form at least a cross. Some corners are in their correct > positions but the colors are in the incorrect position. Go into the > detail for this final step. R'D'RD X2 or X4 just messes up the > cube... Hi, I have a small website with a beginners solution, where I explain in detail how to solve the cube. It's: www.solvethecube.co.uk. From what I understand, the edges of the last layer are orientated, but not the corners. I think that would be step 5 of my solution. The solution on my website only uses moves that are pretty intuitive, and it is therefore a little inefficient. For a more straightforward solution of the last layer, check: http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html. P.S. What does X2 or X4 mean? It looks like R'D'RD X2 is not really an algorithm, but more like a part of a 'system'. Where did you find this? Joel. Yahoo! 657. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 08:32:41 -0000

Most chess tournaments that I have played in make money from the entry fees although sponsorship helps when its available. Local chess clubs often run tournaments to help boost their annual funds (and still give out some prize money). Having not participated in a speedcube tournament since 1983 I don't know what the deal is but how much is usually charged for entry? Of course at the top end in major international chess tournaments there is sponsorship but it has taken chess a long time to get to that position. I think cash prizes is a good idea and if you can get sponsors that would be fantastic but I guess it should still be economic to run tournaments without. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Brent Morgan" <brentmorganmaster@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, February 08, 2005 5:55 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? Hey guys/gals, I see that chess and other tournaments (competitions in science, math, etc.) give out loads of cash... How hard will it be in making that come through for Rubik's organization? The probable problem is that there isn't any sponsors... But maybe this could help the Rubik's organization/community? Maybe we could do something to get some sponsors. Anyone that can apply economics here could help in the outcome of giving money prizes to tournaments... Just a THOUGHT. thoughts are good :). -bm :) --Brent --------------------------------- Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Search presents - Jib Jab's 'Second Term' [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Yahoo! Groups Links
658. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 02:18:10 -0800

Hey Duncan,

What did you compete in in 1983?!?

I charge a minimal amount at my tournaments. Usually just enough to
break even so about $3 per person. Definitely not enough to give out a
cash prize. Whereas a cash prize is cool, I mean... I think it would
be an issue if the same person kept winning the competition over and
over again with no one even close to beating him. Sure it's fine, but
I worry that a cash prize might discourage people when this is the
case. I try to keep entry fees to a minimum so that everyone will
enter... especially those who learned how to solve the cube the day
before or those that need some coaxing to compete.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 9, 2005, at 12:32 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote:

> Most chess tournaments that I have played in make money from the entry
> fees
> although sponsorship helps when its available. Local chess clubs
> often run
> tournaments to help boost their annual funds (and still give out some
> prize
> money). Having not participated in a speedcube tournament since 1983 I
> don't know what the deal is but how much is usually charged for entry?
> Of
> course at the top end in major international chess tournaments there is
> sponsorship but it has taken chess a long time to get to that
> position. I
> think cash prizes is a good idea and if you can get sponsors that
> would be
> fantastic but I guess it should still be economic to run tournaments
> without.
>
> Duncan




659. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 10:32:37 -0000

Hi Tyson, There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. I was at Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we came second but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per team and held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and competed against each other over a number of solves. I seem to remember being surprised at the numbers - probably around ten teams (including some reserves). It was at this tournament that I broke the onehanded record (with around 53 seconds) after the original holder had reduced his record down to around 80 seconds - it all sounds quite quaint now in the light of Chris' fantastic records! I think it was at the same tournament that another of our team John White broke the blindfold record (it was of the order or 20 minutes I think!). I guess chess has the advantage of being able to award grading prizes or hold limited grade tournaments (thats certainly very common over here in the UK anyway). Or maybe less experienced speedcubers could be enticed with prizes for those with best times over 20, 30, 40 seconds etc. I think these days I'd expect to pay ~ ï¿½10 to enter a chess tournament - over $20! Speedcubing is cheap! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 10:18 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? Hey Duncan, What did you compete in in 1983?!? I charge a minimal amount at my tournaments. Usually just enough to break even so about $3 per person. Definitely not enough to give out a cash prize. Whereas a cash prize is cool, I mean... I think it would be an issue if the same person kept winning the competition over and over again with no one even close to beating him. Sure it's fine, but I worry that a cash prize might discourage people when this is the case. I try to keep entry fees to a minimum so that everyone will enter... especially those who learned how to solve the cube the day before or those that need some coaxing to compete. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 9, 2005, at 12:32 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote: > Most chess tournaments that I have played in make money from the entry > fees > although sponsorship helps when its available. Local chess clubs > often run > tournaments to help boost their annual funds (and still give out some > prize > money). Having not participated in a speedcube tournament since 1983 I > don't know what the deal is but how much is usually charged for entry? > Of > course at the top end in major international chess tournaments there is > sponsorship but it has taken chess a long time to get to that > position. I > think cash prizes is a good idea and if you can get sponsors that > would be > fantastic but I guess it should still be economic to run tournaments > without. > > Duncan Yahoo! Groups Links
660. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 02:53:23 -0800

Hi Duncan,

I've always thought about that. People ask me if there are divisions?
Like... sub-20 cubers vs. non-sub 20 cubers? Unfortunately, how can
you say that someone is sub-20? "I've only done a sub-20 average once
and that was lucky." Then watch them as they try to hit 20.01 every
time on the pad. Any ideas?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

662. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 11:49:35 -0000

Hi Gillian, Sadly not - I had offers to go on TV but had the sense to realise I would have been too nervous to be any good. John White the "behind-the-back" cuber did appear - probably on "Nationwide" or something like that - in about 1982/83. I only remember one other fast UK solver from the time and he was Tony Willets (I think!). he was at the Birmingham tournament and he was very fast - sub 25 which was quick then. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: <gmb@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 10:55 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? > > > > > Hi Tyson, > > There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. 663. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 11:55:32 -0000

Hi Tyson, Apart from only allowing averages or times set in official tournaments I dont see what you can do about it other than trust. And with money on the line maybe people can't be trusted. In chess, gradings come from tournament and match play but there are many more opportunities to get an offical grading than there are with speedcubing. Still someone who has never been in a tournament but practiced hard at home maybe should be eligible for "grading" prizes. In Chess Open Tournaments players of all grades are mixed but those of lower grades - say below 2000 or below 1800 USCF - are eligible for more prizes - the highest score of anyone in their rating category as well as the usual prizes. They are only allowed to win one prize of course! How many entrants do you tend to get in tournaments? Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 10:53 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? Hi Duncan, I've always thought about that. People ask me if there are divisions? Like... sub-20 cubers vs. non-sub 20 cubers? Unfortunately, how can you say that someone is sub-20? "I've only done a sub-20 average once and that was lucky." Then watch them as they try to hit 20.01 every time on the pad. Any ideas? 664. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Feb 2005 13:22:13 -0000

Hi All, This topic has come up in the past, and while I see the reasoning behind giving prizes to different levels of times, I don't agree with it. For one, as Tyson said, what's to stop someone from slowing down just a bit in order to get the prize? Even if everyone tried their best on every solve based on the honor system, there's still a flaw. Say competitor A averages 20.53, and competitor B gets 19.24. A gets rewarded for their time, yet they did worse than B, who got nothing? The only way to be fair to those just under each "cut" for prizes is to not have different levels of time. -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Duncan, > > I've always thought about that. People ask me if there are divisions? > Like... sub-20 cubers vs. non-sub 20 cubers? Unfortunately, how can > you say that someone is sub-20? "I've only done a sub-20 average once > and that was lucky." Then watch them as they try to hit 20.01 every > time on the pad. Any ideas? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 2:32 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote: > > > Hi Tyson, > > There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. I > > was at > > Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we came > > second > > but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per team > > and > > held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and competed > > against each other over a number of solves. I seem to remember being > > surprised at the numbers - probably around ten teams (including some > > reserves). It was at this tournament that I broke the onehanded record > > (with around 53 seconds) after the original holder had reduced his > > record > > down to around 80 seconds - it all sounds quite quaint now in the > > light of > > Chris' fantastic records! I think it was at the same tournament that > > another of our team John White broke the blindfold record (it was of > > the > > order or 20 minutes I think!). > > I guess chess has the advantage of being able to award grading prizes > > or > > hold limited grade tournaments (thats certainly very common over here > > in the > > UK anyway). Or maybe less experienced speedcubers could be enticed > > with > > prizes for those with best times over 20, 30, 40 seconds etc. > > I think these days I'd expect to pay ~ £10 to enter a chess tournament > > - > > over $20! Speedcubing is cheap! > > > > Duncan
665. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 13:50:42 -0000

Hi Chris, It works just fine in chess as an incentive for everyone to improve. It doesn't quite work as you have in your example. The over-20 second category, for example, is available for those who have never broken 20 seconds in a tournament before. The chances are that the prize for those in the over-20 second category would be won by someone who breaks 20 seconds for the first time - and thus is not eleigible for that category the next tournament that he or she enters. The time category prizes like this should never be as lucrative as the main prizes for the "open" winner so there is incentive to keep improving in addition. I'm not saying it is the way to go - but it should encourage younger and newer speedcubers to participate. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 1:22 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? Hi All, This topic has come up in the past, and while I see the reasoning behind giving prizes to different levels of times, I don't agree with it. For one, as Tyson said, what's to stop someone from slowing down just a bit in order to get the prize? Even if everyone tried their best on every solve based on the honor system, there's still a flaw. Say competitor A averages 20.53, and competitor B gets 19.24. A gets rewarded for their time, yet they did worse than B, who got nothing? The only way to be fair to those just under each "cut" for prizes is to not have different levels of time. -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Duncan, > > I've always thought about that. People ask me if there are divisions? > Like... sub-20 cubers vs. non-sub 20 cubers? Unfortunately, how can > you say that someone is sub-20? "I've only done a sub-20 average once > and that was lucky." Then watch them as they try to hit 20.01 every > time on the pad. Any ideas? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 2:32 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote: > > > Hi Tyson, > > There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. I > > was at > > Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we came > > second > > but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per team > > and > > held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and competed > > against each other over a number of solves. I seem to remember being > > surprised at the numbers - probably around ten teams (including some > > reserves). It was at this tournament that I broke the onehanded record > > (with around 53 seconds) after the original holder had reduced his > > record > > down to around 80 seconds - it all sounds quite quaint now in the > > light of > > Chris' fantastic records! I think it was at the same tournament that > > another of our team John White broke the blindfold record (it was of > > the > > order or 20 minutes I think!). > > I guess chess has the advantage of being able to award grading prizes > > or > > hold limited grade tournaments (thats certainly very common over here > > in the > > UK anyway). Or maybe less experienced speedcubers could be enticed > > with > > prizes for those with best times over 20, 30, 40 seconds etc. > > I think these days I'd expect to pay ~ ï¿½10 to enter a chess tournament > > - > > over $20! Speedcubing is cheap! > > > > Duncan Yahoo! Groups Links
666. Re: $ at tournaments?
From: "Bob R. Burton" <rrburton@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Feb 2005 15:02:58 -0000

I think it would be much better to give prizes to like top 3-5 or so than different time groups. This way, it gives people more incentive to improve, but it does not mean that you have to be the fastest person to win prize money. Breaking it up into time categories doesn't really make much sense. Somebody who solves in 19 seconds is not much better than somebody who solves it in 21, so they should not be placed into different categories. ~bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Hi Chris, > It works just fine in chess as an incentive for everyone to improve. It > doesn't quite work as you have in your example. The over-20 second > category, for example, is available for those who have never broken 20 > seconds in a tournament before. The chances are that the prize for those in > the over-20 second category would be won by someone who breaks 20 seconds > for the first time - and thus is not eleigible for that category the next > tournament that he or she enters. The time category prizes like this should > never be as lucrative as the main prizes for the "open" winner so there is > incentive to keep improving in addition. > > I'm not saying it is the way to go - but it should encourage younger and > newer speedcubers to participate. > > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@w...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 1:22 PM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? > > > > > Hi All, > > This topic has come up in the past, and while I see the reasoning > behind giving prizes to different levels of times, I don't agree with > it. For one, as Tyson said, what's to stop someone from slowing down > just a bit in order to get the prize? > > Even if everyone tried their best on every solve based on the honor > system, there's still a flaw. Say competitor A averages 20.53, and > competitor B gets 19.24. A gets rewarded for their time, yet they did > worse than B, who got nothing? The only way to be fair to those just > under each "cut" for prizes is to not have different levels of time. > > -Chris Parlette > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hi Duncan, > > > > I've always thought about that. People ask me if there are > divisions? > > Like... sub-20 cubers vs. non-sub 20 cubers? Unfortunately, how > can > > you say that someone is sub-20? "I've only done a sub-20 average > once > > and that was lucky." Then watch them as they try to hit 20.01 > every > > time on the pad. Any ideas? > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 2:32 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote: > > > > > Hi Tyson, > > > There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. > I > > > was at > > > Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we > came > > > second > > > but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per > team > > > and > > > held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and > competed > > > against each other over a number of solves. I seem to remember > being > > > surprised at the numbers - probably around ten teams (including > some > > > reserves). It was at this tournament that I broke the onehanded > record > > > (with around 53 seconds) after the original holder had reduced > his > > > record > > > down to around 80 seconds - it all sounds quite quaint now in the > > > light of > > > Chris' fantastic records! I think it was at the same tournament > that > > > another of our team John White broke the blindfold record (it was > of > > > the > > > order or 20 minutes I think!). > > > I guess chess has the advantage of being able to award grading > prizes > > > or > > > hold limited grade tournaments (thats certainly very common over > here > > > in the > > > UK anyway). Or maybe less experienced speedcubers could be > enticed > > > with > > > prizes for those with best times over 20, 30, 40 seconds etc. > > > I think these days I'd expect to pay ~ £10 to enter a chess > tournament > > > - > > > over $20! Speedcubing is cheap! > > > > > > Duncan > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links
667. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 10:04:30 -0800 (PST)

Well setting up tournaments in one place every time can lead to the issue of someone winning every time.... However if there was national professional regulation on this (as chess does; there's a HUGE chess tournament in Minneapolis this May) throughout the country/world etc., of course that would be more efficient in keeping variety of times, and growth of the community. It's something we could consider for the cubing community; economists feel free to reply. People may feel declined to pay large entry fees (leading to cash prizes) because they might not be "good" enough, especially if they know who's gonig to "win" the prizes. But if there's a large variety of areas to win in some way, (different categories, etc.), or "top 15 get prizes", etc. is a possiblity. In either case, if people feel they aren't going to win something, most won't be willing to pay large amounts or be affiliated with tournaments... Brent Duncan Dicks <duncan@...> wrote: Hi Gillian, Sadly not - I had offers to go on TV but had the sense to realise I would have been too nervous to be any good. John White the "behind-the-back" cuber did appear - probably on "Nationwide" or something like that - in about 1982/83. I only remember one other fast UK solver from the time and he was Tony Willets (I think!). he was at the Birmingham tournament and he was very fast - sub 25 which was quick then. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: <gmb@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 09, 2005 10:55 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments? > > > > > Hi Tyson, > > There was a team tournament held in Birmingham, England in 1983. I was > > at Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we came > > second but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per > > team and held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and > > competed against each other > > I remember someone appearing on TV on the News in around 1981 or 1982, > solving the cube in 45 seconds which was an incredible speed for the time > - could that have been you? > > Gillian Buchanan > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups SponsorADVERTISEMENT document.write(''); --------------------------------- Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. :) --Brent --------------------------------- Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! 669. Video
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 21:56:43 -0000

Hey everyone,



Although I don't posess Gilles' remarkable video editing talents, I did
enjoy making a little video of Ron solving the cube in 17 something seconds.
Complete with very apt music! Those of you in the UK should recognise it
instantly, those of you who are not should know that it is probably the most
famous piece of game show music in existence.



The video is at - www.cubestation.co.uk/videos/roncountdown.wmv



Dan :-)



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



670. rubiks cube lube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Feb 2005 22:08:22 -0000


Does anyone have experience with the cube lube you get from rubiks for
example with the DIY kits? I did get a few of them and I'm wondering
whether I should use their lube or use my normal silicon spray. I
think I remember someone saying that their lube isn't good, but I
don't remember any details and I could be wrong anyway. So?

672. Re: rubiks cube lube
From: "Rommy" <barg0023@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Feb 2005 22:37:06 -0000

My cube seemed to become more viscous when I applied the silicon from the white tube that comes with diy kits. It's only been 2 days... Hopefully it will get better. You might want to try 'Cube- Lube' on a crappy cube. I like the Prestone-Brand silicon lubricant, and I don't think I should have used 'Cube-Lube' on my best speedcube... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Does anyone have experience with the cube lube you get from rubiks for > example with the DIY kits? I did get a few of them and I'm wondering > whether I should use their lube or use my normal silicon spray. I > think I remember someone saying that their lube isn't good, but I > don't remember any details and I could be wrong anyway. So?

674. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 16:39:52 -0800

Just an idea that popped into my head after all the comparison with chess. How about races? Much like chess matches, have people race eachother, best out of three or somethign like that. I know that actualy having two people solving at the same time head to head isn't much different than just solving, but the idea sounds cooler i think, and would be more "intense"(if cubing can be considered intense ;-) i dont know exactly how it would work or anything, i just thought it sounded cool -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Wed, 9 Feb 2005 10:04:30 -0800 (PST), Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...> wrote: > Well setting up tournaments in one place every time can lead to the issue of > someone winning every time.... > However if there was national professional regulation on this (as chess > does; there's a HUGE chess tournament in Minneapolis this May) throughout > the country/world etc., of course that would be more efficient in keeping > variety of times, and growth of the community. 676. looking for Dan Knights
From: jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 01:59:42 -0000


hello
im currently solving my rubik's cube with top cross- f2l - bottom
cross- oll - pll.
but i was wondering how dan knights solved his cube...since he is one
of the best. my friend told me that he solved it in his own way...so i
was wondering if anyone knew what he did.
thanks again





677. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 18:16:22 -0800

Hi Duncan,

We get maybe 30 competitors for each tournament. Larger and better
publicized tournaments such as US Nationals and the Winter 2005 at the
Exploratorium received between 40 and 50 competitors.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 9, 2005, at 3:55 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote:

> Hi Tyson,
> Apart from only allowing averages or times set in official tournaments
> I
> dont see what you can do about it other than trust. And with money on
> the
> line maybe people can't be trusted. In chess, gradings come from
> tournament
> and match play but there are many more opportunities to get an offical
> grading than there are with speedcubing. Still someone who has never
> been
> in a tournament but practiced hard at home maybe should be eligible for
> "grading" prizes. In Chess Open Tournaments players of all grades are
> mixed
> but those of lower grades - say below 2000 or below 1800 USCF - are
> eligible
> for more prizes - the highest score of anyone in their rating category
> as
> well as the usual prizes. They are only allowed to win one prize of
> course!
>
> How many entrants do you tend to get in tournaments?
>
> Duncan

Are you a college student who uses thefacebook.com? Add me! And join
the Rubik's Cube Club!

Tyson Mao

679. Re: [Speed cubing group] looking for Dan Knights
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 18:01:51 -0800

Dan Knights uses a standard Fridrich method. Nothing special. I
really wish he would keep in contact with the community a little bit
more. Just a hint of life would be nice.

I also think many cubers have gotten to much higher strengths since WC
2003. The standards for "one of the best" are now much higher.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 9, 2005, at 5:59 PM, jamessong523 wrote:

> of the best. my friend told me that he solved it in his own way...so i
> was wondering if anyone knew what he did.
> thanks again

California Institute of Technology

681. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Feb 2005 19:26:20 -0800

I've been thinking about the same thing. It's a whole different kind of
competition where good nerves are even more important than for regular
cubing, and where a lot more people can win. Also, it can be done quite
fast, even with a large number of people.

I suggest best of three, since I think is the most nerve wrecking
format.

Ideally, it would NOT be done using timers, but with a simultaneous
start, where the first on to place his solved cube on some surface
wins. You'd have to prevent violent contention for it.

/Lars


On Feb 9, 2005, at 18:09, Tyson Mao wrote:

>
> Like a single elimination tournament? We could do that in April if you
> wanted. It might be fun. I was also thinking relay teams or
> something.
>
> Tyson Mao
> MSC #631
> California Institute of Technology
>
> On Feb 9, 2005, at 4:39 PM, Evan Gates wrote:
>
>> Just an idea that popped into my head after all the comparison with
>> chess. How about races? Much like chess matches, have people race
>> eachother, best out of three or somethign like that. I know that

>> and would be more "intense"(if cubing can be considered intense ;-)
>> i dont know exactly how it would work or anything, i just thought it
>> sounded cool
>>
>> -Evan

683. Re: [Speed cubing group] looking for Dan Knights
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 04:49:40 -0000

I've been in contact with Dan sparsely via e-mail over the past months since he moved to NC. From what I hear he is still practicing a lot, but is busy at his job teaching high school now. Also, as a side note, some of my friends from Duke University were chaperoning (I know I butchered the spelling of that word) some people for a large high school math competition for our state, and Dan Knights happened to be there chaperoning his group as well. The friends I knew from Duke said that Dan had a cube with him and was calmly and easily averaging 17 seconds, so I suspect he is still quite fast, even for the now "higher standards". Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Dan Knights uses a standard Fridrich method. Nothing special. I > really wish he would keep in contact with the community a little bit > more. Just a hint of life would be nice. > > I also think many cubers have gotten to much higher strengths since WC > 2003. The standards for "one of the best" are now much higher. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 5:59 PM, jamessong523 wrote: > > > hello > > im currently solving my rubik's cube with top cross- f2l - bottom > > cross- oll - pll. > > but i was wondering how dan knights solved his cube...since he is one > > of the best. my friend told me that he solved it in his own way...so i > > was wondering if anyone knew what he did. > > thanks again

I am pretty sure that the team event that I competed in back in the 80's was raced head to head between teams but I can't remember how we scored it. I was > > > at Warwick University at the time and we sent a team. I think we came > > > second but I don't remember the details. I think it was five people per > > > team and held on a head to head basis - teams moved around the room and > > > competed against each other > > > > I remember someone appearing on TV on the News in around 1981 or 1982, > > solving the cube in 45 seconds which was an incredible speed for the time > > - could that have been you? > > > > Gillian Buchanan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups SponsorADVERTISEMENT > document.write(''); > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > > :) > --Brent > > --------------------------------- > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Search presents - Jib Jab's 'Second Term' > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > ADVERTISEMENT > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! 685. Re: [Speed cubing group] looking for Dan Knights
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 09:23:50 -0000

Hey Chris :-) That is all well and fine about Dan Knights. Another top cubist who has little or no contact with the online cubing community is Jess Bonde. I'm particularly interested in knowing when he plans to reopen his excellent site www.rubiks.dk ;-) I really love his online timer. His offline timer is not so great since it uses cookies and not a database (for obvious reasons of coz). Another great "lost" cubist is of coz Dan Gosbee. Is he still cubing? And what happened to the cornersfirst group? Happy cubing!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I've been in contact with Dan sparsely via e-mail over the past months > since he moved to NC. From what I hear he is still practicing a lot, > but is busy at his job teaching high school now. > > Also, as a side note, some of my friends from Duke University were > chaperoning (I know I butchered the spelling of that word) some people > for a large high school math competition for our state, and Dan > Knights happened to be there chaperoning his group as well. > > The friends I knew from Duke said that Dan had a cube with him and was > calmly and easily averaging 17 seconds, so I suspect he is still quite > fast, even for the now "higher standards". > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Dan Knights uses a standard Fridrich method. Nothing special. I > > really wish he would keep in contact with the community a little bit > > more. Just a hint of life would be nice. > > > > I also think many cubers have gotten to much higher strengths since WC > > 2003. The standards for "one of the best" are now much higher. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 5:59 PM, jamessong523 wrote: > > > > > hello > > > im currently solving my rubik's cube with top cross- f2l - bottom > > > cross- oll - pll. > > > but i was wondering how dan knights solved his cube...since he is one > > > of the best. my friend told me that he solved it in his own way...so i > > > was wondering if anyone knew what he did. > > > thanks again

687. Re: rubiks cube lube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 12:15:44 -0000

I think that might be because it dries slowly. On the Spanish group, someone recently said it keeps dripping out. But I don't have a problem with that. I think I should modify my question: I'm painting the insides of my cubes with it. Yes, using a paintbrush. I apply about one big drop per cubie and then keep "painting" it until it's dry. Took me about 30 minutes for the whole cube I think. So my new question is: Does it *damage* the cube somehow? Or is the only negative effect that it might not last long in which case I could still change to silicon spray? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rommy" <barg0023@u...> wrote: > > My cube seemed to become more viscous when I applied the silicon > from the white tube that comes with diy kits. It's only been 2 > days... Hopefully it will get better. You might want to try 'Cube- > Lube' on a crappy cube. I like the Prestone-Brand silicon > lubricant, and I don't think I should have used 'Cube-Lube' on my > best speedcube... > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Does anyone have experience with the cube lube you get from rubiks > for > > example with the DIY kits? I did get a few of them and I'm > wondering > > whether I should use their lube or use my normal silicon spray. I > > think I remember someone saying that their lube isn't good, but I > > don't remember any details and I could be wrong anyway. So?

689. Re: rubiks cube lube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 12:51:40 -0000

Hey Stefan ! My simple advice is this: don't use the rubiks.com tube-lube. It's messy to apply, dries painfully slow and wears out really fast. Stick to silicone spray lubricant. Well, if u happen to have some left of it it shouldn't damage ur cube. But don't buy more of the stuff ... hehe ;-) For cubes other than eastsheen ones any silicone spray should work. Petroleum-based or not. The plastic on eastsheens doesn't like the petroleum-based silicone much (or at least not mine). I have spilt the damn tube-lube over a keyboard, my pants etc. I got it with my diy cube. Switching to normal silicone spray lowered my average by 2 secs !!! So forget the silly tube-lube whatever others might say :D Happy cubing, -Per PS! Hmm maybe the tube-lube paradoxically works nicely on the eastsheens? Haven't tried that yet ;-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I think that might be because it dries slowly. On the Spanish group, > someone recently said it keeps dripping out. > > But I don't have a problem with that. I think I should modify my > question: I'm painting the insides of my cubes with it. Yes, using a > paintbrush. I apply about one big drop per cubie and then keep > "painting" it until it's dry. Took me about 30 minutes for the whole > cube I think. > > So my new question is: Does it *damage* the cube somehow? Or is the > only negative effect that it might not last long in which case I could > still change to silicon spray? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rommy" <barg0023@u...> > wrote: > > > > My cube seemed to become more viscous when I applied the silicon > > from the white tube that comes with diy kits. It's only been 2 > > days... Hopefully it will get better. You might want to try 'Cube- > > Lube' on a crappy cube. I like the Prestone-Brand silicon > > lubricant, and I don't think I should have used 'Cube-Lube' on my > > best speedcube... > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Does anyone have experience with the cube lube you get from rubiks > > for > > > example with the DIY kits? I did get a few of them and I'm > > wondering > > > whether I should use their lube or use my normal silicon spray. I > > > think I remember someone saying that their lube isn't good, but I > > > don't remember any details and I could be wrong anyway. So?

691. Re: rubiks cube lube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 16:52:19 -0000

Hi Per, it's not messy the way I use it and it's dry after those 30 minutes. So that's not a big problem. Also, I don't use much to paint an entire cube, so I guess I can lube one cube maybe 5-10 times with one tube. I just do have 30 tubes and I don't like to think of it as waste :-( I did prepare one of my DIYs with it already and I think it's not bad, so far I like it. I'll lube it again and see how well it turns. And then I'll prepare another one with silicone spray and compare them. I was mainly worried about damaging my cubes but if the worst case is just that they could be better then that's ok. Also, since I want to use them mainly for blindsolving it might actually be bad if they're too smooth (cause that could lead to accidental unwanted twists which are deadly in blindfolding ;-). Oh, and if you come to GCD2 I'll show you my cube lube tube prepared cube and you tell me how you like it :-) I think it is a bit better to apply it the way I do than just to squirt it inside and twist it... Thanks and Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey Stefan ! > > My simple advice is this: don't use the rubiks.com tube-lube. Hmm maybe the tube-lube paradoxically works nicely on the > eastsheens? Haven't tried that yet ;-) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > I think that might be because it dries slowly. 692. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 18:01:17 -0000

I've been advocating such kind of Cube Duels earlier. I have perfomed it in the simple way that one scambles the others cube and with simultaneous start, the first to solve wins. Very easy when meeting other Cubists at pubs etc. A developed version would be to have ten scrambed cubes each and the first who solves all ten wins. Or maybe one 2x2x2, one 3x3x3, one 4x4x4 and finally one 5x5x5. Or weight the number of cubes to the time it takes to solve, something like: one 5x5x5, two 4x4x4 and ten 3x3x3. One may include one- handed, blindfolded, feet,... And combined with relay teams. Endless possibilites! /Anders --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > I've been thinking about the same thing. It's a whole different kind of > competition where good nerves are even more important than for regular > cubing, and where a lot more people can win. Also, it can be done quite > fast, even with a large number of people. > > I suggest best of three, since I think is the most nerve wrecking > format. > > Ideally, it would NOT be done using timers, but with a simultaneous > start, where the first on to place his solved cube on some surface > wins. You'd have to prevent violent contention for it. > > /Lars > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 18:09, Tyson Mao wrote: > > > > > Like a single elimination tournament? We could do that in April if you > > wanted. It might be fun. I was also thinking relay teams or > > something. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 4:39 PM, Evan Gates wrote: > > > >> Just an idea that popped into my head after all the comparison with > >> chess. How about races? Much like chess matches, have people race > >> eachother, best out of three or somethign like that. I know that > >> actualy having two people solving at the same time head to head isn't > >> much different than just solving, but the idea sounds cooler i think, > >> and would be more "intense"(if cubing can be considered intense ;-) > >> i dont know exactly how it would work or anything, i just thought it > >> sounded cool > >> > >> -Evan
693. Re: $ at tournaments?
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 19:51:15 -0000


In my opinion the best way to do the tournaments is they way they
have been doing them. If they section poeple into different groups
and give the winner of each group a prize, then what is to keep a
really faster cuber from trying to get into a bad division so they
know they can win. If you make the entry fees to high it will
dicourage people don't think they can win. I don't think chess can
be compared to speed cubing because there is no ratings in
speedcubing. chess is a one on one compitition and that is why they
are able to have a rating system.





694. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Video
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 12:00:04 -0800

Hey Bob, You do some pretty mean finger tricks there! You should switch to cross-on-bottom or something. Just learn to use your same method with the cross on the bottom. You'll be really bad at first but it'll be worth it. It will be training for when you learn the full Fridrich and then everything will be much easier to adjust.
