695. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: $ at tournaments?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 12:01:12 -0800

It would be nice, eventually when we have enough people helping and the
computer expertise to do so, to have a ladder system where you earn
points for each tournament your participate in and you get a ranking or
something.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 10, 2005, at 11:51 AM, metgorubiks wrote:

>
>
> In my opinion the best way to do the tournaments is they way they
> have been doing them. If they section poeple into different groups
> and give the winner of each group a prize, then what is to keep a
> really faster cuber from trying to get into a bad division so they
> know they can win. If you make the entry fees to high it will
> dicourage people don't think they can win. I don't think chess can
> be compared to speed cubing because there is no ratings in
> speedcubing. chess is a one on one compitition and that is why they
> are able to have a rating system.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

698. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 22:30:16 -0000

i started to make the switch last week. it's pretty awkward, and my times are now around 2 minutes, but i'm sure it will pay off in the end. i'm now doing cross on bottom and can do f2l moves that involve either only the edge or only the corner, and a few that place both. it's more than i knew before, so it's a start. :D i just wish i didn't have so much school work so i could practice more. ~bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hey Bob, > > You do some pretty mean finger tricks there! You should switch to > cross-on-bottom or something. Just learn to use your same method with > the cross on the bottom. You'll be really bad at first but it'll be > worth it. It will be training for when you learn the full Fridrich and > then everything will be much easier to adjust. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 10, 2005, at 6:37 AM, rubikscubewhiz wrote: > > > > > > > Oh yea? chew on THIS! :P > > > > www.thexvb.com/cube/videos/video1.avi > > > > lol > > > > ~bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > >> http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/12.05*.AVI > >> > >> Eat it. > >> > >> Tyson Mao > >> MSC #631 > >> California Institute of Technology > >> > >> On Feb 10, 2005, at 4:21 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > >> > >>> > >>> > >>> Is that you or your girlfriend saying "I'm done"? ;-) > >>> > >>> And hey I'd say it's more like 15.7 so even I have a faster > > video ok I > >>> admit it was lucky but so what I'm still faster so you gotta eat > > my > >>> dust baby! > >>> > >>> Cheers! > >>> Stefan > >>> > >>> > >>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > >>> <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > >>>> Here is a video of me solving in 15 something seconds - > >>>> www.cubestation.co.uk/videos/danh15xx.wmv > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> Eat my cube dust Stefan ;) > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> Dan :-) > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> _____ > >>>> > >>>> From: Stefan Pochmann [mailto:pochmann@g...] > >>>> Sent: 09 February 2005 22:11 > >>>> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>>> Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Video > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> That's a modification of an old video, right? 704. Re: [Speed cubing group] $ at tournaments?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Feb 2005 16:19:10 -0800

One problem if you did the races without timers, are races that are too close to call. I remember at the summer camp thing at stanford, two guys were racing, and they put the cube down at what seemed to be exactly the same time. Because they were on a stackmat we found out that one of them won by somewhere around 0.1 seconds or something like that. I guess if we did it without timers we could jsut redo ties? And also, pops. My thought on pops would just be, you pop, you keep going. No redoes because of pops. Just my ideas on this subject. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Thu, 10 Feb 2005 18:01:17 -0000, al_yyz <anders.larsson@...> wrote: > > I've been advocating such kind of Cube Duels earlier. I have > perfomed it in the simple way that one scambles the others cube and > with simultaneous start, the first to solve wins. Very easy when > meeting other Cubists at pubs etc. A developed version would be to > have ten scrambed cubes each and the first who solves all ten wins. > Or maybe one 2x2x2, one 3x3x3, one 4x4x4 and finally one 5x5x5. Or > weight the number of cubes to the time it takes to solve, something > like: one 5x5x5, two 4x4x4 and ten 3x3x3. One may include one- > handed, blindfolded, feet,... And combined with relay teams. > Endless possibilites! > > /Anders > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus > > <lars@n...> wrote: > > I've been thinking about the same thing. It's a whole different > kind of > > competition where good nerves are even more important than for > regular > > cubing, and where a lot more people can win. Also, it can be done > quite > > fast, even with a large number of people. > > > > I suggest best of three, since I think is the most nerve wrecking > > format. > > > > Ideally, it would NOT be done using timers, but with a > simultaneous > > start, where the first on to place his solved cube on some surface > > wins. You'd have to prevent violent contention for it. > > > > /Lars > > > > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 18:09, Tyson Mao wrote: > > > > > > > > Like a single elimination tournament? We could do that in April > if you > > > wanted. It might be fun. I was also thinking relay teams or > > > something. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Feb 9, 2005, at 4:39 PM, Evan Gates wrote: > > > > > >> Just an idea that popped into my head after all the comparison > with > > >> chess. How about races? Much like chess matches, have people > race > > >> eachother, best out of three or somethign like that. I know > that > > >> actualy having two people solving at the same time head to head > isn't > > >> much different than just solving, but the idea sounds cooler i > think, > > >> and would be more "intense"(if cubing can be considered > intense ;-) > > >> i dont know exactly how it would work or anything, i just > thought it > > >> sounded cool > > >> > > >> -Evan > > > > > Yahoo! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I like that. Shows how little you move your hands. Don't know about > other cubers, Yes, analazing different cubing styles could be interesting! > but I think I have much "larger" motions. Something to > analyze... > Try to solve a cube with only 4 moves: L/M/R + U. You'll notice that your hands (wrists) don't move a lot. And most of the insertions of U turns between L/M/R moves can be considered as fingertricks. > Cheers! > Stefan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > http://grrroux.free.fr/eat_my_dust.avi > > > > Bon appétit!
713. Re: iPAQ cube timer
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 19:16:25 -0000

Grant, Thanks so much for this. I've been looking for a cube timer for the iPAQ!! FYI, I've just installed it on my HP hx4705 (WM2003SE, VGA screen) and it seems to run/display fine. I particularly like the very large start/stop buttons. Small start/stop buttons were things that bothered me on other general iPAQ timers I had installed. It's very helpful that so many cubers are software engineers and can build these apps. I've been using Chris' JNetCube for standalone timing on my laptop, Jess' timer for when I'm online, and now I have Grant's iPAQ cube timer. Thanks guys -- you're awesome!! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > > This is a duplicate of my post to the midwestcubeclub group... I > thought there may be people that are part of one group or the other, > but not both... > > - G > > I wrote the following in that group (URL's been modified for this > group): > > I don't know how many people will really find this useful, but Rommy > saw me using a timer on my iPAQ and asked for it while we were at the > competition. I figured I'd just upload it to the files section on > here. It's pretty limited in it's functionality right now, and while > I have many ideas for future improvements, I unfortunately haven't > had time to change it since original development well over 6 months > ago, so who knows when it'll happen. > > It provides good scrambles for 2x2x2, 3x3x3, 4x4x4, and 5x5x5 cubes. > Click start, you get a 15 second countdown (no sound to indicate your > start time, though) and then time starts. Stop and accept/discard > your time (or indicate a pop), and it will show you your times, most > recent at the top, along with a running average of 12. Additionally, > you can elect to look at your best, worst or current average, or > best/worst single time. > > The file name is CubeTimes2Go.exe, and it can be found in the files > section of this group, which is at > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/files/ .
714. Speeding up and would like advice
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 19:39:37 +0000

Hi everyone,

I'm beginning to speed up now - in the last few days I've gone from around
5 minutes with instructions to around 2 minutes 10-15 seconds with my
hybrid solution plus a cheat sheet from the jeays.net site.

What I'm doing is this:-

I'm using the 3 layer solution incorporating a couple of methods I
developed when I reached around a minute and a quarter in the early 80s and
which I've never really forgotten.

I don't form either the cross or position the four corners but I do both at
once, putting each cubie into place in order - side, corner, side, corner,
keeping an eye out for where the next piece is so that I can anticipate and
get other pieces into position.

I'm trying to move 180 degree turns as one move rather than stopping half
way through the turn, and I'm solving the middle layer my own way.

I look to see if there are any pieces the right way round and incorrectly
positioned and position as many as possible with variations of F2 U2 D2
B2. I avoid getting incorrectly orientated pieces into the correct
position where possible especially if there are bottom layer pieces in the
middle layer. Then I position the remaining side pieces by positioning the
correct pieces where there are wrong pieces first then filling in the
gaps. That can get pretty fast because with it it's possible to position
two or three middle layer cubies at once with one algorithm of just four or
five moves.

The final layer I use the algorithms from the jeays.net site - I am
beginning to get more of it to memory now so I'm speeding up.

What I'm wondering is should I move on now and change to a different
solution such as the LL or PLL to get faster, or should I concentrate on
getting this method as fast as possible by learning it thoroughly and then
adapt it further? I'm still making mistakes with some moves particularly
getting the middle layer cubies into place but that will come with practice.

I'm also wondering about the best way to move the middle slices, I do RL,
FB, UD as necessary in the various formats but should I be moving the
middle slice as one as opposed to the two slices on either side?

I'm one of the people who would never have solved the cube in the early 80s
without using the Singmaster solution so I am quite prepared to use a
solution now and adapt it to speed up again. At the moment I'm using
between 80 and 100 moves to solve the 3x3x3 cube so will appreciate any
advice on speeding up:)

Gillian

Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net

I could use some help answering the following questions:

What is the cubing subculture like?

As for the quirkiness of cubers - speed cubers especially - can you
characterize them?

Just doing an interview for WIRED.

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology




716. Re: [Speed cubing group] Speeding up and would like advice
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 12:39:24 -0800 (PST)

cool if you have a unique system that you think might be something you feel like developing nothing is stopping you. sure the fridrich is fast, but maybe you could be up to some new method :) try to improve upon it and see if you can go sub 1min that will be really cool, a new method weeeeeee. many speedcubers are doing fridrich, idk but i think we are becoming clones :\, cant help it hehe. so yeah try some improvements. if things dont go well, there is always the fridrich ;-) John Lwin --- Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...> wrote: > Hi everyone, > > I'm beginning to speed up now - in the last few days > I've gone from around > 5 minutes with instructions to around 2 minutes > 10-15 seconds with my > hybrid solution plus a cheat sheet from the > jeays.net site. > > What I'm doing is this:- > > I'm using the 3 layer solution incorporating a > couple of methods I > developed when I reached around a minute and a > quarter in the early 80s and > which I've never really forgotten. > > I don't form either the cross or position the four > corners but I do both at > once, putting each cubie into place in order - side, > corner, side, corner, > keeping an eye out for where the next piece is so > that I can anticipate and > get other pieces into position. > > I'm trying to move 180 degree turns as one move > rather than stopping half > way through the turn, and I'm solving the middle > layer my own way. > > I look to see if there are any pieces the right way > round and incorrectly > positioned and position as many as possible with > variations of F2 U2 D2 > B2. I avoid getting incorrectly orientated pieces > into the correct > position where possible especially if there are > bottom layer pieces in the > middle layer. Then I position the remaining side > pieces by positioning the > correct pieces where there are wrong pieces first > then filling in the > gaps. That can get pretty fast because with it it's > possible to position > two or three middle layer cubies at once with one > algorithm of just four or > five moves. > > The final layer I use the algorithms from the > jeays.net site - I am > beginning to get more of it to memory now so I'm > speeding up. > > What I'm wondering is should I move on now and > change to a different > solution such as the LL or PLL to get faster, or > should I concentrate on > getting this method as fast as possible by learning > it thoroughly and then > adapt it further? I'm still making mistakes with > some moves particularly > getting the middle layer cubies into place but that > will come with practice. > > I'm also wondering about the best way to move the > middle slices, I do RL, > FB, UD as necessary in the various formats but > should I be moving the > middle slice as one as opposed to the two slices on > either side? > > I'm one of the people who would never have solved > the cube in the early 80s > without using the Singmaster solution so I am quite > prepared to use a > solution now and adapt it to speed up again. At the > moment I'm using > between 80 and 100 moves to solve the 3x3x3 cube so > will appreciate any > advice on speeding up:) > > Gillian > > Gillian Buchanan > Tatting Editor at Bella Online > http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting > http://www.craftsnlace.net > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online

718. Re: subculture of cubing
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Feb 2005 23:50:11 -0000


Ha, this sounds almost like an anthropology assignment. I did an
ethnography on the "International Rubik's Cube Community" a few months
back for an assignment.

> What is the cubing subculture like?

It's like a giant cookie. Only there are about 300 chocolate chips and
maybe 10 caramel chips. The chocolate chips are those using Fridrich
and everyone else is caramel. Together we taste delicious, but just a
little too chocolaty. The bond between the chips is enormous and we
share one thing in common, we all are made of sugar.

> As for the quirkiness of cubers - speed cubers especially - can you
> characterize them?

Obsessive-compulsive individuals who love turning plastic at blazing
speeds and often suffer a dramatic GPA drop when they first discover
the Rubik's Cube.

Sorry, I suck.

-Chris





719. Re: subculture of cubing
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 01:06:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Ha, this sounds almost like an anthropology assignment. I did an > ethnography on the "International Rubik's Cube Community" a few months > back for an assignment. >snip< > -chris Don't intend to hijack the thread here, but my girlfriend is a grad student in comm and would really like to get her hands on a copy of that ethnography if you still have it. She's a casual cuber, solving in a few minutes on average. As for the questions at hand, I can't say much about the subculture as the only interaction I have with other cubers is through this message board. I've met 2 guys on campus who can do it too, but we're all so busy all the time we've never gotten together. But the quirkiness... I'm rife with it. I would say for some (myself included) part of the allure is doing something very well that not many people can do at all, and of course challenging yourself to do better each time. Nothing quite feels like beating your best time/average. Didn't really answer the question, just shared some thoughts... -Daniel
720. Just an idea..
From: "scmozart" <scmozart@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 02:14:25 -0000


I was thinking about all the discussion on the boards regarding
divisions and things.. and I wanted to input on an idea I had.

Is there any way there could be a head to head tourney like the way
Tennis is set up? I think in order for something like that to
happen, people need to be ranked and only the top 100 can compete
(with the occasional non-ranked players allowed to enter).

I am not sure how the tennis world comes up with rankings but i am
assuming that its based on number of tourney wins. For a system like
this to be effective, there would have to be multiple tourneys a
year.

Anyways just a thought.. head to head tourneys are fun because its
sometimes unpredictable.. Like the Sweet 16 for basketball, the ones
slated to win dont nessessary win.. :)





721. Re: Just an idea..
From: "scmozart" <scmozart@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 02:32:03 -0000

Oh this just occurred to me as a followup idea.. Purhaps have ranked players automatically allowed to enter the tourney and nonranked player compete in a qualifying round.. I think this is the way Tennis does it.. taht way nonranked players can still participate in the tournments. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "scmozart" <scmozart@y...> wrote: > > I was thinking about all the discussion on the boards regarding > divisions and things.. and I wanted to input on an idea I had. > > Is there any way there could be a head to head tourney like the way > Tennis is set up? I think in order for something like that to > happen, people need to be ranked and only the top 100 can compete > (with the occasional non-ranked players allowed to enter). > > I am not sure how the tennis world comes up with rankings but i am > assuming that its based on number of tourney wins. For a system like > this to be effective, there would have to be multiple tourneys a > year. > > Anyways just a thought.. head to head tourneys are fun because its > sometimes unpredictable.. Like the Sweet 16 for basketball, the ones > slated to win dont nessessary win.. :)

723. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: subculture of cubing
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 08:39:17 +0000


>he allure is doing something very well that not
>many people can do at all, and of course challenging yourself to do
>better each time. Nothing quite feels like beating your best
>time/average. Didn't really an

Yes I'd agree with that one - from what I've seen on this board we tend to
have a range of interests which are not shared by the vast majority of the
population and at which we excel, a lot of cubers seem to be musicians as
well and yes as I saw in another posting today a lot of cubers are also
programmers of one kind or another. And a lot of cubers also seem to have
strong mathematical leanings with good memories and strong spatial
development in objects such as puzzles where you have to be able to see at
a glance where things are and where they will move to when you do certain
things.

Gillian


Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net



724. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: subculture of cubing
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 01:01:10 -0800

I think that is typical. Most people on this list probably still
haven't met any of the others.

Or in other words, cubing is an internet subculture, where people
communicate with email and home made movies.

An odd feature is that almost everyone is either around 40 or 20.

/Lars

On Feb 11, 2005, at 17:06, Daniel Hayes wrote:

> As for the questions at hand, I can't say much about the subculture
> as the only interaction I have with other cubers is through this
> message board.



725. Re: [Speed cubing group] Speeding up and would like advice
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 10:18:54 -0000

Hi Gillian, It sounds like you do something similar to what I used to do in the early 80's. I got to around 30-35 seconds with it. The main problem is probably the number of moves - 80-100 is quite a lot. Most systems used now are under 60. If you want to try something different to Fridrich, with fewer moves to learn, fewer moves to solve and therefore potentially somewhat faster I believe, try my page http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle If you haven't yet learned the Fridrich F2L then the systems on this site offer an alternative where putting in middle edges with different moves is the main approach. Good look with whatever methods you use. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gillian Buchanan" <gmb@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, February 11, 2005 9:42 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Speeding up and would like advice At 20:39 11/02/2005, you wrote: >cool > >if you have a unique system that you think might be >something you feel like developing nothing is stopping >you. > >sure the fridrich is fast, b Thanks so much, I'm more combining different methods and using things that work well for me rather than coming up with anything really new, but it's fun:) I will take a look at the Fridrich too:) Gillian Gillian Buchanan Tatting Editor at Bella Online http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting http://www.craftsnlace.net http://www.bellaonline.com/ebooks/ebook25 http://www.bellaonline.com/ebooks/ebook44 http://www.bellaonline.com/ebooks/ebook55 Yahoo! Groups Links
726. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: subculture of cubing
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 10:24:03 -0000

Some common characteristics: There seem to be a surprising number of musicians in the community - I guess creativity, nimble fingers and pattern recognition are common to both. I agree that there are a lot of programmers - way back it used to be all mathematicians and there are still a few of us about. Hate to open this can of worms again but - mostly male! Clearly fascinated by games and puzzles of all sorts - we've had a lot of side discussions on other internet games and postings of fun puzzle sites. I get the impression that the average age is fairly low although there are a fair sprinkling of us older speedcubers. Competitive. Just some immediuate thoughts Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Lars Petrus" <lars@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, February 12, 2005 9:01 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: subculture of cubing I think that is typical. An odd feature is that almost everyone is either around 40 or 20. /Lars On Feb 11, 2005, at 17:06, Daniel Hayes wrote: > As for the questions at hand, I can't say much about the subculture > as the only interaction I have with other cubers is through this > message board. Yahoo! Groups Links

Indeed, mostly males and mostly programmers, or some other similar field. Myself, I am am math major, and when people at school ask me my major after I solve it, they never seem surprised. I think the reason for the age gap is because it seems that most people started when they were young (teens) and either started around 1980 or started recently. ~bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gillian Buchanan <gmb@c...> wrote: > > >he allure is doing something very well that not > >many people can do at all, and of course challenging yourself to do > >better each time. 729. Inspiration and favourite cube video
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 16:14:28 -0000


Hello all,

the first speedcubing video I saw was Dan Knights's.
When I saw his video I just couldn't believe it.
The music was so awesome and his time of 18 seconds impressed
me so much. I watched his video maybe 12 times a day and everytime
I got goose bumps.
I think he inspired me the most.

My favourite video is Macky's 19.83s solve with a pop.
http://www.henage.net/dan/cube/caltechspring.htm
Have a look at the guy who is watching Macky solving.
He starts to smile after the solve and must have thought:
"Uhh...wow...pop, and still faster than anyone else here?!"

By whom were you inspired the most, and what is your favourite
speedcubing video?

-Edgardo







730. Fingertricks
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 16:38:55 -0000


Two questions:

1) Do you know any site that shows on how to perform
fingertricks (basic ones like RUR')? I am searching for something
like Dan Knights's videos.

2) Have you also noticed that people have different styles
on how to perfom fingertricks?

Examples:

-Burntbizzkit, Macky, Tyson: They seem to have their
index fingers rather stretched, while I personally bend it
when doing a U-turn.
An extreme example is Stefan Pochmann's solve
http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/other_stuff/videos/Cube15.wmv
Look at timeindex 11seconds, where he uses his index finger to
perform U2.
Furthermore, the cube's position somehow seems
static, they dont tilt the cube.

-Zbigniew Zborowski and Chris Hardwick: They seem to turn the layers
by rather turning their wrist. And also in Chris's video the cube
doesn't seem static, he tilts the cube the whole time to look ahead.

-And then Dan Knights: He uses his thumb a lot has his own cubing style.

I personally like Burntbizzkit's style. It looks so cool.

Regards

Edgardo












731. Extended cross and Gilles Roux's method
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 16:50:16 -0000


Hi all,

1) I wondered who of you can do extended crosses. And even
double-extended cross sounds incredible.

2) Those of you who can do (double) extended cross, would it be easy
for you to switch to Gilles Roux's method, where you build a 1x2x3
block (especially Chris, the inventor of double extended cross)?
http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_1.html

Quote from Gilles's site:
"But methods that begin with a cross or a 2x2x2 block have a too easy
first step with only four corners or edges. Maybe five would be more
interesting, but you must be able to anticipate almost ten moves and
their effects on the five cubies."

Regards

Edgardo

I am searching for something > like Dan Knights's videos. > > 2) Have you also noticed that people have different styles > on how to perfom fingertricks? > > Examples: > > -Burntbizzkit, Macky, Tyson: They seem to have their > index fingers rather stretched, while I personally bend it > when doing a U-turn. > An extreme example is Stefan Pochmann's solve > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/other_stuff/videos/Cube15.wmv > Look at timeindex 11seconds, where he uses his index finger to > perform U2. > Furthermore, the cube's position somehow seems > static, they dont tilt the cube. > > -Zbigniew Zborowski and Chris Hardwick: They seem to turn the layers > by rather turning their wrist. 733. Re: Extended cross and Gilles Roux's method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 17:34:17 -0000

Hey Edgardo, I really need to overalhaul the introduction to my page to better reflect my strategy on the extend cross as it is now. I don't think it is a good idea now to use the extended cross startegy every time, lots of times full cross solves flow much better and make better use of RLUD moves than an extended cross solve would. An Xcross solve would be shorter, but a cross solve would be faster (which is of course the most important to me). I do, however, still use an extended cross or also even Petrich style start quite often (2x2x2 as a sub-step, then solve the other 2 edges). At some point I want to take a 100 average and see how often I actually use a "non-cross" start, but I think it would be around 10-15% or so, so not as much as I mention on my page when I first thought about converting to Xcross 100%. As far as double extended cross solves, they are quite rare. They usually are the ones where I can form a 1x1x3 block out of 2 corners and an edge, and can easily place the other egdges so as to form a 2x2x3. If I can see this in 15 seconds, then I also make sure that during those moves the last edge of the first layer doesn't end up flipped (i.e. a "bad" position that takes more moves to solve after the 2x2x3). However there are also times where I can form an extended cross and also preserve a c/e pair that I can see will be placed together. So I will do an extended cross solve, then follow with an easy 3 move c/e insert. These are not as rare as they would seem, and can often provide good F2L times. As far as Gilles' method, I've never really tried it to be honest, but I have a rough method of estimating for other setups of pieces for the starting step. An extended cross (double extended crosses happen too infrequently, or are too infrequently noticable to really count here as a basis) has 1 corner and 5 edges. Every piece has a position and an orientation (2 for each edge and 3 for the corner) adding all that up I would "rate" it at 19 (add up 1 for each position and 2 for each edge orientation and 3 for the corner orientation). A 1x2x3 has 2 corners and 3 edges, so by the same rating system it is at 17, so I would call it easier to solve. Again this is just my crude rating system for figuring out very roughly how difficult a beginning step would be. Again I don't have experience with Gilles' method so I can't compare it to an Xcross to say more concretely if it is easier, but it seems there is less you have to solve for. Also the double Xcross has a 25 rating by my system, which would also explain why it is so hard and so rare to actually see a direct solve double Xcross. As a comparison a 2x2x2 has rating 13 and the cross has rating 12. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@g...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > 1) I wondered who of you can do extended crosses. And even > double-extended cross sounds incredible. > > 2) Those of you who can do (double) extended cross, would it be easy > for you to switch to Gilles Roux's method, where you build a 1x2x3 > block (especially Chris, the inventor of double extended cross)? > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_1.html > > Quote from Gilles's site: > "But methods that begin with a cross or a 2x2x2 block have a too easy > first step with only four corners or edges. Maybe five would be more > interesting, but you must be able to anticipate almost ten moves and > their effects on the five cubies." > > Regards > > Edgardo

741. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 cubes
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>

Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 12:48:05 -0600

in the hitchhiker's series where douglas adams proclaims the answer to life, the universe, and everything is 42, he also states that the great question to which 42 is the answer is 'what's 6 times 9?' I was just carrying on the reference. come on now, just because I'm from iowa doesn't mean I'm that dumb. ; ) -mike bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Gillian Buchanan<mailto:gmb@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, February 12, 2005 12:43 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 cubes At 18:34 12/02/2005, you wrote: >yep. last I checked, it was the answer to the question 'what's 6 times 9?' > >-mike bennett > ----- Original M Actually no, 6x9 is 54, 42 is 6x7:) Unless 6x9 and 42 have special significance for the cube? 746. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 cubes
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 21:20:38 +0000

At 20:56 12/02/2005, you wrote:

>How many people have tried the 42 cube marathon? I
>looked on speedcubing and there was only one person
>listed. I did 42 in little less than 20 minutes.
>(about a year ago) I'm think

So for the 42 cube marathon do you need to use 42 different cubes, or do
you use a single cube and scramble it with scrambles set by the marathon
organiser? That could make a difference in solution times if you're
practising at home and don't have 42 cubes to hand!

Mind you maybe we could do that in this group, somebody set up 42
scrambling algorithms that we're all to use then we have a marathon with
each person using a single cube... would be fun anyway.

Gillian

Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net

749. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 cubes
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 22:22:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > yep. last I checked, it was the answer to the question 'what's 6 times 9?' > > -mike bennett Interestingly, it works in base-13. Thought to this fact DNA has retorted "No one writes jokes in base-13..." And I for one am glad that we figured out why the pot of petunia's said "Oh no not again" before it plummeted to its death. On an ACTUAL cube related noted, there is a handy cube reference in _Dirk Gently's Holistic Detective Agency_, about trying to maneuver a sofa through an impossible small stairwell. Douglas Adams was my hero! -Daniel

753. New guy intro
From: "keefdcuber" <keefdcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 06:44:03 -0000


Hey people, I've just signed up. I'm Keith, a 36 year old cuber from
Australia. My best time so far is a lucky 29 sec. but I'm usually in
the 40/50 second range.

I learned to solve the cube just after I left school in '84, I could
only do the first 2 layers so I bought a solution book to learn the
last layer.

I always kept a cube handy after the big craze died off and got into
speedcubing about 6 months ago.

Unfortunately there aren't any competetitions that I know of over
here but I'd like to see that change in the future.

Just out of curiosity, what kind of cube do you guys (and girls)
favour?


Keith.





754. Re: [Speed cubing group] New guy intro
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Feb 2005 22:47:23 -0800

I prefer the normal cubes from www.rubiks.com . They vary in quality a
lot so you may have to buy a lot in order to find the perfect one but
in general, I feel that all cubes, after sufficient wearing down, are
all good speedcubes.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

755. Re: New guy intro
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 09:13:28 -0000

I agree with Tyson. I tried a Studio and some other random cubes and always fall back to my trusty Rubiks.com cube. I like the arched centers on the newer cubes. I wish that I didn't loose mine a week ago :( The cube I'm using now is a Rubiks.com cube and, after about a week, it works great. It was horrible at first, but turns like a champ now. -Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I prefer the normal cubes from www.rubiks.com . 756. Re: [Speed cubing group] Inspiration and favourite cube video
From: James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 01:16:09 -0800 (PST)

hey edgardo!!!

me, it is also a speedsolving video that inspired mi
to be a speedcuber, when i saw the first speedsolving
video of my life, it was chris hardwick's speedsolving
video, solving it for 17.88 seconds, with a matrix
background music, it was really cool!!!! i watch it
for i don't know how many times already, and also the
video of macky's 12.11 seconds world record..........

jAybeE

Hey!" I again have a Rubiks Studio cube and really like. I like to be able to adjust the screw tention to get the sides to turn equally. 758. Re: Fingertricks
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 12:40:49 -0000


Hi

> 2) Have you also noticed that people have different styles
> on how to perfom fingertricks?

I think it's very interesting to compare styles. A large fraction of
speedcubers use more or less the same system (Fridrich or variant) but
the way people put it into practice is unique and it can be
fascinating to watch.

What always strikes me when I compare my style to others, is that I
barely use my left hand. Just have a look at some of my videos on this
page:

http://www.cubezone.be/videos.html

Especially the 13.09s solve is a good example. 95% of the movements is
done with my right hand and my left hand is just supporting the cube
and doing the occasional U' move. It's something I've been wanting to
change because I'm sure I can benefit from developping the dexterity
my left hand much more.

Cheers,
LarsV





759. 4x4x4 method
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 16:32:14 -0000


I have had a 4x4x4 for some time now and have lately started to think
about getting in to speedsolving it.

My current method is this:

1. Make 3 centers and the three edge groups that go with them, thereby
forming a 3x3x3.
2. Make a forth center and the two edge groups that I need to extend
to a 3x3x4.
3. Form the two remainging centers and the three edge groups to form a
3x4x4 block (F3L)
4. Solve the LL edge groups and do normal 3x3x3 LL to solve LL.

This is my adaption of the Petrus method to the 4x4x4 cube. The only
thing I don´t do is to orientate all corners after finnishing the
3x3x4.
Does anyone else use a modified or standard Petrus for the 4x4x4?

For those who already are fast on the 4x4x4 how does this method sound
to you in means of speed, recognition and number of moves?

For the moment I average about 150-200 moves but I use my own
(inefficient ways) of pairing up the edge groups. My times are around
3 minutes mostly because it still takes lots of time to find the
cubies I need.

Is this something worth trying to improve and become fast at or is it
just better to switch to an other method (I know it´s a short step to
the method Chris uses)?

Mikael







760. Video archive
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 19:53:25 -0000


There has been a lot of talk about all kinds of cubing videos lately
and most of us like to watch them. When I first started cubing I
searched the web for speedcubing videos and found it quite difficult
to find any.

The one thing I noticed that I never found a video archive with loads
of vidoes. Only a few vidoes here and there on different sites
(usually of the one hosting the site). I think it would be really cool
to have a big archive (on speedcubing.com maybe?) where everybody
could post their own vidoes. The archice could be divided in different
categories like 2x2x2, 3x3x3, fingertricks, LL algs etc. and
subcategories (normal, onehanded, blindfolded etc.) and then arranged
by performer or time. The archive could also contain links to pages
with videos.

Now I don´t know anything about these kinds of things but if someone
would make the effort to put an archive that ppl can submit their
videos to by filling in some kind of form I can´t imaging the whole
thing to be too much work. Or am I completly wrong?

This is something I´ve been missing!

Just an idea,
Mikael

762. Re: Video archive
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 20:59:07 -0000


> depending on how much space that would take up, i could host
> something like that on my site when i get it going. anybody have an
> idea how much space that would require?

It would require an enormous amount of space if you planned on
actually HOSTING all those videos. I think it would be better you
created a database that people could just send links to their videos.
Hosting of the videos would need to be done by the cubers.

-Chris





763. Re: New guy intro
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 21:05:15 -0000

Hi Keith, Welcome. For speedcubing I rate the cubes: 1. Ideal Tiled Deluxe Edition Best all around, no other cube comes close. It has adjusting screws and is arched underneath the centers - the hard, slick plastic is thicker than others and is faster unlubed than all the other cubes lubed. It is a bit heavier than other cubes. Rarely pops or locks up. The Rubik's Game/Challenge has Deluxe cubes with peg holes. I takes about 5 minutes to get used to the peg holes which make for better grip. 2. The new cubes from Seven Towns (Rubiks.com, Hasbro, Winning Moves and Hessport) Comes with arched centers, can be ordered with screws. These never pop. Lighter than the Deluxe, it takes lube well. Tends to lock up more than the Deluxe. Averages 1 1/2 seconds slower than Deluxe for 30 second solve. The paper stickers wear out quickly because the sticker edges catch on fingertips. If you can avoid touching the edges of the stickers they will last longer. The "self colored plastic" stickers wear well but don't look as good. The blue and green are easy to confuse in low light. 3. Ideal cubes circa 1980-1983. The ones made in Hungary, England, and Hong Kong are the best. Avoid the Taiwan-made cubes. Has adjustable screws. Very few have arches, but the arched version is the lightest official cube. Tends to pop instead of locking up. Averages 2 1/2 second slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. 4. Rubik's studio cubes. The ones made in Hungary are have the best plastic of cubes made nowadays. Comes with screws but not arches. Pops quite a lot. Averages nearly three seconds slower than the Deluxe for a 30 second solve. The ones made in Russia are not as good. I don't know about the ones made in China. 5. Older Hasbro (etc) cube (before 2000) had screws, but not arches. A friends older Hasbro speedcube is fairly quick, but I have little experience with this one. 6. Wonderful Puzzler. Well made, comes with arches. Never tried to make one into a speedcube. I don't know if they have screws. 7. C*4 cube Made by Matchbox in the late 80s, with Rubik's silkouette and signature. Lousy plastic. Not a very good cube. 8. Mefferts Decent plastic, but no springs or screws. Not good for speedcubing because they have no pressure and you must stop a turn with effort. Constantly locks up. 9. "Old Brand Magic Square" Terrible cube, avoid it. These are made of cheap thin plastic which breaks very easily. Some people use the tiles one better cubes. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "keefdcuber" <keefdcuber@y...> wrote: > > Hey people, I've just signed up. I'm Keith, a 36 year old cuber from > Australia. My best time so far is a lucky 29 sec. but I'm usually in > the 40/50 second range. > > I learned to solve the cube just after I left school in '84, I could > only do the first 2 layers so I bought a solution book to learn the > last layer. > > I always kept a cube handy after the big craze died off and got into > speedcubing about 6 months ago. > > Unfortunately there aren't any competetitions that I know of over > here but I'd like to see that change in the future. > > Just out of curiosity, what kind of cube do you guys (and girls) > favour? > > > Keith.

765. Re: Video archive
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 21:37:59 -0000


www.rubiks.dk had a huge archive of vids before the revamp. I think
Jesse said that the bandwidth required to host was cost prohibative.
After the revamping he did have a page dedicated to video links.
Anyone who was registered could link to their solving video on their
own host.

The second way is the only way to do it for free IMHO. I have 1.83
GB of movies relating to the cube, 95% are solution vids I've scoured
the internet for, on average they are 6.5 MB each. That's a lot of
space, and a lot of bandwidth.

-Daniel

Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 21:40:38 -0000

Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > www.rubiks.dk had a huge archive of vids before the revamp. 767. Re: 4x4x4 method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 21:47:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > Is this something worth trying to improve and become fast at or is it > just better to switch to an other method (I know it´s a short step to > the method Chris uses)? Hi Mikael, I'd say it's definitely worth trying. I've been playing with some ideas to solve the 4x4 differently than I do so far (which is centers/edges/3x3). I think it will be good for recognition to do "3x3 solving parts" not at the very end but instead earlier (e.g. like you do) because this limits the number of possible places that you have to look at to find pieces. So try it and don't give up too easily! At the very least you'll learn something and you'll create something on your own, which is very good in my opinion. Cheers! Stefan

769. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Fingertricks
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 14:01:02 -0800

I think you and I cube with very similar styles. I also do almost all
of my movements with my right hand while using only the left index
finger to do a U'. It's the product of the cross-on-left cuber. I've
been meaning to build ambidexterity though. I think it'll help... and
it can't hurt.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 13, 2005, at 4:40 AM, Lars Vandenbergh wrote:

> Hi
>
>> 2) Have you also noticed that people have different styles
>> on how to perfom fingertricks?
>
> I think it's very interesting to compare styles. A large fraction of
> speedcubers use more or less the same system (Fridrich or variant) but
> the way people put it into practice is unique and it can be
> fascinating to watch.
>
> What always strikes me when I compare my style to others, is that I
> barely use my left hand. Just have a look at some of my videos on this
> page:
>

770. Re: Video archive
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 22:46:34 -0000

I too have quite a few videos, about 1.75gigs of them. Like Stefan said, the EC2004 video is very large. One of the things I'd like to mention that whether someone hosts a video archive or not, a naming scheme for videos needs to be set. I have been naming the videos I have as "Category Time NameOfPerson.avi" (or wmv, etc.). So for instance, I have "3x3x3 17'88 Chris Hardwick.mpeg". This makes it convenient, since all vids of the same puzzle are grouped, then listed in order of speed. It makes it a lot better than downloading "cubefast.wmv" or "chris3.mpeg". Also, I share all the vids I have on the campus network here at the University of Maryland, and have had quite a few people download them from me. I get messages ranging from "wow thats cool!" to "is that for real?" to "i hate that freaking toy". -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > What about the EC2004 video? That's around 800MB, too. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > EDIT: > > > > I took a peak and realized that I had the WC2003 vid in there which > > was 800+ MB. 773. Half-turn group algorithm
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 02:58:52 -0000


I've been trying to play with the half-turn group (solving with only
half-turns) but I keep running into this problem: UF and UB are
swapped, as are UR and UL. The algorithm I'd use for this position is
M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2, but I can't do this in the half-turn group, and I
can't find an efficient solution.

Does anyone here know of an efficient way to fix this situation using
only half-turns?





774. Re: Half-turn group algorithm
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 03:56:21 -0000

R2 B2 D2 (L2 F2)x3 D2 B2 R2 Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > I've been trying to play with the half-turn group (solving with only > half-turns) but I keep running into this problem: UF and UB are > swapped, as are UR and UL. The algorithm I'd use for this position is > M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2, but I can't do this in the half-turn group, and I > can't find an efficient solution. > > Does anyone here know of an efficient way to fix this situation using > only half-turns?
775. fingers
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 04:09:51 -0000


I just switched over from cross on top to cross on bottom and I've
been working on the F2L. I've noticed that I have a natural
tendency to use my thumb a lot, like for the U' in RU'R, and I use
my middle finger a lot, like in the U in R'UR. Does anybody use a
different style than this?

~bob





776. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method

777. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 cubes
From: keggerius <keggerius@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 22:28:24 -0800 (PST)

Just to make things perfectly clear for those who haven't read the books, heard the radio series, seen the TV show, or fell into the future through a hole in the space-time continuum to May 6th (my birthday, woohoo!) and seen the movie..... ***SPOILER ALERT*** The Earth was actually a giant computer built for the sole purpose of discovering the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything. But when Arthur Dent and Ford Prefect arrived on prehistoric Earth with the Golgafrinchams, the program was disrupted. Therefore the question "What do you get when you multiply six by nine?" (which came from Arthur's brain as a result of him being part of the penultimate configuration of the computer program) is actually NOT the correct Ultimate Question, and Arthur's lament about always thinking that there was something fundamentally wrong with the universe was merely born of the fact that he had finally discovered the purpose of his entire planet, only to realize at the same moment that there was indeed something that had gone fundamentally wrong with it, and that he was part of the cause. Ok, so maybe that did the opposite of making it perfectly clear, but though it may be hard to tell without knowing the rest of the story, you can believe Tyson when he says it is "the most brilliantly crafted line in all of nerd literature." To me, the subtlety and various layers of humor and emotion that can be extracted from what at first glance appears to be a simple quip is what made Douglas Adams a true genius. To quote DNA himself (speaking of a line by a different author), "There is not much in the isolated line to tell you that when you read it in context you are at the pinnacle of one of the most sublime moments in all English literature." Anyhow, I hope I have managed to inspire at least one of you to go and introduce yourself to these marvelous books, and to anyone planning on seeing the movie, I would recommend reading at least the first two books ("The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" and "The Restaurant at the End of the Universe"). Don't Panic! Ben B. P.S. Anyone who would like a copy of the original radio series, the TV show, or any of the books-on-tape (read by the author) including the Dirk Gently books, please let me know. --- Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > in the hitchhiker's series where douglas adams > proclaims the answer to life, the universe, and > everything is 42, he also states that the great > question to which 42 is the answer is 'what's 6 > times 9?' 779. Super-Megaminx
From: keggerius <keggerius@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Feb 2005 23:40:16 -0800 (PST)

Getting back to a more cube-related topic, I recently
finished converting a 12-color tiled Megaminx into a
Super-Megaminx. I have not heard any discussion of
such a puzzle before, at least as more than just a
concept, and I can find no pictures of one. Has anyone
else made one of these?

My best time so far is 9:08.68, as compared to my best
time for a regular Megaminx of 5:05.24, but I'm
improving rapidly, besides which I haven't adjusted
the screws or lubed it yet.

An interesting fact about the Super-Megaminx (at least
to those interested in such things), is that while the
regular Megaminx has fewer possible positions
(1.007*10^68) than the 5x5x5 cube (2.829*10^74), the
Super-Megaminx has more (2.458*10^76), but still less
than the Super-5x5x5 (2.116*10^94), that is if I've
done my math correctly...

Also, I was happy to discover that the simple
Super-3x3x3 alg (FRFR')*5, which leaves the cube
solved except for a half turn of the F center, can be
applied to the Super-Megaminx: (FRFR')*12, which
leaves the Megaminx solved except for a
counter-clockwise 1/5 turn of the F center.

I'm very proud of my creation and how well it turned
out for a first attempt. I'll post some pictures of it
soon.

Ben B.






__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?

http://mail.yahoo.com


780. Re: Super-Megaminx
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 08:12:13 -0000

Hey Ben, That sounds like a very fun puzzle! I'm curious what method you used for the centers, to know when they are correctly oriented? Did you have to take some time to memorize which centers are oriented which way before starting the solve? Or do you use colors on each center so you just have to line up the colors with the adjacent faces? Also about your number of combinations, I get different numbers for the cube puzzles. For the 5x5 I get (2.8287 * 10^74), the super 5x5 I get (5.2892 * 10^93), which is exactly 1/4 your number btw. I agree on the super megaminx number though, I also got (2.458*10^76). As for the cube numbers, the method I used to get those figures is on my page at http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/cubecombos.html For the super 5x5 I think you didn't take into consideration that the parity of both the center piece orbits is fixed once you have permuted the 24-piece edge orbit and the 8 corners. So you get the (24!)^3 term, but you have to divide by 4 to account for both center piece obits having to have fixed parity based on the parities of the corners and the 24-piece edge orbit. By the way, you should do a super-megaminx no inspection solve too, since that would be the purest form of timed megaminx solving that you can do :) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, keggerius <keggerius@y...> wrote: > Getting back to a more cube-related topic, I recently > finished converting a 12-color tiled Megaminx into a > Super-Megaminx. I have not heard any discussion of > such a puzzle before, at least as more than just a > concept, and I can find no pictures of one. Has anyone > else made one of these? > > My best time so far is 9:08.68, as compared to my best > time for a regular Megaminx of 5:05.24, but I'm > improving rapidly, besides which I haven't adjusted > the screws or lubed it yet. > > An interesting fact about the Super-Megaminx (at least > to those interested in such things), is that while the > regular Megaminx has fewer possible positions > (1.007*10^68) than the 5x5x5 cube (2.829*10^74), the > Super-Megaminx has more (2.458*10^76), but still less > than the Super-5x5x5 (2.116*10^94), that is if I've > done my math correctly... > > Also, I was happy to discover that the simple > Super-3x3x3 alg (FRFR')*5, which leaves the cube > solved except for a half turn of the F center, can be > applied to the Super-Megaminx: (FRFR')*12, which > leaves the Megaminx solved except for a > counter-clockwise 1/5 turn of the F center. > > I'm very proud of my creation and how well it turned > out for a first attempt. I'll post some pictures of it > soon. > > Ben B. > > > > > > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! 781. Re: Video archive
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 09:16:22 -0000

Hey! It sounds in theory like a good idea to share the videos by something like BitTorrent. But im afraid of diverging availability. So i would still prefer that they be put on a dedicated server. Another important thing is to standardise on the codec used for compression of the vids. I suggest using either windows media format (wmv) or divx (avi). 386 kbps should be good enough in most circumstances and would assure that those with limited bandwidth can also downloads vids for 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cube (or megaminx or whatever). Most videos can be uncompressed to raw avi and then be recompressed to the desired compressed format. (Virtual Dub or similar). There will still be problems with larger tournaments vids like the swedish video from Amsterdam which is over 700 MB if i remember correctly. Thos vids will in reality still only be available for download for those with a good bandwidth. How about distributing those on cd/dvd? And pay via PayPal or something (symbolic amount to cover just the media cost + shipping). Happy cubewatching ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > There has been a lot of talk about all kinds of cubing videos lately > and most of us like to watch them. When I first started cubing I > searched the web for speedcubing videos and found it quite difficult > to find any. > > The one thing I noticed that I never found a video archive with loads > of vidoes. Only a few vidoes here and there on different sites > (usually of the one hosting the site). I think it would be really cool > to have a big archive (on speedcubing.com maybe?) where everybody > could post their own vidoes. The archice could be divided in different > categories like 2x2x2, 3x3x3, fingertricks, LL algs etc. and > subcategories (normal, onehanded, blindfolded etc.) and then arranged > by performer or time. The archive could also contain links to pages > with videos. > > Now I don´t know anything about these kinds of things but if someone > would make the effort to put an archive that ppl can submit their > videos to by filling in some kind of form I can´t imaging the whole > thing to be too much work. Or am I completly wrong? > > This is something I´ve been missing! > > Just an idea, > Mikael
782. Re: Super-Megaminx
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 09:49:48 -0000

Hey! Cool that it works to "generalise" the (FRF'R)*5 on cubes to (FRF'R) *12 on the megaminx. In terms of moves it's not short but probably as short as it goes? Anyway it doesn't seem very productive to supersolve the megaminx by normal solve then orienting the centers like this. U would have to use that rather long alg something like (2*18)/5 + 2*(2*18)/5 times on average. This equals (36+72)/5 or approx 21 to 22 times. About 1000 moves just for the center orientations :-P The lack of pure slice moves on the megaminx is the reason why we are not likely to find many short supergroup algs, i meanmore specifically algs only turning centers. Such algs are easily found on the 3x3x3 cube. Therefore i believe it's most productive to orient all centers and then solve puzzle more or less exclusively with center-preserving commutators.. It should add something like 1:30 or 2:00 only to ur normal times. But it's only a rough estimate anyway. I hate my megaminx cause it's bl**** 6-color version. With nasty parity issue and also recognition obscurities. I need to look at color-arrangement on the corners as well, when looking for the next. It' not enough simply to have the correct colors on that corner ... arrghhh ... And there are only 15 different edges, 2 of each. 2 of each is why we might end up w parity. The cure is to set up an edge 3-cycle where two of the edges are of the same colors ;-) If i resticker my megaminx to 12-color version i might as well make a super megaminx also ;-) -Per K > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, keggerius <keggerius@y...> wrote: > Getting back to a more cube-related topic, I recently > finished converting a 12-color tiled Megaminx into a > Super-Megaminx. I have not heard any discussion of > such a puzzle before, at least as more than just a > concept, and I can find no pictures of one. Has anyone > else made one of these? > > My best time so far is 9:08.68, as compared to my best > time for a regular Megaminx of 5:05.24, but I'm > improving rapidly, besides which I haven't adjusted > the screws or lubed it yet. > > An interesting fact about the Super-Megaminx (at least > to those interested in such things), is that while the > regular Megaminx has fewer possible positions > (1.007*10^68) than the 5x5x5 cube (2.829*10^74), the > Super-Megaminx has more (2.458*10^76), but still less > than the Super-5x5x5 (2.116*10^94), that is if I've > done my math correctly... > > Also, I was happy to discover that the simple > Super-3x3x3 alg (FRFR')*5, which leaves the cube > solved except for a half turn of the F center, can be > applied to the Super-Megaminx: (FRFR')*12, which > leaves the Megaminx solved except for a > counter-clockwise 1/5 turn of the F center. > > I'm very proud of my creation and how well it turned > out for a first attempt. I'll post some pictures of it > soon. > > Ben B. > > > > > > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com
783. Re: fingers
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 17:13:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I just switched over from cross on top to cross on bottom and I've > been working on the F2L. I've noticed that I have a natural > tendency to use my thumb a lot, like for the U' in RU'R, and I use > my middle finger a lot, like in the U in R'UR. Does anybody use a > different style than this? > > ~bob Hi Bob, I think most speedcubers use their thumb for doing U' in most cases (depends on the situation.. In some cases you can pull it with you left index, or even push it with you right index, but I don't like to do that very much). Same thing for U with right index finger. You should search for some slow video's that illustrate how to do certain algorithms, and you'll see how cubers perform 'standard' triggers like RUR'U', RUR'U, RU2 etc. http://www.speedcubing.com/peter/AllesFastPermute.html has some slow videos, and I know you will find more of them. Here's anohter adres: http://puzzlingaddiction.com/vids/. Good luck, Joël.
784. Re: Super-Megaminx
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 17:35:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Cool that it works to "generalise" the (FRF'R)*5 on cubes to (FRF'R) > *12 on the megaminx. In terms of moves it's not short but probably > as short as it goes? Oh Per, you should really know better ;-) Try (R' d' R Ux R' d R Ux)*3 where d means everything below U and x is how much you want to rotate the center. And it's also supereasy to understand (right?). I thought about blindsolving a supermegaminx way back when but then I didn't want to touch my old megaminx anymore and the new ones weren't ready and then I forgot. Maybe one day... > Therefore i believe it's most productive to orient all centers and > then solve puzzle more or less exclusively with center-preserving > commutators.. It should add something like 1:30 or 2:00 only to ur > normal times. But it's only a rough estimate anyway. I think it would be even better to just orient the centers on the fly, e.g. when you use Grant's method (and probably most others) connect the first edge to the next center so that they're connected the right way. Have you ever solved the megaminx exclusively using commutators? Setup moves are a pain, believe me (cause I of course did that back when) ; -) > I hate my megaminx cause it's bl**** 6-color version. Poor Per ;-) I love my new tiled megaminx so much I even ordered two more. Maybe you should get one, too? You can still use your stickered one to make a nice supermegaminx... Cheers! Stefan

787. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Super-Megaminx
From: keggerius <keggerius@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 12:28:23 -0800 (PST)

To answer Chris's question, I used actual colors on the centers for quick and easy orientation recognition. I took each center tile and chopped five trapezoidal pieces off the outside edges, leaving a smaller pentagon in the middle, then swapped the pieces around (very much like the center pieces on Stefan's Super-5x5x5). (R' d' R Ux R' d R Ux)*3 is a very cool alg, exactly half the length of (FRFR')*12 and can fix any center with only a single application, where (FRFR')*12 takes two applications 50% of the time. However, to make it truly SUPEReasy to understand, I would write it as (F' U' R Ux R' U F Ux)*3. Is that easier? Maybe it's just me... In any case, I don't use such long algs when actually solving it, instead I use a layered approach, for both regular and super-megaminx solving, with the layers all parallel to two opposite faces. To explain my method, I'll refer to the layers thusly, from the top and bottom in towards the middle: 1. U edges and corners, and D edges and corners 2. UA and DA edges (adjacent to the U and D faces, respectively) 3. UA and DA corners(adjacent to the UA and DA edges, respectively) 4. M edges (the ring of 10 edges in the middle) 1: The cross (pentagram?). Made with the D edges, obviously. The D center and the 5 adjacent centers can all be correctly oriented here with a minimum of extra turns. 2: Insert the D corners and DA edges. Usually I insert 4 D corners and then use a working corner for the DA edges, but I'm working on using CE pairs instead (which are easier to do intuitively on the megaminx given the greater free space you have to work with). 3. Insert the DA corners and M edges. This can be done one piece at a time, or as a combination of 5 single edges and 5 CE pairs. During this stage, the 5 centers adjacent to the U face are oriented. 4. Insert 4 of the UA corner and UA edge pairs. Once again these can be done individually or in CE pairs, although doing the pairs intuitively at this stage is harder because space is more limited. 5. Use the last UA slot and the U face to complete the six remaining edges with edge 3-cycles. Usually takes an average of about 3 cycles, but more like 4 if the U center has to be oriented as well. 6. Complete the six remaining corners with corner 3-cycles. Obviously this would take 4 cycles if the first three corners were done one at a time, but with practice it can almost always be done with just 2. So that's my method. There are so few Megaminx methods out there, the more the better, I say. When I post pictures of my Super Megaminx, I'll post some pictures showing each stage of a solve. Who knows, perhaps when I get some free time, I'll turn it into an actual website with actual details! Ben B. --- Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per > Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Cool that it works to "generalise" the (FRF'R)*5 > on cubes to (FRF'R) > > *12 on the megaminx. In terms of moves it's not > short but probably > > as short as it goes? > > Oh Per, you should really know better ;-) > > Try (R' d' R Ux R' d R Ux)*3 where d means > everything below U and x is > how much you want to rotate the center. And it's > also supereasy to > understand (right?). > > I thought about blindsolving a supermegaminx way > back when but then I > didn't want to touch my old megaminx anymore and the > new ones weren't > ready and then I forgot. Maybe one day... > > > Therefore i believe it's most productive to orient > all centers and > > then solve puzzle more or less exclusively with > center-preserving > > commutators.. It should add something like 1:30 or > 2:00 only to ur > > normal times. But it's only a rough estimate > anyway. > > I think it would be even better to just orient the > centers on the fly, > e.g. when you use Grant's method (and probably most > others) connect > the first edge to the next center so that they're > connected the right > way. > > Have you ever solved the megaminx exclusively using > commutators? Setup > moves are a pain, believe me (cause I of course did > that back when) ; > -) > > > I hate my megaminx cause it's bl**** 6-color > version. > > Poor Per ;-) I love my new tiled megaminx so much I > even ordered two > more. Maybe you should get one, too? You can still > use your stickered > one to make a nice supermegaminx... > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around http://mail.yahoo.com

792. Re: Super-Megaminx
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 23:55:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > How's it going with ur UuRr solving. I didn't do it much and now not > > for a long time. I didn't get any fast with it at all. And i guess i > > also lost interest ... hehe ... > > Did that only very seldomly recently. I think after a few warmup > solves I can get sub1:20 again, best average was 1:17 and best single > 1:02 I think. But I'm focusing more on other things now, partly > because I was the only one who seriously did it and competition is > sometimes really needed for motivation ;-) I've been trying to figure out how you did the UuRr solving - looks like you did centers, some edges, and then some other algorithms to fix the thing, but I have absolutely no idea. How do you do that?
793. Re: Types of Cubes
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 23:55:04 -0000

Hi Mark, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mark Longridge <zero1@l...> wrote: > I'm not saying your wrong. Nichols was the first to make a > cubical 2x2x2, but Ideal Toy turned Nichols down. > > If Larry Nichols had an effective mechanism instead of one > based on magnets I don't think Ideal Toy (itself an American company) > would have passed on it. It's hard to say what they were open to back then, but I think you might be right. > To be fair I've no first hand information about his > 2x2x2 but I don't see how a magnet-based 2x2x2 could work except > by forcing it apart and then letting it pull itself back together. I never tried one though I saw a magnet version for sale recently. I read that he first came up with it in 1957. Too bad that he didn't come up with another mechanism. Suppose a 2x2x2 had been marketed back then, do you think others would have been inspired to develop a 3x3x3 before 1974? Anyway, since Eastsheen's mechanism is different from Rubik's, the mechanism isn't the issue. > I'm not personally against the idea of allowing eastsheen or other > types of cubes in tournaments. Neither am I. I think that there would be a better market for 2x2x2s if someone made a decent one. Rubik's 3.75 milliimeter one is too small to handle, and their 2 inch version is impossible to turn, and while Eastsheen's is way too loose, at least it is halfway workable. So far I've wasted a whole lot of time, energy and money trying for a good one. Not letting other brands into the tournaments is fine if their version is the original, like with the 3x3x3, when they are protecting their idea and patents, and most knock-offs are bad, but I don't agree with their not allowing the 2x2x2, when their version is not good, and they didn't originate it. > In bowling tournaments you're not > constrained to use a particular make of bowling ball. In tennis > tournaments I'm pretty sure the players don't use only one > manufacturer of tennis racket. Players get paid for endorsing a brand. The manufacturers realise is that if the good players prefer their brand, it will outsell their competitors. Better product is what real open-market competition is all about. I don't know what it will take to get someone to make an good, adjustable 2x2x2, but I think it begins with letting them know we want one. > > Mark Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mark Longridge <zero1@l...> wrote: > I'm not saying your wrong. Nichols was the first to make a > cubical 2x2x2, but Ideal Toy turned Nichols down. > > If Larry Nichols had an effective mechanism instead of one > based on magnets I don't think Ideal Toy (itself an American company) > would have passed on it. To be fair I've no first hand information about his > 2x2x2 but I don't see how a magnet-based 2x2x2 could work except > by forcing it apart and then letting it pull itself back together. > > I'm not personally against the idea of allowing eastsheen or other > types of cubes in tournaments. In bowling tournaments you're not > constrained to use a particular make of bowling ball. In tennis > tournaments I'm pretty sure the players don't use only one > manufacturer of tennis racket. > > Mark > > > > > On February 4, 2005 08:36 pm, d_j_salvia wrote: > > Hi Per, > > > > One of the things that bothers me about the "no eastsheen 2x2x2" > > rule is that the 2x2x2 was invented (and patented) by Larry Nichols > > long before Rubik invented the 3x3x3. > > > > David J
794. [Speed cubing group] Re: Super-Megaminx
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 23:59:13 -0000


I can do the Megaminx [except for the last layer. can't find any algs.
grr.] using what I call the "wimpy Petrus" method. Do a cross on the
bottom, then keep pairing up an edge and a corner (or sometimes just
an edge if you're starting on to a new face) and putting it in, then
when you have 2 faces left flip all the edges correctly, and on the
last side use some Sune equivalents to orient the corners. I have no
idea for PLL, though.





795. Valentine's Day
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 16:42:48 -0800

Hey Everyone,

I'm either the victim of a really funny prank, or... or else?!?

http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/valentine.JPG

(On the sheet of paper.)

to feel your hands holding my sides firmly
the same way you grab Rubik's cube to solve
to let you try your finger tricks on me
and have my will, with lubricant, dissolve

i'd pull the first two layers off myself
'cause that's the algorithm that i know
but you would need to do the PLL
maybe give the z-permutation a go

after the initial inspection is done
let me know the orientation that you want
i promise that it will be lots of fun
just like your tournaments that i haunt

i yearn for you like you a sub-fifteen
for you're the best solve i have ever seen

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

799. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Valentine's Day
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Feb 2005 20:33:29 -0800

So I was in lab and I came back to my room and it was on my desk. I
actually didn't notice it at first because Macky was in my room using
the computer but then suddenly, we realized it was a cube. Then, we
realized it wasn't just a cube, but it was actually a solve state on
the cube.

The hand writing is definitely from a girl but it could easily have
been a guy's idea and they asked a girl to write it. Still no idea who
did it. When I find out, I'll put a mug shot of them up or something.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology
