800. Re: Weird Cubing Habits
From: albuscorvus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 06:10:36 -0000

I practice my one-handed cubing while driving a lot. I have a 300 mile round trip every weekend, so it gives me something to do on the road. People think I'm crazy, but it's not really that dangerous seeing as you only have to glance at the cube a half-dozen or so times in order to solve it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > I also have to admit that I´m a toiletcuber. But only on sitdown > sessions because one-handed cubing isn´t my strongest area =D > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob R. Burton" > <rrburton@e...> wrote: > > > > I am guilty of toilet cubing...I can even do the 5x5x5 on long > > sessions. > > > > ~bobby b. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "scmozart" > > <scmozart@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Ok fess up guys.. how many cube on the toliet? > > > > > > and if you do.. i hope its a dedicated cube.. > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > > > Hey all, > > > > > > > > This is actually a question from my wife. Does anyone else use > > a > > > cube in the shower (I have one dedicated for this)? Or any other > > > untraditional cubing habits? > > > > > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
801. Cube Sighting
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 06:38:48 -0000


I'm not sure if anyone has noticed this yet...but in the movie Hitch
with will smith...on the female lead's desk...during the scene where
he mails her a walkie-talkie...there is a rubik's cube sitting on her
desk.

I pointed it out to my girlfriend, and she pointed out to me that I
was probably one of about maybe 5 people that noticed it on the
table...she hadn't until I said something.

809. Re: Valentine's Day
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 15:26:51 -0000

Haha, that's brilliant! I love it! I think the handwriting is definitely from a girl and the text is from a serious speedcuber. I don't want to insult the girls but experience shows that these don't go together very often. Also, in "i yearn for you like you a sub-fifteen" I think the second "you" is too much, right? That makes me think even more that the person inventing the text and the person just writing it weren't the same... But even if it's a prank, don't give up hope! Maybe a girl is in love with you and asked a speedcuber to help her write a nice text for you and then she wrote it :-) Hmm, but is that chocolate around the cube? Then you can eliminate most people who'd rather eat it than give it away. Awaiting the conclusion... Cheers! 814. [Speed cubing group] Re: Super-Megaminx
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 16:54:53 -0000

http://grant.tregay.net/cube/solutions/megaminx/index.html the master at work ;) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > I can do the Megaminx [except for the last layer. can't find any algs. > grr.] using what I call the "wimpy Petrus" method. Do a cross on the > bottom, then keep pairing up an edge and a corner (or sometimes just > an edge if you're starting on to a new face) and putting it in, then > when you have 2 faces left flip all the edges correctly, and on the > last side use some Sune equivalents to orient the corners. I have no > idea for PLL, though.
815. Re: L or R
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 17:12:12 -0000

Ok I see... I'd say I prefer L for execution but if this is used to solve an F2L pair then I'd prefer R because I prefer to solve at the back in order to look ahead better. Well if this is the last pair then I'd vote for L again :-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I should have been more clear. I guess what I really meant was > yL'U'L or y'R'U'R. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" > > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > > > does anybody else prefer L'U'L over R'U'R? i find it > less "awkward" > > > > Notice that they have different effects. So you can't really > compare > > them fairly.

817. Re: Valentine's Day
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 19:12:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > [snip] Also, in "i yearn for > you like you a sub-fifteen" I think the second "you" is too much, > right? That makes me think even more that the person inventing the > text and the person just writing it weren't the same...[snip] > Stefan Hi Stefan, The sentence form used by the writer is correct. English is structured where sometimes there are parts missing from a text which are "understood" to be there. If you remove the second "you" the sentence reads, "i yearn for you like a sub-fifteen" which has a different meaning from, "i yearn for you like you [yearn for] a sub-fifteen." Regards, David J > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hey Everyone, > > > > I'm either the victim of a really funny prank, or... or else?!? > > > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/valentine.JPG > > > > (On the sheet of paper.) > > > > to feel your hands holding my sides firmly > > the same way you grab Rubik's cube to solve > > to let you try your finger tricks on me > > and have my will, with lubricant, dissolve > > > > i'd pull the first two layers off myself > > 'cause that's the algorithm that i know > > but you would need to do the PLL > > maybe give the z-permutation a go > > > > after the initial inspection is done > > let me know the orientation that you want > > i promise that it will be lots of fun > > just like your tournaments that i haunt > > > > i yearn for you like you a sub-fifteen > > for you're the best solve i have ever seen > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology

819. Re: L or R
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 19:44:21 -0000

Hey! Im not really a "Fridrich" person so my opinion doens't count for much ;-) But the way i see it one should be equally comfortable with both. It's good to know ur algs from all angles so to speak, in order to minimise rotating the cube physically too much. Obviously there will be exceptions to this, like algs with lots of B turns. But most algs should be using U,R,F and L only, with a few D turns (when last layer is at top). On 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 i try to minimise turning the whole cube. And when i do it's mostly to get a better lookahead. -Per K > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Ok I see... I'd say I prefer L for execution but if this is used to > solve an F2L pair then I'd prefer R because I prefer to solve at the > back in order to look ahead better. Well if this is the last pair then > I'd vote for L again :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > I should have been more clear. I guess what I really meant was > > yL'U'L or y'R'U'R. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" > > > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > does anybody else prefer L'U'L over R'U'R? i find it > > less "awkward" > > > > > > Notice that they have different effects. So you can't really > > compare > > > them fairly.

825. My course for beginners
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 01:48:54 -0000

Hello everyone, I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on solving Rubik's Cube. While there are many decent webpages detailing expert solutions, there are none which really give a detailed account for beginners (apart from Jasmine's wonderful beginner page which was the inspiration for this tutorial). I would love it if a few of you could pretend to be beginners, or maybe some real beginners will have a go too, and go through my solution and see if it is readable. It was a lot of work making these notes, but I hope that they will prove to be useful for beginners in the years to come :-) Like I said, they are almost complete, I have to add the finishing touches still (there are always little things to change!) You can find the notes at http://www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the Link in the red panel which says UEA Cube Club. Cheers! Dan Harris :-) [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

828. RE: [Speed cubing group] My course for beginners
From: "James Stuber" <jstuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 19:20:21 -0800

"If you see a ' in front of the letter" It should be "after the letter" not in front of. Otherwise they might get confused and think R'U means right clockwise up counter clockwise. -----Original Message----- From: Daniel Harris [mailto:dan_j_harris@...] Sent: Tuesday, February 15, 2005 5:49 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] My course for beginners Hello everyone, I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on solving Rubik's Cube. I would love it if a few of you could pretend to be beginners, or maybe some real beginners will have a go too, and go through my solution and see if it is readable. It was a lot of work making these notes, but I hope that they will prove to be useful for beginners in the years to come :-) Like I said, they are almost complete, I have to add the finishing touches still (there are always little things to change!) You can find the notes at http://www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the Link in the red panel which says UEA Cube Club. Cheers! Dan Harris :-) [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Yahoo! Groups Links
829. Re: [Speed cubing group] My course for beginners

Date: Tue, 15 Feb 2005 19:54:31 -0800

hey, i havent taken a look at it yet, but i will, but if i can make a similar request, and have people look through my beginner solution/tutorial? http://www.deepcube.tk click on the beginner solution button at the top thx -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Wed, 16 Feb 2005 01:48:54 -0000, Daniel Harris <dan_j_harris@...> wrote: > Hello everyone, > > > > I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on solving > Rubik's Cube. While there are many decent webpages detailing expert > solutions, there are none which really give a detailed account for beginners > (apart from Jasmine's wonderful beginner page which was the inspiration for > this tutorial). > > > > I would love it if a few of you could pretend to be beginners, or maybe some > real beginners will have a go too, and go through my solution and see if it > is readable. It was a lot of work making these notes, but I hope that they > will prove to be useful for beginners in the years to come :-) > > > > Like I said, they are almost complete, I have to add the finishing touches > still (there are always little things to change!) > > > > You can find the notes at http://www.cubestation.co.uk > <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the Link in the red panel > which says UEA Cube Club. > > > > Cheers! > > > > Dan Harris :-) > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > Yahoo! 830. rubiks.dk back up
From: albuscorvus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 05:11:36 -0000


In case anyone hasn't noticed, www.rubiks.dk is back up, though still
under construction. Unfortunately one is not able to compare their
times with other cubers any more due to having to clean up all the
false entries from the old one. But once the new one is up it looks
like it'll keep a more detailed cubelog for you. It's a great site,
and I for one am very happy to see it back up.

Thanks Jess!

Ben





831. Re: L or R
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 08:15:16 -0000


In reality, since all the faces are just what we term them, any face
turn is merely going to be preference, and not intrinsically what is
easier. For example, left-handed people tend to prefer algorithms
with lots of Ls, where as righties prefer R moves. For example, most
of my solutions contain only R r U M moves, and only lefts when I
need them, lefts are truly only (RM') or vice versa, so it all really
depends on the frame of reference, and how you hold the cube. An
awkward turn often can be fixed, and be great, if you hold the cube
from a slightly different angle.

I guess the point I'm getting at is that it is all very personal, and
that everyone will have their own opinion of what is best. And some
algorithms work better for some people better than others.





832. 1:39 cuber
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 01:34:18 -0800

Hey Everyone,

Is there a cuber out there who wrote that they learned the Rubik's Cube
at summer camp and that their roommate taught them and that they were
really happy to get a time of 1 minute 39 seconds? If you wrote that
on a college application essay, I heard some good news about you.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




833. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Valentine's Day
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 01:47:20 -0800

It goes on. I was working on physics today. I left my room (I left
the door open) for about 10 minutes and went two doors down the hall.
When I came back, a yellow rose was placed on my desk. I'm getting
kinda scared now... all my friends so far have denied any involvement
with this whatsoever.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

> you like you a sub-fifteen" I think the second "you" is too much,

> text and the person just writing it weren't the same...

> and then she wrote it :-)

834. Re: Rubik's Cube Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: Eric Siegel <etsiegel@...>(optonline)
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 02:19:33 -0800

Hi Eric and Marcia,

Please let me know if you have any questions about holding such an
event. If you would like, feel free to contact the Exploratorium
Museum in San Francisco about their experience with us and the
tournament on January 15, 2005. I do not believe hosting an event like
this would cost your museum any significant amount of money at all. If
you have a publicity department, a little bit of money into advertising
the event would easily attract enough visitors to cover that cost.
After the Exploratorium sent out a news letter, every local television
news station aired information about the tournament and aired a few
interviews with some of the competitors. I am quite convinced that the
increase in attendance from this event will easily pay for your
expenses in advertising. Furthermore, their gift shop easily sold out
of Rubik's Cubes. I myself was able to sell about $1000 worth of cube
items at the tournament and I actually ran out of cubes to sell.

As for time, if your museum is able to handle the publicity and
advertising, our club would virtually take care of everything else.
Our only supplies needed for the tournament would be a few tables and
outlets. A form of amplified sound would be very helpful but is not
necessary. We would provide all the timers and other such supplies.

If you have any questions, please contact me. If you would like
another museum's point of view on this, please contact the
Exploratorium in San Francisco. Also, please keep me updated on the
progress of this. I had not received a reply in awhile and I thought
that the idea had died and was starting to look at venues in Texas.

If you would like to see a Rubik's Cube tournament in action, we are
hosting another one on April 16, 2005 at Caltech in Pasadena,
California. I doubt that you guys would have the time to come visit
but I thought I would put the idea on the table. Another tournament is
currently in the works and is being planned for May 28th at the Horace
Mann School. Also, if you would like to speak to some experienced
speed cubers in the area, I know a few people in New York who may be
able to meet with you in person and show you exactly what things would
look like.

ESPN also contacted me last July. I think it may be possible to get
the involved with a Rubik's Cube tournament if we had your museum as a
venue. The main contribution we would ask of the museum is just
publicity. Our club would be able to take care of virtually everything
else.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 15, 2005, at 3:54 PM, Eric Siegel (optonline) wrote:

> Hi, Tyson, meet Marcia Rudy, our Director of Public Programs and
> Special Events. She is the person who would be responsible for this,
> if it is workable. Marcia, can you see what is really involved with
> getting this done. When I circulated Tyson's email a few weeks ago,
> everyone seemed to think that it might be good for us to do, depending
> on the details...time, money, etc
>
> Keep me in the loop, OK?
>
> Thanks!
>
> Eric Siegel
> Executive VP
> Programs and Planning
> NY Hall of Science
> 47-01 111th Street
> Queens, NY 11368
> www.nyscience.org

849. Re: WC 2005
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 21:05:26 -0000

In an ideal world (sometimes in the future?), WCA will be a strong orgaisation which organises tournaments. However, as I understand it, WCA is at present only Tyson, Ron and Chris, and the main activities is to establish tournament rules and to maintain official world records and ranking lists. It seems that it is SevenTowns that will organise WC2005, and take care of the costs... However, I am convinsed that they will listen to the Cube society. Is there any dialogue between WCA and SevenTowns about WC2005? Enjoy Anders --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hmm! > > So do SevenTowns decide what events there will be? So that should not be a > hindrance ... > > Happy cubing ... > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "al_yyz" > <anders.larsson@i...> wrote: > > > > When I met Dave at SevenTowns some months ago, I suggested that > > 2x2x2 should be included in the WC2005. His response indicated > that > > they will consider it. > > > > /Anders > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I would certainly like that!! > > > > > > But I am afraid you can expect that there will not be that many > > > events, because it will take very long, since there will be a > lot > > of > > > participants.. However, a 2x2 is not very hard to scramble, and > > > solving is even faster, so maybe this one has a chance. > > > > > > Joël. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > In this years world championship will there be 2x2 compition > > > because > > > > that would be cool if there was.

852. Cubing and romance?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 01:43:35 -0000


Hi everyone,

I'm just catching up on the last couple of weeks of posts after a
mega-busy time at work. Looks like I've been missing lots of
interesting discussion about the meaning of life (42, obviously),
super-megaminxing, subculture, and eating dust!! ;)

A thread that I found particularly interesting is the one about
Tyson's secret admirer!! I gather this remains a mystery?? Maybe
speedcubing is a way to get a girl's attention?

This reminds me, I recently watched the first episode of Matt
LeBlanc's new show, Joey (it's just started airing in the UK where
I've recently moved). I wasn't planning to watch it, but after someone
in this group said there was a speedcubing reference, I knew I had
too. It cracked me up. Maybe Joey is wrong and in fact speedcubing can
be an interesting topic to talk to girls about!

And speaking of cubing and romance, congrats to Frank and Christy on
their engagment! :) Maybe one day my fiance Peter will learn the cube.
BTW, yes, it's still 'fiance' as we still haven't managed to organise
to get married yet. It's been a very long engagement!

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

854. purchasing a cube!~
From: jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 05:40:13 -0000


hey~
im in need of finding a really good rubik's cube.

im currently looking to buy a Studio Rubik's cube...but i have no idea
on how to get my hands on it. my friend sent an enamil to Ton (from
speedcubing.com) about ordering one from him but he hasnt recieved
anything back from him yet. does anyone have any info on how to buy a
Studio Rubik's cube without using ebay?? (i already tried ebay but
none available!!)
*im currently planning to attend the April competition at Caltech
(hope this info helps..because i was wondering if i could buy one at
the competition..lol)

if its impossible for me to get the studio cube i was thinking about
buying one off ebay that was made in hungary durring the 1980s by
ideal. but most of the cubes on sale are used and are in bad
condition...soo i dont want to take any chances of spending more money
on a bad cube that i cant speedcube with.

if anyone has a better suggestion for buying the "perfect"
cube...please reply here

Thanks in advance!~

p.s. i dont want to spend over 40-50 dollars on it :P





855. Re: [Speed cubing group] purchasing a cube!~
From: Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 21:54:53 -0800 (PST)

u want a good rubik's cube for speedcubing? or u want to collect them. if u want it for speedcubing then i think a deluxe, rubiks.com cube or DIY will be cool, those are like the best right now. (Ton told me) i also tried to buy a studio off Ton. everytime i ask him about the studio cubes, he tells me that DIYs are the best. so i never bought any form him. most cubers use rubiks.com or DIY. yeah, i think u can figure out what i am trying to say, i hope. chun hei jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: hey~ im in need of finding a really good rubik's cube. im currently looking to buy a Studio Rubik's cube...but i have no idea on how to get my hands on it. my friend sent an enamil to Ton (from speedcubing.com) about ordering one from him but he hasnt recieved anything back from him yet. does anyone have any info on how to buy a Studio Rubik's cube without using ebay?? 857. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing and romance?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Feb 2005 22:12:01 -0800

Yes, okay, and the plot thickens. Okay, so to recap to everyone...

Monday (Valentine's Day): Chocolate tiled cube with dirty
cube-innuendo sonnet is left on my desk.

Tuesday: I step out of my room for 10 minutes and walk two doors down
the hall to do some homework. I left the door open and when I came
back, a yellow rose was left on my desk.

Wednesday morning: I was up until about 5 AM doing work and when I
woke up, a neat pile of four chocolates (the same chocolates that were
used as tiles) was placed outside of my door under a piece of paper
with the word "Tyson" printed on it. Also there was another pile of
four chocolates under a piece of paper that said "Macky". Mark
Polinkovsky who lives next to me was also hit with a pile of four
chocolates and so was Jordan, the guy who lives two doors down and
who's room I was in on Tuesday.

Also hit with chocolates were Leyan Lo (current American blindfold and
3x3x3 single solve record holder). That was amazing because he lives
actually quite far away in relation to the main student housing
complex. Also Mithun Diwakar (frequent cube judge), and three other
people that I can think of right now.

I'm a bit creeped out.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 16, 2005, at 5:43 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote:

> A thread that I found particularly interesting is the one about
> Tyson's secret admirer!! I gather this remains a mystery?? Maybe
> speedcubing is a way to get a girl's attention?




858. Greetings from another cuber in Idaho
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 06:19:19 -0000


Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, but not to cubing-
-been doing it since I was a kid in the 80s [I'm 35 now]. Great to
see so many others out there--I thought it had totally died; but
there seems to be a strong resurgence in interest. I hadn't picked
one up in years, but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of
years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, and i'm
addicted again.

My times are about a minute now, so I'm not going to break anyone's
records soon, but I've only memorized about half of the Fridrich
method algs. Hopefully I can get it down under 30 seconds this
year. My old method was pretty simple to learn but took about 150
moves [I used to do it top corners first, then top edges, middle
layer edges, permute bottom corners, orient bottom corners, permute
& orient bottom edges.]

I definitely cube while driving [only at stop lights, of course],
and while flying or waiting at airports or talking on the phone.
Anyone got suggestions on how to dampen the noise? will good lube
help? I've used some silicon spray, but I'm probably not applying
it right or not enough...

Never thought of doing it in the shower--won't the stickers peel off?

I'm also in the market for a new cube--any other comments on where
to get good cubes?

Tyson's valentine's gift/poem was about the funniest thing cube
related I've ever read. The author should definitely fess up,
whoever it was.

best regards,
Kirk






859. Re: purchasing a cube!~
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 06:41:57 -0000

I use a DIY from Rubiks.com ...it's really great. I have never had a pop with it (yet) and it moves faster than any other cube I've ever had. Some who have used it have even said that it is "too loose." I like it that way :) I def. recommend a DIY. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jamessong523 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > hey~ > im in need of finding a really good rubik's cube. > > im currently looking to buy a Studio Rubik's cube...but i have no idea > on how to get my hands on it. my friend sent an enamil to Ton (from > speedcubing.com) about ordering one from him but he hasnt recieved > anything back from him yet. does anyone have any info on how to buy a > Studio Rubik's cube without using ebay?? (i already tried ebay but > none available!!) > *im currently planning to attend the April competition at Caltech > (hope this info helps..because i was wondering if i could buy one at > the competition..lol) > > if its impossible for me to get the studio cube i was thinking about > buying one off ebay that was made in hungary durring the 1980s by > ideal. but most of the cubes on sale are used and are in bad > condition...soo i dont want to take any chances of spending more money > on a bad cube that i cant speedcube with. > > if anyone has a better suggestion for buying the "perfect" > cube...please reply here > > Thanks in advance!~ > > p.s. i dont want to spend over 40-50 dollars on it :P
860. Converting algorithms in your head
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 08:02:30 -0000


Hey everyone,

I've been wanting to make a site like this for quite some time. I
still have a lot more work to do on it, but I have graphics and things
ready for the 3 main types of algorithm conversions.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/algconversion.html

Basically this site is just a couple tutorials on how to reflect
algorithms, invert and also reflect, etc. in your head without writing
anything down.

When learning new algs I personally don't consider the reflections of
algorithms as separate cases, as I'm used to doing this type of alg
transposing in my head.

So anyway those of you who are musicians can treat this site like a
tutorial on how to transpose, only for the cube. Those who aren't
musicians can use this tutorial to make learning new algs easier,
especially reflections.

Like I said I've been wanting to make a site like this for a long
time, so there is still a lot more to come. Also if anyone actually
uses and/or finds these tutorials interesting, please let me know.

I personally do these types of conversions all the time, and thought
it would be useful to make an easy tutorial on how to do it.

Let me know what you think,
Chris





861. Re: Converting algorithms in your head
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 10:03:25 -0000

Woohooo!!! Thanks a lot for that one Chris! I´m using the Petrus method but I have the cube orientated in a different way than Lars has and I´ve had a hard time to convert the algs sometime. And now when I read it from your tutorial it´s all so easy and obvious. Your site will make my life a bit easier =D Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I've been wanting to make a site like this for quite some time. I > still have a lot more work to do on it, but I have graphics and things > ready for the 3 main types of algorithm conversions. > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/algconversion.html > > Basically this site is just a couple tutorials on how to reflect > algorithms, invert and also reflect, etc. in your head without writing > anything down. > > When learning new algs I personally don't consider the reflections of > algorithms as separate cases, as I'm used to doing this type of alg > transposing in my head. > > So anyway those of you who are musicians can treat this site like a > tutorial on how to transpose, only for the cube. Those who aren't > musicians can use this tutorial to make learning new algs easier, > especially reflections. > > Like I said I've been wanting to make a site like this for a long > time, so there is still a lot more to come. 865. Number of moves...
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 17:29:11 -0000


I'm trying to lower my solve times and am currently focusing on the
number of moves I'm performing while solving. Currently I'm averaging
75 moves (44 moves for F2L and 31 moves for LL). I know that
memorizing more of the LL algorithms could lower my LL moves from 30
down to around 18 or so, but am having a hard time lowing my moves on
the F2Ls.

My current goal is to average 30 seconds a solve and am currently
averaging 60 seconds.

The method I currently use constists of 10 steps
1. create 1x1x3 (~4 moves)
2. expand to 1x2x3 (~6 moves)
3. expand to 2x2x3 (~7 moves)
4. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves)
5. Orient and position one edge (~7 moves)
6. Flip bad edges (~6 moves)
7. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves) [finishing F2L]
8. Position corners (~7 moves)
9. Orient corners (~15 moves)
10. Position and Place edges (~9 moves)

Also, any tips on learning finger tricks to speed up moves/seconds
would be apprecieated as well.





866. Re: Number of moves...
From: "Oliver Wolff" <OliverWolff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 19:57:55 -0000

Hi, swapping step 8 and 9 would give two moves less. 8. Orient corners (~9 moves) 9. Position corners (~11 moves) Olli --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@H...> wrote: > > > The method I currently use constists of 10 steps > 1. create 1x1x3 (~4 moves) > 2. expand to 1x2x3 (~6 moves) > 3. expand to 2x2x3 (~7 moves) > 4. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves) > 5. Orient and position one edge (~7 moves) > 6. Flip bad edges (~6 moves) > 7. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves) [finishing F2L] > 8. Position corners (~7 moves) > 9. Orient corners (~15 moves) > 10. Position and Place edges (~9 moves)
867. Texas Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 12:25:57 -0800

Hey Everyone,

The Science Place in Dallas, Texas wants to host our tournament!

http://www.scienceplace.org/

If you live in Texas or think you might want to attend this tournament,
I would recommend joining the Caltech Rubik's Yahoo group at this link
here:

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/caltechrubiks/

It's where we do our discussion. Also, if you live in Texas, I will
need one or two people to nobly sacrifice themselves. I need one or
two people who lives near Dallas... I need someone who is willing to
attend the tournament, not compete, and help me completely in running
the tournament. We were short staffed in San Francisco with 4
full-time tournament staff so please let me know if you're willing to
help me out.

I need people to understand that these tournaments are possible because
many of my friends at Caltech are not very competitive speed cubers and
are willing to sacrifice a competition experience in order to host and
run the tournament for your competition experience. I just need a few
people to help out this time as I don't believe I can take another team
of 5 down to Dallas as I did to San Francisco.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

870. Re: Number of moves...
From: "randmthght" <randmthght@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 20:37:31 -0000

Personally i aim for a 2x2x2 this is easy to loacte in you scan time on the cube as you are looking for three groups of two peices. usually in 8-12 moves a 2x2x2 is made and the rest of the cube can be veiwed from one angle. imho --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Oliver Wolff" <OliverWolff@t...> wrote: > > Hi, > > swapping step 8 and 9 would give two moves less. > > 8. Orient corners (~9 moves) > 9. Position corners (~11 moves) > > Olli > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dwarmaj" > <Dwarmaj@H...> wrote: > > > > > > The method I currently use constists of 10 steps > > 1. create 1x1x3 (~4 moves) > > 2. expand to 1x2x3 (~6 moves) > > 3. expand to 2x2x3 (~7 moves) > > 4. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves) > > 5. Orient and position one edge (~7 moves) > > 6. Flip bad edges (~6 moves) > > 7. Orient and position one edge and corner (~7 moves) [finishing > F2L] > > 8. Position corners (~7 moves) > > 9. Orient corners (~15 moves) > > 10. Position and Place edges (~9 moves)
871. Re: Number of moves...
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 20:37:58 -0000


Thanks for the response.

I think I made a mistake in my original post. It looks like I do
place the corners on the LL before I orient them.

Guess I'll practice a bit more until I can solve smoothly, then look
into other solving methods.

One thing I did notices that struck me as odd... When I'm scrambling
the cube I'm prerforming finger tricks I never knew I could do. Now
if I can only integrate them into my solves I'll be a happy camper.

Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 20:42:54 -0000


Hi everybody,

the 'Part 2' of the beginners solution. The beginners solution
wasn't build for speed, so this new section explains some moves to
speed up the solution, without memorzing too much algs. Can some of
you take a look at it and give me feedback about this? The last time
I asked this, I got some pretty usefull reactions.

873. Re: Number of moves...
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 20:47:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "randmthght" <randmthght@y...> wrote: > > Personally i aim for a 2x2x2 this is easy to loacte in you scan time > on the cube as you are looking for three groups of two peices. > usually in 8-12 moves a 2x2x2 is made and the rest of the cube can be > veiwed from one angle. imho You could be right. I originally used a corners first method and the 1x1x3 was an easier way to start then forming a 2x2x2. Looking at Lar's site, forming a 2x2x2 usually takes 10-14 moves, while I'm averaging 18. Hmm... I also don't look for the most advantages color combinations. :( Guess I need to learn my cube better.

877. Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: "mstk430" <mstksg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 01:15:35 -0000


Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a
half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of
the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms...

But how?

What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards?
Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)?

Is there any site?

Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid.
What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms?





878. Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 01:28:09 -0000

Welcome to the group! I'm a speedcuber from northern Idaho, and Frank Morris who also posts here lives in Boise (I think). A lubrication will help the noise, and make it easier to turn. I (and most people in this group) recommend silicon spray, you can get it at Wal*Mart or any auto supplies store. I use the SNAP brand, and it works well. I wouldn't recommend using the cube in the shower, unless you have a cube devoted to it. it'll wash off any lube that you have on it, and make the stickers peel a little bit. You can order a quality speedcube from Rubiks.com, or you can get a Studio Cube which is often said to be the best for speedcubing from Ton Dennenbroek: speedcubing.com/ton but they take quite some work to get them into top condition, and are more expensive. I'd recommend a Rubiks.com cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, but not to cubing- > -been doing it since I was a kid in the 80s [I'm 35 now]. Great to > see so many others out there--I thought it had totally died; but > there seems to be a strong resurgence in interest. I hadn't picked > one up in years, but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of > years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, and i'm > addicted again. > > My times are about a minute now, so I'm not going to break anyone's > records soon, but I've only memorized about half of the Fridrich > method algs. Hopefully I can get it down under 30 seconds this > year. My old method was pretty simple to learn but took about 150 > moves [I used to do it top corners first, then top edges, middle > layer edges, permute bottom corners, orient bottom corners, permute > & orient bottom edges.] > > I definitely cube while driving [only at stop lights, of course], > and while flying or waiting at airports or talking on the phone. > Anyone got suggestions on how to dampen the noise? will good lube > help? I've used some silicon spray, but I'm probably not applying > it right or not enough... > > Never thought of doing it in the shower--won't the stickers peel off? > > I'm also in the market for a new cube--any other comments on where > to get good cubes? > > Tyson's valentine's gift/poem was about the funniest thing cube > related I've ever read. The author should definitely fess up, > whoever it was. > > best regards, > Kirk

886. Re: Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 03:30:55 -0000

I made of practice sheet of the inverse of all of the LL algorithms that will create each orientation and permutation. I numbered them and did them over and over until I learned each one. I would mark them off after I had learned one. Hope this helps. Wayne --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> wrote: > > Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a > half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of > the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms... > > But how? > > What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards? > Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > Is there any site? > > Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid. > What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms?
887. Re: Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: "Jason Preissig" <ELiTe185@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 03:32:47 -0000

Hey there! This is how i memorized the LL algs. First, i think that someone should learn first PLL then OLL. For memorizing PLL/OLL as a whole, i would recomend doing it one alg at a time. Start with case #1, and learn it. Then, when you have succesfully added it to your archive of algs (when you can recognise it and perform it at full speed from a random solve) then add another alg to the archive, un till you have all the algs. Now, for memorising the individual algs, I find the Java applets spread on the web to be very usefull. I follow along one move at a time, and watch the video for finger ticks. Then, i get to wherei can do it without looking, and i just keep on doing it over and over again. I would be interested in learning how other people do it! Jason Preissig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> wrote: > > Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a > half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of > the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms... > > But how? > > What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards? > Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > Is there any site? > > Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid. > What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms?
888. Re: [Speed cubing group] Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: Doug Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 21:48:57 -0600

The best way for me to learn them was to just try to figure all of the
F2L algs out for myself. Not only is it easier to learn all 40+ algs,
you don't have to bother with learning them from different sides of the
cube. Most algorithms are only a few moves different anyway, generally
a few setup moves, and a 3-move alg to put the pair into place (R Ux R'
and its mirror).

Hope it helps,
Doug

mstk430 wrote:

>Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a
>half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of
>the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms...

>

>Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)?

889. Re: [Speed cubing group] Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 03:55:55 -0000

I just started learning F2L last week. It's a lot more intuitive (and easier) than I remembered from the last time I attempted it. ~bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: > The best way for me to learn them was to just try to figure all of the > F2L algs out for myself. Not only is it easier to learn all 40+ algs, > you don't have to bother with learning them from different sides of the > cube. Most algorithms are only a few moves different anyway, generally > a few setup moves, and a 3-move alg to put the pair into place (R Ux R' > and its mirror). > > Hope it helps, > Doug > > mstk430 wrote: > > >Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a > >half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of > >the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms... > > > >But how? > > > >What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards? > >Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > > >Is there any site? > > > >Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid. > >What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms? > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
890. N x N x N cube
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 03:54:00 -0000


I wrote a program in Java that takes an input N (2-100) and computes
and returns the number of combinations to an NxNxN cube. Anybody
who has Java installed on their computer and want it may download it
at www.cubewhiz.com/nxnxn.zip

Just extract the two .class files into the same directory. :)

~bob





891. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: stickers
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 23:42:43 -0500

Whenever I get a cube, before I start speedcubing on it, I always put regular permanent scotch tape over all the facelets - that is, 54 pieces of tape over the 54 facelets. The pieces of tape don't have to be perfectly square because any excess that hangs over is trimmed off by speedcubing. The tape really does a good job in protecting the colors, and for all the cubes I've done this to, all of the stickers have remained intact. And I've never had to reapply the tape either. ~Erwaman~ ----- Original Message ----- From: mstk430 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, February 17, 2005 9:48 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: stickers Hey, maybe it's because I was doing my F2L with Cross-side-up until a day or two ago. Anyway, white being dead isn't so bad, becasue you can still see the color. This is what I don't get: Why don't the makers simply mold the colors onto the cube, like they do to make all faces white underneat? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I also get my cross on white, but it's not AS bad on that side: > > www.cubewhiz.com/white.jpg > > ^^update: one of the plastic covers has peeled off the white side > today and it is not shown in the pic above (from yesterday) > > ~bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" > <mstksg@g...> wrote: > > > > I noticed that it really peels on the side where you do your > initial > > cross. > > > > Eh...I just got my cube a few days ago and the white side is > already > > completely off :( > > The center sticker with the Rubick's logo is still hanging on, > though ;) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" > > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > > > wow, i got a really bad set of stickers last time :\ > > > > > > I just restickered my cube 3 weeks ago and look at the orange > > > already: > > > > > > www.cubewhiz.com/orange.jpg > > > > > > :( > > > > > > bob ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! 892. Re: [Speed cubing group] Greetings from another cuber in Idaho
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 04:19:29 -0000

Hey Crispy, I'm in Eagle [suburban Boise]. where are you? do any of the Idaho cubers ever get together? I know my times could probably benefit from some live tips and tricks, and it would be interesting to actually meet someone else who is into cubing. Cubing has always been kind of a quirky thing I do, and I have rarely actually met someone else who can do it at all, certainly never actually met anyone faster than me [though I've seen plenty of videos to convince me I'm pretty slow at roughly a minute, but I'm working on that...] I can count on one hand the number of people I've ever met who can actually do it. That's why I was surprised to see so many and such an active online community. Guess I've been living under a rock in that regard. Speaking of other Idaho cubers, I saw Frank Morris on the news a couple of months ago. Also read on speedcubing.com he just set a new unofficial record on the 5x5x5 with an ave. time of 2 min 17 secs. Truly impressive. So I knew there was at least one other in the state. glad to know there are a few more. btw, I saw some posts about what cubers have in common, and gather most or at least a large percentage are in programming. I started college as a math/science geek, but ended up majoring in ancient Greek and Latin, which is about as far removed from programming as you can get. (Of course that degree provided rather limited job opportunities, so I went to law school and now run a fee-only comprehensive wealth management firm). Curious if many other non- math/science majors are into cubing? thanks for the welcome. best regards, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Crispy <redivre@y...> wrote: > Hey there and welcome to the group :) Where abouts in > Idaho are you? You may be surprised on how many of us > are in Idaho already, I know of 4 speedcubers and a > couple other leisure cubers :) > > --- kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, > > but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of > > years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, > > and i'm addicted again. > > > > ===== > Philia, > Crispy > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. > http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
893. Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 04:22:25 -0000

thanks for the welcome. Just broke down and bought a new cube at the store as my stickers on the old one are totally peeling off. I'll give the lube another try on this one. thanks for the tips. What I have is probably not the best, but it will have to do until I can get a better one... best, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@y...> wrote: > > Welcome to the group! I'm a speedcuber from northern Idaho, and Frank > Morris who also posts here lives in Boise (I think). > A lubrication will help the noise, and make it easier to turn. I (and > most people in this group) recommend silicon spray, you can get it at > Wal*Mart or any auto supplies store. I use the SNAP brand, and it > works well. > I wouldn't recommend using the cube in the shower, unless you have a > cube devoted to it. it'll wash off any lube that you have on it, and > make the stickers peel a little bit. > You can order a quality speedcube from Rubiks.com, or you can get a > Studio Cube which is often said to be the best for speedcubing from > Ton Dennenbroek: speedcubing.com/ton > but they take quite some work to get them into top condition, and are > more expensive. I'd recommend a Rubiks.com cube. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, but not to cubing- > > -been doing it since I was a kid in the 80s [I'm 35 now]. Great to > > see so many others out there--I thought it had totally died; but > > there seems to be a strong resurgence in interest. I hadn't picked > > one up in years, but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of > > years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, and i'm > > addicted again. > > > > My times are about a minute now, so I'm not going to break anyone's > > records soon, but I've only memorized about half of the Fridrich > > method algs. Hopefully I can get it down under 30 seconds this > > year. My old method was pretty simple to learn but took about 150 > > moves [I used to do it top corners first, then top edges, middle > > layer edges, permute bottom corners, orient bottom corners, permute > > & orient bottom edges.] > > > > I definitely cube while driving [only at stop lights, of course], > > and while flying or waiting at airports or talking on the phone. > > Anyone got suggestions on how to dampen the noise? will good lube > > help? I've used some silicon spray, but I'm probably not applying > > it right or not enough... > > > > Never thought of doing it in the shower--won't the stickers peel off? > > > > I'm also in the market for a new cube--any other comments on where > > to get good cubes? > > > > Tyson's valentine's gift/poem was about the funniest thing cube > > related I've ever read. The author should definitely fess up, > > whoever it was. > > > > best regards, > > Kirk
894. Re: [Speed cubing group] Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 20:31:06 -0800 (PST)

Hehe personally, i think a good method is to do the f2l intuitively after you get the hang of the algs for f2l. for last layer OLL i just learn the ones that seems to occur often when i solve. maybe its just me but i get more of the L shaped olls most of the time. so the thing is i learn the oll "as they occur". if they keep coming back i make up my mind to learn it anyways. happy cubing! --- rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@...> wrote: > > I just started learning F2L last week. It's a lot > more intuitive > (and easier) than I remembered from the last time I > attempted it. > > ~bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug > Reed > <dougreed@h...> wrote: > > The best way for me to learn them was to just try > to figure all of > the > > F2L algs out for myself. Not only is it easier to > learn all 40+ > algs, > > you don't have to bother with learning them from > different sides > of the > > cube. Most algorithms are only a few moves > different anyway, > generally > > a few setup moves, and a 3-move alg to put the > pair into place (R > Ux R' > > and its mirror). > > > > Hope it helps, > > Doug > > > > mstk430 wrote: > > > > >Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve > it in about two > and a > > >half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I > recently got the hang > of > > >the F2L method and am looking into memorizing > those LL > Algorithms... > > > > > >But how? > > > > > >What is the best way, from your experiences? Do > you use > flashcards? > > >Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > > > > >Is there any site? > > > > > >Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I > just need a > methid. > > >What is a good one to use to memorize those LL > Fridrich > Algorithms? > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! 895. Re: Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 04:37:38 -0000

I'm still learning some of the algs myself--haven't seen the java applets, but that sounds like it would help a lot. I've seen some sites with videos showing slowly how to do some of the PLL or OLL algs, and that's helped me quite a bit. It's not just knowing which face to turn, but which moves to blend together to make it faster and which fingers to use, etc. that kind of thing speeds up the learning process for me. I've also printed out a cheat sheet and check them off as I learn them. To make sure I can remember them, I start with a solved cube, then do each alg several times. works great during commercials... Actually, i have 2 cheat sheets--a short one with just one version of each alg, another with inverses and from different angles. I'll try to learn one of each first. And now when I solve the cube, if I don't know an alg for a situtation, I either look at my cheat sheet or more often just practice 2 of the ones I do know. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Preissig" <ELiTe185@h...> wrote: > > Hey there! > > This is how i memorized the LL algs. First, i think that someone > should learn first PLL then OLL. > > For memorizing PLL/OLL as a whole, i would recomend doing it one alg > at a time. Start with case #1, and learn it. Then, when you have > succesfully added it to your archive of algs (when you can recognise > it and perform it at full speed from a random solve) then add another > alg to the archive, un till you have all the algs. > > Now, for memorising the individual algs, I find the Java applets > spread on the web to be very usefull. I follow along one move at a > time, and watch the video for finger ticks. Then, i get to wherei can > do it without looking, and i just keep on doing it over and over again. > > I would be interested in learning how other people do it! > > Jason Preissig > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> > wrote: > > > > Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a > > half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of > > the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms... > > > > But how? > > > > What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards? > > Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > > > Is there any site? > > > > Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid. > > What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms?

898. Re: Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 05:01:20 -0000

Hey, One thing that helps me when learning new algs is never to time myself. I personally really enjoy taking averages, so when I'm learning new algs I force myself to not time myself at all. This helps motivate me to learn the algs quickly and not beat around the bush and take my time. If you enjoy cubing and timing yourself I would recommend this strategy. It stinks while you're learning, but trust me - it is much more fun to speedsolve using a 3-look or 2-look last layer than it is to solve with a 4-look. The payoff will be worth the time spent learning and not speedcubing. Also by not timing I mean only that. It helps to constantly practice speedcubing, to make sure you can recognize the new algs quickly. Only don't time yourself when you do. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> wrote: > > Hey, I just got my cube on Sunday and can solve it in about two and a > half minutes in a layer-by-layer method. I recently got the hang of > the F2L method and am looking into memorizing those LL Algorithms... > > But how? > > What is the best way, from your experiences? Do you use flashcards? > Nicknaming methods (which worked for F2L)? > > Is there any site? > > Keep in mind that I am a quick memorizer, but I just need a methid. > What is a good one to use to memorize those LL Fridrich Algorithms?
899. Re: [Speed cubing group] Eh...memorizing the Fridrich?
From: "mstk430" <mstksg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 05:02:19 -0000

Oh, yeah. I am not a fan of using Algorithms when "common sense" can take care of it. I don't ever use Algorithms for the F2L, except for the ones I aptly name, ie "R2D2" (two connected corner/middle edge with aligning sides upwards) and "Cycle" (It's basically R'B'L', and it's really fun to do :) ) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@y...> wrote: > Hehe > > personally, i think a good method is to do the f2l > intuitively after you get the hang of the algs for > f2l. > > for last layer OLL i just learn the ones that seems to > occur often when i solve. maybe its just me but i get > more of the L shaped olls most of the time. > > so the thing is i learn the oll "as they occur". if > they keep coming back i make up my mind to learn it > anyways. > > happy cubing! > > --- rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > I just started learning F2L last week. It's a lot > > more intuitive > > (and easier) than I remembered from the last time I > > attempted it. > > > > ~bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug > > Reed > > <dougreed@h...> wrote: > > > The best way for me to learn them was to just try > > to figure all of > > the > > > F2L algs out for myself. 901. Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho - Any Minnesota Cubers?
From: albuscorvus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 05:11:50 -0000

Hey Kirk. I was wondering the same thing about the major issue. I currently go to school at the University of Minnesota, Duluth branch. Looks like I did pretty much the same thing as you so far. I was a math major, but that didn't pan out for me too well once I reached upper level classes... I've since bumped mathematics down to a minor and will graduate with a lowly, ancient History major :) I love it, but yeah, not a lot of job opportunities. I haven't any cubers around here either. I don't recall seeing any other Minnesota cubers in Dan Harris's profile section. I average in around 41, 42 seconds. Any other Minnesota cubers out there? > Hey Crispy, > > I'm in Eagle [suburban Boise]. where are you? do any of the Idaho > cubers ever get together? I know my times could probably benefit > from some live tips and tricks, and it would be interesting to > actually meet someone else who is into cubing. Cubing has always > been kind of a quirky thing I do, and I have rarely actually met > someone else who can do it at all, certainly never actually met > anyone faster than me [though I've seen plenty of videos to convince > me I'm pretty slow at roughly a minute, but I'm working on that...] > I can count on one hand the number of people I've ever met who can > actually do it. That's why I was surprised to see so many and such > an active online community. Guess I've been living under a rock in > that regard. > > Speaking of other Idaho cubers, I saw Frank Morris on the news a > couple of months ago. Also read on speedcubing.com he just set a > new unofficial record on the 5x5x5 with an ave. time of 2 min 17 > secs. Truly impressive. So I knew there was at least one other in > the state. glad to know there are a few more. > > btw, I saw some posts about what cubers have in common, and gather > most or at least a large percentage are in programming. I started > college as a math/science geek, but ended up majoring in ancient > Greek and Latin, which is about as far removed from programming as > you can get. (Of course that degree provided rather limited job > opportunities, so I went to law school and now run a fee-only > comprehensive wealth management firm). Curious if many other non- > math/science majors are into cubing? > > thanks for the welcome. > best regards, > Kirk > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Crispy <redivre@y...> > wrote: > > Hey there and welcome to the group :) Where abouts in > > Idaho are you? You may be surprised on how many of us > > are in Idaho already, I know of 4 speedcubers and a > > couple other leisure cubers :) > > > > --- kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > > > Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, > > > but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of > > > years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, > > > and i'm addicted again. > > > > > > > > ===== > > Philia, > > Crispy > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > > Do you Yahoo!? > > Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. > > http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail
902. Re: [Speed cubing group] famous rubik's cube timer
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2005 21:28:55 -0800

OMG! I'm "famous"!

I currently use Chris Hunt's Java NetCube Timer. In some of Jessica's
videos, she's using Jess Bonde's Internet Explorer Timer. Chris Hunt's
timer has more options and plus, you can do net cube!

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/jnetcube.html

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 17, 2005, at 6:56 PM, jamessong523 wrote:

> hey again
> i would love to get my hands on the "famous" timer that all the
> hardcore cubers use! the one that could be seen used by Jessica
> Fridrich, Tyson Mao...and the rest of the gang. hopefully thats enough
> info..(if thats not enough... the timer has a countdown with sound and
> to stop it you press the press bar..and it also has the algorithms for
> scrambling)
>
> Thanks in advance!~
>
> p.s-in one of the Tyson Mao's videos i tried to zoom in on the timer's
> name but it was too blurry..lol!




903. Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho - Any Minnesota Cubers?
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 07:19:26 -0000

Yeah, I took O-chem as a freshman and it was probably too much for me at that age, and definitely too much lab work for my taste. Math always interested me, but not enough to major. Ancient studies and languages, though, were as addictive as the cube for me. I first took a Latin class on a whim, thought I might go to medical school and perhaps the language would come in handy there, and after one semester basically dropped all the other stuff and focused on classics. Ironically, those classes were harder for me than my math/science classes. But I knew by doing that I'd have to look into law school or business school after undergrad--there definitely were no job opportunities for me anyway, other than in acadamia. I've found a great niche in the financial services industry that fits my personality and skill set. Helping people with taxes, investments, retirement planning, estate planning, etc. is very much a puzzle. anyway, it's another area to look into as you figure out where to go after U of M. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, albuscorvus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey Kirk. I was wondering the same thing about the major issue. I > currently go to school at the University of Minnesota, Duluth branch. > Looks like I did pretty much the same thing as you so far. I was a > math major, but that didn't pan out for me too well once I reached > upper level classes... I've since bumped mathematics down to a minor > and will graduate with a lowly, ancient History major :) I love it, > but yeah, not a lot of job opportunities. > > I haven't any cubers around here either. I don't recall seeing any > other Minnesota cubers in Dan Harris's profile section. I average in > around 41, 42 seconds. Any other Minnesota cubers out there? > > > > Hey Crispy, > > > > I'm in Eagle [suburban Boise]. where are you? do any of the Idaho > > cubers ever get together? I know my times could probably benefit > > from some live tips and tricks, and it would be interesting to > > actually meet someone else who is into cubing. Cubing has always > > been kind of a quirky thing I do, and I have rarely actually met > > someone else who can do it at all, certainly never actually met > > anyone faster than me [though I've seen plenty of videos to > convince > > me I'm pretty slow at roughly a minute, but I'm working on > that...] > > I can count on one hand the number of people I've ever met who can > > actually do it. That's why I was surprised to see so many and such > > an active online community. Guess I've been living under a rock in > > that regard. > > > > Speaking of other Idaho cubers, I saw Frank Morris on the news a > > couple of months ago. Also read on speedcubing.com he just set a > > new unofficial record on the 5x5x5 with an ave. time of 2 min 17 > > secs. Truly impressive. So I knew there was at least one other in > > the state. glad to know there are a few more. > > > > btw, I saw some posts about what cubers have in common, and gather > > most or at least a large percentage are in programming. I started > > college as a math/science geek, but ended up majoring in ancient > > Greek and Latin, which is about as far removed from programming as > > you can get. (Of course that degree provided rather limited job > > opportunities, so I went to law school and now run a fee-only > > comprehensive wealth management firm). Curious if many other non- > > math/science majors are into cubing? > > > > thanks for the welcome. > > best regards, > > Kirk > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Crispy > <redivre@y...> > > wrote: > > > Hey there and welcome to the group :) Where abouts in > > > Idaho are you? You may be surprised on how many of us > > > are in Idaho already, I know of 4 speedcubers and a > > > couple other leisure cubers :) > > > > > > --- kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > > > > > Just thought I'd say hi all. 904. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho - Any Minnesota Cubers?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 01:49:47 -0600

Technically, I'm not a Minnesotan, as I live in Iowa, but I make it up to the Twin Cities most weekends. My girlfriend, whom I taugh and who is now starting a cube craze at her school, lives in a suburb. There are probably upwards of 15 people cubing at her school, all but 2 or 3 who have started in the past two weeks. I know Rommy Barghout (sp?) is from the cities, too, and we met at the Midwest competition. Hopefully we can convince the wonderful Mr. Rueth to organize a tournament up there soon. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: albuscorvus<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, February 17, 2005 11:11 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Greetings from another cuber in Idaho - Any Minnesota Cubers? Hey Kirk. I was wondering the same thing about the major issue. I currently go to school at the University of Minnesota, Duluth branch. Looks like I did pretty much the same thing as you so far. I was a math major, but that didn't pan out for me too well once I reached upper level classes... I've since bumped mathematics down to a minor and will graduate with a lowly, ancient History major :) I love it, but yeah, not a lot of job opportunities. I haven't any cubers around here either. I don't recall seeing any other Minnesota cubers in Dan Harris's profile section. I average in around 41, 42 seconds. Any other Minnesota cubers out there? [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

I'm in Minnesota. I'm talking to the Science Museum of Minnesota about possibly hosting a future tournament there. 907. color scheme
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 15:07:39 -0000


Is it allowed in competitions to use colors that differ from the
normal color schemes? For example, to use brown instead of red or
something like that.





908. Majors
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 16:09:02 -0000



Salvete Kirk and 'White Crow'

Great to hear of cubers who share in my other passions: I study
Latin, ancient Greek and ancient philosophy (Epicureanism). Though
doubtless programming is MUCH more commmon among cubers I feel that
the analytical side of philosophy and Latin syntax is a skill which
directly transfers over to cubing - both blind and speed.

Now if you guys also play rugby that would be a real trifecta!

I am currently teaching at the University of Manitoba in Winnipeg so
I would probably be able to make it down to Minnesota if there were
to be a cuber gathering there.

cavete idibus Martiis,

Rob







909. Re: color scheme
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 16:28:44 -0000

Hi :-) Yes it's allowed to have customised colors on each face. Each face must have a distinct color different from the colors on the other faces. That's all! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > Is it allowed in competitions to use colors that differ from the > normal color schemes? For example, to use brown instead of red or > something like that.
910. University major(s) / Careers / Area(s) of academic interest
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 17:11:26 -0000


Hey everyone,

All this talk about university majors, careers, programming, etc. got
me curious.

We seem to think that "a majority" of cubers are programmers, that we
are "predominantly" math minded, etc..

However I don't think there has ever been a study.

Anyway, I started a new table in the "database" section on the menu on
your left. The list contains an entry for your university major(s) as
well as your career if you are post university study.

If you aren't yet at university there is also a field for area(s) of
academic interest, as well as a potential or proposed major field.

Again this is partly for my own curiosity, and partly for the fact
that I don't think a study has ever been done.

So would everyone please take a moment to fill out the table? It
would only take a few seconds, maybe a minute at most. You don't have
to give your name or e-mail or anything, just your
major/career/academic interests/ etc..

Thanks,
Chris





911. Re: [Speed cubing group] University major(s) / Careers / Area(s) of academic interest
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 18:23:15 +0100 (CET)

maybe you could also add a "name" line, so we know who's doing what... and for those who don't want to say their name, they can just leave it blank... cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: Hey everyone, All this talk about university majors, careers, programming, etc. got me curious. We seem to think that "a majority" of cubers are programmers, that we are "predominantly" math minded, etc.. However I don't think there has ever been a study. Anyway, I started a new table in the "database" section on the menu on your left. The list contains an entry for your university major(s) as well as your career if you are post university study. If you aren't yet at university there is also a field for area(s) of academic interest, as well as a potential or proposed major field. Again this is partly for my own curiosity, and partly for the fact that I don't think a study has ever been done. So would everyone please take a moment to fill out the table? It would only take a few seconds, maybe a minute at most. You don't have to give your name or e-mail or anything, just your major/career/academic interests/ etc.. Thanks, Chris --------------------------------- Yahoo! 912. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 17:26:20 -0000

Having said that we had a discussion last year on a ruling that painted cubes would not automatically be allowed - the local tournament director would rule on each individual case. For those who still have problems with stickers, coloured nail varnish is a fantastic substitute which is very durable and comes in lots of different colours! The reason for the ruling on painted cubes was that "badly" painted cubes can give an advantage to the solver (which makes more sense that it seems at first sight)! Problem is that if your cube is ruled illegal and you have to switch to another cube it may have a different colour scheme. Disaster! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, February 18, 2005 4:28 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme > > > Hi :-) > > Yes it's allowed to have customised colors on each face. Each face > must have a distinct color different from the colors on the other > faces. That's all! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > Is it allowed in competitions to use colors that differ from the > > normal color schemes? For example, to use brown instead of red or > > something like that. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >

The list contains an entry for your university major(s) as > > > well as your career if you are post university study. > > > > > > If you aren't yet at university there is also a field for area(s) of > > > academic interest, as well as a potential or proposed major field. > > > > > > Again this is partly for my own curiosity, and partly for the fact > > > that I don't think a study has ever been done. > > > > > > So would everyone please take a moment to fill out the table? It > > > would only take a few seconds, maybe a minute at most. You don't have > > > to give your name or e-mail or anything, just your > > > major/career/academic interests/ etc.. > > > > > > Thanks, > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > Your use of Yahoo! 919. Re: [Speed cubing group] University major(s) / Careers / Area(s) of academic int
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 23:18:59 -0000

This is cool, thank you everyone for posting on the database! Also, if you haven't posted yet, please post your information! Afterward we can run some numbers on it and figure out more concretely what cubers are like in terms of some of the claims we've heard. Remember, your name isn't required if you don't want to list it. I'm just curious of the percentages that are interested in certain things, like computer programming, engineering, math, etc.. Of course this won't be a very significant sample out of all the cubers, but it will be interesting nonetheless to see what comes of it. Jasmine, I'm also somewhat surprised, I didn't think every single entry would have at least one of the main things that people say are "typical" of cubers. It's still early though, and hopefully we'll see some of the variety present in the cubing community. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris, > > This will be interesting! > > I just had a look at the database and so far there are *zero* entries > which do not contain the words 'maths', 'engineering', 'computer' or > 'IT'. What a surprise!! :) > > Jasmine
