That's because these things make you use the internet in general and this forum in particular more often. Also, you're more likely to understand how to find the table and enter something. Hey, I'm serious! Cheers! Stefan
921. Re: [Speed cubing group] Greetings from another cuber in Idaho
From: Frank Morris <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005 20:06:54 -0800 (PST)

Kirk, Welcome! Some of us Idaho Cubists get together from time to time, and we would like to invite you along. Please email me when you get a chance, so that we can work something out. Frank Morris ephem825@... frankmorris@... kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: Just thought I'd say hi all. I'm new around here, but not to cubing- -been doing it since I was a kid in the 80s [I'm 35 now]. Great to see so many others out there--I thought it had totally died; but there seems to be a strong resurgence in interest. I hadn't picked one up in years, but we moved to Idaho from California a couple of years ago and stumbled across on old cube unpacking, and i'm addicted again. My times are about a minute now, so I'm not going to break anyone's records soon, but I've only memorized about half of the Fridrich method algs. Hopefully I can get it down under 30 seconds this year. My old method was pretty simple to learn but took about 150 moves [I used to do it top corners first, then top edges, middle layer edges, permute bottom corners, orient bottom corners, permute & orient bottom edges.] I definitely cube while driving [only at stop lights, of course], and while flying or waiting at airports or talking on the phone. Anyone got suggestions on how to dampen the noise? will good lube help? I've used some silicon spray, but I'm probably not applying it right or not enough... Never thought of doing it in the shower--won't the stickers peel off? I'm also in the market for a new cube--any other comments on where to get good cubes? Tyson's valentine's gift/poem was about the funniest thing cube related I've ever read. The author should definitely fess up, whoever it was. best regards, Kirk Yahoo! Groups SponsorADVERTISEMENT document.write(''); --------------------------------- Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Search presents - Jib Jab's 'Second Term' [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
922. Unexpected competition tonight!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 07:51:48 -0000


So I'm sitting in my french class and this guy whom I hardly know
says "You know they're having a rubik's cube competition tonight..."
My backpack is covered in cube paraphernalia, and he's seen me do it
a few times so no surprise he thought of me. What shocked me was
that my own college was putting on a Rubik's Cube tourny and I hadn't
heard of it! So I go to the website and the story is this. The main
thing tonight is called the B-cubed LAN party (lanparty.ou.edu). They
had (and are still having) competitions in Counter-Strike, various
Deathmatch games, etc. But this one featured their first ever
rubik's cube tournament!

Since the lan party (by definition) goes from evening to morning the
next day, the cube competition was scheduled for midnight. I showed
up around 10:30 and milled about. Having never been to a LAN party
before, I was kind of at a loss, so I thought I'd cloister myself and
warm up a bit. One guy sees me and comes over. He whips out his
cube and we start talking. Then the camera crew (two guys with a
digicam) came and asked to interview the two of us. It was pretty
cool.

When the competition started, there were 5 people signed up. They
did took the average of your best 3 solves out of 4. The timer was a
stopwatch that the cuber had to start and stop on his own, no
inspection time and the cubes were randomly scrambled by some guy to
the left ;). We had quite a crowd gather around, and a good natured
competition ensued. Three of the guys were doing times in the 1:00-
1:30 range, and one fellow steps up with times floating around 40s.
When it gets to be my turn, I'm shaking quite a bit. I've never
competed, and I've never cubed in front of such a big time. I was
petrified of the "no inspection time" rule. My first time was
24.13s, but I when the cube hit the table, it rotated a quarter turn -
- my "bad" solve that wouldn't be averaged. The next two times were
between 24 and 24.5 and my final solve was 25.xx. Sitting at home a
25s average is really pretty good for me, but I was amazed that I got
such awesome times (for me) with all the pressure.

All said, I won myself a 64MB MP3 player/flash drive, a cd case, and
a bag full of stickers/pens/etc. Not bad for the $10 entry fee (with
free pizza and coke inside)! More importantly I met 3 guys who
really want to get together and cube. We may have the formings of an
OU rubik's cube club!

Anyway, I'm totally stoked and I had to share. I gave the guys this
website along with quite a few others, so maybe we'll see them on
here sometime soon. Can't wait for the Dallas tourney now!

I'm going to bed.
Daniel

It will be biased, because you address the cubers who have a computer, who know the existence of this group, and who also have the will to put their names in the database (i.e. they are interested in the results of this). What would be the results of a poll on the right margin of your website for which the question is : "do you sometimes answer to polls on the right margins of websites ?" (yeah I know, paradoxal people will click on 'no') Well, if you had a column "knows the existence of the speed cubing group" you would have 100% match. 928. Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 14:07:58 -0000

Would it be possible for the WCA to publish a standard for labelling cases
for OLL + PLL, so that everyone would use the same label each time for each
case?



Of course I am only asking for cases in the Fridrich system for now, but I
think a standard should be made for all systems, but Fridrich would be more
useful to me in the long-term. The reason for asking this is that when
people search for algorithms from different websites, Case (eg 14) on one
person's PLL webpage may be Case (eg 19) on someone elses. It would be
easier for anyone in the long run if everyone used the same labels for
particular cases. I realise that for some people this would mean that some
work would have to be put in to change webpages and so forth, but I really
do think it is worth it.



If this means that you would come up with a standard, or I would come up
with a standard, or even if you say we should use the labelling system used
on a particular site, as long as everyone ends up using the same thing, I
wouldn't mind.



Dan Harris :)



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



929. Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 16:03:15 -0000


I've been learning the Petrus method and am not sure what the
differences are between his and the Fridrich method when it comes
the the last layer. Both methods seem to focus on doing F2L then LL.

Are the PLL and OLL algorithms different between the two systems and
if so why?

I don't think there should be any contest about this, she *is* the one who inveneted the method. I can start re-labelling the cases on my page to match hers, assuming there is no disagreement over the labelling system. 934. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 18:22:49 -0000

The only problem I have with this is that Jessica doesn't give all the cases, she gives all the "distinct" OLL and PLL cases, so there would still be no way to label the mirrored cases. I know you also don't give the mirrors on your page, it always used to confuse me why some people would say there are 57 OLL and others would say 40 odd :) But if there was some way of including all 57 + 21 cases, then I would be happy to go with it. Dan :) _____ From: cmhardw [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 19 February 2005 18:19 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases A also agree with this, and as a standard for the Fridrich method I suggest Jessica Fridrich's labelling system. It would be > > easier for anyone in the long run if everyone used the same labels for > > particular cases. I realise that for some people this would mean that > > some > > work would have to be put in to change webpages and so forth, but I > > really > > do think it is worth it. > > > > > > > > If this means that you would come up with a standard, or I would come > > up > > with a standard, or even if you say we should use the labelling system > > used > > on a particular site, as long as everyone ends up using the same > > thing, I > > wouldn't mind. > > > > > > > > Dan Harris :) Yahoo! Groups Sponsor <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129q97945/M=324658.6070095.7083352.3001176/D=gr oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1108923599/A=2343726/R=0/SIG=12il8brsd/*http:/clk.a tdmt.com/VON/go/yhxxxvon01900091von/direct/01/&time=1108837199897398> <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129q97945/M=324658.6070095.7083352.3001176/D=gr oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1108923599/A=2343726/R=1/SIG=12il8brsd/*http:/clk.a tdmt.com/VON/go/yhxxxvon01900091von/direct/01/&time=1108837199897398> Get unlimited calls to <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129q97945/M=324658.6070095.7083352.3001176/D=gr oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1108923599/A=2343726/R=1/SIG=12il8brsd/*http:/clk.a tdmt.com/VON/go/yhxxxvon01900091von/direct/01/&time=1108837199897398> U.S./Canada <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129q97945/M=324658.6070095.7083352.3001176/D=gr oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1108923599/A=2343726/R=1/SIG=12il8brsd/*http:/clk.a tdmt.com/VON/go/yhxxxvon01900091von/direct/01/&time=1108837199897398> <http://view.atdmt.com/VON/view/yhxxxvon01900091von/direct/01/&time=11088371 99897398> <http://us.adserver.yahoo.com/l?M=324658.6070095.7083352.3001176/D=groups/S= :HM/A=2343726/rand=339910789> _____ Yahoo! Hopefully I can get it down under 30 seconds this > year. My old method was pretty simple to learn but took about 150 > moves [I used to do it top corners first, then top edges, middle > layer edges, permute bottom corners, orient bottom corners, permute > & orient bottom edges.] > > I definitely cube while driving [only at stop lights, of course], > and while flying or waiting at airports or talking on the phone. > Anyone got suggestions on how to dampen the noise? will good lube > help? 937. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>

men... that is why katsu rules! i love his webpage. it got everything. weeeeee John Lwin --- Daniel Harris <dan_j_harris@...> wrote: > The only problem I have with this is that Jessica > doesn't give all the > cases, she gives all the "distinct" OLL and PLL > cases, so there would still > be no way to label the mirrored cases. I know you > also don't give the > mirrors on your page, it always used to confuse me > why some people would say > there are 57 OLL and others would say 40 odd :) > > > > But if there was some way of including all 57 + 21 > cases, then I would be > happy to go with it. > > > > Dan :) > > > > _____ > > From: cmhardw [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] > Sent: 19 February 2005 18:19 > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for > labelling LL cases > > > > > A also agree with this, and as a standard for the > Fridrich method I > suggest Jessica Fridrich's labelling system. > > I don't think there should be any contest about > this, she *is* the one > who inveneted the method. > > I can start re-labelling the cases on my page to > match hers, assuming > there is no disagreement over the labelling system. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson > Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > I agree with this. 940. How to prevent cubes from popping
From: "pinkeraserz" <pinkeraser@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 20:15:00 -0000


Hi all. I'm Jane and I've recently become addicted to the cube. :)

One major problem I have encountered is pieces popping from the
cube. This is way too common for me so I'd like to know how I can
fix this problem.

I used DIY kits from rubik's. If I tighten the cube anymore, it will
defeat the purpose of a "speedcube." But regardless of how much I
tighten it, it still pops frequently. I have lubed my cube with
silicone.

Sorry for explaining my situation very vaguely, but can anyone just
give me a few general tips on how I can treat this problem?

Thanks





941. Re: How to prevent cubes from popping
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 20:22:30 -0000

Jane, Welcome to the group! And may your newfound addiction be an asset... because addiction is the right word. I use a studio cube, and when I first got it it popped all the time. Honestly, all I did was keep using it. I eventually got to the point where I could turn it and have maybe 1 pop in 20 solves. My girlfriend, on the other hand, looks at it from across the room and it explodes. Working with it and knowing when you can turn what will help a lot. Beyond that, I don't have much advice and will defer to the various spin doctors (I made a pun) on the boards. Great to have you with us! -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pinkeraserz" <pinkeraser@g...> wrote: > > Hi all. I'm Jane and I've recently become addicted to the cube. :) > > One major problem I have encountered is pieces popping from the > cube. This is way too common for me so I'd like to know how I can > fix this problem. > > I used DIY kits from rubik's. If I tighten the cube anymore, it will > defeat the purpose of a "speedcube." But regardless of how much I > tighten it, it still pops frequently. I have lubed my cube with > silicone. > > Sorry for explaining my situation very vaguely, but can anyone just > give me a few general tips on how I can treat this problem? > > Thanks
942. Re: How to prevent cubes from popping
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 20:36:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pinkeraserz" <pinkeraser@g...> wrote: > > I used DIY kits from rubik's. If I tighten the cube anymore, it will > defeat the purpose of a "speedcube." But regardless of how much I > tighten it, it still pops frequently. I have lubed my cube with > silicone. Hi and welcome Jane! You did something wrong :-) These cube are pretty much impossible to pop. We're speaking about the ones with the arched centers (i.e. round, not flat bottoms of the center cubies), right? Can you take out all edges and corners and pull on each center as much as possible and tell us how far each center can be pulled away? It should be about 1-1.5mm, not more. And they should all be as equal as possible. How about your centers? Cheers! Stefan
943. [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <Jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 20:45:16 -0000


How about using the letters for PLL that I already have on the page?
If you need to distinguish between mirror and inverse algorithms,
why not appending a symbol to the letter, such as "m" and "i"?

As far as the OLL is concerned, we can go a similar way. I think
that we should somehow use visual clues so that it is easier to
remember. For example, we can have OLL named C, H, I, T, O, L, S, V,
etc., again with appropriate "m" for mirror positions. Of course,
there would be four I's that we would have to somehow distinguish,
let me think ...

Jessica





944. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "Dennis Nilsson" <dennis.nilsson@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 22:23:01 +0100

I use Jessica's letter to denote the pattern (with m and ') and Peter J. (at
speedcubing.com) to denote the number for the PLL case. I think that would
pretty much be the standard...

For the OLL, hmm, I have no specific standard to propose; maybe Lars Petrus
cases for all the edges oriented correctly should be set. Or Dan Harris way
to represent the patterns like for instance "T-shapes" T1, T2, "Fish-shape",
F1-F4 etc should be set. I like both but they interfere...

// Dennis

-----Ursprungligt meddelande-----
Från: Jessica Fridrich [mailto:Jess340@...]
Skickat: den 19 februari 2005 21:45
Till: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Ämne: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases



How about using the letters for PLL that I already have on the page?
If you need to distinguish between mirror and inverse algorithms,
why not appending a symbol to the letter, such as "m" and "i"?

As far as the OLL is concerned, we can go a similar way. I think
that we should somehow use visual clues so that it is easier to
remember. For example, we can have OLL named C, H, I, T, O, L, S, V,
etc., again with appropriate "m" for mirror positions. Of course,
there would be four I's that we would have to somehow distinguish,
let me think ...

Jessica

946. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 23:43:07 -0000


Well as far as 50 of the specific last layer orientation algorithms
go, I have names for them that I use. The name assignment and order
of the algorithms on the table that I made is a little bit arbitrary.
But maybe it will help give someone some ideas.

Table:
http://img233.exs.cx/img233/1271/llocepce0do.jpg


Names for 1-50 on the table
sorted by number of correctly oriented ll cubies.
ONE  2:
01 - A +
02 - A -

TWO  2:
03 - E +
04 - E -

THREE  13:
05 - N
06 - D +
07 - D -
08 - I +
09 - I -
10 - I' +
11 - I' -
12 - V1
13 - V2
14 - V3
15 - V4
16 - V5
17 - V6

FOUR  12:
18 - O +
19 - O -
20 - Y +
21 - Y -
22 - L+
23 - L -
24 - L' +
25 - L' -
26 - B +
27 - B -
28 - B' +
29 - B' -

FIVE  19:
30 - U +
31 - U -
32 - S
33 - S'
34 - T +
35 - T -
36 - Q
37 - Q'
38 - W +
39 - W -
40 - P +
41 - P -
42 - P' +
43 - P' -
44 - R +
45 - R -
46 - R' +
47 - R' -
48 - X

SIX  0:

SEVEN  2:
49 - Z
50 - H

EIGHT  0:

NINE  1:
Solved

950. Re: [Speed cubing group] famous rubik's cube timer
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 22:57:12 -0400

> i would love to get my hands on the "famous" timer that all the
> hardcore cubers use! the one that could be seen used by Jessica
> Fridrich, Tyson Mao...and the rest of the gang. hopefully thats enough
> info..(if thats not enough... the timer has a countdown with sound and
> to stop it you press the press bar..and it also has the algorithms for
> scrambling)
I don't know what famous timer is used by them. All I know is that you're
describing almost every rubiks timer existing. Chris', Jess' and my rubik
timer all have sound, countdown and scrambling algs, so you'd have to be
more specific. I think Jess Bonde's timer is the oldest and probably the
most (in)famous. So go to http://rubiks.dk and see for yourself. Or go to
the files section to get Chris' NetCube and if you don't like anything
that's Java or JavaScript download my rubiktimer from the files section or
from http://rubiktimer.tk.

Here's a comparison analysis:

NetCube: online, offline, multiplayer, file log, session avg, countdown,
created with Java or VB (older version)
Rubiks.dk: online, offline, singleplayer, online log, session avg,
countdown, created with JavaScript or ASP (online version)
RubikTimerTalks: offline, singleplayer, file log, online log, day avg,
countdown, voice timer, created with VB and ASP (for logging)

BTW: Ron and Dan also wrote timers. They're probably in the files section
too.

Michiel


>
> Thanks in advance!~
>
> p.s-in one of the Tyson Mao's videos i tried to zoom in on the timer's
> name but it was too blurry..lol!
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>

953. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 22:10:09 -0800 (PST)

Oops... Now this one should actually work: http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/new4x4.html My times with this method are around 2:15 when I'm in practice, about 10-15 seconds slower than when I use the traditional centers first method. -Richard --- Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...> wrote: > > I started working on something a few months ago, but > haven't had time to work with lately. My thoughts > on > the method were initially very optimistic. Now that > some time has past, I believe my excitement in > finding > something new and different (to me) created some > bias > opinions. > > This link should work. > www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/4x4method.html > > -Richard > > --- Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > "mikaelnybrg" > > <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > > > Is this something worth trying to improve and > > become fast at or is > > it > > > just better to switch to an other method (I know > > it���s a short step > > to > > > the method Chris uses)? > > > > Hi Mikael, > > > > I'd say it's definitely worth trying. I've been > > playing with some > > ideas to solve the 4x4 differently than I do so > far > > (which is > > centers/edges/3x3). I think it will be good for > > recognition to do "3x3 > > solving parts" not at the very end but instead > > earlier (e.g. like you > > do) because this limits the number of possible > > places that you have to > > look at to find pieces. > > > > So try it and don't give up too easily! At the > very > > least you'll learn > > something and you'll create something on your own, > > which is very good > > in my opinion. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! 955. Re: [Speed cubing group] color scheme
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 00:34:03 -0800

No, we request that you use the six standard colors, white, yellow,
blue, green, red, and orange in the Rubik's Cube tournament unless
there is some extenuating circumstances. Did you want a different
color scheme because you made your own stickers? If so, I would
recommend buying stickers from www.rubiks.com .

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 18, 2005, at 7:07 AM, rubikscubewhiz wrote:

> Is it allowed in competitions to use colors that differ from the
> normal color schemes? For example, to use brown instead of red or
> something like that.

957. Re: famous rubik's cube timer
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 09:11:40 -0000

If you're using windows, then grab the 1.5 JRE here: http://dlc.sun.com/jdk/jre-1_5_0_01-windows-i586-p.exe If you're not using windows, then download JRE here: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/download.jsp After installing the latest JRE, JNetCube will run. Just double-click the .jar file (If using Windows) or open up the terminal and type: java -jar JNetCube.jar -Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > haha, same thing happened to me when i download the netcube program. then i ask chris which java i need to download, then he gave me the link to download the java for netcube. sorry forgot which java i installed, but it is on www.sun.com for sure. > > Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote:Do you have Java? 959. Re: [Speed cubing group] color scheme
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 13:46:19 -0000

Tyson, all I found in the official rules is this: <quote> Competitors can use any normal 6 color sticker scheme for cubes, as long as the cubes show 1 color per face in solved position. The colors of the cube must be solid and clearly distinct from one another. The cube must either have colored stickers or colored tiles. </quote> What you just wrote looks a lot stricter than those rules. If it's supposed to be meant by "normal 6 color scheme" then I must say that's totally not clear. So far I was convinced any 6 colors are ok as long as they look different enough. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > No, we request that you use the six standard colors, white, yellow, > blue, green, red, and orange in the Rubik's Cube tournament unless > there is some extenuating circumstances. Did you want a different > color scheme because you made your own stickers? If so, I would > recommend buying stickers from www.rubiks.com . > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 18, 2005, at 7:07 AM, rubikscubewhiz wrote: > > > Is it allowed in competitions to use colors that differ from the > > normal color schemes? For example, to use brown instead of red or > > something like that.
960. Re: Standard for labelling LL cases
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 14:13:05 -0000

Hey! I also use the Petrus method. Yes there is a differnce between the two methods LL. First of all with the Petrus method you always have the edges orientated right so you don´t have to worry about them. If you follow the steps on Lars site you will use a 3-look LL, first you permute corners, then you orientate corners and last you permute edges. Fridrich uses a 2-look LL. First you orientate all LL cubies, then you permute all. The Fridrich method might by a bit more effective but you need to memorize 57+21 algorithms to cover all possible situation whereas with Petrus method you can do with 3 to start with and by learning the 19 (I think) algs he has named you can do LL with two looks. Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@H... > wrote: > > I've been learning the Petrus method and am not sure what the > differences are between his and the Fridrich method when it comes > the the last layer. Both methods seem to focus on doing F2L then LL. > > Are the PLL and OLL algorithms different between the two systems and > if so why?
961. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 14:33:21 -0000

Hey Richard! That seems almost exactly like the method I´ve been thinking of! My two biggest problem is how to tackle the problem of keeping track of the cubies in the beginning and my very unefficient pair-up methods after finnishing the 3x4x3. I´d love to hear how you pair up the last edgepairs. Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > Oops... > > Now this one should actually work: > > http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/new4x4.html > > My times with this method are around 2:15 when I'm in > practice, about 10-15 seconds slower than when I use > the traditional centers first method. > > -Richard
962. ZB method stuff
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 17:48:24 -0000


More to come, but here are my notes for trying to learn the method.
So far I don't have very much, but of course the page just started. I
have pictures and the algs I use listed for 2 additional ZBF2L cases
on there. I highly recommend starting with the 9 on Lars' site first
http://www.cubezone.be/zbf2l.html since the algs he chose go together
extremely well.

Anyway, for those curious and/or learning:

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zb.html

Chris

967. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 21:00:05 -0800 (PST)

As far as keeping track of all the cubies in the beginning, this is a problem for me also. After finishing the 3x4x3, you can pair up at least two edge pairs (sometimes 3 edge pairs) with a few setup moves and one sequence. When I find some extra time, I'll write up some more detailed sequences I use in my method. -Richard --- mikaelnybrg <stobe_98@...> wrote: > > Hey Richard! > > That seems almost exactly like the method I���ve been > thinking of! 973. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 02:42:00 -0800

Yes, so I understand that there is a problem that if your cube is ruled
illegal, then it would be devastating to your cubing time. That's why
if you're really concerned and you really want to be sure, then you
should go with a cube with good solid stickers. If you decide to show
up with a painted cube or a shabby stickered cube, you run your own
risk of not being able to use that cube.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 18, 2005, at 9:26 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote:

> Having said that we had a discussion last year on a ruling that painted
> cubes would not automatically be allowed - the local tournament
> director
> would rule on each individual case. For those who still have problems
> with
> stickers, coloured nail varnish is a fantastic substitute which is very
> durable and comes in lots of different colours!
>
> The reason for the ruling on painted cubes was that "badly" painted
> cubes
> can give an advantage to the solver (which makes more sense that it
> seems at
> first sight)! Problem is that if your cube is ruled illegal and you
> have to
> switch to another cube it may have a different colour scheme.
> Disaster!
>
> Duncan




974. Re: Special Cubes???
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 12:54:29 -0000

I use a DIY from rubiks.com and it is the fastest thing I've ever held. It has yet to pop (though I only built it 8 weeks ago) and it's really really fast. I would not want to use any other cube. As for lubricant, I use FTP Multi-purpose Silicone Lube. I'm pretty sure it's pure silicone spray. Bad stickers can slow down recognition, so once the color starts to fade away or it gets hard to distinguish colors, I replace my stickers. I've never tried KY on my cube, but I would imagine you want to use liquid, not jelly. The jelly would probably just make a mess. If you try it, let me know how well it works. Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darerick@t...> wrote: > > Just wondering what kind of cubes do most speedcubist use.. and what > would be the best lubricant.. I heard KY jelly works.. also does > having brand new stickers help?

I'm sure I can con sombody into helping me by then. (i already tried > > ebay > > > but > > > > > > none available!!) > > > > > > *im currently planning to attend the April competition at > > > Caltech > > > > > > (hope this info helps..because i was wondering if i could > > buy > > > one > > > > > at > > > > > > the competition..lol) > > > > > > > > > > > > if its impossible for me to get the studio cube i was > > thinking > > > > > about > > > > > > buying one off ebay that was made in hungary durring the > > > 1980s by > > > > > > ideal. but most of the cubes on sale are used and are in > bad > > > > > > condition...soo i dont want to take any chances of > spending > > > more > > > > > money > > > > > > on a bad cube that i cant speedcube with. > > > > > > > > > > > > if anyone has a better suggestion for buying the "perfect" > > > > > > cube...please reply here > > > > > > > > > > > > Thanks in advance!~ > > > > > > > > > > > > p.s. i dont want to spend over 40-50 dollars on it :P

978. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 15:43:47 -0000

Maybe Chris or someone else of the 4x4x4 gurus has an answer to the keeping track question. It would be nice of you to take the time to share the sequences you use. For the moment I only use one sequence that pairs up either one, two or three pairs, depending on the set-up so a few new tricks to the bag would do me good. Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > As far as keeping track of all the cubies in the > beginning, this is a problem for me also. After > finishing the 3x4x3, you can pair up at least two edge > pairs (sometimes 3 edge pairs) with a few setup moves > and one sequence. When I find some extra time, I'll > write up some more detailed sequences I use in my > method. > > -Richard > --- mikaelnybrg <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > > Hey Richard! > > > > That seems almost exactly like the method I´ve been > > thinking of! My > > two biggest problem is how to tackle the problem of > > keeping track of > > the cubies in the beginning and my very unefficient > > pair-up methods > > after finnishing the 3x4x3. I´d love to hear how you > > pair up the last > > edgepairs. > > > > Mikael > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > Richard Patterson > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > Oops... > > > > > > Now this one should actually work: > > > > > > > > http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/new4x4.html > > > > > > My times with this method are around 2:15 when I'm > > in > > > practice, about 10-15 seconds slower than when I > > use > > > the traditional centers first method. > > > > > > -Richard > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > The all-new My Yahoo! - Get yours free! > http://my.yahoo.com
979. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 16:15:13 -0000

Hey Mikael, Richard, I saw Richard's new 4x4 method a while ago, and messed around some with the 3x3x4 method as well. I too had a hard time finding efficient ways to pair up the edges after making the 3x3x4. I think the method is very promising, though I haven't practiced it much. Obviously I am being closed minded and biased, but I prefer my version of the centers-first method :) just since I've used it for so long. That doesn't mean though that I don't think the 3x3x4 method would be a good speedsolve method - I think it easily could be. I'm sure with lots of specific edge pairing sequences (though probably not too many) and commutaters and the like, that the edge pairing step after the 3x3x4 would be a fast step (maybe 2 looks with some setup moves and commutaters as well??) As far as keeping track of pieces, it all comes down to knowing all the spots where your piece can be. I know that sounds obvious, but you have to just have a general idea of where it could be at all times. Also, hard to see locations (the BR and BL edge locations for edge pieces) should be avoided as much as possible. I try as hard as I can during a solution to keep edge pieces I need out of BR and BL, so that I can see them without rotating the cube. For the 3x3x4 method, all the edges are visible on two faces after building the 3x3x4, so visibility shouldn't be much of a problem. As for the beginning, with the 3x3x4 itself (I gather this is what you meant about keeping track of the pieces), I don't have much advice other than to break it up into easy to handle substeps. The 3x3x4 has LOTS of pieces for a direct solve type of step, so it would be better to break it up into smaller, easier to magane sections. I think with lots of practice that it would be managable to solve this step quickly. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > Maybe Chris or someone else of the 4x4x4 gurus has an answer to the > keeping track question. It would be nice of you to take the time to > share the sequences you use. For the moment I only use one sequence > that pairs up either one, two or three pairs, depending on the set-up > so a few new tricks to the bag would do me good. > > Mikael > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > As far as keeping track of all the cubies in the > > beginning, this is a problem for me also. After > > finishing the 3x4x3, you can pair up at least two edge > > pairs (sometimes 3 edge pairs) with a few setup moves > > and one sequence. When I find some extra time, I'll > > write up some more detailed sequences I use in my > > method. > > > > -Richard

981. Long Time no see - Broke 2 mintunes
From: mtozor@...
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 18:05:54 -0000


Ok I know the 2 minute mark is a joke to most people on here. Now I
can say that I finally broke it and can easly average under it now :-)
I took a month off from the cube (got an XBOX for Christmas) and when
I picked it up only took a me a couple minutes to remember the ALGS
I've learned.

I notice in my guitar playing if I take a break everynow and then when
I start backup I seem to pickup new momentium. Anyone else no what im
talking about ?

Anyway I guess it will be a few months before I break one minute.
Without getting lucky that is.









982. Re: Long Time no see - Broke 2 mintunes
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 18:29:55 -0000


I also get some of my best times after taking a week long break from
the cube. What you should do is practice a lot, learn a whole bunch of
new algorithms/fingertricks or something really well, then take off
from the cube for a week or so. Then your mind will kind of organize
all of this new information, and when you pick it up again, it'll be
second nature to you and much easier.
I hope that paragraph made sense, not sure though....

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mtozor@y... wrote:

From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>

>the cube. What you should do is practice a lot, learn a whole bunch of
>new algorithms/fingertricks or something really well, then take off
>from the cube for a week or so. Then y

Yes I've been unwell from a viral infection for the last week or so and
unable to do anything, even cubing. Then at the weekend I was able to
concentrate again and I've gone down to times under 1 1/2 minutes. I had a
hospital appointment this morning and had an hour to wait for the
appointment, so I practised cubing for a bit - and had quite an audience
from some junior doctors from the ENT department who were at the table next
to me in the coffee shop and suddenly realised what I was doing!

Anyone know where in the UK you can get silicone spray, my cube has
loosened up nicely with use and turns reasonably smoothly but could do with
a little further work because some of the edges are catching slightly from
time to time. Unfortunately we don't have places like Walmart here, but
would I get it in a painter/decorator type shop or is it more an artist's
or craft shop material?

I've started learning the Fridrich system too but that will take time.

Gillian


Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online

985. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes???
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 13:45:19 -0600

Whatever you do, do NOT use KY jelly. It is my understanding that it's a petroleum product, like WD-40, and will eat the plastic that makes up your beloved cube. KY liquid is a reasonable alternative, and because it's water based, will not destroy plastic. Unfortunately, it wears off fairly quickly, is messy to apply, and makes the cube stick sometimes. My girlfriend and I have both attempted to lube our cubes with the liquid and have decided silicon is a much better alternative. On top of that, silicon is far less awkward to obtain, especially if you're a minor. That being said, it does make for much better stories. =) Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: rubikscubewhiz<mailto:rubikscubewhiz@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, February 21, 2005 6:54 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes??? I use a DIY from rubiks.com and it is the fastest thing I've ever held. It has yet to pop (though I only built it 8 weeks ago) and it's really really fast. I would not want to use any other cube. As for lubricant, I use FTP Multi-purpose Silicone Lube. I'm pretty sure it's pure silicone spray. Bad stickers can slow down recognition, so once the color starts to fade away or it gets hard to distinguish colors, I replace my stickers. I've never tried KY on my cube, but I would imagine you want to use liquid, not jelly. The jelly would probably just make a mess. If you try it, let me know how well it works. Bob [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
986. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Long Time no see - Broke 2 mintunes
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 13:48:16 -0600

Actually, you'd be much more likely to find it in a hardware store or an auto parts shop. It's a lubricant, and those are the two best places to find similar materials. Happy cubing. =) Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Gillian Buchanan<mailto:gmb@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, February 21, 2005 1:33 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Long Time no see - Broke 2 mintunes At 18:29 21/02/2005, you wrote: Anyone know where in the UK you can get silicone spray, my cube has loosened up nicely with use and turns reasonably smoothly but could do with a little further work because some of the edges are catching slightly from time to time. 988. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 12:35:46 -0800

What's wrong with that? What are you to do when someone comes up to
you with a cube that's absolutely so shaggy that it takes you 10
seconds of studying before you realize which color sticker is which?
What's the quote... "Oh... that one is green." referring to a white
sticker on the cube. The thing about that cube though was that every
single sticker was white with a miniscule dot of green in the center.

Then, there was the nail polish cube of the winter 2004 tournament
using glitter polish with colors so close to each other that yes, I had
to study the cube for quite some time before I realized which slight
shade of blue was different from which slight shade of green. They all
looked like brown muck to me.

If you're upset with it, suggest something new.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

991. [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>

Hey! I have a simple test for "color distinctiveness". Try scan in the solved state using a webcam and the Cube Explorer. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 21, 2005, at 12:45 PM, Per Kristen Fredlund wrote: > > > Hey! > > I have a simple test for "color distinctiveness". If it accepts the > cube then it's fine ... ;-) > > Judges could in fact do that if in doubt about the suitability of > the colors ;-) > > -Per > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> >> Hmm I think there's nothing wrong with it. There are normal > perfect >> cubes which can obviously be used and there are cubes with all six >> sides having the same color which can obviously not be used. > Somewhere >> in between a line has to be drawn and I think the competition >> organizers are the people who should draw it. Don't you think so? >> >> Cheers! >> Stefan >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" >> <duncan@d...> wrote: >>> Sorry Tyson but this makes my blood boil. I know > you >> put a lot >>> of effort into running competitions and I'm definitely not > getting >> personal >>> but - grrrrr. >>> >>> Duncan >>> >>> >>> ----- Original Message ----- >>> From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@i...> >>> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >>> Sent: Monday, February 21, 2005 10:42 AM >>> Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme >>> >>> >>>> >>>> Yes, so I understand that there is a problem that if your cube > is >> ruled >>>> illegal, then it would be devastating to your cubing time. > That's >> why >>>> if you're really concerned and you really want to be sure, > then >> you >>>> should go with a cube with good solid stickers. 994. Re: Valentine's Day
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 21:07:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > English is structured where sometimes there are parts missing from > a > > text which are "understood" to be there. If you remove the second > > "you" the sentence reads, "i yearn for you like a sub-fifteen" which > > has a different meaning from, "i yearn for you like you [yearn for] > a > > sub-fifteen." > > Ah, ok... I've seen that in written interviews with politicians and > celebrities, but I would've expected a love letter to be written in > cleaner English ;-) At least the "for" should've been added I'd say. > Grumble... Americans... > > Cheers! > Stefan Hi Stefan, That simile *is* written in "clean" Engish; in fact that usage dates back to a time between Chaucer and Shakespeare. Believe it or not, some Americans speak English well. Regards, David J

996. [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes???
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 21:25:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Whatever you do, do NOT use KY jelly. It is my understanding that it's a petroleum product, I believe that the gel is also water based: if it was petroleum based it would damage latex ;) I'm surprised, though, that it doesn't dry out too quickly for use as a cube lubricant... Mike

998. 5x5x5 Speedsolving
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 22:34:39 -0000


I'm working on solving a 5x5x5, and using a centers-first method it
takes me about five minutes to pair up the centers and edges. Is this
method inherently bad for the 5x5x5? How can I do it better? Note that
I use one algorithm for the pairing-up that I consider non-intuitive
(i.e. more than three moves or so). Is there a system of algorithms
that works well?





999. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 14:36:20 -0800

Convenience for the administrators and not the competitors? Think
about it this way. I'm asking you as an individual to help me out a
little bit so I can handle 40 people coming to a tournament. Many
times, my staff is just a few of my close friends and they have to take
time out of their schedule to come and make things work. The fact is I
can't go ahead and tailor the tournament to every single person's
individual needs. Some people can't make a Saturday because of
orchestra rehearsal. Okay... what about the guy who can't make it at
10:30 and wants the tournament to start at 11:30 AM so he can go to
Chinese school?

If 39 people can come to the tournament with good cubes, I'm sure you
can to.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 21, 2005, at 6:05 AM, Duncan Dicks wrote:

> an
> official body and already we're talking about running the sport for the
> convenience of the administrators not the competitors. I know you put
> a lot
> of effort into running competitions and I'm definitely not getting
> personal
> but - grrrrr.
>
> Duncan

fact, most of the time, I end up spending my own money on things. For
the Exploratorium tournament in San Francisco, I was given one cube
trophy. How did people end up with UFOs and all those other prizes? I
paid for them myself.

I'm sorry, I've gotten a bit worked up now. I have some homework to
attend to.

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology

1001. TurkZeka 2005/1 Weekly Puzzle Competition.
From: "yilmazekici2002" <bilgi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 22:42:32 -0000


This e-mail is sent to you in order to inform you about the TurkZeka
2005/1 Weekly Puzzle Competition.

Below are the details about Puzzle Competition and TurkZeka.Com:

Aim : The site TurkZeka.Com was established with a purpose of
helping puzzle fans improve their ability of imaging, thinking,
finding winding key, heading conclusion, finding out the hidden
properties etc. and having nice and useful time at the same time.

CONTENTS :

Puzzle Competitions :

The first puzzle competition which had 50 questions was held in
2004, during all the year.

TurkZeka 2005/1 Puzzle Competition will start on 27 or 28 February
2005.
This year, each competition (total 4 times in a year) is going to
have 10 puzzles and these puzzle competitions will be open to all
country.
Competitions will be published in only Turkish and English.
You will have exactly 7 days to submit the answers of the puzzles
via "Answer" form page, beginning from the puzzle's publishing date.

You should read "How to Answer" page before aswering. Each correct
answer is 100 points and additionally there are two types of bonus
points.
One of the bonus points is given to the first 3 competitors who give
the correct answer (30, 20 and 10 point) and the other bonus is
given depending on answering day, beginning from current puzzle's
publishing date (30, 25, 20, 15, 10 and 5 point).

Correct answers and solutions will be given when the next puzzle is
published. Your score will be updated when you post your answer. You
can see whether your answer is correct or not on the "Score Anlayze
Table". To compete, you have to sign up to the site and log in.

We want the competitors from abroad participate in these
competitions which have great numbers of participants from Turkey
and that pleasent rivalry adds joy to the competitions.
In this respect, you should tell friends who are interested in
puzzles about these competitions and the site.
Our web address is : http://www.turkzeka.com

Thank you.

Good Luck...



Nonograms :

Total 5 new nonograms are published every day.
Nonograms' sizes : 10x10 - 15x15 - 20x20 - 25x25 - 30x30

New types of puzzles will posted coming soon. (Diamond, Mines...)

Just Solve & Enjoy...



Links:

You can add your site or the sites you know as to puzzles to our
Puzzle Sites Link Page


Yilmaz Ekici
(Owner & Administrator of TURKZEKA)

Our Editors :

ÝSMAÝL TÜRK : Project & Software

ÖZTÜRK YILDIRIM : Category Puzzles

CENGÝZHAN TEKÝN : Statistics



Yours Respectfully.

--------------------------------
web : http://www.turkzeka.com
e-mail : turkzeka@...









1002. method improvement
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 23:16:32 -0000


I am currently using Gilles Roux's method
(http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Intro.html) and i can currently
average under 2 min. I have not lubricated my cube ever, and i would
like to get faster. What do you suggest that i do to help my times?

1010. Re: method improvement
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 01:22:59 -0000

This is the method I use. Thanks Lars Petrus. It is somewhat similar to the method you are using. The advantage to the petrus method for the f2l is you can solve the first two layers(f2l) without destroying anything you have done already. After you get used to using this you can start looking ahead for your next peices to solve. This is also true for Fridrich's system and several others. checkout these sites for more detailed info http://www.speedcubing.com http://www.lar5.com/cube/index.html --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I am currently using Gilles Roux's method > (http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Intro.html) and i can currently > average under 2 min. I have not lubricated my cube ever, and i would > like to get faster. What do you suggest that i do to help my times?

I also oppose Guinness, especially since they have already said that they are "not interested" in Rubik's records because they are too out there so to speak. I was told that Guinness doesn't like too many records for a certain type of category (so other than fastest time and blindfolded, they just dont' care). Also, they've already told Jess Bonde that they "aren't interested" in his 2000 cube attempt. I support you guys trying to set a new cube marathon record, that's all well and good. However give up your hopes on Guinness, they've already said that they don't care. Guinness sucks, WCA recognized records are the way to go. 1014. Rules clarification
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 04:01:54 -0000


So I've been solving my rainbow cube a lot recently, as I'm trying to
see how fast I can really get it. I've noticed that on some of my
solves, I can set the rainbow cube up in such a way that I can do the
first few moves without picking up the puzzle. I was wondering if
this would be considered legal in an official tournament. I looked up
the WCA rules (found the workman's compensation administration when I
first googled "WCA rules"), and it says for the 3x3x3 speedsolve:

"The competitor will have 3 seconds to begin his solve after the judge
removes his hand."

and also

"In the Rubik's 3x3x3 Cube  Speed Solve Competition, the
competitor
may return the cube to the solved state by any means."

Now I know these only apply to the 3x3x3, and that rules for other
puzzles aren't written. I was just curious if there would be any
problem with doing this. The rules for the 3x3x3 seem to indicate you
don't really have to pick it up if you don't want to. If this is a
problem, I'd like to know now so I stop doing it.

-Chris Parlette





1015. Re: [Speed cubing group] 24-Hour Cube marathon
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Feb 2005 20:03:52 -0800

You would want about 5 cubes. What if you pop one? It'll be bad.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1017. fun pll
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>

1018. [Speed cubing group] Re: 24-Hour Cube marathon
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 05:03:43 -0000

As far as I remember it was 1) The cube must be new and taken out of its original packaging for the first time before being used for the attempt. 2) Scramble provided by a computer (not sure if there was a move # specification), done by a third party and not seen by the competitor. 3) Competitor given 15 seconds inspection, after which the cube is covered. 4) Countdown or some other start signal given, and the cube is solved and placed back on the table. Basically the solving format of the first world competition. They would have had to have changed this since the 2003 WC however, since I'm sure Jess was using a rather nicely prepared speedcube rather than a cube right out of the box :) I guess the current rules are the above rules, but in place of 1) is a new 1) the time must be achieved in an official world competition (since it is the title of the record) Again that is my answer working from memory from a year ago. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > You can look it up somewhere. I don't remember exactly where otherwise > I'd get you the link. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 21, 2005, at 7:15 PM, rubikscubewhiz wrote: > > > I agree. WCA recognized records are much better than Guinness. :) > > > > ~Bob > > > > BTW....what are Guinness's rules for fastest solve on a cube?

From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 05:10:14 -0000

1020. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 08:09:27 -0000

Ok Guys - really sorry and to some extent I regret my posting. As I said it was not at all personal and I appreciate all the hard work done by those who organise and run tournaments. I still feel pretty strongly that a cube with 6 clearly distinct colours - any colours - whether painted on or stickers or tiles or whatever should be equally acceptable and my understanding is that the rules do allow this at the organisers discretion. I also accept that some effort has to be made to make tournaments run smoothly and making things easier for the administrators is not in itself a bad thing! I guess it bothers me that I can't find stickers that last a decent amount of time, that I don't like the most normal colour scheme because I "grew up" with the original Ideal one and that my beautifully nail-varnished cube may not be acceptable in tournaments even though it confers no advantage! Having said that the rules are the rules and should I ever find the time to make the trip to take part in a tournament then I shall abide! Sorry if I got you worked up Tyson - all your efforts and your many helpful postings are much appreciated. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, February 22, 2005 12:56 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: color scheme > > Stefan, > > Definitely not! I'm sorry I wasn't clear. I was just not happy that I > made Duncan's blood boil. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 21, 2005, at 4:10 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > Tyson, > > > > do you think my post was *against* you? That's not the case. I was > > trying to argue in favour of you, i.e. that there's nothing wrong with > > the way you handle it (and why it should/must be done that way)... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

1022. Re: method improvement
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 08:30:01 -0000

I am also using the Gilles Roux Method...I'm working on learning the corner algorithms, and I currently average about 28-30. I originally started with the petrus method, learned PLL sequences, then learned a few F2L algorithms, and now i am working at this method. The best thing to do is just keep working. Work on getting the solution down, moves-wise and all. Try to get few moves, and then try to slowly build up your speed. Lube will probably get in the way at first until you adjust to having it on your cube, but in the end, it is a huge help. If you want to talk to me about tips or whatever, my e- mail is ( JwillywonkaS at gmail dot com ). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I am currently using Gilles Roux's method > (http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Intro.html) and i can currently > average under 2 min. I have not lubricated my cube ever, and i would > like to get faster. What do you suggest that i do to help my times?

Are you a cuber in college? Is anyone interested in a college vs.
college match? I think it might be fun. You know... 5 cubers from
each school. There are a variety of ways of doing this. It could be
first team to solve 100 cubes or something. Or we could have the top
cubers vs. the top cuber and the 2nd vs. the 2nd and so on and see
which school wins more. Anyway, I think it might be fun.

1030. Re: Rules clarification
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 12:26:13 -0000

Beware: I'm not WCA, this is just my personal guess/opinion. I think as long as we use stackmats (and I'd like to keep using them) there shouldn't be a problem with that. Using the stackmat starts the timer when your hands take off so the time is running when you do moves like that. Also I know at least one person who does the second half of the Magic solve with the Magic lying on the mat and there's no problem with that either (that's not a complaint, I agree that's ok). And I do much of the Master Magic solve with it lying on the mat. I thought about the same for the Megaminx, but I guess since that puzzle takes a lot longer anyway it doesn't really matter to me that much ;-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@w...> wrote: > > So I've been solving my rainbow cube a lot recently, as I'm trying to > see how fast I can really get it. I've noticed that on some of my > solves, I can set the rainbow cube up in such a way that I can do the > first few moves without picking up the puzzle. I was wondering if > this would be considered legal in an official tournament. I looked up > the WCA rules (found the workman's compensation administration when I > first googled "WCA rules"), and it says for the 3x3x3 speedsolve: > > "The competitor will have 3 seconds to begin his solve after the judge > removes his hand." > > and also > > "In the Rubik's 3x3x3 Cube  Speed Solve Competition, the > competitor > may return the cube to the solved state by any means." > > Now I know these only apply to the 3x3x3, and that rules for other > puzzles aren't written. I was just curious if there would be any > problem with doing this. The rules for the 3x3x3 seem to indicate you > don't really have to pick it up if you don't want to. If this is a > problem, I'd like to know now so I stop doing it. > > -Chris Parlette
1031. [Speed cubing group] Re: 24-Hour Cube marathon
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 12:33:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Guinness sucks, WCA recognized records are the way to go. Yeah, I agree too :-) Though I'd like to mention this page which also collects/summarizes our official records: http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html I think at least many of those records also made it into this "book of alternative records": http://www.alternativerecords.co.uk/ I think Ralf Laue is involved in both the webpage and the book and he's a cuber himself, which is obviously a good sign :-) Cheers! Stefan
1032. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rules clarification
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 04:37:37 -0800

Hi Chris,

That's why the WCA uses the StackMat as the official timing device. It
starts the timer once you lift off a hand meaning there is no possible
way you can make a move before starting the timer. Beautiful isn't it?
That is one of the main reasons the WCA will not be using the new
optical sensor timer. I understand there are issues with the StackMat
and if anyone wants to have a discussion about it, please do so.
However, I believe the StackMat satisfies all of our needs and
accommodates basically every puzzle and allows for easy judging, little
discrepancy, and yes, it works well. The argument that "it times the
time it takes you to pick up the puzzle as well which is not fair" is
not a very good one because practically, there is no way to time purely
the solve. 100-meter dash runners have to react to a gun and if you
fall asleep, well, that's your fault.

As for returning the cube to its solved state by any means possible,
when I have time, and that probably means a spring break or summer
break, I will revisit all of the rules and revise them. You should
really be following the spirit of the law there and I will change the
letter of the law to reflect the spirit of the law. One example of
something which would be dishonorable would be twisting two corners
really quickly to solve your cube when you could perform an OLL.
That's cheap... Doug Li brought it up, and I'll revise that rule
sometime.

Again, to answer your question, you can't touch the puzzle while your
hands are on the timer and there's no way for you to lift up a hand
without starting the timer unless you have jedi-powers or unless you
use your feet. Speaking of feet, then that means your feet would have
to be on the timing pad as well. Okay, something else to revise but
you get the point. The rules have been written in such a manner that
takes away any unfair advantage or loop holes or whatever so if there
are loop holes or things you can kind of squeeze around, let us know so
we can improve on them.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 21, 2005, at 8:01 PM, Chris Parlette wrote:

> So I've been solving my rainbow cube a lot recently, as I'm trying to
> see how fast I can really get it. I've noticed that on some of my
> solves, I can set the rainbow cube up in such a way that I can do the
> first few moves without picking up the puzzle. I was wondering if
> this would be considered legal in an official tournament. I looked up
> the WCA rules (found the workman's compensation administration when I
> first googled "WCA rules"), and it says for the 3x3x3 speedsolve:
>
> "The competitor will have 3 seconds to begin his solve after the judge
> removes his hand."
>
> and also
>
> "In the Rubik's 3x3x3 Cube – Speed Solve Competition, the
> competitor
> may return the cube to the solved state by any means."
>
> Now I know these only apply to the 3x3x3, and that rules for other
> puzzles aren't written. I was just curious if there would be any
> problem with doing this. The rules for the 3x3x3 seem to indicate you
> don't really have to pick it up if you don't want to. If this is a
> problem, I'd like to know now so I stop doing it.
>
> -Chris Parlette




1033. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 24-Hour Cube marathon
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 04:41:13 -0800

So... my thoughts on the 24-hour cube marathon. I myself really do
want to make an attempt at this and I'll do it when I have time and
when I can find a good venue with some publicity. If there is someone
out there who wants to try it and you're really serious about it, I'd
like to propose some audition criteria. I'm not going to gather a team
to scramble cubes for you for 24 hours if you don't have a reasonable
chance of breaking that record. Therefore, I really recommend that you
solve 120 cubes in an hour before you even think about anything else.

Sure, 120 cubes in an hour is well over the pace necessary to do 2000
in 24 but when you count in fatigue, yeah, you'll be "crawling" at hour
18. Not to mention bathroom breaks.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 22, 2005, at 4:33 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Yeah, I agree too :-)
>
> Though I'd like to mention this page which also collects/summarizes
> our official records:
> http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html

> http://www.alternativerecords.co.uk/

> he's a cuber himself, which is obviously a good sign :-)

1034. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rules clarification
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 04:43:17 -0800

The StackMat prevents people from exploiting the ability of making a
turn or any type of puzzle manipulation before the timer is started. I
pretty much don't see a way of getting around this unless you use
another part of your body but the rules should say you aren't allowed
to touch the puzzle until the time has started and, well, if it's not
there, it can be written in. Sure, some of you may say that you should
be allowed to touch the puzzle as the time starts but then you risk
starting the time after you've touched the puzzle and any physicist out
there knows that theoretical problems never work in the real world.
Now, about that frictionless swivel chair... whee!

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 22, 2005, at 4:26 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Beware: I'm not WCA, this is just my personal guess/opinion.
>
> I think as long as we use stackmats (and I'd like to keep using them)
> there shouldn't be a problem with that. Using the stackmat starts the
> timer when your hands take off so the time is running when you do
> moves like that. Also I know at least one person who does the second
> half of the Magic solve with the Magic lying on the mat and there's no
> problem with that either (that's not a complaint, I agree that's ok).
> And I do much of the Master Magic solve with it lying on the mat.
>
> I thought about the same for the Megaminx, but I guess since that
> puzzle takes a lot longer anyway it doesn't really matter to me that

> Cheers!

On Feb 21, 2005, at 11:45 AM, Mike Bennett wrote:

> Whatever you do, do NOT use KY jelly. It is my understanding that
> it's a petroleum product, like WD-40, and will eat the plastic that
> makes up your beloved cube. KY liquid is a reasonable alternative,
> and because it's water based, will not destroy plastic.
> Unfortunately, it wears off fairly quickly, is messy to apply, and
> makes the cube stick sometimes. My girlfriend and I have both
> attempted to lube our cubes with the liquid and have decided silicon
> is a much better alternative. On top of that, silicon is far less
> awkward to obtain, especially if you're a minor. That being said, it
> does make for much better stories. =)
>
> Mike Bennett

1038. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes???
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 11:19:48 -0600

Funny story time. A few months ago, myself and a female cohort were planning a night of movies, video games, and eating junk food. Being the addict I am, I also brought my cube, which was sorely in need of a lubing. We needed supplies from Wal-Mart anyway, so we decided to just kill two birds with one stone. I read on someone's site that KY Liquid worked extremely well, so I found some to buy. We pulled up to the register and plopped on the counter: 1 YM magazine, 6 rolls of colored duct tape (we made fantastic wallets and a messenger bag), 1 20 oz. bottle of 7up, a massive log of cookie dough, and a bottle of KY Liquid. The attendant took one look and asked us 'Fun night planned?' -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Tyson Mao<mailto:tmao@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, February 22, 2005 7:23 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes??? 1040. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rules clarification
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 09:34:19 -0800

It's actually quite easy to keep your palms on the timer and solve the
entire cube without starting it, alternately stopping it early and keep
solving.

You'd need a rule saying that the cube needs to be put down a certain
distance from the sensors, both before and after the solve, to make
sure it can't happen.

If a moderately talented illusionist practiced it, I expect they could
trim a second or two off on a way that most judges wouldn't notice.

/Lars

On Feb 22, 2005, at 4:37, Tyson Mao wrote:

>
> Hi Chris,
>
> That's why the WCA uses the StackMat as the official timing device. It
> starts the timer once you lift off a hand meaning there is no possible
> way you can make a move before starting the timer. Beautiful isn't
> it?

1047. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: method improvement
From: "James Stuber" <jstuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 12:14:34 -0800

For the corner sequences, its faster to recognize them like you would recognize COLL. www.cubezone.be has good COLL algs. -----Original Message----- From: jwillywonkas [mailto:jwillywonkas@...] Sent: Tuesday, February 22, 2005 12:30 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: method improvement I am also using the Gilles Roux Method...I'm working on learning the corner algorithms, and I currently average about 28-30. I originally started with the petrus method, learned PLL sequences, then learned a few F2L algorithms, and now i am working at this method. The best thing to do is just keep working. Work on getting the solution down, moves-wise and all. Try to get few moves, and then try to slowly build up your speed. Lube will probably get in the way at first until you adjust to having it on your cube, but in the end, it is a huge help. If you want to talk to me about tips or whatever, my e- mail is ( JwillywonkaS at gmail dot com ). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I am currently using Gilles Roux's method > (http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Intro.html) and i can currently > average under 2 min. I have not lubricated my cube ever, and i would > like to get faster. What do you suggest that i do to help my times? Yahoo! Groups Links

1057. Countries
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 14:27:03 -0800

http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html

What's going on here? There's this site and they're posting up the
WCA's recognized records, and what are they doing? I'm upset because
they have listed Chun Hei as being from China instead of being from
Hong Kong. We recognize Hong Kong. I feel like it's libel in a way...
I mean, they basically make it look like we do not recognize Hong Kong.
My feeling is if you're going to post our records, you need to post
our records without altering them.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1060. Re: Countries
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 22:41:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html > > What's going on here? There's this site and they're posting up the > WCA's recognized records, and what are they doing? Didn't you know this page? Hmm, you make it sound like they just copied the WCA lists, I don't think that's the case. Notice that this page has been around for quite some time, maybe even before we had our own nice lists. And it has been frequently updated after each tournament, taking them time to collect the data. I like their effort. > I'm upset because > they have listed Chun Hei as being from China instead of being from > Hong Kong. We recognize Hong Kong. I feel like it's libel in a way... > I mean, they basically make it look like we do not recognize Hong Kong. > My feeling is if you're going to post our records, you need to post > our records without altering them. I'm sure that's just a mistake. I think Ralf Laue probably maintains it and I'm currently in contact with him anyway so I'll tell him about it. Btw, what's the big deal about Hong Kong vs China? Are Hong Kong people insulted when someone thinks they're Chinese? Cheers! Stefan

1062. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 14:47:53 -0800

Hi Stefan,

I did know the page and I did know Ralf Laue was involved though I only
know Ralf Laue by name and I've never spoken to him. It's not that
they "copied" the WCA list because they didn't. They have records on
there which the WCA does have. However, the Chun Hei Wong record does
belong to the WCA and we recognize it as Hong Kong. I'm upset because
they took our record and modified it.

It would be really nice of you to contact Ralf Laue for me and ask him
about it. I personally am not from Hong Kong but I understand that
Hong Kong people would be insulted to be called Chinese. There are
many political issues out there right now and it is of my opinion that
we recognize Hong Kong. I'm sure Chun Hei will agree with me and if
there is any person out there who feels differently, I ask them the
question, what right do you have to say what nationality Chun Hei is
from? What right do you have to say he is not from Hong Kong but he is
from China?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 22, 2005, at 2:41 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Didn't you know this page?
>
> Hmm, you make it sound like they just copied the WCA lists, I don't
> think that's the case. Notice that this page has been around for quite
> some time, maybe even before we had our own nice lists. And it has
> been frequently updated after each tournament, taking them time to
> collect the data. I like their effort.
>
> I'm sure that's just a mistake. I think Ralf Laue probably maintains
> it and I'm currently in contact with him anyway so I'll tell him about
> it.
>
> Btw, what's the big deal about Hong Kong vs China? Are Hong Kong
> people insulted when someone thinks they're Chinese?
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan




1063. Dallas, Texas
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 15:00:52 -0800

Hey Everyone,

During our spring break, I will be flying to Mississippi to help a
member of the Caltech Mark Team drive his car from Mississippi back to
Pasadena. On the way, on Wednesday, March 23, 2005, Mark and I will be
stopping by "The Science Place" in Dallas, Texas to meet with the
museum administrators to discuss issues about the tournament. If any
cubers would like to attend, please let me know and let's work
something out.

Also, if there any any cubers on the way from Mississippi to Pasadena,
so if you're near Interstate-20 or Interstate-10, let me know. Maybe
we can drop by and have a few races?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology
