1065. Rubik's Cube Test
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 23:09:15 -0000


> Man... I hate having to do work. It's so tempting for me to write a
> "cube test" right now to see how much of a cube geek one is.

I've got a pre-alpha version... why don't you all correct and amend
it?

Rubik's Cube Test

I know...
[] how to solve the Cube
[] in less than a minute
[] 5+ ways
[] in less than 20 seconds
[] in less than 65 moves
[] what OLL stands for
[] what BYO stands for
[] what ZB stands for
[] what AUF stands for
[] what BLD stands for
[] who Erno Rubik is
[] who Uwe Meffert is
[] who Terutoshi Ishige is
[] who Shotaro Makisumi is
[] what the WCA is
[] and am in it
[] and have a high-up position

I have...
[] a Rubik's Cube
[] 5+ Cubes
[] 25+ Cubes
[] 25+ different Cubes
[] a 4x4x4
[] and can solve it
[] in less than two minutes
[] a 5x5x5
[] and can solve it
[] in less than three minutes
[] cube lubrication
[] 3 kinds or more
[] a Megaminx
[] a Square-1
[] and can solve it in less than a minute
[] a Dogic
[] more than one kind
[] made my own kind
[] a nontrivial cube mod
[] that Tony Fisher made
[] that I made
[] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise
[] knockoff Cubes
[] just because they're Cubes
[] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles
[] which is famous
[] won in a championship
[] a WR
[] more than one WR

I know... [2]
[] more than ten algorithms
[] 100 algorithms
[] the entire ZB method
[] all 1211 LL algorithms
[][][] Erno Rubik
[] how to disassemble a Cube
[] without breaking it
[] including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5
[] including an Eastsheen 2x2x2
[] how to solve the Rubik's Magic
[] in less than three seconds
[] what the Superflip is
[] an optimal solution
[] all optimal solutions
[] more than 5 pretty patterns by heart
[] more than 10
[] more than 50
[] what a supercube group is

I like...
[] to solve the Cube
[] even in the bathroom
[] underwater
[] during meals
[] in my dreams
[] hanging around in cubing forums
[] to take twisty puzzles apart
[] and make other things out of them





1066. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 15:12:31 -0800

The issues start to become a lot more sensitive if you want to really
get into it. Hong Kong was... now, correct my history lesson if I'm
wrong, part of the British territories. China gave up Hong Kong to
Britain for 99 years after the "Opium Wars" right? and it was in 1999
when Hong Kong was returned to China. In those 99 years, Hong Kong and
China developed very differently. Now, technically they are "one
country" but people from Hong Kong still identify themselves as from
Hong Kong rather than from China.

Some one better acquainted with this subject might want to jump in
here. It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong
Kong, then I will honor that request. Does anyone know if the Hong
Kong passport is different than the China passport?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 22, 2005, at 3:06 PM, Joël van Noort wrote:

> Hmm..
>
> I don't really know much about the relationship between Hong Kong
> and China, but I do know that it's not really the same as 'two
> different countries', like Spain and Mexico or something. But I
> could be wrong about this... :)..
>
> Bye,
>
> Joël.

take this.

Yahoo! Mail - Find what you need with new enhanced search. http://info.mail.yahoo.com/mail_250
1069. Toy Fair Story
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 23:50:26 -0000


Hi Folks,

On Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday, I helped showcase the Rubik's Cube
at the Winning Moves booth at the annual toy fair at the Jacob
Javits Center in New York. Basically I just solved the cube for
anyone who walked by the booth. I had some TV stints on CBS, NBC,
and a local station called New York 1. One of the clips is
available at http://www.ny1.com/Living/home.html

Right now the toy fair is the lead story...just click the video link
below the title. The video requires Real Media Player. My part of
the video is about 55 seconds in. I'll try to get copies of the
other clips and post them someplace.

I got to meet Dave Jones from Seventowns and he was really cool. I
also met the world record holder for the Bedlam Cube. He puts it
together in about 12 seconds. I think Macky (on the cube) could
give him a run for his money.

Here are some stats:

# of 3x3x3s solved ~300
# of 4x4x4s solved ~10
# of 5x5x5s solved ~5
# of 5x5x5s popped 1
# of minutes to fix the pop ~20
# of people who claimed they used to be able to do the cube ~20
# of people who could actually solve the cube for me 2
# of people who told me that their method of solving was to peel the
stickers off ~43 quintillion

So my fingers hurt from cubing and the colors on the cube all blend
together for me now so I thought I might take a good long cube
break. For the record, I almost made it the whole subway ride home
tonight without playing with the cube :)

Ian Winokur







1070. Re: [Speed cubing group] Toy Fair Story
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 15:58:41 -0800

Excellent TV solve! You looked calm and everything!

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1075. Any interest in replacement stickers?

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 01:16:21 -0000


Hello,

I am new to this group as well as speed cubing, but I have made my
own sets of stickers in sizes for all cubes. They are solid viynl
and computer plotted. I originaly made them for myself, but would
make more if there is interest. I have contacted Tyson to send him
a set to try out and give feedback.

LMK.

Jello33

1078. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 18:23:11 -0800 (PST)

hmmm...although i am from hong kong and born there, but i have a british passport and a pass to go into mainland china.*which is what 80% of the ppl in hk do to themselves. actualy i dont know much about it except that we dont call hong kong a country nor city, we call it the SAR....haha dont know what it means...haha but yea...so am i suppose to represent britain? actualy, nvm forget that. Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote:The issues start to become a lot more sensitive if you want to really get into it. Hong Kong was... now, correct my history lesson if I'm wrong, part of the British territories. China gave up Hong Kong to Britain for 99 years after the "Opium Wars" right? and it was in 1999 when Hong Kong was returned to China. In those 99 years, Hong Kong and China developed very differently. Now, technically they are "one country" but people from Hong Kong still identify themselves as from Hong Kong rather than from China. Some one better acquainted with this subject might want to jump in here. It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request. Does anyone know if the Hong Kong passport is different than the China passport? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 22, 2005, at 3:06 PM, Jo�l van Noort wrote: > Hmm.. > > I don't really know much about the relationship between Hong Kong > and China, but I do know that it's not really the same as 'two > different countries', like Spain and Mexico or something. But I > could be wrong about this... :).. > > Bye, > > Jo�l. --------------------------------- Yahoo! 1080. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Feb 2005 18:39:14 -0800 (PST)

actualy, i really want to represent hong kong, not china~ Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...> wrote: hmmm...although i am from hong kong and born there, but i have a british passport and a pass to go into mainland china.*which is what 80% of the ppl in hk do to themselves. actualy i dont know much about it except that we dont call hong kong a country nor city, we call it the SAR....haha dont know what it means...haha but yea...so am i suppose to represent britain? actualy, nvm forget that. Tyson Mao wrote:The issues start to become a lot more sensitive if you want to really get into it. Hong Kong was... now, correct my history lesson if I'm wrong, part of the British territories. China gave up Hong Kong to Britain for 99 years after the "Opium Wars" right? and it was in 1999 when Hong Kong was returned to China. In those 99 years, Hong Kong and China developed very differently. Now, technically they are "one country" but people from Hong Kong still identify themselves as from Hong Kong rather than from China. Some one better acquainted with this subject might want to jump in here. It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request. Does anyone know if the Hong Kong passport is different than the China passport? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 22, 2005, at 3:06 PM, Jo�l van Noort wrote: > Hmm.. > > I don't really know much about the relationship between Hong Kong > and China, but I do know that it's not really the same as 'two > different countries', like Spain and Mexico or something. But I > could be wrong about this... :).. > > Bye, > > Jo�l. --------------------------------- Yahoo! I think I could find some other cubers from Maryland. I know of at least 2 from thefacebook, and a handful of others who put "rubik's cube" somewhere in their profile. I think it would be awesome if there were a few from each group of 5 that weren't very fast. I think it would show the not-as-fast people that not everyone on the yahoo group is sub-30, but also show them that there is plenty of room to improve, and it would give them incentive to improve to help their school team. 1084. corners first
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 03:44:16 -0000


how effective are corners first methods? it seems really really
easy to solve by doing corners first. therefore, i made a beginner's
method that i will hopefully be posting on the web this weekend
(after exams and such :\). does anybody here use a CF method?

~bob

1086. Re: corners first
From: "Heath" <funny_guy32@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 04:22:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > how effective are corners first methods? it seems really really > easy to solve by doing corners first. therefore, i made a beginner's > method that i will hopefully be posting on the web this weekend > (after exams and such :\). does anybody here use a CF method? > > ~bob some corners first methods are very ineffective, others are very effective. To be effective, like in any other method, a corners first method has to cover many different possibilities and fit the person. I have a corners first method that I do, but its never been my fastest method. One thing i was wanting to work on, but never got around to doing it, is combining my method with corners first, using the idea to solve with which ever method best fits, and be able to combine both methods all the way through the solution....... -Heath

ever try something along those lines?

just a thought...

1090. Re: [Speed cubing group] Stickers
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 07:19:20 -0000


Is what you mean Nail Polish Protective Coat (Clear)? I have tried
that (I did that with the cube that I used at the Animal Planet
informal competition *I believe Tyson saw it since I think he asked
me whether it works well or not*). I do not recommend it since that
the clear layer will rub off and it'll start peeling and get messy
(like film sheets). However, I ALWAYS use it to protect my logo (I
don't know, I just like the logo's on the cubes xD), hope that helps~

~Joseph

http://jliao.tk

> Tyson Mao
> MSC #631
> California Institute of Technology

> > ever try something along those lines?

1091. [Speed cubing group] Re: Special Cubes???
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 07:26:54 -0000

LOL, I guess I have a weird story to tell (It's true). After I read the site on KY Lubricant being a good cube lube (I Think Thomas?), I asked my parents to take me to K-Mart (I've seen it there before) the next time we pass by. Well, I didn't exactly do much "research" before looking for it, and when I asked an employee to help me open the "cage" to the lubricant, and the employee stares at me and asks me what I'm using it for. It ended up being embarassing since the guy thought I was messing with him so I can use the lubricant for "real use." So I didn't buy any. I learned something from the experience...........Never buy anything that isn't normally used for your age group ;)~ Joseph ~ http://jliao.tk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Either that, or your girlfriend and you found a better use for the KY > jelly? One of these days, I'm going to walk into a pharmacy, buy a > tube of KY jelly, and then say, "It's for my Rubik's Cube." > > You know what, during the week, if I get a break from homework, I'm > going to do just that, and get Mark to film it or something. > > Yes, mark my words. (Haha... get it? Mark?) I will bring you all > entertainment via KY Jelly! > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 21, 2005, at 11:45 AM, Mike Bennett wrote: > > > Whatever you do, do NOT use KY jelly. It is my understanding that > > it's a petroleum product, like WD-40, and will eat the plastic that > > makes up your beloved cube. KY liquid is a reasonable alternative, > > and because it's water based, will not destroy plastic. > > Unfortunately, it wears off fairly quickly, is messy to apply, and > > makes the cube stick sometimes. My girlfriend and I have both > > attempted to lube our cubes with the liquid and have decided silicon > > is a much better alternative. On top of that, silicon is far less > > awkward to obtain, especially if you're a minor. That being said, it > > does make for much better stories. =) > > > > Mike Bennett

1094. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 08:21:43 -0000

Just for those who don't know. Hong Kong was leased from China to the UK on a 100 year lease and during this period had a British Governor and british passports. This expired in around 1999 I believe and the island was ceremoniously handed back to China. Given the very different cultures and socio-economic setups in mainland China and Hong Kong the Chinese gave certain assurances to Hong Kong that their more democratic way of life would be maintained although changes are/were inevitable. Many Hong Kong Chinese still have British passports but I'm not sure whether they are eligible to play sport for Britain - I guess they probably are! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Uwe Wong" <lilbeyond@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, February 23, 2005 2:39 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries actualy, i really want to represent hong kong, not china~ Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...> wrote: hmmm...although i am from hong kong and born there, but i have a british passport and a pass to go into mainland china.*which is what 80% of the ppl in hk do to themselves. actualy i dont know much about it except that we dont call hong kong a country nor city, we call it the SAR....haha dont know what it means...haha but yea...so am i suppose to represent britain? actualy, nvm forget that. Tyson Mao wrote:The issues start to become a lot more sensitive if you want to really get into it. Hong Kong was... now, correct my history lesson if I'm wrong, part of the British territories. China gave up Hong Kong to Britain for 99 years after the "Opium Wars" right? and it was in 1999 when Hong Kong was returned to China. In those 99 years, Hong Kong and China developed very differently. Now, technically they are "one country" but people from Hong Kong still identify themselves as from Hong Kong rather than from China. Some one better acquainted with this subject might want to jump in here. It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request. Does anyone know if the Hong Kong passport is different than the China passport? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 22, 2005, at 3:06 PM, Joï¿½l van Noort wrote: > Hmm.. > > I don't really know much about the relationship between Hong Kong > and China, but I do know that it's not really the same as 'two > different countries', like Spain and Mexico or something. But I > could be wrong about this... :).. > > Bye, > > Joï¿½l. --------------------------------- Yahoo! 1095. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 08:24:04 -0000

Oops ignore my bit on Hong Kong - I was reading through the threads and missed this one! ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, February 22, 2005 11:12 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries The issues start to become a lot more sensitive if you want to really get into it. Hong Kong was... now, correct my history lesson if I'm wrong, part of the British territories. China gave up Hong Kong to Britain for 99 years after the "Opium Wars" right? and it was in 1999 when Hong Kong was returned to China. In those 99 years, Hong Kong and China developed very differently. Now, technically they are "one country" but people from Hong Kong still identify themselves as from Hong Kong rather than from China. Some one better acquainted with this subject might want to jump in here. It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request. Does anyone know if the Hong Kong passport is different than the China passport? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 22, 2005, at 3:06 PM, Joï¿½l van Noort wrote: > Hmm.. > > I don't really know much about the relationship between Hong Kong > and China, but I do know that it's not really the same as 'two > different countries', like Spain and Mexico or something. But I > could be wrong about this... :).. > > Bye, > > Joï¿½l. Yahoo! Groups Links
1096. Re: Toy Fair Story
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 08:28:51 -0000

Hi! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Is it ok I dislike the way she says "how impressive" even more than > her "secret"? Non-cubing girls. Pah. Can't get any worse ;-) I thought the girl was really pretty. LOL :D -Per > > Nice solve, though, yes, especially since you're talking at the same > time and it's in front of a camera. But admit it, the cross had > already been solved, right? :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> > wrote: > > > > Hi Folks, > > > > On Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday, I helped showcase the Rubik's Cube > > at the Winning Moves booth at the annual toy fair at the Jacob > > Javits Center in New York. Basically I just solved the cube for > > anyone who walked by the booth. I had some TV stints on CBS, NBC, > > and a local station called New York 1. One of the clips is > > available at http://www.ny1.com/Living/home.html > > > > Right now the toy fair is the lead story...just click the video link > > below the title. The video requires Real Media Player. My part of > > the video is about 55 seconds in. I'll try to get copies of the > > other clips and post them someplace. > > > > I got to meet Dave Jones from Seventowns and he was really cool. I > > also met the world record holder for the Bedlam Cube. He puts it > > together in about 12 seconds. I think Macky (on the cube) could > > give him a run for his money. > > > > Here are some stats: > > > > # of 3x3x3s solved ~300 > > # of 4x4x4s solved ~10 > > # of 5x5x5s solved ~5 > > # of 5x5x5s popped 1 > > # of minutes to fix the pop ~20 > > # of people who claimed they used to be able to do the cube ~20 > > # of people who could actually solve the cube for me 2 > > # of people who told me that their method of solving was to peel the > > stickers off ~43 quintillion > > > > So my fingers hurt from cubing and the colors on the cube all blend > > together for me now so I thought I might take a good long cube > > break. For the record, I almost made it the whole subway ride home > > tonight without playing with the cube :) > > > > Ian Winokur

1098. Re: My course for beginners
From: "B" <vaafanculo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 15:25:00 -0000

Hey bro, I'm a total beginner. I can only solve one side. That's it. It's been that way for about 18 years. 3.5 years ago I suddenly got cube crazy. My roommates friend was visiting and solved the cube I had on the shelf. It took him about 3 minutes. I almost shit my pants. He gave me 2 minutes worth of instructions. I couldn't remember it so he wrote down all this code on a piece of paper. Didn't help. So I said screw it. Bout 2 years ago I decided I was gonna learn how to solve this S.O.B. Went on the internet. Went to all the sites, none of them helped. I read the instructions slowly. I still was blown away. I'm convinced that the only way to solve the cube is to have somebody actually show you in person. Like a Rubik's Cube coach or teacher. I challenge you and your tutorial. You can experiment on me. I have a college degree and am stumped by the rubik's cube. I'll go check out your website. If it doesn't help then I'm gonna hire someone, actually pay someone to teach me how to solve it. I'm tired of only being able to do one side. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hello everyone, > > > > I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on solving > Rubik's Cube. While there are many decent webpages detailing expert > solutions, there are none which really give a detailed account for beginners > (apart from Jasmine's wonderful beginner page which was the inspiration for > this tutorial). > > > > I would love it if a few of you could pretend to be beginners, or maybe some > real beginners will have a go too, and go through my solution and see if it > is readable. It was a lot of work making these notes, but I hope that they > will prove to be useful for beginners in the years to come :-) > > > > Like I said, they are almost complete, I have to add the finishing touches > still (there are always little things to change!) > > > > You can find the notes at http://www.cubestation.co.uk > <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the Link in the red panel > which says UEA Cube Club. > > > > Cheers! > > > > Dan Harris :-) > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

KY liquid is a reasonable > alternative, > > > and because it's water based, will not destroy plastic. > > > Unfortunately, it wears off fairly quickly, is messy to apply, > and > > > makes the cube stick sometimes. My girlfriend and I have both > > > attempted to lube our cubes with the liquid and have decided > silicon > > > is a much better alternative. On top of that, silicon is far > less > > > awkward to obtain, especially if you're a minor. That being > said, it > > > does make for much better stories. =) > > > > > > Mike Bennett

1101. Re: Stickers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

1102. Re: [Speed cubing group] Stickers
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 16:21:08 -0000


Yes, clear nail polish will prolong the life of the stickes as it
keeps the edges from peeling up. It does flake and rub off so you'll
need to keep applying it on a weekly basis.





1103. Re: My course for beginners
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 17:04:34 -0000

Hi B, There's only one thing that you need to know to solve the cube from that point. To make a change - you take something out of place one way, and put it back in place another way. Of course you need to pay attention to what happens to the remaining pieces when you do that. You might want to write down what you do as you go along. If you make a mistake and get lost - don't get discouraged, just try again. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "B" <vaafanculo@h...> wrote: > > Hey bro, > > I'm a total beginner. I can only solve one side. That's it. It's > been that way for about 18 years. 3.5 years ago I suddenly got cube > crazy. My roommates friend was visiting and solved the cube I had on > the shelf. It took him about 3 minutes. I almost shit my pants. He > gave me 2 minutes worth of instructions. I couldn't remember it so > he wrote down all this code on a piece of paper. Didn't help. > So I said screw it. Bout 2 years ago I decided I was gonna learn how > to solve this S.O.B. Went on the internet. Went to all the sites, > none of them helped. I read the instructions slowly. I still was > blown away. > > I'm convinced that the only way to solve the cube is to have somebody > actually show you in person. Like a Rubik's Cube coach or teacher. > > I challenge you and your tutorial. You can experiment on me. I have > a college degree and am stumped by the rubik's cube. I'll go check > out your website. If it doesn't help then I'm gonna hire someone, > actually pay someone to teach me how to solve it. I'm tired of only > being able to do one side. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hello everyone, > > > > > > > > I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on > solving > > Rubik's Cube. While there are many decent webpages detailing expert > > solutions, there are none which really give a detailed account for > beginners > > (apart from Jasmine's wonderful beginner page which was the > inspiration for > > this tutorial). > > > > > > > > I would love it if a few of you could pretend to be beginners, or > maybe some > > real beginners will have a go too, and go through my solution and > see if it > > is readable. It was a lot of work making these notes, but I hope > that they > > will prove to be useful for beginners in the years to come :-) > > > > > > > > Like I said, they are almost complete, I have to add the finishing > touches > > still (there are always little things to change!) > > > > > > > > You can find the notes at http://www.cubestation.co.uk > > <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and click on the Link in the red > panel > > which says UEA Cube Club. > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > Dan Harris :-) > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1108. [Speed cubing group] Re: My course for beginners
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 17:39:39 -0000

Tyson's right. anyone can figure it out how to solve it with enough time. I figured it out as well--it took patience, and a notebook, and i took my cube apart and put it back together many times when it got too messed up for me to figure out [now i hear you can go on the net and color a cube with your current position and it will show you how to solve it]. It took most of the summer between the 6th and 7th grades for me to learn to solve it and get down to about 2 minutes. I'm sure there are great beginner sites out there my quick tips--do one side first, but make sure the side stickers match up with the center squares they're touching. that's something a lot of beginners don't get that you can have a solid color on one side but still not have it correct. Learning that is a solid first step. then learn a simple sequence for inserting a side edge piece into the second layer. Practice those steps until you feel comfortable with them. then go on and learn some sequences for flipping the final corners to the right direction then place them in the right spot, and flipping the final edge pieces and placing them in the right spot. You can do that with only a few algorithms to learn. keep it up, you'll figure it out, and when you do, it's pretty amazing. [ of course then you'll just be back here trying to learn how to do it in under 20 seconds...] good luck --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > That can't be true. Someone had to first learn how to solve it > somewhere or another? My friend actually figured it out himself. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 23, 2005, at 7:25 AM, B wrote: > > > I'm convinced that the only way to solve the cube is to have somebody > > actually show you in person. Like a Rubik's Cube coach or teacher.

1112. Re: Toy Fair Story
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 18:31:26 -0000

Ok...time to fess up. Not that I wasn't expecting you guys to catch me. Before they started filming, I told Jill it would take me about 25 seconds. She said she needed it in 15. No problem for Macky but I decided to start with the cross and first F2L pair done. Outside of that "minor" cheating, the solve was real. The OLL wasn't skipped, Tyson...it was the one where all pieces need to be flipped up and there are two solid bars (of yellow) on opposite sides of the last layer. We actually filmed two solves...I think the other one was a bit faster. The witty repartee between us was identical for both clips. I also showed her how to do the first layer of a 2x2. She was really into it and I was thinking of asking for her number but I thought my wife might protest...especially since it was on tape. I wasn't nervous but I did do the OLL slowly to make sure I didn't mess it up. I heard that MSNBC did a 3 second clip last night where it was me solving the cube and Keith Oberman calling cubers a bunch of nerds. I haven't seen it but I'm still offended. Don't we prefer the term 'geeks'? David: Thanks for the compliment. I'm trying to emulate Ron's style in terms of solving slowly but fluidly. I'm not sure where my finger tricks came from...partly from Dan Harris, Chris Hardwick, and Ron. I'll start speeding up once my mind becomes better at following the pieces but for now I'm content to turn the faces slowly while trying to minimize delays. Ian --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" < d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Ian, > > Your style of solving looks very clean and efficient. ITs similar > to Gilles second half. One of the clips is > > available at http://www.ny1.com/Living/home.html > > > > Right now the toy fair is the lead story...just click the video link > > below the title. The video requires Real Media Player. My part of > > the video is about 55 seconds in. I'll try to get copies of the > > other clips and post them someplace. > > > > I got to meet Dave Jones from Seventowns and he was really cool. 1115. Re: [Speed cubing group] N x N x N cube
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 10:54:23 -0800 (PST)

Hi, I was wondering how you did this...like formula, etc. And if a formula, how did you derive it? thanks -Brent rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@...> wrote: I wrote a program in Java that takes an input N (2-100) and computes and returns the number of combinations to an NxNxN cube. Anybody who has Java installed on their computer and want it may download it at www.cubewhiz.com/nxnxn.zip Just extract the two .class files into the same directory. :) ~bob --------------------------------- Yahoo! 1116. Re: A 5x5x5 and a Megaminx
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 19:28:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > 1. Has anyone else bought their 5x5x5´s or Megaminx from mefferts? Yes. I got two tiled 5x5 (one a few months back, the other three days ago), one tiled megaminx and two stickered megaminxs (though I bought them in stores in England last year but they're meffert). Two more tiled megaminx are on the way. The stickered megaminxs are perfectly ok, too. The only thing I didn't like was that they were 6-colored only, so I made them 12-colored myself. I simply love my tiled megaminx, though I replaced its springs first. See also this thread over at twistypuzzles: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3488 > 2. They both come tiled, good or bad? Good. Of course that's my personal opinion. I like the look, I like the feel, and I think it's good for looking ahead because you can slightly look "around" edges. Lots of the tiles on my first 5x5 though weren't glued good enough and fell off so I had to glue them back on. But the new one seems very good and not have this problem. > 3. Is the 5x5x5 an eastsheen, what about the Megaminx? The tiled 5x5 are *not* eastsheen, the smaller stickered 5x5 are. The tiled ones actually use the same mechanism as the Rubik ones and they have the additional advantage of having screws so you can adjust the tension. Megaminx has nothing to do with eastsheen. I think Meffert has the exclusive rights to the Megaminx and is the only producer. > 4. Is the prize okey (28$ and free shipping)? It is *very* ok. Cheers! Stefan
1117. Re: [Speed cubing group] A 5x5x5 and a Megaminx
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 19:30:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Kyle Bryant <craptastic_crap@y...> wrote: > the 5x5x5 is mint, but the megaminx from mefferts if > not tiled is really bad. Can you tell what's so bad about the non-tiled megaminx? A friend of mine got one and I think it's alright. Cheers! Stefan
1118. Re: Stickers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 19:38:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > From that site, looks like you were experimenting last summer. are > you still using that cyanacrylat-based superglue, and is it still > working ok? It is still working perfectly, though I haven't played with my super 5x5 so much. But I've also protected a normal 5x5 like this and used it quite a bit and it's still perfectly sealed. But I admit it's also quite a bit of work to do this so I haven't done it with other cubes yet. I planned to do it with several more 5x5s but if I can get good vinyl sticker sets for $1 or so then I'll prefer those. Also, I don't think I'd use it for normal sized 3x3 because it seems harder to get right the bigger the to-be-protected stickers are. Bottom line - I love it (perfect protection, nice touch/look), but it's not worth it for normal puzzles. However I would certainly do it again if I made another "super" puzzle like that, in order to protect the then very little sticker parts. Cheers! Stefan
1119. [Speed cubing group] Re: Toy Fair Story
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 19:42:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Is it wrong that I feel like smacking her from the > > time she says "You know what MY secret is?" until the > > end of that segment? > > I bet she hasn't even tried to remove the stickers and solve the cube, > she just thinks she's being witty. AARG! Wow, I never even thought about that possibility. But looking at it from a non-cuber point-of-view, it may be very reasonably to think it's funny and even pretend to be that "cool". Well, since the majority of viewers are probably non-cubers, maybe this is actually positive advertisement for our sport. It's a strange world, out there. Cheers! Stefan
1120. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Toy Fair Story
From: Kyle Bryant <craptastic_crap@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 12:00:40 -0800 (PST)

I think the sad part is that EVERYONE thinks it's witty. If someone said it in monotone and actually meant it, I'd be like..damn, what a frustrated person. But when it's Every person that sees me solve coining the same joke over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again and EVERYONE assuming that it's the funniest thing you've ever heard because it is UBER WITTY gets REALLY ANNOYING. [/rant] -K- --- burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > Is it wrong that I feel like smacking her from the > > time she says "You know what MY secret is?" until > the > > end of that segment? > > No, I actually cursed out loud and punched my > monitor. > > I bet she hasn't even tried to remove the stickers > and solve the cube, > she just thinks she's being witty. AARG! > > -Chris > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Mail - You care about security. So do we. http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail

1122. Re: [Speed cubing group] Stickers
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 21:00:13 -0000

I have done so with (reaches for bottle) "OPI Rapid Dry Top Coat". It worked pretty well for me. You do have to reapply it fairly often if you solve regularly like most of us here. I am going to the vinyl stickers from jello( jellomods@... ). I have yet to find out the price though. i am waiting on an email now. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@y...> wrote: > > Is what you mean Nail Polish Protective Coat (Clear)? I have tried > that (I did that with the cube that I used at the Animal Planet > informal competition *I believe Tyson saw it since I think he asked > me whether it works well or not*). I do not recommend it since that > the clear layer will rub off and it'll start peeling and get messy > (like film sheets). However, I ALWAYS use it to protect my logo (I > don't know, I just like the logo's on the cubes xD), hope that helps~ > > ~Joseph > > http://jliao.tk > > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 22, 2005, at 8:36 PM, kirk83616 wrote: > > > > > I had a random thought about all the talk about stickers--would > it > > > be possible to coat the stickers with a sealant of some kind? > e.g., > > > what about applying some clear finger nail polish over them? > anyone > > > ever try something along those lines? > > > > > > just a thought... > > > --Kirk

1125. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My course for beginners
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 17:38:07 -0800

well two things 1) you dont have to pay anyone, if you just came to one of the events, im sure someone would love to teach you, i know i like teaching as many people as i can, i'd gladly teach you if you came to an event 2) yes it helps alot to have someone teach you, but it deffinately isnt necisary(sp). Although i didnt figure out how to solve it on my own :-( i did read a website or two and i could figure it out, the hardest part, for me at least, was understanding what an edge was, what a corner was, what it means to turn a specified face. I tried to fix that in my beginner solution(at http://www.deepcube.tk ), and put what i beleive to be a fairly in depth introduction to the cube itself. So i hope something works for you, and if not, stop by an event and im sure someone would teach you -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Wed, 23 Feb 2005 17:39:39 -0000, kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Tyson's right. anyone can figure it out how to solve it with enough > time. I figured it out as well--it took patience, and a notebook, > and i took my cube apart and put it back together many times when it > got too messed up for me to figure out [now i hear you can go on the > net and color a cube with your current position and it will show you > how to solve it]. It took most of the summer between the 6th and > 7th grades for me to learn to solve it and get down to about 2 > minutes. > > I'm sure there are great beginner sites out there > my quick tips--do one side first, but make sure the side stickers > match up with the center squares they're touching. that's something > a lot of beginners don't get that you can have a solid color on one > side but still not have it correct. Learning that is a solid first > step. > > then learn a simple sequence for inserting a side edge piece into > the second layer. > > Practice those steps until you feel comfortable with them. then go > on and learn some sequences for flipping the final corners to the > right direction then place them in the right spot, and flipping the > final edge pieces and placing them in the right spot. > > You can do that with only a few algorithms to learn. > > keep it up, you'll figure it out, and when you do, it's pretty > amazing. [ of course then you'll just be back here trying to learn > how to do it in under 20 seconds...] > good luck > --Kirk > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > That can't be true. Someone had to first learn how to solve it > > somewhere or another? My friend actually figured it out himself. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 23, 2005, at 7:25 AM, B wrote: > > > > > I'm convinced that the only way to solve the cube is to have > somebody > > > actually show you in person. Like a Rubik's Cube coach or > teacher. > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
1126. [Speed cubing group] Re: My course for beginners
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 01:55:37 -0000

i can actually speed solve (30-40 seconds) using the method i originally learned on: the stupid one in that booklet that comes with the cube. obviously, nobody showed taught me how to solve it that way because it's a pretty terrible solution. indeed, it is not necessary for somebody to actually teach you how to solve the cube, but it certainl helps. :) ~bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > well two things > > 1) you dont have to pay anyone, if you just came to one of the events, > im sure someone would love to teach you, i know i like teaching as > many people as i can, i'd gladly teach you if you came to an event > > 2) yes it helps alot to have someone teach you, but it deffinately > isnt necisary(sp). > Although i didnt figure out how to solve it on my own :-( i did read a > website or two and i could figure it out, the hardest part, for me at > least, was understanding what an edge was, what a corner was, what it > means to turn a specified face. I tried to fix that in my beginner > solution(at http://www.deepcube.tk ), and put what i beleive to be a > fairly in depth introduction to the cube itself. > > So i hope something works for you, and if not, stop by an event and im > sure someone would teach you > > -Evan > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk > > On Wed, 23 Feb 2005 17:39:39 -0000, kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > > Tyson's right. anyone can figure it out how to solve it with enough > > time. I figured it out as well--it took patience, and a notebook, > > and i took my cube apart and put it back together many times when it > > got too messed up for me to figure out [now i hear you can go on the > > net and color a cube with your current position and it will show you > > how to solve it]. It took most of the summer between the 6th and > > 7th grades for me to learn to solve it and get down to about 2 > > minutes. > > > > I'm sure there are great beginner sites out there > > my quick tips--do one side first, but make sure the side stickers > > match up with the center squares they're touching. that's something > > a lot of beginners don't get that you can have a solid color on one > > side but still not have it correct. Learning that is a solid first > > step. > > > > then learn a simple sequence for inserting a side edge piece into > > the second layer. > > > > Practice those steps until you feel comfortable with them. then go > > on and learn some sequences for flipping the final corners to the > > right direction then place them in the right spot, and flipping the > > final edge pieces and placing them in the right spot. > > > > You can do that with only a few algorithms to learn. > > > > keep it up, you'll figure it out, and when you do, it's pretty > > amazing. [ of course then you'll just be back here trying to learn > > how to do it in under 20 seconds...] > > good luck > > --Kirk > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > > > wrote: > > > That can't be true. 1127. [Speed cubing group] Re: Toy Fair Story
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 01:56:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Is it wrong that I feel like smacking her from the > > time she says "You know what MY secret is?" until the > > end of that segment? > > No, I actually cursed out loud and punched my monitor. > > I bet she hasn't even tried to remove the stickers and solve the cube, > she just thinks she's being witty. AARG! > > -Chris Yet another... "When all else fails, and no one else is looking, puzzlers have been known to cheat by peeling off the colored stickers and rearranging them. Sounds like a solution to us." (from the article linked to by speedcubing.com) I'm wondering what's the best way to react. Best, i.e. not necessarily what I'd intuitively would like to do. Best as in "make everyone happy". Maybe Ian's reaction is the way to go, lets them think they indeed said something funny but also underlines our superiority... Cheers! Stefan
1128. Re: [Speed cubing group] N x N x N cube
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 02:29:35 -0000

I coded it mostly using the BigInteger feature of Java. I used a variation of Richard Carr's and Chris Hardwick's formulae, modified to make the coding more efficient. The code for the program was pretty simple and straight-forward, though:- import java.math.BigInteger; public class Cube { public static void main(String[] args) { int x = IO.readInteger(); if (x < 2 || x > 100) { System.out.println("Be realistic!"); } else { BigInteger n = new BigInteger(String.valueOf(x)); BigInteger odd1 = new BigInteger("282526639718400"); BigInteger odd = odd1.pow(x%2); BigInteger a = odd.multiply(new BigInteger("3674160")); BigInteger b = new BigInteger ("620448401733239439360000"); BigInteger c = b.pow((x*x-2*x)/4); BigInteger num = a.multiply(c); BigInteger fourfact = new BigInteger("24"); BigInteger denom = fourfact.pow(6*((x-2)*(x-2))/4); BigInteger result = num.divide(denom); if (x == 2) { System.out.println("There are "+result+" combinations."); } else { String big = ""+result; String first = big.substring(0,1); String second = big.substring(1); int digits = second.length(); second = big.substring(1,5); String small = first+"."+second+" x 10^"+digits; System.out.println("There are approximately "+small+" combinations."); } } } } I used an IO module from lecture to receive the input because I don't know how to code that part myself. ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > Hi, > I was wondering how you did this...like formula, etc. And if a formula, how did you derive it? thanks > -Brent > > rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I wrote a program in Java that takes an input N (2-100) and computes > and returns the number of combinations to an NxNxN cube. Anybody > who has Java installed on their computer and want it may download it > at www.cubewhiz.com/nxnxn.zip > > Just extract the two .class files into the same directory. :) > > ~bob > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > > :) > --Brent > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1132. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rules clarification
From: "Lars Petrus" <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 06:42:32 -0000

I took a picture: http://lar5.com/stackmat.jpg I hope it's clear what's going on. You can obviously do the same thing in a less demonstrative way. If anyone could seriously pull it off in a competition is of course an other question, but it wouldn't surprise me at all. Cubers can be very capable with their hands. OT: I regularly meet Hong Kong people, and I've yet to hear a good thing about Chinese rule. They just traded one colonial master for a considerably nastier one. /Lars --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Lars, > > I'm having difficulty picturing this in my head exactly how one would > go about doing this. Maybe I'm just not sneaky enough? Could you > describe it? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 22, 2005, at 9:34 AM, Lars Petrus wrote: > > > It's actually quite easy to keep your palms on the timer and solve the > > entire cube without starting it, alternately stopping it early and keep > > solving. > > > > You'd need a rule saying that the cube needs to be put down a certain > > distance from the sensors, both before and after the solve, to make > > sure it can't happen. > > > > If a moderately talented illusionist practiced it, I expect they could > > trim a second or two off on a way that most judges wouldn't notice. > > > > /Lars
1133. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rules clarification
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Feb 2005 23:11:06 -0800

Hi Lars,

You need to start with the palms flat on the sensors. In order to get
that position from a palms-down starting position, it would be
necessary to do a weird sliding of the hands...

I'll see if I can pull that off. Let me know if you guys can pull it
off as well.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 23, 2005, at 10:42 PM, Lars Petrus wrote:

1134. Re: Rules clarification
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 08:01:12 -0000


>Let me know if you guys can pull it off as well.

I just did a whole solve and placed my hands flat again without
starting the timer at all. I don't see how this can help anyone
though, it was slow to solve without moving my palms.

-Chris

Let me know if you guys can pull > it > > off as well. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 23, 2005, at 10:42 PM, Lars Petrus wrote: > > > > > I took a picture: http://lar5.com/stackmat.jpg > > > > > > I hope it's clear what's going on. You can obviously do the same > thing > > > in a less demonstrative way. If anyone could seriously pull it > off in > > > a competition is of course an other question, but it wouldn't > surprise > > > me at all. Cubers can be very capable with their hands. > > > > > > > > > OT: I regularly meet Hong Kong people, and I've yet to hear a > good > > > thing about Chinese rule. They just traded one colonial master > for a > > > considerably nastier one. > > > > > > /Lars

1138. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rules clarification
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>

this is a reply to the entire thread Are that many people trying to cheat the system? I have not been to a tourny yet so I guess it is possible that many people try to cheat?? if so just make one simple rules. The judges rules are above all else. From an illusionist stand point this cheat will not work without being seen unless absolutely no one is paying attention to the fact that the timer isn't moving. To do the move for this cheat would require alot of foresight and practice. most of which we all do practicing cubing. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > New discipline: Telekinecubing. > I suggest the records to belong to the "fun" category. > > Gilles. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey! > > > > With palms flat and the cube placed at least say 20 cm away from the > > sensors i can't see how it's possible to make any turns on the cube. > > Unless using ur nose or something. 1140. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubik's Cube Test

[.] how to solve the Cube [.] in less than a minute [] 5+ ways [] in less than 20 seconds [.] in less than 65 moves [.] what OLL stands for [.] what BYO stands for [.] what ZB stands for [] what AUF stands for [.] what BLD stands for [.] who Erno Rubik is [.] who Uwe Meffert is [] who Terutoshi Ishige is [.] who Shotaro Makisumi is [.] what the WCA is [] and am in it [] and have a high-up position I have... 1142. Super-supercube math stuff
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 22:12:10 -0000


Hey everyone,

I just worked out a proof by induction to the least clear exponent of
my formula for the number of combinations to the nxnxn
super-supercube. The exponent is the one to the term (24!/2). I
realized that I never really explained what that exponent counts, or
even that it is accurate, so here is the proof.

For those math people out there, do you think this is
interesting/important enough to include on combinations page? I'm
thinking about putting it in just for completeness.

Anyway, just in case anyone is interested here is the proof.
---------
I'll do this in 2 cases, the first where n is odd, and the second
where n is even.

Case 1: Let n only be an odd number (so I'm only dealing with odd
sized super-supercubes)

The exponent of (24!/2) on my page for odd cubes is (n^3-13n+12)/24
This counts the total number of 24 piece center and edge piece orbits
(including all levels inside the cube as well).

So first we have to see that it is true for some case, let's do n=5

(5^3-13*5+12)/24 = 3 and there are 2 24 piece center orbits and 1 24
piece edge orbit on the 5x5x5 supercube (none on the 3x3 obviously) so
this is right.

So assuming (n^3-13n+12)/24 is true for some case n, we add the number
of 24 piece orbits on the next level (n+2) odd cube and see if we can
reconcile this to ((n+2)^3-13(n+2)+12)/24

number of oribts (centers and edges) on an odd degree cube (not
super-supercube):
(n^2-2n-3)/4

And now here's the proof:
(n^3-13n+12)/24 + [(n+2)^2-2(n+2)-3]/4
[n^3-13n+12+6((n+2)^2-2n-7)]/24
(n^3-13n+12+6n^2+12n-18)/24
[(n^3+6n^2+12n+8)-13n-14)]/24
[(n+2)^3-13(n+2)+12]/24

And so by induction this counts the total number of 24 piece center
and edge orbits on an odd nxnxn super-supercube.

Also for the verifying case right at the beginning you can start with
n=3 (the smallest possible) and the exponent will be 0, which is
correct. And by induction the formula works from n=3,5,7,9,...

----

Case 2: Let n be even (so we're dealing only with even super-supercube).

The exponent of (24!/2) on my page for even cubes is (n^3-4n)/24 This
counts the total number of 24 piece center and edge piece orbits
(including all levels inside the cube).

So first we have to see that it is true for some case, let's do n=4

(4^3-4*4)/24 = 2

So assuming (n^3-4n)/24 is true for some case n, we add the number of
24 piece oribts on the next level (n+2) even cube and see if we can
reconcile this to ((n+2)^3-4(n+2))/24

number of oribts on an odd degree cube (not the super-supercube):
(n^2-2n)/4

And now here's the proof:
(n^3-4n)/24 + [(n+2)^2-2(n+2)]/4
[n^3-4n+6((n+2)^2-2n-4)]/24
(n^3-4n+6n^2+12n)/24
[(n^3+6n^2+12n+8)-4n-8]/24
[(n+2)^3-4(n+2)]/24

And so by induction this counts the total number of 24 piece center
and edge orbits on an even nxnxn super-supercube.

Also for the first test case we can use n=2 instead of n=4, and we get
0 (which is correct) and thus this exponent counts the number of
oribts for the super-supercubes n=2,4,6,8,...

-------------------------

Also the formula on my page is written (n^3-4n+(n mod 2)(-9n+12))/24
which is easy to see is just a combination of the two to make it
easier to write both.

So in case anyone was curious where that came from, or whether it was
correct or not, there's the proof for why I use that particular exponent.

For you math people, do you think it's necessary to include this proof
on the page with the formulas? Does it seem like something that would
be worth reading?

Chris

1144. Re: My course for beginners
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 23:14:04 -0000

I originaly learned to solve the cube from the solution in the booklet that came with it. (BTW i recently bought a new cube, last summer, the new booklets are different, i tried the solution and could not get it to work) If you would like, i could get the booklet and scan the pages and send them to you. Or better yet, give me a couple of days, and i can write you a tutorial from these moves that will have you solving your cube easy. With the old booklet and a lot of practice, it could solve the cube in under 3 min on average, but i wanted to be faster, so i found a speedcubing solution. It took about 4 hours the first time, but i got it. I currently average aroung 77 sec on this method (a thank you to Gilles Roux). Give me about 4-5 days and it will create an html file w/ pics that will show you a very easy way to solve the cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "B" <vaafanculo@h...> wrote: > > Hey bro, > > I'm a total beginner. I can only solve one side. That's it. It's > been that way for about 18 years. 3.5 years ago I suddenly got cube > crazy. My roommates friend was visiting and solved the cube I had on > the shelf. It took him about 3 minutes. I almost shit my pants. He > gave me 2 minutes worth of instructions. I couldn't remember it so > he wrote down all this code on a piece of paper. Didn't help. > So I said screw it. Bout 2 years ago I decided I was gonna learn how > to solve this S.O.B. Went on the internet. Went to all the sites, > none of them helped. I read the instructions slowly. I still was > blown away. > > I'm convinced that the only way to solve the cube is to have somebody > actually show you in person. Like a Rubik's Cube coach or teacher. > > I challenge you and your tutorial. You can experiment on me. I have > a college degree and am stumped by the rubik's cube. I'll go check > out your website. If it doesn't help then I'm gonna hire someone, > actually pay someone to teach me how to solve it. I'm tired of only > being able to do one side. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hello everyone, > > > > > > > > I have almost written all the notes for my Beginners Tutorial on > solving > > Rubik's Cube. 1146. Rubik's Cube Test: Supplement 1
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 00:19:48 -0000


I can solve the cube...
[] with thick gloves
[] on a keychain cube
[] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded]
[] in one breath
[] above my head
[] in front of a crowd
[] and teach others to solve it
[] and do so more than a hundred times a day
[] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes
[] on the computer
[] on a "flat cube" on the computer
[] in my head
[] to any possible pattern
[] by telling someone what moves to make
[] by doing the moves someone tells me to make
[] with one hand
[] with either hand
[] with one in each hand simultaneously
[] with chopsticks
[] taking account of center rotations
[] while juggling
[] while talking
[] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano)
[] choosing one side to never twist
[] in the 2-generator subgroup
[] in the half-turn subgroup
[] in the antislice subgroup
[] while drunk (or high)

Come on! I need suggestions! You can't just take unmodified the word
of someone who knows six LL algs!

1148. Re: Rubik's Cube Test
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 02:01:19 -0000


I can solve the cube...
[y] with thick gloves
[y] on a keychain cube
[] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded]
[y] in one breath
[y] above my head
[y] in front of a crowd
[y] and teach others to solve it
[y] and do so more than a hundred times a day
[y] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes
[y] on the computer
[y] on a "flat cube" on the computer
[y] in my head
[y] to any possible pattern
[y] by telling someone what moves to make
[y] by doing the moves someone tells me to make
[y] with one hand
[y] with either hand
[y] with one in each hand simultaneously
[y] with chopsticks
[] taking account of center rotations
[] while juggling
[y] while talking
[] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano)
[y] choosing one side to never twist
[] in the 2-generator subgroup
[y] in the half-turn subgroup
[] in the antislice subgroup
[y] while drunk (or high)

> > Rubik's Cube Test
> >
> > I know...
> > [y] how to solve the Cube
> > [y] in less than a minute
> > [] 5+ ways
> > [] in less than 20 seconds
> > [y] in less than 65 moves

> > [y] who Uwe Meffert is
> > [y] who Terutoshi Ishige is

> > [] and am in it
> > [] and have a high-up position

> > I have...
> > [y] a Rubik's Cube
> > [y] 5+ Cubes

> > [] 25+ different Cubes
> > [y] a 4x4x4
> > [y] and can solve it
> > [] in less than two minutes
> > [y] a 5x5x5
> > [y] and can solve it
> > [] in less than three minutes
> > [y] cube lubrication
> > [y] 3 kinds or more
> > [] a Megaminx
> > [y] a Square-1
> > [] and can solve it in less than a minute
> > [] a Dogic
> > [] more than one kind
> > [] made my own kind
> > [] a nontrivial cube mod
> > [] that Tony Fisher made
> > [] that I made
> > [y] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise
> > [y] knockoff Cubes
> > [y] just because they're Cubes
> > [y] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles
> > [] which is famous
> > [] won in a championship
> > [] a WR
> > [] more than one WR
> >
> > I know... [2]
> > [y] more than ten algorithms
> > [] 100 algorithms
> > [] the entire ZB method
> > [] all 1211 LL algorithms
> > [][][] Erno Rubik
> > [y] how to disassemble a Cube
> > [y] without breaking it
> > [y] including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5
> > [] including an Eastsheen 2x2x2
> > [] how to solve the Rubik's Magic
> > [] in less than three seconds
> > [y] what the Superflip is
> > [] an optimal solution
> > [] all optimal solutions
> > [y] more than 5 pretty patterns by heart
> > [] more than 10
> > [] more than 50
> > [] what a supercube group is
> >
> > I like...
> > [y] to solve the Cube
> > [y] even in the bathroom
> > [y] underwater
> > [y] during meals
> > [y] in my dreams
> > [y] hanging around in cubing forums
> > [y] to take twisty puzzles apart
> > [] and make other things out of them





1149. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 24-Hour Cube marathon
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 24 Feb 2005 18:00:36 -0800 (PST)

I agree. Some sort of criteria should be set. I figured this comfortable pace for myself: 100 cubes in 50 minutes, and a 10 minute break on every hour. And then perhaps a few 20-30 minute breaks for lunch and dinner. Just my 2 cents -Richard --- Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > So... my thoughts on the 24-hour cube marathon. I > myself really do > want to make an attempt at this and I'll do it when > I have time and > when I can find a good venue with some publicity. > If there is someone > out there who wants to try it and you're really > serious about it, I'd > like to propose some audition criteria. I'm not > going to gather a team > to scramble cubes for you for 24 hours if you don't > have a reasonable > chance of breaking that record. Therefore, I really > recommend that you > solve 120 cubes in an hour before you even think > about anything else. > > Sure, 120 cubes in an hour is well over the pace > necessary to do 2000 > in 24 but when you count in fatigue, yeah, you'll be > "crawling" at hour > 18. Not to mention bathroom breaks. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 22, 2005, at 4:33 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > Yeah, I agree too :-) > > > > Though I'd like to mention this page which also > collects/summarizes > > our official records: > > http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html > > > > I think at least many of those records also made > it into this "book of > > alternative records": > > http://www.alternativerecords.co.uk/ > > > > I think Ralf Laue is involved in both the webpage > and the book and > > he's a cuber himself, which is obviously a good > sign :-) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Mail - Easier than ever with enhanced search. Learn more. http://info.mail.yahoo.com/mail_250

[x] without breaking it

[] in less than three seconds
[x] what the Superflip is
[x] an optimal solution
[] all optimal solutions
[x] more than 5 pretty patterns by heart
[x] more than 10
[] more than 50
[x] what a supercube group is

[x] to solve the Cube
[x] even in the bathroom
[x] underwater
[x] during meals
[x] in my dreams

[] and make other things out of them

[x] with thick gloves [x] on a keychain cube [x] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded] [] in one breath [x] above my head [x] in front of a crowd [x] and teach others to solve it [x] and do so more than a hundred times a day [] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes [x] on the computer [x] on a "flat cube" on the computer [] in my head [x] to any possible pattern [x] by telling someone what moves to make [x] by doing the moves someone tells me to make [x] with one hand [x] with either hand [] with one in each hand simultaneously [x] with chopsticks [x] taking account of center rotations [x] while juggling [x] while talking [] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano) [x] choosing one side to never twist [x] in the 2-generator subgroup [x] in the half-turn subgroup [] in the antislice subgroup [] while drunk (or high) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > What does "AUF" stand for? You can e-mail me personally if you don't > want to spoil it for the group. I'm serious though, I have absolutely > no idea. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Alan C." > <cub3r_alan@s...> wrote: > > > [] what AUF stands for
1156. Re: Countries
From: ralf_laue <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 09:55:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/rubik.html > > What's going on here? There's this site and they're posting up the > WCA's recognized records, and what are they doing? I'm upset because > they have listed Chun Hei as being from China instead of being from > Hong Kong. Dear Tyson, as you certainly know, Hong Kong is a Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. I have changed the entry in the list anyway, because in other sports Hong Kong did also compete as a separate team. (In the 2004 Olympics the team was called "Hong Kong, China"). In general, I believe that it is the best policy to associate the name of the country as recognized by the UN. (Hong Kong may be a special case, I agree that it is a good idea to follow the policy of the IOC). In another e-mail you write: "It is of my opinion that if someone says they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request." My advice is to be careful with this. What will be your decision if someone says: - I want to represent Montenegro, not "Serbia and Montenegro" - I want to represent Quebec, not Canada etc.? > My feeling is if you're going to post our records, you need to post > our records without altering them. I do not post "your records", I post the best results reported from Rubik's cube events. I did so long before WCA existed. Well, I think that I will stop updating the "sub-20" list somewhen in the future and just publish record progress lists, because all the information is available at speedcubing.com as well. (It would be a good idea to include a all-time ranking there.) Final remark: If you are upset about something on a web site, it is usually a good idea to contact the maintainer of this site instead of complaining in a mailing list. Ralf Laue
1157. Re: Rubik's Cube Test
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>

Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 09:56:42 -0000


Hey!

Here are the votes of the Norwegian Jury. Yes i know this is NOT the
Eurovision Song Contest ;-)

(i scored 47 out of 72 -> cubegeek-score = 65.28%)

Have fun :D

-Per

Rubik's Cube Test

I know...
[*] how to solve the Cube
[*] in less than a minute
[*] 5+ ways
[] in less than 20 seconds
[*] in less than 65 moves
[*] what OLL stands for
[*] what BYO stands for (or BOY ... lol)
[*] what ZB stands for (it's not Zen Buddhism ... haha)
[] what AUF stands for
[*] what BLD stands for
[*] who Erno Rubik is
[*] who Uwe Meffert is
[*] who Terutoshi Ishige is
[*] who Shotaro Makisumi is
[*] what the WCA is
[] and am in it
[] and have a high-up position

I have...
[*] a Rubik's Cube
[*] 5+ Cubes
[*] 25+ Cubes (cubes > twisting puzzles)
[] 25+ different Cubes (cubes > twisting puzzles)
[*] a 4x4x4
[*] and can solve it
[*] in less than two minutes
[*] a 5x5x5
[*] and can solve it
[*] in less than three minutes
[*] cube lubrication
[] 3 kinds or more
[*] a Megaminx
[] a Square-1
[] and can solve it in less than a minute
[] a Dogic
[] more than one kind
[] made my own kind
[] a nontrivial cube mod
[] that Tony Fisher made
[*] that I made
[] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise
[*] knockoff Cubes
[*] just because they're Cubes
[*] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles
[] which is famous
[] won in a championship
[*] a WR
[] more than one WR

I know... [2]
[*] more than ten algorithms
[] 100 algorithms
[] the entire ZB method
[] all 1211 LL algorithms
[*][][] Erno Rubik
[*] how to disassemble a Cube
[*] without breaking it
[*] including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 (both rubiks.com and eastsheen)
[*] including an Eastsheen 2x2x2
[*] how to solve the Rubik's Magic
[] in less than three seconds
[*] what the Superflip is
[*] an optimal solution
[] all optimal solutions (gods algorithm)
[*] more than 5 pretty patterns by heart
[*] more than 10
[] more than 50 (i did before i guess, not now)
[*] what a supercube group is (and super-supercube, cause i
invented it(

I like...
[*] to solve the Cube
[*] even in the bathroom
[] underwater
[*] during meals
[*] in my dreams
[*] hanging around in cubing forums
[*] to take twisty puzzles apart
[*] and make other things out of them





1158. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Countries
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 03:48:53 -0800

Dear Ralf,

I understand I should be careful and I said that we should honor the
request for Hong Kong because it is Hong Kong and not just any area in
the world. Hong Kong, as you said, has its own sports team in the
Olympics. Not that the IOC is what we base things on, but it gives us
an idea that even though Hong Kong is now a part of China, there are
other organizations in this world which believes it still warrants its
own team.

My main issue with this is that whereas it is true you are posting
sub-20 times achieved in Rubik's Cube events and you have done so
before the WCA was created, records obtained at WCA tournaments should
be on some level considered property of the WCA. Changing what we list
as a 'country' or 'representative region' is no different than changing
the time itself. It is misrepresenting the nature of the record
itself. Of course, more people would complain if the time were
changed, but I feel the need that what we write is not altered. It
would have been nice for someone to tell us that they were going to
list it as "China" before doing so. You raise a very sensitive issue
by changing "Hong Kong" to "China" and to disagree with what was
originally set can only bring about political conflict which has no
place in the cubing world.

I want to represent Quebec and not Canada is not the same type of
argument as Hong Kong vs. China. It is necessary to consider the
viewpoints and political situations of the parts of the world which we
deal with, and in the case of the WCA, it is an international
phenomenon. Tensions are very high between different places in certain
parts of the world. It is very difficult to keep everyone happy and by
no means possible. However, by changing "Hong Kong" to "China", you
risk insulting many people who have strong political beliefs about the
subject. We, of course, entertain the possibility of keeping it as
"China" as opposed to "Hong Kong". However, this issue was not raised
to us prior to the posting on your website.

I believe that we have the foremost authority in the events we hold.
Unfortunately, this is not obvious to the world currently because we
lack certain resources to manage everything. Therefore, in order to
preserve the unity of the cubing community, I ask that information that
we post is kept as it is for consistency and uniformity. If we had a
professional website, which I know we will soon, I would not care as
much. People would go around to various websites, look, and they would
see ours and know its the official one. We are not there today so I
plead for your cooperation.

Perhaps writing what I wrote before was not the most tactful thing and
I apologize for that. However, it is vital that the issue I present,
because of the possibility of future occurrences, be heard by everyone
in the community. We all come from different backgrounds and are
generally disinterested in the politics of people far removed from
ourselves. However, we are now an international community and we must
exercise sensitivity in these issues. A member of the United States
media bowed to the queen of England in during a visit. This act
angered many Americans because the country was founded on the principal
that the United States does not recognize democracy. Such a simple
act, and such a hostile response. I hope in the future you take into
consideration that a few characters on a flashing CRT screen can cause
international uproar.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 25, 2005, at 1:55 AM, ralf_laue wrote:

> Dear Tyson,
>
> as you certainly know, Hong Kong is a Special Administrative Region of
> the People's Republic of China.
>
> I have changed the entry in the list anyway, because in other sports
> Hong Kong did also compete as a separate team. (In the 2004 Olympics
> the team was called "Hong Kong, China").
>
> In general, I believe that it is the best policy to associate the name
> of the country as recognized by the UN. (Hong Kong may be a special
> case, I agree that it is a good idea to follow the policy of the IOC).
> In another e-mail you write: "It is of my opinion that if someone says
> they are from Hong Kong, then I will honor that request."
> My advice is to be careful with this. What will be your decision if
> someone says:
> - I want to represent Montenegro, not "Serbia and Montenegro"
> - I want to represent Quebec, not Canada
> etc.?
>
> I do not post "your records", I post the best results reported from
> Rubik's cube events. I did so long before WCA existed.
>
> Well, I think that I will stop updating the "sub-20" list somewhen in
> the future and just publish record progress lists, because all the
> information is available at speedcubing.com as well. (It would be a
> good idea to include a all-time ranking there.)
>
> Final remark:
> If you are upset about something on a web site, it is usually a good
> idea to contact the maintainer of this site instead of complaining in
> a mailing list.
>
> Ralf Laue

Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 05:19:08 -0800

Does anyone have a good way of recognizing COLL or is there a good
website or would a certain 14-year-old guy teach me what he does next
time he comes by my room?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1163. Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 15:53:54 -0000



Recently on this group, questions about color schemes appeared again.
I have one that is related to scrambles, sorry if an answer has
already been written somewhere.

In competitions, scrambles are generated by a computer.
It gives a sequence of moves that reaches a certain cube configuration.
-----> Should this sequence be applied starting always with the same
cube orientation (same colors)?

Of course, God (the guy/girl who solves cubes optimally) does not care
about it.
But I think it's a good thing, because of two reasons:
- If competitors use the same technique (if they start with a white
cross for example), they should have the same chances.
- It makes easier for judges to check for the validity of the scrambling.

An official color scheme would become mandatory.

Gilles.

1167. Re: [Speed cubing group] N x N x N cube
From: "tomrokicki" <rokicki@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 18:50:25 -0000


If anyone wants to compile this themselves, just replace the line

int x = IO.readInteger();

with

int x = Integer.parseInt(args[0]) ;

and pass in the size on the command line.

1173. RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 20:01:35 -0000

It's very easy, just compare the colours on the corner stickers (not your top layer colour), for the positions shown at www.cubestation.co.uk/coll/coll.html If you see a pair of stickers, call that colour the front colour, and relate all the other colours to it. That's what the 4 letter code means. Also check out Lars' COLL page which has colours to go with the letters, so you can see which patterns have adjacently coloured pairs and oppositely coloured pairs and similarly coloured pairs. It's very easy :) Dan :) _____ From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@...] Sent: 25 February 2005 20:00 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition I don't know it?
