1174. Re: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 21:25:19 -0000

Hey Tyson, I definitely do the COLL recognition a different way from the standard method. A good example is the alg: U' L' R U R' U' L U2' R U2 R' On Dan's site it's listed as RB FF where this points to the stickers (the first letter denotes the particular sticker on that piece) UFL UBR FUL UFR but the way I recognize this is by a name. I call it "vertical same". This comes from the stickers (again the first letter is the particular sticker on that piece) LBU <-> UFL are opposite colors (a vertical row as I see it) UBR <-> UFR are opposite colors (also a vertical row as I see it) FUL <-> UFR are the same color (hence the "same" part of "vertical same") Again I'm sure all the other COLL users would argue that my system is much slower and requires more recognition, but I have become quite comfortable in using it and can identify the cases very quickly. Basically for the cases I look at all the stickers on the FUL corner (ignoring the top color really) and the two visible stickers on the BUL corner as well as the UFR corner. Also you can see one sticker of UBR. I use all that to identify the case. After reading Dan's statement, I'm sure most would think my way is slower :-D but I like it. Also one pro for this recognition method is that I can also recognize most all of the cases with the cube rotated by U' or U (still working on U2, I can only do that on very few of the cases). Just my humble two cents of course, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > What's wrong with the standard way that Ron, LarsV, Macky (I expect), and > myself use? > > > > Dan :) > > > > _____ > > From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@i...] > Sent: 25 February 2005 13:19 > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition > > > > Does anyone have a good way of recognizing COLL or is there a good > website or would a certain 14-year-old guy teach me what he does next > time he comes by my room? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > > > > ADVERTISEMENT > > <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129u71657/M=298184.6018725.7038619.3001176/D=gr > oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1109424012/A=2593423/R=0/SIG=11el9gslf/*http:/www.n > etflix.com/Default?mqso=60190075> click here > > > > <http://us.adserver.yahoo.com/l?M=298184.6018725.7038619.3001176/D=groups/S= > :HM/A=2593423/rand=717633432> > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri > be> > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1175. Re: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 21:42:21 -0000

Sorry, I haven't really put this into words before. I just thought of a better way to describe what I do. Using all the stickers I can see I look only for opposite colored groups (of two stickers) and same colored groups (again of two stickers) and how they are arranged. I find this helps for solving on another cross color too, since I don't know what is to the right or left of certain colors for half of the orientations of the cube. So basically look only for pairs of opposite and like colored stickers, all the patterns are very distinct from eachother and I gave them names to help recall them when speedsolving. Hope that makes things clearer, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey Tyson, > > I definitely do the COLL recognition a different way from the standard > method. > > A good example is the alg: U' L' R U R' U' L U2' R U2 R' > > On Dan's site it's listed as > RB > FF > > where this points to the stickers (the first letter denotes the > particular sticker on that piece) > UFL UBR > FUL UFR > > but the way I recognize this is by a name. I call it "vertical same". > > This comes from the stickers (again the first letter is the particular > sticker on that piece) > > LBU <-> UFL are opposite colors (a vertical row as I see it) > UBR <-> UFR are opposite colors (also a vertical row as I see it) > FUL <-> UFR are the same color (hence the "same" part of "vertical same") > > Again I'm sure all the other COLL users would argue that my system is > much slower and requires more recognition, but I have become quite > comfortable in using it and can identify the cases very quickly. > > Basically for the cases I look at all the stickers on the FUL corner > (ignoring the top color really) and the two visible stickers on the > BUL corner as well as the UFR corner. Also you can see one sticker of > UBR. I use all that to identify the case. > > After reading Dan's statement, I'm sure most would think my way is > slower :-D but I like it. > > Also one pro for this recognition method is that I can also recognize > most all of the cases with the cube rotated by U' or U (still working > on U2, I can only do that on very few of the cases). > > Just my humble two cents of course, > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > What's wrong with the standard way that Ron, LarsV, Macky (I > expect), and > > myself use? > > > > > > > > Dan :) > > > > > > > > _____ > > > > From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@i...] > > Sent: 25 February 2005 13:19 > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition > > > > > > > > Does anyone have a good way of recognizing COLL or is there a good > > website or would a certain 14-year-old guy teach me what he does next > > time he comes by my room? > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1179. RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 22:50:37 -0000

Hey Chris, Although you say your way may be slower, I think that you still use the same tricks as me to recognise the case. When you are first learning the cases, you have to have a way to uniquely and easily identify each case, this is where the 4 letter codes come in. But once you become fluent, like you are, then you can start to see shortcuts in the recognition step, like just seeing where the same coloured stickers are in the pattern of four, or whether there is something like an "opposite X" (where you might have Blue - Blue from top left to bottom right, and Green - Green from top right to bottom left). This is by far (in my opinion) the quickest way to recognise these sorts of cases :) but you can only really start to implement it once you have gotten a complete hang of the COLL, and to get this you must first be able to use something like the 4 letter code! Dan :) _____ From: cmhardw [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 25 February 2005 21:25 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition Hey Tyson, I definitely do the COLL recognition a different way from the standard method. A good example is the alg: U' L' R U R' U' L U2' R U2 R' On Dan's site it's listed as RB FF where this points to the stickers (the first letter denotes the particular sticker on that piece) UFL UBR FUL UFR but the way I recognize this is by a name. I call it "vertical same". This comes from the stickers (again the first letter is the particular sticker on that piece) LBU <-> UFL are opposite colors (a vertical row as I see it) UBR <-> UFR are opposite colors (also a vertical row as I see it) FUL <-> UFR are the same color (hence the "same" part of "vertical same") Again I'm sure all the other COLL users would argue that my system is much slower and requires more recognition, but I have become quite comfortable in using it and can identify the cases very quickly. Basically for the cases I look at all the stickers on the FUL corner (ignoring the top color really) and the two visible stickers on the BUL corner as well as the UFR corner. Also you can see one sticker of UBR. I use all that to identify the case. After reading Dan's statement, I'm sure most would think my way is slower :-D but I like it. Also one pro for this recognition method is that I can also recognize most all of the cases with the cube rotated by U' or U (still working on U2, I can only do that on very few of the cases). Just my humble two cents of course, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > What's wrong with the standard way that Ron, LarsV, Macky (I expect), and > myself use? > > > > Dan :) > > > > _____ > > From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@i...] > Sent: 25 February 2005 13:19 > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition > > > > Does anyone have a good way of recognizing COLL or is there a good > website or would a certain 14-year-old guy teach me what he does next > time he comes by my room? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > > > > ADVERTISEMENT > > <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=129u71657/M=298184.6018725.7038619.3001176/D=gr > oups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1109424012/A=2593423/R=0/SIG=11el9gslf/*http:/www.n > etflix.com/Default?mqso=60190075> click here > > > > <http://us.adserver.yahoo.com/l?M=298184.6018725.7038619.3001176/D=groups/S= > :HM/A=2593423/rand=717633432> > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! 1180. RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition
From: "James Stuber" <jstuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 15:37:43 -0800

I don't even pay attention to the letter code I just used the colors on Lars' site, and recognize by color patterns. I guess if you were a read/write type of learner the letters would help. -----Original Message----- From: Daniel Harris [mailto:dan_j_harris@...] Sent: Friday, February 25, 2005 2:51 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition Hey Chris, Although you say your way may be slower, I think that you still use the same tricks as me to recognise the case. When you are first learning the cases, you have to have a way to uniquely and easily identify each case, this is where the 4 letter codes come in. But once you become fluent, like you are, then you can start to see shortcuts in the recognition step, like just seeing where the same coloured stickers are in the pattern of four, or whether there is something like an "opposite X" (where you might have Blue - Blue from top left to bottom right, and Green - Green from top right to bottom left). This is by far (in my opinion) the quickest way to recognise these sorts of cases :) but you can only really start to implement it once you have gotten a complete hang of the COLL, and to get this you must first be able to use something like the 4 letter code! Dan :) _____ From: cmhardw [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 25 February 2005 21:25 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition Hey Tyson, I definitely do the COLL recognition a different way from the standard method. A good example is the alg: U' L' R U R' U' L U2' R U2 R' On Dan's site it's listed as RB FF where this points to the stickers (the first letter denotes the particular sticker on that piece) UFL UBR FUL UFR but the way I recognize this is by a name. I call it "vertical same". This comes from the stickers (again the first letter is the particular sticker on that piece) LBU <-> UFL are opposite colors (a vertical row as I see it) UBR <-> UFR are opposite colors (also a vertical row as I see it) FUL <-> UFR are the same color (hence the "same" part of "vertical same") Again I'm sure all the other COLL users would argue that my system is much slower and requires more recognition, but I have become quite comfortable in using it and can identify the cases very quickly. Basically for the cases I look at all the stickers on the FUL corner (ignoring the top color really) and the two visible stickers on the BUL corner as well as the UFR corner. Also you can see one sticker of UBR. I use all that to identify the case. After reading Dan's statement, I'm sure most would think my way is slower :-D but I like it. Also one pro for this recognition method is that I can also recognize most all of the cases with the cube rotated by U' or U (still working on U2, I can only do that on very few of the cases). Just my humble two cents of course, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > What's wrong with the standard way that Ron, LarsV, Macky (I expect), and > myself use? > > > > Dan :) > > > > _____ > > From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@i...] > Sent: 25 February 2005 13:19 > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] COLL Recognition > > > > Does anyone have a good way of recognizing COLL or is there a good > website or would a certain 14-year-old guy teach me what he does next > time he comes by my room? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1181. Re: [Speed cubing group] N x N x N cube
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 23:27:28 -0000

...actually, I compiled it that way and got a runtime error. Perhaps you could explain why?... I decided to use the code from the IO module that I was using and just add it so that the IO module is no longer needed. So, here is the new code: //Start of Code import java.math.BigInteger; import java.io.*; public class Cube { private static BufferedReader kb = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); public static int readInteger() { while (true) { try { String s = kb.readLine(); return Integer.parseInt(s); } catch (NumberFormatException e) { System.out.print("That is not an integer. Enter again: "); } catch (IOException e) { // should never happen } } } public static void main(String[] args) { int x = readInteger(); if (x < 2 || x > 100) { System.out.println("Be realistic!"); } else { BigInteger n = new BigInteger(String.valueOf(x)); BigInteger odd1 = new BigInteger("282526639718400"); BigInteger odd = odd1.pow(x%2); BigInteger a = odd.multiply(new BigInteger("3674160")); BigInteger b = new BigInteger ("620448401733239439360000"); BigInteger c = b.pow((x*x-2*x)/4); BigInteger num = a.multiply(c); BigInteger fourfact = new BigInteger("24"); BigInteger denom = fourfact.pow(6*((x-2)*(x-2))/4); BigInteger result = num.divide(denom); if (x == 2) { System.out.println("There are "+result+" combinations."); } else { String big = ""+result; String first = big.substring(0,1); String second = big.substring(1); int digits = second.length(); second = big.substring(1,5); String small = first+"."+second+" x 10^"+digits; System.out.println("There are approximately "+small+" combinations."); } } } } // End of Code --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > thanks, i actually didn't know how to do that because i'm only > taking intro to comp sci this semester :) > > ~bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "tomrokicki" > <rokicki@c...> wrote: > > > > If anyone wants to compile this themselves, just replace the line > > > > int x = IO.readInteger(); > > > > with > > > > int x = Integer.parseInt(args[0]) ; > > > > and pass in the size on the command line.

1183. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 17:57:41 -0800

Hi Gilles,

It is something that we have discussed for quite a bit actually. If
competitors do use the same technique, then they should have the same
chances. This is of course correct. Currently, the procedure that we
follow is that we ask the competitor for their "top" color. We don't
say anything else. We do not say "cross" or anything because that
would bias one method or another. If a competitor asks, "Well, do you
mean cross?" I just say, "Whatever you want." It's up to the
competitor to decide what they want their top color to be.

If the competitor requests a front color, we honor that request. This
request is definitely made in blindfold cubing when competitors are
used to solving the cube with certain colors in front of them.

The idea of giving people "same chances" is only loosely followed. We
know that when people make cross differently, even from the same
starting position, it can totally change the rest of the solve. As for
the judges to check the validity of the scrambling, it is not the
judge's job to check the validity of the scrambling. It is the
scrambler's job to check the validity of the scrambling. I must stress
the fact that the "top" color varies though because it would not be
fair for competitors to be biased with one type of "top" color.
Scramblers should be able to check the validity of the scrambling by
translating the colors if necessary.

Official color schemes are not mandatory because we would never be able
to consolidate the Japanese color scheme and the other color scheme.
Furthermore, we would have to ask the manufacturers to unify their
color scheme as well which really isn't in our control.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 25, 2005, at 7:53 AM, Gilles Roux wrote:

> Recently on this group, questions about color schemes appeared again.
> I have one that is related to scrambles, sorry if an answer has
> already been written somewhere.
>
> In competitions, scrambles are generated by a computer.
> It gives a sequence of moves that reaches a certain cube configuration.
> -----> Should this sequence be applied starting always with the same
> cube orientation (same colors)?
>
> Of course, God (the guy/girl who solves cubes optimally) does not care
> about it.
> But I think it's a good thing, because of two reasons:
> - If competitors use the same technique (if they start with a white
> cross for example), they should have the same chances.
> - It makes easier for judges to check for the validity of the
> scrambling.
>
> An official color scheme would become mandatory.
>
> Gilles.




1184. Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "rubikstimer" <rubikstimer@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 02:37:07 -0000


Hi everyone,

First, thanks to everyone here for all the valuable feedback during
the last few months of design and construction of the Rubik's timer.
As everyone knows, there is a valid debate on whether to keep using
the SpeedStacks timer in official competitions, or to switch over to
the new timer for official competitions, when it becomes available.
Both sides of this debate have merit.

Whether or not the new timer is accepted in official tournaments is
of course not up to me. Rather, it is up to everyone here in the
speedcubing community. In all probability, SevenTowns will be
persuaded to go along with whatever the majority of speedcubers on
this Yahoo message board want. I encourage everyone to give careful
thought to the subject, because I believe the people here will
ultimately be the deciding factor.

I would like to speak about the possibility that a competitor
might "cheat" by making a "U" move before lifting the cube, or after
stopping the timer. This is a valid argument and there is no perfect
solution to this problem. Many people will no doubt disagree
completely with my thoughts below, but I offer them more as a
possibility to open more discussion and ideas.

I feel the most certain way to eliminate making a "U" move before
timing starts is to rule that if a competitor makes his first move
within 10 centimeters of the puzzle pad, then his first move cannot
be parallel to the horizontal plane. That is, after pre-inspection,
it is up to the competitor to place the cube on the puzzle-pad in
such an orientation that his first move is not horizontal. A non-
horizontal move will force the cube off the puzzle pad before the
move is barely begun. A judge can easily determine if the first move
is horizontal if the first move is made within 10 cm of the pad.

As for making a "U", "M", or "D" move *after* the cube is back on the
pad and timing has stopped, I think this is very difficult, if not
impossible, to do when making moves at high speed. I encourage
everyone to try the following experiment: Do the moves U' R on a
solved cube, so that the finger-trick R' U will solve the cubethis
is the ideal finish that might allow the competitor to "cheat" on the
last U move. Now hold the cube about 1 cm above a table, and try to
perform R' U, while simultaneously making the "D" face completely
rest on the table after R' but before U. As you attempt this at top
speed, it becomes nearly impossible to make the entire "D" face rest
on the table before performing the U move.

Obviously, the possibilities that I describe above are not perfect;
they are flawed. I do not believe a perfect solution exists. The
SpeedStacks timer itself is flawed, and its flaws are currently
accepted as a part of speed-cubing. In the end, I hope the
speedcubing community as a whole will decide which timing method has
fewer flaws with the lowest impact on tournament competition.

Thanks again for everyone's support,
-eric






1185. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 18:56:51 -0800

Hi Eric,

I feel that such a rule would be infringing on the competitor's freedom
to solve the cube. Furthermore, judging 10 cm would be very difficult.
From a tournament organizer's standpoint, it would be a nightmare to
put these regulations into effect.

Why wasn't the timer built with hand pads like the StackMat? Why did
you decide to use an optical sensor?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 25, 2005, at 6:37 PM, rubikstimer wrote:

> I feel the most certain way to eliminate making a "U" move before
> timing starts is to rule that if a competitor makes his first move
> within 10 centimeters of the puzzle pad, then his first move cannot
> be parallel to the horizontal plane. That is, after pre-inspection,
> it is up to the competitor to place the cube on the puzzle-pad in
> such an orientation that his first move is not horizontal. A non-
> horizontal move will force the cube off the puzzle pad before the
> move is barely begun. A judge can easily determine if the first move
> is horizontal if the first move is made within 10 cm of the pad.




1186. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 03:33:28 -0000

To make things equal for everybody, you could put some sort of square, outlined in tape or something on the mat for the puzzle to be placed in before the solve. This would ensure that the puzzle is the same distance from every competitor at the start of the time. Furthermore, I also like the idea of using hand pads over an optical sensor. I am also opposed to restricting the first move on the puzzle. I don't believe cheating is a major problem. It should be pretty clear whether or not time has started when the competitor begins solving the puzzle. After all, there is somebody watching him, and that judge is responsible for paying attention to only that competitor. So, the judge can focus completely on the hands of the competitor, and since the Stackmat has the blinking lights feature, it should be relatively easy to see whether or not the lights are blinking during the competitor's first move. ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Eric, > > I feel that such a rule would be infringing on the competitor's freedom > to solve the cube. Furthermore, judging 10 cm would be very difficult. > From a tournament organizer's standpoint, it would be a nightmare to > put these regulations into effect. > > Why wasn't the timer built with hand pads like the StackMat? Why did > you decide to use an optical sensor? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 25, 2005, at 6:37 PM, rubikstimer wrote: > > > I feel the most certain way to eliminate making a "U" move before > > timing starts is to rule that if a competitor makes his first move > > within 10 centimeters of the puzzle pad, then his first move cannot > > be parallel to the horizontal plane. That is, after pre- inspection, > > it is up to the competitor to place the cube on the puzzle-pad in > > such an orientation that his first move is not horizontal. A non- > > horizontal move will force the cube off the puzzle pad before the > > move is barely begun. A judge can easily determine if the first move > > is horizontal if the first move is made within 10 cm of the pad.

1188. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2005 20:19:05 -0800

That's what I've been thinking. To take it a bit further you could put
a sensor in the area, very much like the Rubiks Timer and combine both
approaches. That way you know the cube and the hands are in different
places both when the timer stops and when it starts.

It's probably not necessary, but if you want something that's above
every suspicion, it's the way to go.

/Lars


On Feb 25, 2005, at 20:01, rubikscubewhiz wrote:

>
> To make it more clear what I'm talking about, I made an image, found
> at www.cubewhiz.com/stackmat.jpg it should be clear from the
> picture what i mean.

1190. Where can I buy a 1980 Rubik's CUBE!!!
From: "darereck" <darerick@...>

1191. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 19:32:56 +1100

There was a consensus in 2003 that StackMats were unnatural for
speedcubing. In particular, it is unnatural for a cubist to not be
holding onto the cube at the beginning of the solve, and it is unnatural
to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest
time. Not to mention that the StackMat measures the time it takes to
move your hands to and from the cube, which is not really a part of the
activity of speedcubing.

The fact that you can get used to using a StackMat still does not make
the StackMat natural for speedcubing. I would like something that
allowed me to hold onto the cube at the beginning and not drop it at the
end.

Eric, I like the timing device you have designed. It is more natural for
speedcubing than the StackMat is, and will also measure faster and more
accurate times. However, as others have pointed out, it is possible to
cheat with your device, by performing untimed U-turns and D-turns for
free at the end. When you place your cube against one flat surface at
the end of the solve, this prevents you from turning only 4 of the 6
sides of the cube. However, if you place your cube against two
perpendicular flat surfaces at the end of the solve, this prevents you
from turning all 6 sides of the cube.

Is it possible to incorporate a second perpendicular surface into your
design? This surface could stand behind the cube should be less than the
width of the cube so that your fingers can grip the rear side of the
cube when picking it up and placing it down. The sensor can be placed at
the edge between the two surfaces.

On second thought, this standing surface need not be flat. It can curve
away from the cube on the left and right sides, leaving room for the
fingers. For example, it could be a standing cylinder. This has the
additional benefit of providing no sharp edges to hurt your fingers on.

Ryan


1192. what the...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 09:20:00 -0000


Average: 23.09 seconds
Individual Times: 21.35, 23.37, 23.61, (23.99), 23.28, 23.82, 23.21,
22.04, 23.38, 23.43, 23.40, (20.99)

Standard Deviation: 00.47

I decided to take an average before I went to bed. The average sucked,
but holy crap it's consistant!

There should be a record on speedcubing.com for lowest standard
deviation. :)

-Chris





1193. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 11:13:01 -0000



> [...]
> I would like to speak about the possibility that a competitor
> might "cheat" by making a "U" move before lifting the cube, or after
> stopping the timer. This is a valid argument and there is no perfect
> solution to this problem.
> [...]

Just a thought... Would it be hard to add a sensor on a second flat
surface? Look at the picture: http://grrroux.free.fr/2flat.jpg

I understand that the enclosure would become rather thick, but this
would solve 2 problems:
- The U/E/D turn before/after.
- It ensures the cube really is a cube, the problem with "2 sec"
penalties disappears.

Such a device would work with big cubes too, but not with some other
exotic puzzle.
I think you still can pick up the cube rather naturally.

Gilles

[] in less than three seconds
[] what the Superflip is
[] an optimal solution
[] all optimal solutions

[] more than 10
[] more than 50
[] what a supercube group is

[x] to solve the Cube
[x] even in the bathroom
[] underwater
[x] during meals
[x] in my dreams
[x] hanging around in cubing forums
[x] to take twisty puzzles apart
[] and make other things out of them

[x] with thick gloves

[] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded]
[x] in one breath
[x] above my head
[x] in front of a crowd
[x] and teach others to solve it
[x] and do so more than a hundred times a day
[] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes

[] on a "flat cube" on the computer
[] in my head
[] to any possible pattern
[x] by telling someone what moves to make
[x] by doing the moves someone tells me to make

[x] with either hand
[] with one in each hand simultaneously
[] with chopsticks
[] taking account of center rotations
[] while juggling

[] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano)
[] choosing one side to never twist
[] in the 2-generator subgroup
[] in the half-turn subgroup
[] in the antislice subgroup

Mikael





1197. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 16:19:01 +0100

Hi Ryan, I do not agree with you on this one. There has never been a consensus that StackMats were unnatural for speedcubing. At least I wasn't part of that consensus. :-) In fact I would dare to claim that without StackMat there wouldn't have been as many tourmanents as there have been recently. I also dare to claim that more than half of the competitors don't bother much about the timers, as long as the competition is fair. It is only a few people (some of them have never been to a tournament, some have never touched a StackMat!) who are discussing this subject. During Euro2004 we did not have a single complaint about the timers. There was one case where the timer didn't stop because the competitor didn't touch both pads at the same time. I would like to compare this discussion to the 100 meter dash. We all start after the gun shot. But reaction time is included and also the acceleration time. There are much better ways to measure the true 100 meter dash running time. I think StackMat gives us better time measurement than athletics timers. My main problems with StackMat are the price and the ugly mat. The old version also has problems with durability (dropping gives pits). The new version can have a separate mat, so that we can also make a mat specifically for speedcubing (nice WCA logo maybe?). The price of StackMat will drop once speedstacks.com doesn't have a monopoly anymore. Although StackMat also lacks functionality (like generating scrambles or taking averages), I do not think this is an issue for competitions until all timing devices are connected to a central computer. In which case the central computer could also provide that functionality. For home use StackMat indeed lacks that functionality. But at home anyone can decide what timer he/she uses. (Who has an official athletics timer at home?) The device you propose is an interesting one, but even such a device has some awkward issues. If picking up the cube is a problem for StackMat, then picking will also be a problem for the new timer. Same goes for stopping it. No, I do not have Speedstacks.com shares. I am just conservative and proud of it. :-) StackMat has been the recent standard for competitions. It works great! We have a great timer to compare competitors. The extra time for picking up and putting down the cube is very low. People are enjoying speedcubing. Speedcubing meetings have been full of friendship and fun. And a great timer for the official stuff. Even though there may be better ways to measure the times, I think there are hardly better ways to minimize cheating or at least avoid discussions afterwards. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: "Ryan Heise" <rheise@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 9:32 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol > > There was a consensus in 2003 that StackMats were unnatural for > speedcubing. In particular, it is unnatural for a cubist to not be > holding onto the cube at the beginning of the solve, and it is unnatural > to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest > time. Not to mention that the StackMat measures the time it takes to > move your hands to and from the cube, which is not really a part of the > activity of speedcubing. > > The fact that you can get used to using a StackMat still does not make > the StackMat natural for speedcubing. I would like something that > allowed me to hold onto the cube at the beginning and not drop it at the > end. > > Eric, I like the timing device you have designed. It is more natural for > speedcubing than the StackMat is, and will also measure faster and more > accurate times. However, as others have pointed out, it is possible to > cheat with your device, by performing untimed U-turns and D-turns for > free at the end. When you place your cube against one flat surface at > the end of the solve, this prevents you from turning only 4 of the 6 > sides of the cube. However, if you place your cube against two > perpendicular flat surfaces at the end of the solve, this prevents you > from turning all 6 sides of the cube. > > Is it possible to incorporate a second perpendicular surface into your > design? This surface could stand behind the cube should be less than the > width of the cube so that your fingers can grip the rear side of the > cube when picking it up and placing it down. The sensor can be placed at > the edge between the two surfaces. > > On second thought, this standing surface need not be flat. It can curve > away from the cube on the left and right sides, leaving room for the > fingers. For example, it could be a standing cylinder. This has the > additional benefit of providing no sharp edges to hurt your fingers on. > > Ryan > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1198. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 15:27:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Gilles, > > It is something that we have discussed for quite a bit actually. If > competitors do use the same technique, then they should have the same > chances. This is of course correct. Currently, the procedure that we > follow is that we ask the competitor for their "top" color. We don't > say anything else. We do not say "cross" or anything because that > would bias one method or another. If a competitor asks, "Well, do you > mean cross?" I just say, "Whatever you want." It's up to the > competitor to decide what they want their top color to be. > > If the competitor requests a front color, we honor that request. This > request is definitely made in blindfold cubing when competitors are > used to solving the cube with certain colors in front of them. > I'm reading your comment for the third time, but I still can't imagine why someone would tell the scramblers to choose a given color or another, unless he knows what the scrambling sequence does(!). The only thing that matters is what centers will be on top/front when the inspection begins (and in my opinion these centers should not be decided by anyone, only by a computer, scrambling sequences could include slice moves). By the way, I know that some record breakers in the "no inspection" category use this cheat. Of course they don't see it as a cheat, they think that a 3x3x3 has no centers because they're considered fixed in the scrambling sequence and in their way of solving. With a 15-sec long inspection, it does not matter. > The idea of giving people "same chances" is only loosely followed. We > know that when people make cross differently, even from the same > starting position, it can totally change the rest of the solve. If an Extended Cross (TM) based on white can be reached within 3 moves, I bet most of good F2L cubers starting with white (i.e. most of top speedcubers) will choose it. > As for > the judges to check the validity of the scrambling, it is not the > judge's job to check the validity of the scrambling. It is the > scrambler's job to check the validity of the scrambling. Ok, the scrambler judges the validity of the scrambling, so he/she is another judge. > I must stress > the fact that the "top" color varies though because it would not be > fair for competitors to be biased with one type of "top" color. > Scramblers should be able to check the validity of the scrambling by > translating the colors if necessary. > > Official color schemes are not mandatory because we would never be able > to consolidate the Japanese color scheme and the other color scheme. > Furthermore, we would have to ask the manufacturers to unify their > color scheme as well which really isn't in our control. > Of course, I'm not asking you for miracles. I just wanted to raise a problem that has a significant importance when choosing a winner with only 5 times (not the winner, sorry, the one who comes after SuperMacky). It's like a changing wind during a long jump competition. But there are still jumpers who have fun practicing their sport :-) Gilles.
1199. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 15:29:17 -0000


Hey Ryan,

.....
> and it is unnatural
> to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest
> time.
...

With a little practice you can avoid having to drop the cube, yet
still stop the timer quickly. I even asked Tyson about my technique
(I'm sure others do the same thing too) at the 2004 US competition
and he said there was no problem with it.

What I do is to continue holding the cube as I move my hands to the
timer. That way the cube hits the table just as your hands hit the
timer pads, so it satisfies the WCA rules in that the cube is on the
table as your hands stop the timter, however your hands bring the
cube to the table (which is faster than gravity alone btw, so it is
even faster than dropping).

I just wanted to mention that this flaw in the stackmat can be
overcome with practice on a stackmat. This has its own problem in
that people who can't afford stackmats can't practice this.

Maybe just before the rounds start at a competition, when stackmats
are provided for people to practice, this technique should be shown
by the judges to those who aren't used to the mat? I think that
could help with people who are afraid of dropping.

Just a thought,
Chris







1200. Re: Rubik's Cube Test

1204. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 18:45:43 +0100

Hi friends, I would like to add to this discussion that already in Toronto, people could tell which color they wanted to use. Since the first round took a looong time (there was even a break of one night!), people heard from other competitors whether cube x had a tough cross when using your normal color. In fact I heard Janosz say that he figured out some extra hard scrambles (no random scrambles???). Anyways, there were a lot of competitors not choosing their normal starting color, because that would mean a tough cross for some cubes. To prevent this you have to choose the color BEFORE the competition starts. That said, it is still possible to choose a different color than your normal color. Not to mention that different systems means different scrambles being easier or not. My conclusion is: = we must have the same scrambles = we must have the color chosen before the competition But only to have good scrambles and no discussion like "his/her scramble was easier than mine". Not to have the same difficulty for all competitors and all systems. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 4:27 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Hi Gilles, >> >> It is something that we have discussed for quite a bit actually. If >> competitors do use the same technique, then they should have the same >> chances. This is of course correct. Currently, the procedure that we >> follow is that we ask the competitor for their "top" color. We don't >> say anything else. We do not say "cross" or anything because that >> would bias one method or another. If a competitor asks, "Well, do you >> mean cross?" I just say, "Whatever you want." It's up to the >> competitor to decide what they want their top color to be. >> >> If the competitor requests a front color, we honor that request. This >> request is definitely made in blindfold cubing when competitors are >> used to solving the cube with certain colors in front of them. >> > > I'm reading your comment for the third time, but I still can't imagine > why someone would tell the scramblers to choose a given color or > another, unless he knows what the scrambling sequence does(!). > The only thing that matters is what centers will be on top/front when > the inspection begins (and in my opinion these centers should not be > decided by anyone, only by a computer, scrambling sequences could > include slice moves). By the way, I know that some record breakers in > the "no inspection" category use this cheat. Of course they don't see > it as a cheat, they think that a 3x3x3 has no centers because they're > considered fixed in the scrambling sequence and in their way of solving. > With a 15-sec long inspection, it does not matter. > >> The idea of giving people "same chances" is only loosely followed. We >> know that when people make cross differently, even from the same >> starting position, it can totally change the rest of the solve. > > If an Extended Cross (TM) based on white can be reached within 3 > moves, I bet most of good F2L cubers starting with white (i.e. most of > top speedcubers) will choose it. > >> As for >> the judges to check the validity of the scrambling, it is not the >> judge's job to check the validity of the scrambling. It is the >> scrambler's job to check the validity of the scrambling. > > Ok, the scrambler judges the validity of the scrambling, so he/she is > another judge. > >> I must stress >> the fact that the "top" color varies though because it would not be >> fair for competitors to be biased with one type of "top" color. >> Scramblers should be able to check the validity of the scrambling by >> translating the colors if necessary. >> >> Official color schemes are not mandatory because we would never be able >> to consolidate the Japanese color scheme and the other color scheme. >> Furthermore, we would have to ask the manufacturers to unify their >> color scheme as well which really isn't in our control. >> > > Of course, I'm not asking you for miracles. > > I just wanted to raise a problem that has a significant importance > when choosing a winner with only 5 times (not the winner, sorry, the > one who comes after SuperMacky). > It's like a changing wind during a long jump competition. But there > are still jumpers who have fun practicing their sport :-) > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1205. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: "devlish_cuber" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 20:40:48 -0000

Good points Ron. I sceamble the cube with white on top and red in front. but you probably scramble differently. Of course even I find that different scrambles harder then some others. I think this would be true of anyone. That being said I agree that a starting top color has to be decided before any competition, and to make it even more fair to everyone, a different color be used for every scramble. Of course these would never be given to the competitors. I think this would make it fair for all concerned. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friends, > > I would like to add to this discussion that already in Toronto, people could > tell which color they wanted to use. > Since the first round took a looong time (there was even a break of one > night!), people heard from other competitors whether cube x had a tough > cross when using your normal color. In fact I heard Janosz say that he > figured out some extra hard scrambles (no random scrambles???). > Anyways, there were a lot of competitors not choosing their normal starting > color, because that would mean a tough cross for some cubes. > > To prevent this you have to choose the color BEFORE the competition starts. > That said, it is still possible to choose a different color than your normal > color. Not to mention that different systems means different scrambles being > easier or not. > > My conclusion is: > = we must have the same scrambles > = we must have the color chosen before the competition > But only to have good scrambles and no discussion like "his/her scramble was > easier than mine". > Not to have the same difficulty for all competitors and all systems. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 4:27 PM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > >> Hi Gilles, > >> > >> It is something that we have discussed for quite a bit actually. If > >> competitors do use the same technique, then they should have the same > >> chances. This is of course correct. Currently, the procedure that we > >> follow is that we ask the competitor for their "top" color. We don't > >> say anything else. We do not say "cross" or anything because that > >> would bias one method or another. If a competitor asks, "Well, do you > >> mean cross?" I just say, "Whatever you want." It's up to the > >> competitor to decide what they want their top color to be. > >> > >> If the competitor requests a front color, we honor that request. This > >> request is definitely made in blindfold cubing when competitors are > >> used to solving the cube with certain colors in front of them. > >> > > > > I'm reading your comment for the third time, but I still can't imagine > > why someone would tell the scramblers to choose a given color or > > another, unless he knows what the scrambling sequence does(!). > > The only thing that matters is what centers will be on top/front when > > the inspection begins (and in my opinion these centers should not be > > decided by anyone, only by a computer, scrambling sequences could > > include slice moves). By the way, I know that some record breakers in > > the "no inspection" category use this cheat. Of course they don't see > > it as a cheat, they think that a 3x3x3 has no centers because they're > > considered fixed in the scrambling sequence and in their way of solving. > > With a 15-sec long inspection, it does not matter. > > > >> The idea of giving people "same chances" is only loosely followed. We > >> know that when people make cross differently, even from the same > >> starting position, it can totally change the rest of the solve. > > > > If an Extended Cross (TM) based on white can be reached within 3 > > moves, I bet most of good F2L cubers starting with white (i.e. most of > > top speedcubers) will choose it. > > > >> As for > >> the judges to check the validity of the scrambling, it is not the > >> judge's job to check the validity of the scrambling. It is the > >> scrambler's job to check the validity of the scrambling. > > > > Ok, the scrambler judges the validity of the scrambling, so he/she is > > another judge. > > > >> I must stress > >> the fact that the "top" color varies though because it would not be > >> fair for competitors to be biased with one type of "top" color. > >> Scramblers should be able to check the validity of the scrambling by > >> translating the colors if necessary. > >> > >> Official color schemes are not mandatory because we would never be able > >> to consolidate the Japanese color scheme and the other color scheme. > >> Furthermore, we would have to ask the manufacturers to unify their > >> color scheme as well which really isn't in our control. > >> > > > > Of course, I'm not asking you for miracles. > > > > I just wanted to raise a problem that has a significant importance > > when choosing a winner with only 5 times (not the winner, sorry, the > > one who comes after SuperMacky). > > It's like a changing wind during a long jump competition. But there > > are still jumpers who have fun practicing their sport :-) > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1206. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 14:49:15 -0800

Hi Everyone, Just to clarify what I do at my tournaments: The scrambles are pre-generated using a computer. They come with little diagrams that allow you to check the states of the scramble cube but I do not look at them until the day of the tournament. If one of the scrambles is "easy" for anyone, oh well, I do not do anything about it. You guys got lucky, it was random, and fine, that's the end of it. At the beginning of the tournament, you mark down what your top and front (if desired) colors are and that remains throughout the entire tournament. All of this is done to put some control into the fairness of the scramble without taking into any consideration of method or anything. We all know that there's no such thing as an easy "case" unless you have a bunch of pieces solved because every method is different and you will have different sets of cases depending on how you approach the cube given the same method. Here's a funny story you might like to hear. I was discussing records for the April 2004 tournament and I told one person that "a single solve record is meaningless because eventually someone is going to get lucky and they'll set the record at 8 seconds and no one will be able to break it in ages!" This guy's response to me was, "Nonsense! The scrambles at the [tournament] were all calculated so that there would be no lucky cases!" I mean... seriously... that just shows complete and utter lack of everything true and beautiful to the cube... but anyway, on a random note, waking up at 2:30 PM is divine. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 26, 2005, at 9:45 AM, Ron van Bruchem wrote: > > Hi friends, > > I would like to add to this discussion that already in Toronto, people > could > tell which color they wanted to use. > Since the first round took a looong time (there was even a break of one > night!), people heard from other competitors whether cube x had a tough > cross when using your normal color. In fact I heard Janosz say that he > figured out some extra hard scrambles (no random scrambles???). > Anyways, there were a lot of competitors not choosing their normal > starting > color, because that would mean a tough cross for some cubes. > > To prevent this you have to choose the color BEFORE the competition > starts. > That said, it is still possible to choose a different color than your > normal > color. Not to mention that different systems means different scrambles > being > easier or not. > > My conclusion is: > = we must have the same scrambles > = we must have the color chosen before the competition > But only to have good scrambles and no discussion like "his/her > scramble was > easier than mine". > Not to have the same difficulty for all competitors and all systems. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 4:27 PM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes > > >> >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> >> wrote: >>> Hi Gilles, >>> >>> It is something that we have discussed for quite a bit actually. If >>> competitors do use the same technique, then they should have the same >>> chances. This is of course correct. 1207. Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 22:49:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > If the competitor requests a front color, we honor that request. This > request is definitely made in blindfold cubing when competitors are > used to solving the cube with certain colors in front of them. Huh? What's so special about blindfold cubing here? I'd almost claim it matters less there than in speedcubing... Cheers! Stefan
1208. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 14:55:07 -0800

It's a formality issue. Because in blindfold cubing, the competitor
himself has defined a top and a front throughout the entire solve. I
mean, when I scramble a cube, I scramble it with yellow on top and
green in the front. If I were blindfolding cubing, that's how I would
want the cube placed in front of me.

If you were to go back and redo your solve, it also makes things easier
because the scramble orientation would be the same as your solve
orientation. It definitely matters very little for the solve but the
principle of the whole thing... you're given a scramble algorithm and
if the competitor is going to define things, there's no reason you
shouldn't do it the same way especially since it won't make a
difference in the solve.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 26, 2005, at 2:49 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Huh? What's so special about blindfold cubing here? I'd almost claim
> it matters less there than in speedcubing...
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan




1209. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 14:59:22 -0800

Hi Everyone, We've been using this 100 meter dash example forever by now. I do not believe that the time it takes you to solve a cube is from when you first move the cube to when you stop moving the cube. It's just too hard to measure something like that. I also do not have any shares in StackMat either. I don't have any shares in anything at all. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Feb 26, 2005, at 7:19 AM, Ron van Bruchem wrote: > > Hi Ryan, > > I do not agree with you on this one. There has never been a consensus > that > StackMats were unnatural for speedcubing. At least I wasn't part of > that > consensus. :-) > In fact I would dare to claim that without StackMat there wouldn't > have been > as many tourmanents as there have been recently. > I also dare to claim that more than half of the competitors don't > bother > much about the timers, as long as the competition is fair. It is only > a few > people (some of them have never been to a tournament, some have never > touched a StackMat!) who are discussing this subject. During Euro2004 > we did > not have a single complaint about the timers. There was one case where > the > timer didn't stop because the competitor didn't touch both pads at the > same > time. > > I would like to compare this discussion to the 100 meter dash. We all > start > after the gun shot. But reaction time is included and also the > acceleration > time. There are much better ways to measure the true 100 meter dash > running > time. I think StackMat gives us better time measurement than athletics > timers. > > My main problems with StackMat are the price and the ugly mat. The old > version also has problems with durability (dropping gives pits). > The new version can have a separate mat, so that we can also make a mat > specifically for speedcubing (nice WCA logo maybe?). > The price of StackMat will drop once speedstacks.com doesn't have a > monopoly > anymore. > Although StackMat also lacks functionality (like generating scrambles > or > taking averages), I do not think this is an issue for competitions > until all > timing devices are connected to a central computer. In which case the > central computer could also provide that functionality. > For home use StackMat indeed lacks that functionality. But at home > anyone > can decide what timer he/she uses. (Who has an official athletics > timer at > home?) > > The device you propose is an interesting one, but even such a device > has > some awkward issues. > If picking up the cube is a problem for StackMat, then picking will > also be > a problem for the new timer. Same goes for stopping it. > > No, I do not have Speedstacks.com shares. I am just conservative and > proud > of it. :-) > StackMat has been the recent standard for competitions. It works great! > We have a great timer to compare competitors. The extra time for > picking up > and putting down the cube is very low. > People are enjoying speedcubing. Speedcubing meetings have been full of > friendship and fun. And a great timer for the official stuff. > Even though there may be better ways to measure the times, I think > there are > hardly better ways to minimize cheating or at least avoid discussions > afterwards. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Ryan Heise" <rheise@...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 9:32 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol > > >> >> There was a consensus in 2003 that StackMats were unnatural for >> speedcubing. In particular, it is unnatural for a cubist to not be >> holding onto the cube at the beginning of the solve, and it is >> unnatural >> to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest >> time. Not to mention that the StackMat measures the time it takes to >> move your hands to and from the cube, which is not really a part of >> the >> activity of speedcubing. >> >> The fact that you can get used to using a StackMat still does not make >> the StackMat natural for speedcubing. I would like something that >> allowed me to hold onto the cube at the beginning and not drop it at >> the >> end. >> >> Eric, I like the timing device you have designed. It is more natural >> for >> speedcubing than the StackMat is, and will also measure faster and >> more >> accurate times. However, as others have pointed out, it is possible to >> cheat with your device, by performing untimed U-turns and D-turns for >> free at the end. When you place your cube against one flat surface at >> the end of the solve, this prevents you from turning only 4 of the 6 >> sides of the cube. However, if you place your cube against two >> perpendicular flat surfaces at the end of the solve, this prevents you >> from turning all 6 sides of the cube. >> >> Is it possible to incorporate a second perpendicular surface into your >> design? This surface could stand behind the cube should be less than >> the >> width of the cube so that your fingers can grip the rear side of the >> cube when picking it up and placing it down. The sensor can be placed >> at >> the edge between the two surfaces. >> >> On second thought, this standing surface need not be flat. It can >> curve >> away from the cube on the left and right sides, leaving room for the >> fingers. For example, it could be a standing cylinder. This has the >> additional benefit of providing no sharp edges to hurt your fingers >> on. >> >> Ryan >> >> >> >> Yahoo! Groups Links >> >> >> >> >> >> >> > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1210. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles and color schemes
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 15:03:23 -0800

Hi Gilles,

The person doesn't know what the scrambling sequence is. It is only
used as one facet of implementing fairness of the scramble.

Yes, every speed cuber would choose it but none of them would know
which color it's on (including me) and even if they did know, they
would have already said which color they wanted and it would be too
late unless they were willing to risk using a different color which
usually results and disaster and furthermore, they would be cheating.

The competitors are not allowed to be judges! Judges need to be
impartial observes to the competition... it is inappropriate that
someone involved with a solve judges the solve at the same time.
There's a reason why I haven't been competing ever and that's part of
it.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1211. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 15:08:18 -0800

In short, it all boils down to this. In a competition, we are not
looking for the fastest cuber. In a competition, we are seeing who can
solve the cube fastest in a competition setting with competition
pressure under the competition regulations and using the competition
equipment.

People here say that dropping the cube might cause it to turn once so
they don't want to use the StackMat. My suggestion to all of you is to
buy a StackMat and practice. If not, during all of the competitions,
at least the ones I run, the timers are open for people to practice on.

It's the same pretty much for everything. The 100-meter dash doesn't
find the fastest runner. It finds the person able to get from here to
there given the procedures of the race, the gun shot, the chest pump to
kill off .01 of a second, and the track, and the shoes. It would be
unreasonable for someone to complain that they didn't have a track or a
gun to practice with. Get someone to stand there and fire blanks into
the air so you can practice your reaction time. Also, go find a track.
If it were up to me, fine, I'd love everyone to have a StackMat. I
can't provide this to you as the olympic committee can't give their
runners 100-meters of red track running surface.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 26, 2005, at 7:29 AM, cmhardw wrote:

> Hey Ryan,
>
> .....
>> and it is unnatural
>> to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest
>> time.
> ...
>
> With a little practice you can avoid having to drop the cube, yet
> still stop the timer quickly. I even asked Tyson about my technique
> (I'm sure others do the same thing too) at the 2004 US competition
> and he said there was no problem with it.
>
> What I do is to continue holding the cube as I move my hands to the
> timer. That way the cube hits the table just as your hands hit the
> timer pads, so it satisfies the WCA rules in that the cube is on the
> table as your hands stop the timter, however your hands bring the
> cube to the table (which is faster than gravity alone btw, so it is
> even faster than dropping).
>
> I just wanted to mention that this flaw in the stackmat can be
> overcome with practice on a stackmat. This has its own problem in
> that people who can't afford stackmats can't practice this.
>
> Maybe just before the rounds start at a competition, when stackmats
> are provided for people to practice, this technique should be shown
> by the judges to those who aren't used to the mat? I think that
> could help with people who are afraid of dropping.
>
> Just a thought,
> Chris




1212. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:09:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikstimer" <rubikstimer@c...> wrote: > > I would like to speak about the possibility that a competitor > might "cheat" by making a "U" move before lifting the cube, or after > stopping the timer. General question: Is this timer intended for cubes only? There's some reason to make moves with the puzzle on the surface for example with Magic, Megaminx, Rainbow Cube. > That is, after pre-inspection, > it is up to the competitor to place the cube on the puzzle-pad in > such an orientation that his first move is not horizontal. I'd prefer more freedom... > As you attempt this at top > speed, it becomes nearly impossible to make the entire "D" face rest > on the table before performing the U move. Depends a little on the size of your hands. Damn, another advantage of young cubers! ;-) > The > SpeedStacks timer itself is flawed, and its flaws are currently > accepted as a part of speed-cubing. I guess I belong to those who'd say that's a bit exaggerated... I think the only way to perfectly measure the time is video analysis or puzzles that measure the time themselves, but both ways must be combined with the solver somehow clearly stating that he/she thinks the cube is solved. Hmm, actually even that is still a little problematic. Not to mention it probably won't be very practical in the near future. Hey btw, I'm among those who should complain loudest about stackmats, since I'm among the serious Rubik's magic solvers. My stackmat record is an awful 38% slower than my video analysis record ;-) But for competition it still gives a good comparison which is why I like it nevertheless. Well, the main problem is picking up the magic which would still be a problem with the new timer (which has the end-problem with it, too). On stackmat it could be improved by putting the magic on a CD case, on the new timer maybe by cutting the sides off so that the actual surface area is even smaller ;-) Cheers! Stefan
1213. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:10:51 -0000

The amount of time it takes to pick up a cube and begin is miniscule, and the same goes for placing it back on the mat. It almost takes no time at all, and the difference in times between different competitors for these things is even much smaller. I would imagine it makes a difference of less than .1 second in most cases (or even smaller). I think the Stackmat is an excellent timing device, though a bit expensive. I see no reason to replace it (other than its high price). ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > We've been using this 100 meter dash example forever by now. I do not > believe that the time it takes you to solve a cube is from when you > first move the cube to when you stop moving the cube. It's just too > hard to measure something like that. > > I also do not have any shares in StackMat either. I don't have any > shares in anything at all. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 26, 2005, at 7:19 AM, Ron van Bruchem wrote: > > > > > Hi Ryan, > > > > I do not agree with you on this one. There has never been a consensus > > that > > StackMats were unnatural for speedcubing. At least I wasn't part of > > that > > consensus. :-) > > In fact I would dare to claim that without StackMat there wouldn't > > have been > > as many tourmanents as there have been recently. > > I also dare to claim that more than half of the competitors don't > > bother > > much about the timers, as long as the competition is fair. It is only > > a few > > people (some of them have never been to a tournament, some have never > > touched a StackMat!) who are discussing this subject. During Euro2004 > > we did > > not have a single complaint about the timers. There was one case where > > the > > timer didn't stop because the competitor didn't touch both pads at the > > same > > time. > > > > I would like to compare this discussion to the 100 meter dash. We all > > start > > after the gun shot. But reaction time is included and also the > > acceleration > > time. There are much better ways to measure the true 100 meter dash > > running > > time. I think StackMat gives us better time measurement than athletics > > timers. > > > > My main problems with StackMat are the price and the ugly mat. The old > > version also has problems with durability (dropping gives pits). > > The new version can have a separate mat, so that we can also make a mat > > specifically for speedcubing (nice WCA logo maybe?). > > The price of StackMat will drop once speedstacks.com doesn't have a > > monopoly > > anymore. > > Although StackMat also lacks functionality (like generating scrambles > > or > > taking averages), I do not think this is an issue for competitions > > until all > > timing devices are connected to a central computer. In which case the > > central computer could also provide that functionality. > > For home use StackMat indeed lacks that functionality. But at home > > anyone > > can decide what timer he/she uses. (Who has an official athletics > > timer at > > home?) > > > > The device you propose is an interesting one, but even such a device > > has > > some awkward issues. > > If picking up the cube is a problem for StackMat, then picking will > > also be > > a problem for the new timer. Same goes for stopping it. > > > > No, I do not have Speedstacks.com shares. I am just conservative and > > proud > > of it. :-) > > StackMat has been the recent standard for competitions. It works great! > > We have a great timer to compare competitors. The extra time for > > picking up > > and putting down the cube is very low. > > People are enjoying speedcubing. Speedcubing meetings have been full of > > friendship and fun. And a great timer for the official stuff. > > Even though there may be better ways to measure the times, I think > > there are > > hardly better ways to minimize cheating or at least avoid discussions > > afterwards. > > > > Have fun, > > > > Ron > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Ryan Heise" <rheise@p...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Saturday, February 26, 2005 9:32 AM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol > > > > > >> > >> There was a consensus in 2003 that StackMats were unnatural for > >> speedcubing. In particular, it is unnatural for a cubist to not be > >> holding onto the cube at the beginning of the solve, and it is > >> unnatural > >> to have to drop the cube at the end of the solve to get the fastest > >> time. Not to mention that the StackMat measures the time it takes to > >> move your hands to and from the cube, which is not really a part of > >> the > >> activity of speedcubing. > >> > >> The fact that you can get used to using a StackMat still does not make > >> the StackMat natural for speedcubing. I would like something that > >> allowed me to hold onto the cube at the beginning and not drop it at > >> the > >> end. > >> > >> Eric, I like the timing device you have designed. It is more natural > >> for > >> speedcubing than the StackMat is, and will also measure faster and > >> more > >> accurate times. However, as others have pointed out, it is possible to > >> cheat with your device, by performing untimed U-turns and D- turns for > >> free at the end. When you place your cube against one flat surface at > >> the end of the solve, this prevents you from turning only 4 of the 6 > >> sides of the cube. However, if you place your cube against two > >> perpendicular flat surfaces at the end of the solve, this prevents you > >> from turning all 6 sides of the cube. > >> > >> Is it possible to incorporate a second perpendicular surface into your > >> design? This surface could stand behind the cube should be less than > >> the > >> width of the cube so that your fingers can grip the rear side of the > >> cube when picking it up and placing it down. The sensor can be placed > >> at > >> the edge between the two surfaces. > >> > >> On second thought, this standing surface need not be flat. It can > >> curve > >> away from the cube on the left and right sides, leaving room for the > >> fingers. For example, it could be a standing cylinder. This has the > >> additional benefit of providing no sharp edges to hurt your fingers > >> on. > >> > >> Ryan > >> > >> > >> > >> Yahoo! Groups Links > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:16:21 -0000


Hey Stefan,

I watched your video of you setting the Magic WR, and afterwards you
look so angry! It's almost as if you were giving somebody a dirty
look!

~ Bob

1216. Re: [Speed cubing group] angry?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:33:56 -0000

Haha, that's not the first time I hear this :-) But that's not my angry-face, that's my proud-as-hell-face. Yes, some other solves were horrible so I got a bad average. But this was the fifth (and last) solve. I was quite sure I had no chance anymore to win, so I said to Jaap who was standing next to me "I'm gonna do a world record now" and then went full-risk-full-speed. So that's the story. I was not angry :-) For that I think I'd need to be more much serious about the competitions. Programming contests have taught me to not care too much... Hey, did you see how very very sad Macky is after an 18.05s solve? http://chrono.org/puzzles/MVI_0280.AVI Poor boy. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi Bob, > > Yes, he was!!! :-) > Just check the results of that round. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Sunday, February 27, 2005 12:16 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] angry? > > > > > > > > Hey Stefan, > > > > I watched your video of you setting the Magic WR, and afterwards you > > look so angry!
