1218. Re: Java Cubes
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:42:15 -0000

Easy. First goto http://www.randelshofer.ch/ and download the RubikPlayer. Extract it into a folder and open up Readme.html. Pick a script to write in, then open parameters.html. Edit the form to match what you want, then press Generate and show. Make sure the cube is what you want, then press Generate HTML code and bingo, there is the code to copy into your website. I made a site with these. Check it out: www.geocities.com/pjgat09/cube.html. Good luck. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I'm making a site and I was wondering if any of you could tell me how > to make java cubes.
1219. Re: Java Cubes
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 23:44:10 -0000

If you want a 5x5 java cube for a website, http://www.randelshofer.ch/ has an execelent 5x5 cube along with a 4x4 and a 3x3. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "nineteen_9" <nineteen_9@y...> wrote: > Well I have been looking throughout the internet for a good 5x5 java > cube. I was hoping to find one on Rubiks.com because I like their 3x3 > java cube. I don't like the oinkleburger java cube because it's too > confusing. I think that I can significantly drop times with a java > cube because slices are much easier. Thanks. > > Dylan
1220. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 13:04:01 +1100

On Sat, Feb 26, 2005 at 04:19:01PM +0100, Ron van Bruchem wrote:
>
> Hi Ryan,

Hi Ron. Before I begin to respond, I will make some claims:

- StackMats are unnatural for speedcubing
- The fact that you can get used to using a StackMat still does not make
the StackMat natural for speedcubing.
- Eric's timing device is more natural for speedcubing than the StackMat
is, and will also measure faster and more accurate times.

Since you disagree with me, I will now gather your claims:

> In fact I would dare to claim that without StackMat there wouldn't have been
> as many tourmanents as there have been recently.

I cannot conclude from this that StackMats are natural for speedcubing.

> I also dare to claim that more than half of the competitors don't bother
> much about the timers, as long as the competition is fair.

I cannot conclude from this that StackMats are natural for speedcubing.

> It is only a few people (some of them have never been to a tournament,
> some have never touched a StackMat!) who are discussing this subject.

Again, I cannot reach any conclusion. Most people have not touched
Eric's timer device either.

> During Euro2004 we did not have a single complaint about the timers.
> There was one case where the timer didn't stop because the competitor
> didn't touch both pads at the same time.

>From this, I can conclude that people can get used to StackMats, but not
that StackMats are natural for speedcubing.



Now for the arguments:

> I would like to compare this discussion to the 100 meter dash. We all start
> after the gun shot. But reaction time is included and also the acceleration
> time. There are much better ways to measure the true 100 meter dash running
> time. I think StackMat gives us better time measurement than athletics
> timers.

I put it to you that the 100 metre dash is not a mere "measurement of
speed", but a specific activity that starts from "GO" and ends at the
finish line. Naturally it includes acceleration. The "GO" part has been
implemented in different ways, of course.

What is important is that their feet are on the ground when they start
the race, right?




> My main problems with StackMat are the price and the ugly mat. The old
> version also has problems with durability (dropping gives pits).
> The new version can have a separate mat, so that we can also make a mat
> specifically for speedcubing (nice WCA logo maybe?).
> The price of StackMat will drop once speedstacks.com doesn't have a monopoly
> anymore.
> Although StackMat also lacks functionality (like generating scrambles or
> taking averages), I do not think this is an issue for competitions until all
> timing devices are connected to a central computer. In which case the
> central computer could also provide that functionality.
> For home use StackMat indeed lacks that functionality. But at home anyone
> can decide what timer he/she uses. (Who has an official athletics timer at
> home?)

No comment...

> The device you propose is an interesting one, but even such a device has
> some awkward issues.
> If picking up the cube is a problem for StackMat, then picking will also be
> a problem for the new timer. Same goes for stopping it.

I would like to make a distinction: picking up the cube is less of a
problem for the new timer timer. Same goes for stopping it.

My claim is that Eric's timing device (with or without my extension) is
"more natural" for speedcubing than the StackMat is.


To summarise, you claim:

- people can get used to StackMats (I agree)
- the availability of StackMats has allowed for tournaments (I agree)
- people enjoy tournaments with StackMats (I agree)

I'm making a different, but very narrow claim:

- StackMats are unnatural for speedcubing.

Or to put it in another way:

- StackMats are unnatural for speedcubing, but they work well enough
that many people don't mind.

I prefer the original, and more direct, claim.



Just one more small comment:

On Sat, Feb 26, 2005 at 03:29:17PM -0000, cmhardw wrote:
> I just wanted to mention that this flaw in the stackmat can be
> overcome with practice on a stackmat. This has its own problem in
> that people who can't afford stackmats can't practice this.
>
> Maybe just before the rounds start at a competition, when stackmats
> are provided for people to practice, this technique should be shown
> by the judges to those who aren't used to the mat? I think that
> could help with people who are afraid of dropping.

(Hi Chris)

This is an example of what I consider unnatural. Sure, people can learn
this technique, and eventually be happy doing it. But my point is only
to say that it is unnatural. Furthermore, starting and stopping with
Eric's timer is more natural than this.

Ryan


1221. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Feb 2005 19:20:45 -0800

Hi Ryan,

You keep saying the word "unnatural for cubing" but you really don't
say anything about what unnatural and natural are. Without putting in
any arguments, I do not believe you can claim that one is more
"natural" than the other. It is of my understanding that you have not
tried Eric's timer.

Furthermore, I could take every single claim you have here, and reverse
it in favor of the StackMat saying that it does not conclude that the
StackMat is unnatural for speedcubing.

You attempt to define natural and unnatural only for yourself. In
order to actually claim that the StackMat is unnatural for cubing,
you're going to have to give arguments and not just state the fact that
it is unnatural for cubing. I for one feel that the StackMat is very
natural for cubing.

The StackMat is natural for cubing.

The StackMat is natural for cubing.

The StackMat is natural for cubing.

Oh, and by the way:

The StackMat is natural for cubing.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 26, 2005, at 6:04 PM, Ryan Heise wrote:

1222. [Speed cubing group] Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 06:47:26 -0000

There was a brief exchange between Dror and me about this at WC2003. Because we always memorize and solve with a fixed orientation of the centers (so that permutation is easy to memorize), while the permutation is virtually not affected, orientation can be very different when scrambled from a different direction. Take this scramble: R2 I always memorize my cubes with blue on top and green in front (Japanese color scheme...haha). If the cube is scramble with blue on top and green in front, corner orientation is already done (from my perspective). Meanwhile, if it is scrambled after doing x, I am left with 8 incorrectly oriented corners. Of course, I could turn the cube so that all corners are correctly oriented, but this would make memorization of permutation very hard since I wouldn't be used to this new ordering of the centers. Macky p.s. I could even use the identity scramble for an example, but just to make a point, R2 was easier =) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > It's a formality issue. Because in blindfold cubing, the competitor > himself has defined a top and a front throughout the entire solve. I > mean, when I scramble a cube, I scramble it with yellow on top and > green in the front. If I were blindfolding cubing, that's how I would > want the cube placed in front of me. > > If you were to go back and redo your solve, it also makes things easier > because the scramble orientation would be the same as your solve > orientation. It definitely matters very little for the solve but the > principle of the whole thing... you're given a scramble algorithm and > if the competitor is going to define things, there's no reason you > shouldn't do it the same way especially since it won't make a > difference in the solve. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 26, 2005, at 2:49 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > Huh? What's so special about blindfold cubing here? I'd almost claim > > it matters less there than in speedcubing... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan
1223. [Speed cubing group] Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 07:47:17 -0000

Sorry, I was being dumb. That's a very bad scramble for this example, and "I" is even worse. =) Better scramble: U' R' F2 L D F L2 U L' U2 R2 L' F2 R' L2 B U2 B Holding your cube the way you do to memorize it and scramble. Orientation is done. Now, holding your cube the way you do to memorize, do x and then scramble. Now do x', and you see that now you have four corners to orient. You _could_ start with all corners oriented correctly by not doing that x', but it would be very hard to memorize the permutation this way. Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > There was a brief exchange between Dror and me about this at WC2003. > Because we always memorize and solve with a fixed orientation of the > centers (so that permutation is easy to memorize), while the > permutation is virtually not affected, orientation can be very > different when scrambled from a different direction. > > Take this scramble: R2 > > I always memorize my cubes with blue on top and green in front > (Japanese color scheme...haha). If the cube is scramble with blue on > top and green in front, corner orientation is already done (from my > perspective). Meanwhile, if it is scrambled after doing x, I am left > with 8 incorrectly oriented corners. Of course, I could turn the cube > so that all corners are correctly oriented, but this would make > memorization of permutation very hard since I wouldn't be used to > this new ordering of the centers. > > Macky > > p.s. I could even use the identity scramble for an example, but just > to make a point, R2 was easier =) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > It's a formality issue. Because in blindfold cubing, the > competitor > > himself has defined a top and a front throughout the entire solve. > I > > mean, when I scramble a cube, I scramble it with yellow on top and > > green in the front. If I were blindfolding cubing, that's how I > would > > want the cube placed in front of me. > > > > If you were to go back and redo your solve, it also makes things > easier > > because the scramble orientation would be the same as your solve > > orientation. It definitely matters very little for the solve but > the > > principle of the whole thing... you're given a scramble algorithm > and > > if the competitor is going to define things, there's no reason you > > shouldn't do it the same way especially since it won't make a > > difference in the solve. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 26, 2005, at 2:49 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > > > Huh? What's so special about blindfold cubing here? I'd almost > claim > > > it matters less there than in speedcubing... > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan
1224. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 19:05:27 +1100

On Sat, Feb 26, 2005 at 07:20:45PM -0800, Tyson Mao wrote:

> You keep saying the word "unnatural for cubing" but you really don't
> say anything about what unnatural and natural are. Without putting in
> any arguments, I do not believe you can claim that one is more
> "natural" than the other.

The arguments have already been put forward. Please refer to 2003/2004.

I do not recall any arguments to support the claim that StackMats are
natural for speedcubing. There are comments along the lines of
"StackMats are not perfect for speedcubing, but the problems are
relatively small. You can get used to using them, and after you do, they
work quite well. We also need a standard timer for tournaments and
StackMats have filled that role quite well. Maybe there exist better
speedcubing timers than the StackMat, but it is unclear whether they
increase the risk of cheating. We already know the StackMats work quite
well so there's no reason to change."

If you have found something about StackMats that are more natural for
speedcubing than Eric's timer, please tell me.

Ryan


1225. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 12:02:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... > wrote: > If you have found something about StackMats that are more natural for > speedcubing than Eric's timer, please tell me. - They prevent cheating better (including unintentional). - They work for all puzzles. I won't say they're "natural" (because I don't know what that is) but I will say they're almost perfect (price being the main problem). Cheers! Stefan
1226. [Speed cubing group] Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 12:18:53 -0000

I think you really really ought to mention the context. If someone defines orientation different from you (e.g. rotated by x) then for him that very same scramble is awful, while the one that's awful for you is perfect for him. I'd say it doesn't matter at all if you look at one solve unless the scrambler knows you and intentionally wants to give you a hard scramble. But with random scrambles it is no issue. It doesn't even matter to compare different people solving the same scramble. The only context I agree it does matter is when you want to solve the same scramble twice, like Tyson mentioned, since then you'd want to use the *same* cube orientation, but only the same, and it doesn't matter which one. But I'd like to add I think it's important that the scrambles are executed correctly, especially in blindsolving. That will at least guarantee that the same number of pieces are already solved, or at the right position but badly oriented, and that the "parities" are the same for everyone. Though I know different people have different amount of trouble with these things, too (e.g. I hate goodPerm+badOrient but parity is nothing). Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > Sorry, I was being dumb. That's a very bad scramble for this example, > and "I" is even worse. =) > > Better scramble: U' R' F2 L D F L2 U L' U2 R2 L' F2 R' L2 B U2 B > Holding your cube the way you do to memorize it and scramble. > Orientation is done. Now, holding your cube the way you do to > memorize, do x and then scramble. Now do x', and you see that now you > have four corners to orient. You _could_ start with all corners > oriented correctly by not doing that x', but it would be very hard to > memorize the permutation this way. > > Macky > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" > <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > > > There was a brief exchange between Dror and me about this at > WC2003. > > Because we always memorize and solve with a fixed orientation of > the > > centers (so that permutation is easy to memorize), while the > > permutation is virtually not affected, orientation can be very > > different when scrambled from a different direction. > > > > Take this scramble: R2 > > > > I always memorize my cubes with blue on top and green in front > > (Japanese color scheme...haha). If the cube is scramble with blue > on > > top and green in front, corner orientation is already done (from my > > perspective). Meanwhile, if it is scrambled after doing x, I am > left > > with 8 incorrectly oriented corners. Of course, I could turn the > cube > > so that all corners are correctly oriented, but this would make > > memorization of permutation very hard since I wouldn't be used to > > this new ordering of the centers. > > > > Macky > > > > p.s. I could even use the identity scramble for an example, but > just > > to make a point, R2 was easier =) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > It's a formality issue. Because in blindfold cubing, the > > competitor > > > himself has defined a top and a front throughout the entire > solve. > > I > > > mean, when I scramble a cube, I scramble it with yellow on top > and > > > green in the front. If I were blindfolding cubing, that's how I > > would > > > want the cube placed in front of me. > > > > > > If you were to go back and redo your solve, it also makes things > > easier > > > because the scramble orientation would be the same as your solve > > > orientation. It definitely matters very little for the solve but > > the > > > principle of the whole thing... you're given a scramble algorithm > > and > > > if the competitor is going to define things, there's no reason > you > > > shouldn't do it the same way especially since it won't make a > > > difference in the solve. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Feb 26, 2005, at 2:49 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > > > > > Huh? What's so special about blindfold cubing here? I'd almost > > claim > > > > it matters less there than in speedcubing... > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > Stefan
1227. [Speed cubing group] Re: Toy Fair Story
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 13:36:12 -0000


Hey guys,

Here's the clip from MSNBC (I'm national!!). You can briefly see
two of my students (Kamran Jehle and Krishanu Sankar) and myself.

1. Click on the link below to go to the "Countdown with Keith
Olbermann" show page.

2. Scroll down about 1/4 of the page to the section
called "ODDBALL"

3. Click on "Feb. 22: Elks on the run" This should automatically
launch the MSN video player (RealPlayer or Windows Media Player)
(speed depends on your connection).

4. You'll have to sit through a commercial. Once the Countdown
section begins, you can scroll to about 1:04 to see my segment.

http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036677/

Ian





1228. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 14:04:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p. .. > > wrote: > > > If you have found something about StackMats that are more natural > for > > speedcubing than Eric's timer, please tell me. > > - They prevent cheating better (including unintentional). > - They work for all puzzles. 1229. Rubik's Cube Test
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 17:51:32 -0000


It's nice that all of you are posting your scores. A few things:

(1) Per: how can you know 1/3 of Erno?

(2) Why are people taking the effort to know how to solve it
blindfolded but not to be able to solve it over their head?

(3) There isn't a standardized ruler stick, just compare against each
other.

(4) Add more things, if you think of them! Don't just take it as a
final version! If there's something cool you can do with the Cube
(like solve it looking in a mirror, or do it in a really hard/obscure
way like top and bottom first then middle, or have actually finished a
cube of size > 9x9x9, or do it without using your thumbs) then just
make a suggestion to add it!

(5) Just for curiosity's sake, I'm posting a revised version with the
proper indentation (apparently Yahoo doesn't take kindly to multiple
spaces) and also the scores I'd get:

I know...
[X] how to solve the Cube
[X] .. in less than a minute
[ ] .. .. 5+ ways
[ ] .. in less than 20 seconds
[ ] .. in less than 65 moves
[X] what OLL stands for
[X] what BYO stands for
[X] what ZB stands for
[ ] what AUF stands for
[ ] what BLD stands for
[X] who Erno Rubik is
[X] who Uwe Meffert is
[X] who Terutoshi Ishige is
[X] who Shotaro Makisumi is
[X] what the WCA is
[ ] .. and am in it
[ ] .. .. and have a high-up position

I have...
[X] a Rubik's Cube
[X] .. 5+ Cubes
[ ] .. 25+ Cubes
[ ] .. .. 25+ different Cubes
[X] a 4x4x4
[X] .. and can solve it
[ ] .. .. in less than two minutes
[X] a 5x5x5
[X] .. and can solve it
[ ] .. .. in less than three minutes
[X] cube lubrication
[ ] 3 kinds or more
[X] a Megaminx
[X] a Square-1
[ ] .. and can solve it in less than a minute
[ ] a Dogic
[ ] .. more than one kind
[ ] .. made my own kind
[ ] a nontrivial cube mod
[ ] .. that Tony Fisher made
[ ] .. that I made
[X] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise
[X] knockoff Cubes
[X] .. just because they're Cubes
[ ] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles
[ ] .. which is famous
[ ] won in a championship
[ ] a WR
[ ] .. more than one WR

I know... [2]
[X] more than ten algorithms
[ ] .. 100 algorithms
[ ] .. the entire ZB method
[ ] .. all 1211 LL algorithms
[ ][ ][ ] Erno Rubik
[X] how to disassemble a Cube
[X] .. without breaking it
[X] .. including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5
[ ] .. including an Eastsheen 2x2x2
[ ] how to solve the Rubik's Magic
[ ] .. in less than three seconds
[X] what the Superflip is
[ ] .. an optimal solution
[ ] .. all optimal solutions
[X] more than 5 pretty patterns by heart
[ ] .. more than 10
[ ] .. more than 50
[X] what a supercube group is

I like...
[X] to solve the Cube
[ ] .. even in the bathroom
[ ] .. underwater
[ ] .. during meals
[ ] .. in my dreams
[X] hanging around in cubing forums
[X] to take twisty puzzles apart
[ ] .. and make other things out of them

I can solve the cube...
[X] with thick gloves
[X] on a keychain cube
[ ] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded]
[ ] in one breath
[X] above my head
[ ] in front of a crowd
[ ] and teach others to solve it
[ ] and do so more than a hundred times a day
[X] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes
[X] on the computer
[ ] .. on a "flat cube" on the computer
[ ] in my head
[X] to any possible pattern
[ ] by telling someone what moves to make
[ ] by doing the moves someone tells me to make
[X] with one hand
[ ] with either hand
[ ] with one in each hand simultaneously
[ ] with chopsticks
[X] taking account of center rotations
[ ] while juggling
[X] while talking
[ ] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano)
[X] choosing one side to never twist
[ ] in the 2-generator subgroup
[ ] in the half-turn subgroup
[ ] in the antislice subgroup
[ ] while drunk (or high)

1232. OLL algs
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 19:16:25 -0000


Does anybody recommend learning the OLL algs in any type of order?
It seems somewhat silly to just learn them in a random order, so I
was wondering if anyone could make a suggestion.

~Bob





1233. Re: [Speed cubing group] OLL algs
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 11:17:20 -0800

Learn the ones with the crosses first. Then, I'm not sure... I just
kind of went down the list actually.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 27, 2005, at 11:16 AM, rubikscubewhiz wrote:

> Does anybody recommend learning the OLL algs in any type of order?
> It seems somewhat silly to just learn them in a random order, so I
> was wondering if anyone could make a suggestion.
>
> ~Bob




1234. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 11:27:23 -0800

I assure you, in the blindfold rounds, we (usually I) check the
scramble state of the cubes quite carefully. I mean, for me, it could
be kind of bad if someone set a world record (which is always a
possibility with Macky) and then went back and wanted to recreate the
solve and then realized I had scrambled the cube wrong.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 27, 2005, at 4:18 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> But I'd like to add I think it's important that the scrambles are
> executed correctly, especially in blindsolving. That will at least
> guarantee that the same number of pieces are already solved, or at the
> right position but badly oriented, and that the "parities" are the
> same for everyone. Though I know different people have different
> amount of trouble with these things, too (e.g. I hate
> goodPerm+badOrient but parity is nothing).




1235. Re: [Speed cubing group] OLL algs
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 11:55:11 -0800

I would learn them in order of decreasing probability of appearance. Learn the ones that show up the most first, and work your way down. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Sun, 27 Feb 2005 11:17:20 -0800, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > Learn the ones with the crosses first. Then, I'm not sure... I just > kind of went down the list actually. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > On Feb 27, 2005, at 11:16 AM, rubikscubewhiz wrote: > > > Does anybody recommend learning the OLL algs in any type of order? > > It seems somewhat silly to just learn them in a random order, so I > > was wondering if anyone could make a suggestion. > > > > ~Bob > > > > Yahoo! 1236. Re: [Speed cubing group] OLL algs
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 12:09:15 -0800 (PST)

visit my site http://cubing.blogspot.com i put two algs up there on how to make an oll cross. from that, then you can do OLL with edges already flipped forming a cross, like the sune. double sune ,bruno and the others. that is how i got started, and i learnt the rest of the OLL on how often they occur. good luck --- rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@...> wrote: > > Does anybody recommend learning the OLL algs in any > type of order? > It seems somewhat silly to just learn them in a > random order, so I > was wondering if anyone could make a suggestion. > > ~Bob > > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Take Yahoo! Mail with you! Get it on your mobile phone. http://mobile.yahoo.com/maildemo
1237. Re: OLL algs
From: "Leyan Lo" <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 21:33:48 -0000

Start with all the algs with the cross in place, and then all the ones with no edges oriented because those are a pain. Fill in the rest as you go. Learn the algorithm's inverse at the same time so you can practice. Solved cube -> apply inverse alg -> OLL state -> apply alg -> solved cube. Also, it's good to learn the mirror algorithm at the same time -- just switch hands and do the same motions. You can knock down four algorithms at the same time this way, by learning the inverse, mirror, and mirror inverse. this is not always the case, as there are some algorithms that are symmetric and have no mirrors, and some that are their own inverses. Leyan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > Does anybody recommend learning the OLL algs in any type of order? > It seems somewhat silly to just learn them in a random order, so I > was wondering if anyone could make a suggestion. > > ~Bob
1238. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2005 22:01:55 -0000

Until we all have timers directly built into our Rubik's cubes...and until those timers can wirelessly transmit the solving times, and scramble themselves...perhaps we will have to use the stackmats... They prevent unintentional forms of cheating, and have worked for a while already. That having been said, I still plan on purchasing a rubik's timer...I think that would be a great travel/college dorm room item to have. ~Just my 2 cents. Joe Spadafora --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... > > wrote: > > > If you have found something about StackMats that are more natural > for > > speedcubing than Eric's timer, please tell me. > > - They prevent cheating better (including unintentional). > - They work for all puzzles. > > I won't say they're "natural" (because I don't know what that is) but > I will say they're almost perfect (price being the main problem). > > Cheers! > Stefan

1240. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 10:03:39 +1100

On Sun, Feb 27, 2005 at 12:02:13PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> I won't say they're "natural" (because I don't know what that is)

I'm not going to argue about the word "natural", so here's another word:
"well suited". It doesn't have quite the same meaning, but it is close
enough.

> > If you have found something about StackMats that are more natural
> > for speedcubing than Eric's timer, please tell me.
>
> - They prevent cheating better (including unintentional).
> - They work for all puzzles.

The first point is on topic. The second is an answer to a different
question.

Are there any more points to add to the list?

Ryan

you cannot define either for a general population of cubers.

1242. Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 02:07:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I think you really really ought to mention the context. If someone > defines orientation different from you (e.g. rotated by x) then for > him that very same scramble is awful, while the one that's awful for > you is perfect for him. Right. And to avoid this difference, each competitor picks in advance his top color and front color (or at least this was what I thought to be the reason). > I'd say it doesn't matter at all if you look at one solve unless the > scrambler knows you and intentionally wants to give you a hard > scramble. But with random scrambles it is no issue. It matters because you only get a few attempts, and so having an easier orientation on one of the solves can dramatically change the outcome of the competition? > It doesn't even matter to compare different people solving the same > scramble. The only context I agree it does matter is when you want to > solve the same scramble twice, like Tyson mentioned, since then you'd > want to use the *same* cube orientation, but only the same, and it > doesn't matter which one. > > But I'd like to add I think it's important that the scrambles are > executed correctly, especially in blindsolving. That will at least > guarantee that the same number of pieces are already solved, or at the > right position but badly oriented, and that the "parities" are the > same for everyone. Though I know different people have different > amount of trouble with these things, too (e.g. I hate > goodPerm+badOrient but parity is nothing). > > Cheers! > Stefan Agreed. =) Macky > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" > <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > > > Sorry, I was being dumb. That's a very bad scramble for this > example, > > and "I" is even worse. =) > > > > Better scramble: U' R' F2 L D F L2 U L' U2 R2 L' F2 R' L2 B U2 B > > Holding your cube the way you do to memorize it and scramble. > > Orientation is done. Now, holding your cube the way you do to > > memorize, do x and then scramble. Now do x', and you see that now > you > > have four corners to orient. You _could_ start with all corners > > oriented correctly by not doing that x', but it would be very hard > to > > memorize the permutation this way. > > > > Macky

1246. Re: Scrambles and color schemes
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 10:39:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > I'd say it doesn't matter at all if you look at one solve unless > the > > scrambler knows you and intentionally wants to give you a hard > > scramble. But with random scrambles it is no issue. > > It matters because you only get a few attempts, and so having an > easier orientation on one of the solves can dramatically change the > outcome of the competition? Think of it this way: Let there be a "standard orientation" for everyone, let's say "brightest" color on top and brightest adjacent to it at front. The cube orientation you choose is nothing else than a cube rotation, let's say (x z'). Then the random scramble RS is applied. But the whole thing together is nothing but the algorithm (x z' RS), which is also a random scramble. By choosing an orientation you don't win anything. You seem to say it's good to choose because it can give you an easy scramble. But it can just as well give you a hard scramble and then you'll wish you hadn't made your choice. If it's random, it's random. Whether you rotate the cube before the scramble (e.g. x z' RS) or after it (e.g. RS x z') doesn't matter. Yes, it will give different results, but you can't say the first way is generally better for you. Cheers! Stefan
1247. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...>

Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 10:57:31 -0000

Just pick it up and put it down. /Gustav --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p...> wrote: > On Sun, Feb 27, 2005 at 03:09:39PM -0800, Tyson Mao wrote: > > > Substituting "well suited" for "natural" doesn't change the fact that > > you cannot define either for a general population of cubers. > > So far, we have: > > - StackMats prevent cheating (including unintentional) better than > Eric's timer. > > > I am asking for positional arguments. Not arguments that everyone agrees > with. You're right, not everyone will agree with what is natural or well > suited for speedcubing. Please add your own position to the list (if you > have any). > > The list will be useful because such a list doesn't already exist. > > Ryan

1251. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol

I must agree with both of those statements. Certainly using the Stackmat is easier than speedsolving. :) I have a question: has there been any problem with using the Stackmats that we need to change our timer? It seems to me that they are (almost) optimal for ensuring fair competitions, preventing cheating, and recording accurate times. ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gustav Fredell" > <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > > > I think in favor of the Rubikstimer that it is more intuitive to use > > for someone who has never used a stackmat or a the new timer. 1252. Re: [Speed cubing group] Concerts This Weekend
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 14:56:14 -0000

Haha, true. 1253. Re: [Speed cubing group] Concerts This Weekend
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>

Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 15:03:38 -0000

Hey! I'd go if it didn't cost me $500 plus taking the best part of a day to get there :-P And the best part of another day to get home ;-) -Per PS! And Francois would go if he wasn't on holiday ... lol ... He plays cello ;-) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > Haha, true. If it wouldn't cost me hundreds of dollars to get > there, I'd definitely be there too. :) Good luck Tyson. > > ~Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > I'll try to be there for you Tyson. > > > > > > > > Shame I'm in a different continent, makes travelling a bit tricky : > ( > > > > > > > > Dan ;) > > > > > > > > _____ > > > > From: Tyson Mao [mailto:tmao@i...] > > Sent: 28 February 2005 11:28 > > To: mbrown@g...; Xiangyun Wang; Anneila Sargent; Richard Ellis; > > lynne hillenbrand; Heun Jin Lee; fming@h...; Nick Scoville; > > wws@a...; Betsy Abrams; Shri Kulkarni > > Cc: Karin Oberg; Monica Mao; Sam Lawler; zzxia83@i...; > > chaoyi@u...; Tammy Dong; Anthony G.Mendoza; 'Mark Polinkovsky'; > > stephafc@u...; amos@i...; Scott Medling; > > flems@u...; tcneo@i...; richwang@u...; > > damiano@u...; simonque@i...; Amber N.Swenson; > > cassie_chou@h...; Vivian U; Craig Countryman; James D.Yoon; > > llkwan@u...; chang@i...; mmaindi@h...; Rachel Stevenson; > > Macky Makisumi; Francesca K.Colonnese; sschang@u...; John Keith; > Meaghan > > Paceley; Michael E.Turk; escher@p...; Priya Kollipara; > > csiu@i...; akil@i...; jankausk@c...; > > parag@i...; simon@a...; Joseph E.Gonzalez; Tyson > > Mao; Brad Cenko; Fiddlesmom@a...; Timothy Nguyen; Anne Rajala; > > jessetpt@u...; surratt@c... > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Concerts This Weekend > > > > > > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > I'm writing this e-mail just to invite you all to this weekends > > concerts performed by the Caltech/Occidental Symphony orchestra. > The > > performances will be on Saturday March 5 at Thorne Hall at > Occidental > > College and on Sunday March 6 at Ramo Audiotirum at Caltech. 1254. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 16:49:12 -0000


(See comments below, these are from two different previous posts).
This message is long, but I don't feel that there has been any
objective debate about this issue yet. Everyone is either for or
against the timer(s) of their choice right from the start of their
messages and, frankly, it is getting annoying and I find the
arguments childish.

Here is my attempt at the first objective argument.

--------------------

> I think in favor of the Rubikstimer that it is more intuitive to
> use for someone who has never used a stackmat or a the new
> timer. Just pick it up and put it down.

-----------------

> ... has there been any problem with using the Stackmats that we
> need to change our timer? It seems to me that they are (almost)
> optimal for ensuring fair competitions, preventing cheating, and
> recording accurate times.

-----------------

(end replies from other messages)

It seems that everyone has already made their decision as to which
timer they like, and no one seems willing to compromise. Well here
is my attempt to try to list pros and cons and lets decide this.
Obviously a lot of money and time is being spent in developing this
new Rubik's timer, so let's not bash it down before even trying it
just because the stackmat has worked so far.

----

Stackmat pros:
1) Timer cannot start before hands touch the cube. Simply specify a
rough distance that is further than fingers can reach for the intial
start position of the cube and all these problems about manipulating
before starting the timer dissapear.

2) It is *very* difficult to simultaneously stop the timer and
continue doing a move. The cube has to end up on the table, and
bringing it down to the mat and trying to do a move all very quickly
and all at the same time is very hard. This is not a likely option
for a common "cheat"

Stackmat cons:
1) If you are not used to the distance between the hand pads, you
can think you've stopped the timer, but not applied enough pressure
to the pads correctly and it won't stop.

2) If you haven't practiced bringing your cube to the timer along
with your hands, it seems the only reasonable way to stop it quickly
is to drop your cube. This leads to misaligned faces and damage to
larger/more fragile cubes/puzzles.

3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube from
hands flat on the table, solve it, bring the cube back down to the
table and place your hands in their original start positions.

4) High cost makes it difficult for most to buy one to practice and
get used to it before competitions.

---------

Rubik's Timer pros:
1) Assuming someone doesn't cheat, you could lift the cube from the
optical sensor and start solving more fluidly and quickly than from
the start pads of a stackmat.

2) Nearing the end of the solve you could "hover" over the timer,
close to the table, for the last few moves and lightly set down your
cube to stop it rather than practicing the "bring your cube to the
table" stackmat manuever.

3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube (not from
hands flat on the table, regardless of whether this is required as
procedure or not for the start); plus solve the cube, plus set the
cube back down.

Rubik's Timer cons:
1) It is possible to misalign the U layer from the scramble before
even starting the timer.

2) It is possible to set the cube down, thus stopping the timer, and
finishing the final portion of a U turn (even if this is
unintentional).

3) If trying to go quickly, you may slam your cube down too hard,
causing damage (this can easily be fixed with padding).

------------------

I don't know how much the Rubik's timer will cost, but that is
obviously going to be either a pro or con. Notice I haven't
included anything about the Rubik's timer's ability to provide
scrambles, do averages etc.. I think this is totally and wholly
irrelevant to the issue of which timer to use in competitions,
though I think it is an interesting and useful addition to the timer
itself.

My objective consensus on this issue is that the cons of the Rubik's
timer will likely lead to video analysis for potential new records
to see if any sort of U turn was down before or after the timer was
started/stopped. The pros of the Rubik timer are nice, in that it
times a closer margin around just the solve than the stackmat does.
Also the fact that it is easy to learn how to efficiently use a
Rubik's timer is a big pro in my opinion.

Subjectively, the cons for the Rubik timer, to me, heavily outweigh
the pros in that I don't want to lose a fast solve becuase, on
watching the video analysis of a fast solve, I hit the U layer as my
hands grabbed the cube and before I picked it up. I would be very
frustrated by the potential time disqualifications this timer would
bring to competitions.

Objectively looking at the stackmat it has about as many cons as the
rubik timer, but it doesn't include the likelihood of a bad turn
before starting the solve, as the rubik timer does.

Disturbing for me about the stackmat is that it times a larger
margin around the solve than the Rubik's timer, and that it takes
lots of practice and familiarity with a Stackmat to use it
efficiently in a competition.

Personally I think both timers are bad, but both are also good.
Subjectively now, I think the cons of the rubik's timer are pretty
large. I wouldn't want to use one in a competition as the timer is
designed right now, with the likelihood of disqualified records and
fast solves because of this "U-face problem".

I also don't like the stackmat because it times a larger margin of
the solve that we are interested in. However this may be necessary
to ensure good flow and ease of timing in a competition.

Personally I think both timers suck and we should all go to video
analysis for it's purity sake. However this too has huge problems
with money and supplies.

I say that last unreasonable option (and it is most unreasonable, I
would never campaing in favor of completely video analysis
tournaments) only to say that I think both timers suck, I am not in
either camp. However, based on the qualifications of the Rubik's
timer and my opinions as a competitor, I right now prefer the
stackmat simply as a lesser of two evils.

If the "U-face problem" could be fixed with the start and stop of
the solve on the Rubik's timer, I would greatly prefer the Rubik's
timer over the stackmat as it has better pros and (with the absence
of those two huge cons on my list), not so many cons left.

Come one guys, stop being so subjective and partial and not even
giving valid arguments. We're all smarter and better than that.
Just because the Stackmat has worked before doesn't mean it's a
great timer and we need to accept everything status quo. Also, just
because the Rubik's timer has so many great pros doesn't make it a
great timer either, as a competitor I am VERY nervous about this
problem with U face turns on the start and stop.

**Both timer have big downfalls** So don't get all high and mighty
in supporting your favorite.

Both timer suck, but in my opinion with all the information on both
timers, I would prefer to have a stackmat in front of me in a
competition over a Rubik's timer until this "U-face problem" is
fixed on the Rubik's timer.

If and when the U-face problem is fixed, I would much rather have a
Rubik's timer in front of me during a competition.

My two (and hopefully sufficiently objective) cents,
Chris

P.S. Please let's continue this discussion with arguments about the
pros and cons of these timers, and not advertisements about how your
favorite time is the übertimer and all other ones are crap.





1255. Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 17:07:31 -0000

In the interest of being objective I just realized one more con I forgot to include about the Stackmat2 that I think is definitely worth mentioning. The reset button is very close the base next to the right hand pad. If you bring your right hand down too close to the upraised middle portion, the fleshy part of your thumb will hit the reset button and you will lose the time before even seeing what it was. I discovered this when practicing some blindfolded solves, and I think it could also happen to those who are unfamiliar and/or using the stackmat for the first time. Simply that the possibility is there is a con, and worth considering. Though I said in my last message that I prefer the stackmat given all the current information, this con make me even more willing to go over to the rubik timer if that U-face problem can be fixed. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > (See comments below, these are from two different previous posts). > This message is long, but I don't feel that there has been any > objective debate about this issue yet. Everyone is either for or > against the timer(s) of their choice right from the start of their > messages and, frankly, it is getting annoying and I find the > arguments childish. > > Here is my attempt at the first objective argument. > > -------------------- > > > I think in favor of the Rubikstimer that it is more intuitive to > > use for someone who has never used a stackmat or a the new > > timer. Just pick it up and put it down. > > ----------------- > > > ... has there been any problem with using the Stackmats that we > > need to change our timer? It seems to me that they are (almost) > > optimal for ensuring fair competitions, preventing cheating, and > > recording accurate times. > > ----------------- > > (end replies from other messages) > > It seems that everyone has already made their decision as to which > timer they like, and no one seems willing to compromise. Well here > is my attempt to try to list pros and cons and lets decide this. > Obviously a lot of money and time is being spent in developing this > new Rubik's timer, so let's not bash it down before even trying it > just because the stackmat has worked so far. > > ---- > > Stackmat pros: > 1) Timer cannot start before hands touch the cube. Simply specify a > rough distance that is further than fingers can reach for the intial > start position of the cube and all these problems about manipulating > before starting the timer dissapear. > > 2) It is *very* difficult to simultaneously stop the timer and > continue doing a move. This is not a likely option > for a common "cheat" > > Stackmat cons: > 1) If you are not used to the distance between the hand pads, you > can think you've stopped the timer, but not applied enough pressure > to the pads correctly and it won't stop. > > 2) If you haven't practiced bringing your cube to the timer along > with your hands, it seems the only reasonable way to stop it quickly > is to drop your cube. This leads to misaligned faces and damage to > larger/more fragile cubes/puzzles. > > 3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube from > hands flat on the table, solve it, bring the cube back down to the > table and place your hands in their original start positions. > > 4) High cost makes it difficult for most to buy one to practice and > get used to it before competitions. > > --------- > > Rubik's Timer pros: > 1) Assuming someone doesn't cheat, you could lift the cube from the > optical sensor and start solving more fluidly and quickly than from > the start pads of a stackmat. > > 2) Nearing the end of the solve you could "hover" over the timer, > close to the table, for the last few moves and lightly set down your > cube to stop it rather than practicing the "bring your cube to the > table" stackmat manuever. > > 3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube (not from > hands flat on the table, regardless of whether this is required as > procedure or not for the start); plus solve the cube, plus set the > cube back down. > > Rubik's Timer cons: > 1) It is possible to misalign the U layer from the scramble before > even starting the timer. > > 2) It is possible to set the cube down, thus stopping the timer, and > finishing the final portion of a U turn (even if this is > unintentional). > > 3) If trying to go quickly, you may slam your cube down too hard, > causing damage (this can easily be fixed with padding). > > ------------------ > > I don't know how much the Rubik's timer will cost, but that is > obviously going to be either a pro or con. 1256. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 17:46:56 -0000

Lots of good points Chris. Since I havent used either I won't comment. Although I've ordered a stackmat for my birthday! When I broke the world record for one hand it was timed by a guy holding a stop watch - is that so terrible! It also has pros and cons of course but possibly no more than the two options already under discussion. Higher technology isn't always better (although may well be in this case). Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "cmhardw" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, February 28, 2005 5:07 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol In the interest of being objective I just realized one more con I forgot to include about the Stackmat2 that I think is definitely worth mentioning. I discovered this when practicing some blindfolded solves, and I think it could also happen to those who are unfamiliar and/or using the stackmat for the first time. Notice I haven't > included anything about the Rubik's timer's ability to provide > scrambles, do averages etc.. I think this is totally and wholly > irrelevant to the issue of which timer to use in competitions, > though I think it is an interesting and useful addition to the timer > itself. > > My objective consensus on this issue is that the cons of the Rubik's > timer will likely lead to video analysis for potential new records > to see if any sort of U turn was down before or after the timer was > started/stopped. The pros of the Rubik timer are nice, in that it > times a closer margin around just the solve than the stackmat does. > Also the fact that it is easy to learn how to efficiently use a > Rubik's timer is a big pro in my opinion. > > Subjectively, the cons for the Rubik timer, to me, heavily outweigh > the pros in that I don't want to lose a fast solve becuase, on > watching the video analysis of a fast solve, I hit the U layer as my > hands grabbed the cube and before I picked it up. I would be very > frustrated by the potential time disqualifications this timer would > bring to competitions. > > Objectively looking at the stackmat it has about as many cons as the > rubik timer, but it doesn't include the likelihood of a bad turn > before starting the solve, as the rubik timer does. > > Disturbing for me about the stackmat is that it times a larger > margin around the solve than the Rubik's timer, and that it takes > lots of practice and familiarity with a Stackmat to use it > efficiently in a competition. > > Personally I think both timers are bad, but both are also good. > Subjectively now, I think the cons of the rubik's timer are pretty > large. I wouldn't want to use one in a competition as the timer is > designed right now, with the likelihood of disqualified records and > fast solves because of this "U-face problem". > > I also don't like the stackmat because it times a larger margin of > the solve that we are interested in. However this may be necessary > to ensure good flow and ease of timing in a competition. > > Personally I think both timers suck and we should all go to video > analysis for it's purity sake. However this too has huge problems > with money and supplies. > > I say that last unreasonable option (and it is most unreasonable, I > would never campaing in favor of completely video analysis > tournaments) only to say that I think both timers suck, I am not in > either camp. However, based on the qualifications of the Rubik's > timer and my opinions as a competitor, I right now prefer the > stackmat simply as a lesser of two evils. > > If the "U-face problem" could be fixed with the start and stop of > the solve on the Rubik's timer, I would greatly prefer the Rubik's > timer over the stackmat as it has better pros and (with the absence > of those two huge cons on my list), not so many cons left. > > Come one guys, stop being so subjective and partial and not even > giving valid arguments. We're all smarter and better than that. > Just because the Stackmat has worked before doesn't mean it's a > great timer and we need to accept everything status quo. Also, just > because the Rubik's timer has so many great pros doesn't make it a > great timer either, as a competitor I am VERY nervous about this > problem with U face turns on the start and stop. > > **Both timer have big downfalls** So don't get all high and mighty > in supporting your favorite. > > Both timer suck, but in my opinion with all the information on both > timers, I would prefer to have a stackmat in front of me in a > competition over a Rubik's timer until this "U-face problem" is > fixed on the Rubik's timer. > > If and when the U-face problem is fixed, I would much rather have a > Rubik's timer in front of me during a competition. > > My two (and hopefully sufficiently objective) cents, > Chris > > P.S. Please let's continue this discussion with arguments about the > pros and cons of these timers, and not advertisements about how your > favorite time is the ï¿½bertimer and all other ones are crap. Yahoo! Groups Links

[X] with one 'look' [i.e. blindfolded] [] in one breath [X] above my head [X] in front of a crowd (at least if I am the only cubist there) [X] and teach others to solve it I taught some people to solve blindfolded. [] and do so more than a hundred times a day (Is that teach others to solve it more than 100 times a day?) [] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes (No idea what that means - MIB never appeared as an acronym above.) [X] on the computer [] on a "flat cube" on the computer (Don't know what that is.) [X] in my head Surely, that's what one does with blindfold cubing. [X] to any possible pattern It's basically the same problem [X] by telling someone what moves to make Same again [] by doing the moves someone tells me to make Whether I can do that depends entirely on whether I have competent instruction on what moves to make! [X] with one hand (Blindfolded too) [X] with either hand [] with one in each hand simultaneously [] with chopsticks [X] taking account of center rotations [] while juggling [X] while talking [] while playing a musical instrument (includes piano) [X] choosing one side to never twist (I guess so, but not the supercube generally because then it may not be possible.) [X] in the 2-generator subgroup (which one, if you mean <U,R>, I think I probably can. If you mean the full group - which is in fact a 2-generator group - then I can do that too, but it takes a long time.) [] in the half-turn subgroup (probably, but I haven't thought about it) [] in the antislice subgroup (probably, but I haven't thought about it) [] while drunk (or high) I've solved it in a plane - does that count? I'm claiming 42 but that could be up or down some depending on interpretation. Can I get a point for inventing a method? Can I get a point for obtaining an optimization result? (Diameter of the orientation subgroup.)
1260. Re: 4x4 program- system needs
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:31:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > Hello... > I was just wondering about this. I know there has been discussion on 4x4 programs, and how they really can't be valid because of the _needed_ computer power. Well what exactly would be needed for there to be a "cube explorer" for the 4x4? or the 5x5? > > curious,... bm > > > > :) > --Brent I don't know about the programming side of things but I can say that one difficulty would be that the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 aren't like the 3x3x3 in the sense that unless you label the centres they don't have a group structure (under the usual generators). (There are moves that appear to do nothing in some situations that obviously do do things in other situations - e.g. a 3 cycle of centres.) What you could do (supposing the goal was the centre) is for each possible permutation X of the centres of the solved cube that leaves the cube solved (but possibly would change the supercube) obtain one fixed solution and then a solution optimal for that fixed solution concatenated with X for each X and then minimize over all such X. But that involves a lot of extra work - plus there are more standard generators. > > --------------------------------- > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Mail - now with 250MB free storage. Learn more. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1261. F2L Question
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:57:29 -0000


My question concerns the Fridrich F2L.

I'm in the middle of learning all those algorithms right now and I'm
trying to implement the ones I know into my current solution, but it
seems that quite often, I find that the edge piece that goes with the
corner I'm looking at isn't on the bottom layer (I solve the cross on
the top). I spend quite a bit of time looking before I realize that
I have to move on.

Are there any special tricks for doing the F2L without any of those
delays?





1262. Rubik's Cube Test: Reply and Notes
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 20:33:53 -0000

> > [ ] .. .. 5+ ways > (define "ways") That would be, do you know how to solve the cube in less than a minute using any of five different methods? > > [ ] .. in less than 20 seconds > > [ ] .. in less than 65 moves > for the above 2: I know how to do so but I can't do so (in the sense > that I know the sort of thing I would need to learn (algorithms, > dexterity, mental speed, recognition etc.) but I that doesn't mean I > am able to do all that stuff) Me too. Tough. > > [X] what BLD stands for > (assuming it's a particular piece/corner of the cube) I realized I overlooked that and that BLD has two different meanings. I propose to replace it with BRD to eliminate all possible confusion. > > [X] a 4x4x4 > > [X] .. and can solve it > (not the physical one, but the computer one for sure) That doesn't count, though; everybody 'has' a computer one (unless you programmed it yourself, in which case you can give yourself an auxiliary point or something). You can check off "and can solve it", though, even if you don't have one, as long as you can restore it to a proper solved state. > > [ ] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise > I didn't even know there was any. Oh, there's plenty. Rubik's Eclipse, Rubik's Infinity, and Rubik's Tac Toe are out now, and there are a lot of older ones like Rubik's ZigZaw. > > [ ] knockoff Cubes > Not sure what you mean - he didn't patent it, right? That's the thing - he does have a patent. Any cube made for profit without his permission or his company's permission is a knockoff Cube. Note that I use Cube with a capital C - a Rubik's Cube, just maybe not by Rubik, not anything cube-shaped. > > [X] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles > > [X] .. which is famous > (Kind of, but it's hosted at Jessica's page and I haven't updated it > in a while.) It doesn't matter if you update it or not. Although what site is it? How famous is it? > > [ ] a WR > I've got more than unofficial world record for the computer cubes up > at oinkleburger/puzzlingaddiction. Do they count? Meh, sure. Unless somebody beats you. :) > > [ ] .. .. including an Eastsheen 2x2x2 > (No, that one's broken!) I put that one on because Eastsheen 2x2x2s are notoriously difficult to disassemble. I'm surprised Macky knows how. > > [X] how to solve the Rubik's Magic > > [X] .. in less than three seconds Teach me how! Please! > > [X] what the Superflip is > > [X] .. an optimal solution > (to the superflip, or just any optimal solution?) > (I'm going to cheat here by specifying a long set of generators so > that I am bound to be optimal! But off the top of my head I don't > know an optimal solution to superflip in any of the standard metrics) An optimal solution specifically for the superflip. That's what the indentation is for. The point here is to have memorized an optimal solution to the superflip. For the "all optimal solutions" I'm looking for the ones in quarter- and face-turn notation, any others are extra credit (like slice notation, axis notation, Fxyz notation, clockwise turn notation, whatever). > > [ ] with thick gloves > (probably, but I haven't tried) You should. It's easy. > > [ ] on a keychain cube > (with thick gloves on a keychain cube? or just solve a keychain > cube? The latter yes probably, the former probably not.) Just solve a keychain cube. On the newer version it isn't indented. Extra credit for both, though. Maybe I'll add it next version. > > [X] in front of a crowd > (at least if I am the only cubist there) Does that really make a difference? > > [X] and teach others to solve it > I taught some people to solve blindfolded. I'd like to learn, myself. I can't stand all the "imagine labeling your cube, spend the next ten minutes figuring out the notation, then group everything together, etc etc" stuff. > > [ ] and do so more than a hundred times a day > (Is that teach others to solve it more than 100 times a day?) Heh, no. I'd be surprised if anyone converted 100 non-cubists in a month. > > [ ] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes > (No idea what that means - MIB never appeared as an acronym above.) Sorry. Mint In Box. That is - do you have unopened cubes with mint packaging that you would use except that you don't want to open them? > [ ] on a "flat cube" on the computer > (Don't know what that is.) This is a slightly more difficult computer cube where no perspective is even attempted and all stickers are laid as flat, parallel squares on the screen. Extra points if you can do it when the stickers are arranged in a weird pattern. > > [X] in my head > Surely, that's what one does with blindfold cubing. I should remove this, unless I can think of some gibberish like "but you have to visualize it!" > > [X] to any possible pattern > It's basically the same problem As what? I mean, if you're into an advanced method you might have conceptual problems with solving to a Giant Meson or a 6-H pattern. > > [X] by telling someone what moves to make > Same again Except when they can't see the cube. They do the moves you tell them to, and when they remove the blindfold they've solved it. > > [ ] by doing the moves someone tells me to make > Whether I can do that depends entirely on whether I have competent > instruction on what moves to make! True. Should be on the "to remove" list. > > [X] with one hand > (Blindfolded too) Heh. Nice. > > [ ] with one in each hand simultaneously Errata: You don't actually have to be able to concentrate on both cubes at once, although that would be cool. > > [X] choosing one side to never twist > (I guess so, but not the supercube generally because then it may not > be possible.) Of course not. Just on a normal cube. It's a fun excercise to turn the D face and then solve it without turning the D face again. > > [X] in the 2-generator subgroup > (which one, if you mean <U,R>, I think I probably can. If you mean > the full group - which is in fact a 2-generator group - then I can > do that too, but it takes a long time.) What do you mean, the full group is in fact a 2-generator group? I mean the <U,R> group thing. > > [ ] while drunk (or high) > I've solved it in a plane - does that count? Heh. That's a good idea to add. I haven't done it in a plane, but I'm traveling to France in three weeks and I'm definately bringing along my Eastsheen 5-by. > Can I get a point for inventing a method? Not in this version, but in the next version definately. > Can I get a point for obtaining an optimization result? (Diameter of > the orientation subgroup.) What do you mean exactly by the diameter of the orientation subgroup? Random ideas for cube points: - Inventing a cube-solving method or algorithm - Making a really cool cube-related video - Amount of life devoted to cubes

1264. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L Question
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 12:45:46 -0800

Oh yeah, I had a lot of problems with that. Hmmm... okay, take your
solved cube and do the following:

F U' F2 U F

Okay, so let's say you do a white cross and you scramble with yellow on
top and green in front. Ignore the orange/green pair for now. Let's
say that was was in the red/green slot and was unavailable. Let's do
the green red pair. Well... notice you have the corner free but the
edge is in the wrong place.

No problem, do U'. This move lines up the red/green corner with the
red/green edge.

Now, if this pair were in the right slot, we'd do the full algorithm.
It's not though, so we're going to do half of the algorithm, then
adjust the U, and then put it in. Here's what I'm talking about.

Do: U F' U' F

Notice now, the green/red pair is that position where it only takes a 3
move algorithm to put that slot in. Well, go ahead and do that.
Sometimes, you might have to do a U turn to AUF (adjust U face...
whoa... I never thought I'd use that) before putting in the pair.

Finish off with: F U' F'.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 28, 2005, at 11:57 AM, Ben King wrote:

> My question concerns the Fridrich F2L.
>
> I'm in the middle of learning all those algorithms right now and I'm
> trying to implement the ones I know into my current solution, but it
> seems that quite often, I find that the edge piece that goes with the
> corner I'm looking at isn't on the bottom layer (I solve the cross on
> the top). I spend quite a bit of time looking before I realize that
> I have to move on.
>
> Are there any special tricks for doing the F2L without any of those
> delays?

Hello everybody, a question:

What's the record using Fridrich?

I don't know how far can an human go with that mhetod... maybe 17
seconds.

Thanks

Naranjagrillo,





1266. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich' limits
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 13:21:46 -0800

Definitely a lot faster. Macky averages sub-15 and he's not applying
COLL OLL nor does he do a VH-F2L or anything on everything...

What I'm trying to say is, Macky averages sub-15 doing mostly just the
basic Fridrich steps.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 28, 2005, at 1:18 PM, naranjagrillo wrote:

> What's the record using Fridrich?
>
> I don't know how far can an human go with that mhetod... maybe 17
> seconds.

1267. Re: 4x4 program- system needs
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 21:33:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > I was just wondering about this. I know there has been discussion on 4x4 programs, and how they really can't be valid because of the _needed_ computer power. Well what exactly would be needed for there to be a "cube explorer" for the 4x4? or the 5x5? A clever idea. Cube Explorer isn't so fast because it brutally explores the full cube state in some efficient way, but because it does it in two nicely separated steps, combining the first two and the last two steps of the 4-step Thistlethwaite algorithm. Each of the 2 steps does use brute force, though. Think about normal speedsolving. The bigger the puzzle gets, the more steps you need. For a 4x4 or 5x5 Cube Explorer I guess you'd need a few more steps, since each step can be just so complex. But finding nice steps would be the first goal... Cheers! Stefan
1268. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L Question
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 21:40:29 -0000

Gosh, Tyson! Do you have to use F turns all over the place?!? ;-) Cheers! Well... notice you have the corner free but the > edge is in the wrong place. > > No problem, do U'. This move lines up the red/green corner with the > red/green edge. > > Now, if this pair were in the right slot, we'd do the full algorithm. > It's not though, so we're going to do half of the algorithm, then > adjust the U, and then put it in. Here's what I'm talking about. > > Do: U F' U' F > > Notice now, the green/red pair is that position where it only takes a 3 > move algorithm to put that slot in. Well, go ahead and do that. > Sometimes, you might have to do a U turn to AUF (adjust U face... > whoa... I never thought I'd use that) before putting in the pair. > > Finish off with: F U' F'. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 28, 2005, at 11:57 AM, Ben King wrote: > > > My question concerns the Fridrich F2L. > > > > I'm in the middle of learning all those algorithms right now and I'm > > trying to implement the ones I know into my current solution, but it > > seems that quite often, I find that the edge piece that goes with the > > corner I'm looking at isn't on the bottom layer (I solve the cross on > > the top). I spend quite a bit of time looking before I realize that > > I have to move on. > > > > Are there any special tricks for doing the F2L without any of those > > delays?
1269. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L Question
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 13:46:15 -0800

Turn the cube!

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 28, 2005, at 1:40 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

1270. Re: Fridrich' limits
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 22:10:43 -0000

Yeah but I'm sure Macky uses a lot of stuff to influence the last layer with the last c/e pair. This still counts as Fridrich of course, but a sort of easier Fridrich since the odds for the OLLs change. Also, in a significant portion of the videos I've seen of Macky he ends with an edge three cycle, which implies liberal use of COLL, at least for video solves :-D I've also wondered that. What is the limit of Fridrich assuming just OLL/PLL without influencing the LL? (Of course allowing as many F2L tricks as you can manage.) Btw, I'm almost done learning the ZBF2L, I will be finished learning in about 2 weeks at my current pace, and after that I will start working on improving recognition on the newest cases of course. In about a month I will try doing an average and see how it affects my times. I'm very optimistic that recognition time will be insignificantly slower than normal F2L with practice (though still slower of course since the last slot of the F2L becomes a "look" instead of just plain intuition). I find it hard to believe that Macky doesn't use ZBF2L tricks or even straight up algs, but then again I do admit that it is possible. Opinion and hearsay :-D Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Definitely a lot faster. Macky averages sub-15 and he's not applying > COLL OLL nor does he do a VH-F2L or anything on everything... > > What I'm trying to say is, Macky averages sub-15 doing mostly just the > basic Fridrich steps. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

1272. How to buy a good cube?
From: "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 23:09:17 -0000


Hi all,

Today I went to a store to buy a Rubik's cube.
So I opened the package and played a little bit with three
cubes, but they were all stiff, so I ended up not buying one.
I am not sure if that is the case for all new cubes,
but I remember someone here in the group saying that
he has bought a cube from Walmart and it went smooth right
from the beginning.

Now my question:
If you buy a new cube, how do you know that it is a good speedcube?
(I tried to open the cube by a pop to see if it had arched centers but
the cube was still too stiff)

Have you ever encountered a case where the layers were easy
turn right from the beginning?

-Edgardo






1273. Re: How to buy a good cube?
From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 23:19:59 -0000

I prefer the Rubiks.com DIY cubes. If you prepare them right, they are smooth right from the beginning. All cubes I've ever bought at a store have been stiff, though some can be lubed and prepared to be excellent for speedcubing. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@g...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > Today I went to a store to buy a Rubik's cube. > So I opened the package and played a little bit with three > cubes, but they were all stiff, so I ended up not buying one. > I am not sure if that is the case for all new cubes, > but I remember someone here in the group saying that > he has bought a cube from Walmart and it went smooth right > from the beginning. > > Now my question: > If you buy a new cube, how do you know that it is a good speedcube? > (I tried to open the cube by a pop to see if it had arched centers but > the cube was still too stiff) > > Have you ever encountered a case where the layers were easy > turn right from the beginning? > > -Edgardo

From: "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@...>

Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 00:04:47 -0000

1275. Re: [Speed cubing group] How to buy a good cube?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 16:07:26 -0800

Yeah I have.

Actually, my best speedcubes were all great to turn from the beginning.
I mean, they weren't absolutely fabulous, but I could do pretty decent
times with those cubes. Back when I bought my cube no. 2 and cube no.
3, I was averaging about 35 to 40 seconds and I could solve the cube at
about the same times.

Maybe ask a store if you can open the boxes up and test them out?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology
