1277. [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 00:46:56 -0000

Thanks chris for putting this in a much better light than previously what was being done. I posted this question before and would really like an answer. Are there that many people trying to cheat and does not the judge have final say. I ask because I have never been to competition. While having never been I still get a feeling of honesty that pervades us. The honor system used on jess' site for the longest time worked quit well save the fact that some inet posers would arrive now and again or we would make a mistake. So he had to keep cleaning the times. I have yet to use either timer. I like the ideas of both and feel that they, while stronger each in specific areas, are basically on equal footing from my stand point. I want them both and I would not feel mistreated in the least were I to go to competition and see that either one was in use. So long as all people at that competition are using the same thing I would feel things are being handled fairly. I really like the Idea of having scrambles and other options. When I mix my cube I usually end with one of the hardest possible solves at least for me to do. When I do use algs for mixing provided by pc the mixes are more consistent. This would make my practice different. I have actually considered making some device to give me scrambles and for me that would be a large plus to the rubiks. Realistically I will buy both because I like options. Here area couple of solutions for one of the issues for each timer. Stackmat issue: reset button is easily pressed while finishing solve. This could be handled by using something to build a wall around the reset button thus recessing it. There are several things that could be used. Rubik's issue: possible cheat of U or D either blatantly or unintentionally. Put a wall on the timer that will be perpendicular. The whole timer could then be placed on a 45 degree angle like Gilles suggested on this page http://grrroux.free.fr/2flat.jpg. This makes it fair for left or right hands still and stops the cheat factor. It also reduces the chance of misalignment were someone to drop it into the v shape. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Lots of good points Chris. Since I havent used either I won't comment. > Although I've ordered a stackmat for my birthday! > When I broke the world record for one hand it was timed by a guy holding a > stop watch - is that so terrible! It also has pros and cons of course but > possibly no more than the two options already under discussion. Higher > technology isn't always better (although may well be in this case). > > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "cmhardw" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Monday, February 28, 2005 5:07 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol > > > > > In the interest of being objective I just realized one more con I > forgot to include about the Stackmat2 that I think is definitely worth > mentioning. > > The reset button is very close the base next to the right hand pad. > If you bring your right hand down too close to the upraised middle > portion, the fleshy part of your thumb will hit the reset button and > you will lose the time before even seeing what it was. > > I discovered this when practicing some blindfolded solves, and I think > it could also happen to those who are unfamiliar and/or using the > stackmat for the first time. > > Simply that the possibility is there is a con, and worth considering. > Though I said in my last message that I prefer the stackmat given all > the current information, this con make me even more willing to go over > to the rubik timer if that U-face problem can be fixed. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > (See comments below, these are from two different previous posts). > > This message is long, but I don't feel that there has been any > > objective debate about this issue yet. Everyone is either for or > > against the timer(s) of their choice right from the start of their > > messages and, frankly, it is getting annoying and I find the > > arguments childish. > > > > Here is my attempt at the first objective argument. > > > > -------------------- > > > > > I think in favor of the Rubikstimer that it is more intuitive to > > > use for someone who has never used a stackmat or a the new > > > timer. Just pick it up and put it down. > > > > ----------------- > > > > > ... has there been any problem with using the Stackmats that we > > > need to change our timer? It seems to me that they are (almost) > > > optimal for ensuring fair competitions, preventing cheating, and > > > recording accurate times. > > > > ----------------- > > > > (end replies from other messages) > > > > It seems that everyone has already made their decision as to which > > timer they like, and no one seems willing to compromise. Well here > > is my attempt to try to list pros and cons and lets decide this. > > Obviously a lot of money and time is being spent in developing this > > new Rubik's timer, so let's not bash it down before even trying it > > just because the stackmat has worked so far. > > > > ---- > > > > Stackmat pros: > > 1) Timer cannot start before hands touch the cube. Simply specify a > > rough distance that is further than fingers can reach for the intial > > start position of the cube and all these problems about manipulating > > before starting the timer dissapear. > > > > 2) It is *very* difficult to simultaneously stop the timer and > > continue doing a move. The cube has to end up on the table, and > > bringing it down to the mat and trying to do a move all very quickly > > and all at the same time is very hard. This is not a likely option > > for a common "cheat" > > > > Stackmat cons: > > 1) If you are not used to the distance between the hand pads, you > > can think you've stopped the timer, but not applied enough pressure > > to the pads correctly and it won't stop. > > > > 2) If you haven't practiced bringing your cube to the timer along > > with your hands, it seems the only reasonable way to stop it quickly > > is to drop your cube. This leads to misaligned faces and damage to > > larger/more fragile cubes/puzzles. > > > > 3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube from > > hands flat on the table, solve it, bring the cube back down to the > > table and place your hands in their original start positions. > > > > 4) High cost makes it difficult for most to buy one to practice and > > get used to it before competitions. > > > > --------- > > > > Rubik's Timer pros: > > 1) Assuming someone doesn't cheat, you could lift the cube from the > > optical sensor and start solving more fluidly and quickly than from > > the start pads of a stackmat. > > > > 2) Nearing the end of the solve you could "hover" over the timer, > > close to the table, for the last few moves and lightly set down your > > cube to stop it rather than practicing the "bring your cube to the > > table" stackmat manuever. > > > > 3) The final time is how long it takes to pick up the cube (not from > > hands flat on the table, regardless of whether this is required as > > procedure or not for the start); plus solve the cube, plus set the > > cube back down. > > > > Rubik's Timer cons: > > 1) It is possible to misalign the U layer from the scramble before > > even starting the timer. > > > > 2) It is possible to set the cube down, thus stopping the timer, and > > finishing the final portion of a U turn (even if this is > > unintentional). > > > > 3) If trying to go quickly, you may slam your cube down too hard, > > causing damage (this can easily be fixed with padding). > > > > ------------------ > > > > I don't know how much the Rubik's timer will cost, but that is > > obviously going to be either a pro or con. Notice I haven't > > included anything about the Rubik's timer's ability to provide > > scrambles, do averages etc.. I think this is totally and wholly > > irrelevant to the issue of which timer to use in competitions, > > though I think it is an interesting and useful addition to the timer > > itself. > > > > My objective consensus on this issue is that the cons of the Rubik's > > timer will likely lead to video analysis for potential new records > > to see if any sort of U turn was down before or after the timer was > > started/stopped. The pros of the Rubik timer are nice, in that it > > times a closer margin around just the solve than the stackmat does. > > Also the fact that it is easy to learn how to efficiently use a > > Rubik's timer is a big pro in my opinion. > > > > Subjectively, the cons for the Rubik timer, to me, heavily outweigh > > the pros in that I don't want to lose a fast solve becuase, on > > watching the video analysis of a fast solve, I hit the U layer as my > > hands grabbed the cube and before I picked it up. I would be very > > frustrated by the potential time disqualifications this timer would > > bring to competitions. > > > > Objectively looking at the stackmat it has about as many cons as the > > rubik timer, but it doesn't include the likelihood of a bad turn > > before starting the solve, as the rubik timer does. > > > > Disturbing for me about the stackmat is that it times a larger > > margin around the solve than the Rubik's timer, and that it takes > > lots of practice and familiarity with a Stackmat to use it > > efficiently in a competition. > > > > Personally I think both timers are bad, but both are also good. > > Subjectively now, I think the cons of the rubik's timer are pretty > > large. I wouldn't want to use one in a competition as the timer is > > designed right now, with the likelihood of disqualified records and > > fast solves because of this "U-face problem". > > > > I also don't like the stackmat because it times a larger margin of > > the solve that we are interested in. However this may be necessary > > to ensure good flow and ease of timing in a competition. > > > > Personally I think both timers suck and we should all go to video > > analysis for it's purity sake. However this too has huge problems > > with money and supplies. > > > > I say that last unreasonable option (and it is most unreasonable, I > > would never campaing in favor of completely video analysis > > tournaments) only to say that I think both timers suck, I am not in > > either camp. However, based on the qualifications of the Rubik's > > timer and my opinions as a competitor, I right now prefer the > > stackmat simply as a lesser of two evils. > > > > If the "U-face problem" could be fixed with the start and stop of > > the solve on the Rubik's timer, I would greatly prefer the Rubik's > > timer over the stackmat as it has better pros and (with the absence > > of those two huge cons on my list), not so many cons left. > > > > Come one guys, stop being so subjective and partial and not even > > giving valid arguments. We're all smarter and better than that. > > Just because the Stackmat has worked before doesn't mean it's a > > great timer and we need to accept everything status quo. Also, just > > because the Rubik's timer has so many great pros doesn't make it a > > great timer either, as a competitor I am VERY nervous about this > > problem with U face turns on the start and stop. > > > > **Both timer have big downfalls** So don't get all high and mighty > > in supporting your favorite. > > > > Both timer suck, but in my opinion with all the information on both > > timers, I would prefer to have a stackmat in front of me in a > > competition over a Rubik's timer until this "U-face problem" is > > fixed on the Rubik's timer. > > > > If and when the U-face problem is fixed, I would much rather have a > > Rubik's timer in front of me during a competition. > > > > My two (and hopefully sufficiently objective) cents, > > Chris > > > > P.S. Please let's continue this discussion with arguments about the > > pros and cons of these timers, and not advertisements about how your > > favorite time is the übertimer and all other ones are crap. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links

1279. Re: How to buy a good cube?
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 01:27:55 -0000

I have bought most of my cubes at toy r' us and walmart. The thing i have found best is to have an old cube you can still solve with you. go in and open the boxes. test them. you may have to try a few cubes but you should find one that is relatively equal on all sides and fairly loose. Then just spray prestone silicone high viscosity formula in and mix cube until it gets hard to turn on all sides. This means the liquid(you don't have to use alot at all) is spread. Let dry and you should have a good turing cube that will do nothing but get faster as you use it. I have noticed that on the new cubes with the stand included. They are taping he sides of this container making it harder to check. I don't like that and have started buying diy's. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "edgardo_deza" <edgardo.deza@g...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > Today I went to a store to buy a Rubik's cube. > So I opened the package and played a little bit with three > cubes, but they were all stiff, so I ended up not buying one. > I am not sure if that is the case for all new cubes, > but I remember someone here in the group saying that > he has bought a cube from Walmart and it went smooth right > from the beginning. > > Now my question: > If you buy a new cube, how do you know that it is a good speedcube? > (I tried to open the cube by a pop to see if it had arched centers but > the cube was still too stiff) > > Have you ever encountered a case where the layers were easy > turn right from the beginning? > > -Edgardo
1280. Re: Fridrich' limits
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 01:38:54 -0000

> How long did it take you to learn the ZBF2L? Hi, I haven't finished yet, I'm actually still working on it. So far I know a little over 100 of the ZBF2L cases (each one has a reflection as well, so a little over 200 if you count reflections as separate algs). I still have about 44 cases left to learn (88 if you count reflections). I started Jan 27, so I've been learning for 33 days. I took an average just now using the VH system (so ZBF2L followed by COLL followed by PLL, 3 looks total) with (13.5/19) + (5/19)*(1/8) = 74.34% of ZBF2L. Again I'm still learning the cases and I often have to take several seconds to recognize the case I do have. However, I am getting excited, I'm already almost sub-20 again! I haven't taken many averages since I started learning, but this is my fastest yet so far. 18.05 17.02 21.13 (15.58) 24.95 (26.32) 21.20 23.01 26.14 21.87 19.07 16.93 = 20.94 If you are interested in learning ZBF2L, you should! I think it has lots of benefits and helps your times a lot, though I don't have any evidence of this yet. If anyone else uses ZBF2L please post an average! I know Dan H, Lars V. and I are vocal about learning the method, as well as Ron and Zbigniew obviously. Ron, Zbigniew, how much of the system do you guys use by now? I think cubers should help others cubers learn. I know for a fact that I am not the person who uses the most ZBF2L algs out there. So please, if you use ZBF2L speak up! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikscubewhiz" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > i was considering going straight into learning ZB once i learn OLL, > since i'll still be in "learning mode" as i call it. How long did > it take you to learn the ZBF2L?

1284. hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!
From: jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 03:28:02 -0000


Hello fellow speedcubers! :)

I am having some difficulty finding the right lubricant for my Rubik's
cube. I know it should be silicon based but I was wondering if anyone
could suggest the brand name of the lubricant that could be found in
southern California. (Around L.A.)Name of the department store would
be very helpful!

I recently bought one from home depot called, Gunk 12 Oz. Gunk Heavy
Duty Silicone Spray Lubricant.
link is
http://www.homedepot.com/prel80/HDUS/EN_US/diy_main/pg_diy.jsp?CNTTYPE=PROD_META&CNTKEY=misc%2fsearchResults.jsp&BV_SessionID=@@@@0405304785.1109647008@@@@&BV_EngineID=ccffadddmilhdlgcgelceffdfgidglo.0&MID=9876
When I applied this on my cube, it made it worse and made it so much
louder. The smell was unbearable too. Can anyone help me please???!!

Thanks in advance






1285. Re: [Speed cubing group] hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!
From: Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:33:10 -0800 (PST)

go to walmart and get preston silicone lubricant from the car section. it is cheap i think i got them for less than $2. ppl say that the lub u are using, gunk, doesn't work on cubes. well i personally use gunk on my japanese packaging cube, it works well with those plastic. chun hei uwe jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: Hello fellow speedcubers! :) I am having some difficulty finding the right lubricant for my Rubik's cube. I know it should be silicon based but I was wondering if anyone could suggest the brand name of the lubricant that could be found in southern California. (Around L.A.)Name of the department store would be very helpful! I recently bought one from home depot called, Gunk 12 Oz. 1286. Re: [Speed cubing group] hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!
From: chris brownlee <heretogame@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:49:46 -0800 (PST)

i'm going to have to say that the gunk lube is great that you found... but it isn't going to do anything for your cube unless you wait and cube 2-3 days or take your cube apart and dry the wet lube off after working it in...the only wet lube that i have found that is great is called tri-flow which is teflon based... but only then it works when your cube is loosened up some... keep with the gunk silicon and work it in take apart and dry all pieces jamessong523 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: Hello fellow speedcubers! :) I am having some difficulty finding the right lubricant for my Rubik's cube. 1288. Re: [Speed cubing group] Learning ZB
From: chris brownlee <heretogame@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:54:09 -0800 (PST)

by what i understand the ZB method actually cuts your 1look solve in 1/4 because when you finishing off your LL you are orienting crosses and it cuts the LL cases from 1211 down to around 300




If you already know the entire fridrich system, how many algorithms
would you have to learn to know the full ZB?

1290. Cheating by looking
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 20:52:25 -0800

Not to imply that cheating is a big problem or anything, but since
we're talking about it, I don't think anyone has mentioned the perhaps
most practical and serious form.

Since ever competitor gets the same mix, I can look at those solving
before me and study the position for much longer than 15 seconds. Well,
personally I can't do much with it, but with blindfolders being able to
memorize the entire cube in around a minute, I have to think others
could. And even I could take a few pictures with a digital camera and
reconstruct the entire position in a few minutes.

One way to fix that would be to not let competitors see previous
attempt in the same round, as was done in Budapest 1982, but that makes
it a lot less fun and requires more organizing resources. And to stop
cooperating competitors you'd have to take away people's cell phones.

The rounds go by pretty quickly in the Caltech tournaments, and that
does minimize the risk, but the only real way to remove this problem
seems to be to have a unique random mix for each individual solve. That
would take away a bit of the fun, but I don''t think that would make
the competitions any less fair.


/Lars
PS. I *really* like the two plane version of the rubik timer that
several people suggested. It's much simpler than my suggestion, and
solves both the U problem and the 2 second problem.


On Feb 26, 2005, at 9:45, Ron van Bruchem wrote:

>
> Hi friends,
>
> I would like to add to this discussion that already in Toronto, people
> could
> tell which color they wanted to use.
> Since the first round took a looong time (there was even a break of one
> night!), people heard from other competitors whether cube x had a tough
> cross when using your normal color.



1291. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: Reply and Notes
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 08:37:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > [ ] .. .. 5+ ways > > (define "ways") > > That would be, do you know how to solve the cube in less than a minute > using any of five different methods? > > > > [ ] .. in less than 20 seconds > > > [ ] .. in less than 65 moves > > for the above 2: I know how to do so but I can't do so (in the sense > > that I know the sort of thing I would need to learn (algorithms, > > dexterity, mental speed, recognition etc.) but I that doesn't mean I > > am able to do all that stuff) > > Me too. Tough. > > > > [X] what BLD stands for > > (assuming it's a particular piece/corner of the cube) > > I realized I overlooked that and that BLD has two different meanings. > I propose to replace it with BRD to eliminate all possible confusion. > > > > [X] a 4x4x4 > > > [X] .. and can solve it > > (not the physical one, but the computer one for sure) > > That doesn't count, though; everybody 'has' a computer one (unless you > programmed it yourself, in which case you can give yourself an > auxiliary point or something). You can check off "and can solve it", > though, even if you don't have one, as long as you can restore it to a > proper solved state. No, I have a real-life one - but I can only solve it in under 2 minutes on a computer cube (like oinkleburger). Similarly, I have a real 5x5x5 one but I can only solve it in under 2 minutes on oinkleburger. > Not sure what you mean - he didn't patent it, right? >That's the thing - he does have a patent. Any cube made for profit >without his permission or his company's permission is a knockoff >Cube. Are you sure he does? I thought he had one on all his subsequent puzzles (like magic and so on) but not on the original cube. > > [X] in front of a crowd > (at least if I am the only cubist there) >Does that really make a difference? Yes - it's very hard to concentrate if there's other clicking in the background (as I found out last August). > > [ ] but I don't want to open any of my MIB cubes > (No idea what that means - MIB never appeared as an acronym above.) >Sorry. Mint In Box. That is - do you have unopened cubes with mint >packaging that you would use except that you don't want to open >them? And here's me thinking it might be a Men In Black Cube (like a Simpsons cube only with Will Smith and that they might be hyper- rare). > > [X] in my head > Surely, that's what one does with blindfold cubing. >I should remove this, unless I can think of some gibberish like "but >you have to visualize it!" But I don't visualize it. > > [X] to any possible pattern > It's basically the same problem >As what? I mean, if you're into an advanced method you might have >conceptual problems with solving to a Giant Meson or a 6-H pattern. As solving to any other state without looking/in one's head. > > [X] by telling someone what moves to make > Same again >Except when they can't see the cube. They do the moves you tell them >to, and when they remove the blindfold they've solved it. Oh, I thought you meant I can't see it and tell someone what to do and they follow the instructions and it ends up solved. I'm not sure it makes a difference if they can't see it. >What do you mean, the full group is in fact a 2-generator group? I >mean the <U,R> group thing. I mean there are moves X, Y such that the cube group is just <X,Y> - that is any move can be done using just X and Y. >What do you mean exactly by the diameter of the orientation >subgroup? The superflip takes 20 moves (HTM, a QTM result would be better) - that's well known. Any other move that just involves flipping edges/twisting corners in place can also be done in 20 or fewer moves (HTM) so 20 is the diameter of the orientation subgroup in the HTM. There are several positions requiring 20 moves (of the 66 classes which superflip the edges, 10 require 20 moves), but of the 94,518 classes I've recently got to the point where less than 20,000 require 20 moves and I'm sure that I can knock that down a fair bit more.

I'd just be interested to know if anyone has got as fast as I believe is possible with it (all this talk of the number of algorithms for ZB makes me think L2L must be very viable!) Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 10:34:07 -0000

As you might have guessed I'm in the process of learning the L2L4. I'm going really slow at the moment though as my cubing interest really have it's ups and downs. I'm also doing everything with the first layer down and finding and converting algorithms takes some time. But one day I'll hopefully. As for now I only know the algs for step 3, but all of them can pretty easily be performed in less than 2 seconds which feels great. 1296. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: Reply and Notes

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Not sure what you mean - he didn't patent it, right? > > >That's the thing - he does have a patent. Any cube made for profit > >without his permission or his company's permission is a knockoff > >Cube. > > Are you sure he does? I thought he had one on all his subsequent > puzzles (like magic and so on) but not on the original cube. I'm sure he did. On January 30, 1975. That's why I was interviewed for a small TV report about its 30th anniversary this January. See also: http://web.idirect.com/~cubeman/cchrono.txt Cheers! Stefan
1297. [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Timer Competition Protocol
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 11:56:50 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "randmthght" <wombat@r. ..> wrote: > > Stackmat issue: reset button is easily pressed while finishing solve. Please say "Stackmat 2". The first version doesn't have that problem. Also I prefer it for Magic solves because it's flat. > Put a wall on the timer that will be perpendicular. The whole > timer could then be placed on a 45 degree angle like Gilles suggested > on this page http://grrroux.free.fr/2flat.jpg. We should do tests then what's the easier way to stop the timer, put your hands down or put the cube against two walls. Cheers! Stefan
1298. Re: How to buy a good cube?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 11:58:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "randmthght" <wombat@r. ..> wrote: > > I have bought most of my cubes at toy r' us and walmart. The thing i > have found best is to have an old cube you can still solve with you. > go in and open the boxes. test them. you may have to try a few cubes > but you should find one that is relatively equal on all sides and > fairly loose. Then just spray prestone silicone high viscosity > formula in and mix cube until it gets hard to turn on all sides. You don't mention it but I hope between trying cubes and spraying into one you've paid for it? ;-) Cheers! Stefan
1299. Re: Fridrich' limits
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 12:23:55 -0000

Hi, I'd like to add that up until now, I haven't used anything more than the basic set of Fridrich algorithms for speedsolving and I've set numerous averages under 16 seconds with it in practice. So the "old" 17 second limit has certainly been surpassed now due to the increasing standard of speedcubers we have nowadays. Just have a look at the unofficial 3x3x3 rankings on speedcubing.com. cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I started Jan 27, so I've been learning for 33 days. > > I took an average just now using the VH system (so ZBF2L followed by > COLL followed by PLL, 3 looks total) with (13.5/19) + (5/19)*(1/8) = > 74.34% of ZBF2L. Chris, I'm so amazed at how fast you go about learning all this. It's been an inspiration to me. I also know about 1/3 of the ZBF2L system now and I'm making fast progress. I'm convinced that you can become a bit faster using VH if you master the complete ZBF2L. As you said the final pair will be just as fast with practice, COLL is only slightly slower than OLL but you always get a fast finish (mostly 3-cycle edges). I'm thinking about learning one additional set of 40 COLL algorithms (1 for each corner case) after I've finished learning the complete F2L so I can always finish with 3-cycle edges. That would reduce the final step to close to one second. But the most important thing to me is that learning ZBF2L is a lot of fun! And you don't _really_ have to learn 305 distinct algorithms. You can go a long way by just experimenting with breaking up pairs, putting them back together and moving empty slots. I figured out over 160 cases myself just using pencil, paper and a cube. After that, it all made much more sense to me. Have fun, LarsV
1300. Rubik's Cube Test Version alpha+1
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 18:02:37 -0000

This is my next version of the Rubik's Cube Test. It includes a few other things and some notes. Notes and Errata: 1. Indentation indicates that something is a subcategory of or is based on a previous thing - it isn't there for ornamentation only. In certain purposes, you may check it if you haven't checked its category, but that's rare. 2. A cube is an object in the shape of a cube. A Cube is a Rubik's Cube, either official or knockoff (i.e. not authorized by Rubik). 3. If there are more than one box near a clue, and it applies to you, check both or all of those boxes. Note that indentation will go as it usually is: [ ][ ] have met him is indented. I know... [ ] how to solve the Cube [ ] .. in less than a minute [ ] .. .. using any of 5+ methods [ ] .. in less than 20 seconds [ ] .. in less than 65 moves [ ] what OLL stands for [ ] what BYO stands for [ ] what ZB stands for [ ] what AUF stands for [ ] what BRD stands for [ ] what the WCA is [ ] .. and am in it [ ] .. .. and have a high-up position I have... [ ] a Rubik's Cube [ ] .. 5+ Cubes [ ] .. 25+ Cubes [ ] .. .. 25+ Cubes with different patterns [ ] a 4x4x4 [ ] a 5x5x5 [ ] cube lubrication [ ] .. 3 kinds or more [ ] a Megaminx [ ] a Pyraminx [ ] a Square-1 [ ] an Alexander's Star [ ] a calendar Cube [ ] a Dogic [ ] .. more than one kind [ ] a nontrivial Cube modification [ ] .. that Tony Fisher made [ ] .. that I made [ ] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise [ ] .. more than three different things [ ] knockoff Cubes [ ] .. just because they're Cubes [ ] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles [ ] .. which is well-known [ ] won first place in a championship [ ] any WR [ ] .. more than one WR [ ] .. an official WR [ ] optimized a method [ ][ ] invented my own method [ ][ ][ ] which is well-known I know... [2] [ ] more than ten algorithms [ ] .. 100 algorithms [ ] .. the entire ZB method [ ] .. all 1211 LL algorithms [ ] how to disassemble a Cube [ ] .. without breaking it [ ] .. including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 [ ] .. including an Eastsheen 2x2x2 [ ] what the Superflip is [ ] .. an optimal solution to it [ ] .. all optimal solutions to it in quarter- and face-turn metric [ ] .. an optimal solution in any other, more obscure metric [ ] optimal paths to more than 5 pretty patterns by heart [ ] .. more than 10 [ ] .. more than 50 [ ] what a supercube group is I like... [ ] to solve the Cube [ ] .. even in the bathroom [ ] .. underwater [ ] .. during meals [ ] .. in my dreams [ ] .. in front of people [ ] hanging around in cubing forums [ ] to take twisty puzzles apart [ ] .. and make other things out of them I can solve the Cube... [ ] and do so more than a hundred times a day [ ] with thick gloves [ ] .. on a keychain Cube [ ] with a one-look last layer [ ][ ] with one look total [i.e. blindfolded] [ ] .. .. with one hand [ ] in one breath [ ] above my head [ ] in front of a crowd [ ] and teach others to solve it [ ] but I don't want to open any of my mint-in-box Cubes [ ] on the computer [ ] .. on a "flat Cube" on the computer [ ] to any possible pattern [ ] by telling someone what moves to make [ ] with one hand [ ] .. with either hand [ ] .. with one in each hand simultaneously [ ] with chopsticks [ ] taking account of center rotations [ ] while juggling [ ] .. if the juggling uses both hands [ ] while talking [ ] .. and maintaining eye contact [ ] while playing a musical instrument with the other hand [ ] choosing one side to never twist [ ] in the 2-generator subgroup <U,R> [ ] in the half-turn subgroup [ ] in the antislice subgroup [ ] while drunk (or high) [ ] looking through a mirror [ ] without using my thumbs [ ] with my feet I know... [3] [ ] who Erno Rubik is [ ] .. and I have his autograph [ ][ ] and I have met him personally [ ] .. and I can recognize his face [ ] .. and I'm sure how to pronounce his name [ ] who Uwe Meffert is [ ] .. and I have his autograph [ ] who Terutoshi Ishige is [ ] who Larry Nichols is [ ] who Tibor Laczi is [ ] what a Buvos Kocka is [ ] what a Zauberwurfel is I can solve... [2] [ ] a 4x4x4 [ ] .. in two minutes or less (on the computer is OK) [ ] a 5x5x5 [ ] .. in three minutes or less (on the computer is OK) [ ] a Square-1 [ ] .. in a minute or less [ ] a Rubik's Magic [ ] .. in four seconds or less [ ] a Cube with any cubical dimensions 10x10x10 or greater [ ] .. and I've actually spent the time to do it [ ] a non-cubical Cube [ ] .. a 2x2x3 [ ] .. a 2x3x3 [ ][ ] any non-cubical Cube [ ] the 4D 2x2x2 Cube [ ][ ] the 4D 3x3x3 I cube / I have cubed... [ ] rather than eat [ ] .. rather than sleep [ ] .. rather than go somewhere important [ ] an hour a day [ ] .. three or more hours a day [ ] .. all of my free time [ ] for an hour nonstop [ ] .. for four hours [ ] .. for 24 hours [ ] since the 1980s [ ] .. since the 1970s [ ] since my teens [ ] .. since before that [ ] while I surf the 'Web [ ] while I watch TV

1305. Re: hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!
From: "randmthght" <wombat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 01 Mar 2005 22:40:20 -0000

IMHO I have bought most of my cubes at toy r' us and walmart. The thing i have found best is to have an old cube you can still solve with you. go in and open the boxes. test them. you may have to try a few cubes but you should find one that is relatively equal on all sides and fairly loose. Then just spray prestone silicone high viscosity formula in and mix cube until it gets hard to turn on all sides. This means the liquid(you don't have to use alot at all) is spread. Let dry and you should have a good turning cube that will do nothing but get faster as you use it. it drys in one hour at most --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jamessong523 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hello fellow speedcubers! :) > > I am having some difficulty finding the right lubricant for my Rubik's > cube. I know it should be silicon based but I was wondering if anyone > could suggest the brand name of the lubricant that could be found in > southern California. (Around L.A.)Name of the department store would > be very helpful! > > I recently bought one from home depot called, Gunk 12 Oz. Gunk Heavy > Duty Silicone Spray Lubricant. > link is > http://www.homedepot.com/prel80/HDUS/EN_US/diy_main/pg_diy.jsp? CNTTYPE=PROD_META&CNTKEY=misc% 2fsearchResults.jsp&BV_SessionID=@@@@0405304785.1109647008@@@@&BV_Engi neID=ccffadddmilhdlgcgelceffdfgidglo.0&MID=9876 > When I applied this on my cube, it made it worse and made it so much > louder. The smell was unbearable too. Can anyone help me please???!! > > Thanks in advance

1307. Re: hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!

Date: Wed, 02 Mar 2005 00:22:46 -0000

I found that pledge works really well. Just spray it in, let it dry, and it is super slick. Make sure that you use the lemon one though. 1308. Re: hunting for the PERFECT lubricant!
From: "darereck" <darerick@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Mar 2005 00:48:21 -0000

I have a friend that also bought the "gunk heavy silicon spray". he used it on his cube and says that it got stuck.. and smells horribly bad. even after he washed off the lubricant... its was getting pretty stiff. I would recomend using a silcion based spray with VERY VERY HIGH viscosity.. it will make that cube spin! But What lube DO people like Fridrich or Lars Use or other world champions??? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "siferdomm123" <SiferDomm@G...> wrote: > > I found that pledge works really well. Just spray it in, let it dry, > and it is super slick. Make sure that you use the lemon one though. It > smells better. =) > Jeremy > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "randmthght" > <wombat@r...> wrote: > > > > IMHO > > > > I have bought most of my cubes at toy r' us and walmart. The thing i > > have found best is to have an old cube you can still solve with you. > > go in and open the boxes. test them. you may have to try a few cubes > > but you should find one that is relatively equal on all sides and > > fairly loose. Then just spray prestone silicone high viscosity > > formula in and mix cube until it gets hard to turn on all sides. This > > means the liquid(you don't have to use alot at all) is spread. Let > > dry and you should have a good turning cube that will do nothing but > > get faster as you use it. it drys in one hour at most > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jamessong523 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hello fellow speedcubers! :) > > > > > > I am having some difficulty finding the right lubricant for my > > Rubik's > > > cube. I know it should be silicon based but I was wondering if > > anyone > > > could suggest the brand name of the lubricant that could be found in > > > southern California. (Around L.A.)Name of the department store would > > > be very helpful! > > > > > > I recently bought one from home depot called, Gunk 12 Oz. Gunk Heavy > > > Duty Silicone Spray Lubricant. > > > link is > > > http://www.homedepot.com/prel80/HDUS/EN_US/diy_main/pg_diy.jsp? > > CNTTYPE=PROD_META&CNTKEY=misc% > > 2fsearchResults.jsp&BV_SessionID=@@@@0405304785.1109647008@@@@&BV_Eng i > > neID=ccffadddmilhdlgcgelceffdfgidglo.0&MID=9876 > > > When I applied this on my cube, it made it worse and made it so much > > > louder. The smell was unbearable too. Can anyone help me > > please???!! > > > > > > Thanks in advance
1309. Re: Rubik's Cube Test Version alpha+1
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Mar 2005 03:20:11 -0000

Much better Score=56 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > This is my next version of the Rubik's Cube Test. It includes a few > other things and some notes. > > Notes and Errata: > > 1. Indentation indicates that something is a subcategory of or is > based on a previous thing - it isn't there for ornamentation only. In > certain purposes, you may check it if you haven't checked its > category, but that's rare. > > 2. A cube is an object in the shape of a cube. A Cube is a Rubik's > Cube, either official or knockoff (i.e. not authorized by Rubik). > > 3. If there are more than one box near a clue, and it applies to you, > check both or all of those boxes. Note that indentation will go as it > usually is: > [ ][ ] have met him > is indented. > > I know... > [x] how to solve the Cube > [x] .. in less than a minute > [ ] .. .. using any of 5+ methods > [ ] .. in less than 20 seconds > [ ] .. in less than 65 moves > [x] what OLL stands for > [x] what BYO stands for > [x] what ZB stands for > [ ] what AUF stands for > [ ] what BRD stands for > [x] what the WCA is > [ ] .. and am in it > [ ] .. .. and have a high-up position > > I have... > [x] a Rubik's Cube > [x] .. 5+ Cubes > [ ] .. 25+ Cubes > [ ] .. .. 25+ Cubes with different patterns > [ ] a 4x4x4 > [x] a 5x5x5 > [ ] cube lubrication > [ ] .. 3 kinds or more > [ ] a Megaminx > [ ] a Pyraminx > [ ] a Square-1 > [ ] an Alexander's Star > [ ] a calendar Cube > [ ] a Dogic > [ ] .. more than one kind > [ ] a nontrivial Cube modification > [ ] .. that Tony Fisher made > [ ] .. that I made > [x] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise > [ ] .. more than three different things > [x] knockoff Cubes > [x] .. just because they're Cubes > [x] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles > [ ] .. which is well-known > [ ] won first place in a championship > [ ] any WR > [ ] .. more than one WR > [ ] .. an official WR > [ ] optimized a method > [ ][ ] invented my own method > [ ][ ][ ] which is well-known > > I know... [2] > [x] more than ten algorithms > [ ] .. 100 algorithms > [ ] .. the entire ZB method > [ ] .. all 1211 LL algorithms > [x] how to disassemble a Cube > [x] .. without breaking it > [x] .. including a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 > [ ] .. including an Eastsheen 2x2x2 > [x] what the Superflip is > [ ] .. an optimal solution to it > [ ] .. all optimal solutions to it in quarter- and face-turn metric > [ ] .. an optimal solution in any other, more obscure metric > [x] optimal paths to more than 5 pretty patterns by heart > [ ] .. more than 10 > [ ] .. more than 50 > [ ] what a supercube group is > > I like... > [x] to solve the Cube > [x] .. even in the bathroom > [ ] .. underwater > [x] .. during meals > [x] .. in my dreams > [x] .. in front of people > [x] hanging around in cubing forums > [x] to take twisty puzzles apart > [x] .. and make other things out of them > > I can solve the Cube... > [x] and do so more than a hundred times a day > [ ] with thick gloves > [ ] .. on a keychain Cube > [ ] with a one-look last layer > [ ][ ] with one look total [i.e. blindfolded] > [x] .. .. with one hand > [ ] in one breath > [ ] above my head > [x] in front of a crowd > [x] and teach others to solve it > [x] but I don't want to open any of my mint-in-box Cubes > [x] on the computer > [ ] .. on a "flat Cube" on the computer > [x] to any possible pattern > [x] by telling someone what moves to make > [x] with one hand > [x] .. with either hand > [x] .. with one in each hand simultaneously > [ ] with chopsticks > [x] taking account of center rotations > [ ] while juggling > [ ] .. if the juggling uses both hands > [x] while talking > [ ] .. and maintaining eye contact > [ ] while playing a musical instrument with the other hand > [ ] choosing one side to never twist > [ ] in the 2-generator subgroup <U,R> > [ ] in the half-turn subgroup > [ ] in the antislice subgroup > [ ] while drunk (or high) > [ ] looking through a mirror > [x] without using my thumbs > [ ] with my feet > > I know... [2] > [ ] a 4x4x4 > [ ] .. in two minutes or less (on the computer is OK) > [x] a 5x5x5 > [ ] .. in three minutes or less (on the computer is OK) > [ ] a Square-1 > [ ] .. in a minute or less > [ ] a Rubik's Magic > [ ] .. in four seconds or less > [ ] a Cube with any cubical dimensions 10x10x10 or greater > [ ] .. and I've actually spent the time to do it > [ ] a non-cubical Cube > [ ] .. a 2x2x3 > [ ] .. a 2x3x3 > [ ][ ] any non-cubical Cube > [ ] the 4D 2x2x2 Cube > [ ][ ] the 4D 3x3x3 > > I cube / I have cubed... > [x] rather than eat > [x] .. rather than sleep > [x] .. rather than go somewhere important > [x] an hour a day > [x] .. three or more hours a day > [x] .. all of my free time > [x] for an hour nonstop > [x] .. for four hours > [ ] .. for 24 hours > [ ] since the 1980s > [ ] .. since the 1970s > [x] since my teens > [x] .. since before that > [x] while I surf the 'Web > [x] while I watch TV

From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > This is my next version of the Rubik's Cube Test. It includes a few > other things and some notes. > > Notes and Errata: > > 1. Indentation indicates that something is a subcategory of or is > based on a previous thing - it isn't there for ornamentation only. In > certain purposes, you may check it if you haven't checked its > category, but that's rare. > > 2. A cube is an object in the shape of a cube. A Cube is a Rubik's > Cube, either official or knockoff (i.e. not authorized by Rubik). > > 3. If there are more than one box near a clue, and it applies to you, > check both or all of those boxes. Note that indentation will go as it > usually is: > [ ][ ] have met him > is indented. > > I know... > [X ] how to solve the Cube > [X ] .. in less than a minute > [ ] .. .. using any of 5+ methods > [ ] .. in less than 20 seconds > [ ] .. in less than 65 moves > [X ] what OLL stands for > [X ] what BYO stands for > [ ] what ZB stands for > [ ] what AUF stands for > [X ] what BRD stands for (Assuming it refers to a particular position on the cube.) > [X ] what the WCA is > [ ] .. and am in it > [ ] .. .. and have a high-up position > > I have... > [X ] a Rubik's Cube > [X ] .. 5+ Cubes > [ ] .. 25+ Cubes > [ ] .. .. 25+ Cubes with different patterns > [X ] a 4x4x4 > [X ] a 5x5x5 > [X ] cube lubrication > [ ] .. 3 kinds or more > [X ] a Megaminx > [ ] a Pyraminx > [ ] a Square-1 > [ ] an Alexander's Star > [ ] a calendar Cube > [ ] a Dogic > [ ] .. more than one kind > [ ] a nontrivial Cube modification > [ ] .. that Tony Fisher made > [ ] .. that I made > [ ] other Rubik non-twisting merchandise > [ ] .. more than three different things > [X ] knockoff Cubes (I'm guessing one with flags of countries on counts?) > [ ] .. just because they're Cubes > [X ] a website on Rubik's Cube-related puzzles > [X ] .. which is well-known > [ ] won first place in a championship > [X ] any WR > [X ] .. more than one WR > [ ] .. an official WR > [X ] optimized a method > [X ][X ] invented my own method > [ ][ ][ ] which is well-known > > I know... [2] > [X ] a 4x4x4 > [X ] .. in two minutes or less (on the computer is OK) > [X ] a 5x5x5 > [X ] .. in three minutes or less (on the computer is OK) > [ ] a Square-1 > [ ] .. in a minute or less > [X ] a Rubik's Magic > [X ] .. in four seconds or less > [X ] a Cube with any cubical dimensions 10x10x10 or greater > [X ] .. and I've actually spent the time to do it > [ ] a non-cubical Cube (for reference, a non-cubical Cuboid would be the appropriate terminology, but I haven't seen them - except pictures of them) > [ ] .. a 2x2x3 > [ ] .. a 2x3x3 > [ ][ ] any non-cubical Cube > [ ] the 4D 2x2x2 Cube > [ ][ ] the 4D 3x3x3 > > I cube / I have cubed... (This isn't a question above, but I'll mention it for fun. [X ] solved the cube effectively blindfolded whilst getting my hair cut - i.e. underneath the shroud that they put over you to stop the hairs getting all over.)
1313. Cube moding

easy starter mod?





1314. Re: Fridrich' limits
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Mar 2005 02:50:37 -0000


Lars,

I'm absolutely amazed at how you can get sub-16 averages with only
Fridrich. I was able to get sub-18 using just Fridrich but I had to
learn all of COLL before I ever started getting sub-17 averages. I
still have never even gotten sub-16. I'm hoping these new algs will
help me with that though.

Lars that's quite impressive in my opinion. I can't imagine the times
you'll will get when you know ZB in full.

> > I took an average just now using the VH system (so ZBF2L followed by
> > COLL followed by PLL, 3 looks total) with (13.5/19) + (5/19)*(1/8) =
> > 74.34% of ZBF2L.
>
> Chris, I'm so amazed at how fast you go about learning all this. It's
> been an inspiration to me. I also know about 1/3 of the ZBF2L system
> now and I'm making fast progress.

It turns out I did my calculations incorrectly. I don't in fact know
74.34% of ZBF2L. I miscalculated the number of total cases and so
that number is wrong. I just went through and looked more thoroughly
and there are 157 total ZBF2L cases, and I know 101 so far. So that's
64.33% not 74.34% So I know almost 2/3 so far.

Wow, so yeah I think I can have the rest of it learned in a little
over three weeks from now based on my previous progress, not two.

Sorry for the misstatement, I wanted to post again to clear that up.

So I think it will be possible to have learned all the algs in a
little over two months total.

Chris





1315. New York Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Mar 2005 20:37:29 -0800

Hi Everyone,

I'm pleased to announce the following tournament in New York:

Event: Horace Mann Spring tournament 2005 (official tournament WCA)

Date: May 28, 2005

City: Riverdale, New York, USA

Venue:
Horace Mann School
Tillinghast Building
Corner of W 246th Street and Tibbett Ave
Riverdale, NY 10471

Organizer: Ian Winokur

Events
3x3x3: speed solving, one-handed, blindfolded. 2x2x2. 4x4x4.

Information
Time schedule:
9:15 AM - 9:45 AM: Registration
10 AM: Competition Start

Check out this website for more info:

http://home.manhattan.edu/~ian.winokur/CubeTournament.html

1319. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Fridrich' limits
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 3 Mar 2005 00:25:43 -0800 (PST)

The ZB method is great, because learning the most basic cases can benefit your time. After learning 40-50 (including inverses) of the most basic cases shaved about a second off my average. iThis happened most because I knew what to expect for my LL case. Instead of anticipating 57 cases, I only had to anticipate 7. Not only that, sometimes it is possible to know the orientation case before you even complete your f2l algorithm. ZB algs are incredibly easy to memorize. I can comfortably learn 10 or more in a week and recall them easily. It is not a matter of learning algoritms, but developing a greater intuitive sense. I noticed after a few weeks of fooling around with the ZB method, I'm able to figure out nearly optimal sequences with no outside assistance. Of course this information is already familiar with many people. Also, out of curiousity, what are the number of algs for learning this system: insert c/e pair+ orient corners I know this is many more cases, and likely more difficult in recognition, but if anyone wants to flex their math muscles, feel free. -Richard --- cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Lars, > > I'm absolutely amazed at how you can get sub-16 > averages with only > Fridrich. I was able to get sub-18 using just > Fridrich but I had to > learn all of COLL before I ever started getting > sub-17 averages. I > still have never even gotten sub-16. I'm hoping > these new algs will > help me with that though. > > Lars that's quite impressive in my opinion. I can't > imagine the times > you'll will get when you know ZB in full. > > > > I took an average just now using the VH system > (so ZBF2L followed by > > > COLL followed by PLL, 3 looks total) with > (13.5/19) + (5/19)*(1/8) = > > > 74.34% of ZBF2L. > > > > Chris, I'm so amazed at how fast you go about > learning all this. It's > > been an inspiration to me. I also know about 1/3 > of the ZBF2L system > > now and I'm making fast progress. > > It turns out I did my calculations incorrectly. I > don't in fact know > 74.34% of ZBF2L. I miscalculated the number of > total cases and so > that number is wrong. I just went through and > looked more thoroughly > and there are 157 total ZBF2L cases, and I know 101 > so far. So that's > 64.33% not 74.34% So I know almost 2/3 so far. > > Wow, so yeah I think I can have the rest of it > learned in a little > over three weeks from now based on my previous > progress, not two. > > Sorry for the misstatement, I wanted to post again > to clear that up. > > So I think it will be possible to have learned all > the algs in a > little over two months total. > > Chris > > > > __________________________________ Celebrate Yahoo!'s 10th Birthday! Yahoo! Netrospective: 100 Moments of the Web http://birthday.yahoo.com/netrospective/

1321. [Speed cubing group] Re: Fridrich' limits
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Mar 2005 15:25:37 -0000


> Also, out of curiousity, what are the number of algs
> for learning this system:
>
> insert c/e pair+ orient corners
>
> I know this is many more cases, and likely more
> difficult in recognition, but if anyone wants to flex
> their math muscles, feel free.

I think it should be 527 cases for last c/e pair + orient corners.

17 of the F2L cases are asymmetrical and allow all 27 different corner
orientation states.

4 of the cases have the F2L pieces already in their slot so they only
allow the 7 corner orientation cases due to symmetry.

2 of the cases are symmetrical across a line from BUL to FDR and so
each case only allows 20 possibly different corner orientations giving
40 for both of those together.

so 17*27 + 4*7 + 2*20 = 527

It's early in the morning and I only tried to do this in my head so
I'm going to call this an estimate just in case it comes out wrong. I
think it will be at least fairly close to the actual number if it is
wrong though. I'll do a more thorough count later (have to get to
class soon).

Chris







1322. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Fridrich' limits
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>

going straight into zb wouldn't be a wise decision... atleast for my capabilities when i first started out. but good luck with that. bm rubikscubewhiz <rubikscubewhiz@...> wrote: i was considering going straight into learning ZB once i learn OLL, since i'll still be in "learning mode" as i call it. How long did it take you to learn the ZBF2L? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Yeah but I'm sure Macky uses a lot of stuff to influence the last > layer with the last c/e pair. This still counts as Fridrich of > course, but a sort of easier Fridrich since the odds for the OLLs > change. Also, in a significant portion of the videos I've seen of > Macky he ends with an edge three cycle, which implies liberal use of > COLL, at least for video solves :-D > > I've also wondered that. What is the limit of Fridrich assuming > just OLL/PLL without influencing the LL? (Of course allowing as > many F2L tricks as you can manage.) > > Btw, I'm almost done learning the ZBF2L, I will be finished learning > in about 2 weeks at my current pace, and after that I will start > working on improving recognition on the newest cases of course. In > about a month I will try doing an average and see how it affects my > times. I'm very optimistic that recognition time will be > insignificantly slower than normal F2L with practice (though still > slower of course since the last slot of the F2L becomes a "look" > instead of just plain intuition). I find it hard to believe that > Macky doesn't use ZBF2L tricks or even straight up algs, but then > again I do admit that it is possible. Opinion and hearsay :-D > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Definitely a lot faster. Macky averages sub-15 and he's not > applying > > COLL OLL nor does he do a VH-F2L or anything on everything... > > > > What I'm trying to say is, Macky averages sub-15 doing mostly just > the > > basic Fridrich steps. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology Yahoo! 1323. Mini Cube 2x2x2

There's a 2x2x2 cube for sale at Rubiks.com:

https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm?lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=clasic&lvl4=cubmni

Rubiks.com gives the dimensions as 4 x 4 x 4 cm or 1-5/8 x 1-5/8 x
1-5/8 inches, but all the ones I've seen, including 4 that I have
bought are smaller than this.

Has anyone bought this mini 2x2x2 cube? I'd like an accurate
measurement of it.

David J

>a 1980's cube if Ton's not selling t

I e-mailed him too about ten days ago, I haven't had a reply either. The
people who posted about him did say he sometimes takes a while to reply so
I'd give it time yet.

Ebay quite often has 80s cubes but you have to be quite careful what you
buy. The sellers often are not very clear about what it is exactly that
they're selling though you can get lucky.

1326. Rubik's Cube stickers
From: "siferdomm123" <SiferDomm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Mar 2005 23:40:29 -0000


I am going to start making sticker sets for 3x3x3's. Standard colors.
They are a hair smaller than the original stickers and have more
rounded corners for longer life. They are self-sticking vinyl that
will last a very long time. The price is looking like $1 a set. I am
trying to see how many I should make for this first run off which I
will hopefully start sending out next week. If you are interested in
buying a set, please email me at J2005D@... with the amount of
sets you would like to buy in the subject line.
Thank You
Jeremy

Note that I am just trying to get a count on how many I should make
right now, but when I am ready to start selling them, I will go in the
order of who emailed me first.
What it is looking like right now is that I will give you my address
and you can mail me the amount and I will mail you back the stickers.
For 1-4 set, you will need to include a stamp in the envelope to cover
the shipping, and for 5+ set, the shipping will be free.

1329. Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 04:29:14 -0000


I'd like to say that there aren't any defined standards for how many
you need to check to be a cube fanatic. Just compare scores and wait
for the final version (or a more final one, at any rate).

Some extra notes and clarifications:

1. Most important of all - I put the spaces in there so the stuff
would be all nice and aligned. Don't go [x ] or something, that looks
ugly and is not how I intended it at all.

2. Don't mark something you haven't already done unless you're
absolutely, 100% sure you can do it. For example, Steven Pochmann gave
himself a half-point for solving the MxNxP cube because he knows
commutators and permutation stuff. If you just assume you'd be able to
solve it but don't know how hard it actually is, don't go ahead and
say you can.

3. David J asked if I would be willing to include knowing 200, 300,
400, 500 algorithms (and another thing like that). My answer is no. I
think that as you get farther in things get more specialized and
giving points out for each step of the way unnecessarily lowers the
score of beginners who haven't even got 50 algorithms down. I make an
exception for stuff like Blindfold solving because it's such an
important jump. I would, however, add "solved the cube myself" and
"use some of my own algorithms" (but not all or a big list). If I did
that, people who (for example) use optimum F2L algs found by someone
else with a cube program would be cheated of lots of points.

4. A few things from GameofDeath2:
> (Assuming it refers to a particular position on the cube.)
Yes, it does. To everyone, though: if you know one Cube-related
meaning of an abbreviation, you know the abbreviation.
> (I'm guessing one with flags of countries on counts?)
Well, I'd characterize something like that as a different pattern.
> (Allowing for the discrete metric!)
What's that? Counting all moves as one in total? I was thinking more
like slice metric, axial metric (all turns on an axis is one move,
e.g. LR2), something like that.
> (I can, I'm sure, though I haven't tried it)
It's not so bad, but just try on an East Sheen.
> (Well, behind my back, so above my head is a similar problem, I
> think)
No, actually it's rather different. Above the head is a perspective
shift, the point is the change in the view of the cube.
> (I think so.)
Remember, you must solve using only U and R turns.
> (In the sense of in a plane, but I don't think that's what you mean)
No, it's not. Solving in a plane doesn't demonstrate a real
accomplishment any more than doing it at the dentist's waiting room
does. And besides, you could annoy people doing it, which is bad.
> (What happened to Macky?)
0_o I forgot.
> (for reference, a non-cubical Cuboid would be the appropriate
> terminology, but I haven't seen them - except pictures of them)
Or just a cuboid. There are some important ones (3x3x2, 2x2x3, 4x4x5,
2x2x4, 2x2x6) but some people find a way to do it on the computer.
> (in most cases, where applicable, rarely)
Once is enough. Note that "rather than eat" means to skip a meal
because of cubing, "rather than sleep" means to skip a large amount of
sleep (a few hours or the entire night) because of cubing, etc.
> (31x31x31 cube took almost 8 hours and was non-stop *)
Sounds fun and hard. Cool.
> (but not continuously - I had more than a decade off)
That's OK. I don't mind.
> (if you count solving on the web!)
No, actually I don't. The idea is to be so into cubing that you do it
while you're on the web even.


5. I'm sort of surprised at you cubists, some of you can't even
recognize Rubik's face! Or pronounce his name... Some reverence. (Not
that I can pronounce his name either. But go look up WC2003 for a
piccy of him.) By the way, Zauberwurfel and Buvos Kocka are names for
the Cube in German and Hungarian (correct me if I'm wrong) and are
pretty common to see if you go looking around the 'web.

6. Is there an actual WCA that you can join yet?, because if there
isn't, I'm going to delete that [ ].





1330. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube moding
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 03 Mar 2005 23:32:08 -0500

IMHO, the best cube mod to start off with is a Siamese Cube order 1, 2, 3 (look it up if you don't know what it means) where you cut some corners and edges in half and glue them back together to make what has the appearance of two cubes fused together, and my next choice would be the Siamese Cube order 8 where a 2x2x2 block is shared - this is made by gluing the spindles together.

Good ulck.

--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1334. German Open 2005
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 08:31:53 -0000


Hi friends,

German Open on April 23, 2005! Your chance to meet other cubers!

So if you are in Europe, then please drop me a line if you are
interested in coming over. Maybe we can arrange something for you.

You could fly to Amsterdam (on wednesday 20 or thursday 21), stay at
another cuber's place, then drive with us to Germany on friday 22.
We drive back on saturday night after dinner. Then again you could
stay at another cuber's place and fly back on sunday 24.

Just think of it. I am sure we can help you out, if you have:
= money for a ticket to Amsterdam (or boat if you are in UK) (I may
help you to find cheap ones)
= 25 euros for 1 night in a hotel
= 10 euros for entrance fee German Cube Day
= a lot of money to buy a lot of puzzles :-)

German Open is a very nice tournament, with a great atmosphere.

Have fun,

Ron






1335. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 10:46:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > (Well, behind my back, so above my head is a similar problem, I > > think) > No, actually it's rather different. Above the head is a perspective > shift, the point is the change in the view of the cube. Well, just lie down flat and solve it as normal. Similarly, if you want to solve a cube under water, put a glass of water on the table and solve the cube under the table (and under the water). > 5. I'm sort of surprised at you cubists, some of you can't even > recognize Rubik's face! Or pronounce his name... Waaaiiit. I think the question explicitly asked whether I'm "sure" I know how to pronounce his name. I think I do know, but since I'm not 100% sure I didn't give me that point.
1336. An idea I got last night
From: "mikaelnybrg" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 09:34:55 -0000


Hello!

Last night I was solving the cube and came up with (for me) a new way
to slove the F2L. I´m sure someone has already tried this or is using
it but I haven´t seen it on any sites.
This is some kind of a crossing between Petrus and Fridrich methods.

Step 1: Make a "T" (as making the cross but leaving one edge out)

Step 2: Make a 2x2x3 block (insert the first c/e pair to form a 2x2x2
then the second pair to finnish the 2x2x3)

Step 3: Oreintate all edges (exactly as Step 3 in the Petrus method)

Step 4: Finnish F2L (using Petrus or Fridirch)

I have played around a bit with this and think it works quite well for
me. I have been using Petrus method until now and I really like having
the edges orientated when I finnish F2L so thats why I do step 3.

I´d really like to hear your opinions on this as a speedsolving method
or even better your own experiences if you have used it already. All
suggestions to improve it is more than welcome.

Just an idea that I wanted to share,
Mikael

1339. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 17:23:32 -0000

Hi qqwref, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: [snip] > 3. David J asked if I would be willing to include knowing 200, 300, > 400, 500 algorithms (and another thing like that). My answer is no. I > think that as you get farther in things get more specialized and > giving points out for each step of the way unnecessarily lowers the > score of beginners who haven't even got 50 algorithms down. Unneccesarily? I did it that way so that someone who knows more algs gets more points. So you want the freshmen to score the same as the seniors, but without doing the work? What then is the point? I thought the test was to assess skill. Among other things this leaves the freshman with nothing to work towards. Oh, I get it you want everyone to score the same, no wait, there's "world record" - boy that lowers the score of all but, a handful of people. > I make an > exception for stuff like Blindfold solving because it's such an > important jump. I would, however, add "solved the cube myself" and > "use some of my own algorithms" (but not all or a big list). Why not all? You include trivia, like knowing a few abreviations, but not important things? There are two basic ways to solve the cube: 1. Figure it out yourself. 2. Memorise how someone else solved it. Most people are somewhere between these two, and this marks the main difference between people's approaches. I thought that one of the purposes of this test was to be able to see how different people are approaching the same task. I, for one, would like to know of others who only use their own algorithms. > If I did > that, people who (for example) use optimum F2L algs found by someone > else with a cube program would be cheated of lots of points. Cheated? Since when is earning a higher score cheating? In some places people equate a good memory with the ability to think. If I were you I wouldn't expect too many people to accept that. Regards, David J
1340. Re: Rubik's Cube stickers

logos, different color schemes), you could still have all black with
stickers.

1343. Re: [Speed cubing group] An idea I got last night

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 5 Mar 2005 09:16:44 +1100

On Fri, Mar 04, 2005 at 09:34:55AM -0000, mikaelnybrg wrote:

> or even better your own experiences if you have used it already. All
> suggestions to improve it is more than welcome.

1344. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 22:21:37 -0000


> Unneccesarily? I did it that way so that someone who knows more
> algs gets more points. So you want the freshmen to score the same
> as the seniors, but without doing the work?
> What then is the point? I thought the test was to assess skill.
> Among other things this leaves the freshman with nothing to work
> towards.
> Oh, I get it you want everyone to score the same, no wait,
> there's "world record" - boy that lowers the score of all but, a
> handful of people.
> Why not all? You include trivia, like knowing a few abreviations,
> but not important things?

Urgh. I should have explained myself better. The thing is that the
test isn't entertaining if you have all of the steps for something.
Sure, learning the next 100 algorithms is a wonderful barrier, and
assessing skill is the meaning of the thing, but if you have so many
steps then everything else of comparable difficulty (blindfold
solving, for example, or lowering your time, or learning to do it in
fewer moves) has to have a lot of steps, and that transforms the test
into a sluggish mess rather than a fun quiz.

If you look at the Geek Test, for example, they don't have boxes for
"Have seen 20 Star Trek episodes", "Have seen 40 Star Trek episodes",
"Have seen 60 Star Trek episodes", etc. all the way down the line.
They only dwell on one thing if there's a good reason - the questions
are different enough that they are enjoyable.

Would you rather that I had "can solve it in 40 seconds", "can solve
it in 30 seconds", "can solve it in 25 seconds", "can solve it in 18
seconds", "can solve it in 17 seconds" all on the test? I sure
wouldn't. I mean sure, they're good milestones for cubers, but they're
not interesting to people who can't already do them. If you don't know
100 algorithms (or even if you do) having those separate steps is
tedious and not fun. Maybe I'll change the algorithms to "1 look LL"
or something rather than "full ZB".

My point isn't that I want everyone's score to be the same, I just
don't want people who aren't already at the highest rungs of the
ladder to get pathetically low scores all the time. If you have more
questions in the middle range of difficulty (solving a 4-by, 100 algs,
with one hand, in front of a crowd) the test is more exciting.

Also, if you want to use the test to see what someone's done and can
do, you probably won't care if they know 300 algs or 400, but you
probably will care if they know what BYO stands for or if they can do
the 5-by.

What exactly do you consider important? The difference between 200 and
300 algorithms? That may be a difficult step, but I don't think it's
interesting. If you think something is interesting other than what
you've said so far, just tell us.

> There are two basic ways to solve the cube:
> 1. Figure it out yourself.
> 2. Memorise how someone else solved it.
> Most people are somewhere between these two, and this marks the
> main difference between people's approaches. I thought that one of
> the purposes of this test was to be able to see how different people
> are approaching the same task.
> I, for one, would like to know of others who only use their own
> algorithms.

Here's the dilemma - I see your reasoning that knowing your own
algoritms is good, but there are other factors that would prevent all
except the most reclusive cuber from getting a higher score. I don't
doubt that using some of your own algorithms is good, but at about 40%
I draw the line - on the next version I do plan to put in a box that
says "some of the algorithms I use are my own". If you go above that
40% you run the danger of not being efficient because you haven't
optimized your LL as much as others have. While it is a good
characteristic of cubers to be able to be self-independent and figure
things out for themselves, it isn't a good characteristic to not take
help and tips from others - in the form of algorithms, or in the form
of something else.

> > If I did that, people who (for example) use optimum F2L algs found
> > by someone else with a cube program would be cheated of lots of
> > points.
> Cheated? Since when is earning a higher score cheating?

I don't think you understood what I was saying there. What I was
saying was this: Suppose Person A uses a computer program or an
exhaustive search by hand to determine optimal algorithms for, say,
the Fridrich F2L, and posts them on his website. Then say Person B,
learning to speedsolve, comes across Person A's website and commits to
memory his optimal algorithms. Even if Person B made his own LL
algorithms, he would lose points (to be cheated of = to lose unfairly)
on the test and, even if he became a famous and well-known cuber, he
would virtually never be able to regain those points.

> In some places people equate a good memory with the ability to
> think. If I were you I wouldn't expect too many people to accept
> that.

So, I shouldn't expect people to accept that having a good memory
gives you the ability to think? I don't accept it and I'm not trying
to expect people to, so why the comment?

> Regards,
>
> David J

--qqwref

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 22:23:41 -0000

> Dock yourself a mark for not being able to spell Stefan's name
correctly :)
>
> Dan ;)

Oops. I'm sorry, Stefan. I thought I corrected that.





1346. Re: Mini Cube 2x2x2
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 22:30:04 -0000


> Has anyone bought this mini 2x2x2 cube? I'd like an accurate
> measurement of it.

Well, I have a 2-by that came from that kind of box, so I guess that's
it. Comparing it to my standard Rubik's it looks like it's the size of
2/3 of the cube plus 2 mm or so, and on my Eastsheen 5-by it's very
slightly more than 2/3 of the cube, so I'd say 40 mm or very slightly
over. I don't actually have a ruler.





1347. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube moding
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>

> each cube, and gluing the two cubes together in the right place. I
> still haven't made any other mods, but I really want to, just have
> to get to it.

Yeah, I know, the ones where you take stuff out and glue the cubes
together are always easier. I tend not to like them because I don't
think they're elegant, but whatever. What I'd do is add the edge
inserts to the center piece and stuff.

1357. NCC
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Mar 2005 08:16:58 -0000


I know we tried the WCC (World Cube Cup)

What about a NCC in the States? Regional qualifiers are established
in different regions, and complete teams would compete with each
other in a national even. At this time the idea may be horribly
ambitious, but I feel it's something we should look forward to.

Of course this idea of regional qualifiers and national tournaments,
is great for any country.

-Richard





1358. Re: [Speed cubing group] An idea I got last night
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Mar 2005 08:28:37 -0000

Well I haven´t found that troublesome. To not have the last edge placed gives me lots of room pair up the c/e pairs as I use the whole F-layer as an empty slot. Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jstuber@p...> wrote: > The only problem I see with it is if one of the edges you need is where the > last cross piece should be. > > -----Original Message----- > From: Ryan Heise [mailto:rheise@p...] > Sent: Friday, March 04, 2005 2:17 PM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] An idea I got last night > > > On Fri, Mar 04, 2005 at 09:34:55AM -0000, mikaelnybrg wrote: > > I´m sure someone has already tried this or is using it but I haven´t > > seen it on any sites. > > > I´d really like to hear your opinions on this as a speedsolving method > > or even better your own experiences if you have used it already. All > > suggestions to improve it is more than welcome. > > IIRC, I think AdaM developed a style similar to this. > > Ryan > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links

1361. New PB avg.
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Mar 2005 23:01:54 -0000


Hey all,
22.95s - not too exciting if you're a fast guy but I was
stoked. First average under 23s (even if just barely). It's
frustrating to have an average in the low 20's and still hardly ever
get sub 20 solves. I've rededicated myself to learning the rest of
the OLL's, when I can find time in between classes.

Anyway, thought I'd share.
-Daniel




----- JNetCube Best Average for Sat Mar 05 16:52:28 CST 2005 -----

Fastest Time: 21.23
lowest Time: 25.92
Standard Deviation: 01.17
Individual Times:

1362. Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Mar 2005 23:43:09 -0000


Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have
collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does not
yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms on
Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and wonder if
I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other
centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry that
I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the
next week or longer.





1363. Re: New PB avg.
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 05 Mar 2005 23:48:50 -0000

I felt like that when I was learning Petrus. It worked well, and I got into the low 20s. It's those last seconds that are the hardest. I've gone to the gilles roux method, and i've been working on it. I got a new PB last night, 24.97 average, and 16.47 Single solve, non- lucky. On the other hand though, i feel that when I can see ahead, I easily get sub-20 solves. if you work hard enough at it, you'll get to be sub-20. At this point, it's a mental block. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > Hey all, > 22.95s - not too exciting if you're a fast guy but I was > stoked.
