1364. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Mar 2005 02:02:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does not > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms on > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and wonder if > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry that > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the > next week or longer. Nice, pictures please :-) If you can solve the 4x4 or the 5x5 you shouldn't have trouble solving the super 5x5. It's not really much harder (for blindsolving it's actually easier for me than normal 5x5), it's mainly just more work. But man, try to figure it out yourself first ;-) Cheers! Stefan P.S. If you have too much time, consider swapping pieces of all 25 stickers on each side, not only the middle 9. Technically it doesn't matter but I could imagine it looks even better cause it seems more consistent...
1365. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Mar 2005 00:48:22 -0500

> Nice, pictures please :-)

> If you can solve the 4x4 or the 5x5 you shouldn't have trouble solving
> the super 5x5. It's not really much harder (for blindsolving it's
> actually easier for me than normal 5x5), it's mainly just more work.
> But man, try to figure it out yourself first ;-)

I find that it's easy to solve the 3-by with centers oriented using just
one algorithm (although it takes a bit longer to solve because there's
aligning involved in the F2L) which rotates the top center 180 degrees.
If I was doing the 5-by supercube, I'd be more careful when aligning the
centers in the center-matching step, and then I'd just solve like the
center-orientation 3-by.

> P.S. If you have too much time, consider swapping pieces of all 25
> stickers on each side, not only the middle 9. Technically it doesn't
> matter but I could imagine it looks even better cause it seems more
> consistent...

Actually, if I made my own 5-by supercube (which I might do if my East
Sheen's stickers wear off) I would do this. Not only does it look better
(which is usually a plus) but it is easier to tell when centers are
rotated.

Hmm... actually, it might help to do this on the edges and corners of a
3-by - it would probably make it easier to do stuff like PLL.

--qqwref

1370. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Mar 2005 09:59:59 -0000

Hey! U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed centers on the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 kinds: Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + center can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). However some slice moves do change both types of centers. The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u are lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + centers) independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, which u simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will need to interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u have a 2- cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u perform 2 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u do that. All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There are faster ways if u do the centers first. Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does not > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms on > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and wonder if > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry that > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the > next week or longer.
1371. Re: Rubik's Cube stickers
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Mar 2005 15:17:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > I, too, would be quite interested. But I would also need a visual > > representation of the quality. > > > > I still don't understand why they don't just print the color into > > the plastic? > > > > -DWC > > It's been done a few times. The first time was this cube: > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=590 > > DJ That is quite interesting, thank you for providing me with that bit of information. Does this mean that no attempt to print the color into the plastic, according to standard colors, has been successful? I can't help but be skeptical at the theory of it not being feasible. Plastic gets colored successfully all the time; just walk down any isle at Toys R Us. What if instead of black plastic, they used white? Not that anyone here has a say in this, I am just curious as to the limitations and possible reasons for never implementing what would seem to be an obvious solution to the sticker problem. Or is it simply that Rubik's wants people to keep buying new stickers from them? -DWC
1372. Re: Rubik's Cube stickers
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Mar 2005 18:11:18 -0000

Hi wet dog. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I, too, would be quite interested. But I would also need a > visual > > > representation of the quality. > > > > > > I still don't understand why they don't just print the color > into > > > the plastic? > > > > > > -DWC > > > > It's been done a few times. The first time was this cube: > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=590 > > > > DJ > > > > > > > That is quite interesting, thank you for providing me with that bit > of information. Does this mean that no attempt to print the color > into the plastic, according to standard colors, has been successful? No. That first try was unsatifactory, that is, they couldn't get orange, so it was not pursued. There have been other attempts. I think that this silk screening went well: http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1305 > I can't help but be skeptical at the theory of it not being > feasible. It was tried recently, but I think that again they didn't like the resulting "palette:" http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2027%20SevenTowns%20prototype%20fused%20stickers.htm > Plastic gets colored successfully all the time; just walk > down any isle at Toys R Us. What if instead of black plastic, they > used white? I wish they'd put out an assembly cube using white plastic. They do make white plastic cubes, but only for corporations...and that's a shame since the white plastic is slicker than the black. Here are two examples from other companies, of painting on the cubes; one of them is white: http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=792 http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=845 > Not that anyone here has a say in this, I am just curious as to the > limitations and possible reasons for never implementing what would > seem to be an obvious solution to the sticker problem. Or is it > simply that Rubik's wants people to keep buying new stickers from > them? Well, for one thing, being able to change the color scheme is good, seeing that some cubers like me use the original "official" color scheme, and are put off by the new standard. They do put out more colors than just the standard colors, but I wish the present day stickers were as good as on the 1980 era Ideal cubes. They could also make tiles, but that's another story... > > -DWC David J
1373. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubik's Cube stickers
From: Mark Longridge <mark@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 7 Mar 2005 13:35:52 -0500

There are two ways to go with coloured plastic.

You can buy white or some light coloured plastic and paint
it or you can add pigment to plastic pellets then mold it
or extrude it.

But if you look at multi-coloured plastic puzzles you will
probably see that there are seams where the different
colours fit together. Now try to apply that to the Rubik's
Cube pieces and you can see why it's easier to use
tiles.

Now the big question in my mind is "What happened to the
tooling for the deluxe Rubik's Cube"? The engineer who
worked on it is no longer with us. Believe or not it's even
possible that tooling was _destroyed_.

Nevertheless, I believe we will see an ersatz deluxe in
the near future. But to recreate the original deluxe with
the recessed tiles and tapered tiles is going to take
major $$$. Given the effort necessary to make the deluxe
in the first place I'm kind of surprised Ideal Toy didn't
make more of them.

Mark

> > It's been done a few times. The first time was this cube:
> > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=590
> >
> > DJ
>
> That is quite interesting, thank you for providing me with that bit
> of information. Does this mean that no attempt to print the color

> I can't help but be skeptical at the theory of it not being
> feasible. Plastic gets colored successfully all the time; just walk

> used white?

1376. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 02:35:43 -0000

Thank you. I've only completed making three sides so far, it's taking much longer than I thought to make and I took Stefan's suggestion of bordering the edges and corners. I couldn't wait last night to start solving though, even with three sides suped up. Though I think I've got it, I'm eager to see how the the other three sides are being affected. Thanks again. MGW --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed centers on > the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 kinds: > > Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) > > Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) > > And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + center > can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). However > some slice moves do change both types of centers. > > The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u are > lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + centers) > independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, which u > simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will need to > interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u have a 2- > cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u perform 2 > 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u do that. > > All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There are > faster ways if u do the centers first. > > Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have > > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does > not > > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms > on > > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and wonder > if > > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other > > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry that > > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the > > next week or longer.

1378. First sub-20
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 06:37:29 -0000


It's been 14 months and I have my first sub-20 average. YEAH!!

Average: 19.85 seconds

Individual Times: 18.45, 19.89, 19.85, 22.27, 20.07, (22.28), (16.40),
19.83, 19.94, 19.94, 19.34, 18.89

I did this on a stackmat. :)

-Chris

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi wet dog.> > > > > > > > > I, too, would be quite interested. But I would also need a > > visual > > > > representation of the quality. > > > > > > > > I still don't understand why they don't just print the color > > into > > > > the plastic? > > > > > > > > -DWC > > > > > > It's been done a few times. The first time was this cube: > > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=590 > > > > > > DJ > > > > > > > > > > > > > > That is quite interesting, thank you for providing me with that bit > > of information. Does this mean that no attempt to print the color > > into the plastic, according to standard colors, has been successful? > > No. That first try was unsatifactory, that is, they couldn't get > orange, so it was not pursued. There have been other attempts. > > I think that this silk screening went well: > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1305 > > > > I can't help but be skeptical at the theory of it not being > > feasible. > > It was tried recently, but I think that again they didn't like the > resulting "palette:" > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2027%20SevenTowns% 20prototype%20fused%20stickers.htm > > > > Plastic gets colored successfully all the time; just walk > > down any isle at Toys R Us. What if instead of black plastic, they > > used white? > > I wish they'd put out an assembly cube using white plastic. They do > make white plastic cubes, but only for corporations...and that's a > shame since the white plastic is slicker than the black. > > Here are two examples from other companies, of painting on the > cubes; one of them is white: > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=792 > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=845 > > > Not that anyone here has a say in this, I am just curious as to the > > limitations and possible reasons for never implementing what would > > seem to be an obvious solution to the sticker problem. Or is it > > simply that Rubik's wants people to keep buying new stickers from > > them? > > Well, for one thing, being able to change the color scheme is good, > seeing that some cubers like me use the original "official" color > scheme, and are put off by the new standard. > > They do put out more colors than just the standard colors, but I wish > the present day stickers were as good as on the 1980 era Ideal cubes. > > They could also make tiles, but that's another story... > > > > > -DWC > > David J David J First off, let me thank you for being so informative, and receptive to my questions. I am new here, and you have made me feel quite welcome. The silk screening looks nice. Of course, I would require it to be an actual color (yes, I am stating the obvious). I like the idea of the plastic tiles. Does this add additional weight to the cube? The white cube looks nice, though I can see it shows the grime on the cube a lot more. It would mean you would have to keep it a lot cleaner. But I suppose that is a good thing. I completely understand the concept of needing a different color scheme. But that could easily be solved by manufacturing two color schemes, and the user buys their own preference. Out of curiosity, what was the original official color scheme? Today, I am assuming, it is White -> Yellow, Blue -> Green, and Red -> Orange. While we are on the conversation of making the cube better, why not make the entire cubie smooth, like their faces, instead of the clip- in piece of plastic on the corners? Is there an obvious reason for having this that I am overlooking? Mark, forgive me for my ignorance, but could you expand more on your message? Of what exactly does "an ersatz deluxe" cube consist, and how were they tooling the deluxe cube before? -DWC
1385. U3 references
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Mar 2005 11:30:50 -0400

Just a quick question about alg1 'T' in the PLL of Fridrich Method.

Why is the first move an U3 and not U' ??

Noticed that there are other U3 references such as alg3 in 'Y' and alg2 in 'F'.
There must be some sort of hidden advantage to performing U3.

Thanks
Dwayne

1390. Re: Rubik's Cube stickers
From: "jello33" <jellomods@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 18:30:17 -0000

Hello All, I am a silkscreen printer, and while I have yet to try printing directly on a cube, I do print on lots of different kinds of plactic regularly. I can tell you that the process for screening the cubes colors would be intensive. To do it right all the colors would need to be backed up with white first to avoid the colors being washed out by the black behind them. Also, any type of screen printing will scratch if handled roughly. In the past few weeks I have been working on a couple of ideas for the cube stickers. I have made viynl labels which look very good and don't wear off, but my latest idea is closer to "tiles". I have sub-surface printed some thin clear lexan, backed it up with white and then applied addhesive to the backside. The results are a plastic "tile" witch can't be scratched. The adhesive I've used is an aircraft grade glue which sticks great without leaving behind a residue when removed, and seems to not be bothered by the spraying of silicone lube. I am just finishing up the first trial run of these tiles, and have made them in 2 different thicknesses. I will try and get these all done and applied to some cubes to post some pictures by this weekend. I will also be sending out a couple of sample sets to people who will hopefully post some feedback. Thanks Chris L --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi wet dog.> > > > > > > > > > > > I, too, would be quite interested. But I would also need a > > > visual > > > > > representation of the quality. > > > > > > > > > > I still don't understand why they don't just print the color > > > into > > > > > the plastic? > > > > > > > > > > -DWC > > > > > > > > It's been done a few times. The first time was this cube: > > > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=590 > > > > > > > > DJ > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > That is quite interesting, thank you for providing me with that > bit > > > of information. Does this mean that no attempt to print the > color > > > into the plastic, according to standard colors, has been > successful? > > > > No. That first try was unsatifactory, that is, they couldn't get > > orange, so it was not pursued. There have been other attempts. > > > > I think that this silk screening went well: > > > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1305 > > > > > > > I can't help but be skeptical at the theory of it not being > > > feasible. > > > > It was tried recently, but I think that again they didn't like > the > > resulting "palette:" > > > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/pages/Rubik%27s%2027%20SevenTowns% > 20prototype%20fused%20stickers.htm > > > > > > > Plastic gets colored successfully all the time; just walk > > > down any isle at Toys R Us. What if instead of black plastic, > they > > > used white? > > > > I wish they'd put out an assembly cube using white plastic. > They do > > make white plastic cubes, but only for corporations...and that's a > > shame since the white plastic is slicker than the black. > > > > Here are two examples from other companies, of painting on the > > cubes; one of them is white: > > > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=792 > > > > http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=845 > > > > > Not that anyone here has a say in this, I am just curious as to > the > > > limitations and possible reasons for never implementing what > would > > > seem to be an obvious solution to the sticker problem. Or is it > > > simply that Rubik's wants people to keep buying new stickers > from > > > them? > > > > Well, for one thing, being able to change the color scheme is good, > > seeing that some cubers like me use the original "official" color > > scheme, and are put off by the new standard. > > > > They do put out more colors than just the standard colors, but I > wish > > the present day stickers were as good as on the 1980 era Ideal > cubes. > > > > They could also make tiles, but that's another story... > > > > > > > > -DWC > > > > David J > > > > > David J > > First off, let me thank you for being so informative, and receptive > to my questions. I am new here, and you have made me feel quite > welcome. > > The silk screening looks nice. Of course, I would require it to be > an actual color (yes, I am stating the obvious). I like the idea of > the plastic tiles. Does this add additional weight to the cube? > The white cube looks nice, though I can see it shows the grime on > the cube a lot more. It would mean you would have to keep it a lot > cleaner. But I suppose that is a good thing. > > I completely understand the concept of needing a different color > scheme. But that could easily be solved by manufacturing two color > schemes, and the user buys their own preference. Out of curiosity, > what was the original official color scheme? Today, I am assuming, > it is White -> Yellow, Blue -> Green, and Red -> Orange. > > While we are on the conversation of making the cube better, why not > make the entire cubie smooth, like their faces, instead of the clip- > in piece of plastic on the corners? 1394. Re: Animal Planet
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 03:05:56 -0000

Haha. Go Macky! Cool stuff. I just saw the Caltech Rubik's Cube Club on that Animal Planet's Most Extreme. It's at the very end of the episode, in case anyone's interested. like a conventional 3x3, it seems as though it's gonna break.

1399. Parity Errors for 5x5
From: "Minh" <minh144@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 06:11:05 -0000


I "attempt" to solve by solving centres first, edges next and
routine 3x3. But when I get to the edges, I always seem to get a
situation where there are 2 out of the 3 edges of a dedge flipped
the wrong way. Can anyone tell me of a way to get rid of this?

Thanks,
Minh





1400. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 09:25:52 -0000

Hey! If u bought from Mefferts then u are lucky to have screws inside the middle centers (fixing them to the core/spindle inside). U might be lucky to get one of the centercaps off using a sharp knife to break the gluing. If u do then u can loosen up the screw which would make disassembling a few pieces much easier. But actually i recommend to struggle with it for a few weeks to "break it in" a little before lubing with silicone spray. One brand which is good and hopefully worldwide available is the CRC silicone spray. It comes in a 200 ml can with a handy small tube for accurate spraying. When the cube is relatively new u can spray a little every few weeks. Use a soft cloth to wipe off silicone from outside of the cube. Those very thin synthetic fibre kitchen cloths will do nicely. Other than lubing, since u have a mefferts cube, u can play around with adjusting all those screws. U might find that u have to use a little superglue on the tip of the screws to make them stay put where u want. How loose/tight u want ur cube is a personal matter only. But too loose and u will have trouble with some of the centers rotating and locking the cube. Happy 5x5x5-ing ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Minh" <minh144@y...> wrote: > > hi guys ~ > I just bought a cube from Mefferts and opened it today. My one seems > a little stiff and my fingers start to feel sore after a few minutes > playing with it. Is there any way to lube it? When I try to pop it > like a conventional 3x3, it seems as though it's gonna break. > > Thanks, > Minh
1401. Re: Parity Errors for 5x5
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 13:17:29 -0000

I solve my edges first and my centers last, so I don't have this, but couldn't you fix this in the same manner you fix the 4X4 edge parity? You would use all the same moves and disregard the middle slices, but maybe my way for the 4X4 is different from yours, too. Good luck. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Minh" <minh144@y...> wrote: > > I "attempt" to solve by solving centres first, edges next and > routine 3x3. But when I get to the edges, I always seem to get a > situation where there are 2 out of the 3 edges of a dedge flipped > the wrong way. Can anyone tell me of a way to get rid of this? > > Thanks, > Minh
1402. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 18:00:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > If u bought from Mefferts then u are lucky to have screws inside the > middle centers (fixing them to the core/spindle inside). U might be > lucky to get one of the centercaps off using a sharp knife to break > the gluing. First we should ask what type of cube it is ;-) If it's an Eastsheen then it's way easier and I'd suggest a small screwdriver instead of a sharp knife to pop off a centercap (since there are nice holes around it). > U might find that u have to use a > little superglue on the tip of the screws to make them stay put > where u want. You could also use the hammer-method or make a few scratches or put a square piece of paper between cap and piece. Oh, and never ever play above a floor with holes :-( Cheers! Stefan
1403. Re: Rubik's Cube stickers
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 18:27:38 -0000

Hi DWC, Do tiles add weight to the cube? Depends on how they are done and the plastic used. I think they could be done like the center caps on a regular cube and weigh no more. The clip in piece is thre because they use a very thin plastic - if it wasn't there it would catch and the cube would lock up too much. The Deluxe cubes used a lighter plastic and so the sides could be thicker - more than twice as thick as the regular cubes - so there was no need for a clip in piece. The original color scheme was Blue Opposite White, Red opposite Orange, Green opposite Yellow with one corner RBG. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: [snip] > > David J > > First off, let me thank you for being so informative, and receptive > to my questions. I am new here, and you have made me feel quite > welcome. > > The silk screening looks nice. Of course, I would require it to be > an actual color (yes, I am stating the obvious). I like the idea of > the plastic tiles. Does this add additional weight to the cube? > The white cube looks nice, though I can see it shows the grime on > the cube a lot more. It would mean you would have to keep it a lot > cleaner. But I suppose that is a good thing. > > I completely understand the concept of needing a different color > scheme. But that could easily be solved by manufacturing two color > schemes, and the user buys their own preference. Out of curiosity, > what was the original official color scheme? Today, I am assuming, > it is White -> Yellow, Blue -> Green, and Red -> Orange. > > While we are on the conversation of making the cube better, why not > make the entire cubie smooth, like their faces, instead of the clip- > in piece of plastic on the corners? Is there an obvious reason for > having this that I am overlooking? > > Mark, forgive me for my ignorance, but could you expand more on your > message? Of what exactly does "an ersatz deluxe" cube > consist, and > how were they tooling the deluxe cube before? > > -DWC
1404. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 20:54:29 -0000

5x5x5 cubes are easy to dissasemble. NOTE: Try this, but your cube may be different. Also, my directions for putting it back together probably will not make any sence, but try them. You are going to pop 18 pieces out all at the same time. Turn tow layers 1/2 turn so that the edge piece is centered above the corner. Put your thumb under the edge and the piece below it and pull gently up. If your cube is like mine, your cube will litteraly fall apart. >From there, i think you are capable of taking it apart. To put it back together, it is a little more difficult. I hope to have a rough website up by sunday describing the process.Here is what it is going to basicly tell you: Put the bottom layer together, put the bottom three layers together, put the four corners in place on the top layer, put the main edge pieces in place, finish a 2X3X5 block on the top layer, solve the left 2x2x2 block with out the X piece, solve the right 2x2x2 block without the X piece, put in the three pieces and put it in place. Keep an eye on my website. It should be ready by saturday night, but things can change: www.geocities.com/pjgat09/ it is on the "miscellaneous" page. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Minh" <minh144@y...> wrote: > > hi guys ~ > I just bought a cube from Mefferts and opened it today. My one seems > a little stiff and my fingers start to feel sore after a few minutes > playing with it. Is there any way to lube it? When I try to pop it > like a conventional 3x3, it seems as though it's gonna break. > > Thanks, > Minh
1405. Re: Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 21:23:54 -0000

Hi qqwref, I had no idea that my suggestions would be a major stumbling block for you. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: [portions snipped] > > > Unneccesarily? I did it that way so that someone who knows more > > algs gets more points. So you want the freshmen to score the same > > as the seniors, but without doing the work? > > What then is the point? I thought the test was to assess skill. > > Among other things this leaves the freshman with nothing to work > > towards. > > Oh, I get it you want everyone to score the same, no wait, > > there's "world record" - boy that lowers the score of all but, a > > handful of people. > > Why not all? You include trivia, like knowing a few abreviations, > > but not important things? > > Urgh. I should have explained myself better. The thing is that the > test isn't entertaining if you have all of the steps for something. > Sure, learning the next 100 algorithms is a wonderful barrier, and > assessing skill is the meaning of the thing, but if you have so many > steps then everything else of comparable difficulty (blindfold > solving, for example, or lowering your time, or learning to do it in > fewer moves) has to have a lot of steps, and that transforms the test > into a sluggish mess rather than a fun quiz. I thought the test might be interesting if I could see in detail how someone is progressing. > If you look at the Geek Test, for example, they don't have boxes for > "Have seen 20 Star Trek episodes", "Have seen 40 Star Trek episodes", > "Have seen 60 Star Trek episodes", etc. all the way down the line. > They only dwell on one thing if there's a good reason - the questions > are different enough that they are enjoyable. You put multiple check boxes by Erno Rubik as a progression. I thought you could do the same elsewhere. > Would you rather that I had "can solve it in 40 seconds", "can solve > it in 30 seconds", "can solve it in 25 seconds", "can solve it in 18 > seconds", "can solve it in 17 seconds" all on the test? I sure > wouldn't. I mean sure, they're good milestones for cubers, but they're > not interesting to people who can't already do them. If you don't know > 100 algorithms (or even if you do) having those separate steps is > tedious and not fun. Maybe I'll change the algorithms to "1 look LL" > or something rather than "full ZB". > > My point isn't that I want everyone's score to be the same, I just > don't want people who aren't already at the highest rungs of the > ladder to get pathetically low scores all the time. If you have more > questions in the middle range of difficulty (solving a 4-by, 100 algs, > with one hand, in front of a crowd) the test is more exciting. > > Also, if you want to use the test to see what someone's done and can > do, you probably won't care if they know 300 algs or 400, but you > probably will care if they know what BYO stands for or if they can do > the 5-by. > What exactly do you consider important? The difference between 200 and > 300 algorithms? That may be a difficult step, but I don't think it's > interesting. If you think something is interesting other than what > you've said so far, just tell us. Well for one thing, the questions that I might ask someone who has developed over a hundred of their own algorithms would be different from questions I might ask someone who only knows what others have done. > > There are two basic ways to solve the cube: > > 1. Figure it out yourself. > > 2. Memorise how someone else solved it. > > Most people are somewhere between these two, and this marks the > > main difference between people's approaches. I thought that one of > > the purposes of this test was to be able to see how different people > > are approaching the same task. > > I, for one, would like to know of others who only use their own > > algorithms. > > Here's the dilemma - I see your reasoning that knowing your own > algoritms is good, but there are other factors that would prevent all > except the most reclusive cuber from getting a higher score. I don't > doubt that using some of your own algorithms is good, but at about 40% > I draw the line - on the next version I do plan to put in a box that > says "some of the algorithms I use are my own". If you go above that > 40% you run the danger of not being efficient because you haven't > optimized your LL as much as others have. While I am willing to look at this being true for you, where did you get the idea that this is true for others? > While it is a good > characteristic of cubers to be able to be self-independent and figure > things out for themselves, it isn't a good characteristic to not take > help and tips from others - in the form of algorithms, or in the form > of something else. If you are working on the same project I agree that it is good to be open to others - which is part of why I'm looking for people who approach the cube the way I do. > > > If I did that, people who (for example) use optimum F2L algs found > > > by someone else with a cube program would be cheated of lots of > > > points. > > Cheated? Since when is earning a higher score cheating? > > I don't think you understood what I was saying there. What I was > saying was this: Suppose Person A uses a computer program or an > exhaustive search by hand to determine optimal algorithms for, say, > the Fridrich F2L, and posts them on his website. Then say Person B, > learning to speedsolve, comes across Person A's website and commits to > memory his optimal algorithms. Even if Person B made his own LL > algorithms, he would lose points (to be cheated of = to lose unfairly) > on the test and, even if he became a famous and well-known cuber, he > would virtually never be able to regain those points. Not at all. Following my suggestions that person would get credit for whatever algs he or she developed, and besides it sounds like that person was cheating him or herself. There is nothing unfair in my suggestions. I really don't care whether you include my suggestions or not. I tacked on what I would be interested in, if it doesn't interest you, that's fine. Regards, David J
1406. Re: stickers
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: "jello" <jellomods@...>
Date: Wed, 9 Mar 2005 18:25:16 -0800

Hi Chris, I had my friend Mark Sullivan try your stickers and he brought the cube by today. The stickers are excellent. We used the brighter orange color with the slightly different texture and it really sticks out from the red a lot. The green is also lighter than the traditional green and looks a bit like Lars Petrus' green. I've been cubing my whole life with rubiks.com stickers so I wasn't used to it at first but I'm sure that about after a day of cubing, I would be easily adjusted to the slightly different colors. The stickers are very bright and it's very easy and perhaps even more distinctive to tell the colors apart. Also, they stick well, don't leave a residue, and provide for a good feel of the cube. It'll be awhile before we see how the stickers wear down though but I suspect they are quite durable and definitely more durable than the rubiks.com stickers. Let me know if you'd be interested in selling them at our tournament. I'll take a picture... oh wait, no, I lost my digital camera. Anyway, I'll try to get a picture up but the stickers look really good. Thanks for the sample! Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Mar 8, 2005, at 7:42 PM, jello wrote: > Good to hear. I like the brighter orange but I don't like the fact > that it dosen't match in gloss. The yellows, I think I like the > darker one as the brighter one is a little close to the white. > > I made another type of sticker that I am sending to you tomorrow. It > is a plastic overlay with the colors subsurface printed. I think they > came out really nice. It is like a thin tile. The adhesive on them > is not affected by silicone spray either. I am going to try and post > some pics of them and the stickers by this weekend. Let me know what > you think. > > Chris > > ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> > To: "jello" <jellomods@...> > Sent: Tuesday, March 08, 2005 2:40 PM > Subject: stickers > > >> I received your stickers today. One of my friends will be trying >> them out and I'll get back to you. I noticed you sent me two types >> of oranges and yellows. Which ones do you prefer? >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> >
1407. Re: [Speed cubing group] Parity Errors for 5x5
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 22:13:14 -0500

I solve the 5-by centers-first as well. The basic reason this parity error happens is because one of the semi-middle layers (like u or r) is rotated 90 degrees. I use this alg: u (R2 u' R2 u) (F2 u' F2 u) (L2 u' L2 u), which isn't very efficient (it mixes up some edges) but it works, sort of. There are way more efficient ones, but I seriously doubt you'll find one that's easier to remember.

--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1408. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Parity Errors for 5x5
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 22:14:48 -0500

> I solve my edges first and my centers last

This I'm interested in. I've been having tons of trouble solving the centers with the edges already solved - my current solution means having to mess the whole thing up, and that takes me five minutes because I'm slow as hell - so I'd like to know: how does your solution work?

--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1409. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubik's Cube Test: More Errata
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Mar 2005 22:26:35 -0500

> I thought the test might be interesting if I could see in detail
> how someone is progressing.

I see your point. You can always make a separate test with lots of levels
if you want, but as for me, I'm not going to change unless some other
people ask (so I know that's what everyone wants). It's a big change.

> You put multiple check boxes by Erno Rubik as a progression. I
> thought you could do the same elsewhere.

Actually, that was because knowing Erno Rubik and knowing about Erno
Rubik are sort of semi-important things in cubing (if I like juggling -
which I do - I want to know about its history) and I feel that it should
be worth a lot of points. Like bonus. I don't expect anyone to ever get
100%.

> Well for one thing, the questions that I might ask someone who has
> developed over a hundred of their own algorithms would be different
> from questions I might ask someone who only knows what others have done.
Yeah, that's true. It would probably be a good idea to have "I have
developed x of my own algorithms" and "I regularly use my own algorithms"
on there.

> While I am willing to look at this being true for you, where did
> you get the idea that this is true for others?

Just the idea that there are only so many algorithms to be created. I
suppose you're right.

> Not at all. Following my suggestions that person would get credit
> for whatever algs he or she developed, and besides it sounds like that
> person was cheating him or herself.

My point was just that you can't get near the "100% of my own algorithms"
thing if you have learned a lot of someone else's algorithms.


> I really don't care whether you include my suggestions or not. I
> tacked on what I would be interested in, if it doesn't interest you,
> that's fine.

It's not really that it doesn't interest me, I'm just not sure how it
would work out in the test.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1410. RU Rubik's Club
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 04:35:32 -0000


The Rutgers University Rubik's Cube Club held its first official
meeting tonight and I am glad to say that there was a decent
interest among the student body. At least a dozen people showed up
to the meeting, though it wasn't very well advertised. I plan on
holding two more meetings throughout the semester, but it was good
to meet some more people who can solve the cube and see various
styles of cubing. My hopes are to organize a tournament perhaps in
the fall or something here at Rutgers, once we are officially
recognized as a club (right now it is still provisional). I am just
pretty excited that there is some interest in cubing at school and
am really glad that the meeting went to well. :)

~ Bob

1412. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 09:22:40 -0000

Hi! See below ;-) | | | | | \_/ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > If u bought from Mefferts then u are lucky to have screws inside the > > middle centers (fixing them to the core/spindle inside). U might be > > lucky to get one of the centercaps off using a sharp knife to break > > the gluing. > > First we should ask what type of cube it is ;-) Hmmm. He stated that he bought from Mefferts. Mefferts sell the original Professor cube and the spinoff Eastsheen 5x5x5, which some prefer (but that's a different discussion). I have never heard of anyone getting sore hands from Eastsheens ;-) So it gotta be the original Professor cube design. And those do have screws for the middle centers. And so do indeed the Eastsheens also in fact :D Like i have stated before a petroleum-based silicone works fine on cubes that are not eastsheen. Eastsheens seem more fuzzy bout the silicone, most likely cause it's a different kind of plastic used in molding the cubies. If it's an Eastsheen > then it's way easier and I'd suggest a small screwdriver instead of a > sharp knife to pop off a centercap (since there are nice holes around > it). > > > U might find that u have to use a > > little superglue on the tip of the screws to make them stay put > > where u want. > > You could also use the hammer-method or make a few scratches or put a > square piece of paper between cap and piece. Right, that works for holding in place the centercaps. I was talking about maing sure the screws don't "unscrew" themselves too easily :-) Oh, and never ever play > above a floor with holes :-( > > Cheers! > Stefan More cheers !! -Per

1414. Re: RU Rubik's Club
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 16:52:26 -0000

That's definately within driving distance for me...I live about 20 miles north of Phili. Cool...keep me posted. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > It's in central New Jersey > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jwillywonkas" > <jwillywonkas@y...> wrote: > > > > Where is Rutgers? > > > > If it's somewhere nearby, maybe I can attend. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > > > The Rutgers University Rubik's Cube Club held its first official > > > meeting tonight and I am glad to say that there was a decent > > > interest among the student body. At least a dozen people showed > up > > > to the meeting, though it wasn't very well advertised. I plan > on > > > holding two more meetings throughout the semester, but it was > good > > > to meet some more people who can solve the cube and see various > > > styles of cubing. My hopes are to organize a tournament perhaps > in > > > the fall or something here at Rutgers, once we are officially > > > recognized as a club (right now it is still provisional). I am > > just > > > pretty excited that there is some interest in cubing at school > and > > > am really glad that the meeting went to well. :) > > > > > > ~ Bob
1415. question
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 10:12:52 -0800 (PST)


Hey everyone,
Someone mentioned the cube is "no brain activity and it's just memorization" to know how to solve the cube (his time was 4 minutes or so- rookie). But do we really understand zbll and oll/pll? f2l I think we understand, but is it just memorization, or is it more? I beg to differ that it is just memorization...
bm



:)
--Brent

Do you Yahoo!?

1416. Re: [Speed cubing group] Parity Errors for 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 19:16:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I solve the 5-by centers-first as well. The basic reason this parity error happens is because one of the semi-middle layers (like u or r) is rotated 90 degrees. I use this alg: u (R2 u' R2 u) (F2 u' F2 u) (L2 u' L2 u), which isn't very efficient (it mixes up some edges) but it works, sort of. There are way more efficient ones, but I seriously doubt you'll find one that's easier to remember. Try this, just to destroy your doubts ;-) (u R2) * 4.5 Cheers! Stefan
1417. Re: question
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 19:21:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > Someone mentioned the cube is "no brain activity and it's just memorization" If that guy wants to get some good laughs (about himself) he should tell (neuro)psychologists that memorization is no brain activity... Cheers! Stefan
1418. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 19:25:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > I have never heard of > anyone getting sore hands from Eastsheens ;-) Without lubing, my new large professor cube turns much easier than the Eastsheens so I'd say it might actually be easier to get sore hands from the Eastsheen :-) > > > U might find that u have to use a > > > little superglue on the tip of the screws to make them stay put > > > where u want. > > > > You could also use the hammer-method or make a few scratches or > put a > > square piece of paper between cap and piece. > > Right, that works for holding in place the centercaps. I was talking > about maing sure the screws don't "unscrew" themselves too easily : -) Right, my mistake, I misread. I've almost never had the "unscrewing" problem but often that of loose centercaps ;-) Well, my Megaminx had the unscrewing problem but that was because of way too strong/long springs and I fixed it by replacing the springs. Cheers! Stefan
1419. SweCube Annual Meeting Tournament
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 20:27:48 -0000


Announcement

Event: SweCube Annual Meeting Tournament
Date: Sunday 27 March
City: Uppsala, Sweden
Venue: Contact Gustav Fredell (gustavATsvekub.se) for details
Organizer: Swedish Cube Association
Registration: e-mail to Anders Larsson (andersATsvekub.se) or Gustav
Fredell (gustavATsvekub.se)
Website: www.svekub.se (in Swedish)
Events: 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 speedcubing, other events if time allows.

Welcome!
Anders






1420. Re: question
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 21:41:31 -0000

I think true speedcubing, so Fridrich, ZBLL etc. is a mix of no-brainer memorized algs and intuition. Ideally you would have all 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 God's algorithms memorized with finger tricks etc.. However since that is absolutely impossible it is better to use logic and intuition to get the cube to a point where you *can* have all possible positions memorized and just apply memorized algorithms as fast as your hands can possibly move. I agree that this isn't truly solving the puzzle via logic alone, but that's not what speedcubing is about - it's about solving as quickly as possible. Someone who avergages 15 seconds who has no idea why their sequences work is indeed a better speedcuber than someone who uses their own algorithms, all of which they understand perfectly, but averages 16-17 seconds. In speedcubing only the time matters, I mean look at how we rank ourselves in competitions. Now in terms of gernal puzzling I would say that the 15 second averager who doesn't understand exactly how their algorithms work is a much worse puzzler than the person who uses their own method. It's a question a semantics to me. Would you rather be a good puzzler or a good speedcuber? Or both? If you want to be a good puzzler (which I imagine is how that one person who you met thinks) then yes speedcubers as a general rule are poor puzzlers (who knows the commutater notation/entire logic behind all their OLL and PLL algs?). If you want to be a good speedcuber, then memorizing lots of cases is the way to go. Sorry to get on my soap box but I've thought about this a lot too. Personally I consider myself a much better speedcuber than puzzler. I understand the F2L pretty well, and I can figure out most any rubik-like puzzle since I understand how commutaters work. However I still use lots of algorithms that I don't understand at all. I guess I am more interested in being a speedcuber than a puzzler. But again that is just a personal choice. I think there are lots of people who are good speedcubers and good puzzlers, some that are good puzzlers but who maybe aren't as interested in speedcubing. It all depends, and it's all based on semantics. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > Someone mentioned the cube is "no brain activity and it's just memorization" to know how to solve the cube (his time was 4 minutes or so- rookie). But do we really understand zbll and oll/pll? f2l I think we understand, but is it just memorization, or is it more? I beg to differ that it is just memorization... > bm
1421. Re: question
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 21:57:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > [...] > Would you rather be a good puzzler > or a good speedcuber? Or both? > [...] Definitely both. In competitions, there could be a combined ranking that would mix speedcubing and FMC results. Gilles.

1424. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: question
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 15:09:42 -0800 (PST)

Nice way in putting this down... I thought about this and I think it's more than "just memorization"; however particular logic can lead to faster times (f2l, etc.). I can solve it using techniques I can understand by logic but it will be over a minute...but for sub-20 i have to use fridrich oll/pll, etc. Interesting. bm cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: I think true speedcubing, so Fridrich, ZBLL etc. is a mix of no-brainer memorized algs and intuition. 1426. Re: question
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 19:25:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > Someone mentioned the cube is "no brain activity and it's just memorization" to know how to solve the cube (his time was 4 minutes or so- rookie). But do we really understand zbll and oll/pll? f2l I think we understand, but is it just memorization, or is it more? I beg to differ that it is just memorization... > bm > > > > :) > --Brent Hi Brent, Solving Rubik's Cube can be a mindless memory-based action. Consider Evans cube-solving robot "deep cube": the robot has nothing approaching comprehension. However, this doesn't mean that all of it is a mindless memory-based action. Memorization and applying what is memorized within an integrated system involves brain activity, though in the robot's case the brain activity is Evan's. Remember the computer didn't program itself. I think that comprehension beats mimicry hands down, but I also appreciate discipline. There is the real possibility that memorisation can lead to comprehension. This is the (understood) basis of our schooling systems, even though there are, and have been, few signs that many people do comprehend what they learn in schools. Then there are the people who develop their own ways of solving the cube and don't rely at all on the methods and algorithms of others. Your friend cannot lump all solving under such a stereotypical description as "no brain activity and it's just memorization." Regards, David J

1429. Re: Master Magic
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 20:49:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I want to get a Master magic, but rubiks.com is sold out... It's even worse than that. It's not just "out of stock" like the DIY 3x3. It's not even produced anymore (if I understood the mail from rubiks.com correctly). > anybody > know any alternative places to get one? One possibility is Ebay. For example, you could've gotten one from the 80s together with two cubes two days ago: http://cgi.ebay.de/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=5171416353 Went for a quite cheap price, though. Usually it's two or three times that much. Also, try flea markets. I only started visiting them last summer, and I found a 4x2 magic almost every week the first few weeks (well, four overall). Now in winter I haven't found one in quite a while, though, but I hope it gets better again next summer. And maybe I'll eventually find a Master Magic, too... Anyway, *if* you find something at a flea market, then you'll almost always get an awesome cheap price, because people have no clue what treasures they have there. Cheers! Stefan
1430. Re: ...forgot...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 20:52:43 -0000

I have never tried a new Master Magic, but the old and new 4x2 magic feel pretty much the same (if played with the same amount). The big difference is the wiring, it's upside down I think. Though actually it should be possible to just take out all strings and put them in the other way, no? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > oh, and another thing: is there a speed difference between the new > and old versions of the magic? like, does one work better than the > other, or are they pretty much the same? > > ~Bob
1431. Re: Master Magic
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 22:40:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > I want to get a Master magic, but rubiks.com is sold out... > > It's even worse than that. It's not just "out of stock" like the DIY > 3x3. It's not even produced anymore (if I understood the mail from > rubiks.com correctly). > > > anybody > > know any alternative places to get one? > > One possibility is Ebay. For example, you could've gotten one from the > 80s together with two cubes two days ago: > http://cgi.ebay.de/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=5171416353 > Went for a quite cheap price, though. Usually it's two or three times > that much. > > Also, try flea markets. I only started visiting them last summer, and > I found a 4x2 magic almost every week the first few weeks (well, four > overall). Now in winter I haven't found one in quite a while, though, > but I hope it gets better again next summer. And maybe I'll eventually > find a Master Magic, too... Anyway, *if* you find something at a flea > market, then you'll almost always get an awesome cheap price, because > people have no clue what treasures they have there. > > Cheers! > Stefan I bought a couple of the DIY magics from rubiks.com a couple months ago before they disappeared from the site so I could make a master magic, but you don't even need the kits to make one. They have the Harry Potter and Simpsons magics for five bucks each right now. You can buy two of those and take them apart and then go to the free downloads on rubiks.com to get the how-to video to make it, and the templates for the master magic. The template isn't the silver one, but black just like the original magic. It took me a full week (even with the video) of trial and error until I could get it together right, but for only ten dollars it may be a worthwhile, inexpensive option.

You > can buy two of those and take them apart and then go to the free > downloads on rubiks.com to get the how-to video to make it, and the > templates for the master magic. Right, that's probably the best way (other than being lucky on the flea market...). Jaap has some very good instructions how to assemble any Magic and twistypuzzles.com has some articles, too (though I prefer Jaap's description). Damn, why didn't I think of this last time I ordered something from rubiks.com... Cheers! Stefan
1435. Worst cube I've ever purchased
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 02:55:37 -0000


Hey everyone,

I just wanted to post a note on my experience with buying a new store
cube recently.

I've had heard a lot of good comments about the new DIY cubes from
rubiks.com, which are currently out of stock. Well, while I was
waiting for them to come back into stock I went down to Wal-mart today
and bought one of the main rubiks brand cubes that you buy in a store.
In the past these cubes have always been fairly nice and break in
pretty well.

Well this cube is absolutely terrible. My main complaints with this
cube are that:

1) The tension of the different faces is radically different. In
particular one face is about three timers looser than any of the
others and turns constantly, even when I don't mean it to. One of the
other faces is a bit tigher than the incredibly loose one but still
very loose for a brand new cube. The other 4 have decently uniform
tension, and require a nice normal turning pressure.

2) Also the cube does not feel tight/stable. Right out of the box
all 8 corners rattle very audibly when I shake the cube. This cube
has no sense of stability like you get on a studio cube.

I hope this cube is just a fluke, seeing as how I met with Chris
Brownlee a week or so ago and tried his new store bought cube and it
was fairly nice.

I know some of the people from Seven Towns are members of this board,
and I would like to ask when the DIY cubes will be available again. I
very much want to get a hold of a good cube with screws again.

Seriously though this cube is such a terrible cube that I am going to
go back to Wal-mart tomorrow and return it. There's no way I am going
to keep this thing.

Chris







1436. Re: [Speed cubing group] Worst cube I've ever purchased
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 19:13:59 -0800 (PST)

Hey Chris, I can relate with this situation. I bought a Rubik's brand cube from wal-mart as well, and found out it had a monsterous defect on the axel, which prevented any possibility of comfortable turning. I did the WRONG thing though and tried fixing it myself...After some sanding and lubing the puzzle was still horrible. I contacted David Jones in regards to this problem, and provided a serial number in case the problem could be tracked down. Four months later I am still waiting for further information. Buying a cube 'feels' like too much of a gamble for me now, because I haven't the means to purchase many cubes until I find one that's decent. -Richard --- cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I just wanted to post a note on my experience with > buying a new store > cube recently. > > I've had heard a lot of good comments about the new > DIY cubes from > rubiks.com, which are currently out of stock. Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 06:38:11 -0000


Thanks to the cube i get more attention that usual :)

my name is all over campus.

By teaching others to cube, especially those classified as "loners" in
school, i have raised their self confidence and they feel more
belonging now.

Ahh. i feel relieved, i feel i have achieved something if i can teach
someone to cube to become a better person.


PS: dont cube and drive

Have fun!





1442. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: question
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 08:39:33 -0000

It seems to me that even those who have memorised lots of algorithms without comprehension carry out at least 3 steps at each stage of solving a cube. The first is, as someone posted earlier, pattern recognition. This requires an understanding of the sort of pattern to be looking for which depends on the stage of solving (obvious examples would be searching for an F2L pair or the difference between OLL and PPL in a 2 look LL). The second is the call up from memory of the algorithm required for this particular pattern. This is the real memory element. Third is carrying out that algorithm on the cube itself. This is brain/hand coordination - a complex mix of left and right brained activity I would have thought. As Chris pointed out in his excellent post speedcubing is different to problem solving. I would think that speed in the first and third steps are extremely important for speedcubers although the third step would hardly register on a list of skills required for general puzzle and problem solving I suspect. The first step is critical to most puzzles and is required regardless of how much memorisation has taken place. While I've been writing this I can't helping comparing it to chess. Chess performance relies very heavily on the first and second of these skills. Pattern recognition cuts down enormously the amount of calculation required. In the Kasparov era (had to get a mention in now he has announced his retirement!) memory of concrete lines has become one of the major factors in taking the game to new levels (supported very much by the huge databases of games that are now available). Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "metgorubiks" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, March 12, 2005 12:26 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: question > > > I think solving the cube requires thinking but it is more of a > subconscious thinking. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
1443. Re: question
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 11:39:23 -0000


> Hey everyone,
> Someone mentioned the cube is "no brain activity and it's just
memorization" to know how to solve the cube (his time was 4 minutes or
so- rookie). But do we really understand zbll and oll/pll? f2l I
think we understand, but is it just memorization, or is it more? I
beg to differ that it is just memorization...
> bm


Before you can even think about starting to memorize algorithms you
have to understand how the cube is built and how the cubies move
relative to each other, that takes brain activity for sure.
I don´t believe you can become really fast at F2L by only learning
algs without understanding how they work and what they do, that too
takes brain activity. And at some point most of F2L will be mostly
intuitive because of this understanding. The LL might be more
memorizing but as people have pointed out, it also takes quick pattern
recognition and understanding commutators and conjugates makes it
easier to understand.
And now that was only speedsolving which maybe takes less brain
activity of the different types of solving. To be able to solve the
cube blindfolded or with a little less than 30 moves can´t be done
without lots of brain activity.

Just my two cents,
Mikael

1445. How many moves back to solved?
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 17:37:00 -0000


Right now I'm playing with the idea of doing a set of moves over and
over again from a solved state until the Cube is solved again, and
counting how many times you have to do that. Well, I'm stuck on one of
them, I've done it at least 500 times and have no idea what's happening:

On a 5x5x5, do R'Lf and then look at the down side. See what it does?
Now do it over and over until it's solved again.

I've figured out that it's probably a multiple of 40 times, but after
that nothing. Anyone know?





1446. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 18:29:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > Right now I'm playing with the idea of doing a set of moves over and > over again from a solved state until the Cube is solved again, and > counting how many times you have to do that. Well, I'm stuck on one of > them, I've done it at least 500 times and have no idea what's happening: > > On a 5x5x5, do R'Lf and then look at the down side. See what it does? > Now do it over and over until it's solved again. > > I've figured out that it's probably a multiple of 40 times, but after > that nothing. Anyone know? I've had this theory too. One of the warmup exersices i do is repeat RUR'U' five times ad it is solved. Another one i tried was RU. I had to repeat this 105 times. I think that it is possible that repeating the same moves over and over from a solve cube to a solved cube is possible. BTW, if your hands are becoming tired of performing those moves above, use the proffesor cube applet. http://www.randelshofer.ch/professorplayer/download.html This simulates the professor cube in a java applet.
1447. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 18:31:32 -0000

Finished my site: www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5a.html (taking apart the cube) www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5b.htmk (puting it back together) Check these out and tell me if they help. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > 5x5x5 cubes are easy to dissasemble. NOTE: Try this, but your cube > may be different. Also, my directions for putting it back together > probably will not make any sence, but try them. > You are going to pop 18 pieces out all at the same time. Turn tow > layers 1/2 turn so that the edge piece is centered above the corner. > Put your thumb under the edge and the piece below it and pull gently > up. If your cube is like mine, your cube will litteraly fall apart. > From there, i think you are capable of taking it apart. > > To put it back together, it is a little more difficult. I hope to > have a rough website up by sunday describing the process.Here is what > it is going to basicly tell you: Put the bottom layer together, put > the bottom three layers together, put the four corners in place on > the top layer, put the main edge pieces in place, finish a 2X3X5 > block on the top layer, solve the left 2x2x2 block with out the X > piece, solve the right 2x2x2 block without the X piece, put in the > three pieces and put it in place. Keep an eye on my website. It > should be ready by saturday night, but things can change: > www.geocities.com/pjgat09/ > it is on the "miscellaneous" page. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Minh" <minh144@y...> > wrote: > > > > hi guys ~ > > I just bought a cube from Mefferts and opened it today. My one > seems > > a little stiff and my fingers start to feel sore after a few > minutes > > playing with it. Is there any way to lube it? When I try to pop it > > like a conventional 3x3, it seems as though it's gonna break. > > > > Thanks, > > Minh
1448. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 18:33:52 -0000

It is 80 repetitions of R'Lf on a 5x5x5 till the cube solves again, or 240 moves total. 1) corners and inner edges: each group on the L and R faces are in a 4 cycle and thus solve every four repetitions 2) edge orbit : These are in a complete 16 cycle and thus solve every 16 repetitions. 3) + centers: These are in a complete 10 cycle, and thus solve every 10 repetitions. 4) x centers: 8 of the pieces are in an 8 cycle and the other 4 are in a 4 cycle. So these solve every 8 repetitions. LCM(4,16,10,8)=80 and 80*3=240 moves total. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > Right now I'm playing with the idea of doing a set of moves over and > over again from a solved state until the Cube is solved again, and > counting how many times you have to do that. Well, I'm stuck on one of > them, I've done it at least 500 times and have no idea what's happening: > > On a 5x5x5, do R'Lf and then look at the down side. See what it does? > Now do it over and over until it's solved again. > > I've figured out that it's probably a multiple of 40 times, but after > that nothing. Anyone know?
1449. Re: ...forgot...
From: "h4m573r1" <h4m573r1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 19:51:30 -0000

Heh...I haven't been posting much, but I've kept up with the messages. I can't stay out of this one... The new Master's Magic wiring is in fact "upside-down." I personally don't like this. Stefan Pochmann's method is very hard to do with the newer Magic because you need to flip the dang thing after the first two steps, then you have to flip it back! I use a newer Magic, and my own method, but I know Stefan's method is much faster. Sub-5s is much easier with Stefan's method (I can proudly say I did a sub- 5..like 2 times :( ) If you're looking for a Master's Magic on eBay, if possible, try to get one of the older ones. They really are better for speed-Magic- ing =P -Sunil --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I have never tried a new Master Magic, but the old and new 4x2 magic > feel pretty much the same (if played with the same amount). > > The big difference is the wiring, it's upside down I think. 1450. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 19:58:39 -0000


No, not R'Lf, but R'Lf and then look at the down side, as one move.
Probably a better explanation would be to move the middle three layers
as if doing a R move, then do an u. I don't know what your notation
for 5-by slices is, I use Rs but you all probably use something
completely different.

I made a program to do it, and it turns out it's what I had thought
before: 3,080 repetitions. Good thing I didn't do it out in full!

8 reps fix the edges
8*5 reps fix the center corners
8*5*7 reps fix the right center
8*5*11 reps fix the left center
8*5*7*11 reps fix all centers.

That's a lot.

1452. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 20:15:43 -0000


Oh yeah, and I just tried out R'Lf.

After 20, you get a pretty regular pattern that seems to take 6 moves
to finish, but actually doing it that total of 120 times (I did) gives
three corners a twist, so you have to do it a total of 360 times. I
don't know what you did with your math, but, especially with 5-bys, it
seems to be really difficult if not impossible to accurately do
something like this.

I'm going to spiff up my program so you can put in a set of
instructions and tell it how many times to do it.





1453. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 20:43:22 -0000

Sorry, I misread your explanation of the alg and thought it was just R'Lf. I just looked at R'Lfx which is the move you gave where you also twist the cube at the end. If you do this four times, the cube comes back to the same original orientation. Also it solves all the corners and edges and just moves around 10 of those 3x1 rows of centers. If you look at the centers specifically (doing the move on a supercube makes it easier to see which row goes where) then you see that they are in a 10 cycle. So you have to do four times the move ten times. So I agree with your original answer that 40 repetitions of R'Lfx solves the cube again. Of course 3080 is divisible by 40, so I agree that the cube solves in 3080 repetitions as well, but your original answer of 40 was correct, and is the fewest number of repetitions needed to solve the cube. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > No, not R'Lf, but R'Lf and then look at the down side, as one move. > Probably a better explanation would be to move the middle three layers > as if doing a R move, then do an u. I don't know what your notation > for 5-by slices is, I use Rs but you all probably use something > completely different. > > I made a program to do it, and it turns out it's what I had thought > before: 3,080 repetitions. Good thing I didn't do it out in full! > > 8 reps fix the edges > 8*5 reps fix the center corners > 8*5*7 reps fix the right center > 8*5*11 reps fix the left center > 8*5*7*11 reps fix all centers. > > That's a lot.
1454. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 21:00:15 -0000

R'Lf doesn't twist the corners. Do it four times to see that it solves all the corners and central edges again. I too did R'Lf on my cube and it solved in 80 repetitions, which is exactly what the math predicted. Doing R'Lf 120 times will mean that the corners and central edges will be solved (both orientation and permutation) and not twisted. This is because 120 is divisible evenly by 4. You can see that the f turn in R'Lf does not affect the orientations of the corners, and the R'L turns just cycle the corners around like just doing R'L (which solves in 4 reps). So this algorithm in a way doesn't affect corner orientation at all, other than to cycle them around exactly like doing R'L. I don't agree that doing this kind of stuff is really difficult or nearly impossible to do on the 5x5. It just takes some practice, and a supercube helps too for tracking the centers :) Try looking at R'Lf again. It does indeed solve the cube again every 80 reps, there is no error in the math, and I also tested it on my 5x5 and it worked in practice. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > Oh yeah, and I just tried out R'Lf. > > After 20, you get a pretty regular pattern that seems to take 6 moves > to finish, but actually doing it that total of 120 times (I did) gives > three corners a twist, so you have to do it a total of 360 times. I > don't know what you did with your math, but, especially with 5-bys, it > seems to be really difficult if not impossible to accurately do > something like this. > > I'm going to spiff up my program so you can put in a set of > instructions and tell it how many times to do it.
