1456. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 22:09:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Finished my site: > www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5a.html (taking apart the cube) > www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5b.htmk (puting it back together) > Check these out and tell me if they help. If you're not going to link to the full-size pictures then I'd suggest shrinking them (even Windows Paint does a quite good job at that). Not only will it reduce the size and thus the loading time of your page but it will also look better because browsers have poor on-the-fly shrinking capabilities. Now about the content :-) I personally prefer to build the cube bottom-up, building the top layer upside-down on a large adhesive strip and then putting this last layer on top of the bottom four as one big block. This of course requires that you open and unscrew at least the top center piece but you'll want to do that anyway, right? Uh, unless you have rivets... Cheers! Stefan
1457. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 22:39:53 -0000

Any news? Btw, I just noticed there had probably been a nice super 5x5 before: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1241 Using four colors you can have 6 different stickers (take one color as "reference", then you can have 3! permutations of the other three). So that's one sticker design for each face. Also, the orientation/position of a sticker on the correct face is forced. So this is a very nice (and probably ultimately confusing) super cube. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > Thank you. I've only completed making three sides so far, it's > taking much longer than I thought to make and I took Stefan's > suggestion of bordering the edges and corners. I couldn't wait last > night to start solving though, even with three sides suped up. > Though I think I've got it, I'm eager to see how the the other three > sides are being affected. Thanks again. > > MGW > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey! > > > > U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed centers > on > > the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 kinds: > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) > > > > And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + center > > can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). > However > > some slice moves do change both types of centers. > > > > The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u are > > lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + centers) > > independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, which u > > simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will need to > > interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u have a 2- > > cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u perform > 2 > > 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u do > that. > > > > All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There are > > faster ways if u do the centers first. > > > > Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have > > > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does > > not > > > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms > > on > > > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and > wonder > > if > > > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other > > > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry > that > > > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the > > > next week or longer.
1458. One-Handed UWR
From: "Ryan Patricio" <ryn_patricio@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Mar 2005 23:07:59 -0000


Here is my Pb and UWR average and Fastest single solve for One-
handed. I got an insane 23.38 because of a super easy scramble, but
not lucky, and a few other sub-30's as well, which were all non-
lucky solves. I use the Fridrich with 2-LL for one-handed cubing
with no special algs yet. My main goal is to average sub-30 before
the Champs. Its quite possibly as you can see by my many sub-30
solves.

Average: 32.34
Fastsest Time:23.38
Slowest Time:37.24
Standard Deviation:03.14

Individual Times:
1) 35.68 R2 B2 U' R D' L' B' F2 D' U L D B2 U' F'
U L2 B2 D2 B L2 F L' U' F'
2) 23.38 B' F D' F U R2 L2 U D B L2 B' R2 U D2 R2
L2 B2 L2 D2 L2 D' U' L F2
3) 35.63 U2 B' L U F' R D R2 U B R L F L U' B' U'
F' D' B2 R D2 R L B'
4) 29.83 B' F U' F' U R L2 B R F L U' R2 D' B2 R
F' R2 D B2 L' U B D F'
5) 31.36 U B' L' U2 D R2 B' D' B2 L D R2 L2 F' R2
F2 D' F' U' L' D U R B' U'
6) 37.24 R' F2 R' B2 D2 U R2 B' L2 F2 U' F2 R2 F
B' L2 U2 R' U R L' B R' U' D'
7) 32.09 U L' U' R2 D2 B R2 U' B' F' D2 B2 L' U'
B' L2 R U' D B' R' L U D2 B
8) 32.83 L' D2 R F2 U2 L D B2 L F2 D2 B L' B L R F
R L2 F B U L B R
9) 26.38 U' B R' D R' D2 F2 U' F2 D2 F R2 D2 R2 F'
R F2 U' F D' L F2 D2 U L
10) 32.81 B' R' D L U2 R2 B' D' F' U R2 D2 B2 R2 D
L' U2 R2 F' U2 F' D2 L' R' U2
11) 36.65 F2 U2 B2 R' L' U' F' B2 L' U' L2 D F' B'
R' B2 F L U' R2 U2 F B2 D2 F
12) 30.14 F2 U B L' U D2 L' F R D2 F' B2 D' U' F L
D B L' U2 L F U' F U'

1460. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 01:25:55 -0000


Agh, I just realized why we're getting different results. I use u as
turn the two layers at the U face, it looks like you only turn the
second layer. If you do it with turning both layers you'll see it does
take longer.





1461. Re: One-Handed UWR
From: "Ryan Patricio" <ryn_patricio@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 02:40:04 -0000

I'll post my solution to the one-handed 23.38 I did. I cube cross on left, so I'll try to note all the rotations I did. The cross on the solve was practically done except for 1 edge. Then many edges were correctly oriented so the F2L were a breeze. OLL was not so bad but he PLL was awesome. 1463. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 13:56:19 -0000

Hmm .... :-0 Solving that cube would give me long lasting headaches for sure. It looks even more evil than 6-color megaminx:-P U will have to look at the cycleic structure of each 4-colored sticker to know which layer (s) it belongs to. OMG. That seems so horrible. If ever i make myself a super-5x5x5 (or super-4x4x4) i will never have several colors on a "sticker". I will simply cut small arrows on each of the stickers on the centers and on one edgetriplet (or -pair) on each face. That is just my personal preference of course ;-) Happy super-cubing ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Any news? Btw, I just noticed there had probably been a nice super 5x5 > before: > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1241 > Using four colors you can have 6 different stickers (take one color as > "reference", then you can have 3! permutations of the other three). So > that's one sticker design for each face. Also, the > orientation/position of a sticker on the correct face is forced. So > this is a very nice (and probably ultimately confusing) super cube. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > Thank you. I've only completed making three sides so far, it's > > taking much longer than I thought to make and I took Stefan's > > suggestion of bordering the edges and corners. I couldn't wait last > > night to start solving though, even with three sides suped up. > > Though I think I've got it, I'm eager to see how the the other three > > sides are being affected. Thanks again. > > > > MGW > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey! > > > > > > U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed centers > > on > > > the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 kinds: > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) > > > > > > And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + center > > > can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). > > However > > > some slice moves do change both types of centers. > > > > > > The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u are > > > lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + centers) > > > independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, which u > > > simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will need to > > > interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u have a 2- > > > cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u perform > > 2 > > > 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u do > > that. > > > > > > All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There are > > > faster ways if u do the centers first. > > > > > > Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I have > > > > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife does > > > not > > > > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the algorithms > > > on > > > > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and > > wonder > > > if > > > > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the other > > > > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I worry > > that > > > > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for the > > > > next week or longer.

1465. Re: How many moves back to solved?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 14:48:15 -0000

Hey! I accidentally did R'L'f many times over... I found that after 12 repetitions it twists 6 corners clockwise. So obviously repeating 36 times and u are back to solved (same) state. But!! Four of the centers will be rotated 180 degrees (U, R, D and L). So to come to supersolved (super same) state we need to repeat 72 times. So how many repetitions are needed to twist those same corners while preserving the center-orientations? Doing it forwards one will need repeat 12 + 36 = 48 times. But applied backwards it will be enough with 2 * 12 = 24 repetitions ;-) In fact doing it forward one will reach counterclockwise rotation of those 6 corners while preserving the center-orientations after 24 repetitions. I wonder if any of this is good for blindfold solving? As sidenote there is a very easy way to twist 3 corners in 4 repetitions : ((R'D'RL) Fc)*4 (Fc denotes cube rotation.) Have fun!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > R'Lf doesn't twist the corners. Do it four times to see that it > solves all the corners and central edges again. > > I too did R'Lf on my cube and it solved in 80 repetitions, which is > exactly what the math predicted. > > Doing R'Lf 120 times will mean that the corners and central edges will > be solved (both orientation and permutation) and not twisted. This is > because 120 is divisible evenly by 4. You can see that the f turn in > R'Lf does not affect the orientations of the corners, and the R'L > turns just cycle the corners around like just doing R'L (which solves > in 4 reps). So this algorithm in a way doesn't affect corner > orientation at all, other than to cycle them around exactly like doing > R'L. > > I don't agree that doing this kind of stuff is really difficult or > nearly impossible to do on the 5x5. It just takes some practice, and > a supercube helps too for tracking the centers :) Try looking at R'Lf > again. It does indeed solve the cube again every 80 reps, there is no > error in the math, and I also tested it on my 5x5 and it worked in > practice. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > Oh yeah, and I just tried out R'Lf. > > > > After 20, you get a pretty regular pattern that seems to take 6 moves > > to finish, but actually doing it that total of 120 times (I did) gives > > three corners a twist, so you have to do it a total of 360 times. I > > don't know what you did with your math, but, especially with 5- bys, it > > seems to be really difficult if not impossible to accurately do > > something like this. > > > > I'm going to spiff up my program so you can put in a set of > > instructions and tell it how many times to do it.
1466. Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>

Btw, I just noticed there had probably been a nice super > 5x5 > > before: > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1241 > > Using four colors you can have 6 different stickers (take one > color as > > "reference", then you can have 3! permutations of the other > three). So > > that's one sticker design for each face. Also, the > > orientation/position of a sticker on the correct face is forced. > So > > this is a very nice (and probably ultimately confusing) super cube. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > Thank you. I couldn't wait > last > > > night to start solving though, even with three sides suped up. > > > Though I think I've got it, I'm eager to see how the the other > three > > > sides are being affected. Thanks > again. > > > > > > MGW > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Hey! > > > > > > > > U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed > centers > > > on > > > > the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 > kinds: > > > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) > > > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) > > > > > > > > And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + > center > > > > can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). > > > However > > > > some slice moves do change both types of centers. > > > > > > > > The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u > are > > > > lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + > centers) > > > > independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, > which u > > > > simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will need > to > > > > interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u have > a 2- > > > > cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u > perform > > > 2 > > > > 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u do > > > that. > > > > > > > > All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There > are > > > > faster ways if u do the centers first. > > > > > > > > Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I > have > > > > > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my wife > does > > > > not > > > > > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the > algorithms > > > > on > > > > > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and > > > wonder > > > > if > > > > > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the > other > > > > > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. I > worry > > > that > > > > > I'll be spending hours to create something I can't solve for > the > > > > > next week or longer.
1467. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Stefan's Super 5X5
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 07:38:36 -0800

But they're both solved! Kinda crazy huh? -E On Sun, 13 Mar 2005 15:11:41 -0000, mgwallisa <mattwallisa@...> wrote: > > Wow, why would anyone want to cause himself so much pain? It took > me a few seconds to realize which picture was scrambled and which > solved. Today mine will at last be done. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hmm .... :-0 > > > > Solving that cube would give me long lasting headaches for sure. > It > > looks even more evil than 6-color megaminx:-P U will have to look > at > > the cycleic structure of each 4-colored sticker to know which layer > > (s) it belongs to. OMG. That seems so horrible. If ever i make > > myself a super-5x5x5 (or super-4x4x4) i will never have several > > colors on a "sticker". I will simply cut small arrows on each of > the > > stickers on the centers and on one edgetriplet (or -pair) on each > > face. That is just my personal preference of course ;-) > > > > Happy super-cubing ;-) > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Any news? Btw, I just noticed there had probably been a nice > super > > 5x5 > > > before: > > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1241 > > > Using four colors you can have 6 different stickers (take one > > color as > > > "reference", then you can have 3! permutations of the other > > three). So > > > that's one sticker design for each face. Also, the > > > orientation/position of a sticker on the correct face is forced. > > So > > > this is a very nice (and probably ultimately confusing) super > cube. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Thank you. I've only completed making three sides so far, it's > > > > taking much longer than I thought to make and I took Stefan's > > > > suggestion of bordering the edges and corners. I couldn't > wait > > last > > > > night to start solving though, even with three sides suped > up. > > > > Though I think I've got it, I'm eager to see how the the other > > three > > > > sides are being affected. Thanks > > again. > > > > > > > > MGW > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > > > > Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hey! > > > > > > > > > > U can use the algorithms for 3x3x3 supercube on the fixed > > centers > > > > on > > > > > the 5x5x5 also of course :-) For the outer centers u have 2 > > kinds: > > > > > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the middle edges (+ centers) > > > > > > > > > > Those btw the fixed center and the corners (x centers) > > > > > > > > > > And of coz those 2 centergroups are kinda independent. A + > > center > > > > > can never go into the slot of an x center (and vice versa). > > > > However > > > > > some slice moves do change both types of centers. > > > > > > > > > > The way to solve these centers will be to permute them. If u > > are > > > > > lucky u can solve the 4 centers on a face (x centers or + > > centers) > > > > > independently of the other faces (a 3-cycle or 2 2-cycles, > > which u > > > > > simulate by 2 3-cycles actually). Or in some cases u will > need > > to > > > > > interoperate with centers on another face also, say if u > have > > a 2- > > > > > cycle (swap) on one face and same on another face. Then u > > perform > > > > 2 > > > > > 3-cycles involving those 2 faces. Im not gonna tell u how u > do > > > > that. > > > > > > > > > > All this of coz if u do the centers as the last step. There > > are > > > > > faster ways if u do the centers first. > > > > > > > > > > Best of luck with 5x5x5 supersolving :-) > > > > > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" > > > > > <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > Having been inspired from the pictures on Stefan's site, I > > have > > > > > > collected the materials and set aside this evening (my > wife > > does > > > > > not > > > > > > yet know) to replicating his Super 5X5. I've used the > > algorithms > > > > > on > > > > > > Jaap's site for solving the centers on the Rubik World and > > > > wonder > > > > > if > > > > > > I'd be going in the right direction by using this for the > > other > > > > > > centers on the 5X5, just adjusting the algs slightly. 1470. 4x4x4 speed solving
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 01:25:43 -0000


I have a 4x4x4, but due to my attempts at speedcubing, one of the
face pieces snapped off. I glue it back on but it comes off again
every third time.

Are there any special ways that you can get under three minutes
without breaking the cube?





1471. Re: 4x4x4 speed solving
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 01:33:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y... > wrote: > > I have a 4x4x4, but due to my attempts at speedcubing, one of the > face pieces snapped off. I glue it back on but it comes off again > every third time. > > Are there any special ways that you can get under three minutes > without breaking the cube? Yes, you must hypnotize the cube. Now seriously... what kind of 4x4 do you have? Rubik? Eastsheen? Eastsheen shouldn't need to be glued I think. If it's a Rubik, then you might want to disassemble the cube so that you can properly fix the piece that broke. However, solving fast has not much to do with (not) breaking the cube. It's the technique that matters and elimination of breaks, which is even more important and harder than for 3x3. I doubt any of the top 4x4 solvers take special care about not breaking the cube. Just twist nicely. And own a good cube. Preferably one that's not broken already ;-) Or own two and fix one with pieces from the other... Cheers! Stefan
1472. Re: 4x4x4 speed solving
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 04:18:17 -0000

Five dollars at rubiks.com will get you two corner, edge, and center pieces and two sets of stickers. That's not too bad, since it's the same price for three sets of stickers, you're probably going to re- sticker the cube some time anyway. Now my problem is how to ever solve that in three minutes... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > > I have a 4x4x4, but due to my attempts at speedcubing, one of the > face pieces snapped off. I glue it back on but it comes off again > every third time. > > Are there any special ways that you can get under three minutes > without breaking the cube?

1476. Store bought cube continued
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 16:03:04 -0000


I thought I would post the rest of what happened with my bad Wal-mart
cube.

I took back the cube I bought and exchanged it for another one. This
time though in the store I tried out the cubes on the shelf instead of
just picking one of them up. I was able to find one that had uniform
turning for the faces, but it is still surprisingly loose for a new cube.

I imagine as a speedcube this cube will wear out pretty quickly, but
if it does I guess I'll just try to break it in further for a
one-handed cube.

Just curious, but what happened to the manufacturing of the general
store version cubes? When did it change and what did they do?

Chris





1477. Re: Store bought cube continued
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 16:28:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I imagine as a speedcube this cube will wear out pretty quickly One suggestion I have would be to use silicone spray inside the center pieces as well. Since those rivets are impossible to get out, there's no danger. But it might make it turn a bit easier and protect the plastic a bit better so that it doesn't get so loose so fast. With screws, nowadays I take them out, sand the spring ends flat and use silicone spray almost everywhere. It does help a lot. I'd imagine just spraying helps already, too. > Just curious, but what happened to the manufacturing of the general > store version cubes? When did it change and what did they do? When was the last time you bought one? Did you buy an arched-center cube before? My impression is that the change came with the arched centers. When stores still had both versions I could usually tell whether they have arched centers just by testing the tension. Cheers! Stefan
1478. Re: Lubing a 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 16:41:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y.. .> > wrote: > > > > Finished my site: > > www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5a.html (taking apart the cube) > > www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc5b.htmk (puting it back together) > > Check these out and tell me if they help. > > Now about the content :-) I personally prefer to build the cube > bottom-up, building the top layer upside-down on a large adhesive > strip and then putting this last layer on top of the bottom four as > one big block. This of course requires that you open and unscrew at > least the top center piece but you'll want to do that anyway, right? > Uh, unless you have rivets... Hmm, I found a disadvantage of my way. My last action (well, before adding the centercap) is to tighten the screw of the U center. But then I can't control the tension nicely anymore because the view is blocked by then. So next time I'll perfectly adjust the tension of all six centers and assemble my cube your way. Thanks and Cheers! Stefan

1480. Re: U3 references
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 17:42:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@r...> wrote: > Just a quick question about alg1 'T' in the PLL of Fridrich Method. > > Why is the first move an U3 and not U' ?? > > Noticed that there are other U3 references such as alg3 in 'Y' and alg2 in 'F'. > There must be some sort of hidden advantage to performing U3. > > Thanks > Dwayne Hi Dwayne, Most often in the very first attempts at notation, people began using a single letter and a number to mark a turn. They labeled turns with the colors of the sides, and 1, 2 or 3 for how much to turn. Thus turns were labeled, for example, R1 for a clockwise turn of Red, B2 for 180 degree turn of Blue, and O3 for a counterclockwise turn of Orange. This, of course, worked fairly well until you met up with someone with a different color scheme. Then there was a lot of variation, like T for Top or U for Upper, B for Bottom or Back, R for Rear or Right, and it wasn't until David Singmaster's work got around that cubists generally began using the same letters and the single apostrophe ' for 3. I used the colors to start with. I wonder what other early cubists used at first. Regards, David J
1481. Re: Rubik's Cube is going mobile.
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 17:46:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > http://home.businesswire.com/portal/site/google/in > dex.jsp?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20050314005355&newsLang=en > > -Chris The cube is going mobile? Thank goodness! I can't tell you how much I hate having this cord attached to it all the time
1482. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: U3 references
From: Mark Longridge <mark@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Mar 2005 15:13:58 -0500

I can't speak for everyone but I can say why I used U3. In the days of early dot matrix printers the ' symbol was so slight it was rather hard to read so 3 was used instead. In my earliest notes I wrote down U- instead of U3. It was only when I started to use the computer that I used U3 and the like. To this day I still used a single letter suffixed by a number. By May 1982 I was a Singmaster notation user. If you scan through the old cube-lovers lists you can see some alternatives, like using A B C D E F instead of Befuddler notation. After I saw Minh Thai's book I started to use pictographs as well as Befuddler. But with puzzles like the megaminx U3 for U- becomes problematic. I guess pictographs are best for the megaminx although I never had a good algebraic system I'd be curious to hear about one. Mark On March 14, 2005 12:42 pm, d_j_salvia wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > > <ddollard@r...> wrote: > > Just a quick question about alg1 'T' in the PLL of Fridrich Method. > > > > Why is the first move an U3 and not U' ?? > > > > Noticed that there are other U3 references such as alg3 in 'Y' and > > alg2 in 'F'. > > > There must be some sort of hidden advantage to performing U3. > > > > Thanks > > Dwayne > > Hi Dwayne, > > Most often in the very first attempts at notation, people began > using a single letter and a number to mark a turn. They labeled turns > with the colors of the sides, and 1, 2 or 3 for how much to turn. Thus > turns were labeled, for example, R1 for a clockwise turn of Red, B2 > for 180 degree turn of Blue, and O3 for a counterclockwise turn of > Orange. This, of course, worked fairly well until you met up with > someone with a different color scheme. > Then there was a lot of variation, like T for Top or U for Upper, B > for Bottom or Back, R for Rear or Right, and it wasn't until David > Singmaster's work got around that cubists generally began using the > same letters and the single apostrophe ' for 3. > > I used the colors to start with. I wonder what other early cubists > used at first. > > Regards, > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > >

I do not work for Seven Towns, but I did contact Rubik's to inquire
about the availability of the DIY cubes. This is the response I
received:

"The DIY 3x3 assembly kits were ordered at the beginning of
February. The estimated time for the manufacturer to fill the order,
travel time and clearing customs is usually 8-12 weeks."

I currently use a DIY cube, and found it to be very good.

Hope that helps.

-DWC

1488. 4x4x4 parity errors
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 02:11:43 -0000


Just got my first 4x4x4 cube. I am using a modified 5x5x5 method. In
this method, i solve centers, then i pair the edges, then i solve
like a 3x3x3. But it is not that easy. I have two problems which come
up. One is where two edges are fliped incorrectly. Another is where
(talking in terms of a 3x3x3, meaning two edges of a 4x4x4= one edge
of a 3x3x3) two edge pieces need to be switched which is impossible
on the 3x3x3 so i do not know anymoves that will fix it. What algs
can i use to fix these two problems?





1489. Re: 4x4x4 parity errors
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 04:02:50 -0000


> What algs can i use to fix these two problems?

I use Chris' Algs:

Flip edge: (R2 r2) B2 U2 (L l) U2 (R' r') U2 (R r) U2 F2 (R r) F2
(L' l') B2 (R2 r2).

Switch two edges: r2 U2 r2 U2 u2 r2 u2

-Chris





1490. Yo-Yos
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 07:56:11 -0000


I was just curious, I was online tonight, and decided I really missed
my yo-yo at home, and decided to order one...was anyone else a big
fan of Yo-Yo tricks?

Joe S

1499. Re: [Speed cubing group] Yo-Yos
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 17:07:07 -0000

Ahh yes, the yo-yo I pull a few strings myself. More than 5 years ago, I saved for almost 6 months and bought myslef the Pro-Yo Cold Fusion (at that time, it held the world record for sleep time)for $150. I worked with it and got pretty good. I'm doing a little yo practicing right now. Over spring break, I help my mother teach her 6th grade science students a bit about yo-yo physics. Fun stuff. My fav trick is Boing-y-Boing where the yo is bounced back and forth between 2 strings. It's really neat. TBTTFox --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, nascarjon2001 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > I still yo every once in a while. I use my Custom Reactor or Yomega > Hyperwarps most of the time. I like my Metallic Missile too. > > Jon
1500. Re: 4x4x4 parity errors
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 17:51:00 -0000

I recently switched over one of these algs to one of the ones on Stefan Pochmann's site. Instead of r2 U2 r2 U2 u2 r2 u2 I now do Stefan's move: (Uu)2 (Ll)2 U2 l2 U2 (Ll)2 (Uu)2 It is one move shorter in big cube turning metric (I don't think it has a name yet) but it is the metric I always use for the 4x4 and 5x5. I'm going to switch it over on my site soon, or at least include both moves. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > What algs can i use to fix these two problems? > > I use Chris' Algs: > > Flip edge: (R2 r2) B2 U2 (L l) U2 (R' r') U2 (R r) U2 F2 (R r) F2 > (L' l') B2 (R2 r2). > > Switch two edges: r2 U2 r2 U2 u2 r2 u2 > > -Chris

1506. Re: [Speed cubing group] Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 18:10:20 -0600

It actually happened to me last week. Granted, I did a little bit during the F2L in order to make sure I didn't wind up with all of my edges needing oriented, but it was still a heck of a lot more done than I had intended. I was so surprised I forgot to stop the timer, though. For shame, I know. I've also had a incredible amount of lucky step skipping solves since Monday when I started toying around (hooray for puns!) with Gilles' method. And for some strange reason, after I've been using Gilles' method and I solve using my layer-by-layer solution, my times are always fantastic. I'm averaging about 33 seconds for solves that way, and about 38 or 39 for layer-by-layer solves when that's all I use. I'm currently averaging just under 55 seconds with Gilles' method, but I'm improving quickly. The hardest part is assembling that cursed second block. Oh well. I shall perservere. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: metgorubiks<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, March 16, 2005 5:53 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve I was wondering if any of you have ever been lucky enough to have skip the OLL and PLL in the same solve. It has never happend to me, but I know it is possible. Yahoo! 1513. nxnxn program
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 04:05:47 -0000


I'm making a really basic flatcube program for an nxnxn cube - the
idea is that you have a set of predefined moves, e.g. (Ll)', which are
done by parsing the input (or maybe something else), but you can also
make a queue of moves which the program will find how many moves it
takes to solve.

Does anyone have a use for such a program?
What would you want to see in a flatcube program?

PS. I'm not at all fond of drag-drop on flatcubes, but I may implement
it if I can figure out how I'd like it to be...

Hmm... I'll need a scrambler... should I just do n^3 random moves or what?





1514. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 08:38:37 -0000

"It's happened to me probably about 10-15 times. -Chris" Wow, do you play the lottery? ;) This is one of my favourite cubing stories that I like to get out from time to time. The first time this happened to me was when I was in Toronto for the World Championships of 2003. At this point I was averaging around 25-30 seconds probably, I'm not exactly sure. I was waiting in the lobby of the hotel for some familiar faces to come along so I could join them, and I was just practicing solving a few cubes. In the second cube I solved of the day, insert final F2L pair, make a U2, cube is solved! It was an incredible feeling, probably part disbelief, and part the feeling you get when you solve the cube for the first time. I had always wondered when it would happen to me. If only it had happened a day later at the actual championships, the time was around 16 seconds or so! Ah well. Since 2003 it has only happened to me once more, at Christmas time last year. The time was 11.79s, but so incredibly lucky of course! Dan Harris :) - www.cubestation.co.uk _____ From: burntbizzkit [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 17 March 2005 00:42 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve It's happened to me probably about 10-15 times. -Chris Yahoo! 1516. [Speed cubing group] Re: Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 08:50:35 -0000

Back when I was using petrus, it happened to me somewhere between 4-6 times in a session...where I got really lucky cases, and skipped stuff. Of twelve solves, I had maybe 1 PLL OLL skip, and 5 PLL skips. I was almost convinced that i was subconsciously fixing everything. 1517. Re: nxnxn program
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 09:36:14 -0000


--- "qqwref" wrote:
> I'm making a really basic flatcube program for an nxnxn cube - the
> idea is that you have a set of predefined moves, e.g. (Ll)', which
> are done by parsing the input (or maybe something else), but you
> can also make a queue of moves which the program will find how
> many moves it takes to solve.

What do you mean by that last part? That you give it a scramble and
it gives you the number of moves it takes to solve using some
straightforward solving method?

> Hmm... I'll need a scrambler... should I just do n^3 random moves
> or what?

That is certainly the easiest way, though you must weed out trivial
simplifications such as LRL. This is done by insisting that if the
next move lies on the same axis as the previous one, it must be
closer to the Left, Back, or Down face (if not, it is rejected and a
new random move tried instead).

Jaap





1518. Re: Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 09:38:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering if any of you have ever been lucky enough to have > skip the OLL and PLL in the same solve. It has never happend to me, > but I know it is possible. If you have solved more than 3!.4!.3^3.2^3/2=15552 cubes, then you're an unlucky guy. Something must be wrong with your date of birth or stars positions. Of course, statistics for people who try to do more during the F2L stage are different. When I was using Lars' approach, I got many cubes automagically solved. But in this case (LL edges oriented), chances increase to 1/1944. Gilles.
1519. Re: Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 17:38:59 -0000

1524. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 17:20:23 -0500

> What do you mean by that last part? That you give it a scramble and
> it gives you the number of moves it takes to solve using some
> straightforward solving method?

Actually, the idea is that you give it a set of moves and it will tell
you how many times, from the solved state, you have to do that to get
back to a solved state.

> That is certainly the easiest way, though you must weed out trivial
> simplifications such as LRL. This is done by insisting that if the
> next move lies on the same axis as the previous one, it must be
> closer to the Left, Back, or Down face (if not, it is rejected and a
> new random move tried instead).

What I will probably do is since I have three functions (for example,
turn_F(3,-1) would turn the 3rd face from F 1 turn ccw - in effect,
a B on a 3-by) is just not do two in a row.

Although I might have some trouble getting it to do a thousand of those
(10-by) because I can't program anything but Visual Basic, which is one
of the slowest programming languages in existance.

--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1527. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Mar 2005 21:26:58 -0500

I just timed it, it takes ~6 sec for 10,000 moves.

If I have 1000 moves, it will take .6 seconds, and that's quite a
noticeable lag. It might not be so bad, but if your computer is
moderately old it might get up to a few seconds, in which case it
would be quite a problem.

I don't have the stuff stored as numbers, I have it stored as colors.
Reflecting on that, I see it's a really bad decision, but I guess it
will work for now.

--qqwref

Hey! Yes i agree that Visual Basic is a poor language for algorithmic stuff (and most other stuff too). It shouldn't be hard for u to switch to programming in Delphi instead. Then u get much faster code, and not least real standalone executables. U won't need Delphi70run.dll or anything to run the code ;-) But yes, what are u actually planning to make? A visualisation program, a basic solver, something similar to ACube for larger cubes ... ?? Anyway, good luck with it :-) -Per >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > What do you mean by that last part? 1531. [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 15:21:13 -0000

You, too, Per ?!? I'm not really a fan of micro$oft and haven't hear much good about VB, but it's not that slow. If the program is that much too slow then I claim it's the fault of the programmer! I did a little test. The same code fragment in three different languages. Here are the results: VB: 6.02 seconds C++: 6.06 seconds Java: 6.66 seconds So think again! Here's the code: -------------------------------------------------------- Public Class HowEasy Function pointVal ( ByVal myStr As String ) As Integer Dim i As Integer Dim sum As Integer i = 0 sum = 0 While i < 100000000 sum = (sum + i) Mod 5214247 i = i + 1 End While Return sum End Function End Class -------------------------------------------------------- public class HowEasy { public int pointVal ( String s ) { int i = 0; int sum = 0; while( i < 100000000 ){ sum = (sum + i) % 5214247; i = i + 1; } return sum; } } -------------------------------------------------------- #include <string> using namespace std; struct HowEasy { int pointVal ( string s ) { int i = 0; int sum = 0; while( i < 100000000 ){ sum = (sum + i) % 5214247; i = i + 1; } return sum; } }; -------------------------------------------------------- Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > Yes i agree that Visual Basic is a poor language for algorithmic > stuff (and most other stuff too). It shouldn't be hard for u to > switch to programming in Delphi instead. Then u get much faster > code, and not least real standalone executables. U won't need > Delphi70run.dll or anything to run the code ;-) > > But yes, what are u actually planning to make? A visualisation > program, a basic solver, something similar to ACube for larger > cubes ... ?? > > Anyway, good luck with it :-) > > -Per > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs > Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > What do you mean by that last part? That you give it a scramble > and > > > it gives you the number of moves it takes to solve using some > > > straightforward solving method? > > > > Actually, the idea is that you give it a set of moves and it will > tell > > you how many times, from the solved state, you have to do that to > get > > back to a solved state. > > > > > That is certainly the easiest way, though you must weed out > trivial > > > simplifications such as LRL. 1532. [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 15:31:29 -0000

Sorry about the bad (= non-existing) indenting. Btw, the "Mod" operation takes a lot of time. If I do "sum = sum + 1" instead, then the VB program runs in 0.57 seconds. So 100 million of my loop iterations in about the time the cube program does 1000 cube twists. So 1 cube twist is 100,000 of my loop iterations. Hard to believe unless you have a really huge cube. Cheers! Stefan P.S. Yes, I know the comparison is a bit naive because the computers used were probably a bit different... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I did a little test. The same code fragment in three different > languages. Here are the results: > > VB: 6.02 seconds > C++: 6.06 seconds > Java: 6.66 seconds

1534. Re: [Speed cubing group] Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 17:09:28 -0000

Recently I came to the LL of my Megaminx and all I had to do was a 3-cycle of corners I think. Edges were completely solved, corners were all oriented. Megaminx LL has (4!/2)*(3^4)*(5!/2)*(2^4)=933120 possibilities. There are 5*4*3=60 ones with just a corner 3-cycle. So 60/933120=1/15552 chance to get that, almost the same as complete 3x3 LL. But if I ever get complete Megaminx LL for free... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@y...> wrote: > happened once during a solve for me, it was a 17.12 :) > > finished solving f2l and boom, im done! > > can we call this an extremely lucky case. > > > > --- Doug Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: > > Funny that this thread popped up when it did. I was > > practicing today > > and got a 10.62s solve with a LL skip. Just had to > > perform a U' or > > something. It was pretty neat. > > > > metgorubiks wrote: > > > > >I was wondering if any of you have ever been lucky > > enough to have > > >skip the OLL and PLL in the same solve. It has > > never happend to me, > > >but I know it is possible. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Small Business - Try our new resources site! > http://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/resources/
1535. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program

Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 17:58:25 -0500

Well, what I'm basically doing is sending it to a function which swaps colors four at a time. What I *should* be doing is storing it as numbers, but (1) I'm lazy and (2) I'm going to be in France for two weeks and then I have school again.

The point of the program was to make a program to tell for sure how many times you have to do a certain move, although I do agree it will probably be faster if I store the whole thing as a number array.

Actually, I'm learning how to do good drawing in C++ right about now, maybe version 0.0.0.0.0.2 won't stay in VB.

1536. Re: [Speed cubing group] Have any of you ever skiped the OLL and PLL in the same solve
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 18:03:45 -0500

Quite literally one in a million, I think!

...By the way, when I do the cube for patterns I do a 4-step LL, and while that's not very efficient I think it would be good for the Megaminx, at least until I figure out how to get the thing open and lube it. Does anyone have any functional Megaminx LL algorithms in a good format? I can orient the thing (barely) knowing the FURU'R'F' and the Sune, but permutation is something I really need. I haven't been able to find anything because all the sites I've seen either use complicated and counterintuitive (at least for me and my closed-minded FURLBD system) instructions, or a compeltely different LL system (permutation first, or corners first, or weird 3-cycle arrangements with no pictures.

--qqwref

1540. F2L...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 12:37:09 -0000


Scramble with (L U L') y (L' U2 L). Now there should be a pair at FL
that belongs into RB. Until now I would've solved this with the
inverse of the above (i.e. with (L' U2 L y' L U' L')).

Yesterday I had the idea to rethink my 3x3 algorithms (because it has
helped me for megaminx, too) and now I see two more ways which I might
like better: (R' F U' F' R) and (L' U L x' U' R U [Ll]'). How do you
solve this case?

Cheers!
Stefan






1541. Megaminx PLL (was: something else)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 12:49:47 -0000

Hmm, maybe that's not true, since he solves edges first. But he explains corner permutation, so only edge permutation is missing. I'd have two suggestions for methods like the one for corners. Both can be used for 3x3 as well. One way would be like: (L' R F L R') U (L' R F' L R') U (L' R F L R') U2 (L' R F' L R') The second idea (lowercase = double layer turn): (L d L') U (L d' L') U (L d L') U2 (L d' L') However, I believe that edges first is better for the megaminx, since corners are much easier to move around without destroying other things. Without knowing any real algorithms (just understandable beginners methods like those above, also for orientation) I got a sub2 average recently (by now I've learned a few algorithms, though). Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Did you look at Grant Tregay's method I mentioned to you a while ago? > Your description of what you do *not* want doesn't fit his solution I > think ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs > Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > > > ...By the way, when I do the cube for patterns I do a 4-step LL, and > while that's not very efficient I think it would be good for the > Megaminx, at least until I figure out how to get the thing open and > lube it. Does anyone have any functional Megaminx LL algorithms in a > good format? I can orient the thing (barely) knowing the FURU'R'F' and > the Sune, but permutation is something I really need. I haven't been > able to find anything because all the sites I've seen either use > complicated and counterintuitive (at least for me and my closed-minded > FURLBD system) instructions, or a compeltely different LL system > (permutation first, or corners first, or weird 3-cycle arrangements > with no pictures. > > > > --qqwref > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1542. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 10:35:48 -0500

> I have to admit I'm quite confused. What do you mean with you work on
> "colors"? The computer doesn't know anything about colors. The
> computer only knows numbers (or bits, bytes...).

Visual Basic does. The whole thing is sort of designed around making
everything really easy to do (although it is sort of slow). I have a shape
Squar.Item(40) and it has a property BackColor, and if I want I can say
Squar.Item(30).BackColor = Squar.Item(40).BackColor, and it will change
the colors, although it is very very slow. Very slow. It has to convert
the current color to an RGB value, set the other to it, and display it.

> Oh wait, I just saw you said "drawing". You mean you're displaying the
> cube? That would somehow explain my question above. Is this the case?
> Then I'm not surprised it's so slow... better don't expect a language
> change to work wonders.

Visual Basic is just... really really slow. If I did the thing in C++
with a number array I would not be surprised if it ran a hundred times
faster. Most modern games are written in C++ anyway, and so you probably
know how fast certain computer games can get when they're in C++...

Visual Basic is basically a language for beginners.

--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1543. Re: F2L...
From: "Andy C" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 16:39:02 -0000


> How do you solve this case?

I've been doing basically the same thing for over a year. It's just another one of my F2L
shortcuts. Take advantage of open pairs.

Andy

http://andyscubepage.tk





1544. [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 19:13:17 -0000

Hey! Ok, i might have a been a bit premature with judging VB as very slow. it seems later versions of VB have gotten up to speed,unlike the early versions ... If the shapes work in VB as they do in Delphi then for sure u are not going the best way about it. What u need is a color-array clrArray= array[0..5] of color -> 6 different colors Now have the facelets of the cube assigned a color by simply assigning a number 0->5. This converts to a color by looking up in the clrArray. Only look this up when u do drawing, not when doing behind the scenes calculations (like when scrambling the cube with umpteen moves). The way u do it i think ur shapes has no choice but to repaint themselves each time u change the colour. So when doing a scrambling with ur basic method one would see lots of flickering on the screen until the scrambling is done. This leads me to another point. Look up how u can do double buffering technique. It's really worth checking out since u get a much more pleasant visual experience with it. Setting up double buffering in delphi is a breeze actually. If u put an image on a panel, then simple setting the panel doublebuffered will make ur image doublebuffered. In fact i recommend not using shapes. Make ur own methods for showing cubies, using simple line graphics or polygons. As an alternative make ur own transparent graphics (sprites) that u copy to the basic image when updating the display. Yet another hint. Find some components that support DirectX if u wanna code it solely for Windows. U will get much faster graphics code than using the basic GDI, which is what u use with default images. I guess that's it for now ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > I have to admit I'm quite confused. What do you mean with you work on > > "colors"? The computer doesn't know anything about colors. The > > computer only knows numbers (or bits, bytes...). > > Visual Basic does. The whole thing is sort of designed around making > everything really easy to do (although it is sort of slow). I have a shape > Squar.Item(40) and it has a property BackColor, and if I want I can say > Squar.Item(30).BackColor = Squar.Item(40).BackColor, and it will change > the colors, although it is very very slow. Very slow. It has to convert > the current color to an RGB value, set the other to it, and display it. > > > Oh wait, I just saw you said "drawing". You mean you're displaying the > > cube? That would somehow explain my question above. Is this the case? > > Then I'm not surprised it's so slow... better don't expect a language > > change to work wonders. > > Visual Basic is just... really really slow. If I did the thing in C++ > with a number array I would not be surprised if it ran a hundred times > faster. Most modern games are written in C++ anyway, and so you probably > know how fast certain computer games can get when they're in C++... > > Visual Basic is basically a language for beginners. > > --qqwref > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1545. [Speed cubing group] Re: nxnxn program
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 22:16:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > Visual Basic is just... really really slow. If I did the thing in C++ > with a number array I would not be surprised if it ran a hundred times > faster. Most modern games are written in C++ anyway, and so you probably > know how fast certain computer games can get when they're in C++... Listen to what you say, man! Visual Basic is not slow. The way you're using it is slow. Of course I agree with what you say, that C++ with simple arrays will speed it up dramatically. But that's not because of C++ but because of the simple arrays. You could do the same thing in VB and also get a dramatic speed up. It's not the fault of the language. Cheers! Stefan

From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

1547. Re: F2L...
From: "Andy C" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Mar 2005 04:13:22 -0000



> What's "the same thing"? I mentioned three different ways ;-)

Sorry about that. I meant to say that I have been using all three of those solutions( (L' U2 L
y' L U' L'), (R' F U' F' R), and (L' U L x' U' R U l') ) for over a year. I usually choose which one
to use randomly or how the cube is oriented in my hands (so I don't have to do any x, y, or
z setup moves). Or sometimes there is another c/e pair that I could preserve for later if I
use a certain sequence.

I hope that cleared things up for you.

Andy





1548. RE: [Speed cubing group] F2L...
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 20 Mar 2005 17:02:33 -0000

Hi Stefan, I like this algorithm: B r' F r B' - I also might use (L' U L) d (L U' L') Dan :) _____ From: Stefan Pochmann [mailto:pochmann@...] Sent: 19 March 2005 12:37 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] F2L... Scramble with (L U L') y (L' U2 L). Now there should be a pair at FL that belongs into RB. Until now I would've solved this with the inverse of the above (i.e. with (L' U2 L y' L U' L')). Yesterday I had the idea to rethink my 3x3 algorithms (because it has helped me for megaminx, too) and now I see two more ways which I might like better: (R' F U' F' R) and (L' U L x' U' R U [Ll]'). How do you solve this case? Cheers! Stefan Yahoo! 1560. Re: 2 > 3
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 00:04:23 -0000

It cannot be true. A 3x3 actually has a 2x2 built into it (ignoring edges). Surely, ADDING extra pieces to solve makes it more difficult. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Question: Why is the 2x2 actually *harder* to solve than the 3x3, as > claimed by a current auction? > > Stefan

1563. Re: 2 > 3
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 01:19:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > It cannot be true. A 3x3 actually has a 2x2 built into it (ignoring > edges). That's pretty much what I said when I asked why the 2x2 should be harder. The answer I got was that the 3x3 offers more possibilities to twist. That was a new reason to me. And I'm not making fun. I do believe he believes it. In the past I've read a few times from people who can solve the 3x3 that they have trouble with the 2x2. My guess was that the main reason for it is the missing "color reference" (the centers), and a lack of understanding their 3x3 solution. So I was a bit surprised when I heard this new reason. Sometimes I do want to understand how non-cubers think ;-) Cheers! Stefan

1572. Re: 2 > 3
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 10:17:13 -0000

--- Bob Burton <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > It cannot be true. A 3x3 actually has a 2x2 built > into it (ignoring > edges). Surely, ADDING extra pieces to solve makes > it more difficult. I consider the 4x4x4 more difficult than the 5x5x5, since the parity problems are visible on the 5x5x5 but not on the 4x4x4. Also, at a certain point adding more pieces does not make it harder, just longer to solve. Other than that, I definitely agree with you. --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > That's pretty much what I said when I asked why the 2x2 should be > harder. The answer I got was that the 3x3 offers more possibilities > to twist. In a general sense, the more moves are possible, the easier it gets, because you have more 'degrees of freedom'. Think of the Rubik's shells for example. That one also has to do with how many pieces are affected by a single move - the more piece affected by a single move, the harder it gets. Anyway, the number of positions is not always a good indicator of how difficult a puzzle really is. It can be a lot easier than that number suggests if: - there are many moves are available - the moves affect only a few pieces - there are two moves that both affect a small number of pieces. The last point is because that would make commutators (ABA'B' for moves A and B) have small and frequently useful effects. As for the 2x2x2 cube, it not only has so few positions compared to the 3x3x3, two of the three criteria show that it should be even more easy than that. Jaap
1573. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2 > 3
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 10:30:54 -0000

Nothing much to add. This just reminded me of all those maths results that are proven for dimensions 5 (sometimes 6) and higher but either require much harder proofs or remain unproven in 3 and 4 dimensions. Geometrically and topologically its all to do with degrees of freedom. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "_jaap" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, March 21, 2005 10:17 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2 > 3 > > > > --- Bob Burton <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > It cannot be true. A 3x3 actually has a 2x2 built > > into it (ignoring > > edges). Surely, ADDING extra pieces to solve makes > > it more difficult. > > I consider the 4x4x4 more difficult than the 5x5x5, since the parity > problems are visible on the 5x5x5 but not on the 4x4x4. > Also, at a certain point adding more pieces does not make it harder, > just longer to solve. > Other than that, I definitely agree with you. > > --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > That's pretty much what I said when I asked why the 2x2 should be > > harder. The answer I got was that the 3x3 offers more possibilities > > to twist. > > In a general sense, the more moves are possible, the easier it gets, > because you have more 'degrees of freedom'. Think of the Rubik's > shells for example. That one also has to do with how many pieces are > affected by a single move - the more piece affected by a single move, > the harder it gets. > > Anyway, the number of positions is not always a good indicator of how > difficult a puzzle really is. It can be a lot easier than that number > suggests if: > - there are many moves are available > - the moves affect only a few pieces > - there are two moves that both affect a small number of pieces. > > The last point is because that would make commutators (ABA'B' for > moves A and B) have small and frequently useful effects. > > As for the 2x2x2 cube, it not only has so few positions compared to > the 3x3x3, two of the three criteria show that it should be even more > easy than that. > > Jaap > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
1574. Re: 2 > 3
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 12:12:32 -0000

Hahahahaha ... good one Stefan ;-) The missing moves on a 2x2x2 wrt 3x3x3 are not needed. Missing color reference is understandable. About reference, i find it much easier to solve larger cubes layer by layer than edge-pairing/3x3x3 reduction. This is simply cause it's much easier to have the "whole cube" as reference, compared with having to find 2 (or 3) matching edges to pair up. Those could be scattered wherever on the cube. Better reference -> better lookahead -> faster solving !!! Even i probably use more moves, the better lookahead makes up for that :-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > It cannot be true. A 3x3 actually has a 2x2 built into it (ignoring > > edges). > > That's pretty much what I said when I asked why the 2x2 should be > harder. The answer I got was that the 3x3 offers more possibilities to > twist. > > That was a new reason to me. And I'm not making fun. I do believe he > believes it. In the past I've read a few times from people who can > solve the 3x3 that they have trouble with the 2x2. My guess was that > the main reason for it is the missing "color reference" (the centers), > and a lack of understanding their 3x3 solution. So I was a bit > surprised when I heard this new reason. Sometimes I do want to > understand how non-cubers think ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan
1575. Re: 2 > 3 (Jaap)

Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 12:32:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I consider the 4x4x4 more difficult than the 5x5x5, since the parity > problems are visible on the 5x5x5 but not on the 4x4x4. > Also, at a certain point adding more pieces does not make it harder, > just longer to solve. Especially when you consider that all the "center" pieces you add have only 1 facelet (no orientation). I never tried supercubing with a big cube. Is it more interesting, or just even longer to solve than a normal one? If I remember correctly, last year you were thinking about a software cube with nxnxn real cubies. I'm curious about the difficulty of such a beast... Gilles.

1577. negative time rules
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 19:25:14 -0000


Does a negative time solve have to be during daylight savings time, or
can it be across different time zones?





1578. Re: [Speed cubing group] negative time rules
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 13:35:05 -0800

Traditionally we do it across daylight savings. That's because we only
have one time to do it each year. If you do it across time zones, you
would have more opportunities up to the point where it wasn't anything
special.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Mar 21, 2005, at 11:25 AM, Ben King wrote:

>
>
> Does a negative time solve have to be during daylight savings time, or
> can it be across different time zones?
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>

1580. Re: 2 > 3

1581. Dallas, Texas
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 21 Mar 2005 14:00:09 -0800

Hi Everyone,

Those of you in the Caltech Rubik's Cube Group already know of this
plan pretty well by now.

We are planning a tournament for August 13, 2005 in Dallas, Texas. It
will be held at a museum called The Science Place and you can easily
look them up online. (http://www.scienceplace.org/) We, Mark Sullivan
and I, will be meeting with museum staff on Wednesday to discuss the
tournament.

As with any tournament, our success depends on the number of
participants. I have created a table in the database section of the
Caltech Rubik's yahoo groups. The yahoo groups can be accessed here:
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/caltechrubiks/ .

Just enter in your name and what city you're from. The goal for me is
to see that at least 20 people from this online community are
interested in this tournament. Sign up please if you think you can
possibly go.

If I feel the interest in sufficient (so sign up...), we will
officially announce this tournament after the meeting with the museum.
For those of you where at the tournament in San Francisco, this one
promises to be at least as good. Our club has learned from our
mistakes the changes that are necessary in order to run a tournament in
a museum so it should run much more smoothly.

Anyway, I can do only so much. Without you guys, the tournament
doesn't happen so if you live around the Dallas area or you think you'd
be willing to fly there for an ultimate cube experience, sign up!

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




1582. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2 > 3
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 08:20:01 -0000

Poincare is certainly one. I used to work in Algebraic Geometry where results for surfaces and 3-folds also suffer from this lack of degrees of freedom. I have a vague memory that there are lots of other problems in topology, knot theory, geometry etc that have the same issues. At the very least the the proofs are substantially more difficult and often of an entirely different nature in lower dimensions. I wish I remembered enough to give even one good example! 1583. Idea for improved strategy - <50 moves?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 14:55:49 -0000

Hi,

I've really started working on learning the L2L4 algorithms now although my
time constraints mean that it will take a while before I get there.

As I have got into them I realised that it wouldnt be too hard to combine
the 2nd and 3rd steps. Even if the average number of moves for the
algorithms for this combined step was as high as 12 this should still
represent a saving of around 5 moves in total. As I currently think L2L4
should give an average of 55 moves or less for the solve then this compacted
form should come out less than 50.

Two downsides at first glance:
1. Instead of 6 + 8 = 14 algorithms for steps 2 and 3 you would need to
learn ~48 for the combination (this brings the total up to 80 something
algorithms).
2. I think the recognition aspect of this new step would be tricky - you
have to position the corners (which are already oriented) and orient the
edges at the same time.

Any views?

Duncan

1587. Online Monthly Cube News Letter
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 21:16:14 -0000


Hi everyone,

For a long time I've been interested in organizing a monthly cube
newsletter. I want to make this a reality, but I just don't have the
time (or the patience for that matter) to do it all myself.

I'm looking for fellow cubers who are interested in helping out with
this. I need people for editing, writing articles, etc.

A lot of fantastic ideas have been tossed around, but I'd like
everyone's feedback on what exactly this newsletter should include.
Post any ideas you have on the group, so that everyone else can build
on it. Anyone who is interested in helping with the paper directly,
please contact me personally: richy_jr_2000@...

I hope to hear from all of you! Happy cubing!

-Richard

1589. About COLL
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 21:39:21 -0000


I read on speedcubing.com under algorithms that with the advantanges
of COLL are

- in 1 out of 12 cases you can solve the LL in one algorithm!
- in 8 out of 12 cases you leave an easy 3-cycle of edges
- in 2 out of 12 cases you leave the edges zigzag permutation
- in 1 out of 12 cases you leave the edges cross permutation

>From my own experience, I'd say that the 8/12 to get a 3 cycle is
right, but the 1/12 you are supposed to solve the LL in 1 alg, i
think it is more like 1/25. I did the cube 50 times with COLL and I
got 35 3-edgecycles, 7 zigzags, 6 cross, and only 2 solves.





1590. Computing the number of configurations - revisited
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 22:24:47 -0000


- You can see any cubie as a 6-color little cube.
- When the whole big 3x3x3 cube is solved, all the cubies have the
same orientation.
- A cubie can have 24 orientations.
- At a corner position, a given corner cubie can have only 3 orientations.
- At an edge position, a given edge cubie can have only 2 orientations.
- At a center position, a given center cubie can have only 4 orientations.
- Have a thought for the 27th cubie inside if you want.
- At any position, two different cubies can't share the same orientation.

With fixed centers, you've got:
(24x21x18x15x12x9x6x3) [corners]
x (24x22x20x18x16x14x12x10x8x6x4x2) [edges]
/ 3 / 2 / 2 [don't forget the well known parity constraints]
= 43,252,003,274,489,856,000

Think of it this way. There are 24 possible orientations for the first
corner position, but only 21 for the second position, because it lacks
the 3 orientations that only the previous cubie could have displayed
here, and so on.
There's nothing new, of course, (24x21x18x15x12x9x6x3) = 8!
[permutations] x 3^8 [orientations].
But it comes from a different point of view. All cubies are born
equal, but in different places.

Gilles.


PS: Don't worry for my mental health, it's because of the new glue I
bought. It makes me want to dream about finding an optimal algorithm :-)





1591. Re: About COLL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 22:50:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I read on speedcubing.com under algorithms that with the advantanges > of COLL are > > - in 1 out of 12 cases you can solve the LL in one algorithm! > - in 8 out of 12 cases you leave an easy 3-cycle of edges > - in 2 out of 12 cases you leave the edges zigzag permutation > - in 1 out of 12 cases you leave the edges cross permutation > > From my own experience, I'd say that the 8/12 to get a 3 cycle is > right, but the 1/12 you are supposed to solve the LL in 1 alg, i > think it is more like 1/25. I did the cube 50 times with COLL and I > got 35 3-edgecycles, 7 zigzags, 6 cross, and only 2 solves. How serious are you? The SCC numbers are easily calculated. Cheers! Stefan
1592. Re: Computing the number of configurations - revisited
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Mar 2005 22:53:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > But it comes from a different point of view. All cubies are born > equal, but in different places. I like it :-) Maybe for other puzzles this kind of view (or even more others) can be helpful to compute the number of positions? I vaguely remember that for example the number of positions for Square-1 for example was harder to determine... Cheers! Stefan
1593. Re: [Speed cubing group] negative time rules
From: David Barr <david20708@...>

when crossing the international date line.


1594. Re: Idea for improved strategy - <50 moves?
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Mar 2005 00:46:05 -0000

Checking the permutation of oriented corners is easy...you just look at which side has 2 on it, and edge orientation is an easy id too....two very easily identifiable items. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Hi, > > I've really started working on learning the L2L4 algorithms now although my > time constraints mean that it will take a while before I get there. > > As I have got into them I realised that it wouldnt be too hard to combine > the 2nd and 3rd steps. Even if the average number of moves for the > algorithms for this combined step was as high as 12 this should still > represent a saving of around 5 moves in total. As I currently think L2L4 > should give an average of 55 moves or less for the solve then this compacted > form should come out less than 50. > > Two downsides at first glance: > 1. Instead of 6 + 8 = 14 algorithms for steps 2 and 3 you would need to > learn ~48 for the combination (this brings the total up to 80 something > algorithms). > 2. I think the recognition aspect of this new step would be tricky - you > have to position the corners (which are already oriented) and orient the > edges at the same time. > > Any views? > > Duncan
1595. Re: [Speed cubing group] Another great method for puzzles...
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Mar 2005 00:49:23 -0000

Another point...anyone who would notice that it's not a real position, would also probably be tipped off by the lack of cube clicking noises, when the magician "solves the puzzle". --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug Reed <dougreed@h...> wrote: > Is it just me, or is that not only just a cheap gag, but isn't that an > IMPOSSIBLE position on the 4x4x4? Take a look at the corner piece > nearest to the camera. It might just be me, but that looks like it has > two red "stickers" on it. > > On the other hand, anyone willing to buy this probably doesn't care > enough about whether it's a possible position or not :-P > > Doug > > richy_jr_2000 wrote: > > >http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll? > >ViewItem&category=14014&item=6519510195&rd=1 > > > >this made me laugh... > > > >-Richard > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo!
