Its structure is exactly like the 3x3. Just more of > everything. > > > > > Any tips on making it faster? > > > > 1. Take it apart. > > 2. Open the centers. > > 3. Replace the springs with softer ones with ends sanded flat > > (preferably with your Dremel-clone). > > 4. Lube it. Including inside the centers. > > > > A fellow puzzler used his Dremel-clone to polish each piece with > the > > soft white disc soaked with silicone spray. His Megaminx was > really > > sweet if I remember correctly. I'll do the same with mine soon. > > > > Oh, and... > > 5. Assemble and play ;-) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan
1689. 4x4x4 centers-last methods (Re: Interesting paradox)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:19:36 -0000

Hmmm .... Centers on 4 faces. I reckon it should take maybe 20 secs or so. Do u cycle blocks of centers also? Or always just 3-cycling center cubies? U can cycle blocks similar to this : <r'(ud')r,U2> - commutator I think i already showed u some algs for opposite faces, like : (r2 u2)*2 (r2 E2)*2 (on 5x5x5 cube) There is more to commutators than meets the eye ... hehe ... <(r'l)d2(rl'),U> (mostly on 4x4x4, 5 cycle) Yes practice practice should help u alot of coz ;-) Have fun!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > Congratulations Per, your times with such a method are impressive! > > My method is different, it looks a bit like my 3x3x3 technique: > - 1x3x4 block on a side > - 1x3x4 block on the opposite side > - U corners > - 12 remaining edges > - last 4 centers > I can't reach good times (about 1:50 on average), perhaps because I > rarely practice. > > I would be interested in looking at a video of you solving the last > centers. 1690. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:35:01 -0000


> any position which
> can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can also > be
> solved using the chain.

Can we extend that to say this as well? --->

1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd number of
quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the keychain
corner.

2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain corner.

3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain corner
can be used to solve it.

If I am understanding this correctly, it should be possible to solve
any position using the keychain corner. If any position with even
parity can be solved, then simply do a quarter turn if you have odd
parity and use your normal strategy for solving even positions.

That works for the permutations of the pieces, but can every position
in the cube orientation group be solved when any corner is the
keychain corner? If that is true than any combination of the cube,
with any corner as the keychain corner is solvable.

Chris





1691. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:34:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > The extra parity restriction is the only one, i.e. any position which > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can also be > solved using the chain. WRONG! Hahaha ;-) You made the same mistake I made first. Consider the scramble (L R) which is a clear counter-example. But Sebastian (and you yourself in the old thread) said it the right way: The restriction is to do an even number of quarter turns not including the keychain corner. At least the old thread didn't show a solution. Now I have one. F2L is indeed not too hard so I'll only show LL. Hold LL as U. Let the keychain be on DFR. This way the algs can be applied at any angle by doing a u-turn setup move. You'll likely have to use them several times and their inverses, too. The parentheses don't group finger tricks but group "steps". I provide 1 algorithm for each phase but for clarity it might be spread over several lines. I'm particularly proud of the corner permutation alg since it nicely uses the "F2L slot change" technique (or however you call it) and gave me some new insights there. ------------------- Orient Corners: (R U2) (B' R B R2) (F' U F) (R U R') ------------------- Orient Edges: (R U2) (B' R B R2) (F' U F) (R U R') D' (L' U L) (F U F') (L2 B L B') (U2 L) D ------------------- Permute Corners: (R U' B L) (U L' B' U R') (U' R B U' B' U R') ------------------- Permute Edges: (R U' B L) (U L' B' U R') (U' R B U' B' U R') (F' U L' B') (U' B L U' F) (U F' L' U L U' F) Cheers! Stefan
1692. Re: 14 second craziness
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:36:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Is it just me or is the world such a crazy place that not one, but > indeed TWO people now average 14 seconds to solve the 3x3x3. My mind > can't comprehend... Well, the world may be larger than the table where you've seen these times, there are many many more potential sub-15 cubers... Take for example Lars V. 16.19 average, 7 months ago, under pressure in a competition. Don't tell me he can't do much better on a good day ;-) > > fasijhroqirhiolkenhfkldmfloj2q09u49pi21ujr.faiwfajswei9ur2 <----- my > mind trying to comprehend, but not succceeding. > > Many congrats to Jean Pons and of course to Macky as well for their > crazy cubing skill. > > Chris When I saw Jean, I noticed his dexterity was remarkable, smooth and natural. Hey Jean, send a video! Gilles.

From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:42:30 -0000

Hahaha, this so funny ;-) Don't believe everything you read, might contain mistakes ;-) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > any position which > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can also > be > > solved using the chain. > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd number of > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the keychain > corner. > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain corner. > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain corner > can be used to solve it. > > If I am understanding this correctly, it should be possible to solve > any position using the keychain corner. If any position with even > parity can be solved, then simply do a quarter turn if you have odd > parity and use your normal strategy for solving even positions. > > That works for the permutations of the pieces, but can every position > in the cube orientation group be solved when any corner is the > keychain corner? If that is true than any combination of the cube, > with any corner as the keychain corner is solvable. > > Chris
1694. 4x4x4 centers-last methods (Re: Interesting paradox)
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 12:56:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hmmm .... > > Centers on 4 faces. I reckon it should take maybe 20 secs or so. Do > u cycle blocks of centers also? Or always just 3-cycling center > cubies? U can cycle blocks similar to this : > > <r'(ud')r,U2> - commutator > > I think i already showed u some algs for opposite faces, like : > > (r2 u2)*2 > > (r2 E2)*2 (on 5x5x5 cube) > > There is more to commutators than meets the eye ... hehe ... > > <(r'l)d2(rl'),U> (mostly on 4x4x4, 5 cycle) > > Yes practice practice should help u alot of coz ;-) > I know all these sequences and commutators. Yes, practice is the key, that's why I was asking for a video of someone who practiced a lot, to see what it looks like ;-) Usually, I separate center pieces and move them to their final side, or to the opposite side. And when it's possible, I try to build 1x1x2 blocks, because finishing with (u2r2)^2 is much faster. But sequences like (ur2u'r2) that can change 4 sides at a time thanks to a *very* simple move look interesting... > Have fun!! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > Congratulations Per, your times with such a method are impressive! > > > > My method is different, it looks a bit like my 3x3x3 technique: > > - 1x3x4 block on a side > > - 1x3x4 block on the opposite side > > - U corners > > - 12 remaining edges > > - last 4 centers > > I can't reach good times (about 1:50 on average), perhaps because I > > rarely practice. > > > > I would be interested in looking at a video of you solving the last > > centers. In my case there are only 4 centers (not 5), but I need > > almost 30 seconds on average. How long do you think it should take? > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey! > > > > > > Well then im one of those weird cubers :D I do centers last on > the > > > 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. And as u can see from the unofficial world > records > > > im quite fast with it too ;-) The benefit of doing centers last > (for > > > me anyway) is that the rest of the solve speeds up. Doing the > > > centers on the last 5 faces last is a bit slower than doing > centers > > > first. But at least by now the rest of the cube is solves and u > have > > > easier recognition. Easy recognition is the way to success on > the > > > larger cubes. many (including me) find that pairing up is too > > > awkward since ur only ppoint of reference is one (or two) other > edge > > > (s) only. The pairing up stage is what most ppl struggle to > speed > > > up. I know of good cubers who spend more time on the pairing-up > > > stage than on one of my complete solves. So the normal 3x3x3 > > > reduction "regime" is not the salvation for everyone :-) > > > > > > I would call my method the cage method. It's somewhat similar to > > > columns first method. > > > > > > First layer (top) > > > Middle layers edges (hold solved layer to the left) > > > Last layer corners then edges (and parity) > > > Final centers > > > > > > Happy cubing !! > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Centres last? What kind of weird cubers try that? > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > > > <no_reply@y...> > > > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > I just realized something I had never thought of. Winning > > > moves > > > > > > doesn't produce true general cubes where the orientations > of > > > the > > > > > > centers doesn't matter. The white sticker always has a > design > > > > on it, > > > > > > so in competitions your cube is only solved 1/4 the time, > yet > > > we > > > > still > > > > > > consider it solved. > > > > > > > > > > > > So we've all been frequently (75% of the time actually) > > > counting > > > > cubes > > > > > > as solved that never were in fact solved. There has been > > > rampant > > > > > > cheating in the cubing community for almost 2 years :) > > > > > > > > > > > > Perhaps we should memorize which way the design of the > white > > > > sticker > > > > > > is oriented when we buy our cubes to make sure we don't > cheat > > > > and just > > > > > > half solve it :) > > > > > > > > > > > > And no I'm not serious at all in my claims of cheating. I > just > > > > > > thought it was a funny way to look at things ;-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > Logos on stickers should be forbidden in competitions. At > least, > > > it > > > > > can help "centers-last" cubers locate pieces faster. > > > > > And yes, I'm serious. ;-) > > > > > > > > > > Gilles.
1695. Re: keychain cube problem
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:05:04 -0000

Oops! I should of course have said something like this: Any even permutation with the keychain corner in its correct location can be solved. If the keychain corner is not at its home location, you have to add the number of quarter turns it takes to get it to its home to the number of quarter turns it took to mix. It's just like the old 15 sliding tile puzzle. Any even permutation is possible amongst the tiles, even though you can swap the space with any adjacent tile (which seems to be an odd permutation). Allowing a choice of corner to which you attach the chain after you have seen the scramble, will no necessarily make it solvable. If all corners are correct apart form two diagonally swap ones, then it will not be solvable whatever corner you chain up. Jaap --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Hahaha, this so funny ;-) > Don't believe everything you read, might contain mistakes ;-) > > --- cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > any position which > > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can > > > also be solved using the chain. > > > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd number > > of > > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the > > keychain corner. > > > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain > > corner. > > > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain > > corner can be used to solve it.
1696. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:32:49 -0000

Here's a keychain alg that flips three corners. If we can prove that you can make any setup moves necessary, this should be sufficient to prove that any position for the corner orientation group can be solved. (R U' R' F' U' F)x15 key chain corner: DFR It's 90 moves long, but it flips FUL, BUL, BUR all clockwise leaving everything else untouched. Also, here is an algorithm that flips two edges and leaves everything else untouched. (R U' B U')x70 key chain corner: DFR It is 280 moves but it does what we need it to do. Again if we can prove that any setup move is possible for getting the two necessary edges to flip then we can show that any position in the edge orientation group can be solved. Now that we know of useful flip algs, maybe the setup moves part won't be so hard (I hope). Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > any position which > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can also > be > > solved using the chain. > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd number of > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the keychain > corner. > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain corner. > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain corner > can be used to solve it. > > If I am understanding this correctly, it should be possible to solve > any position using the keychain corner. If any position with even > parity can be solved, then simply do a quarter turn if you have odd > parity and use your normal strategy for solving even positions. > > That works for the permutations of the pieces, but can every position > in the cube orientation group be solved when any corner is the > keychain corner? If that is true than any combination of the cube, > with any corner as the keychain corner is solvable. > > Chris
1697. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:29:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Allowing a choice of corner to which you attach the chain after you > have seen the scramble, will no necessarily make it solvable. If all > corners are correct apart form two diagonally swap ones, then it will > not be solvable whatever corner you chain up. Mmh... what do you mean with "diagonally"? I first thought you meant diagonally across the cube, in which case I simply chain up one of the two swapped corners and then I *can* solve it. It does work though if you mean diagonally across one face. Proof of both claims is left as exercise to Chris ;-) I'd suggest the (L R) scramble, I think it's even easier to prove being impossible to solve: As soon as you place your chain, you can undo one of L or R but the other screws you. Cheers! Stefan
1698. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:38:49 -0000

Ignore my edge flip alg, it doesn't return the keychain corner to the home location, and it isn't even a legal move. The corner flip alg is fine though. 1701. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:48:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Here's an alg that flips two edges and leaves the rest of the cube solved. > > (R U' B U' F2)x42 Just two edges? Are you sure? I haven't tried it physically but here: http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp (enter "(R U' B U' F2)*42", i.e. with '*') Btw, how do you come up with these algs? I guess you don't make up a short sequence that returns the keychain corner and repeat and repeat until it looks nice again? Cheers! Stefan
1702. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:43:44 -0000

Hey! I been reading all this keychain cube solving with some interest. What i understand is that one always has to move the layer that contains the corner with the chain attached. That's the only constraint, right ? While i was on easter holiday i thought of a similar problem. Im not sure whether it's much tougher or not. Let's imagine that only clockwise turns of faces are allowed. Ie we disallow any double turn or counterclockwise turn. When we have moved one face 1 step clockwise we have to move another face clockwise. And so on ... How hard is it to solve like this? Is every state of the cube still possible? Jaap, u have any idea about this? Anyone who can come up with some nice flipping and/or twisting algorithms? What is devillish is of course that even if we come up with this. Setup moves won't work. Cause the "un-setup" moves will not be possible (would necessarily have had to be counterclockwise turns). Hmmm ... Have fun figure this one out :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Oops! > > I should of course have said something like this: > Any even permutation with the keychain corner in its correct location > can be solved. > If the keychain corner is not at its home location, you have to add > the number of quarter turns it takes to get it to its home to the > number of quarter turns it took to mix. > > It's just like the old 15 sliding tile puzzle. Any even permutation > is possible amongst the tiles, even though you can swap the space > with any adjacent tile (which seems to be an odd permutation). > > Allowing a choice of corner to which you attach the chain after you > have seen the scramble, will no necessarily make it solvable. If all > corners are correct apart form two diagonally swap ones, then it will > not be solvable whatever corner you chain up. > > Jaap > > --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hahaha, this so funny ;-) > > Don't believe everything you read, might contain mistakes ;-) > > > > --- cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > any position which > > > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can > > > > also be solved using the chain. > > > > > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > > > > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd number > > > of > > > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the > > > keychain corner. > > > > > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain > > > corner. > > > > > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain > > > corner can be used to solve it.
1703. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 13:55:51 -0000

Yeah my second alg doesn't work either, I just double checked it an I messed it up. My idea for the edges is to form an edge cycle such that two pieces swap and one gets flipped. Then I check to make sure I can solve everything else in a number that is congruent to 2 (mod 4). Thus flipping the edges. The move R U' B U' swaps UL and UR and flips one of the edges. THe last move F2 returns the keychain corner, the largest edge cycle then solves in 12, thus always congruent to 0 (mod 4). I'm still working on finding one that works, but that is my strategy. lol no I didn't just apply useful moves over an over, I have somewhat of a system to the madness :) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > Here's an alg that flips two edges and leaves the rest of the cube > solved. > > > > (R U' B U' F2)x42 > > Just two edges? Are you sure? I haven't tried it physically but here: > http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp > (enter "(R U' B U' F2)*42", i.e. with '*') > > Btw, how do you come up with these algs? I guess you don't make up a > short sequence that returns the keychain corner and repeat and repeat > until it looks nice again? > > Cheers! > Stefan

It only orients three non-keychain corners, though. How do you prove you can orient the keychain corner, too? Btw, my (R' F R F' U2)x15 works, too ;-) Cheers! Stefan
1705. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:01:27 -0000

Proof that we can still get everything: U (FB)*4 U How to undo setup moves: Apply them order-1 times. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > I been reading all this keychain cube solving with some interest. > What i understand is that one always has to move the layer that > contains the corner with the chain attached. Let's imagine that only > clockwise turns of faces are allowed. Ie we disallow any double turn > or counterclockwise turn. When we have moved one face 1 step > clockwise we have to move another face clockwise. And so on ... How > hard is it to solve like this? Is every state of the cube still > possible? > > Jaap, u have any idea about this? > > Anyone who can come up with some nice flipping and/or twisting > algorithms? What is devillish is of course that even if we come up > with this. Setup moves won't work. Cause the "un-setup" moves will > not be possible (would necessarily have had to be counterclockwise > turns). > > Hmmm ... > > Have fun figure this one out :-) > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Oops! > > > > I should of course have said something like this: > > Any even permutation with the keychain corner in its correct > location > > can be solved. > > If the keychain corner is not at its home location, you have to > add > > the number of quarter turns it takes to get it to its home to the > > number of quarter turns it took to mix. > > > > It's just like the old 15 sliding tile puzzle. Any even > permutation > > is possible amongst the tiles, even though you can swap the space > > with any adjacent tile (which seems to be an odd permutation). > > > > Allowing a choice of corner to which you attach the chain after > you > > have seen the scramble, will no necessarily make it solvable. If > all > > corners are correct apart form two diagonally swap ones, then it > will > > not be solvable whatever corner you chain up. > > > > Jaap > > > > --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > Hahaha, this so funny ;-) > > > Don't believe everything you read, might contain mistakes ;-) > > > > > > --- cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > any position which > > > > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns can > > > > > also be solved using the chain. > > > > > > > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > > > > > > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd > number > > > > of > > > > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the > > > > keychain corner. > > > > > > > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain > > > > corner. > > > > > > > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain > > > > corner can be used to solve it.
1706. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:11:05 -0000


> It only orients three non-keychain corners, though. How do you prove
> you can orient the keychain corner, too?

One step ahead of you :)

(DR)*35 RU'R' (F D' F' R' D' R)*15 RUR'
key-chain corner: DFR

I found (DR)x35 which flips 6 corners in the 2-generator case earlier
when working on a 3 corner flipper, and I just used my non-keychain
corner flipper to flix 3 of them.

166 moves, but it proves it is possible.

Chris





1707. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:19:50 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > What is devillish is of course that even if we come up > with this. Setup moves won't work. Cause the "un-setup" moves will > not be possible (would necessarily have had to be counterclockwise > turns). What's even more devilish is that I can't just apply one algorithm after the other (if the first ends with the same move that the second begins with). Of course I can separate with like (LR)*4 but it's still annoying. Cheers! Stefan
1708. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:22:59 -0000

Even if the rules are, 1) You may only do a single clockwise quarter turn when turing a face 2) After turning a face you may only turn one of its 4 adjacent faces. You could do U (RBLF)*315 U to still get everything. Cheers!!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Even if the rules are, > > 1) You may only do a single clockwise quarter turn when turing a face > 2) After turning a face you may only turn one of its 4 adjacent faces. > > You could do U (RBLF)*315 U to still get everything. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Proof that we can still get everything: > > U (FB)*4 U > > > > How to undo setup moves: > > Apply them order-1 times. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey! > > > > > > I been reading all this keychain cube solving with some interest. > > > What i understand is that one always has to move the layer that > > > contains the corner with the chain attached. That's the only > > > constraint, right ? > > > > > > While i was on easter holiday i thought of a similar problem. Im not > > > sure whether it's much tougher or not. Let's imagine that only > > > clockwise turns of faces are allowed. Ie we disallow any double turn > > > or counterclockwise turn. When we have moved one face 1 step > > > clockwise we have to move another face clockwise. And so on ... How > > > hard is it to solve like this? Is every state of the cube still > > > possible? > > > > > > Jaap, u have any idea about this? > > > > > > Anyone who can come up with some nice flipping and/or twisting > > > algorithms? What is devillish is of course that even if we come up > > > with this. Setup moves won't work. Cause the "un-setup" moves will > > > not be possible (would necessarily have had to be counterclockwise > > > turns). > > > > > > Hmmm ... > > > > > > Have fun figure this one out :-) > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Oops! > > > > > > > > I should of course have said something like this: > > > > Any even permutation with the keychain corner in its correct > > > location > > > > can be solved. > > > > If the keychain corner is not at its home location, you have to > > > add > > > > the number of quarter turns it takes to get it to its home to the > > > > number of quarter turns it took to mix. > > > > > > > > It's just like the old 15 sliding tile puzzle. Any even > > > permutation > > > > is possible amongst the tiles, even though you can swap the space > > > > with any adjacent tile (which seems to be an odd permutation). > > > > > > > > Allowing a choice of corner to which you attach the chain after > > > you > > > > have seen the scramble, will no necessarily make it solvable. If > > > all > > > > corners are correct apart form two diagonally swap ones, then it > > > will > > > > not be solvable whatever corner you chain up. > > > > > > > > Jaap > > > > > > > > --- "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > Hahaha, this so funny ;-) > > > > > Don't believe everything you read, might contain mistakes ;-) > > > > > > > > > > --- cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > > any position which > > > > > > > can be solved normally by an even number of quarter turns > > can > > > > > > > also be solved using the chain. > > > > > > > > > > > > Can we extend that to say this as well? ---> > > > > > > > > > > > > 1) Pick any combination for the cube that requires an odd > > > number > > > > > > of > > > > > > quarter turns to solve. Pick any of the 8 corners to be the > > > > > > keychain corner. > > > > > > > > > > > > 2) Do one of the 6 allowable quarter turns using the keychain > > > > > > corner. > > > > > > > > > > > > 3) Now we have a position of even parity and thus the keychain > > > > > > corner can be used to solve it.
1711. Re: keychain cube problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:36:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > You could do U (RBLF)*315 U to still get everything. Why so complicated and long? ;-) U (RF)*105 U Sorry Per, no "nice" short algs yet... Cheers! Stefan
1712. Re: clockwise turns only
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:42:11 -0000

Wow, this is harder. We've already proven that solving is possible so the strategy is a bit different. I found (RBLF)x105 to flip three corners, DLF, DBL, DBR all counter-clockwise. I had already studied the cycles for RBLF for the keychain problem so that one was easy. That's probably a terrible strategy, I think a fewest moves strategy would work better. I think 3 cycles of pieces would be more useful for this type of solving. I don't have any right now, but I want to think about that. I wonder what the upper limit of moves is for an efficient method of this type. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hmm .... > > Alright Stefan and Chris. This proves that we can solve like i said > (even w Chris' restriction) in one billion moves or thereabout. Any > useful algs for solving efficiently ?? > > Cheers!!! > > -Per
1713. Re: keychain cube problem
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:44:19 -0000

True, and since we both had the goal of proving that it was solvable I think you beat me pretty soundly :-P Chris P.S. For the method for the edge flippers the "getting the other stuff to solve in some number congruent to 2 mod 4 is the trial and error part, so it isn't even that efficient. I suppose with more thought you could find a setup move that does this, but then again maybe following the corner cycles (with orientations) would be hard to do intuitively. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > One step ahead of you :) > > Yeah ok but only because I don't try hard because I consider my > solving method to be proof enough ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > P.S. I like the way you came up with your edge flippers...
1714. Re: clockwise turns only
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 14:54:16 -0000

I suggest going with my addition to the rules of, 2) after turning any face you may only turn one of its four adjacent faces. To do U2 when trying to solve with a shorter efficient approach it doesn't take much time to do U (FB)x4 U, and in fact that is probably how I would do it and use my usual speed solve approach. As long as you use other shortcuts to avoid doing counter-clockwise turns when possible during the F2L it isn't that inefficient. The LL would be a different story. Perhaps we should just analyze the LL if we allow turning of opposite faces. It's a lot harder though in general if you can only do adjacent face turns, since your shortest option is the (RU)x105 for the same trick as Stefan said. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Wow, this is harder. We've already proven that solving is possible so > the strategy is a bit different. > > I found > (RBLF)x105 to flip three corners, DLF, DBL, DBR all counter-clockwise. > > I had already studied the cycles for RBLF for the keychain problem so > that one was easy. > > That's probably a terrible strategy, I think a fewest moves strategy > would work better. I think 3 cycles of pieces would be more useful > for this type of solving. I don't have any right now, but I want to > think about that. > > I wonder what the upper limit of moves is for an efficient method of > this type. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hmm .... > > > > Alright Stefan and Chris. This proves that we can solve like i said > > (even w Chris' restriction) in one billion moves or thereabout. Any > > useful algs for solving efficiently ?? > > > > Cheers!!! > > > > -Per
1715. Re: clockwise turns only
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 15:11:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It's a lot harder though in general if you can only do adjacent face > turns, since your shortest option is the (RU)x105 for the same trick > as Stefan said. Well, the shortest we know until now ;-) I'm sure there must be a much shorter one. And here's my first alg for this version that I'm a little proud of: (RFU LBU)*15 It flips two edges in 90 moves. Per, maybe you'll not only like it because it's much shorter than what we've had before, but also because I constructed it thinking about commutators :-) The idea was to combine two relatively independent sequences (RF and LB). Of course I had to insert something in between to connect them, so I chose U. Hmm, wait a moment. What if I simply combine R and L that way? Yes, (RULU)*45 is identity! The record is thus 180 moves now ;-) And if I try to combine L and R not always with U but instead with the same face relative to the R center? Results in a 4-edge flipper in just 36 moves: (RL U RL B RL D RL F)*3 Cheers! Stefan
1716. Re: Megaminx
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 16:21:50 -0000

Ah, yes. The puzzle is from mefferts and the springs are very strong. There are plastic washers in each center (one on each side of the spring). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Go to a dollar store, get two clones like > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=706 > and rip out their springs. That's what I did with my current main > Megaminx. If you don't have $2, look in a certain somebody's garbage > can ;-) > > Is it a new Megaminx from Meffert? With very strong springs? Does it > have plastic washers and how many? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > Eh, well that only took about 3 hours. I don't have other springs > > here so I had to just sand the ones given. That last piece was not > > overly fun to put back in :\ End result: better than before. > > Thanks. :) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > I bought a megaminx and it is really hard to turn... > > > > > > Sounds familiar. > > > > > > > do they come apart and go back together? > > > > > > Yes. Its structure is exactly like the 3x3. Just more of > > everything. > > > > > > > Any tips on making it faster? > > > > > > 1. Take it apart. > > > 2. Open the centers. > > > 3. Replace the springs with softer ones with ends sanded flat > > > (preferably with your Dremel-clone). > > > 4. Lube it. Including inside the centers. > > > > > > A fellow puzzler used his Dremel-clone to polish each piece with > > the > > > soft white disc soaked with silicone spray. His Megaminx was > > really > > > sweet if I remember correctly. I'll do the same with mine soon. > > > > > > Oh, and... > > > 5. Assemble and play ;-) > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan
1717. Re: keychain cube problem
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 17:01:16 -0000


> At least the old thread didn't show a solution. Now I have one.
>F2L is
> indeed not too hard so I'll only show LL.
>
> Hold LL as U. Let the keychain be on DFR. This way the algs can be
> applied at any angle by doing a u-turn setup move. You'll likely
>have
> to use them several times and their inverses, too. The parentheses
> don't group finger tricks but group "steps". I provide 1 algorithm
>for
> each phase but for clarity it might be spread over several lines.
>
> I'm particularly proud of the corner permutation alg since it
nicely
> uses the "F2L slot change" technique (or however you call it) and
gave
> me some new insights there.
>
> -------------------
> Orient Corners:
>
> (R U2) (B' R B R2) (F' U F) (R U R')
>
> -------------------
> Orient Edges:
>
> (R U2) (B' R B R2) (F' U F) (R U R')
> D'
> (L' U L) (F U F') (L2 B L B') (U2 L)
> D
>
> -------------------
> Permute Corners:
>
> (R U' B L) (U L' B' U R') (U' R B U' B' U R')
>
> -------------------
> Permute Edges:
>
> (R U' B L) (U L' B' U R') (U' R B U' B' U R')
> (F' U L' B') (U' B L U' F) (U F' L' U L U' F)
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

Nice... You indeed solved the problem. Now to find all the 1211
optimal LL algorithms :)

The keychain-corner-in-F2L idea is very good, and I think that the
best place for the keychain corner is in the last F2L slot, that is,
last solved piece before LL. I have only solved with the keychain
corner in LL because I use fixed colours and it happenned that it
was in LL.

Hey, but that means that the same position will need more than one
alg, because the position of the keychain corner matters. Anyway,
let me show what I got by myself. Here's my first PLL (keychain
corner UFR i.e. in the last layer):

(F' U' F R) (F' U' F R) U' (B U B' R') U (R' F' U F)

18 moves: it's longer than Stefan's. The edge 3-cycle was this alg
applied twice. Exactly like Stefan has it. The 9-move alg

(F' U' F R) U' (B U B' R')

could be used for the orient corners part, since edges are solved
afterwards. Nothing else for now.

Sebastian





1718. Re: Corner or cross?
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 17:17:07 -0000

A few months ago, I was about where you are. I opted to try to learn the Fridrich method first since it's so widely used, but I plan on learning Petrus and a corners first method eventually [and now maybe the Gilles method, though not sure I even know what that is]. And I still use some moves from my old method. With my old method, my times were about 1.5 - 2.5 minutes. When I started to learn Fridrich on my own, I was able to drop to about a minute rather quickly [couple of weeks practice]. Switching to cross first and doing it on the bottom was the first major adjustment [my old method did the top corners first, then the top edges]. then learing how to insert the corner/edge pairs was the second big adjustment for me, and I still don't know all of those [old method was get top layer all done, then insert each middle layer edge]. last big adjustmetn I made was to learn some of the PLL algs. With that, I was at a minute to 1:15 within a couple of weeks. I've only this week learned the final 4 of the PLL algs, and I still know only 3 OLL algs [the ones from my old method], and my times have steadily dropped. My best is now 38.9, and I consistently get in the 40s and 50s. I got to the minute mark mostly by studying/practicing the sequences I printed off various sites. I didn't look at too many videos at first because I wanted to try the moves on my own. Later, I studied lots of videos to watch hand technique, and that really helped. There are lots of good sites out there [Dan plugged his, and frankly, it was indeed extremely helpful]. Finally, getting together with a couple of cubers who are much faster than me helped with the last 15-20 seconds of progress. anyway, that's my story. hope it's helpful. best regards, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > Ok guys, I am an better-than-newbie at cubing right > now. I can solve the cube in about 2 mins but my > method is really very sloggy and it consumes a lot of > steps. So I was thinking of shifting to some another > method. I found that there are mainly two widespread > methods - the Lars Petrus's Corner method and the > cross method(I am not thinking about the Fridrich > method right now). So can you guys suggest which > method to use considering the documentation available > of the method and the number of steps achieved by each > method. > Currently the Lars Petrus's method is on top of my > list since it has some nice Java cubes alongwith the > explanation. I havent found such a site for the cross > method. > Please reply! > > _____________________________________________________________________ ___ > Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partner online > Go to: http://yahoo.shaadi.com/india-matrimony
1719. Re: clockwise turns only
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 17:18:47 -0000



Obviously I needed a little break.

> Hmm, wait a moment. What if I simply combine R and L that way? Yes,
> (RULU)*45 is identity! The record is thus 180 moves now ;-)

Not at all better than 2*90 (twice my 2-edge-flip).

> Results in a 4-edge flipper in
> just 36 moves: (RL U RL B RL D RL F)*3

Not even allowed.

But here's a nice one orienting 3 corners in 60 moves:
(RULU)*15

To find my above identity (*45) I had started with *1 and looked at
the cycle of the UFR corner. It had length 3, so I tried *3 next. Of
course UFR was now at the correct place but it was oriented wrong. So
I added another factor 3 and tried *9. Then I saw there was a 5-corner
cycle left so I added factor 5 and tried *45 which resulted in
identity. So I tried only *1, *3, *9 and *45 and missed *15 which is
very nice...

What can I learn from this? Find the order (*45) and then try to take
out any one prime factor. If it still looks interesting, continue. If
I take 5 out of 45 and try *9 then both edges and corners look ugly.
So that's bad and I stop. If instead I take 3 out of 45 and try *15
then that looks nice. I continue by taking out another 3 and try 5:
(RULU)*5
Bingo, another nice one! It leaves all edges intact.

Sadly it permutes/orients all 8 corners, though. But wait! Actually
only 3 corners are permuted, the other 5 are just oriented. And all in
the same direction! Which means I should try a rotation and do it
twice. There are four possibilities:
(RULU)*5 (RULU)*10 - orients 3, permutes 0
(RULU)*5 (FUBU)*10 - orients 4, permutes 3
(RULU)*5 (LURU)*10 - orients 3, permutes 4
(RULU)*5 (BUFU)*10 - orients 2, permutes 3

This is fun now :-)

I also tried rotating the alg around x (i.e. with RULU, RBLB, RDLD and
RFRF as second part) but that leads to larger effects.

Cheers!
Stefan






1720. Re: clockwise turns only
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 17:47:25 -0000


> Which means I should try a rotation and do it
> twice. There are four possibilities:
> (RULU)*5 (RULU)*10 - orients 3, permutes 0
> (RULU)*5 (FUBU)*10 - orients 4, permutes 3
> (RULU)*5 (LURU)*10 - orients 3, permutes 4
> (RULU)*5 (BUFU)*10 - orients 2, permutes 3

Actually why should I not split it into 3 steps? Try these:

(RULU)*5 y (RULU)*5 y (RULU)*5
(RULU)*5 y (RULU)*5 y2 (RULU)*5

Baboom! Sweet little 3-corner permutations (first one even without
orientation).

Cheers!
Stefan






1721. Re: [Speed cubing group] article
From: djmarmalade <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 00:54:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > *Dodges Tyson's handbag* > > > > A very funny article, completely rubbish of course, who is this woman > anyway. I think she might be tracked down and taught a lesson or two. Hello all, This will probably be my only post ever on your board. I know Sandy Becker personally and we were having a conversation about subcultures when this message board came up. Sandy is one of the nicest, most considerate, honest, and genuine people that I've ever had the pleasure of knowing. Thus, I was a bit surprised to hear that people on here were being so critical. The response to her article is, in my opinion, unwarranted and a bit narrow. The article appeard in a publication that highlights activity and people at the University of Michigan. It was not intended to be of interest to the "hardcore speedcubing" community. The facts that are important in this article are those facts that relate to Sandy Becker, her employment at U of M, her academic background, and her interests, not, as some people seem to think, "speedcubing". Further, the article was not written because Sandy solves the cube in two minutes, frankly, she even points out in the article that her speed is quite slow relative to others. Rather, the article was written because Sandy is an employee of the University of Michigan who wrote her Master's Thesis on Group Theory of the Rubix Cube. Perhaps the number of people who can solve the cube in a few minutes is quite large. Certainly at the time I write this it is at least 750 people based on the unnoficial lists. However, the number of people who can solve it in a few minutes, who have written a graduate thesis on the mathematics of the cube, who also work at the University of Michigan, and who haven't already been spotlighted in the university's magazine is substantially smaller. I might be wrong, but I suspect that number was one, and is now zero. Sandy's reported time came from her one officially timed event. The video was part of the annual pi day celebration, so, in a sense, it was just for fun. Sandy's interest lies in mathematics and group theory, and in particular, symmetries and permutation groups. I'm quite sure she'd be interested in discussing such topics whith those of you who have a similar background. Her contact information is readily available from the University's web site. So "tracking her down", is quite unnecesary. daryl
1722. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Corner or cross?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 29 Mar 2005 19:17:59 -0600

I picked up a cube for the first serious time last May and have been thoroughly hooked since. My initial method was similar to Kirk's in that it involved the first layer on top, corners before edges, then inserted each middle layer edge afterward. I've since upgraded to cross on bottom, followed by the corner/edge pairs (which I've learned how to do on my own). I use a 4 look last layer with a little bit of partial edge control, several special cases, and a few extra tricks. With this method I am able to average around 35 seconds with my best times hovering a tad under 24 seconds. A few weeks ago, I decided to try my hand at the Roux method. It requires fewer moves, on average, so, theoretically, I have the potential to be faster with it. Using his system with two 1x2x3 blocks and minimal step 3 and 4 algorithms, I am able to average consistently under 39 seconds, with a pair of best times fractions of a second slower than my best fridrich times. I'm incredibly pleased with my progress, despite minimal learning. I use this new method exclusively in practice now, and hope to have my times greatly improved by the summer when I'm able to attend another competition. I've decided to commit to learning more algorithms for the last layer corners and some of the 26 special cases for the last layer over the next few weeks. Basically, toying around with other methods is a fantastic way to improve your times, even if you stick with your old method. They can be invaluable for providing you with easy to recognize special cases you would otherwise never have learned. Also, meeting with other cubers is immensely helpful. They can teach you things you thought previously impossible to understand. I hope I've helped. Happy cubing, -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: kirk83616<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, March 29, 2005 11:17 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Corner or cross? And I still use some moves from my old method. With my old method, my times were about 1.5 - 2.5 minutes. When I started to learn Fridrich on my own, I was able to drop to about a minute rather quickly [couple of weeks practice]. Switching to cross first and doing it on the bottom was the first major adjustment [my old method did the top corners first, then the top edges]. then learing how to insert the corner/edge pairs was the second big adjustment for me, and I still don't know all of those [old method was get top layer all done, then insert each middle layer edge]. last big adjustmetn I made was to learn some of the PLL algs. With that, I was at a minute to 1:15 within a couple of weeks. I've only this week learned the final 4 of the PLL algs, and I still know only 3 OLL algs [the ones from my old method], and my times have steadily dropped. There are lots of good sites out there [Dan plugged his, and frankly, it was indeed extremely helpful]. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service<http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1723. Re: [Speed cubing group] article
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 02:07:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, djmarmalade <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > *Dodges Tyson's handbag* > > > > > > > > A very funny article, completely rubbish of course, who is this woman > > anyway. I think she might be tracked down and taught a lesson or two. > I had to go back nearly three months to January 1st to find the original post referred to in this one! > Hello all, > > This will probably be my only post ever on your board. > > I know Sandy Becker personally and we were having a conversation about > subcultures when this message board came up. Sandy is one of the > nicest, most considerate, honest, and genuine people that I've ever > had the pleasure of knowing. Thus, I was a bit surprised to hear that > people on here were being so critical. > > The response to her article is, in my opinion, unwarranted and a bit > narrow. The article appeard in a publication that highlights activity > and people at the University of Michigan. It was not intended to be of > interest to the "hardcore speedcubing" community. The facts that are > important in this article are those facts that relate to Sandy Becker, > her employment at U of M, her academic background, and her interests, > not, as some people seem to think, "speedcubing". I don't recall anything negative directed specifically at her. From what I can see, there were three responses to the article. The first was about the title of the article, and the other two were criticizing the accuracy of the article with reference to the official record and winner of the WC2003. > > Further, the article was not written because Sandy solves the cube in > two minutes, frankly, she even points out in the article that her > speed is quite slow relative to others. I will quote the article: "Becker is no ordinary player. She was pretty quick two decades ago, but now she's lightning fast. Her personal best time for solving the cube is 2 minutes and 46 seconds, no easy feat when you consider that the cube has 43 quintillion permutations." I don't even consider myself to be "lightning fast" with a personal best of 20.12... > Rather, the article was > written because Sandy is an employee of the University of Michigan who > wrote her Master's Thesis on Group Theory of the Rubix Cube. > I don't think there is such thing as a "Rubix Cube." In fact, I think that Mr. Rubik would find this remark more offensive than any of the responses to the article were. :P > Perhaps the number of people who can solve the cube in a few minutes > is quite large. Certainly at the time I write this it is at least 750 > people based on the unnoficial lists. Plus the countless more that aren't even on the lists! :) > However, the number of people > who can solve it in a few minutes, who have written a graduate thesis > on the mathematics of the cube, who also work at the University of > Michigan, and who haven't already been spotlighted in the university's > magazine is substantially smaller. I might be wrong, but I suspect > that number was one, and is now zero. > I would agree that this is probably correct. > Sandy's reported time came from her one officially timed event. The > video was part of the annual pi day celebration, so, in a sense, it > was just for fun. Sandy's interest lies in mathematics and group > theory, and in particular, symmetries and permutation groups. I'm > quite sure she'd be interested in discussing such topics whith those > of you who have a similar background. Her contact information is > readily available from the University's web site. So "tracking her > down", is quite unnecesary. > I feel that you may have looked into the responses waaay too much. I don't think that anybody meant anything offensive toward Sandy and I'm sure she's a very nice person. I doubt anybody in the cubing community has anything personally against her. I don't think anybody actually intended on "tracking her down." > daryl ~ Bob
1724. Re: [Speed cubing group] article
From: djmarmalade <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 03:30:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > A very funny article, completely rubbish of course, who is this > woman > > > anyway. I think she might be tracked down and taught a lesson or > two. > I don't recall anything negative directed specifically at her. The article is about her, not speedcubing, and as quoted above is called "complete rubbish", and suggests that she needs "lessons". > I don't even consider myself to be "lightning fast" with a personal > best of 20.12... You aren't the intended reader, Sandy did not write the article. Thus, your criticism is unfounded. Who really cares how fast you are, or what your definition of "lightning fast" is. It is an non-specific relative measure of time in this context. To interpret it literally is nonsense. Anything less than five minutes in comparison to people who aren't "cubers", would most likely be considered lightning fast. > I don't think anybody actually intended on "tracking her down." Well, then if something isn't intended, don't say it. However, my point was that it's not like this is some big mystery. She's easy to contact if you have questions or comments. daryl

1730. A nice forum...
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 15:59:03 -0000


Hello speedcubing friends,

This is just a proposal, to see if anyone agrees with me. Most
conversations between speedcubers are probably done online. That's
why a discussion group or forum is very valueable for the
speedcubing community. However, I must say, I don't really enjoy
posting on this yahoo group. It's not very organized, the replies on
one specific topic are hard to find, there are too many ads etc. I
also heard another cuber say he would post more if there was a
better forum. I think I would also have a lot more fun posting on a
speedcubing forum if we just had a good looking, organized forum.
For an example, take a look at this forum:
http://www.phpbb.com/styles/demo.php.

As an example of what I have in mind, I have been fooling around
with this free forum today: http://speedcubing.proboards20.com/.

DON'T get me wrong! I don't want everybody to agree with me, of
course. If you really like this yahoo group, that's fine with me...
I am just interested in your opinion! Am I the only one used to nice
forums? :)

I am also not saying that the example I made is perfect, but it's
just an example.

Happy cubing,

Joël.





1731. Re: A nice forum...
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

1732. Re: A nice forum...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 16:44:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hello speedcubing friends, > > This is just a proposal, to see if anyone agrees with me. Most > conversations between speedcubers are probably done online. That's > why a discussion group or forum is very valueable for the > speedcubing community. However, I must say, I don't really enjoy > posting on this yahoo group. It's not very organized, the replies on > one specific topic are hard to find, there are too many ads etc. I > also heard another cuber say he would post more if there was a > better forum. I think I would also have a lot more fun posting on a > speedcubing forum if we just had a good looking, organized forum. > For an example, take a look at this forum: > http://www.phpbb.com/styles/demo.php. > > As an example of what I have in mind, I have been fooling around > with this free forum today: http://speedcubing.proboards20.com/. > > DON'T get me wrong! I don't want everybody to agree with me, of > course. If you really like this yahoo group, that's fine with me... > I am just interested in your opinion! Am I the only one used to nice > forums? :) > > I am also not saying that the example I made is perfect, but it's > just an example. > > Happy cubing, > > Joël. I totally agree with you, a forum based on PHPBB (for example) is 3x3x3 times better than these Yahoo groups (even worse to read since they changed the layout). Categories are more than useful. Fingertricks, blindfold techniques, F2L, corners-first, ..., and "general chat" for messages with a short lifespan. Three things are needed. A stable webserver, moderators mature enough and a willing community. Hey! Just add a "Forum" area to speedcubing.com's menus! ;-) Gilles.

I agree with you too. Previously, this was the only forum I followed, so I didn't know what the other options were. Then I became interested in iPAQs and so started occasionally reading the Pocket PC Thoughts forum (http://www.pocketpcthoughts.com/forums/index.php) and saw how .php discussion forums were organised. I am very happy to go with the majority view on this issue, however, since we are expressing preferences here... I do prefer the .php style discussion forums and would be happy to move to one. :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com/ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Boy.. 1736. Re: A nice forum...
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 18:56:44 -0000

I think that a forum is a great idea. The Swedish cubers have a quite active forum at the site of SweCube (the Swedish Cube Association) <www.svekub.se>. Earlier we had a yahoo group (rubikskub) but since we started the forum, the yahoo group has been deserted. One good thing with our forum is that it is connected to our website, and thereby a bit easier for a newcomber to find compared to an yahoo e-mail list. I'm mainly lurking here. Personally, I would probably be more active on a forum. Enjoy, Anders --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hello speedcubing friends, > > This is just a proposal, to see if anyone agrees with me. 1737. Re: Edge permutations during PLL
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 19:45:45 -0000

Hi Chris, It seems to me that you take way too many moves. I approach grip as something I can see coming so that I can do any facing at pretty much the same speed. You may already know these, but I find them very quick. (Q means rotate the whole cube and lower case letters move just the slice) One in three out: F2 U r U2 r' U F2 and it's reverse F2 U' r U2 r' U' F2 Z pattern (swap edge pairs adjacent) r2 D b2 D' b r2 b' and it's reverse r2 D' b2 D b r2 b' Cross pattern (Swap edge pairs across) r2 U r2 U2 r2 U r2 If I want I can do (R' L' D2 R L U) 2 :) Happy cubing! David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I know I've mentioned that I am working on ZBF2L, and I've recently > made an improvement to my PLL because of it that I wanted to share. > > Since ZBF2L is followed by COLL, 2/3 of your solves end up in a 3 > cycle of edges. Also, 1/6 of your solves end up in the zig zag > pattern. Since these come up _so_ often I have revised me way of > executing these algs. > > I now use what I consider 12 algs for the edge 3-cycle (including > reflections) and what I consider 6 algs for the zig-zag patter also > including reflections. I also use my alg for the plus permutation > where opposite pairs of edges swap in addition to its reflection, so > what I consider to be two algs. > > I want to soon work on my permutations page to include all the algs I > use now as well as finger tricks, but since that may take a while I > wanted to post about these new algs here. > > Obviously this approach is good (IMHO) for people who orient the edges > of their LL, then do COLL and then do the edge PLL. However, even if > you are just using OLL and PLL, these algs make the edge cycle > permutations very, very fast. > > Here are all the algs I use for all the edge permutations, in addition > to how I view them. What is most important here is which hand is > gripping the cube after finishing the alg just before PLL. So I not > only pay attention to what case it is, but which hand is gripping the > cube. > > --------------- > > Edge 3-cycles: > > 1) Right hand is gripping the cube > > a) the solved edge is on the F face > - edges go clockwise: ((L')2 U) (L U L' U') (L' U') (L' U L') > - edges go counter-clockwise: (L U' L) (U) (L U) (L U') (L' U' L2) > > b) the solved edge is on the back face > - edges go clockwise: (L' U L') (U') (L' U') (L' U) (L U L2) > - edges go counter-clockwise: ((L)2 U' L') (U' L U) (L U) (L U' L) > > c) the solved edge is on the right face > - egdge go clockwise: (L' U2 L') (U') (L' U' (L)2) (U) (L U L2) > - edges go counter-clockwise: ((L)2 U') (L' U' (L)2) (U) (L U) (L U2 L) > > d) the solved edge is on the left face > - regrip the cube with the left hand and do 2d) > > 2) Left hand is gripping the cube > > a) the solved edge is on the F face > - edges go clockwise: (R' U R') (U') (R' U') (R' U) (R U (R')2) > - edges go counter-clockwise: ((R)2 U') (R' U' R) (U) (R U) (R U' R) > > b) the solved edge is on the back face > - edges go clockwise: ((R')2 U R) (U R' U') (R' U') (R' U R') > - edges go counter-clockwise: (R U' R) (U) (R U) (R U') (R' U' (R)2) > > c) the solved edge is on the right face > - regrip the cube with the right hand and do 1c) > > d) the solved edge is on the left face > - edges go clockwise: ((R')2 U) (R U (R')2) (U') (R' U') (R' U2 R') > - edge go counter-clockwise: (R U2 R) (U) (R U (R')2) (U') (R' U' (R)2) > > I consider each of these a separate case and as you can see the only > time you ever have to regrip the cube is for 1d and 2c. This is a > fast regrip since it only goes from right to left or vice versa and > there is no cube rotation. > > As you can see I only really use 2 algorithms, but I do the inverse of > one of them as well as the inverse and rotation of one of the others. > It helps to think of them as really 12 different cases though instead > of 2 algs applied 12 different ways. > > -------- > > I also use 6 algs for the zig-zag case. It really is only one > algorithm, similar to the above. However, when you view it as 6 > different cases the solves always go quickly and you don't have to > think about which way to turn the U layer when you're done. > > If you would like an explanation of the cube rotation notation I'm > using see http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/3-orientations.html and > read the info at the top. > > 1) Algs done right handed: > a) x' (R U') (R' U) [(D R' D) (U')] (R' U R) z' x' (l2 U) > - without finger trick notation this alg is R B' R' B F R' F B' R' B > R F2 U > b) x' (R U') (R' U) [(D R' D) (U')] (R' U R) z' x' (l2 U') > - without finger trick notation this alg is R B' R' B F R' F B' R' B > R F2 U' > c) x' (R U') (R' U) [(D R' D) (U')] (R' U R) z' x' (l2) > - without finger trick notation this alg is R B' R' B F R' F B' R' B > R F2 > > Do the inverse of each alg to get to the situation. As you can see > the only thing that changes is the U turn at the end. It either goes > one way or the other, or isn't there at all. > > 2) Algs done left handed: > a) x' (L' U) (L U') [(D' L D') (U)] (L U' L') z x' (r2 U') > - without finger trick notation this alg is L' B L B' F' L F' B L B' > L' F2 U' > b) x' (L' U) (L U') [(D' L D') (U)] (L U' L') z x' (r2 U) > - without finger trick notation this alg is L' B L B' F' L F' B L B' > L' F2 U > c) x' (L' U) (L U') [(D' L D') (U)] (L U' L') z x' (r2) > - without finger trick notation this alg is L' B L B' F' L F' B L B' > L' F2 > > Again this is always the same alg with a different U move at the end, > or even no U move. It is better to view this as 6 different cases > than to think of which way the U face is turned when solving. > > ----------- > > Lastly the edge perm where both pairs of opposite centers switch. I > use the same alg for each case, but I would do either the alg or its > reflections depending on the last face turned and which hand is > gripping the cube before I start. > > 1) right hand is gripping the cube > a) L' (R' U2 R) L y' R (L U2 L') R' > > 2) left hand is gripping the cube > b) R (L U2 L') R' y L' (R' U2 R) L > > ------------ > > Especially for when you always end with one of these permutations I > find it is better to expand to using more algs than to rotate the cube > and/or the U layer to get it to an angle that you know. > > I think this would also be helpful for a 2,3, or 4 look approach. You > have to work more to learn lots of cases where previously there were > only two, but you can almost always do the edge permutations from the > angle you encounter them. You will have to rotate the cube and/or > regrip sometimes using these algs, but much less often than normal. > > Again I find this helpful for VH solving, but I think it would apply > to solving in general which is why I posted. Obviously I think this > approach is very worthwhile for those using some sort of ZBF2L style > solving and always (or often) ending with an edge permutation. > > Chris

1739. 4x4x4 methods Was Interesting paradox
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 20:19:06 -0000

Hi Per, Gilles, et al, I also do centers last. I think that there's much greater freedom of movement, and if you learn to spot it you can solve parity with a single half turn. I do: 1 Eight corners 2 two opposing centers "middle level" At this point there is a center column of 4 centers all the way around the cube and the top and bottom levels may be rotated at will, so there is lots of flexibility. The front and back sides may be rotated followed by center moves, and rotated back to place the first. 3 all four "middle level" edge pairs You lose the front and back turns but that's no handicap. 4 two FL edge pairs (on the already-solved centers) Now all the changes happen using the top level and the four unsolved centers. 5 two LL edge pairs (on the already-solved centers) At this point you have the left and right side solved, and the remaining edges can be lined up easily. 6 pair up the remaining edges This is really easy, and it only takes a moment to see if you need to 6a solve parity Done now this only takes one move. You will need to pair up the remaining edges again without undoing parity. Two sets of algs can be used if you spot whether you need to solve parity or not after step 5. 8 place the four remaining edge pairs 9 fix the four remaining centers I hope my description makes sense. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > Well then im one of those weird cubers :D I do centers last on the > 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. And as u can see from the unofficial world records > im quite fast with it too ;-) The benefit of doing centers last (for > me anyway) is that the rest of the solve speeds up. Doing the > centers on the last 5 faces last is a bit slower than doing centers > first. But at least by now the rest of the cube is solves and u have > easier recognition. Easy recognition is the way to success on the > larger cubes. many (including me) find that pairing up is too > awkward since ur only ppoint of reference is one (or two) other edge > (s) only. The pairing up stage is what most ppl struggle to speed > up. I know of good cubers who spend more time on the pairing-up > stage than on one of my complete solves. So the normal 3x3x3 > reduction "regime" is not the salvation for everyone :-) > > I would call my method the cage method. It's somewhat similar to > columns first method. > > First layer (top) > Middle layers edges (hold solved layer to the left) > Last layer corners then edges (and parity) > Final centers > > Happy cubing !! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > Centres last? What kind of weird cubers try that? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > <no_reply@y...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > I just realized something I had never thought of. Winning > moves > > > > doesn't produce true general cubes where the orientations of > the > > > > centers doesn't matter. The white sticker always has a design > > on it, > > > > so in competitions your cube is only solved 1/4 the time, yet > we > > still > > > > consider it solved. > > > > > > > > So we've all been frequently (75% of the time actually) > counting > > cubes > > > > as solved that never were in fact solved. There has been > rampant > > > > cheating in the cubing community for almost 2 years :) > > > > > > > > Perhaps we should memorize which way the design of the white > > sticker > > > > is oriented when we buy our cubes to make sure we don't cheat > > and just > > > > half solve it :) > > > > > > > > And no I'm not serious at all in my claims of cheating. I just > > > > thought it was a funny way to look at things ;-) > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > Logos on stickers should be forbidden in competitions. At least, > it > > > can help "centers-last" cubers locate pieces faster. > > > And yes, I'm serious. ;-) > > > > > > Gilles.

1745. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: A nice forum...
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Mar 2005 18:00:31 -0500

I generally like participating in groups like this through e-mail. I
currently have all of the Yahoo messages forwarded over to a Gmail
account, and it is very easy to use. It is simple to view all new
messages across all topics grouped by thread.

One of the e-mail lists that I'm on (work related) has recently moved
to PHPBB. I don't like it. They don't allow me to receive the entire
messages via e-mail. Trying to look at new messages means I need to
click through lots of different forums rather than looking at a list
of message subjects for the entire board.

If the new forum can deal with these issues, then I wouldn't mind
moving. But I'm pretty happy with the group as it is now.
