1748. Re: Edge permutations during PLL
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 01:36:07 -0000

Hey David, The reason I use those longer moves is that, for me, the longer algs are much faster to perform than R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 or the equivalent with slice moves. I like the longer ones since your grip hand never moves and you never have to rotate the cube. I know that there are shorter and more efficient algs for swapping the edges, but I listed the particular ones I did since for me they are all faster to perform and thus more of what I am looking for. I'm not being weird just to be weird, there is a method to my madness :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Chris, > > It seems to me that you take way too many moves. > > I approach grip as something I can see coming so that I can do any > facing at pretty much the same speed. > > You may already know these, but I find them very quick. > > (Q means rotate the whole cube and lower case letters move just the > slice) > One in three out: > F2 U r U2 r' U F2 and it's reverse F2 U' r U2 r' U' F2 > Z pattern (swap edge pairs adjacent) > r2 D b2 D' b r2 b' and it's reverse r2 D' b2 D b r2 b' > Cross pattern (Swap edge pairs across) > r2 U r2 U2 r2 U r2 > If I want I can do (R' L' D2 R L U) 2 :) > > Happy cubing! > > David J
1749. Re: Edge permutations during PLL
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 05:29:10 -0000

or perhaps a method to your madness? nah...just kidding. (switching UF<>UR and UL<>UB) the Z perm http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html Ls Ds2 Ls D Ls2 U' Bs2 http://www.planet-puzzle.com/cubepll.html U R'U'R U'R - U R U'R'U R - U R2 U'R'U the second one has a lot more moves....17 as opposed to 7, but i can perform the 2nd one a lot faster. Just something to think about...in my opinion, speedcubing is finding the best algorithms for yourself, so...whichever you can perfrom the quickest, is the best. Of course the best option are those you can perform quickly, and are the shortest moves...for example the Sune... R U R' U R U2 R'...less than one second. although, some prefer the "Niklas". R U' L U R' U' L ....It depends on the cuber. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey David, > > The reason I use those longer moves is that, for me, the longer algs > are much faster to perform than R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 or the > equivalent with slice moves. > > I like the longer ones since your grip hand never moves and you never > have to rotate the cube. > > I know that there are shorter and more efficient algs for swapping the > edges, but I listed the particular ones I did since for me they are > all faster to perform and thus more of what I am looking for. > > I'm not being weird just to be weird, there is a method to my madness :-) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Chris, > > > > It seems to me that you take way too many moves. > > > > I approach grip as something I can see coming so that I can do any > > facing at pretty much the same speed. > > > > You may already know these, but I find them very quick. > > > > (Q means rotate the whole cube and lower case letters move just the > > slice) > > One in three out: > > F2 U r U2 r' U F2 and it's reverse F2 U' r U2 r' U' F2 > > Z pattern (swap edge pairs adjacent) > > r2 D b2 D' b r2 b' and it's reverse r2 D' b2 D b r2 b' > > Cross pattern (Swap edge pairs across) > > r2 U r2 U2 r2 U r2 > > If I want I can do (R' L' D2 R L U) 2 :) > > > > Happy cubing! > > > > David J
1750. Re: Corner or cross?
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 05:33:19 -0000

I definately agree. I started with the petrus method, after playing around self teaching myself the LBL method, but not really suceeding. I learned some F2l algorithms, and how to do a basic corners first method, all of which have helped me in using the Roux method (avg ~24.8) The beauty is that speedcubing is less reliant on the method, and more about looking ahead. The more you know and practice, the better you get. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I picked up a cube for the first serious time last May and have been thoroughly hooked since. My initial method was similar to Kirk's in that it involved the first layer on top, corners before edges, then inserted each middle layer edge afterward. I've since upgraded to cross on bottom, followed by the corner/edge pairs (which I've learned how to do on my own). I use a 4 look last layer with a little bit of partial edge control, several special cases, and a few extra tricks. With this method I am able to average around 35 seconds with my best times hovering a tad under 24 seconds. > > A few weeks ago, I decided to try my hand at the Roux method. It requires fewer moves, on average, so, theoretically, I have the potential to be faster with it. Using his system with two 1x2x3 blocks and minimal step 3 and 4 algorithms, I am able to average consistently under 39 seconds, with a pair of best times fractions of a second slower than my best fridrich times. I'm incredibly pleased with my progress, despite minimal learning. I use this new method exclusively in practice now, and hope to have my times greatly improved by the summer when I'm able to attend another competition. I've decided to commit to learning more algorithms for the last layer corners and some of the 26 special cases for the last layer over the next few weeks. > > Basically, toying around with other methods is a fantastic way to improve your times, even if you stick with your old method. They can be invaluable for providing you with easy to recognize special cases you would otherwise never have learned. Also, meeting with other cubers is immensely helpful. They can teach you things you thought previously impossible to understand. I hope I've helped. > > Happy cubing, > -Mike Bennett > ----- Original Message ----- > From: kirk83616<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@y ahoogroups.com> > Sent: Tuesday, March 29, 2005 11:17 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Corner or cross? > > > > A few months ago, I was about where you are. I opted to try to > learn the Fridrich method first since it's so widely used, but I > plan on learning Petrus and a corners first method eventually [and > now maybe the Gilles method, though not sure I even know what that > is]. And I still use some moves from my old method. > > With my old method, my times were about 1.5 - 2.5 minutes. When I > started to learn Fridrich on my own, I was able to drop to about a > minute rather quickly [couple of weeks practice]. Switching to > cross first and doing it on the bottom was the first major > adjustment [my old method did the top corners first, then the top > edges]. then learing how to insert the corner/edge pairs was the > second big adjustment for me, and I still don't know all of those > [old method was get top layer all done, then insert each middle > layer edge]. last big adjustmetn I made was to learn some of the > PLL algs. With that, I was at a minute to 1:15 within a couple of > weeks. > > I've only this week learned the final 4 of the PLL algs, and I still > know only 3 OLL algs [the ones from my old method], and my times > have steadily dropped. My best is now 38.9, and I consistently get > in the 40s and 50s. > > I got to the minute mark mostly by studying/practicing the sequences > I printed off various sites. I didn't look at too many videos at > first because I wanted to try the moves on my own. Later, I studied > lots of videos to watch hand technique, and that really helped. > There are lots of good sites out there [Dan plugged his, and > frankly, it was indeed extremely helpful]. Finally, getting > together with a couple of cubers who are much faster than me helped > with the last 15-20 seconds of progress. > > anyway, that's my story. hope it's helpful. > best regards, > Kirk > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar > <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > > Ok guys, I am an better-than-newbie at cubing right > > now. I can solve the cube in about 2 mins but my > > method is really very sloggy and it consumes a lot of > > steps. So I was thinking of shifting to some another > > method. I found that there are mainly two widespread > > methods - the Lars Petrus's Corner method and the > > cross method(I am not thinking about the Fridrich > > method right now). So can you guys suggest which > > method to use considering the documentation available > > of the method and the number of steps achieved by each > > method. > > Currently the Lars Petrus's method is on top of my > > list since it has some nice Java cubes alongwith the > > explanation. I havent found such a site for the cross > > method. > > Please reply! > > > > > _____________________________________________________________________ > ___ > > Yahoo! India Matrimony: Find your life partner online > > Go to: http://yahoo.shaadi.com/india- matrimony<http://yahoo.shaadi.com/india-matrimony> > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > ADVERTISEMENT > <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/SIG=1295t1t57/M=298184.6018725.7038619.300117 6/D=groups/S=1705297356:HM/EXP=1112203066/A=2593423/R=0/SIG=11el9gslf/ *http://www.netflix.com/Default?mqso=60190075> > > > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------- > Yahoo! 1751. Re: Edge permutations during PLL
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 05:35:53 -0000

Also, i meant madness to your method.... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@y...> wrote: > > or perhaps a method to your madness? > > nah...just kidding. > > (switching UF<>UR and UL<>UB) the Z perm > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > Ls Ds2 Ls D Ls2 U' Bs2 > > > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/cubepll.html > U R'U'R U'R - U R U'R'U R - U R2 U'R'U > > the second one has a lot more moves....17 as opposed to 7, but i can > perform the 2nd one a lot faster. > > Just something to think about...in my opinion, speedcubing is finding > the best algorithms for yourself, so...whichever you can perfrom the > quickest, is the best. Of course the best option are those you can > perform quickly, and are the shortest moves...for example the Sune... > > R U R' U R U2 R'...less than one second. > > although, some prefer the "Niklas". > > R U' L U R' U' L > > ....It depends on the cuber. > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey David, > > > > The reason I use those longer moves is that, for me, the longer algs > > are much faster to perform than R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 or the > > equivalent with slice moves. > > > > I like the longer ones since your grip hand never moves and you > never > > have to rotate the cube. > > > > I know that there are shorter and more efficient algs for swapping > the > > edges, but I listed the particular ones I did since for me they are > > all faster to perform and thus more of what I am looking for. > > > > I'm not being weird just to be weird, there is a method to my > madness :-) > > > > Chris > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi Chris, > > > > > > It seems to me that you take way too many moves. > > > > > > I approach grip as something I can see coming so that I can do any > > > facing at pretty much the same speed. > > > > > > You may already know these, but I find them very quick. > > > > > > (Q means rotate the whole cube and lower case letters move just > the > > > slice) > > > One in three out: > > > F2 U r U2 r' U F2 and it's reverse F2 U' r U2 r' U' F2 > > > Z pattern (swap edge pairs adjacent) > > > r2 D b2 D' b r2 b' and it's reverse r2 D' b2 D b r2 b' > > > Cross pattern (Swap edge pairs across) > > > r2 U r2 U2 r2 U r2 > > > If I want I can do (R' L' D2 R L U) 2 :) > > > > > > Happy cubing! > > > > > > David J
1752. Done!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 06:44:25 -0000


Hey everyone,

I am very happy, I finished learning all 158 ZBF2L cases today! It
took me a little over 2 months to do it, which worked out to about 2.5
cases per day. I now solve exclusively using the VH method (F2L w/
orienting LL edges, COLL, PLL) and average 19-23 seconds using it. I
still need to work on my recognition time and moving algs to my
subconscious, particularly with the ones I have learned more recently.
The algs I started with two months ago I can recognize very quickly,
and I don't think recognition for all 158 cases will be hard with lots
of pratice.

I'm going to take about 2-3 weeks off from learning to really cement
all these algs in my head very well. After that I'll move on to the
ZBLL and start learning those too.

For those who thought ZBF2L might be too unreasonable because of the
number of algs I can say that I don't think it will be at all. I
think it will take a lot of practice, but for about half the algs (the
ones I learned 1 month ago or more) I have very quick recognition and
execution. I imagine in another month I will be comfortable with all
the cases.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zb.html

See my site for the algs I use for ZBF2L as well as what I consider to
be a useful order for which cases to learn first.

So far I only know for certain of 4 other people learning ZB right
now, but I would like to wish everyone that is (including those I
don't know about) lots of luck and fun by learning!

Chris

1762. Re: A nice forum...
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 11:04:13 -0000


Hi,

I am recently working on the web site of my office.
(Sorry this is not disclosed yet. )
I really love CMS and want to change my cubing site into CMS managed
one.

PhPBB must be a great CMS.
But there are many good free CMSs.
http://www.opensourcecms.com/index.php

I tested a few of them and chose XOOPS.
http://www.xoops.org

It is partly because there are many ehthusiastic developers in Japan.
But this is not the only reason.
You can easily create not only forums but also movie albums,
calendar, headline news, poll, etc.

XOOPS also offers great multilanguage support including two byte code
languages.(Of course, it can'T translate contents just header and
bottuns. ) What you need is just multilanguage module and language
fiels.

examples of multilanguage support
http://www.peak.ne.jp/xoops/?easiestml_lang=xlang:en

http://demo.smartfactory.ca/

This must be great advantage for everybody accessing from different
countries.

>Before the layout change this forum was ok, but now i find it very
>hard to read with the new colors, the previews of the messages in
the
>message board and and the ads.
Every visitor can choose background and layout from provided list if
theme changer is installed.

Japanese example
Try to click titles in the middle column. Theme will change.
http://hello.oceannet.jp/

>messages via e-mail. Trying to look at new messages means I need to
>click through lots of different forums rather than looking at a list
>of message subjects for the entire board.
>If the new forum can deal with these issues, then I wouldn't mind
>moving. But I'm pretty happy with the group as it is now.
XOOPS offers your choices to recieve notification with or without
text.
But you have to set these options by yourself.

just my 2 cents.


Masayuki

1764. Re: Done!
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 14:15:29 -0000

Hey Chris! *Respect* :D. I don't know if I'll ever try to learn that many algs. btw, didn't you ever think of orientating the edges before making the cross? It's maybe a little hard to master that, but if it's possible, you would not have to memorize all those ZB f2l algs :). Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I am very happy, I finished learning all 158 ZBF2L cases today! It > took me a little over 2 months to do it, which worked out to about 2.5 > cases per day. I now solve exclusively using the VH method (F2L w/ > orienting LL edges, COLL, PLL) and average 19-23 seconds using it. I > still need to work on my recognition time and moving algs to my > subconscious, particularly with the ones I have learned more recently. > The algs I started with two months ago I can recognize very quickly, > and I don't think recognition for all 158 cases will be hard with lots > of pratice. > > I'm going to take about 2-3 weeks off from learning to really cement > all these algs in my head very well. After that I'll move on to the > ZBLL and start learning those too. > > For those who thought ZBF2L might be too unreasonable because of the > number of algs I can say that I don't think it will be at all. I > think it will take a lot of practice, but for about half the algs (the > ones I learned 1 month ago or more) I have very quick recognition and > execution. I imagine in another month I will be comfortable with all > the cases. > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zb.html > > See my site for the algs I use for ZBF2L as well as what I consider to > be a useful order for which cases to learn first. > > So far I only know for certain of 4 other people learning ZB right > now, but I would like to wish everyone that is (including those I > don't know about) lots of luck and fun by learning! > > Chris

1768. 4x4x4 "cage" - Question to Per
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 15:26:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote many interesting things, including: > > First layer (top) > Middle layers edges (hold solved layer to the left) > Last layer corners then edges (and parity) > Final centers > Please tell us how many moves are needed to build the cage. I'm a rookie, but my first stats look like: - L-layer: 40 - rl-edges: 40 - R-corners: 10 - R-edges: ? You must have found some ways of shortening the process, because much more than 100 moves is too much (I need about 90 moves to solve this "cage" + R-centers using my technique). Any tips? Gilles. PS: In a decent forum, someone interested by 4x4x4 techniques can find this message several months after it has been posted, just go to the "4x4x4" section. In this group, it's gonna be burried and forgotten in no time. I'm not saying that this post is interesting, but I hope the answer will, for me and for others as well (or else, I would have sent it privately).

1771. Re: A nice forum...
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 16:20:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. > .> wrote: > > > > Plus, I wouldn't > > have to quote the entire message when I replied!! *looks up at the > > top of the screen* > > At the top of the screen? Where? Oops, I've cut it away, which indeed > is possible ;-) No, you are correct. Cutting the quote away is possible, hence my phrasing it that "I wouldn't have to quote" instead of "it would not force me to quote". It is just good practice to do so incase someone enters the topic at a point below the originating post. That way people that are reading my entry know to which part I am referring. But in a message board environment, it is always visible on the page, so the need is omitted.
1772. Re: Replacement stickers outside of USA?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 16:33:24 -0000

update: I just tried out restickering my cube using robust plastic dividers, like Gilles advises on his page. In case you are interested in trying this: It works very good... However, you should really use pretty thick dividers, and the colors should be very 'vivid' (that's what the dictionary says :)). - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Well, I am not that sure... > > You could try to use Gilles' tip about making stickers yourself, > though :): > > http://grrroux.free.fr/ > > (Goto 'workshop'). I haven't tried this myself yet... From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 16:42:00 -0000

Hey! Im on my way home now. Short reply only now ... 90-100 moves sounds reasonable. 2 moves/sec and u are at 45/50 secs before the centers. Im nearer to 55 when at full speed. And then 25 secs to finish off the centers. Better reply tomorrow :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote many interesting things, including: > > > > > First layer (top) > > Middle layers edges (hold solved layer to the left) > > Last layer corners then edges (and parity) > > Final centers > > > > Please tell us how many moves are needed to build the cage. > > I'm a rookie, but my first stats look like: > - L-layer: 40 > - rl-edges: 40 > - R-corners: 10 > - R-edges: ? > > You must have found some ways of shortening the process, because much > more than 100 moves is too much (I need about 90 moves to solve this > "cage" + R-centers using my technique). > Any tips? > > Gilles. > > PS: In a decent forum, someone interested by 4x4x4 techniques can find > this message several months after it has been posted, just go to the > "4x4x4" section. 1775. Re: 4x4x4 methods Was Interesting paradox
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 17:24:46 -0000

Hi Stefan, and All, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > you can solve parity with a single half turn. > > "half turn"? Don't confuse newbies ;-) They'll trust and misunderstand > you and never fix the parity. Sorry, this should have read "quarter turn." I know that Yahoo is proud of their new page, and I'm glad that so many people complained that Yahoo put back the "post number search," but I dislike that the "edit your own post" feature is gone now. > > 9 fix the four remaining centers > > After all this detail (not at all a complaint ;-) something's still > missing: What are your times with this method? I only just got a cube that might be good for speedcubing, so all my times are are on cubes which cannot be turned quickly. I did calculate the number of turns I take, though: 12 (12) 6 + 4 + 8 + 5 (35) 5 + 7 (47) 8 + 8 (63) 5 (68) 14 + 14 (96) 1 (97) 7 (104) 9 + 21 (134) Is this comparable to others? Actually the first step is really 11, but I don't know the all 11 move algs. > Cheers! > Stefan Thanks, David J

1777. Re: Edge permutations during PLL
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 18:05:40 -0000

Hey Chris, I understand. I just optimized what my hands do. You've probably spent a lot of time getting those quick, but it may only be a different style/technique. I'd probable have as much trouble switching to your algs, as you would switching to mine. I know there's method to your madness, it's just a different method... :) Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey David, > > The reason I use those longer moves is that, for me, the longer algs > are much faster to perform than R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 or the > equivalent with slice moves. > > I like the longer ones since your grip hand never moves and you never > have to rotate the cube. > > I know that there are shorter and more efficient algs for swapping the > edges, but I listed the particular ones I did since for me they are > all faster to perform and thus more of what I am looking for. > > I'm not being weird just to be weird, there is a method to my madness :-) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Chris, > > > > It seems to me that you take way too many moves. > > > > I approach grip as something I can see coming so that I can do any > > facing at pretty much the same speed. > > > > You may already know these, but I find them very quick. > > > > [snip] lower case letters move just the slice) > > One in three out: > > F2 U r U2 r' U F2 and it's reverse F2 U' r U2 r' U' F2 > > Z pattern (swap edge pairs adjacent) > > r2 D b2 D' b r2 b' and it's reverse r2 D' b2 D b r2 b' > > Cross pattern (Swap edge pairs across) > > r2 U r2 U2 r2 U r2 > > If I want I can do (R' L' D2 R L U) 2 :) > > > > Happy cubing! > > > > David J

1779. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Lubing
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 14:56:41 -0500

Very similar to 3x3x3. Rotate one face by about 45 degrees so that
an edge cubie is lined up with the corner. Stick your finger or a
screwdriver under the edge and pop it out (as gently as possible). Be
careful, because the center pieces are prone to breaking. After the
first piece is out, the rest of them should come out (and go back in)
without the need for force.

These instructions are for the Rubik's brand 4x4x4. I've never taken
apart an Eastsheen cube, and they may be constructed a little
differently.

1783. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Lubing
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>

Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 21:53:44 -0000

Do you line up the pieces about the same to spray them? After you take it apart, are there any surprise pieces? When I lube my 3x3x3, I take it completely apart (wash it most times), and then line up the pieces and spray. The last time I did it, I had some help from a friend, and he's back home, but i need to spray mine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > Very similar to 3x3x3. 1788. RE: [Speed cubing group] Done!
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Apr 2005 08:46:04 +0100

Congratulations Chris, I am very proud of you :) Now maybe you could give me some motivation to carry on with ZB, I am falling behind. :( Dan :P _____ From: cmhardw [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: 31 March 2005 07:44 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Done! Hey everyone, I am very happy, I finished learning all 158 ZBF2L cases today! It took me a little over 2 months to do it, which worked out to about 2.5 cases per day. I now solve exclusively using the VH method (F2L w/ orienting LL edges, COLL, PLL) and average 19-23 seconds using it. I still need to work on my recognition time and moving algs to my subconscious, particularly with the ones I have learned more recently. The algs I started with two months ago I can recognize very quickly, and I don't think recognition for all 158 cases will be hard with lots of pratice. I'm going to take about 2-3 weeks off from learning to really cement all these algs in my head very well. After that I'll move on to the ZBLL and start learning those too. For those who thought ZBF2L might be too unreasonable because of the number of algs I can say that I don't think it will be at all. I think it will take a lot of practice, but for about half the algs (the ones I learned 1 month ago or more) I have very quick recognition and execution. I imagine in another month I will be comfortable with all the cases. http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zb.html See my site for the algs I use for ZBF2L as well as what I consider to be a useful order for which cases to learn first. So far I only know for certain of 4 other people learning ZB right now, but I would like to wish everyone that is (including those I don't know about) lots of luck and fun by learning! Chris Yahoo! 1789. Re: [Speed cubing group] video compression
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Apr 2005 09:49:21 -0000

Hey! I have another suggestion also. Use the VirtualDub to make an uncompressed .avi file first. Then use the STOIK video converter to make a compressed video. It's much easier to use that program than the cumbersome VirtualDub. Esp when working w multiple files. The advantage of uncompressing w VirtualDub is that is supports many more fileformats. The STOIK can output divx or .wmv as useful compressed formats. Link to the STOIK : http://www.stoik.com/products/svc/ Choose the free version ;-) Have fun!! -Per PS! And use VLC for viewing files that the windows mediaplayer struggles with ;-) The GUI is not so nice but the playback is very good :-) VLC is free :-) (Link : http://www.videolan.org/vlc/) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > much thanks! :) > > Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Doug Reed > <dougreed@h...> wrote: > > Here ya go, try this: > > > > http://www.virtualdub.org/ > > > > Doug > > > > Bob Burton wrote: > > > > >could somebody tell me how to compress a .avi video? my vid is > about > > >13 mb and that is waaay too large for me to be happy with. > > > > > >~bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

1795. Re: A nice forum...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Apr 2005 14:18:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > No, you are correct. Cutting the quote away is possible, hence my > phrasing it that "I wouldn't have to quote" instead of "it would > not force me to quote". Hmm, I don't really see the difference... Is there any? > It is just good practice to do so incase > someone enters the topic at a point below the originating post. If I want to know the *whole* previous message(s in case of quoted quotes etc) then I click on "Up Thread". > That way people that are reading my entry know to which part I am > referring. No they don't. Unless you quote and reply to pieces. Oh wait, you don't mean part of message but part of thread? Use "Up Thread". > But in a message board environment, it is always > visible on the page, so the need is omitted. There's no need here, either. Use "Up Thread". Usually though I think it's best to indeed use quotes. But don't quote the whole message including all previously quoted quotes, that's just stupid waste (I don't want to offend anyone, but it's the truth). I try to always quote the name of the poster and then only selected quotes. So that readers actually know what you reply to. And the same is true for message boards. Cheers! Stefan

1798. Re: A nice forum...
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Apr 2005 18:17:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. > .> wrote: > > > > No, you are correct. Cutting the quote away is possible, hence my > > phrasing it that "I wouldn't have to quote" instead of "it would > > not force me to quote". > > Hmm, I don't really see the difference... Is there any? Indeed there is a difference, and an important one at that. The difference is the freedom of choice. > > It is just good practice to do so incase > > someone enters the topic at a point below the originating post. > > If I want to know the *whole* previous message(s in case of quoted > quotes etc) then I click on "Up Thread". Fair enough, but as it was discovered quite recently, not everyone is aware of this feature. Also, it only brings you to the message immediately above the current one in the thread. It can be time consuming for someone to click through posts, reading them all looking for one single reference. It is just easier, and more efficient to include it in your post. > > But in a message board environment, it is always > > visible on the page, so the need is omitted. > > There's no need here, either. Use "Up Thread". If you are hoping for people to navigate through many pages just to understand which part you are taking about, it is probably not going to happen as often as you may think. There doesn't seem to be much harm in quoting a message to which you are replying. I only quoted the *entire* message the first time because I wasn't responding to a specific part, but rather a response on the post in general. It seems valid to me, but apparently you have your own opinions on the subject. > Usually though I think it's best to indeed use quotes. But don't quote > the whole message including all previously quoted quotes, that's just > stupid waste (I don't want to offend anyone, but it's the truth). It isn't a waste of time in the true sense of the term, because yahoo automatically includes it for you in your post. Thereby eliminating any "time" required to perform the aforementioned action. However, I agree, I wouldn't do that unless it was relevant to what I was posting about. > I try to always quote the name of the poster and then only selected > quotes. So that readers actually know what you reply to. And the same > is true for message boards. I agree with you, and I do the same thing. You seem to be rather passionate about the structure in which people participate on these types of forums. That is great; having a passion for just about anything is admirable. Perhaps you should write up a guide for new, and veteran, people so that no one else comes along and puts your knickers in a knot.

1801. Re: A nice forum...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Apr 2005 21:28:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > Indeed there is a difference, and an important one at that. The > difference is the freedom of choice. "having to quote" is more freedom than "being forced to quote"? I still don't see the difference. > There doesn't seem to be > much harm in quoting a message to which you are replying. I only > quoted the *entire* message the first time because I wasn't > responding to a specific part, but rather a response on the post in > general. Let me clarify one thing: I didn't really complain about yours. I only commented it because it sounded like you had no choice. I remember a few posts a while ago where several people quoted and quoted again and in the end we had several posts of up to 19 screen pages each. Yes, 19 pages! Each post! But only a few lines of actually new text! *That* is what I really consider to be unnecessary waste. > It isn't a waste of time in the true sense of the term, because > yahoo automatically includes it for you in your post. Hello?! Don't you *read* messages, too? Don't you have to download them from the web? If you use the "expanded" view, don't you have to scroll over quotes? Doesn't that all cost time? And how about bandwith? If I take a few seconds to cut quotes than it will potentially save *hundreds* of other people some time! Which makes it worth it I think. > You seem to be rather passionate about the structure in which people > participate on these types of forums. Again, I'm mainly against completely unnecessary and huge repeated quoting. Sorry if I sounded harsh. Cheers! Stefan

1804. Where to buy cubes in San Diego CA
From: pabloruizcampos <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Apr 2005 02:10:39 -0000


Cubist living in San Diego, i need your help.
I have a relative living in San Diego and he can send me cubes and
sillicon spray ( i live in Mexico and they are impossible to find ),
but my questions are: Is there a specialized place where he can buy
cubes ( I want a 2x2x2, a 3x3x3, a 3x3x3 keychain, a 4x4x4, a 5x5x5
and
a Square-1 ) or where can he find them? and what about the sillicon,
what brands are easy to find and where?

Thank you all

Ps. Please excuse my bad english :).

ruiz_campos_pablo@...





1805. Re: Where to buy cubes in San Diego CA
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Apr 2005 02:33:26 -0000

Rubiks.com is of course the most obvious choice (they have 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, & 5x5 (i don't remember if they still carry the keychain). there was a recent thread about purchasing square-1. Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pabloruizcampos <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Cubist living in San Diego, i need your help. > I have a relative living in San Diego and he can send me cubes and > sillicon spray ( i live in Mexico and they are impossible to find ), > but my questions are: Is there a specialized place where he can buy > cubes ( I want a 2x2x2, a 3x3x3, a 3x3x3 keychain, a 4x4x4, a 5x5x5 > and > a Square-1 ) or where can he find them? and what about the sillicon, > what brands are easy to find and where? > > Thank you all > > Ps. 1806. Re: [Speed cubing group] Where to buy cubes in San Diego CA
From: Doug Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Apr 2005 20:37:52 -0600

You can get the 3x3x3 at pretty much any big one-stop-shop type store
(i.e. Wal Mart) or toy store. Barnes and Noble has started to carry
4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cubes. I've found 3x3x3 Keychain cubes at a local
Family Dollar store, also. As for the 2x2x2 and Square-1, I'm afraid I
can't help.

Doug

Has anyone tried teflon spray instead of silicone?

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology




1813. Re: teflon
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Apr 2005 22:52:31 -0000

I did and it didn't work as well as silicon. I got the dupont spray can of teflon from Lowes. I thought it would've been better, but it wasn't in my opinion. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > Has anyone tried teflon spray instead of silicone? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1814. Re: teflon
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 03 Apr 2005 02:02:02 -0000

Strange....DuPoint Teflon Silicone (From lowe's as well) works awesome on my cubes. This is how I decide what kind of lube to use for cubes: ~First Time (When it's sealed): Use WD-40 if the cube seriously sucks so that it will eat away the plastic. If it's just brand new and average, I just use SNAP, and leave it there overnight and the cube becomes "loose" the next day. ~3 Days after playing:The SNAP will wear out because the pieces compress together more, which makes it rub against each other and makes it "go away" (sorry for my non-scientific explanation, spring break has gotten to my head already -_-"). I then spray a little bit of Pledge (wood polisher) and play with it. ~A week after the 3 days: I use DU-Point Teflon Silicone. It makes the cube feel "slower" but ALOT smoother. By this time, the cube should be good enough a speedcube. ~After the cube is almost worn out: Use silicone wax or cube lube and then the cube will probably become your best speedcube (at least for me) Hope that helps~ ~Joseph http://jliao.tk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@g...> wrote: > > I did and it didn't work as well as silicon. I got the dupont spray > can of teflon from Lowes. I thought it would've been better, but it > wasn't in my opinion. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > Has anyone tried teflon spray instead of silicone? > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology
1815. HAHAHA

Shipping Cost $15.00

Delivery time: 2-3 weeks

Total: $40 for 2-3 week delivery of a puzzle that sells for $5 on
rubiks.com! :) (ebay is so fun to look at)

Bob

seee in the speedcubing videos.

1817. Re: teflon
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 03 Apr 2005 12:19:09 -0000

Yes, when I was a newbie, I started using teflon spray as lubricant. It does not work that good on every cube; it depends on the cube. I would not recommend using teflon spray in an Arxon cube, but on my old cube, it worked pretty good. But I would also advise you not to try this with your favorite cube... You never know what will happen. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > Has anyone tried teflon spray instead of silicone? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

1827. Dallas Cube Promotion
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 4 Apr 2005 02:17:06 -0700

Hey Everyone,

In order to try and encourage people to attend the tournament in
Dallas, Texas, the Caltech Rubik's Cube Club is offering this cube
selling promotion. If you sell 100 cubes, we'll send you to Dallas for
free! E-mail me at tmao at its dot caltech dot edu for more details.
Basically, you find 100 people to buy cubes, we'll send you 100 cubes,
and that plane ticket to Dallas. How does one go about selling 100
cubes? Easy! Just start teaching people... find that club fair at
your school, etc. Just cube in public, have a supply of cubes on hand,
and just trade a cube for a $10 bill and you're all set.

Either that, or if you buy 100 cubes from us, we'll send you to Dallas
for free as well! Actually, we'll throw in 8 cubes just for free
because that makes it divisible by 12.

Other free plane tickets to Dallas deals can be worked out. I just
really want people to go to the tournament in Dallas... so go sign up
on our yahoo database. We have 5 people right now. 5. It would be
nice if it were 50.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1829. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: A nice forum...
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 4 Apr 2005 09:40:20 -0400

I don't see much advantage to logging in to read posts. I prefer the Gmail user interface to the Yahoo message board interface. The group has things other than messages (files, chat, member list) that you can access via the website. Setting up e-mail delivery is more complicated than logging in to the forum (no setup). If you want to be able to post through e-mail, you have make sure that the e-mail address that you give to the group matches the sender address that your e-mail program puts on the messages. If you use an e-mail forwarding service, this may not be the case. If you are searching for old messages, the group has messages going back to 6/18/2000, and your e-mail only has messages going back to when you signed up for e-mail delivery. On Apr 4, 2005 7:18 AM, Duncan Dicks <duncan@...> wrote: > I never log into the forum itself but just get all the posts directly > forwarded to my e-mail. > > Am I missing out by doing this? Is there more to be gained by actually > logging on? This is the only group I use so I don't know much about groups > and really would like some constructive answers (if there are any)!
1830. Number of possibilities?
From: "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 19:42:55 -0000


I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there
are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer
simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was
curious exactly how large it is.





1831. Re: Number of possibilities?
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 19:51:30 -0000

I'd assume it's approximately the number of F2L Cases 42 in 4 places times 57 orientation cases...approximately 42*57*4 or... 9576? It'd be easier to memorize the 1211 LL cases instead. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there > are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer > simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was > curious exactly how large it is.
1832. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Number of possibilities?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 4 Apr 2005 12:54:23 -0700

No, that can't be right. For a given F2L case, you already limit the corner orientation and edge orientation. Isn't the number around 700? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Apr 4, 2005, at 12:51 PM, jwillywonkas wrote: > > > I'd assume it's approximately the number of F2L Cases > > 42 in 4 places times 57 orientation cases...approximately 42*57*4 or... > 9576? It'd be easier to memorize the 1211 LL cases instead. > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: >> >> I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations > there >> are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer >> simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was >> curious exactly how large it is. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1833. Re: Number of possibilities?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 19:58:01 -0000

Ok.. I'll just try to roughly estimate this.. If there are 42 F2L cases, there are 4! permutations for the corners, and 4! for the edges.. There are 3^3 corner orientations, and 2^3edge orientations.. I also multiply by (1/2) to deal with the parity... 42*4!*4!*3^3*2^3 *(1/2)= 2612736 So that's about 2.6 million possibilities.. Can anyone confirm this? Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there > are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer > simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was > curious exactly how large it is.
1834. Re: Number of possibilities?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 20:01:22 -0000

Sorry.. I totally misunderstood, the first time.. I'll try again.. Assuming there are 42 F2L cases, there are about: 42*3^3*2^3 = 9072 possibilities (I think). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there > are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer > simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was > curious exactly how large it is.
1835. Re: Number of possibilities?
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 21:15:14 -0000

Well recently I'v started learning the zb f2l, and I know all the cases where you already have the corner edge pair already paired up and I know a few others but when I do these cases I orient the last layer by finishing the f2l a lot more often than when I just used fridrich f2l. I'd estimate using the zb f2l I skip the OLL about 1/50 solves, I do it on a daily basis now, it used to be a rare thing for me when I was doing fridrich f2l. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there > are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer > simultaneously. I'm sure this number is pretty large, but I was > curious exactly how large it is.

1837. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2 > 3
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 17:39:29 -0400

> I consider the 4x4x4 more difficult than the 5x5x5, since the parity
> problems are visible on the 5x5x5 but not on the 4x4x4.
> Also, at a certain point adding more pieces does not make it harder,
> just longer to solve.
> Other than that, I definitely agree with you.

There's an interesting change there. On the 5-by, there's one parity error you need to know, and it's obvious to detect if you go the 3-by reduction method, but on the 4-by there are three possible parity problems and they don't show themselves until you are almost on top of them in some situations.

--MZRG


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1838. A long LL list.....
From: Andreas Renberg <rubikssites@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 4 Apr 2005 14:44:28 -0700 (PDT)

I am currently writing a long list of all the different algs for all the PLL and OLL.

Using that list, people can try several of the algs and choose the alg wich they consider to be the easiest they personally feel.

I am writing 2 seperate lists; one that only uses the basic notation ( F L' U2 F B etc.) and another one that uses speedcuber notations ( x' F2 r [L B2] x' r' [U2 L2] d etc. )

If anyone has any algs they would like to contribute, or any websites that have several algs listed on them, send me feedback at:

rubikssites@...
or post the messages on my Yahoo Group RubiksSites
http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/rubikssites/

Do not reply to this group, because I do not recive messages to my email account on a few of these groups...

Note; All websites and submitters will recive credit for the algs


Thank You,
IQ Andreas

PS. Dont try out the website yet, i have hardly started building on it

Do you Yahoo!?
Make Yahoo! your home page

1841. Re: Number of possibilities?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 22:00:17 -0000

Sorry about my previous messages, I screwed up all the math in each post. That's awesome that you're learning ZBF2L, I hope more people will get interested and start learning it. So far I know that Lars and I are working very hard on it, and that Ron and Zbigniew have worked on it a lot too. It seems a lot of people do this intuitively, and I have no idea whether it is better to learn the computer optimized cases first and then try to understand them, or just do it intuitively from the start. I can say that there are lots of patterns that come up a lot in the ZBF2L algs, and those patterns are easy to understand. You can tell that most of the algs trasform the case you have into one of those new patterns and then solves from there. Anyway good luck with ZBF2L, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Well recently I'v started learning the zb f2l, and I know all the > cases where you already have the corner edge pair already paired up > and I know a few others but when I do these cases I orient the last > layer by finishing the f2l a lot more often than when I just used > fridrich f2l. I'd estimate using the zb f2l I skip the OLL about 1/50 > solves, I do it on a daily basis now, it used to be a rare thing for > me when I was doing fridrich f2l. > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <rubikscubewhiz@y...> wrote: > > > > I was wondering if anyone knew the number of possible situations there > > are for solving the last F2L pair and orienting the ENTIRE last layer > > simultaneously. 1843. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Interesting paradox
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 18:02:55 -0400


Hey!

Well then im one of those weird cubers :D I do centers last on the
4x4x4 and 5x5x5. And as u can see from the unofficial world records
im quite fast with it too ;-) The benefit of doing centers last (for
me anyway) is that the rest of the solve speeds up. Doing the
centers on the last 5 faces last is a bit slower than doing centers
first. But at least by now the rest of the cube is solves and u have
easier recognition. Easy recognition is the way to success on the
larger cubes. many (including me) find that pairing up is too
awkward since ur only ppoint of reference is one (or two) other edge
(s) only. The pairing up stage is what most ppl struggle to speed
up. I know of good cubers who spend more time on the pairing-up
stage than on one of my complete solves. So the normal 3x3x3
reduction "regime" is not the salvation for everyone :-)

I would call my method the cage method. It's somewhat similar to
columns first method.

First layer (top)
Middle layers edges (hold solved layer to the left)
Last layer corners then edges (and parity)
Final centers

Happy cubing !!

-Per




I'm still learning to do the 4-by and 5-by cubes (takes me five minutes for the 5-by using the reduction thing) and I'd really like to learn your method, as I think it might help me - especially when I'm doing patterns, where often I have to move some centers around. What kind of algorithms do you use for the centers?

--MZRG


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1844. Practice Tool
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Apr 2005 23:53:47 -0000


Hey folks,

My brother Jason wrote an applet to help me learn my OLL algs. This
program helps you associate a given state (picture) of the cube with a
given algorithm and can be used for PLL, ZBF2l, etc. Here's the
website:

http://www.jaywinyeah.com/rubikscube

It takes a few minutes to set up but check it out if you're interested
and let me know what you think!

Ian

PS The program crashes once in a while for some unknown reason. If
he knows people are using it, Jason might be motivated to try to fix
the bug.





1845. 'official' timing device will cost more then expected.
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 02:37:17 -0000


It looks like the original quote of $50 for the 'official' timing pad
will retail for closer to twice that:

"...it turns out that in order to sell these timers on
rubiks.com, there are other parties that need to take a share in the
price. This includes a royalty to SevenTowns for using the Rubik's
trademark name, and a royalty to the people who run the rubiks.com
website. These two royalties will account for a significant portion of
the list price, so it looks like the final sale price of the timer
will be closer to $100 than to $50..."

http://home.comcast.net/~epj69/timer/journal.htm

I may think twice about buying the pad now, but I guess I won't know
for sure until the thing is for sale on Rubiks.com

:(

-Chris

Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It looks like the original quote of $50 for the 'official' timing pad > will retail for closer to twice that: > > "...it turns out that in order to sell these timers on > rubiks.com, there are other parties that need to take a share in the > price. This includes a royalty to SevenTowns for using the Rubik's > trademark name, and a royalty to the people who run the rubiks.com > website. These two royalties will account for a significant portion of > the list price, so it looks like the final sale price of the timer > will be closer to $100 than to $50..." > > http://home.comcast.net/~epj69/timer/journal.htm > > I may think twice about buying the pad now, but I guess I won't know > for sure until the thing is for sale on Rubiks.com > > :( > > -Chris
1847. Re: 'official' timing device will cost more then expected.
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 07:55:41 -0000


> Does anybody know if this timing device is intended for cubes only
> or all puzzles?

It generates scrambles for 3x3 -> 5x5 cubes, but I think that the
light sensors will work with almost any puzzle. The puzzle just needs
to block light when placed back on the pad :)

-Chris





1848. Re: Practice Tool
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>

Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 08:36:20 -0000

But one little advantage could be, that you can choose to enable the algs you already know... I'll keep it, anyway :). Bye, Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> wrote: > > Hey folks, > > My brother Jason wrote an applet to help me learn my OLL algs. This > program helps you associate a given state (picture) of the cube with a > given algorithm and can be used for PLL, ZBF2l, etc. Here's the > website: > > http://www.jaywinyeah.com/rubikscube > > It takes a few minutes to set up but check it out if you're interested > and let me know what you think! > > Ian > > PS The program crashes once in a while for some unknown reason. If > he knows people are using it, Jason might be motivated to try to fix > the bug.

Advertise it from private webpages like speedcubing.com, cubestation.co.uk and so on. It's also possible for u to set up an ebay shop, and organise payment through PayPal. However, just don't give it up yet. It's possible u have already committed urself to those tradenames (a shame). Think of every possible option to sell it cheaper before u give up :-) Kind regards, Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It looks like the original quote of $50 for the 'official' timing pad > will retail for closer to twice that: > > "...it turns out that in order to sell these timers on > rubiks.com, there are other parties that need to take a share in the > price. 1853. L2L algorithms for step 1 - corner orientation
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 14:25:16 +0100

Just a quick update. Spent the last week learning these 26 algorithms and now have them. As I already know and use the edge orientation algorithms I only have 17 more to learn to do the whole L2L4 strategy. I am averaging around 55 moves with what I already know. Not too fast yet - around 40 seconds average. Its really great not having to do the OLL step though! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, April 05, 2005 2:02 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 'official' timing device will cost more then expected. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > It looks like the original quote of $50 for the 'official' timing > pad > > > Actually the original price hope was $80, not $50. Click on the link > "concept proposal document" right behind the "$50" and you'll land > here: > http://home.comcast.net/~epj69/timer/timer_concept.pdf > > Last page, section 3.1.3 says $80. Where does the $50 come from? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
1854. Solving Layer 1
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 14:35:44 +0100

I've spent some time on ways of solving layer 1 - which is step 1 of the L2L
strategies.

My favourite method of the moment is to put in one edge piece and then add
in layer 1 corner-edge pairs (average ~moves each) until I have a 3x2x1
rectangle on the top layer - this takes 10 moves in total. Then either put
in one more corner-ege pair and a corner separate or try to build the final
edge and two corners and put in. Either way theoretically its still 18-19
moves.

The annoying thing is that going slow in practice I can usually do the 15-16
moves.

Using just corner and edge orientation steps of the L2L strategies the 3x2x1
block approach is great. 10 moves plus 2 for the last edge. Then use
Fridrich pairs to finish the last two corners with two middel edges - total
so far 12+7+7 = 26. Then use the two L2L steps and PLL to finish. Its
coming out at 55 in practice - I think 55-56 in theory.

Looking through posts yesterday I saw mention of a 3x2x1 block method (maybe
Gilles method?). I'll look it up to see if it helps but if anyone has any
helpful suggestions I'd love to hear.

Duncan




1855. New member
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 13:53:04 -0000


G'day fellow cubers, I'm Keith, a new member from Australia. I'm 36
and I've been into cubing since around August '04. I was in high
school during the big cube craze in the early eighties but I could
only do the first 2 layers back then.

When I left school I bought a solution book and learnt to do the LL.
I always kept a cube handy and would solve it occasionally just to
keep in my mind how to do it. I often wondered if (and hoped) the
cube would make a comeback.

One day at the local library on the internet I thought I'd do a
search for rubiks cubes, not really expecting to find much and to my
surprise there was a lot more than I anticipated, and the rest as
they say, is history!


I'm currently using the usual F2L and 3 look LL, I have learnt some
OLL algs but there's still for me a lot to learn yet. At the moment
my times are in the 40/50 sec range though I have managed some low
30's and two in the 20's, a 29- and 28.84 or something.


Keith.







1856. Re: [Speed cubing group] New member
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 15:03:19 +0100

Hi Keith, welcome to the group!

You have some great times already, keep up the good work, you will always find plenty of help and friendly faces here :) I found this group and all the websites in pretty much exactly the same fashion as you.

Good Luck with your cubing,

Dan Harris :) - www.cubestation.co.uk

1860. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: "Carlos Angosto" <rubikaz@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 16:47:14 +0200 (Hora est���ndar romance)

Jessica Fridrich use this notation (for example in this page http://www.ws
binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/orient.html ):



Us = UD'



Ua = Da = UD



U'a = D'a= U'D'



...........







Carlos......



-------Mensaje original-------



De: Bob Burton

Fecha: 04/05/05 16:42:51

moves?

Thanks,

Bob

1863. question about COLL alg
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 19:15:49 -0000


Hey everyone,

I have a question about a particular COLL case for those who use it.
Does anyone have a fast alg for this case, or a fast trigger for one
of these two algs?

1) BL'U2LB'L'BU2B'L
2) R'DR2DL2D'R2DL2D2R

Both algs are the solving algorithm for the same COLL case, so do the
inverse to set it up.

I currently use the first alg and I do it like this to average 3-3.5
seconds each execution.

(B) y2 (R' U2 R) y L' F' (L U2 L') (F)

This is probably my slowest COLL case, or at least one of my slowest.

If anyone has any tips for this case it would be very much appreciated :-)

Chris





1864. Re: question about COLL alg
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 19:22:00 -0000

I just found this trick which seems to go fast as well, maybe this is also an option for making that case faster. Alg) BL'U2LB'L'BU2B'L Alg with trick) (B) (L' U2) x' [(L U') (L' U)] y' R2 (U') (F) do the (U') and (F) with your left and right index fingers respectively. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I have a question about a particular COLL case for those who use it. > Does anyone have a fast alg for this case, or a fast trigger for one > of these two algs? > > 1) BL'U2LB'L'BU2B'L > 2) R'DR2DL2D'R2DL2D2R > > Both algs are the solving algorithm for the same COLL case, so do the > inverse to set it up. > > I currently use the first alg and I do it like this to average 3-3.5 > seconds each execution. > > (B) y2 (R' U2 R) y L' F' (L U2 L') (F) > > This is probably my slowest COLL case, or at least one of my slowest. > > If anyone has any tips for this case it would be very much appreciated :-) > > Chris

simple timing device, in my opinion they only look like there worth
about $5 or $10, is there somthing complex about them that makes them
coast so much. Whats the deal?





1867. 5x5
From: "Gautam Kandlikar" <bewareofgautam@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 21:47:36 -0000


Hello everyone,

The 3x3 has become 'cool' at my school again. Almost everyone has one
of them these a days, and one isn't really 'hot' if he/she can solve
it. Being a highly regarded cubist at school, although I average only
about 55 secs, I want to pwn the 5x5s, which I have played with the
5x5 before. I was almost able to get it in the 3x3 form (and later
trying to solve it). However, the cube wasn't mine, and my friend
messed the whole thing up.

Hence, I want to buy a 5x5 and be able to solve it peacefully,
without any disruption. Now, as I haven't much knowledge about them,
I want someone to help with buying one of them. I have come across 3
kinds:

A Tiled "Limited Edition Professor Cube" on Mefferts -
http://sites.webec.com.hk/meffert/index.cfm?
fuseaction=detail&id=74322&product=123

A Tiled, Regular Professor Cube also on Mefferts -
http://sites.webec.com.hk/meffert/index.cfm?
fuseaction=detail&id=74322&product=10

A Stickered Regular Professor Cube on Rubiks.com -
https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm?
lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=clasic&lvl4=cubprf

A DIY East Sheen cube - http://www.eastsheen.com.tw/a5.htm

These are all the various 5x5s i could find on the net. Which one is
best among these? Are there any others out there that are better? Are
tiled ones better than stickered ones? I know that stickers may peel
off, but are replacement tiles available anywhere?

I know these are too many questions, but I will be glad if you can
answer my questions and help me in purchasing a 5x5.

Thanks,

Gautam







1868. Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 14:55:37 -0700

It's the accuracy of the stackmat that makes it so expensive. It's not
just a button that stops the timer. It operates by using capacitance
so that it can be very accurate.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Apr 5, 2005, at 2:07 PM, metgorubiks wrote:

> about $5 or $10, is there somthing complex about them that makes them
> coast so much. Whats the deal?
>
>
>
>
>

> Yahoo! Groups Links

>
>

1869. Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Apr 2005 17:59:11 -0400

The name my friend the name. Any time you put a name on something, the cost increases by a factor of at leats three. Look at the new cube timer, just because the names have to appear on it, doubled the cost.
----- Original Message -----
From: metgorubiks

about $5 or $10, is there somthing complex about them that makes them

1871. Re: Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Apr 2005 23:39:56 -0000

It is the official timing device for cup stacking, so if you would be at a serious cupstacking disadvantage if you didn't have one to practice with. hence, it is crucial to cupstackers to buy stackmats rather than using other timing devices. this certainly adds to the cost of the product. ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I was wondering why do stackmat timers coast so much, they are just a > simple timing device, in my opinion they only look like there worth > about $5 or $10, is there somthing complex about them that makes them > coast so much. Whats the deal?

things about the Eastsheen.

Bob





1875. New videos / stickers

1877. Sub-19!!!
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Apr 2005 09:52:57 -0000


I finally broke 19 seconds on average. [18.76 seconds]

If I can do this, anyone can! It took me a year to get from ~20
seconds to break 19...at this rate I will contend with all you sub
15.5 cubers in a few years!! lol

Happy Cubing Everyone!

-Richard





1878. Re: Sub-19!!!
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Apr 2005 10:12:37 -0000

Nice! And be optimistic, you may become much faster in the next months without any good reason :-) By the way, is there a record for the number of consecutive sub-20 solves? Mine is now 56. I think it's a good measure of consistency and endurance. People who did cube marathons should be good at this. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > I finally broke 19 seconds on average. [18.76 seconds] > > If I can do this, anyone can! 1880. Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Apr 2005 10:47:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > The name my friend the name. Any time you put a name on something, the cost increases by a factor of at leats three. Look at the new cube timer, just because the names have to appear on it, doubled the cost. How is 100/80 = 2 ? Cheers! Stefan

1886. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5
From: Dennis Webb <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 6 Apr 2005 10:08:16 -0500

My Rubiks.com 5x5 was very stiff when I first got it. My thumbs hurt
after playing with it for a while. After about 24 hours of use
though, it is quite loose. The outside RUFBUD faces are harder to
turn than the rufbud faces though. I also have lubed it and it has
helped a lot.

I just recently saw 5x5's at Barnes and Noble for sale for $30. If
your like me, you would rather get one on the spot than wait on mail
order.


1887. Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Perhaps this is the way mathematics now works, now that we've realized our folly and recognize that 2 is, indeed, greater than 3. ; ) LOL :-) Someone with a good memory, eh? 1888. Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 6 Apr 2005 13:17:24 -0500

Actually, I started learning recently from your site. I haven't worked on it very much, so I can't solve a whole cube yet. I've been so busy learning different methods I've been neglecting to fulfill any of my plans for blindsolving. On the upside, though, I've managed to get sub 50 averages with 4 separate methods. I learned a layer by layer solution, originally. I can average slightly sub 30 with my 4 look LL. A month ago I switched to the Roux method, with which I'm averaging around 35. I got my best time with that, a 22.86. I recently developed a corners first method that I'm using to teach friends how to solve the cube. It's pretty simple and averages between 75 and 85 moves, but it works. Yesterday I decided to learn the Petrus method. I like the approach, and with it I managed to average under 45 after only an hour of practice. Anywho, I hope to have more time to work on blindsolving tonight. Any extra advice will still be welcome, though. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan Pochmann<mailto:pochmann@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 06, 2005 11:38 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Why do stackmat timers coast so much? LOL :-) Someone with a good memory, eh? Tried blindsolving yet? Cheers! Stefan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a..
