1891. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Apr 2005 23:18:27 -0400

I'd like to ask all you guys what is a good way to think of x, y, z as. I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and the other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but since none of you use that...

I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If you accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? What would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look like? What do you use for {X X X X}?

How do you keep track of it all?


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1892. Blindfold solve
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 04:22:55 -0000


I have been wanting to try a blindfold solve for a while, but just
never really thought I could memorize the state of the cube. I proved
myself wrong, but I still failed in solving. Close only counts in
horse shoes and hand grenades, as they say. :\

Anybody who would like to read about my first blindsolve attempt can
find it here:

http://www.cubewhiz.com/blind1.html

:)
~Bob





1893. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 08:14:57 -0000

I'm unusual, i prefer to write [r][u'][f2] for cube rotations, and it's simply the face turned that many times, witht he whole cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I'd like to ask all you guys what is a good way to think of x, y, z as. I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and the other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but since none of you use that... > > I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If you accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? What would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look like? What do you use for {X X X X}? > > How do you keep track of it all? > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1894. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: "Leyan Lo" <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 08:42:16 -0000

so you first think of your xyz axes. x points to the right, y points up, z points at you. now to perform x, y, or z, you just rotate the cube about that axis. let's take for example x (which points to the right). what i do to keep from getting confused is to hold the R face with my right hand. then i rotate the cube in the direction of my thumb (clockwise). i should end up with the D face facing me after this move. likewise with the y (grab the U face with the right hand) or z (grab the F face with the right hand) moves. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I'd like to ask all you guys what is a good way to think of x, y, z as. I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and the other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but since none of you use that... > > I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If you accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? What would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look like? What do you use for {X X X X}? > > How do you keep track of it all? > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1895. Re: Notation shortcut?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 09:25:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@y...> wrote: > I'm unusual, i prefer to write [r][u'][f2] for cube rotations, and > it's simply the face turned that many times, witht he whole cube. Nice -- someone here who uses a transparent notation! :) Some of us use Rc Uc' Fc2 for these same rotations. For M, E and S, I prefer Lm (or Rm'), Dm and Fm. Probably there are others who do the same. For the 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 notations, I use the "standard" ones, even though that forces you to write things like (R r) for a move that is easier to do than r alone -- and the symbol r has a totally different meaning here from the 2-layer move on the 3x3x3. However, if you don't mind numerical subscripts (and they *are* inconvenient for typing), one possibility would be to use R_n for a turn of the rightmost n+1 layers and r_n for a turn of the n-th slice alone (i.e., the (n+1)-th layer) counted from the right. Or some other, similar counting convention. It's not a very serious suggestion ;) Mike
1896. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 09:26:47 -0000

Hey!!! Seriously, x y z notation is really confusing. This has been discussed many times before. Ppl have different notions about what they are supposed to mean. So it does indeed create confusion. For the official meaning of x y z check this link : http://www.speedcubing.com/moves.html I prefer personally to use Rc = x, Lc = x', Uc = y, Dc = y', Fc = z, Bc = z' This is because everyone already knows the basic faceturns. For a halfturn of the cube use either R2c or (better) (Rc)2 ... and so on ... Cheers!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Leyan Lo" <leyanlo@h...> wrote: > > so you first think of your xyz axes. x points to the right, y points > up, z points at you. now to perform x, y, or z, you just rotate the > cube about that axis. let's take for example x (which points to the > right). what i do to keep from getting confused is to hold the R > face with my right hand. then i rotate the cube in the direction of > my thumb (clockwise). i should end up with the D face facing me > after this move. likewise with the y (grab the U face with the right > hand) or z (grab the F face with the right hand) moves. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs > Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > I'd like to ask all you guys what is a good way to think of x, y, z > as. I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and the > other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many > explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but since > none of you use that... > > > > I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on > higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What > symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If you > accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you > accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? What > would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look like? > What do you use for {X X X X}? > > > > How do you keep track of it all? > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1897. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubers documentary (OS vs NS)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

1898. Re: Blindfold solve
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 12:10:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Anybody who would like to read about my first blindsolve attempt can > find it here: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/blind1.html Hehe, I like the stories you made up for memorizing :-) I think it's good that you have many persons as objects. I have too much food and other non-living items. I'm in the process of expanding my collection of objects, so that for each color pair I have two possible encodings, one living person and one dead object. I already memorize in pairs, and when I have to memorize a tomato and an orange it's hard to remember which one came first. I try to make the first one active, so for example a giant killer tomato squeezes the orange flat. But if I encode RG with a person instead of tomato, then it's much easier. The person always comes first, doing something with the second (dead) object. Good luck for your next attempts! Cheers! Stefan
1899. 4x4x4 Packaging
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 19:05:27 -0000


I just bought a 4x4x4 cube and i was looking at the packaging. One of
the pictures shows the cube as if it were one move away, but with a
little know you would know that that is not true. Did Rubiks do this to
trick unsispecting people like begginers, or do they not know about it?





1900. Re: Notation shortcut?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>

I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and > the > > other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many > > explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but > since > > none of you use that... > > > > > > I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on > > higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What > > symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If > you > > accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you > > accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? > What > > would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look > like? > > What do you use for {X X X X}? > > > > > > How do you keep track of it all? > > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1901. A bit of algorithm help
From: "mstk430" <mstksg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:03:23 -0000


Does anybody have any algorithms that can help me in this situation?
I've managed to come up with my own, but these I can't figure out.

1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces
opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations.
2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL,
preserving corners' orientations.





1902. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:29:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> wrote: > 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces > opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations. http://speedcubing.com/peter/images/pos79.gif (L'RUR'U'(RM'))(R'URU') > 2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, > preserving corners' orientations. http://speedcubing.com/peter/images/pos30.gif (MU)(RUR'U')(M²U)(RU'(MR')) -Chris
1903. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: "mstk430" <mstksg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:34:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> > wrote: > > 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces > > opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations. > > http://speedcubing.com/peter/images/pos79.gif > (L'RUR'U'(RM'))(R'URU') > > > 2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, > > preserving corners' orientations. > > http://speedcubing.com/peter/images/pos30.gif > (MU)(RUR'U')(M²U)(RU'(MR')) > > -Chris Thanks :D Although I don't undersatnd some of your notation. What is "M"?
1904. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:36:02 -0000


> 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces
> opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations.

I assume you are referring to an H pattern? (orients UF and UB)
How about this: (R U R' U' r) (R' U) (R U' r')

> 2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL,
> preserving corners' orientations.

I assume you are referring to an X pattern? (orients all four edges)
I use this: (r' R U) (R U R' U') (r2 R2' U) (R U' r')

Hope this helps,
Bob





1905. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:38:11 -0000


> Thanks :D
>
> Although I don't undersatnd some of your notation. What is "M"?


Before M:
http://www.cubewhiz.com/images/notation/base.gif

After M:
http://www.cubewhiz.com/images/notation/m.gif





1906. Re: Notation shortcut?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:39:11 -0000

- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hmm... That link is even more confusing than x, y, z notation :). > But I agree with you, x y z is a little confusing indeed. I still get confused with x, y, and z from time to time. :\
1907. Re: [Speed cubing group] A bit of algorithm help
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 15:42:23 -0500

----- Original Message ----- From: mstk430<mailto:mstksg@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 3:03 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] A bit of algorithm help 'Does anybody have any algorithms that can help me in this situation? I've managed to come up with my own, but these I can't figure out. 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations.' I don't know any nice fast ones, but this is what I use. It had the added bonus of not shuffling anything around, just fixing the two pieces' orientations. (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M' U M') U2 '2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, preserving corners' orientations.' To orient 2 of them UF and UR) as is, and not shuffle anything: (M U M') U2 (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M2) Or, to orient 2 of them (UF and UR) while 3 cycling edges clockwise (UR->UF, UF->UL, UL->UR) (M U M') U2 (M U M) [possible U] Perform that last one twice and the corners stay put, but your edges are oriented and have gone through the z permutation (UL<->UF and UB<->UR). I hope this helps. 'What is "M"?' M is when you turn the slice in between L and R what would be clockwise for the L face. In other words, it's like turning l and then turning L' (or r' followed by R like I do). Good luck. Happy cubing, -Mike Bennett [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1908. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation shortcut?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 14:13:21 -0700

I personaly like the idea of using somehthing along the lines of C followed by the face, so you turn the entire cube as if you were turning that face. so CR and CL' would be the same for example and CR would be the equivilent of x etc. just my opinion -E On Apr 7, 2005 1:39 PM, Bob Burton <bob@cubewhiz.com> wrote: > > - In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > Hmm... That link is even more confusing than x, y, z notation :). > > But I agree with you, x y z is a little confusing indeed. > > I still get confused with x, y, and z from time to time. :\ > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! 1909. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation shortcut?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 16:16:39 -0500

----- Original Message ----- From: Evan Gates<mailto:evan.gates@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 4:13 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Notation shortcut? I personaly like the idea of using somehthing along the lines of C followed by the face, so you turn the entire cube as if you were turning that face. I'll second that. It's simple, easy to understand, and best of all, it makes sense. -Mike Bennett [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1910. Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 21:31:06 -0000


Hey everyone,

I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different things.

Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations since
it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube rotation
and once learned is easy to understand.

The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making the
basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for
x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same.

Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know that it
lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you have
to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the notation
so that both line up with LDF?

This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could
learn the basis LDF and know how both work.

Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the
speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the bases of
these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer
people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it would
take long to relearn.

Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you
need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment.

I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as long
as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no problem.

I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my
site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as
the LDF basis for MES.

Chris





1911. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 21:37:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g.. .> > wrote: > > 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces > > opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations. > > http://speedcubing.com/peter/images/pos79.gif > (L'RUR'U'(RM'))(R'URU') I used to use this alg but now I'm switching. I liked the alg in itself, but I can't fit it nicely into the solve. Actually I executed it more like this: x (L' l U R' U' r) (R' U R U') x' So I started with x and ended with x'. I love what's between them but those cube rotations suck. Can you do it without? Cheers! Stefan

1913. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 21:45:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as > the LDF basis for MES. I can live with MESxyz and use it myself, but yeah, the two different bases have been bugging me. But why oh why, do you want LDF and not RUF? ;-) For 3x3 two-handed I'm righthanded, thus RUF are my "main" faces to turn. We could also use "mes" instead of "xyz" :-) But I don't mind how things are or how things might change, so don't take this too serious... Cheers! Stefan
1914. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 17:03:52 -0500

I'm going to have to agree with Stefan on this one. There should be a unified standard for notation. However, I think RUF make more sense as a basis for notation, not necessarily because of the majority of right handedness, but because R, U, and F are all visible faces. Not only does that help with learning for beginners, but with visualisation. LDF is a good standard, but I feel that the visibility and proximity of the RUF faces gives them more merit as a standard to notate against.

-Mike Bennett

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1915. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 22:06:48 -0000


I don't like the x,y,z notation because it is confusee me when I
first started cubing. A y rotation is a horizontal rotaion, and x in
a virtical rotation, well this confused me because in mathamatics x is
horizontal and y is vertical.





1916. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "Leyan Lo" <leyanlo@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 15:15:44 -0700

a y rotation is a rotation about the vertical axis. an x rotation is a rotation about the horizontal axis. at least that's how i explained it to myself when i first learned the notation. perhaps better explanations are in order as well? ----- Original Message ----- From: "metgorubiks" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 3:06 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ?? > > I don't like the x,y,z notation because it is confusee me when I > first started cubing. 1917. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 15:19:52 -0700

If we use a notation that uses a letter to denominate a certain type of move, such as C for cube, w is used for two layers, etc. then that is the only thing which must be defined. so say we made M followed by a face mean the layer next to that face turned as if you were turning that face. So ML is the same as the M we use now, which is the same as MR', and MD is the same as the E we use now, which is the same as MU'. I know that it adds up to more letters, but I believe that it is easier to understand. Likewise, if C were for a cube rotation, CU would be the same as y and etc. I know I just said pretty much the same thing in another thread, but it seems to fit here better. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Apr 7, 2005 3:06 PM, metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > I don't like the x,y,z notation because it is confusee me when I > first started cubing. A y rotation is a horizontal rotaion, and x in > a virtical rotation, well this confused me because in mathamatics x is > horizontal and y is vertical. > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
1918. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 22:24:41 -0000

I absolutely don't prefer either LDF or RUF to the other, I just think we should use only one of them. I also agree that RUF is much more visible than LDF and if it would help for learning then I think the standard should be RUF for both bases. So I am also in agreement, the standard should be RUF. If we can get the notation page on speedcubing.com changed to this, then I will also change the notation on my pages to reflect this. 1919. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Apr 2005 23:08:17 -0000

Personally, I agree with some things that have been said, namely relating everything back to the 6 fundamental letters, RUFBDL. Although different solutions have different needs. For example, having a definition of M makes a lot of sense to me, since i use the Roux Method and lots of Rs rs Ms and Us. I think for cube turns, CR, CR' CR2 makes a lot more sense, and is less counter-intuitive. From a mathematical point of view, it makes less sense, but for a new learner, it is a lot easier. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I absolutely don't prefer either LDF or RUF to the other, I just think > we should use only one of them. > > I also agree that RUF is much more visible than LDF and if it would > help for learning then I think the standard should be RUF for both bases. > > So I am also in agreement, the standard should be RUF. > > If we can get the notation page on speedcubing.com changed to this, > then I will also change the notation on my pages to reflect this. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > I'm going to have to agree with Stefan on this one. 1920. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2 > 3
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Apr 2005 23:22:09 -0400

The one of getting the centers wrong is probably the one you aren't thinking of. I consider that a parity error because, although most good solvers intuitively check for it, it can sometimes rear its ugly head when you start the 3-by F2L (if you go by that method).


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1922. Ryan Heise's method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: "cube" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 20:44:14 -0500

I was just wondering if anyone out there uses Ryan Heise's method for speedcubing, or if anyone uses it, or a similar approach for fewest moves. I started learning it last evening in an effort to better understand commutators and how my cube works. As it turns out, I'm having a bit of trouble during the second step. I can solve all of the edges, but I don't quite understand how to make sure all of the edges are correct while still making sure two of the LL corners are. It leaves me with 4 incorrect corners in several cases, and 5 incorrect corners in most cases. I have difficulty with doing the corners in two steps. If anyone (Ryan included) has any advice to offer, it would be greatly appreciated. Here's hoping.

-Mike Bennett

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1923. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 03:17:15 -0000

I think that it should all be standardized to be based on RUF. It is easy to see and easy to understand. I like M,E,S,x,y,z. I am probably one of few that uses m,e, and s to represent things like (FB') and similar moves, but it is for that reason that I do not agree with making m,e,s the cube rotations. I believe it would be a great idea to come to some sort of standard that is consistent. Consistency should be the main idea. Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different things. > > Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations since > it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube rotation > and once learned is easy to understand. > > The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making the > basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for > x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same. > > Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know that it > lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you have > to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the notation > so that both line up with LDF? > > This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could > learn the basis LDF and know how both work. > > Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the > speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the bases of > these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer > people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it would > take long to relearn. > > Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you > need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment. > > I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as long > as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no problem. > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as > the LDF basis for MES. > > Chris
1924. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 2005 20:24:15 -0700

I think that the main problem with using RUF, is although it is more intuitive I beleive than LDF, what about left handed people? or people who cube left handed, as I believe Chris Hardwick and Lars Petrus do. To them LUF would be more intuitive. I know I stated it before, so I hope I'm not getting annoying with it, but I think that something that states the face that it is refering to, would be much better than having it defined elswhere or assumed. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Apr 7, 2005 8:17 PM, Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > > I think that it should all be standardized to be based on RUF. It > is easy to see and easy to understand. I like M,E,S,x,y,z. I am > probably one of few that uses m,e, and s to represent things like > (FB') and similar moves, but it is for that reason that I do not > agree with making m,e,s the cube rotations. I believe it would be a > great idea to come to some sort of standard that is consistent. > Consistency should be the main idea. > > Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different > things. > > > > Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations > since > > it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube > rotation > > and once learned is easy to understand. > > > > The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making > the > > basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for > > x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same. > > > > Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know > that it > > lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you > have > > to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the > notation > > so that both line up with LDF? > > > > This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could > > learn the basis LDF and know how both work. > > > > Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the > > speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the > bases of > > these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer > > people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it > would > > take long to relearn. > > > > Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you > > need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment. > > > > I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as > long > > as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no > problem. > > > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same > as > > the LDF basis for MES. > > > > Chris > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
1925. Another ZBLL site
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 03:30:07 -0000


Hey everyone,

I just put up the first part to my ZBLL site. So far I only have 19
cases up, but I will be adding more as I learn them. If you are
interested in ZBLL at all check it out.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbll.html

Chris





1926. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 03:56:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > I think that the main problem with using RUF, is although it is more > intuitive I beleive than LDF, what about left handed people? or people > who cube left handed, as I believe Chris Hardwick and Lars Petrus do. In this case, it would probably be better to go with the majority. It isn't like it will actually affect their ability to cube or anything like that. It's just to make things more convenient, isn't it? Most of us know the notation, but I was under the impression we are just trying to make things easier for people in the future. Since 90% of the world is right-handed, it seems more natural to use a right-handed definition. Obviously, it would be silly to use a separate basis for left-handed cubers and give that a separate notation. > I know I stated it before, so I > hope I'm not getting annoying with it, but I think that something that > states the face that it is refering to, would be much better than > having it defined elswhere or assumed. This is also a good way of doing it. I am just used to the current notation. I'm sure if we made that the standard, I would become accustomed to it as if it was what I learned in the first place. :) Bob
1927. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 06:46:18 -0000

I continue to agree with evan, using the letter of a face to represent turns is much more intuitive that renaming it...but, notation also has a lot to do with what metric you solve in, and what twisting style you use. Truly the best thing to have, would just be a definition of people's notation, and a universal converter...then you could take other people's notation, and put it into your own. I would assume this wouldn't be a challenging program to make. ~Joe Spadafora --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates > <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > > I think that the main problem with using RUF, is although it is > more > > intuitive I beleive than LDF, what about left handed people? or > people > > who cube left handed, as I believe Chris Hardwick and Lars Petrus > do. > > In this case, it would probably be better to go with the majority. > It isn't like it will actually affect their ability to cube or > anything like that. It's just to make things more convenient, isn't > it? Most of us know the notation, but I was under the impression we > are just trying to make things easier for people in the future. > Since 90% of the world is right-handed, it seems more natural to use > a right-handed definition. Obviously, it would be silly to use a > separate basis for left-handed cubers and give that a separate > notation. > > > I know I stated it before, so I > > hope I'm not getting annoying with it, but I think that something > that > > states the face that it is refering to, would be much better than > > having it defined elswhere or assumed. > > This is also a good way of doing it. I am just used to the current > notation. I'm sure if we made that the standard, I would become > accustomed to it as if it was what I learned in the first place. :) > > Bob

1929. Re: Ryan Heise's method
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 14:41:55 -0000



Hello!

I use a method similar to Ryan Heise´s for FMC (I use Petrus for
speedcubing). I looked at his method when I started to learn how to
solve in few moves. The first step was easy for me as I was used to
the Petrus-method.

The second step was really hard for me to understand (as Ryan´s site
is still under construction and no explanations are given). One
approach that I use is to build a 2x2x1 block in the U-face thus
leaving you with 3 edges and 4 corners left to solve. Then I solve the
edges and hope that one corner will solve as well. If not I´m left
with a corner 4-cycle that I solve with two 3-cycles. Some times I
just use a LL alg that leaves me with a 3-cycle to finnish with.

I think Ryan explains how to use commuters and conjugates very nicely.
I also learned from his site. And something that really helped me to
faster see how to cycle is a trick often used in FMC. Put little
numbered stickers on the corners that need cycling to better see how
they need to be cycled. For a good explanation check: http://games.
groups.yahoo.com/group/fewestmoveschallenge/message/403

Using that same sticker trick it´s easier to cycle 4 or 5 corners
around. For 4-cycle only 1->2 or 2->3 etc. is needed (in other words
you only have to place on corner in its right position) and for
5-cycles any 3-cycle is good (2->3->4 or 5->1->2 etc.)
And if you happened to get all corners but have edges to cycle there
are similar commutators that work with edges.

I hope I make any sence,
Mikael





1930. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubers documentary (OS vs NS)
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 15:26:02 -0000

I dunno, to me Gosbee was making it look like there is this division in cubing, the OS vs. NS, and that the OS is concentrated more on God's algorithm, while the NS is the devious youth that rips off of the OS just to be apart of the rekindled fad. In all honesty, there really isn't a division at all in this community. Sure we have people who have been cubing in the early 80's but the ultimate goals are still the same. Yes the methods have changed, the alg generation has changed, but we all are focused on becoming faster, and the hunt for gods algorithm is still being searched. I guess thats the glory of film in the editing room. jake --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > i guess I never picked up on this whole "new school" vs. "old > school" > > > feud. > > What exactly is this "feud" all about? I'm intrigued. > > Mike
1931. Re: [Speed cubing group] Notation shortcut?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 16:52:55 -0000

Hello Michael, I keep telling the speedcubers here that x,y,z and MES confuse people but few people seem willing to acknowledge that. I use the same notation on the 3x3x3 as the one commonly accepted for the 4x4x4, that is, lower case letters r, l, f, b, u and d are for slices. To this I add "Q" for cube rotatations, so QR means rotate the entire cube clockwise 90 degrees like you would turn the right side clockwise. Even though most speedcubers will spend incredible amounts of time and energy simplifing every other aspect of cubing, most will not budge on notation - go figure. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I'd like to ask all you guys what is a good way to think of x, y, z as. I know it's whole cube rotations, but just as with E, M, and the other middle thingy I tend to get confused no matter how many explanations I read. I'd love to use my old vX/mX system, but since none of you use that... > > I think we should totally revamp the system for compatibility on higher-order cubes (and, of course, efficiency)... But how? What symbol would you use for turning the right 3 layers of a 5-by? If you accept Us on the 3-by, would you accept it on the 4-by? Would you accept "us"? How about (Uu)s? Is there a symbol for {X Y X' Y'}? What would Megaminx, Skewb, Pyraminx, Alexander's Star notation look like? What do you use for {X X X X}? > > How do you keep track of it all? > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1932. Re: A bit of algorithm help
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 17:12:38 -0000

Hi mstk430, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mstk430" <mstksg@g...> wrote: > > Does anybody have any algorithms that can help me in this situation? > I've managed to come up with my own, but these I can't figure out. These algs leave the edges where they are. > 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces > opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations. Flipping over two edges can be done several ways. I use lower case letters to mean slices only. An easy way for two edges flipped (across) is the old r U r U r D2d2 r U r U r U2. There's a general idea that what you do to one piece you undo to the other: 1. R' d' R2 d2 R' flips over one edge without changing anything on the Last Level. 2. then you put any of the other LL edes where the newly flipped ege is: U U2 OR U' 3. then flip over the second edge by undoing the first part: R d2 R2 d R 4. then put the first edge back in place U' U2 OR U. > 2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, > preserving corners' orientations. r U2 r' U2 r U r' U2 r U2 r' U' I hope that helps. Regards, David J
1933. Re: [Speed cubing group] A bit of algorithm help
From: "mstk430" <mstksg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 17:16:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: mstk430<mailto:mstksg@g...> > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 3:03 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] A bit of algorithm help > > > > 'Does anybody have any algorithms that can help me in this situation? > I've managed to come up with my own, but these I can't figure out. > > 1) LL Algorithm that re-orients two incorrectly oriented edge pieces > opposite eachother on the LL, preserving LL corners' orientations.' > > I don't know any nice fast ones, but this is what I use. It had the added bonus of not shuffling anything around, just fixing the two pieces' orientations. > (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M' U M') U2 > > '2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, > preserving corners' orientations.' > > To orient 2 of them UF and UR) as is, and not shuffle anything: > (M U M') U2 (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M2) > > Or, to orient 2 of them (UF and UR) while 3 cycling edges clockwise (UR->UF, UF->UL, UL->UR) > (M U M') U2 (M U M) [possible U] > Perform that last one twice and the corners stay put, but your edges are oriented and have gone through the z permutation (UL<->UF and UB<->UR). I hope this helps. > > 'What is "M"?' > > M is when you turn the slice in between L and R what would be clockwise for the L face. In other words, it's like turning l and then turning L' (or r' followed by R like I do). Good luck. > > Happy cubing, > -Mike Bennett > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Oh, M is turning the MIDDLE :-p Gotcha. Also, if it's not too much trouble, can I have an algorithm that orients: http://img41.exs.cx/img41/3993/orient5yg.jpg (two corners opposite incorrectly oriented) while -ingoring- corners?

It had > the added bonus of not shuffling anything around, just fixing the two > pieces' orientations. > > (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M' U M') U2 > > > > '2) LL Algorithm that re-orients all of the edge pieces on the LL, > > preserving corners' orientations.' > > > > To orient 2 of them UF and UR) as is, and not shuffle anything: > > (M U M') U2 (M U M U M) U2 (M' U M2) > > > > Or, to orient 2 of them (UF and UR) while 3 cycling edges > clockwise (UR->UF, UF->UL, UL->UR) > > (M U M') U2 (M U M) [possible U] > > Perform that last one twice and the corners stay put, but your > edges are oriented and have gone through the z permutation (UL<->UF > and UB<->UR). I hope this helps. > > > > 'What is "M"?' > > > > M is when you turn the slice in between L and R what would be > clockwise for the L face. In other words, it's like turning l and > then turning L' (or r' followed by R like I do). Good luck. > > > > Happy cubing, > > -Mike Bennett > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] IGNORE MY LAST POST > Oh, M is turning the MIDDLE :-p > Gotcha. > > Also, if it's not too much trouble, can I have an algorithm that orients: http://img41.exs.cx/img41/1039/orient4os.jpg > (two corners opposite incorrectly oriented) > while -ignoring- EDGES?

1939. L2L Step 2
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Apr 2005 20:41:42 +0100

I started learning the 5 position corners algorithms yesterday. They are
much easier to learn than I expected. Also I realised that on my site I
don't show the positions in the easiest to recognise way. Each of the
possible positions is just a swap of a pair of corners. Which means that if
a pair of adjacent corners are correctly placed then its the other two
corners that need swapping. If no two adjacent corners are correctly placed
then its diagonal corners that need swapping. Its so easy to recognise. I
had been messing about trying to recognise 3-cycles of corners which is just
that bit more painful (and time consuming).

I'm discounting the trivial case (corners already correctly positioned) in
the above when you just pass straight through to step 3.

This easy-to-recognise-ness means that my concern about combining steps 2
and 3, namely that the positions would be hard to recognise, will definitely
not be a problem (as someone already pointed out I seem to remember!).

Duncan




1940. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 19:54:39 -0000

Hey Chris.. I really agree with you that M,E,S would make more sense if you define them by the RUF defenition.. But that's also just because I never really learned the M E S moves, because they are so confusing.. I think I would learn them if they were defined by the R U F :). However, it will probably be very hard to standardize this notation, because a lot of people out there are totaly used to M E S moves. Just wanted to let you know, I agree with you.. Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different things. > > Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations since > it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube rotation > and once learned is easy to understand. > > The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making the > basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for > x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same. > > Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know that it > lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you have > to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the notation > so that both line up with LDF? > > This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could > learn the basis LDF and know how both work. > > Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the > speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the bases of > these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer > people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it would > take long to relearn. > > Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you > need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment. > > I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as long > as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no problem. > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as > the LDF basis for MES. > > Chris

1942. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 20:58:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > I think that the main problem with using RUF, is although it is more > intuitive I beleive than LDF, what about left handed people? or people > who cube left handed, as I believe Chris Hardwick and Lars Petrus do. > To them LUF would be more intuitive. I know I stated it before, so I > hope I'm not getting annoying with it, but I think that something that > states the face that it is refering to, would be much better than > having it defined elswhere or assumed. > > -Evan > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk Don't forget me! I'm left-handed not only in cubing, but in about all other activities which concern assimmetry: writing, eating etc. But I one-handed cube better with the right hand. Actually I'm not any better at one-handed cubing that any other cuber, so that probably doesn't count. I'm definitely for R U F. NOt only that 90% right-handed make a clear majority, but I'm accustomed to seeing a cube from the RUF perspective, not LUF. And anyway the three most used faces are in my opinion R U L, so the true argument for R U F is that we see them. Please officialize the notation! Sebastian
1943. [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5

My thumbs hurt > after playing with it for a while. After about 24 hours of use > though, it is quite loose. The outside RUFBUD faces are harder to > turn than the rufbud faces though. I also have lubed it and it has > helped a lot. > > I just recently saw 5x5's at Barnes and Noble for sale for $30. If > your like me, you would rather get one on the spot than wait on mail > order.
1944. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 22:09:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different things. > > Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations since > it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube rotation > and once learned is easy to understand. > > The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making the > basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for > x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same. > > Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know that it > lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you have > to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the notation > so that both line up with LDF? > > This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could > learn the basis LDF and know how both work. > > Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the > speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the bases of > these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer > people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it would > take long to relearn. > > Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you > need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment. > > I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as long > as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no problem. > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as > the LDF basis for MES. > > Chris Hi Chris, It's nice to see that you're willing to change to lessen the confusion, but why not go all the way with it? I have to ask, other than being used to it, why do you want a system which isn't intuitive and requires learning new letters? Even if you switch xyz to mean different axes you still aren't using the coordinates the way they have been used traditionally. I know that trades have historically hidden their knowledge behind lingo, deliberately making things hard to learn for newcomers, but does speedcubing have to be that way? Regards, David J
1945. No Subject
From: souzamusic <souzamusic@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Apr 2005 19:26:37 -0300

The Meffert's Limited Edition Professort Cube for me it's the best..I've got mine about one year ago, and since then, it is with me wherever I go..It's true that it's a lot hard to move in the very beggining, but with some lub it become perfect..but that's just my opinion.. www.mefferts.com The delivery is very fast. I live in Brazil, outside U.S. and it came to me in 10 days..look for yourself! =)) ----- Original Message ----- From: Gautam Kandlikar To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Friday, April 08, 2005 6:57 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5 any more suggestions/recommendations, anyone? again, I want to know which is a good 5x5 cube to buy. I played with the Rubiks.com one a few days ago, and It was stiff.... any better ones out there? and how do I buy an east sheen cube? do they have a website for the transactions? Thanks, Gautam --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Dennis Webb <dhwebb@g...> wrote: > My Rubiks.com 5x5 was very stiff when I first got it. My thumbs hurt > after playing with it for a while. After about 24 hours of use > though, it is quite loose. The outside RUFBUD faces are harder to > turn than the rufbud faces though. I also have lubed it and it has > helped a lot. > > I just recently saw 5x5's at Barnes and Noble for sale for $30. If > your like me, you would rather get one on the spot than wait on mail > order. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yahoo! 1946. My new cube
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 23:49:11 -0000


I just bought a new cube in the kast couple of days. The blue and green
sides are stiffer than the other four sides. I have tried streching the
springs with credit cards with no effect. I need this cube to be up to
speedcubing value in the next month. What else can i try to "break it
in" before i lube it?





1947. Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Apr 2005 23:54:41 -0000

I wouldn't mind learning this new notation, but i have found one problem. There are many websites out there that use these moves. Lets say we change their meaning. How will someone know if the webpage maker is using the old or the new notation unless they have a notations page. But if they don't, how is someone to tell? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I know this is a touchy subject since people prefer different things. > > Personally I greatly prefer M,E,S,x,y,z to all other notations since > it is one letter that stands for either a face turn or cube rotation > and once learned is easy to understand. > > The catch is the "once learned." What I want to propose is making the > basis for M,E,S turns, namely the LDF definition, and the basis for > x,y,z, turns, namely the RUF definition the same. > > Right now, to know the direction of MES turns you have to know that it > lines up with LDF and to know the direction of xyz rotations you have > to know that they line up with RUF. Why don't we change the notation > so that both line up with LDF? > > This would make it easier to learn MESxyz notation since you could > learn the basis LDF and know how both work. > > Of course it seems that all of us MESxyz supporters go by the > speedcubing.com definitions of moves. I propose changing the bases of > these moves to be the same. This would make it easier for newer > people to learn and for us people already used to it, I doubt it would > take long to relearn. > > Obviously if you don't support MESxyz notation don't feel that you > need to respond. If you do support this notation please comment. > > I think we will all use our different forms of notation, and as long > as you define it on any site where you use it there should be no problem. > > I greatly prefer MESxyz notation and will continue to use it on my > site, however I would prefer making the RUF basis for xyz the same as > the LDF basis for MES. > > Chris

1950. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>

Date: Fri, 8 Apr 2005 17:05:11 -0700

Hopefully it would be possible to send them emails and get them to change it (yeah right). If that doesn't work then hopefully they have a deffinition on their site (rare). Other than that, you pretty much have to know, or figure it out (eek). So yeah, transitioning wouldn't be easy, then again transition to the metric system, or to euros, etc. probably wasn't easy either (parentheses). I wonder if we will ever come up with something or if it will just stay this way and we will argue over it forever (this is probably one of the hotter threads ever in the group). I'm not too picky what it ends up being (although I do prefer the way that I have stated in previous messages), I would just like a standard. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On Apr 8, 2005 4:54 PM, pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > I wouldn't mind learning this new notation, but i have found one > problem. 1951. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 02:30:02 +0200

Hi Duncan,

As always my interest in the cube is a roller coaster, but at the moment
this interest seems to begin turning upwards again.

I'm still dealing with step 3 and unlike you I'm doing it with the FL
down. I've also tried to do some right hand optimizations and these are
the algs I like best for step 3 at the moment:

UUU - R' U' R' U' R U R U R
UFU - (U) r R' U R U' r' R U R'
UUF - (U) r U' r' U' r R' U R U r'
UFF - (U2) r' U' R' U' R' U R U r
FUU - r U' r' R U2 r R' U' r'
FFU - r' U' R' U' R U R U r
FUF - (U) F U' r U' r' R U R' U F'
FFF - R2 U' f R' F f' R F' U R2

Most of them feels awesome to execute.

Step 1 still feels like the real bottleneck in this but I haven't
practiced it much to be honest (if at all).

When thinking of combining steps 2 and 3 I guess you assume both edges
being the LL right? Having edges out of the LL is of course a problem in
all but step 1 and I wonder how you deal with this. Do you avoid this in
some clever way?

Maybe I could run some calculations with ACube for combining steps 2 and
3 and see what the result is. It is a pretty tedious job to write down
the setup positions though so it might not happen any time soon (if at all).

I'm still very much in love with this method and I think it could be
really awesome if step 1 could be mastered. I hope I pull myself
together and try to learn it more seriously :)

/Gustav Fredell



Duncan Dicks skrev:

>I started learning the 5 position corners algorithms yesterday. They are
>much easier to learn than I expected. Also I realised that on my site I
>don't show the positions in the easiest to recognise way. Each of the
>possible positions is just a swap of a pair of corners. Which means that if
>a pair of adjacent corners are correctly placed then its the other two
>corners that need swapping. If no two adjacent corners are correctly placed
>then its diagonal corners that need swapping. Its so easy to recognise. I
>had been messing about trying to recognise 3-cycles of corners which is just
>that bit more painful (and time consuming).
>
>I'm discounting the trivial case (corners already correctly positioned) in
>the above when you just pass straight through to step 3.
>
>This easy-to-recognise-ness means that my concern about combining steps 2
>and 3, namely that the positions would be hard to recognise, will definitely
>not be a problem (as someone already pointed out I seem to remember!).
>
>Duncan
>
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

1952. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 02:45:17 +0200

Oh... one more thing. How sure are you about that combining steps 2 and
3 gives about 48 cases? Are you taking into considerations the many
combinations the edges can be placed in the middle layer? If not, there
will probably be lots more combinations (thinking ZB). I'm to tired to
do any actual calculations right now but I might look into it more in
the morning.

/Gustav Fredell

1954. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 9 Apr 2005 08:40:04 +0100

Hi Gustav, By combining steps 2 and 3 I mean having a single step where you put in one middle edge but position LL corners and orient LL edges at the same time. So altogether there would only be three middle edge/LL steps. I guess you would do the first middle edge as a Fridrich F2L pair. You lose a whole step (about 10 moves) but have to add back in the gains/losses from doing that Fridrich pair as opposed to doing a corner as part of the first layer. I believe a total improvement of maybe 6 moves. It would be great if we could get together to work out some of the missing algorithms for this. I think it is too hard to try to put two middle edges in at the same time - too many cases for me to learn anyway! Once I sat down and seriously startede to learn Step 1 it was easier than I expected. I learned 3-6 algorithms a day. I go through them in my head when I wake up every morning! I'm thinking of improving the site a bit soon. Good luck. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, April 09, 2005 1:45 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2 > > Oh... one more thing. How sure are you about that combining steps 2 and > 3 gives about 48 cases? Are you taking into considerations the many > combinations the edges can be placed in the middle layer? If not, there > will probably be lots more combinations (thinking ZB). I'm to tired to > do any actual calculations right now but I might look into it more in > the morning. > > /Gustav Fredell > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

1957. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 11:09:07 +0200

Hi Mikael,

The only complete description I know of is on Duncans site:
http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle . The method we are
currently discussing is L2L4 and combining steps 2 and 3 of it. Maybe a
new name Duncan? Duncan's site seems to be invisible to google so it's
not that easy to find :) I'll probably put up information of it on
www.svekub.se (home of the Swedish Cube Association), but I wan't to
learn more algs first.

What I mainly like about this method is the small number of steps, and
the fairly small amount of moves is a bonus too. Not too much algs to
learn, but I'm not too happy wth step 1 being relatively big and
intuitive. But hey... you can't have them all :)

/Gustav Fredell

1959. Re: [Speed cubing group] A bit of algorithm help

1960. Re: My new cube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 09:57:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I just bought a new cube in the kast couple of days. The blue and green > sides are stiffer than the other four sides. I have tried streching the > springs with credit cards with no effect. I need this cube to be up to > speedcubing value in the next month. What else can i try to "break it > in" before i lube it? You could break it in half a few times. Well, a saw might be better. Destroy the cube kernel inside so you can can transfer not only the edges and corners but also the centers to a new kernel with screws. Ok, I'm not that serious, but I am indeed thinking of trying it. I might use a cheap clone cube to steal the kernel (and its screws/springs) from... Hey Chris, I had a closer look at the rivets that came with the DIY. It's built so that it's probably impossible to pull them out but it's possible to push them in (what a surprise, how would they get it in in the first place otherwise?) so if your cube is too loose you should indeed be able to tighten them by pushing the rivets in deeper. Cheers! Stefan
1961. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 9 Apr 2005 12:00:18 +0100

Hi Mikael, L2L (Last 2 Layers) is a strategy I developed last year. Gustav and others have helped with producing the algorithms needed to make it work but none of us have learned all of them well enough to speedcube with it yet (not that there are many - we just don't have that much time!). I think my site is the only one (see Gustav's link). I haven't registered it with any search engines but after some success registering another site I will get round to it eventually! Gustav - I had thought of calling it L2L compact or something like. Open to any suggestions for a cool name though! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, April 09, 2005 10:09 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2 > > Hi Mikael, > > The only complete description I know of is on Duncans site: > http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle . The method we are > currently discussing is L2L4 and combining steps 2 and 3 of it. Maybe a > new name Duncan? Duncan's site seems to be invisible to google so it's > not that easy to find :) I'll probably put up information of it on > www.svekub.se (home of the Swedish Cube Association), but I wan't to > learn more algs first. > > What I mainly like about this method is the small number of steps, and > the fairly small amount of moves is a bonus too. Not too much algs to > learn, but I'm not too happy wth step 1 being relatively big and > intuitive. But hey... you can't have them all :) > > /Gustav Fredell > > Mikael skrev: > > >Hello! > > > >Iï¿½ve seen L2L mentioned a few times but this thread has made me > >interested in what itï¿½s all about. 1962. [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 11:40:33 -0000

Hey! IMHO the Rubiks.com 5x5x5 are the best. Particularly if ur style is more wrist action than fingertricks. If ur style is mostly fingertricks and outer slice turns mostly i guess the eastsheen is maybe better. But !!! It takes a few months to break in a Rubiks.com 5x5x5. So don't give up just because it's really stiff initially. It could be a dream cube if u are patient with it (and expose ur wrists to some pain while breaking it in ;-) ). Also i think the eastsheens are much more prone to popping when they become too loose ... On the other hand the cubies on easteheens never break. On Rubiks.com once a while a centercubie might snap. But it's not too difficult to glue with superglue either ... Some say the mefferts cubes are better cause the tension is adjustable. On Rubiks.com the middle centers are attaced to the core with rivets, not screws like on the mefferts ones. But those cubes on the other hand are tiled. So if u don't like the tiles or the colorscheme used u have quite a job ... *sigh* It's truelly not too easy to decide. Try all of them ... lol :D -Per --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gautam Kandlikar" <bewareofgautam@y...> wrote: > > any more suggestions/recommendations, anyone? > > again, I want to know which is a good 5x5 cube to buy. I played with > the Rubiks.com one a few days ago, and It was stiff.... any better > ones out there? > > and how do I buy an east sheen cube? do they have a website for the > transactions? > > Thanks, > > Gautam > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Dennis Webb > <dhwebb@g...> wrote: > > My Rubiks.com 5x5 was very stiff when I first got it. My thumbs hurt > > after playing with it for a while. After about 24 hours of use > > though, it is quite loose. The outside RUFBUD faces are harder to > > turn than the rufbud faces though. I also have lubed it and it has > > helped a lot. > > > > I just recently saw 5x5's at Barnes and Noble for sale for $30. If > > your like me, you would rather get one on the spot than wait on mail > > order.
1963. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 14:29:02 +0200

I don't know about the name yet. L2L4 sounds a bit technical and not
very fun. And adding compact doesn't make it much better :) I'll think
about it.

Doing the setups for the combining steps 2 and 3 were not at all as
tedious as I first imagined. I simply combined my previous setups into
48 new lines and it was made in less than 10 minutes. Calculating it all
took about half an hour (poor computer is all hot now).

If I've done it all correctly, the average number of moves is (in
HTM)... *drumroll* : ~11.04

So it means cutting moves about 8.5 moves in average. But then of course
some moves will be added for the extended first layer. Total moves for
L2L4 compact is then about 30 + "number of moves to complete first layer
+ 1 edge".

/Gustav Fredell

1966. [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 13:24:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Some say the mefferts cubes are better cause the tension is > adjustable. On Rubiks.com the middle centers are attaced to the core > with rivets, not screws like on the mefferts ones. But those cubes > on the other hand are tiled. So if u don't like the tiles or the > colorscheme used u have quite a job ... *sigh* Aren't tiles an advantage because you can look around edges? And aren't they a lot more beautiful, too? And to switch to the normal Rubik colorscheme you only need to swap two adjacent colors, that is only 15 tiles (actually only 13 because you can swap the center caps when you open the centers for adjusting the screws). I think I can do that faster than you can wear in your Rubik 5x5 (what did you say? months? ;-). http://stefan-pochmann. de/spocc/other_stuff/4x4_5x5_algs/#ColorSchemeModifiers Cheers! Stefan

1970. [Speed cubing group] Re: Shall we standardize M,E,S,x,y,z ??
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 19:41:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > Hopefully it would be possible to send them emails and get them to > change it (yeah right). If that doesn't work then hopefully they have > a deffinition on their site (rare). Other than that, you pretty much > have to know, or figure it out (eek). So yeah, transitioning wouldn't > be easy, then again transition to the metric system, or to euros, etc. > probably wasn't easy either (parentheses). I wonder if we will ever > come up with something or if it will just stay this way and we will > argue over it forever (this is probably one of the hotter threads ever > in the group). > > I'm not too picky what it ends up being (although I do prefer the way > that I have stated in previous messages), I would just like a > standard. > > -Evan > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk Then we could just have everybody who uses notation on their site have at least a link to a thorough and correct notation page, even if it's no theirs. Or even have an official notations page by WCA. We would know that a site uses the correct notation when it has the WCA logo on it. It's not that hard, come on! Sebastian
1971. 4x4x4 Algs-moving center facelets
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 20:47:00 -0000


Hi there

I am looking for a few good algs to shuffle center cubies on a 4x4x4 cube.

The method I use is based on the corners first method listed on Jaap's
site: http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cube4.htm#corner

1. Solve 2 opposite centers (which will be L and R centers in step 3).

2. Solve the corners.

3. Solve all the L edges, Solve all R edges.

4. Solve 3 l edges, then last l edge.

5. Solve the 4 r edges.

6. Separate remaining centers into groups of opposite faces( eg, if
solving the green, blue white and yellow centers, group center
facelets so that blue and green go together, white and yellow go together)

7. Solve centers.

At this point, for step 6, I use 1 alg to move one center cubie from
the U face to the F face to eventually separate the blue/green group
from the white/yellow group. This process can get pretty tedious.

for step 7, I solve opposite centers by swaping cubies as outlined in
Jaaps solution. This involves applying a single alg repeatedly.

In step 6, I used to ensure that as I separated the groups, that each
group ended up in the correct face, so that blue or green cubies get
sent to either the blue or green face. Now, I am incorporating algs
that swap whole center groups (from the pretty patterns section on
Jaap's pages) to the process. That way, if I have 3 blue or green
center cubies in the white face, and one blue cubie in a blue or green
face, I can complete the blue green group with one cubie swap, and
eventually do an appropriate center group swap later, rather than
doing 3 cubie swaps to get those 3 blue greens from the white face to
the blue or green face.

At this point, the whole center cubie separation process is still a
bit tricky, and could be a bit more efficient.

I am wondering if anyone knows of some algs that will swap multiple
center cubies between 2 faces? for example, swap Fur + Fdr with Ubl +
Ufr. In other words, algs that swap more than one but less than four
center cubies between adjacent or opposite faces.

Lucas





1972. RE: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Algs-moving center facelets
From: "Bill MCGAUGH" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 15:19:18 -0700

Hi Lucas, Some things to play with that move groups of centers: l2 u2 l2 u2 and r2 B2 r' (f b') r B2 r' (f' b) r Bill McGaugh >From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Algs-moving center facelets >Date: Sat, 09 Apr 2005 20:47:00 -0000 > > > >Hi there > >I am looking for a few good algs to shuffle center cubies on a 4x4x4 cube. > >The method I use is based on the corners first method listed on Jaap's >site: http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cube4.htm#corner > >1. That way, if I have 3 blue or green >center cubies in the white face, and one blue cubie in a blue or green >face, I can complete the blue green group with one cubie swap, and >eventually do an appropriate center group swap later, rather than >doing 3 cubie swaps to get those 3 blue greens from the white face to > the blue or green face. > >At this point, the whole center cubie separation process is still a >bit tricky, and could be a bit more efficient. > >I am wondering if anyone knows of some algs that will swap multiple >center cubies between 2 faces? for example, swap Fur + Fdr with Ubl + >Ufr. 1975. PLL Vids
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 07:29:48 -0000


I feel that there aren't quite enough videos demonstrating algorithms,
so I posted videos (fast and slow) demonstrating exactly how I perform
all of the 21 permutations on my permutations page
(www.cubewhiz.com/pll.html). I think this should prove helpful to
anybody trying to learn any of the PLL algs.

~Bob

1977. Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 11:55:19 +0200

Not that big, but over 200KB and some mail systems seems to object to that. Sent the mail yesterday afternoon but now I've put it up on http://www.svekub.se/L2L4c.txt instead. Below is the the test from the mail: Hi Duncan, Calculations are finished now and attached are a lot of algorithms. The file also contains a lot of "junk"-algorithms and may well contain a lot of duplicates. There should be at least one optimal (in HTM) algoritm for each case though. The numbering is like this: First number is the step 3 pattern and the second is the step 2 pattern. 2.3 is then UUF and switching the two right corners. They should also hopefully be converted to your solving preferences. (edit: this might not be entirely accurate since I might be confused because we use a different setup. But there should be some system to it :)) Please let me know of any errors or so and keep me updated on your thougts, progress and ideas. /Gustav Duncan Dicks skrev: >Hi Gustav - no I haven't received anything. >Is it really that big! > >Duncan > >----- Original Message ----- >From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...> >To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >Sent: Sunday, April 10, 2005 8:23 AM >Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2 > > > > >>Hi Duncan, >> >>Did you get the results? Just want to make sure the mail didn't get >>caught because of size restriction or something :) >> >>/Gustav >> >>Duncan Dicks skrev: >> >> >> >>>Hi Gustav, >>>That was quick! Fantastic. My estimates have been based on the 30 moves >>>plus first layer plus one edge. >>>Any chance you could send me your results (e-mail on the website)? >>>Any format you like.
