Below is the the test from the mail: > > Hi Duncan, > > Calculations are finished now and attached are a lot of algorithms. The > file also contains a lot of "junk"-algorithms and may well contain a lot > of duplicates. There should be at least one optimal (in HTM) algoritm > for each case though. > > The numbering is like this: First number is the step 3 pattern and the > second is the step 2 pattern. 2.3 is then UUF and switching the two > right corners. They should also hopefully be converted to your solving > preferences. (edit: this might not be entirely accurate since I might be > confused because we use a different setup. But there should be some > system to it :)) > > Please let me know of any errors or so and keep me updated on your > thougts, progress and ideas. > > /Gustav > > Duncan Dicks skrev: > > >Hi Gustav - no I haven't received anything. > >Is it really that big! > > > >Duncan > > > >----- Original Message ----- > >From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...> > >To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > >Sent: Sunday, April 10, 2005 8:23 AM > >Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] L2L Step 2 > > > > > > > > > >>Hi Duncan, > >> > >>Did you get the results? Just want to make sure the mail didn't get > >>caught because of size restriction or something :) > >> > >>/Gustav > >> > >>Duncan Dicks skrev: > >> > >> > >> > >>>Hi Gustav, > >>>That was quick! Fantastic. My estimates have been based on the 30 moves > >>>plus first layer plus one edge. > >>>Any chance you could send me your results (e-mail on the website)? > >>>Any format you like. From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 17:17:57 +0100

I like to finish with white so I start with yellow (so I'm only happy with cubes that have these opposite each other!). 1987. Re: Starting Color
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 17:22:06 -0000

I begin with white. When I first started, it was easiest to recognize because of its brightness. Of course, it is true that the starting color is practically irrelevant once you get used to starting with a specific color. Is there anybody out there that starts with the color that looks like it will be easiest to begin with? ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Just curious, what color do most of you do the cross with, I used > green, from watching solving videos it seems like most people do white.
1988. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 12:40:39 -0500

I start with a white cross in Fridrich, white on bottom with Petrus, white on bottom with red and orange as left and right for Roux and either white or yellow on bottom with corners first, depending on which looks easier. When I solve for few moves with Ryan Heise's method, though, I do try to be completely color neutral and go with what has the most that looks easy at the beginning, though I'm still usually able to see white or yellow on bottom easiest.

-Mike Bennett

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1989. Re: Starting Color
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 17:42:35 -0000

I always start with white, but the color white isn't as important to me, it's more important that I end with yellow. If I cube with a different color scheme (white opposite blue), then I always start with green so that I can still end with yellow. So I guess ending with yellow is more how I view it, rather than starting with white. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Just curious, what color do most of you do the cross with, I used > green, from watching solving videos it seems like most people do white.
1990. Equation!
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 19:18:53 -0000


Hey,

Does anybody have a good response for when they are asked:

"I know there is a mathematical equation that solves the cube. What is
it?"

I get asked this on a regular basis and I haven't been able to come up
with any clever reply for it.

~Bob





1991. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 12:26:42 -0700 (PDT)

I posted earlier that I start with blue. If I see a very obvious/simple cross or xCross for green, I'll solve for green. Since the edge pair colors are somewhat similiar if I hyperfocus I can keep on top of things :P -Richard --- Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > > I begin with white. 1992. Link
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 19:30:00 -0000


Has anybody ever taken a look at this page? I'm not sure if it has
been discussed here or not (though it probably has):

http://www.b-link.co.uk/ckn/inventors/enro_rubik.htm

I find it funny that, other than spelling Mr. Rubik's name incorrectly,
the page says that nobody has ever solved the cube in less than 52
moves! (talk about being out of date!)

~Bob

1995. Re: [Speed cubing group] Equation!
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 15:10:35 -0500

'You + the cube = never.' Alternately, you could mention something about the number of combinations, divided by the number of times people tell you that is something similar to 1. I'm bad at math, but those are a few ideas. 1998. [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 21:49:32 -0000

With fridrich, i start with a white cross, with petrus, i am color neutral, with roux, i start with white or yellow for the 1x2x3 blocks, and for corners first, after i get the corners, i put the yellow and white edges in. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I start with a white cross in Fridrich, white on bottom with Petrus, white on bottom with red and orange as left and right for Roux and either white or yellow on bottom with corners first, depending on which looks easier. When I solve for few moves with Ryan Heise's method, though, I do try to be completely color neutral and go with what has the most that looks easy at the beginning, though I'm still usually able to see white or yellow on bottom easiest. > > -Mike Bennett > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1999. [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 21:55:07 -0000

Well, it all depends on what method you use, for the petrus method, you work in very small intuitive steps through the whole solution, and you adapt on the fly, but with fridrich, i've found that it's a lot harder to be color neutral with the fridrich method and with the roux method...it just doesn't work as well, but i have no problems being color neutral with your method. There aren't any truly hard looks in your method, and with the fridrich method, it makes it a lot easier to identify cases throughout the entire solve, i would imagine especially the OLL section. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > I'm the only one I know of. It's not hard, so I'm pretty astonished so > few are doing it. > > /Lars > > On Apr 10, 2005, at 10:22, Bob Burton wrote: > > > Is there anybody out there that starts with the color > > that looks like it will be easiest to begin with? > > > > ~Bob > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." > --- Frank Zappa > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com
2000. Re: Equation!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 21:57:45 -0000

Off the top of my head, you might claim that "it has been shown that a proof of the Reimann-Zeta Hypothesis [or some equally difficult math problem] would necessarily have 'God's Algorithm' as a consequence..." That would shush all bu the most persistant. You could also do a preemtive strike: "I dunno, I just got tired of pealing the stickers off..." Which steals there inevitable next line :). -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Hey, > > Does anybody have a good response for when they are asked: > > "I know there is a mathematical equation that solves the cube. What is > it?" > > I get asked this on a regular basis and I haven't been able to come up > with any clever reply for it. > > ~Bob
